translated: “I will do business after I have made a raft.” He made a raft and said to his mother, “Mother, I will do business by boat.” His mother said to him, “My dear, you are my only son. translated: After he had learned all the arts, he returned home. His father then gave him a suitable wife.

original: saṃyojesi. So aparabhāge mātāpitūnaṃ accayena sabbissariyaṃ paṭipajji. Athekadivasaṃ🔽ratanakoṭṭhāgārāni viloketvā varapallaṅkamajjhagato suvaṇṇapaṭṭaṃ āharāpetvā “ettakaṃ
analyzed: saṃyojesi saḥ aparabhāge mātā pitūnam accayena sa bissariyam paṭipajji atha eka divasam  ratana koṭṭhāgārāni viloketvā vara pallaṅka majjhagataḥ suvaṇṇa paṭṭam āharāpetvā ettakam
translated: and he was brought up. Later, when his parents died, he succeeded to the throne. One day,🔽after looking over the treasure-houses, he sat down on a splendid couch and had a golden tablet brought to him. On it were written the words, “This much wealth was produced by so-and-so,

original: dhanaṃ asukena uppāditaṃ, ettakaṃ asukenā”ti pubbañātīhi suvaṇṇapaṭṭe likhitāni akkharāni
analyzed: dhanam asukena uppāditam ettakam asukena ati pubba ñātīhi suvaṇṇa paṭṭe likhitāni akkharāni
translated: this much by so-and-so,” written by the former treasurers.

original: disvā cintesi “yehi imaṃ dhanaṃ uppāditaṃ, te na paññāyanti, dhanameva paññāyati,
analyzed: disvā cintesi yehi imam dhanam uppāditam te na paññāyanti dhanam eva paññāyati
translated: Seeing this, he thought, “I do not know who produced this wealth. Only the wealth is known.

original: ekopi idaṃ dhanaṃ gahetvā gato nāma natthi, na kho pana sakkā dhanabhaṇḍikaṃ bandhitvā
analyzed: ekaḥ api idam dhanam gahetvā gataḥ nāma natthi na kho pana sakkā dhanabhaṇḍikam bandhitvā
translated: There is no one who has taken this wealth and gone to the other world. But it is not possible to bind up a bundle of wealth

original: paralokaṃ gantuṃ. Pañcannaṃ verānaṃ sādhāraṇabhāvena hi asārassa dhanassa dānaṃ sāro,
analyzed: para lokam gantum sādhāraṇa bhāvena hi asārassa dhanassa dānam sāraḥ
translated: and go to the other world. The essence of wealth is to give it away, for it is insubstantial, being shared by the five enemies .

original: bahurogasādhāraṇabhāvena asārassa sarīrassa sīlavantesu abhivādanādikammaṃ sāro,
analyzed: bahu roga sādhāraṇa bhāvena asārassa sarīrassa sīlavantesu abhivādana ādi kammam sāraḥ
translated: The essence of the body is to pay homage to virtuous people, for it is insubstantial, being shared by many diseases.

original: aniccābhibhūtabhāvena asārassa jīvitassa aniccādivasena vipassanāyogo sāro, tasmā
analyzed: anicca abhibhūta bhāvena asārassa jīvitassa anicca ādi vasena vipassanā yogo sāraḥ tasmā
translated: The essence of life is the practice of insight meditation, considering impermanence, etc., for it is insubstantial, being overcome by death. Therefore,

original: asārehi bhogehi sāraggahaṇatthaṃ dānaṃ dassāmī”ti.
analyzed: asārehi bhogehi sāra ggahaṇa attham dānam dassāmi iti
translated: “I will give gifts for the sake of acquiring the essence with my inessential wealth.”

original: So āsanā vuṭṭhāya rañño santikaṃ gantvā rājānaṃ āpucchitvā mahādānaṃ pavattesi. Yāva
analyzed: saḥ āsanā vuṭṭhāya rañño santikam gantvā rājānam āpucchitvā mahādānam pavattesi yāva
translated: He rose from his seat, went to the king, and after paying homage to the king, he gave a great gift. For seven days he saw his wealth

original: sattamā divasā dhanaṃ aparikkhīyamānaṃ disvā “kiṃ me dhanena, yāva maṃ jarā nābhibhavati,
analyzed: sattamāḥ divasāḥ dhanam a parikkhīyamānam disvā kim me dhanena yāva mama jarā na abhibhavati
translated: undiminished. “What is wealth to me? As long as old age does not overcome me,

original: tāvadeva pabbajitvā abhiññā ca samāpattiyo ca nibbattetvā brahmalokaparāyaṇo bhavissāmī”ti
analyzed: tāvat eva pabbajitvā abhiññā ca samāpattiyaḥ ca nibbattetvā brahma loka parāyaṇaḥ bhavissāmi iti
translated: I will go forth and, after developing the supernormal powers and deep meditations, I will go to the Brahma-world.”

original: cintetvā gehe sabbadvārāni vivarāpetvā “dinnaṃ me, harantū”ti asuciṃ viya jigucchanto
analyzed: cintetvā gehe sabba dvārāni vivarāpetvā dinnam me harantu iti asucim viya jigucchantaḥ
translated: After thinking thus, he had all the doors of his house opened and said, “Take what is given by me,” as if he were disgusted with impurity.

original: vatthukāme pahāya mahājanassa rodantassa paridevantassa nagarā nikkhamitvā himavantapadesaṃ
analyzed: vatthu kāme pahāya mahājanassa rodantassa paridevantassa nagarā nikkhamitvā himavanta padesam
translated: After abandoning sensual pleasures, he went out of the city, while the people cried and lamented, and entered the Himalayas.

original: pavisitvā isipabbajjaṃ pabbajitvā attano vasanatthāya ramaṇīyaṃ bhūmibhāgaṃ olokento
analyzed: pavisitvā isipabbajjam pabbajitvā attanaḥ vasana atthāya ramaṇīyam bhūmi bhāgam olokento
translated: After going forth as an ascetic, he looked for a pleasant place to live in.

original: imaṃ ṭhānaṃ patvā “idha vasissāmī”ti ekaṃ indavāruṇīrukkhaṃ gocaragāmaṃ adhiṭṭhāya
analyzed: imam ṭhānam patvā idha vasissāmi iti ekam indavāruṇī rukkham gocara gāmam adhiṭṭhāya
translated: After reaching this place, he thought, “I will live here.” He designated a tree, the Indavāruṇī tree, as his alms-resort village.

original: tasseva rukkhassa mūle vihāsi. Gāmantasenāsanaṃ pahāya āraññiko ahosi, paṇṇasālaṃ🔽akatvā rukkhamūliko ahosi, abbhokāsiko nesajjiko. Sace nipajjitukāmo, bhūmiyaṃyeva
analyzed: tassa iva rukkhassa mūle vihāsi gāmanta senāsanam pahāya āraññikaḥ ahosi paṇṇasālam  a katvā rukkhamūlikaḥ ahosi abbhokāsikaḥ nesajjikaḥ sace nipajjitu kāmaḥ bhūmiyaṃyeva
translated: and he lived at the foot of that very tree. He gave up the village dwelling and became a forest-dweller,🔽he gave up the leaf hut and became a tree-root-dweller, a sky-dweller, a non-pillow-user. If he wanted to lie down, he would lie down

original: nipajjati, dantamūsaliko hutvā anaggipakkameva khādati, thusaparikkhittaṃ kiñci na
analyzed: nipajjati dantamūsalikaḥ hutvā an aggi pakkam eva khādati thusa parikkhittam kiñci na
translated: on the ground. He became a tooth-stick-user, a non-fire-kindler, he did not eat anything

original: khādati, ekadivasaṃ ekavārameva khādati, ekāsaniko ahosi. Khamāya pathavīāpatejavāyusamo🔽hutvā ete ettake dhutaṅgaguṇe samādāya vattati, imasmiṃ kira jātake bodhisatto paramappiccho
analyzed: khādati eka divasam eka vāram eva khādati eka āsanikaḥ ahosi khamāya pathavīāpa teja vāyu samaḥ  hutvā ete ettake dhutaṅga guṇe samādāya vattati imasmin kira jātake bodhisatto parama ppicchaḥ
translated: surrounded by chaff, he ate once a day, he became a one-seat-user. He became equal to the earth, water, fire, and air elements,

original: ahosi. So na cirasseva abhiññā ca samāpattiyo ca nibbattetvā jhānakīḷaṃ kīḷanto tattheva
analyzed: ahosi so na cirassa iva abhiññā ca samāpattiyaḥ ca nibbattetvā jhāna kīḷam kīḷantaḥ tattha eva
translated: and he lived with these qualities of ascetic practice. In this Jātaka it seems the Bodhisatta was extremely greedy. He soon developed the higher knowledges and attainments, and living there he played with the jhānas,

original: vasati, phalāphalatthampi aññattha na gacchati, rukkhassa phalitakāle phalaṃ khādati,
analyzed: vasati phala a phalattham pi aññattha na gacchati rukkhassa phalita kāle phalam khādati
translated: he did not go anywhere else for fruit and so on, when the tree had fruit he ate the fruit,

original: pupphitakāle pupphaṃ khādati, sapattakāle pattāni khādati, nippattakāle papaṭikaṃ
analyzed: pupphita kāle puppham khādati sa patta kāle pattāni khādati nippatta kāle papaṭikam
translated: when it had flowers he ate the flowers, when it had leaves he ate the leaves, when it had no leaves he ate the bark,

original: khādati. Evaṃ paramasantuṭṭho hutvā imasmiṃ ṭhāne ciraṃ vasati.
analyzed: khādati evam parama santuṭṭhaḥ hutvā imasmin ṭhāne ciram vasati
translated: and so he lived there for a long time, satisfied with what he got.

original: So ekadivasaṃ pubbaṇhasamaye tassa rukkhassa pakkāni phalāni gaṇhi, gaṇhanto pana
analyzed: so eka divasam pubbaṇha samaye tassa rukkhassa pakkāni phalāni gaṇhi gaṇhantaḥ pana
translated: One day, in the morning, he took the ripe fruit of that tree. But while he was taking it,

original: loluppacārena uṭṭhāya aññasmiṃ padese na gaṇhāti, yathānisinnova hatthaṃ pasāretvā
analyzed: loluppa cārena uṭṭhāya aññasmin padese na gaṇhāti yathā nisinnaḥ uva hattham pasāretvā
translated: he did not get up with greed and take it from another place. He just stretched out his hand where he was sitting

original: hatthappasāraṇaṭṭhāne ṭhitāni phalāni saṃharati, tesupi manāpāmanāpaṃ avicinitvā
analyzed: hattha ppasāraṇa ṭhāne ṭhitāni phalāni saṃharati tesu pi manāpa amanāpam a vicinitvā
translated: and took the fruit that was within reach. He did not examine whether they were good or bad,

original: sampattasampattameva gaṇhāti. Evaṃ paramasantuṭṭhassa tassa sīlatejena sakkassa paṇḍukambalasilāsanaṃ
analyzed: sampatta sampattam eva gaṇhāti evam parama santuṭṭhassa tassa sīla tejena sakkassa paṇḍu kambala silā āsanam
translated: but took whatever he got. Thus, by the power of his virtue, the seat of Sakka, the white-lotus seat,

original: uṇhākāraṃ dassesi. Taṃ kira sakkassa āyukkhayena vā uṇhaṃ hoti puññakkhayena vā,🔽aññasmiṃ vā mahānubhāvasatte taṃ ṭhānaṃ patthente, dhammikānaṃ vā mahiddhikasamaṇabrāhmaṇānaṃ
analyzed: uṇhākāram dassesi tam kira sakkassa āyu kkhayena vā uṇham hoti puñña kkhayena vā  aññasmin vā mahā anubhāva satte tam ṭhānam patthente dhammikānam vā mahiddhika samaṇa brāhmaṇānam
translated: showed signs of heat. It is said that it becomes hot either through the exhaustion of Sakka’s life-span or through the exhaustion of his merit,

original: sīlatejena uṇhaṃ hoti. Sakko “ko nu kho maṃ ṭhānā cāvetukāmo”ti āvajjetvā imasmiṃ
analyzed: sīla tejena uṇham hoti sakko kaḥ nu kho mama ṭhānā cāvetu kāmaḥ ti āvajjetvā imasmin
translated: or when another being of great power aspires to that place, or through the power of the virtue of righteous ascetics and brahmins of great spiritual power. Sakka thought, “Who is it that wants to displace me?” and, understanding,

original: padese vasantaṃ kaṇhaṃ isiṃ rukkhaphalāni uccinantaṃ disvā cintesi “ayaṃ isi ghoratapo
analyzed: padese vasantam kaṇham isim rukkha phalāni uccinantam disvā cintesi ayam isi ghora tapo
translated: Seeing the ascetic Kaṇha living in that place, gathering fruits from trees, he thought: “This ascetic is of terrible austerities,

original: paramajitindriyo, imaṃ dhammakathāya sīhanādaṃ nadāpetvā sukāraṇaṃ sutvā varena santappetvā
analyzed: paramajitindriyaḥ imam dhamma kathāya sīha nādam nadāpetvā su kāraṇam sutvā varena santappetvā
translated: of the highest self-control. I will make him roar the lion’s roar of the Dhamma, and having heard the good reason, I will please my wife,

original: imamassa rukkhaṃ dhuvaphalaṃ katvā āgamissāmī”ti. So mahantenānubhāvena sīghaṃ otaritvā🔽tasmiṃ rukkhamūle tassa piṭṭhipasse ṭhatvā “attano avaṇṇe kathite kujjhissati nu
analyzed: imam assa rukkham dhuva phalam katvā āgamissāmi iti saḥ mahantena anubhāvena sīgham otaritvā  tasmim rukkha mūle tassa piṭṭhi passe ṭhatvā attanaḥ avaṇṇe kathite kujjhissati nu
translated: and having made his tree a tree of perpetual fruit, I will return.” With great majesty he quickly descended🔽and stood at the foot of that tree, behind him, thinking: “If I speak his dispraise, will he be angry or not?”

original: kho, no”ti vīmaṃsanto paṭhamaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: kho no ti vīmaṃsantaḥ paṭhamam gātham āha
translated: and thus testing him, he spoke the first stanza:

original: “Kaṇho vatāyaṃ puriso, kaṇhaṃ bhuñjati bhojanaṃ;
analyzed: kaṇhaḥ vata ayam purisaḥ kaṇham bhuñjati bhojanam
translated: “Black is this man, and black the food he eats,

original: Kaṇhe bhūmipadesasmiṃ, na mayhaṃ manaso piyo”ti.
analyzed: kaṇhe bhūmi padesasmin na mayham manasaḥ
translated: In a black place he lives: he is not dear to my heart.”

original: Tattha kaṇhoti kāḷavaṇṇo. Bhojananti rukkhaphalabhojanaṃ.
analyzed: tattha kaṇho ti kāḷa vaṇṇo bhojanam ti rukkha phala bhojanam
translated: Herein, black is the colour black. Food: the food of tree-fruits.

original: Kaṇho isi sakkassa vacanaṃ sutvā “ko nu kho mayā saddhiṃ kathetī”ti dibbacakkhunā upadhārento “sakko”ti ñatvā anivattitvā anoloketvāva dutiyaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: kaṇhaḥ isi sakkassa vacanam sutvā kaḥ nu kho mayā saddhim katheti iti dibba cakkhunā upadhārento sakko ti ñatvā a nivattitvā dutiyam gātham āha
translated: The sage Kanha, having heard Sakka’s words, thought with his divine eye: “Who is it that talks with me?” and knowing it was Sakka, he spoke a second verse without turning back or looking:

original: “Na kaṇho tacasā hoti, antosāro hi brāhmaṇo;
analyzed: na kaṇhaḥ tacasā hoti antosāraḥ hi brāhmaṇaḥ
translated: “Not by the bark is one a Kanha, for the inner core is the brahmin;

original: Yasmiṃ pāpāni kammāni, sa ve kaṇho sujampatī”ti.
analyzed: yasmin pāpāni kammāni sa ve kaṇhaḥ su jampati iti
translated: In whom are evil deeds, he is the Kanha, the husband of Suja.”

original: Tattha tacasāti tacena kaṇho nāma na hotīti attho. Antosāroti abbhantare sīlasamādhipaññāvimuttivimuttiñāṇadassanasārehi🔽samannāgato. Evarūpo hi bāhitapāpattā brāhmaṇo nāma hoti. Sa veti yasmiṃ pana pāpāni
analyzed: tattha tacasā āti tacena kaṇhaḥ nāma na hoti iti attho antosāro ti abbhantare sīla samādhi paññā vimutti vimutti ñāṇa dassana sārehi  samannāgataḥ evarūpaḥ hi brāhmaṇaḥ nāma hoti sa veti yasmin pana pāpāni
translated: Herein, tacas means: by the bark one is not called a Kanha. Antosāro means: endowed with the inner core of virtue, concentration, wisdom, freedom, and the knowledge and vision of freedom.

original: kammāni atthi, so yattha katthaci kule jātopi yena kenaci sarīravaṇṇena samannāgatopi kāḷakova.
analyzed: atthi saḥ yattha katthaci kule jātaḥ api yena kenaci sarīra vaṇṇena samannāgataḥ api kāḷakaḥ uva
translated: For such a one, having expelled evil, is called a brahmin. Sa ve means: but in whom are evil deeds, he is a Kanha, wherever he is born in any family, and whatever his bodily complexion.

original: Evañca pana vatvā imesaṃ sattānaṃ kaṇhabhāvakarāni pāpakammāni ekavidhādibhedehi
analyzed: evam ca pana vatvā imesam sattānam kaṇha bhāva karāni pāpa kammāni ekavidha ādi bhedehi
translated: Having said this, the evil deeds that cause beings to become Kanhas, by means of the classification of the one-factored, etc.,

original: vitthāretvā sabbānipi tāni garahitvā sīlādayo guṇe pasaṃsitvā ākāse candaṃ uṭṭhāpento
analyzed: vitthāretvā sabbāni api tāni garahitvā sīla ādayaḥ guṇe pasaṃsitvā ākāse candam uṭṭhāpento
translated: and after rebuking all of them in detail, and praising the virtues of morality, etc., he preached the Dhamma to Sakka as if he were raising the moon in the sky.

original: viya sakkassa dhammaṃ desesi. Sakko tassa dhammakathaṃ sutvā pamudito somanassajāto
analyzed: viya sakkassa dhammaṃ desesi sakkaḥ tassa dhamma katham sutvā pamuditaḥ somanassa jātaḥ
translated: When Sakka had heard the Dhamma, he was delighted and glad.

original: mahāsattaṃ varena nimantento tatiyaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: mahāsattam varena nimantentaḥ tatiyam gātham āha
translated: Inviting the Great Being to accept a boon, he spoke the third stanza:

original: “Etasmiṃ te sulapite, patirūpe subhāsite;
analyzed: etasmin te su lapite pati rūpe su bhāsite
translated: “In this well-spoken, fitting speech,

original: Varaṃ brāhmaṇa te dammi, yaṃ kiñci manasicchasī”ti.
analyzed: varam brāhmaṇa te dammi yam kiñci manasi icchasi iti
translated: I grant you a boon, O brahman, whatever you desire.”

original: Tattha etasminti yaṃ idaṃ tayā sabbaññubuddhena viya sulapitaṃ, tasmiṃ sulapite tumhākameva
analyzed: tattha etasmin ti yam idam tayā sabbaññu buddhena viya su lapitam tasmin su lapite tumhākam eva
translated: Herein, in this means in this well-spoken speech of yours, which is well-spoken as if by a Buddha omniscient, in this well-spoken speech, which is fitting for you alone

original: anucchavikattā patirūpe subhāsite yaṃ kiñci manasā icchasi, sabbaṃ te yaṃ varaṃ icchitaṃ
analyzed: pati rūpe su bhāsite yam kiñci manasā icchasi sabbam te yam varam icchitam
translated: because it is in accordance with your status, whatever you desire in your mind, whatever boon you wish for,

original: patthitaṃ, taṃ dammīti attho.
analyzed: patthitam tam dammi iti
translated: whatever you long for, I grant it to you—this is the meaning.

original: Taṃ sutvā mahāsatto cintesi “ayaṃ kiṃ nu kho attano avaṇṇe kathite kujjhissati, noti
analyzed: tam sutvā mahāsatto cintesi ayam kim nu kho attanaḥ avaṇṇe kathite kujjhissati no ti
translated: When he heard this, the Great Being thought, “Now, will he be angry when I speak his dispraise?”

original: maṃ vīmaṃsanto mayhaṃ chavivaṇṇañca bhojanañca vasanaṭṭhānañca garahitvā idāni mayhaṃ
analyzed: mam vīmaṃsantaḥ mayham chavi vaṇṇañca bhojanañca vasana ṭṭhānañca garahitvā idāni mayham
translated: Testing me, after rebuking my appearance, my food, and my dwelling, he now

original: akuddhabhāvaṃ ñatvā pasannacitto varaṃ deti, maṃ kho panesa ‘sakkissariyabrhmissariyānaṃ🔽atthāya brahmacariyaṃ caratī’tipi maññeyya, tatrassa nikkaṅkhabhāvatthaṃ mayhaṃ paresu🔽kodho vā doso vā mā uppajjatu, parasampattiyaṃ lobho vā paresu sineho vā mā uppajjatu,
analyzed: a kuddha bhāvam ñatvā pasanna cittaḥ varam deti mam kho pana isa sakkissariya brhmissariyānam  atthāya brahmacariyam carati iti pi maññeyya tatrassa nikkaṅkha bhāva ttham mayham paresu  kodhaḥ vā dosaḥ vā mā uppajjatu para sampattiyam lobho vā paresu sinehaḥ vā mā uppajjatu
translated: Knowing that he was not angry, the king, with a mind of faith, gave him a boon. But he might think that I was leading the holy life for the sake of Sakka or Brahma. So, in order to remove his doubts, I should take four boons from him, thinking: ‘Let no anger or hatred arise in me towards others, let no greed or affection arise in me towards others,

original: majjhattova bhaveyyanti ime mayā cattāro vare gahetuṃ vaṭṭatī”ti. So tassa nikkaṅkhabhāvatthāya
analyzed: majjhattaḥ uva bhaveyyanti ime mayā cattāraḥ vare gahetum vaṭṭati iti so tassa nikkaṅkha bhāva tthāya
translated: but let me be impartial.’ ” So, in order to remove his doubts,

original: cattāro vare gaṇhanto catutthaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: cattāraḥ vare gaṇhantaḥ catuttham gātham āha
translated: taking four boons, he spoke the fourth stanza:

original: “Varañce me ado sakka, sabbabhūtānamissara;
analyzed: varañce me ado sakka
translated: “If you will grant me a boon, O Sakka, lord of all beings,

original: Sunikkodhaṃ suniddosaṃ, nillobhaṃ vuttimattano;
analyzed: su nikkodham su niddosam nillobham
translated: I would have no anger, no hatred, no greed, and a livelihood of my own;

original: Nisnehamabhikaṅkhāmi, ete me caturo vare”ti.
analyzed: nisneham abhikaṅkhāmi ete me caturaḥ vara iti
translated: I would have no affection, and this is the boon I would have.”

original: Tattha varañce me ado sakkāti sace tvaṃ mayhaṃ varaṃ adāsi. Sunikkodhanti akujjhanavasena
analyzed: tattha varañce me sakkā ati sace tvam mayham varam adāsi akujjhana vasena
translated: Herein, if you will grant me a boon means if you will give me a boon. No anger means no annoyance.

original: suṭṭhu nikkodhaṃ. Suniddosanti adussanavasena suṭṭhu niddosaṃ. Nillobhanti parasampattīsu🔽nillobhaṃ. Vuttimattanoti evarūpaṃ attano vuttiṃ. Nisnehanti puttadhītādīsu vā saviññāṇakesu🔽dhanadhaññādīsu vā aviññāṇakesu attano santakesupi nisnehaṃ apagatalobhaṃ. original: ativiya anavajje vare gaṇhi, etesu varesu guṇadosaṃ etameva pucchissāmī”ti. Atha
analyzed: anavajje vare gaṇhi etesu varesu guṇa dosam etam eva pucchissāmi iti atha
translated: and he thought to himself, “I will ask him about the good and bad qualities of these very things.” So he asked him,

original: naṃ pucchanto pañcamaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: pucchantaḥ pañcamam gātham āha
translated: and in the fifth stanza he said:

original: “Kiṃnu kodhe vā dose vā, lobhe snehe ca brāhmaṇa;
analyzed: kiṃnu kodhe vā dose vā lobhe snehe ca brāhmaṇa
translated: “What danger do you see, O Brahman, in anger, in hatred, in greed, and in love?

original: Ādīnavaṃ tvaṃ passasi, taṃ me akkhāhi pucchito”ti.
analyzed: ādīnavam tvam passasi tam me akkhāhi pucchito ti
translated: Tell me this, when I ask you.”

original: Tassattho – brāhmaṇa kiṃ nu kho tvaṃ kodhe dose lobhe snehe ca ādīnavaṃ passasi, taṃ tāva me pucchito akkhāhi, na hi mayaṃ ettha ādīnavaṃ jānāmāti.
analyzed: tassa atthaḥ brāhmaṇa kim nu kho tvam kodhe dose lobhe snehe ca ādīnavam passasi tam tāva me pucchitaḥ akkhāhi na hi mayam ettha ādīnavam jānāma ati
translated: The meaning is this: O Brahman, what danger do you see in anger, in hatred, in greed, and in love? Tell me this, when I ask you. For we do not know what danger there is in these things.

original: Atha naṃ mahāsatto “tena hi suṇāhī”ti vatvā catasso gāthā abhāsi –
analyzed: atha nam mahāsatto tena hi suṇāhi iti vatvā catassaḥ gāthāḥ abhāsi
translated: Then the Great Being said, “Listen, then,” and he spoke four stanzas:

original: “Appo hutvā bahu hoti, vaḍḍhate so akhantijo;
analyzed: appaḥ hutvā bahu hoti vaḍḍhate saḥ a khanti jaḥ
translated: “A little thing grows into a great thing, and it is born of anger;

original: Āsaṅgī bahupāyāso, tasmā kodhaṃ na rocaye.
analyzed: āsaṅgī bahu pāyāsaḥ tasmai kodham na rocaye
translated: It is full of hope and full of fear: therefore I do not approve of anger.

original: “Duṭṭhassa pharusā vācā, parāmāso anantarā;
analyzed: duṭṭhassa pharusā vācā parāmāsaḥ anantarā
translated: “The angry man speaks harsh words, and he is full of hate;

original: Tato pāṇi tato daṇḍo, satthassa paramā gati;
analyzed: tato pāṇi tato daṇḍaḥ satthassa paramā gati
translated: Then he takes a stick and strikes, and the sword is the last resort;

original: Doso kodhasamuṭṭhāno, tasmā dosaṃ na rocaye.
analyzed: doso kodha samuṭṭhāno tasmai dosam na rocaye
translated: Hatred is born of anger: therefore I do not approve of hatred.

original: “Ālopasāhasākārā, nikatī vañcanāni ca;
analyzed: ālopa sāhasa ākārāḥ nikatī vañcanāni ca
translated: “The angry man is full of deceit, and he is full of guile;

original: Dissanti lobhadhammesu, tasmā lobhaṃ na rocaye.
analyzed: dissanti lobha dhammesu tasmai lobham na rocaye
translated: They are seen in things that are greedy, So do not delight in greed.

original: “Snehasaṅgathitā ganthā, senti manomayā puthū;
analyzed: sneha saṅgathitā ganthā senti manaḥ mayā puthū
translated: The bonds are bound by affection, They go about in many ways,

original: Te bhusaṃ upatāpenti, tasmā snehaṃ na rocaye”ti.
analyzed: te bhusam upatāpenti tasmai sneham na rocaya iti
translated: They torment one very much, So do not delight in affection.

original: Tattha akhantijoti so anadhivāsakajātikassa akhantito jāto kodho paṭhamaṃ paritto
analyzed: tattha akhanti jaḥ ti so anadhivāsaka jātikassa akhantitaḥ jātaḥ kodhaḥ paṭhamam parittaḥ
translated: Herein, anger born of intolerance is anger born of the intolerance of one who will not endure and tolerate. It is small at first,

original: hutvā pacchā bahu hoti aparāparaṃ vaḍḍhati. Tassa vaḍḍhanabhāvo khantivādījātakena🔽ceva cūḷadhammapālajātakena ca vaṇṇetabbo. Apica tissāmaccassapettha bhariyaṃ ādiṃ
analyzed: hutvā pacchā bahu hoti apara aparam vaḍḍhati tassa vaḍḍhana bhāvaḥ khantivādī jātakena  ca iva cūḷa dhammapāla jātakena ca vaṇṇetabbaḥ apica bhariyam ādim
translated: but later on it becomes great and grows to more and more, like the flame of a grass-fire. Its growth should be told in the way begun thus, “When he has no tolerance”

original: katvā sabbaṃ saparijanaṃ māretvā pacchā attano māritavatthu kathetabbaṃ. Āsaṅgīti
analyzed: katvā sabbam sa parijanam māretvā pacchā attanaḥ mārita vatthu kathetabbam āsaṅgi iti
translated: and in the way begun thus, “When he has no tolerance” . Furthermore, after killing his wife and all his retinue beginning with his daughter, Tissa the brahman should tell the story of his own deed.

original: āsaṅgakaraṇo. Yassa uppajjati, taṃ āsattaṃ laggitaṃ karoti, taṃ vatthuṃ vissajjetvā
analyzed: āsaṅga karaṇaḥ yassa uppajjati tam āsattam laggitam karoti tam vatthum vissajjetvā
translated: The one who clings is the one who makes clinging. He arises and makes clinging and attachment to that thing; he does not let go of that thing, he turns back and reviles and so on.

original: gantuṃ na deti, nivattitvā akkosanādīni kāreti. Bahupāyāsoti bahunā kāyikacetasikadukkhasaṅkhātena
analyzed: gantum na deti nivattitvā akkosana ādīni kāreti bahu pāyāsaḥ ti bahunā kāyika cetasika dukkha saṅkhātena
translated: He is much beset by suffering, by grief, by sorrow, by lamentation, by despair, by tribulation, by fever, by the dart of grief, by mental disturbance, by bodily disquiet, by the dart of bodily feeling, by the dart of mental feeling, by the dart of bodily-cum-mental feeling.

original: upāyāsena kilamathena samannāgato. Kodhaṃ nissāya hi kodhavasena ariyādīsu katavītikkamā🔽diṭṭhadhamme ceva samparāye ca vadhabandhavippaṭisārādīni ceva pañcavidhabandhanakammakaraṇādīni
analyzed: upāyāsena kilamathena samannāgato kodham nissāya hi kodha vasena ariya ādīsu kata vītikkamā  diṭṭhadhamme ca iva samparāye ca vadha bandha vippaṭisāra ādīni ca iva pañcavidha bandhana kamma karaṇa ādīni
translated: and he is full of distress and weariness. For by depending on anger and by being under the sway of anger, he commits offences against Noble Ones,🔽and he experiences the five kinds of suffering beginning with killing, imprisoning, and accusing, and the many kinds of suffering beginning with the five kinds of bondage, the work of executioners, and so on, both in this world and in the next. That is why anger is called “full of distress.”

original: ca bahūni dukkhāni anubhavantīti kodho bahupāyāso nāma. Tasmāti yasmā esa evaṃ anekādīnavo,
analyzed: ca bahūni dukkhāni anubhavanti iti kodhaḥ bahu pāyāsaḥ nāma tasmā ati yasmai esaḥ evam aneka ādīnavaḥ
translated: Therefore, because it has these many dangers,

original: tasmā kodhaṃ na rocemi.
analyzed: tasmai kodham na rocemi
translated: I do not approve of anger.

original: Duṭṭhassāti kujjhanalakkhaṇena kodhena kujjhitvā aparabhāge dussanalakkhaṇena dosena
analyzed: duṭṭhassa ati kujjhana lakkhaṇena kodhena kujjhitvā aparabhāge dussana lakkhaṇena dosena
translated: Of the angry man: having first been angry through anger, which has the characteristic of annoyance,

original: duṭṭhassa paṭhamaṃ tāva “are, dāsa, pessā”ti pharusavācā niccharati, vācāya anantarā🔽ākaḍḍhanavikaḍḍhanavasena hatthaparāmāso, tato anantarā upakkamanavasena pāṇi pavattati,
analyzed: duṭṭhassa paṭhamam tāva are dāsa pessā ati pharusa vācā niccharati vācāya anantarā  ākaḍḍhana vikaḍḍhana vasena hattha parāmāsaḥ tatas anantarā upakkamana vasena pāṇi pavattati
translated: he becomes hostile through hate, which has the characteristic of hating. First of all, harsh speech comes forth, saying “Hey, you slave, you servant,”🔽and after that, the hand moves to strike through the characteristic of dragging and pulling.🔽After that, the stick comes into play through the characteristic of advancing.

original: tato daṇḍo, daṇḍappahāre atikkamitvā pana ekatodhāraubhatodhārassa satthassa paramā
analyzed: tatas daṇḍaḥ daṇḍa ppahāre atikkamitvā pana ekatodhāra aubhatodhārassa satthassa paramā
translated: After the blows of the stick, the supreme penalty of the death sentence, either by the sword or by the gallows, comes into play.

original: gati, sabbapariyantā satthanipphatti hoti. Yadā hi satthena paraṃ jīvitā voropetvā
analyzed: gati sabba pariyantā sattha nipphatti hoti yadā hi satthena param jīvitā voropetvā
translated: the whole extent of the weapon’s flight is the extent of the weapon’s effect. For when someone has deprived another of life with a weapon,

original: pacchā teneva satthena attānaṃ jīvitā voropeti, tadā doso matthakappatto hoti. Doso🔽kodhasamuṭṭhānoti yathā anambilaṃ takkaṃ vā kañjikaṃ vā pariṇāmavasena parivattitvā
analyzed: pacchā tena iva satthena attānam jīvitā voropeti tadā dosaḥ matthaka ppattaḥ hoti doso  kodha samuṭṭhānaḥ ti yathā anambilam takkam vā kañjikam vā pariṇāma vasena
translated: The weapon’s full range is the extent of its effect. For when someone kills another with a weapon and then kills himself with that same weapon, then the hate has reached its climax.

original: ambilaṃ hoti, taṃ ekajātikampi samānaṃ ambilaṃ anambilanti nānā vuccati, tathā pubbakāle🔽kodho pariṇamitvā aparabhāge doso hoti. So akusalamūlattena ekajātikopi samāno kodho
analyzed: ambilam hoti tam eka jātikam pi samānam ambilam an ambilam ti nānā vuccati tathā pubba kāle  kodhaḥ pariṇamitvā aparabhāge dosaḥ hoti saḥ akusala mūla ttena eka jātikaḥ api samānaḥ kodhaḥ
translated: Hate is rooted in anger: just as sour gruel or sour curd is called “sour” even though it is of one kind, because of the difference of its taste due to the change it has undergone, so too, hate is called “rooted in anger” because it is anger that has changed and occurred in a later stage.🔽And although it is of one kind as a root of the unprofitable, still it is called “hate” and “rooted in anger” in order to show that it is a different state.

original: dosoti nānā vuccati. Yathā anambilato ambilaṃ, evaṃ sopi kodhato samuṭṭhātīti kodhasamuṭṭhāno.
analyzed: dosaḥ ti nānā vuccati yathā an ambilataḥ ambilam evam saḥ api kodhato samuṭṭhāti iti kodha samuṭṭhānaḥ
translated: Just as “sour” is different from “sour gruel” and “sour curd,” so too this is different from anger.

original: Tasmāti yasmā evaṃ anekādīnavo doso, tasmā dosampi na rocemi.
analyzed: tasmā ati yasmai evam aneka ādīnavaḥ doso tasmai dosam pi na rocemi
translated: Therefore: since hate has such a variety of dangers, I do not relish hate.

original: Ālopasāhasākārāti divā divasseva gāmaṃ paharitvā vilumpanāni ca āvudhaṃ sarīre ṭhapetvā
analyzed: divā divassa iva gāmam paharitvā vilumpanāni ca āvudham sarīre ṭhapetvā
translated: The form of violence that is rashness: the kind of violence that is rashness is the kind that is done by day and by night in the village and the forest by those who plunder and rob.

original: “idaṃ nāma me dehī”ti sāhasākārā ca. Nikatī vañcanāni cāti patirūpakaṃ dassetvā parassa🔽haraṇaṃ nikati nāma, sā asuvaṇṇameva “suvaṇṇa”nti kūṭakahāpaṇaṃ “kahāpaṇo”ti datvā
analyzed: idam nāma me dehi iti sāhasa ākārā ca nikatī vañcanāni ca ati patirūpakam dassetvā parassa  haraṇam nikati nāma sā a suvaṇṇam eva suvaṇṇam ti kūṭa kahāpaṇam da tvā
translated: And “by force” is by the form of violence such as “Give me this.” “By fraud” is by deception.

original: parasantakaggahaṇe daṭṭhabbā. Paṭibhānavasena pana upāyakusalatāya parasantakaggahaṇaṃ🔽vañcanaṃ nāma. Tassevaṃ pavatti daṭṭhabbā – eko kira ujujātiko gāmikapuriso araññato🔽sasakaṃ ānetvā nadītīre ṭhapetvā nhāyituṃ otari. Atheko dhutto taṃ sasakaṃ sīse katvā
analyzed: para santaka ggahaṇe daṭṭhabbā paṭibhāna vasena pana upāya kusala tāya para santaka ggahaṇam  vañcanam nāma tassa ivam pavatti daṭṭhabbā ekaḥ kira uju jātikaḥ gāmika purisaḥ araññataḥ  sasakam ānetvā nadī tīre ṭhapetvā nhāyitum otari atha ekaḥ dhutto tam sasakam sīse katvā
translated: The taking of another’s goods by showing a counterfeit is called “deception.” It should be seen in the taking of another’s goods by giving a counterfeit suvanṇa coin for a suvanṇa coin, a counterfeit kahāpaṇa coin for a kahāpaṇa coin, etc.

original: nhāyituṃ otiṇṇo. Itaro uttaritvā sasakaṃ apassanto ito cito ca vilokesi. Tamenaṃ
analyzed: nhāyitum otiṇṇaḥ itaraḥ uttaritvā sasakam a passantaḥ itas citas ca vilokesi tam enam
translated: But by the method of explanation, the taking of another’s goods by skill in means is called “fraud.” Its occurrence should be seen thus: a certain simpleton, it seems, brought some meat from the forest and set it down on the bank of a river. He then went in to bathe. A thief, having put the meat on his head, went in to bathe. The simpleton came out and not seeing the meat looked here and there. The thief said, “Why are you looking, sir? ”—

original: dhutto “kiṃ bho vilokesī”ti vatvā “imasmiṃ me ṭhāne sasako ṭhapito, taṃ na passāmī”ti
analyzed: dhutto kim bho vilokesi iti vatvā imasmim me ṭhāne sasakaḥ ṭhapito tam na passāmi iti
translated: “I set the meat down in this place, and I do not see it.”

original: vutte “andhabāla, tvaṃ na jānāsi, sasakā nāma nadītīre ṭhapitā palāyanti, passa ahaṃ
analyzed: vutte andha bāla tvam na jānāsi sasakā nāma nadī tīre ṭhapitā palāyanti passa aham
translated: “You are blind and foolish, sir, you do not know that meat set down on the bank of a river runs away. Look, I have run it away.”

original: attano sasakaṃ sīse ṭhapetvāva nhāyāmī”ti āha. So appaṭibhānatāya “evaṃ bhavissatī”ti
analyzed: attano sasakam sīse ṭhapetvā ava nhāyāmi iti āha saḥ appaṭibhāna tāya evam bhavissati iti
translated: and he said, “I shall bathe only after placing my own money on my head.” The other, being unable to reply, said, “So be it,” and he went away.

original: pakkāmi. Ekakahāpaṇena migapotakaṃ gahetvā puna taṃ datvā dvikahāpaṇagghanakassa
analyzed: eka kahāpaṇena miga potakam gahetvā puna tam da tvā dvi kahāpaṇa ghanakassa
translated: Taking a young deer for one kahāpaṇa, he gave it to the other and took a deer worth two kahāpaṇas.🔽The story of the deer’s capture should be told here.

original: migassa gahitavatthupettha kathetabbaṃ. Dissanti lobhadhammesūti sakka, ime ālopādayo🔽pāpadhammā lobhasabhāvesu lobhābhibhūtesu sattesu dissanti. Na hi aluddhā evarūpāni
analyzed: migassa kathetabbam dissanti lobha dhammesu iti sakkaḥ ime ālopa ādayaḥ  pāpa dhammā lobha sabhāvesu lobha abhibhūtesu sattesu dissanti na hi a luddhā evarūpāni
translated: “Greed is seen among the greedy”: O Sakka, these evil things beginning with greed

original: kammāni karonti. Evaṃ lobho anekādīnavo, tasmā lobhampi na rocemi.🔽Snehasaṅgathitā ganthāti ārammaṇesu allīyanalakkhaṇena snehena saṅgathitā punappunaṃ
analyzed: kammāni karonti evam lobhaḥ aneka ādīnavaḥ tasmai lobham pi na rocemi  sneha saṅgathitā ganthā ati ārammaṇesu allīyana lakkhaṇena snehena saṅgathitā punappunam
translated: are seen among beings who are dominated by greed. For those who are not greedy do not commit such actions. Thus greed has many disadvantages. Therefore I do not approve of greed.🔽“The bonds of affection are knots”: The bonds of affection are knots because they are tied again and again by affection, which has the characteristic of sticking to objects. Like flowers bound together with a thread, they occur in various ways in regard to the many kinds of objects.

original: uppādavasena ghaṭitā suttena pupphāni viya baddhā nānappakāresu ārammaṇesu pavattamānā
analyzed: uppāda vasena ghaṭitā suttena pupphāni viya baddhā nānappakāresu ārammaṇesu pavattamānā
translated: They are the bond of covetousness in the form of the fetter of sense desire.

original: abhijjhākāyaganthā. Senti manomayā puthūti te puthūsu ārammaṇesu uppannā suvaṇṇādīhi
analyzed: abhijjhā kāya ganthā manaḥ mayā te puthūsu ārammaṇesu uppannā suvaṇṇa ādīhi
translated: “Many are the thoughts that wander through the mind” : These thoughts that arise in regard to the various objects are made of mind. They are called “thoughts” because they think of various objects.

original: nibbattāni suvaṇṇādimayāni ābharaṇādīni viya manena nibbattattā manomayā abhijjhākāyaganthā

original: udapādi. Evaṃ pūritapāramīnaṃ mahāsattānaṃ pemaṃ upatāpaṃ karotiyeva. Ayaṃ snehe🔽ādīnavo, tasmā snehampi na rocemīti.

translated: The story of the man who was pierced by an arrow is the basis for the verse: “He suffers as one pierced by an arrow” . Moreover, when the Bodhisatta Mangala gave his children away, his heart broke from the intense grief. When the Bodhisatta Vessantara experienced great sorrow. translated: When she saw him, she thought to herself, “A field of merit has come to me. original: papphoṭetvā gandhatelena makkhetvā tassa pādesu paṭimuñcitvā “bhante, imā upāhanā
analyzed: papphoṭetvā gandha telena makkhetvā tassa pādesu paṭimuñcitvā bhante imā upāhanā

original: āruyha chattaṃ matthake katvā gacchathā”ti chattupāhanaṃ adāsi. So assa anuggahatthāya
analyzed: āruyha chattam matthake katvā gacchatha iti chattupāhanam adāsi saḥ assa anuggaha tthāya

analyzed: ekam upaṭṭhākam gahetvā sakala sarīram telena makkhetvā sappinā saddhim sakkhara cuṇṇam  yāvadattham khāditvā tam pi khādāpetvā tena saddhim kūpaka yaṭṭhi matthakam āruyha
translated: taking one attendant, anointed his whole body with oil, and with sugar-candy and ghee🔽ate as much as he could, and made him eat the remainder. Then, climbing with him to the top of the mast, “In this direction is our city,”

analyzed: jātaḥ saḥ tasmim pi kāle loṇa udakena mukham vikkhāletvā uposathikaḥ  tadā pana catūhi lokapālehi maṇimekhalā nāma deva dhītā sace samudde nāvāya bhinnāya

analyzed: ti saraṇa gatāḥ vā sīla sampannāḥ vā mātā pitu paṭṭhākāḥ vā manussāḥ dukkha ppattāḥ honti te

analyzed: rakkheyyāsi iti samudde ārakkhaṇa atthāya ṭhapitā hoti sā attanaḥ issariyena sattāham anubhavitvā

analyzed: tattha gantvā tassa puratas ākāse ṭhatvā brāhmaṇa tvam satta aham nirāhāraḥ idam dibba bhojanaṃ

analyzed: upaṭṭhāko pacchatas āgataḥ devatam a disvā saddam eva sutvā ayam brāhmaṇaḥ pakati sukhu mālo

analyzed: sattāham nirāhāra tāya dukkhitaḥ maraṇa bhayena vilapati maññe assāsessāmi cintetvā

original: paṭhamaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: paṭhamam gātham āha

original: “Bahussuto sutadhammosi saṅkha, diṭṭhā tayā samaṇabrāhmaṇā ca;

translated: “Well-read, thou art a man of learning, Saṅkha, and hast seen the recluses and the brahmins;

analyzed: athakkhaṇe dassayase vilāpam aññaḥ nu ko te paṭimantakaḥ mayā ati

analyzed: tattha suta dhammā asi iti dhammaḥ api tayā dhammika samaṇa brāhmaṇānam santike sutaḥ asi diṭṭhā
translated: Herein, thou art a man of learning means that thou hast heard the Dhamma from the recluses and brahmins who are men of learning. Thou hast seen means that thou hast seen the recluses and brahmins who are men of learning.

original: tayāti tesaṃ paccaye dentena veyyāvaccaṃ karontena dhammikasamaṇabrāhmaṇā ca tayā🔽diṭṭhā. Evaṃ akaronto hi passantopi te na passatiyeva. Athakkhaṇeti atha akkhaṇe🔽sallapantassa kassaci abhāvena vacanassa anokāse. Dassayaseti “ahaṃ uposathiko”ti
analyzed: tayā ati tesam paccaye dentena veyyāvaccam karontena dhammika samaṇa brāhmaṇā ca tayā  diṭṭhāḥ evam a karontaḥ hi passantaḥ pi te na passatiyā iva athakkhaṇe ti atha akkhaṇe  sallapantassa kassaci abhāvena vacanassa anokāse dassayase iti aham uposathikaḥ ti
translated: “You” : by one who gives requisites to them, by one who does service to them, righteous ascetics and brahmans are seen by you.🔽For one who does not do so, even though he sees them, he does not see them at all. “At the wrong time” : at the time when there is no opportunity for speaking, because there is no one to speak to. “You show” : “I am one who observes the Uposatha” .🔽🔽

original: vadanto vilāpaṃ dassesi. Paṭimantakoti mayā añño ko tava paṭimantako paṭivacanadāyako,🔽kiṃkāraṇā evaṃ vippalapasīti?
analyzed: vadantaḥ vilāpam dassesi paṭimantako ti mayā añño ko tava paṭimantako paṭivacana dāyako  kiṃkāraṇā evam vippalapasi iti
translated: “You have seen” means: you have seen those righteous ascetics and brahmins who give you requisites and render you service. For if you do not act thus, you do not see them even though you look. “At the wrong time” means: at a time when there is no opportunity for speech, because no one is talking. “You show” means: by saying, “I am one who observes the uposatha,” you show your lamentations. “Who is your respondent?” means: who else is there to give you a reply? Why do you lament thus?

original: So tassa vacanaṃ sutvā “imassa devatā na paññāyati maññe”ti cintetvā “samma, nāhaṃ maraṇassa bhāyāmi, atthi pana me añño paṭimantako”ti vatvā dutiyaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: so tassa vacanam sutvā imassa devatā na paññāyati maññā iti cintetvā samma na aham maraṇassa bhāyāmi atthi pana me añño paṭimantako ti vatvā dutiyam gātham āha
translated: Having heard his words, the deity thought, “It seems that he does not know the deity,” and said, “Good man, I am not afraid of death, but I have another respondent.” Then he spoke the second verse:

translated: “Subbhū, Subhā, Suppaṭimukkakambu, in a golden bowl,

analyzed: tattha subbhūti subhamukhā subhāti pāsādikā uttama rūpa dharā  paṭimukka suvaṇṇa alaṅkārā paggayha ati suvaṇṇa pātiyā bhattam gahetvā ukkhipitvā saddhāvittā ati  saddhā ca iva tuṭṭha cittā ca saddham cittam ti pi pāṭho tassa attho saddham ti saddahantam

original: cittanti tuṭṭhacittaṃ. Tamahaṃ notīti tamahaṃ devataṃ uposathikattā paṭikkhipanto
analyzed: cittam ti tuṭṭha cittam tam aham noti iti tam aham devatam uposathika ttā paṭikkhipantaḥ
translated: Herein, ‘Subbhūti’ is ‘Subhamukha’. ‘Subha’ is ‘beautiful’, ‘possessing the highest beauty’. ‘Suppaṭimukkakambū’ is ‘having a face adorned with a golden ornament’. ‘Paggayha’ is ‘having lifted up’. ‘Saddhāvitta’ is ‘having faith and a contented mind’. ‘Saddhaṃ citta’ is also a reading; the meaning of that is as follows: ‘Saddhaṃ’ is ‘having faith’, ‘citta’ is ‘a contented mind’. ‘Tamahaṃ notī’ is ‘I refuse that deity because of the observance-day fast’.

original: noti brūmi, na vippalapāmi sammāti.
analyzed: no ti brūmi na vippalapāmi
translated: ‘Sammā’ is ‘I speak, I do not prattle’.

original: Athassa so tatiyaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: athassa saḥ tatiyam gātham āha
translated: Then he spoke this third verse:

original: “Etādisaṃ brāhmaṇa disvāna yakkhaṃ, puccheyya poso sukhamāsisāno;
analyzed: etādisam brāhmaṇa disvāna yakkham puccheyya posaḥ sukham āsisānaḥ
translated: ‘Seeing such a yakkha, a man who desires happiness should ask him:

analyzed: uṭṭhehi nam pañjalikā abhipuccha devī nusi tvam uda mānusī nu ti
translated: “Rise up, ask him with palms together: “Are you a goddess or are you a human?””’

analyzed: amhākam sukham bhavissati na bhavissati iti puccheyya uṭṭhehi iti udakataḥ uṭṭhāna ākāram  dassentaḥ uṭṭhaha pañjalika abhipuccha ati añjalikaḥ hutvā abhipuccha uda mānusī iti udāhu
translated: “Rise up” means “rise up from the water.”🔽“With joined hands” means “with hands joined in reverence.”

original: mahiddhikā mānusī tvanti.
analyzed: mahiddhikā mānusī
translated: “Are you a human being of great power?” means “Are you a human being of great power?”

original: Bodhisatto “yuttaṃ kathesī”ti taṃ pucchanto catutthaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: bodhisattaḥ yuttam kathesi iti tam pucchantaḥ catuttham gātham āha
translated: The Bodhisatta, thinking “She speaks well,” asked her a question, and spoke the fourth stanza:

original: “Yaṃ tvaṃ sukhenābhisamekkhase maṃ, bhuñjassu bhattaṃ iti maṃ vadesi;
analyzed: yam tvam sukhena abhisamekkhase mam bhuñjassu bhattam iti mama vadesi
translated: “The reason why you look at me with pleasure, and say ‘Eat your food,’

analyzed: pucchāmi tam nāri mahā anubhāve devī tvam uda mānusī
translated: I ask you, lady of great power, are you a goddess or a human being?”🔽Herein, “The reason why you look at me with pleasure” means “The reason why you look at me with a loving eye.”

original: Tattha yaṃ tvanti yasmā tvaṃ sukhena maṃ abhisamekkhase, piyacakkhūhi olokesi. Pucchāmi tanti tena kāraṇena taṃ pucchāmi.

translated: “I ask you” means “For that reason I ask you.”

original: Tato devadhītā dve gāthā abhāsi –
analyzed: tatas deva dhītāḥ dve gāthāḥ abhāsi
translated: Then the goddess spoke two stanzas:

analyzed: devī aham saṅkha mahā anubhāvā idha āgatā sāgara vāri majjhe
translated: “I am a goddess, Saṅkha of great power, come hither from the midst of the ocean’s waters;

original: Anukampikā no ca paduṭṭhacittā, taveva atthāya idhāgatāsmi.
analyzed: anukampikā no ca paduṭṭha cittā tava iva atthāya idha āgatā asmi

translated: “Food and drink, couches and seats, and vehicles of various kinds,

translated: All these I offer to thee, whatever thou desirest in thy heart.”

analyzed: tattha idha ati imasmin mahā samudde nānā vividhāni iti bahūni ca aneka ppakārāni ca hatthi yāna assa yāna ādīni  atthi sabbassa tassa anna pāna ādinaḥ sabbassa sāmikam katvā tam te anna pāna ādim
translated: Herein, “here” means in this great ocean. “Vehicles of various kinds” means many and of various kinds, such as elephant-vehicles, horse-vehicles, etc.

original: paṭipādayāmi dadāmi. Yaṃ kiñcīti aññampi yaṃ kiñci manasā icchitaṃ, taṃ sabbaṃ te dammīti.
analyzed: paṭipādayāmi dadāmi yam kiñci iti aññam pi yam kiñci manasā icchitam tam sabbam te dammi iti
translated: “All these I offer to thee” means I give to thee this food, drink, etc., making thee their owner. “Whatever thou desirest” means I give thee all that thou wishest for in thy heart.

original: Taṃ sutvā mahāsatto “ayaṃ devadhītā samuddapiṭṭhe mayhaṃ ‘idañcidañca dammī’ti vadati,
analyzed: tam sutvā mahāsattaḥ ayam deva dhītā samudda piṭṭhe mayham idam cidam ca dammi iti vadati
translated: Hearing this, the Great Being thought, “This goddess, on the shore of the ocean, says to me, ‘I give thee this and that.’

translated: When the Teacher heard of his angry disposition, he sent for him and asked him, “Is it true, as men say, that you are angry?”🔽“It is true, Reverend Sir.”

analyzed: uttama rūpa dharāḥ deva chara paṭibhāgā tesam an icchamāna anaññā iva aññam aññam āvāha vivāham  kariṃsu ubhinnam pana etesam kilesa samudācāro nāma na bhūta pubbo saṃrāga vasena aññamaññassa

analyzed: pabbajitā apica kho pana me gihi kāle pāda paricārikā ahosi iti tam sutvā rājā ayam  kira itassa kiñci na hoti apica kho pana gihi kāle pāda paricārikā kirassa ahosi sace

analyzed: khippam nivāreti tathā khippam eva nam mettā bhāvanāya niggahetvā vāressāmi iti  evam mahāsatto sīhanādam nadi rājā panassa katham sutvā api andha bāla tāya paṭibaddham

translated: crafty, and might do me harm by some trick or other.

translated: I will go and see what he is doing.” Unable to remain where he was, he went to the park.

analyzed: yam nu pubbe vikatthitthaḥ balamhi iva a passitaḥ
translated: “What, after boasting so before, now art thou silent, as one

translated: The Great Being, hearing this, thought to himself, “The king, I suppose, is speaking to me in anger. I will tell him how I have overcome the anger that has arisen in him.” Accordingly he spoke the fourth stanza:—

original: Taṃ sutvā rājā “kiṃ nu kho esa kopameva sandhāya vadati, udāhu aññaṃ kiñci sippaṃ sandhāya kathesi, pucchissāmi tāva na”nti cintetvā pucchanto pañcamaṃ gāthamāha –

translated: Hearing this, the king thought to himself, “What is it that he is speaking of in this figure of speech? Or is he speaking of some other craft? I will ask him.” Accordingly he spoke the fifth stanza:—

original: “Kiṃ te uppajji no mucci, kiṃ te na mucci jīvato;
analyzed: kim te uppajji no mucci kim te na mucci jīvataḥ
translated: “What was it that rose and stayed not? What was it that would not stay with thee alive?

original: Rajaṃva vipulā vuṭṭhi, katamaṃ taṃ nivārayī”ti.
analyzed: katamam tam nivārayi iti
translated: As the great rain of dust that falls when the wind blows, how could you restrain it?”

original: Tattha kiṃ te uppajji no muccīti kiṃ tava uppajji ceva na mucci ca.
analyzed: tattha kim te uppajji no mucci iti kim tava uppajji ca iva na mucci ca
translated: Herein, what arose in you and did not pass away?

analyzed: tam sutvā bodhisattaḥ mahā rāja evam kodhaḥ bahu ādīnavaḥ mahā vināsa dāyakaḥ esaḥ mama uppajji uppannam ca nam mettā bhāvanāya nivāresinti kodhe ādīnavam pakāsentaḥ
translated: Hearing this, the Bodhisatta said, “Great king, anger is thus full of peril and brings great destruction. It arose in me, but by the practice of loving-kindness I restrained it.” So saying, he proclaimed the peril of anger:

original: “Yamhi jāte na passati, ajāte sādhu passati;
analyzed: yamhi jāte na passati ajāte sādhu passati
translated: “What is born brings no joy, but what is unborn brings joy;

original: So me uppajji no mucci, kodho dummedhagocaro.
analyzed: saḥ me uppajji no mucci kodhaḥ dummedha gocaraḥ
translated: That arose in me and did not pass away, anger, the resort of fools.

original: “Yena jātena nandanti, amittā dukkhamesino;
analyzed: yena jātena nandanti amittāḥ dukkhamesino
translated: “What is born brings grief to foes who wish one ill;

original: So me uppajji no mucci, kodho dummedhagocaro.
analyzed: saḥ me uppajji no mucci kodhaḥ dummedha gocaraḥ
translated: That arose in me and did not pass away, anger, the resort of fools.

original: “Yasmiñca jāyamānamhi, sadatthaṃ nāvabujjhati;
analyzed: yasmin ca jāyamānamhi sat attham na avabujjhati
translated: “What is born brings no understanding of one’s true good;

original: So me uppajji no mucci, kodho dummedhagocaro.
analyzed: saḥ me uppajji no mucci kodhaḥ dummedha gocaraḥ
translated: That arose in me and did not pass away, anger, the resort of fools.

original: “Yenābhibhūto kusalaṃ jahāti, parakkare vipulañcāpi atthaṃ;
analyzed: kusalam jahāti parakkare vipulam ca api attham
translated: “What is born makes one abandon what is good, and great good that one has done;

original: Sa bhīmaseno balavā pamaddī, kodho mahārāja na me amuccatha.
analyzed: sa bhīmasenaḥ balavā pamaddī kodhaḥ mahā rāja na me amuccatha
translated: That anger, great king, did not pass away from me, though I am terrible, strong, and mighty.”

original: “Kaṭṭhasmiṃ matthamānasmiṃ, pāvako nāma jāyati;
analyzed: kaṭṭhasmim matthamānasmim pāvakaḥ nāma jāyati
translated: “When wood is being burnt, a fire arises;

original: Tameva kaṭṭhaṃ ḍahati, yasmā so jāyate gini.
analyzed: tam eva kaṭṭham ḍahati saḥ jāyate
translated: It burns the very wood it burns, since it is from the wood it burns.

original: “Evaṃ mandassa posassa, bālassa avijānato;
analyzed: evam mandassa posassa bālassa a vijānataḥ
translated: “So too, when a fool is being scolded, anger arises in him;

analyzed: sa ārambhā jāyate saḥ upi tena iva ḍayhati
translated: It burns the very fool it burns, since it is from the fool it burns.

analyzed: aggi iva tiṇa kaṭṭhasmim kodhaḥ yassa pavaḍḍhati
translated: “When anger grows in a man,

analyzed: nihīyati tassa yasaḥ kāḷapakkhā iva candimā
translated: His fame diminishes, like the moon in waning fortnight.

original: “Anedho dhūmaketūva, kodho yassūpasammati;
analyzed: anedhaḥ kodhaḥ
translated: “But when anger is quelled in a man,

analyzed: āpūrati tassa yasaḥ sukka pakkhā iva candimā iti imāḥ gāthāḥ āha
translated: His fame waxes, like the moon in waxing fortnight.”

analyzed: tattha na passati iti atta attham pi na passati pagā iva parattham sādhu passati iti atta attham
translated: Herein, he does not see is that he does not see even his own good, let alone that of others. He sees well is that he sees well his own good,

translated: the good of others, and the good of both. The fool’s domain is that it is the domain of those who are not skilled.

analyzed: dukkham esinoti dukkham icchantā attanaḥ attha bhūtam atthataḥ ca iva dhammato
translated: Seeking suffering is that they seek suffering. Their own good is that which is their own good, which is good as a possession, good as a practice, good as a resort, and good as an accumulation. Their own good is not that which is not like this.

original: ca vuddhiṃ. Parakkareti vipulampi atthaṃ uppannaṃ parato kāreti, apanetha, na me🔽iminā atthoti vadati. Sa bhīmasenoti so kodho bhīmāya bhayajananiyā mahatiyā kilesasenāya🔽samannāgato. Pamaddīti attano balavabhāvena uḷārepi satte gahetvā attano vase karaṇena🔽maddanasamattho. Na me amuccathāti mama santikā mokkhaṃ na labhati, hadaye vā pana
analyzed: ca vuddhim parakkareti vipulam pi attham uppannam paratas kāreti apanetha na me  iminā attho ti vadati sa bhīmasenaḥ iti saḥ kodhaḥ bhīmāya bhaya jananiyā mahatiyā kilesa senāya  samannāgataḥ pamaddī iti attanaḥ balava bhāvena uḷāre pi satte gahetvā attanaḥ vase karaṇena  maddana samatthaḥ na me amuccatha ati mama santikā mokkham na labhati hadaye vā pana
translated: and growth. He makes others do it: he makes others do even a great deal of work that has arisen; he says: “Take it away, I have no use for it.” He is fearful: he is endowed with a great army of fear, of fearfulness, of fear-generating defilements. He is a tormentor: he is capable of tormenting, of bringing even lofty beings under his control, by the power of his own strength. He does not let me go: he does not give me release, or he does not let me go from his heart,

original: me khīraṃ viya muhuttaṃ dadhibhāvena na patiṭṭhahitthātipi attho.
analyzed: me khīram viya muhuttam dadhi bhāvena na attho
translated: and growth. He makes others do what is to be done: he says, “Remove it, I have no use for this” when some great benefit has arisen from another. He is Bhīmasena: he is endowed with a great army of defilements that generate fear. He maddens: he is able to seize even lofty beings and bring them under his own control by the power of his own strength. He does not let me go: he does not allow me to escape from him; or the meaning is: he does not stand still in my heart for a moment like milk that turns to curd.

original: Kaṭṭhasmiṃ matthamānasminti araṇīsahitena matthiyamāne, “maddamānasmi”ntipi pāṭho.🔽Yasmāti yato kaṭṭhā jāyati, tameva ḍahati. Ginīti aggi. Bālassa avijānatoti bālassa
analyzed: kaṭṭhasmin matthamānasmin ti araṇī sahitena matthiyamāne maddamānasmin tipi pāṭhaḥ  yasmā iti yatas kaṭṭhā jāyati tam eva ḍahati ginī iti aggi bālassa a vijānato ti bālassa
translated: In the wood that is being rubbed: in the wood that is being rubbed together with the fire-stick; the reading is also “maddamānasmin” .

original: avijānantassa. Sārambhā jāyateti ahaṃ tvanti ākaḍḍhanavikaḍḍhanaṃ karontassa karaṇuttariyalakkhaṇā
analyzed: a vijānantassa sārambhā jāyata iti aham ākaḍḍhana vikaḍḍhanam karontassa karaṇa uttariya lakkhaṇā
translated: From that: from the wood the fire is born, and it burns that very wood. The fire: the fire. Of the ignorant fool: of the ignorant fool. Arising from agitation: arising from the agitation of “I” and “mine” that takes the form of doing and instrumentality.

original: sārambhā araṇīmatthanā viya pāvako kodho jāyati. Sopi tenevāti sopi bālo teneva kodhena
analyzed: sa ārambhāḥ araṇīmatthanāḥ viya pāvako kodhaḥ jāyati saḥ api tena iva ati saḥ api bālaḥ tena iva kodhena
translated: Anger arises in him like a fire kindled by rubbing sticks together.🔽And he, too, by that same anger,

original: kaṭṭhaṃ viya agginā ḍayhati. Anedho dhūmaketūvāti anindhano aggi viya. Tassāti tassa
analyzed: kaṭṭham viya agginā ḍayhati an edhaḥ dhūma ketu uvā ati an indhanaḥ aggi viya tassa ati tassa
translated: Anger arises in him, like fire from the friction of wet sticks. He, too, is burned by that anger, like wood by fire. He is like a fire without fuel.

original: adhivāsanakhantiyā samannāgatassa puggalassa sukkapakkhe cando viya laddho yaso aparāparaṃ āpūratīti.
analyzed: adhivāsana khantiyā samannāgatassa puggalassa sukka pakkhe candaḥ viya laddhaḥ yasaḥ apara aparam āpūrati iti
translated: The glory of him who is endowed with the virtue of patience increases, like the moon in the bright fortnight.

original: Rājā mahāsattassa dhammakathaṃ sutvā tuṭṭho ekaṃ amaccaṃ āṇāpetvā paribbājikaṃ āharāpetvā
analyzed: rājā mahāsattassa dhamma katham sutvā tuṭṭhaḥ ekam amaccam āṇāpetvā paribbājikam āharāpetvā
translated: The king, having heard the discourse of the Great Being, was pleased, and having ordered a minister, had the female Wanderer brought.

original: “bhante nikkodhatāpasa, ubhopi tumhe pabbajjāsukhena vītināmentā idheva uyyāne vasatha,
analyzed: bhante nikkodha tāpasa ubho pi tumhe pabbajja asukhena idha iva uyyāne vasatha
translated: “Reverend Nikkodha, you and she, having passed your days in the happiness of the religious life, should dwell right here in the garden.

original: ahaṃ vo dhammikaṃ rakkhāvaraṇaguttiṃ karissāmī”ti vatvā khamāpetvā vanditvā pakkāmi.
analyzed: aham vaḥ dhammikam rakkhā āvaraṇa guttim karissāmi iti vatvā khamāpetvā vanditvā pakkāmi
translated: I will give you both the protection of the law.” Having thus spoken, he asked their pardon, saluted them, and departed.

original: Te ubhopi tattheva vasiṃsu. Aparabhāge paribbājikā kālamakāsi. Bodhisatto tassā kālakatāya
analyzed: te ubho pi tattha iva vasiṃsu aparabhāge paribbājikā kālam akāsi bodhisatto tassā kālakatāya
translated: They both dwelt there. In course of time the female Wanderer died. The Bodhisatta, on account of her death,

original: himavantaṃ pavisitvā abhiññā ca samāpattiyo ca nibbattetvā cattāro brahmavihāre bhāvetvā
analyzed: himavantam pavisitvā abhiññā ca samāpattiyo ca nibbattetvā cattāraḥ brahmavihāre bhāvetvā

original: brahmalokaparāyaṇo ahosi.
analyzed: brahma loka parāyaṇaḥ ahosi
translated: and he passed on to the Brahma-world.

original: Satthā imaṃ dhammadesanaṃ āharitvā saccāni pakāsetvā jātakaṃ samodhānesi, saccapariyosāne kodhano bhikkhu anāgāmiphale patiṭṭhahi.
analyzed: satthā imam dhamma desanam āharitvā saccāni pakāsetvā jātakam samodhānesi sacca pariyosāne kodhanaḥ bhikkhu anāgāmi phale patiṭṭhahi
translated: When the Teacher had related this story, he made the Truths evident, and at the conclusion of the Truths the angry monk was established in the fruit of non-returner.

original: Tadā paribbājikā rāhulamātā ahosi, rājā ānando, paribbājako pana ahameva ahosinti.
analyzed: tadā paribbājikā rāhula mātā ahosi rājā ānandaḥ paribbājakaḥ pana aham eva ahosinti
translated: At that time Rāhula’s mother was the female wanderer, Ānanda was the king, and I myself was the male wanderer.

original: Cūḷabodhijātakavaṇṇanā pañcamā.
analyzed: cūḷabodhijātakavaṇṇanā pañcamā
translated: The Storiy of Cūḷabodhi.

original: [444] 6. Kaṇhadīpāyanajātakavaṇṇanā
translated: The Story of Kaṇhadīpāyana.

original: Sattāhamevāhanti idaṃ satthā jetavane viharanto ekaṃ ukkaṇṭhitabhikkhuṃ ārabbha kathesi.🔽Vatthu kusajātake āvi bhavissati. Satthā taṃ bhikkhuṃ “saccaṃ kira tvaṃ bhikkhu ukkaṇṭhitosī”ti
analyzed: sattāham eva aham ti idam satthā jetavane viharantaḥ ekam ukkaṇṭhita bhikkhum ārabbha kathesi  vatthu kusa jātake āvi bhavissati satthā tam bhikkhum saccam kira tvam bhikkhu ukkaṇṭhito asi iti
translated: For seven days only: the Teacher told this story while dwelling in Jetavana, about a monk who was discontented.🔽The story will be told in the Kusajātaka. The Teacher asked the monk, “Is it true, monk, that you are discontented?”

analyzed: pucchitvā saccam bhante ti vutte bhikkhu porāṇaka paṇḍitāḥ anuppanne buddhe bāhiraka pabbajjam

analyzed: pabbajitvā atireka paññāsa vassāni an abhiratāḥ brahmacariyam carantāḥ hirottappa bheda bhayena

translated: they had not told anyone of their discontent. Why then should you, having gone forth in such a religion as this, which is so well preached and so well proclaimed,

analyzed: karosi kimattham attanaḥ hirottappam na rakkhasi iti vatvā atītam āhari
translated: Why do you not preserve your shame and fear of wrongdoing?”

original: Atīte vaṃsaraṭṭhe kosambiyaṃ nāma nagare kosambako nāma rājā rajjaṃ kāresi. Tadā
analyzed: atīte vaṃsaraṭṭhe kosambiyam nāma nagare kosambakaḥ nāma rājā rajjam kāresi tadā

analyzed: nikkhamitvā himavanta padese assamapadam katvā pabbajitvā uñchā cariyāya vana mūla phala aphalena

analyzed: yāpentā paṇṇāsa vassāni vasiṃsu jhānam uppādetum na asakkhiṃsu te paṇṇāsa vassa cayena

translated: they went wandering through the country to see the sea and the river, and they reached the country of Kāsi. There, in a certain

analyzed: agamaṃsu saḥ te disvā ava atta manaḥ paṇṇa sālam kāretvā ubho api te catūhi paccayehi upaṭṭhahi
translated: He was delighted to see them, had a leaf-hut built, and looked after them with the four requisites.

analyzed: te tattha tīṇi cattāri vassāni vasitvā tam āpucchitvā cārikam carantāḥ bārāṇasim patvā
translated: After living there for three or four years, they took leave of him and went wandering. They reached Bārāṇasī and

analyzed: atimuttaka susāne tattha dīpāyanaḥ yathā abhirantam viharitvā puna tassa iva sahāyassa
translated: lived in the charnel ground of Atimuttaka. There Dīpāyaṇa lived as long as he liked, and then he went back to his friend

analyzed: santikam gataḥ maṇḍabya tāpaso tattha iva vasi
translated: Maṇḍabyā. The ascetic Maṇḍabyā lived right there.

original: Athekadivasaṃ eko coro antonagare corikaṃ katvā dhanasāraṃ ādāya nikkhanto “coro”ti
analyzed: atha eka divasam ekaḥ coraḥ antar nagare corikam katvā dhanasāram ādāya nikkhanto coro ti
translated: One day a thief, after committing a theft in the city, took some valuables and left. People shouted, “Thief!”

analyzed: ñatvā paṭibuddhehi ghara ssāmikehi ca iva ārakkha manussehi ca anubaddhaḥ niddhamanena
translated: The householders and the guards, having understood, followed him.

analyzed: nikkhamitvā vegena susānam pavisitvā tāpasassa paṇṇasāla dvāre bhaṇḍikam chaṭṭetvā

analyzed: palāyi manussāḥ bhaṇḍikam disvā are duṭṭha jaṭila tvam rattim corikam katvā divā
translated: he ran away. The people, having seen the bundle, said: “Hey, you wicked ascetic, at night you do thievery,

analyzed: tāpasa rūpena carasi iti tat jetvā pothetvā tam ādāya netvā raññaḥ dassayiṃsu rājā an upaparikkhitvā ava
translated: and by day you go about in the guise of an ascetic,” and after rebuking and reviling him, taking him, they went and showed him to the King. The King, without investigating,

original: “gacchatha, naṃ sūle uttāsethā”ti āha. Te taṃ susānaṃ netvā khadirasūlaṃ āropayiṃsu,
analyzed: gacchatha nam sūle uttāsetha iti āha te tam su sānam netvā khadira sūlam āropayiṃsu
translated: said: “Go, impale him on a stake.” They took him to the charnel ground and put him on a stake of Khadira wood,

original: tāpasassa sarīre sūlaṃ na pavisati. Tato nimbasūlaṃ āhariṃsu, tampi na pavisati.
analyzed: tāpasassa sarīre sūlam na pavisati tatas nimba sūlam āhariṃsu tam pi na pavisati
translated: but the stake would not enter the ascetic’s body. Then they brought a stake of Nimba wood, but that also would not enter.

original: Ayasūlaṃ āhariṃsu, tampi na pavisati. Tāpaso “kiṃ nu kho me pubbakamma”nti olokesi,
analyzed: ayasūlam āhariṃsu tam pi na pavisati tāpasaḥ kim nu kho me pubba kammanti olokesi
translated: They brought an iron stake, but that also would not enter. The ascetic thought: ‘What is my past deed?’

analyzed: athassa jāti ssara ñāṇam uppajji tena pubba kammam oloketvā addasa kim panassa pubba kammanti
translated: Then knowledge of his past lives arose, and by that he looked at his past deed and saw. But what was his past deed?

original: Koviḷārasūle makkhikāvedhanaṃ. So kira purimabhave vaḍḍhakiputto hutvā pitu rukkhatacchanaṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: koviḷāra sūle makkhikā vedhanam so kira purima bhave vaḍḍhaki putto hutvā pitu
translated: The impalement on the Kovidāra stake was the impalement of the fly. He was the son of a gardener, it seems, and on one occasion he went with his father to the place where the trees were being pruned.

original: gantvā ekaṃ makkhikaṃ gahetvā koviḷārasalākāya sūle viya vijjhi. Tamenaṃ pāpakammaṃ🔽imaṃ ṭhānaṃ patvā gaṇhi. So “na sakkā ito pāpā mayā muccitu”nti ñatvā rājapurise
analyzed: gantvā ekam makkhikam gahetvā koviḍāra salākāya sūle viya vijjhi tam enam pāpa kammam  imam ṭhānam patvā gaṇhi saḥ na sakkā itas pāpāḥ mayā muccitunti ñatvā rāja purise
translated: He caught a fly and impaled it on a branch of the Kovidāra tree as though on a stake.🔽That evil deed caught up with him in this place.

original: āha “sace maṃ sūle uttāsetukāmattha, koviḷārasūlaṃ āharathā”ti. Te tathā katvā taṃ
analyzed: āha sace mam sūle koviḷāra sūlam āharatha ati te tathā katvā tam
translated: Knowing that he could not escape from his evil deed, he said to the king’s men, “If you want to impale me on a stake, bring the Kovidāra stake.” They did so,

original: sūle uttāsetvā ārakkhaṃ datvā pakkamiṃsu.
analyzed: sūle uttāsetvā ārakkham datvā pakkamiṃsu
translated: and after impaling him on the stake, they left a guard and departed.

analyzed: ārakkhakā paṭicchannā hutvā tassa santikam āgacchante olokenti tadā dīpāyanaḥ cira diṭṭhaḥ  me sahāyaḥ iti maṇḍabyassa santikam āgacchantaḥ sūle uttāsito ti tam divasaññā iva antarāmagge
translated: The guards were hidden, and they watched as he approached. At that time Dīpaṅkara, thinking, “I have not seen my friend for a long time,”🔽was approaching the pavilion. Having heard on the way that very day that he had been impaled on a stake, he went to that place and stood to one side.

original: sutvā taṃ ṭhānaṃ gantvā ekamantaṃ ṭhito “kiṃ samma kārakosī”ti pucchitvā “akārakomhī”ti
analyzed: sutvā tam ṭhānam gantvā ekamantam ṭhito kim samma kārako asi iti pucchitvā a kārako asi iti
translated: Asking, “What is it, my friend?” he was told, “I have done nothing wrong.”

original: vutte “attano manopadosaṃ rakkhituṃ sakkhi, nāsakkhī”ti pucchi. “Samma, yehi ahaṃ🔽gahito, neva tesaṃ, na rañño upari mayhaṃ manopadoso atthī”ti. “Evaṃ sante tādisassa🔽sīlavato chāyā mayhaṃ sukhā”ti vatvā dīpāyano sūlaṃ nissāya nisīdi. Athassa sarīre
analyzed: vutte attanaḥ manaḥ upadosam rakkhitum sakkhi na asakkhi iti pucchi samma yehi aham  gahitaḥ nā iva tesam na raññaḥ upari mayham manaḥ upadoso atthi iti evam sante tādisassa  sīlavataḥ chāyā mayham sukhā ati vatvā dīpāyanaḥ sūlam nissāya nisīdi athassa sarīre
translated: When this was said, the king asked, “Was it possible for you to protect your own anger?” “Yes, sire, but I did not protect it.” “If that is so, then the shade of such a virtuous man is pleasant to me.” So saying, the king sat down near the stake. Then the king’s anger was appeased.

original: maṇḍabyassa sarīrato lohitabindūni patiṃsu. Tāni suvaṇṇavaṇṇasarīre patitapatitāni🔽sussitvā kāḷakāni uppajjiṃsu. Tato paṭṭhāyeva so kaṇhadīpāyano nāma ahosi. So sabbarattiṃ tattheva nisīdi.🔽Punadivase ārakkhapurisā āgantvā taṃ pavattiṃ rañño ārocesuṃ. Rājā “anisāmetvāva
