translated: Dīpāyaṇa, why, being disgusted, do you live the holy life unwillingly?”

original: Tassattho – ye keci khattiyādayo kāme pahāya idha loke pabbajanti, te aññatra kaṇhā
analyzed: tassa atthaḥ ye keci khattiya ādayaḥ kāme pahāya idha loke pabbajanti te aññatra kaṇhā
translated: Its meaning is this: Whatever Khattiyas, etc., having given up sense desires, go forth in this world, they are not black apart from you, black-one.

original: bhavantaṃ kaṇhaṃ ṭhapetvā aññe akāmarūpā nāma natthi, sabbe jhānabhāvanāya kilesānaṃ
analyzed: bhavantam kaṇham ṭhapetvā aññe akāmarūpāḥ nāma natthi sabbe jhāna bhāvanāya kilesānaṃ
translated: There are none who are black apart from you, black-one. All of them, having calmed defilements by the development of jhāna,

original: samitattā santā, cakkhādīni dvārāni yathā nibbisevanāni honti, tathā tesaṃ damitattā
analyzed: samita ttā santā cakkha ādīni dvārāni yathā nibbisevanāni honti tathā tesam damita ttā
translated: are calm, and having controlled the doors of the eye, etc., so that they are not used for indulgence,

original: dantā hutvā abhiratāva brahmacariyaṃ caranti, tvaṃ pana bhante dīpāyana, kiṃkāraṇā
analyzed: dantāḥ hutvā abhiratāḥ ava brahmacariyam caranti tvam pana bhante dīpāyana kiṃkāraṇā
translated: they live the holy life happily, being self-controlled. But why, venerable Dīpāyaṇa,

original: tapaṃ jigucchamāno akāmako hutvā brahmacariyaṃ carasi, kasmā puna na agārameva ajjhāvasasīti.
analyzed: tapam jigucchamānaḥ akāmakaḥ hutvā brahmacariyam carasi kasmai puna na agāram eva ajjhāvasasi iti
translated: being disgusted with austerity, do you live the holy life unwillingly? Why do you not live at home again?”

original: Athassa so kāraṇaṃ kathento pañcamaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: athassa saḥ kāraṇam kathentaḥ pañcamam gātham āha
translated: Then he spoke the fifth stanza, telling the reason:

original: “Saddhāya nikkhamma punaṃ nivatto, so eḷamūgova bālo vatāyaṃ;
analyzed: saddhāya nikkhamma punar nivatto saḥ eḷamūgaḥ iva bālaḥ vata ayam
translated: “Having gone forth through faith, he has turned back again, this fool is like a blind man who has lost his way;

original: Etassa vādassa jigucchamāno, akāmako carāmi brahmacariyaṃ;
analyzed: etassa vādassa jigucchamānaḥ akāmakaḥ carāmi brahmacariyam
translated: Disgusted with this doctrine, unwilling, I live the holy life.

original: Viññuppasatthañca satañca ṭhānaṃ, evampahaṃ puññakaro bhavāmī”ti.
analyzed: viññuppasatthañca satañca ṭhānam evampaham puñña karaḥ bhavāmi iti
translated: The wise and the good approve it, and so I am a doer of merit.”

original: Tassattho – kaṇho kammañca phalañca saddahitvā tāva mahantaṃ vibhavaṃ pahāya agārā
analyzed: kaṇhaḥ kammañca phalañca saddahitvā tāva mahantam vibhavam pahāya
translated: The meaning is: Having believed in the doctrine of black deeds and their fruits, he left home and renounced his great wealth.

original: nikkhamitvā yaṃ jahi, puna tadatthameva nivatto. So ayaṃ eḷamūgo gāmadārako viya
analyzed: nikkhamitvā yam jahi puna tad attham eva nivatto saḥ ayam eḷamūgaḥ gāma dārakaḥ
translated: But he returned to it again, just as the village boy Eḷamūgaka did.

original: bālo vatāti imaṃ vādaṃ jigucchamāno ahaṃ attano hirottappabhedabhayena anicchamānopi
analyzed: bālaḥ vata ati imam vādam jigucchamānaḥ aham hiraḥ uttappa bheda bhayena an icchamānaḥ api
translated: Disgusted with this doctrine, I live the holy life unwillingly, out of fear of the loss of my sense of shame and moral dread.

original: brahmacariyaṃ carāmi. Kiñca bhiyyo pabbajjāpuññañca nāmetaṃ viññūhi buddhādīhi pasatthaṃ,
analyzed: brahmacariyam carāmi kiñca bhiyyas pabbajjāpuññam ca nāma etam viññūhi buddha ādīhi pasattham
translated: Moreover, this merit of going forth is approved by the wise, by the Buddhas and so on,

original: tesaṃyeva ca sataṃ nivāsaṭṭhānaṃ. Evaṃ imināpi kāraṇena ahaṃ puññakaro bhavāmi, assumukhopi
analyzed: tesam yeva ca satam nivāsa ṭṭhānam evam iminā api kāraṇena aham puñña karaḥ bhavāmi assumukhaḥ pi
translated: and it is the abode of the good. For this reason too I am a doer of merit. Even though I go forth weeping,

original: rudamāno brahmacariyaṃ carāmiyevāti.
analyzed: rudamānaḥ brahmacariyam carāmi iya iva ati
translated: with tearful face, I still live the holy life.”

original: Evaṃ so attano ajjhāsayaṃ kathetvā puna maṇḍabyaṃ pucchanto chaṭṭhaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: evam saḥ attanaḥ ajjhāsayam kathetvā puna maṇḍabyam pucchantaḥ chaṭṭham gātham āha
translated: Having thus expressed his own opinion, he asked Maṇḍabya a question with the following verse:

original: “Samaṇe tuvaṃ brāhmaṇe addhike ca, santappayāsi annapānena bhikkhaṃ;
analyzed: samaṇe tuvam brāhmaṇe addhike ca santappayāsi anna pānena bhikkham
translated: “You, who give alms to ascetics, to Brahmins, and to those who are better off,

original: Opānabhūtaṃva gharaṃ tava yidaṃ, annena pānena upetarūpaṃ;
analyzed: opāna bhūtam iva annena pānena upeta rūpam
translated: This house of yours is like a place of rest, a place to which those who are thirsty come for water,

original: Atha kissa vādassa jigucchamāno, akāmako dānamimaṃ dadāsī”ti.
analyzed: atha kissa vādassa jigucchamānaḥ akāmakaḥ dānam imam dadāsi iti
translated: Why, being one who is scrupulous about what is said, do you give this gift unwillingly?”

original: Tattha bhikkhanti bhikkhāya carantānaṃ bhikkhañca sampādetvā dadāsi. Opānabhūtaṃvāti catumahāpathe khatasādhāraṇapokkharaṇī viya.
analyzed: tattha bhikkhanti bhikkhāya carantānam bhikkham ca sampādetvā dadāsi opāna bhūtaṃva ati catu mahāpathe khata sādhāraṇa pokkharaṇī viya
translated: Herein, “alms” is almsfood. “A place of rest” is like a public tank in a crossroads.

original: Tato maṇḍabyo attano ajjhāsayaṃ kathento sattamaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: tatas maṇḍabyaḥ attanaḥ ajjhāsayam kathentaḥ sattamam gātham āha
translated: Then the householder, in his own mind, spoke this verse:

original: “Pitaro ca me āsuṃ pitāmahā ca, saddhā ahuṃ dānapatī vadaññū;
analyzed: pitaro ca me āsum pitāmahā ca saddhā ahum dānapatī vadaññū
translated: “My fathers and grandfathers were faithful, givers of gifts, generous,

original: Taṃ kullavattaṃ anuvattamāno, māhaṃ kule antimagandhano ahuṃ;
analyzed: tam kullavattam anuvattamānaḥ mā aham kule antima gandhanaḥ ahum
translated: Following in the footsteps of those who were good, I have not been the last in the family to be fragrant with virtue.

original: Etassa vādassa jigucchamāno, akāmako dānamimaṃ dadāmī”ti.
analyzed: etassa vādassa jigucchamānaḥ akāmakaḥ dānam imam dadāmi iti
translated: Why, being one who is scrupulous about what is said, do I give this gift unwillingly?”

original: Tattha “āsu”nti padassa “saddhā”ti iminā sambandho, saddhā ahesunti attho. Ahunti
analyzed: tattha āsunti padassa saddhā ati iminā sambandhaḥ saddhā ahesunti atthaḥ ahunti
translated: Herein, the word “were” is connected with “faithful,” the meaning is: they were faithful. “They” is the plural form of “he.”

original: saddhā hutvā tato uttari dānajeṭṭhakā ceva “detha karothā”ti vuttavacanassa atthajānanakā🔽ca ahesuṃ. Taṃ kullavattanti taṃ kulavattaṃ, aṭṭhakathāyaṃ pana ayameva pāṭho. Māhaṃ
analyzed: saddhā hutvā tatas uttari dāna jeṭṭhakā ca iva detha karotha ati vutta vacanassa attha jānanakā  ca ahesum tam kulla vattanti tam kula vattam aṭṭhakathā ayam pana ayam eva pāṭhaḥ mā aham
translated: and they were faithful, and they were the chief givers of gifts, and they knew the meaning of the words “Give! Make!”🔽This family-custom, however, is called “the last of the family” in the commentary. I do not wish

original: kule antimagandhano ahunti “ahaṃ attano kule sabbapacchimako ceva kulapalāpo ca mā
analyzed: kule antima gandhanaḥ ahunti aham attano kule sabbapacchimako ca iva kula palāpo ca mā
translated: to be the last of the family, the disgrace of the family.

original: ahu”nti sallakkhetvā etaṃ “kulaantimo kulapalāpo”ti vādaṃ jigucchamāno dānaṃ anicchantopi
analyzed: ahunti sallakkhetvā etam kula antimaḥ kula palāpaḥ iti vādam jigucchamānaḥ dānam an icchantaḥ api
translated: Thinking thus, and being disgusted with the idea of being “the last of the family, the disgrace of the family,” and not wishing to give the gift,

original: idaṃ dānaṃ dadāmīti dīpeti.
analyzed: idam dānam dadāmi iti dīpa iti
translated: he says, “I give this gift.”

original: Evañca pana vatvā maṇḍabyo attano bhariyaṃ pucchamāno aṭṭhamaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: evañca pana vatvā maṇḍabyaḥ attanaḥ bhariyam pucchamānaḥ aṭṭhamam gātham āha
translated: Having said this, the pavilion-dweller, asking his wife, spoke the eighth verse:

original: “Dahariṃ kumāriṃ asamatthapaññaṃ, yaṃ tānayiṃ ñātikulā sugatte;
analyzed: daharim kumārim a samattha paññam yam tānayim ñāti kulā su gatte
translated: “A young girl, a maiden, of little wisdom, whom I brought from my relatives’ family, a good woman,

original: Na cāpi me appiyataṃ avedi, aññatra kāmā paricārayantā;
analyzed: na ca api me appiyatam avedi aññatra kāmā paricārayantā
translated: she has not shown herself displeasing to me, except in that she has not attended to my desires;

original: Atha kena vaṇṇena mayā te bhoti, saṃvāsadhammo ahu evarūpo”ti.
analyzed: atha kena vaṇṇena mayā te bhoti saṃvāsa dhammo evarūpo ti
translated: but for what reason, my dear, has our way of life been such?”

original: Tattha asamatthapaññanti kuṭumbaṃ vicāretuṃ appaṭibalapaññaṃ atitaruṇiññeva samānaṃ.
analyzed: tattha asamattha paññam ti kuṭumbam vicāretum appaṭibala paññam samānam
translated: “Incapable of understanding” means that she was incapable of understanding the household affairs, and was like a mere child.

original: Yaṃ tānayinti yaṃ taṃ ānayiṃ, ahaṃ daharimeva samānaṃ taṃ ñātikulato ānesinti vuttaṃ
analyzed: yam tānayin ti yam tam ānayin aham daharim eva samānam tam ñāti kulataḥ ānesin ti vuttam
translated: “What I brought” means that I brought her from her relatives’ home, although she was still a mere child.

original: hoti. Aññatra kāmā paricārayantāti ettakaṃ kālaṃ vinā kāmena anicchāya maṃ paricārayantāpi
analyzed: hoti aññatra kāmā ettakam kālam vinā kāmena an icchāya mam paricārayantā api
translated: “Without desire” means that for so long a time, even though they were serving me without desire, without wishing for it,

original: attano appiyataṃ maṃ na jānāpesi, sampiyāyamānarūpāva paricari. Kena vaṇṇenāti kena
analyzed: attanaḥ appiya tam mam na jānāpesi sampiyāyamāna rūpā ava paricari kena vaṇṇena ati kena
translated: they did not make me known as their own, but served me as if they were fond of me. “For what reason?” means “for what reason?”

original: kāraṇena. Bhotīti taṃ ālapati. Evarūpoti āsīvisasamānapaṭikūlabhāvena mayā saddhiṃ
analyzed: kāraṇena tam ālapati evarūpaḥ iti āsīvisa samāna paṭikūla bhāvena mayā saddhim
translated: “Lady” is an address to her. “Such a one” means that your living with me, which is as disagreeable as a snake,

original: tava saṃvāsadhammo evarūpo piyasaṃvāso viya kathaṃ jātoti.
analyzed: tava saṃvāsa dhammo evarūpaḥ piya saṃvāso viya katham jātaḥ iti
translated: how did it come to be like living with a dear one?

original: Athassa sā kathentī navamaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: atha assa sā kathentī navamam gātham āha
translated: Then she spoke the ninth verse:

original: “Ārā dūre nayidha kadāci atthi, paramparā nāma kule imasmiṃ;
analyzed: ārā dūre kadāci atthi paramparā nāma kule imasmin
translated: “There is no such thing as a distant relative here, in this family it is said to be a succession;

original: Taṃ kullavattaṃ anuvattamānā, māhaṃ kule antimagandhinī ahuṃ;
analyzed: tam kullavattam anuvattamānā mā aham kule antima gandhinī ahum
translated: Following that family custom, I did not become the last stinking one in the family;

original: Etassa vādassa jigucchamānā, akāmikā paddhacarāmhi tuyha”nti.
analyzed: etassa vādassa jigucchamānā akāmikā paddhacarāmhi tuyhanti
translated: “I, too, am not willing, disgusted with this talk, to be your slave.”

original: Tattha ārā dūreti aññamaññavevacanaṃ. Atidūreti vā dassentī evamāha. Idhāti nipātamattaṃ,
analyzed: tattha ārā dūrā iti aññamañña vevacanam atidūrā iti vā dassentī evam āha idha iti nipāta mattam
translated: Herein, “too far” is a synonym for “too much.” Or she said this showing that it was too far. “Here” is merely a particle;

original: na kadācīti attho. Paramparāti purisaparamparā. Idaṃ vuttaṃ hoti – sāmi, imasmiṃ
analyzed: na kadāci iti attho paramparā ti purisa paramparā idam vuttam hoti sāmi imasmin
translated: the meaning is, “never.” “Succession” is a succession of men. This is what is said:

original: amhākaṃ ñātikule dūrato paṭṭhāya yāva sattamā kulaparivaṭṭā purisaparamparā nāma
analyzed: amhākam ñāti kule dūratas paṭṭhāya yāva sattamā kula parivaṭṭā purisaparamparā nāma
translated: “Master, in this family of ours, from the beginning of the seventh generation of families, there is no succession of men,

original: na kadāci atthi, ekitthiyāpi sāmikaṃ chaḍḍetvā añño puriso gahitapubbo nāma natthīti.🔽Taṃ kullavattanti ahampi taṃ kulavattaṃ kulapaveṇiṃ anuvattamānā attano kule pacchimikā
analyzed: na kadāci atthi eka itthiyā api sāmikam chaḍḍetvā aññaḥ puriso gahita pubbaḥ nāma natthi iti  tam kullavattanti aham pi tam kulavattam kula paveṇim anuvattamānā attano kule pacchimikā
translated: no man has ever been taken by one woman after abandoning her husband.”🔽“I, too, following that family tradition, that family line, thinking, ‘Let me not be the last woman in my family,

original: palālabhūtā mā ahunti sallakkhetvā etaṃ kulaantimā kulagandhinīti vādaṃ jigucchamānā
analyzed: palāla bhūtāḥ mā ahunti sallakkhetvā etam kula antimā kula gandhinī iti vādam jigucchamānā
translated: the last of the lineage, the last of the clan,’ disgusted with this talk,

original: akāmikāpi tuyhaṃ paddhacarāmhi veyyāvaccakārikā pādaparicārikā jātāmhīti.
analyzed: akāmikā api tuyham paddhacarāmhi veyyāvacca kārikā pāda paricārikā jātā amhi iti
translated: though not willing, have become your slave, your servant, your slave girl.”

original: Evañca pana vatvā “mayā sāmikassa santike abhāsitapubbaṃ guyhaṃ bhāsitaṃ, kujjheyyapi
analyzed: evam ca pana vatvā mayā sāmikassa santike a bhāsita pubbam guyham bhāsitam
translated: Having so spoken, she thought to herself, “I have spoken words that ought not to be spoken in the presence of my husband. He may be angry with me.

original: me ayaṃ, amhākaṃ kulūpakatāpasassa sammukheyeva khamāpessāmī”ti cintetvā khamāpentī dasamaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: me ayam amhākam kulūpaka tāpasassa sammukhā iya iva khamāpessāmi iti cintetvā khamāpentī dasamam gātham āha
translated: I will ask his forgiveness in the presence of our family priest.” So she spoke the tenth stanza,

original: “Maṇḍabya bhāsiṃ yamabhāsaneyyaṃ, taṃ khamyataṃ puttakahetu majja;
analyzed: maṇḍabya bhāsim yamabhāsaneyyam tam puttaka hetu majja
translated: “O Maṇḍabya, I have spoken words that ought not to be spoken; forgive me for the sake of our son.

original: Puttapemā na idha paratthi kiñci, so no ayaṃ jīvati yaññadatto”ti.
analyzed: putta pemā naḥ idha paratthi kiñci saḥ naḥ ayam jīvati yañña datto ti
translated: There is nothing that we love so well as our son; he is our life, he is Yaññadatta.”

original: Tattha taṃ khamyatanti taṃ khamayatu. Puttakahetu majjāti taṃ mama bhāsitaṃ ajja
analyzed: tattha tam tam khamayatu puttaka hetu majja ati tam mama bhāsitam ajja
translated: Herein, forgive me means pardon me. For the sake of our son means pardon me for what I have said to-day

original: imassa puttassa hetu khamayatu. So no ayanti yassa puttassa kāraṇā mayā etaṃ bhāsitaṃ,
analyzed: imassa puttassa hetu khamayatu saḥ naḥ yassa puttassa kāraṇā mayā etam bhāsitam
translated: on account of our son. He is our life means the son for whose sake I have spoken thus;

original: so no putto jīvati, imassa jīvitalābhabhāvena me khama sāmi, ajjato paṭṭhāya tava
analyzed: saḥ no puttaḥ jīvati imassa jīvita lābha bhāvena me khama sāmi ajjataḥ paṭṭhāya tava
translated: he is our life. By reason of the fact that he has obtained life, pardon me, my lord. From this day forth I will be

original: vasavattinī bhavissāmīti.
analyzed: vasa vattinī bhavissāmi iti
translated: your slave.”

original: Atha naṃ maṇḍabyo “uṭṭhehi bhadde, khamāmi te, ito pana paṭṭhāya mā pharusacittā
analyzed: atha nam maṇḍabyaḥ uṭṭhehi bhadde khamāmi te itas pana paṭṭhāya mā pharusa cittā
translated: Then Maṇḍabya said to her, “Rise up, my dear; I pardon you. But from this day forth do not be angry with me.

original: ahosi, ahampi te appiyaṃ na karissāmī”ti āha. Bodhisatto maṇḍabyaṃ āha – “āvuso,
analyzed: ahosi aham pi te appiyam na karissāmi iti āha bodhisattaḥ maṇḍabyam āha āvuso
translated: The Bodhisatta said to Maṇḍabyā, “Friend,

original: tayā dussaṅgharaṃ dhanaṃ saṅgharitvā kammañca phalañca asaddahitvā dānaṃ dadantena
analyzed: tayā dussaṅgharam dhanam saṅgharitvā kammañca phalañca a saddahitvā dānam dadantena
translated: you have gathered wealth with difficulty, and have given gifts without faith in the fruit of action.🔽This is not right. Henceforth give gifts with faith.”

original: ayuttaṃ kataṃ, ito paṭṭhāya dānaṃ saddahitvā dehī”ti. So “sādhū”ti sampaṭicchitvā
analyzed: ayuttam katam itas paṭṭhāya dānam saddahitvā dehi iti saḥ sādhu iti sampaṭicchitvā
translated: “Very well,” he replied, and agreed to do so.

original: bodhisattaṃ āha – “bhante, tayā amhākaṃ dakkhiṇeyyabhāve ṭhatvā anabhiratena brahmacariyaṃ
analyzed: bodhisattam āha bhante tayā amhākam dakkhiṇeyya bhāve ṭhatvā an abhiratena brahmacariyam
translated: Then he said to the Bodhisatta, “Reverend Sir, you have lived the holy life dissatisfied with the position of one who is worthy of offerings in our eyes.

original: carantena ayuttaṃ kataṃ, ito paṭṭhāya idāni yathā tayi katakārā mahapphalā honti,
analyzed: carantena ayuttam katam itas paṭṭhāya idāni yathā tayi kata kārāḥ mahapphalāḥ honti
translated: This is not right. Henceforth, in order that the service rendered to you may bear fruit,

original: evaṃ cittaṃ pasādetvā suddhacitto abhirato hutvā brahmacariyaṃ carāhī”ti. Te mahāsattaṃ
analyzed: evam cittam pasādetvā suddha cittaḥ abhirataḥ hutvā brahmacariyam carāhi iti te mahāsattam
translated: make your mind serene, and live the holy life with a pure heart and a contented mind.”🔽They saluted the Great Being and departed.

original: vanditvā uṭṭhāya agamaṃsu. Tato paṭṭhāya bhariyā sāmike sasnehā ahosi, maṇḍabyo pasannacitto
analyzed: vanditvā uṭṭhāya agamaṃsu tatas paṭṭhāya bhariyā sāmike sa snehā ahosi maṇḍabyaḥ pasanna citto
translated: From that time forth Maṇḍabyā was kind to her husband, and Maṇḍabyā was serene of heart.

original: saddhāya dānaṃ adāsi. Bodhisatto anabhiratiṃ vinodetvā jhānābhiññaṃ uppādetvā brahmalokaparāyaṇo ahosi.
analyzed: saddhāya dānam adāsi bodhisattaḥ anabhiratim vinodetvā jhāna abhiññam uppādetvā brahma loka parāyaṇaḥ ahosi
translated: and gave the gift in faith. The Bodhisatta, having dispelled his discontent, produced the meditations and the super-knowledges, and passed on to the Brahma-world.

original: Satthā imaṃ dhammadesanaṃ āharitvā saccāni pakāsetvā jātakaṃ samodhānesi, saccapariyosāne
analyzed: satthā imam dhamma desanam āharitvā saccāni pakāsetvā jātakam samodhānesi sacca pariyosāne
translated: When the Master had related this story, he made the Truths clear, and identified the Birth:

original: ukkaṇṭhito bhikkhu sotāpattiphale patiṭṭhahi. Tadā maṇḍabyo ānando ahosi, bhariyā
analyzed: ukkaṇṭhitaḥ bhikkhu sotāpatti phale patiṭṭhahi tadā maṇḍabyaḥ ānandaḥ ahosi bhariyā

original: “Suṇoma dhammaṃ asataṃ satañca, na cāpi dhammaṃ asataṃ rocayāma;
analyzed: suṇoma dhammam asatam satam ca na ca api dhammam asatam rocayāma
translated: “We listen to the Dhamma, whether good or bad, but we do not approve of the Dhamma that is bad.

original: Hitvā asante na jahāma sante, tasmā hi amhaṃ daharā na mīyare.
analyzed: hitvā asante na jahāma sante tasmai hi amham daharāḥ na mīyare
translated: We abandon the bad and follow the good, therefore the young people in our family do not die.

original: “Pubbeva dānā sumanā bhavāma, dadampi ve attamanā bhavāma;
analyzed: pubbā iva dānā su manāḥ bhavāma dadam pi ve atta manāḥ bhavāma
translated: “Before we give, we are glad; while we give, we are glad; after we have given, we are glad.

original: Datvāpi ve nānutappāma pacchā, tasmā hi amhaṃ daharā na mīyare.
analyzed: da tvā api na anutappāma pacchā tasmai hi amham daharāḥ na mīyare
translated: Therefore the young people in our family do not die.

original: “Samaṇe mayaṃ brāhmaṇe addhike ca, vanibbake yācanake dalidde;
analyzed: samaṇe mayam brāhmaṇe addhike ca vanibbake yācanake dalidde
translated: “We satisfy with food and drink ascetics, Brahmans, and those who are in want, beggars, and the poor.

original: Annena pānena abhitappayāma, tasmā hi amhaṃ daharā na mīyare.
analyzed: annena pānena abhitappayāma tasmai hi amham daharāḥ na mīyare
translated: Therefore the young people in our family do not die.

original: “Mayañca bhariyaṃ nātikkamāma, amhe ca bhariyā nātikkamanti;
analyzed: mayam ca bhariyam na atikkamāma amhe ca bhariyāḥ na atikkamanti
translated: “We do not transgress against our wives, nor do our wives transgress against us.

original: Aññatra tāhi brahmacariyaṃ carāma, tasmā hi amhaṃ daharā na mīyare.
analyzed: aññatra brahmacariyam carāma tasmai hi amham daharāḥ na mīyare
translated: We live the holy life without those things, therefore our young ones do not die.

original: “Pāṇātipātā viramāma sabbe, loke adinnaṃ parivajjayāma;
analyzed: pāṇa atipātāḥ viramāma sabbe loke adinnam parivajjayāma
translated: We all abstain from killing living beings, in the world we avoid what is not given,

original: Amajjapā nopi musā bhaṇāma, tasmā hi amhaṃ daharā na mīyare.
analyzed: a majja pāḥ musā bhaṇāma tasmai hi amham daharāḥ na mīyare
translated: We do not drink liquor or speak falsely, therefore our young ones do not die.

original: “Etāsu ve jāyare suttamāsu, medhāvino honti pahūtapaññā;
analyzed: etāsu ve suttamāsu medhāvinaḥ honti pahūta paññā
translated: In these best of women are born sons, they are wise, and have abundant wisdom,

original: Bahussutā vedaguno ca honti, tasmā hi amhaṃ daharā na mīyare.
analyzed: bahussutāḥ ca honti tasmai hi amham daharāḥ na mīyare
translated: They are learned, and become Brahmins, therefore our young ones do not die.🔽Our mothers, fathers, sisters, brothers,

original: “Mātā pitā ca bhaginī bhātaro ca, puttā ca dārā ca mayañca sabbe;
analyzed: mātā pitā ca bhaginī bhātaro ca puttā ca dārā ca mayam ca sabbe
translated: Sons, wives, and all of us,

original: Dhammaṃ carāma paralokahetu, tasmā hi amhaṃ daharā na mīyare.
analyzed: dhammam carāma para loka hetu tasmai hi amham daharāḥ na mīyare
translated: We live righteously for the sake of the next world, therefore our young ones do not die.🔽Our slaves, slave-women, servants,

original: “Dāsā ca dāsyo anujīvino ca, paricārakā kammakarā ca sabbe;
analyzed: dāsā ca dāsyaḥ anujīvino ca paricārakā kammakarā ca sabbe
translated: Attendants, and all our workers,

original: Dhammaṃ caranti paralokahetu, tasmā hi amhaṃ daharā na mīyare”ti. –
analyzed: dhammam caranti para loka hetu tasmai hi amham daharāḥ
translated: They live righteously for the sake of the next world, therefore our young ones do not die.”

original: Imā gāthā āha.
analyzed: imāḥ gāthāḥ āha
translated: These were the verses she spoke.

original: Tattha dhammaṃ carāmāti dasakusalakammapathadhammaṃ carāma, attano jīvitahetu antamaso
analyzed: tattha dhammam carāma ati dasa kusala kammapatha dhammam carāma attanaḥ jīvita hetu antamaso
translated: Herein, we live righteously means we live righteously in the Dhamma of the ten wholesome courses of action, for the sake of our own lives, at least

original: kunthakipillikampi jīvitā na voropema, parabhaṇḍaṃ lobhacittena na olokemāti sabbaṃ🔽vitthāretabbaṃ. Musāvādo cettha musāvādissa akaraṇapāpaṃ nāma natthīti ussannavasena
analyzed: kuntha kipillikam pi jīvitā na voropema parabhaṇḍam lobha cittena na olokema ati sabbam  vitthāretabbam musāvādaḥ ca ittha musāvādissa akaraṇa pāpam nāma natthi iti ussanna vasena
translated: We do not deprive even a gnat or an ant of life, nor do we look at another’s goods with a covetous mind. All this should be expanded. As to false speech, there is no such thing as a sin of omission in the case of one who is disposed to lie. It is mentioned again

original: puna vutto. Te kira hasādhippāyenapi musā na bhaṇanti. Pāpānīti sabbāni nirayagāmikammāni.
analyzed: puna vuttaḥ te kira hasa adhippāyena api musā na bhaṇanti pāpāni iti sabbāni niraya gāmi kammāni
translated: because of its prevalence. They do not tell a lie even with the intention of joking. “Evil deeds” : all the deeds that lead to hell.

original: Anariyanti ariyagarahitaṃ sabbaṃ asundaraṃ aparisuddhaṃ kammaṃ parivajjayāma. Tasmā🔽hi amhanti ettha hi-kāro nipātamatto, tena kāraṇena amhākaṃ daharā na mīyanti, antarā
analyzed: anariyanti ariyaga rahitam sabbam asundaram a parisuddham kammam parivajjayāma tasmai  hi ettha hikāraḥ nipāta mattaḥ tena kāraṇena amhākam daharāḥ na antarā
translated: “Unedifying” : we avoid all unwholesome, impure deeds that are censured by the noble ones. Therefore

original: akālamaraṇaṃ nāma no natthīti attho. “Tasmā amha”ntipi pāṭho. Suṇomāti mayaṃ kiriyavādānaṃ🔽sappurisānaṃ kusaladīpanampi asappurisānaṃ akusaladīpanampi dhammaṃ suṇoma, so pana
analyzed: akāla maraṇam nāma no natthi iti attho tasmā suṇoma ati mayam kiriya vādānam  sappurisānam kusala dīpanam pi a sappurisānam a kusala dīpanam pi dhammam suṇoma so pana
translated: “we” : here the word “hi” is merely a particle. For this reason our young do not die, and we have no untimely death.

original: no sutamattakova hoti, taṃ na rocayāma. Tehi pana no saddhiṃ viggaho vā vivādo vā
analyzed: no suta mattakaḥ iva hoti tam na rocayāma tehi pana no saddhim viggahaḥ vā vivādaḥ vā
translated: “Therefore we” is another reading. “We listen” : we listen to the Dhamma that reveals the wholesome in the case of good people and the unwholesome in the case of bad people. But that is merely hearsay for us; we do not approve of it. We do not quarrel or dispute with them.

original: mā hotūti dhammaṃ suṇāma, sutvāpi hitvā asante sante vattāma, ekampi khaṇaṃ na jahāma
analyzed: mā hotu uti dhammam suṇāma sutvā api hitvā a sante sante vattāma ekam pi khaṇam na jahāma
translated: We listen to the Dhamma, thinking: ‘May it not be.’ Having listened, we practice in accordance with the Dhamma. We do not abandon the Dhamma even for a moment.

original: sante, pāpamitte pahāya kalyāṇamittasevinova homāti.🔽Samaṇe mayaṃ brāhmaṇeti mayaṃ samitapāpe bāhitapāpe paccekabuddhasamaṇabrāhmaṇepi
analyzed: sante pāpa mitte pahāya kalyāṇa mitta sevinaḥ uva homa ati  samaṇe mayam brāhmaṇa iti mayam samita pāpe bāhita pāpe paccekabuddha samaṇa brāhmaṇe pi
translated: We abandon bad friends and we serve good friends.

original: avasesadhammikasamaṇabrāhmaṇepi addhikayācake sesajanepi annapānena abhitappemāti
analyzed: avasesa dhammika samaṇa brāhmaṇe pi addhika yācake sesa jane pi anna pānena abhitappema ati
translated: We are ascetics, we are brahmans. We are ascetics in the sense of having extinguished evil, in the sense of having expelled evil. We are brahmans in the sense of being paccekabuddhas, in the sense of being other ascetics and brahmans who possess the Dhamma.🔽We satisfy with food and drink those ascetics and brahmans who are in need of them, as well as other people who are in need.

original: attho. Pāḷiyaṃ pana ayaṃ gāthā “pubbeva dānā”ti gāthāya pacchato āgatā. Nātikkamāmāti🔽attano bhariyaṃ atikkamitvā bahi aññaṃ micchācāraṃ na karoma. Aññatra tāhīti tā attano
analyzed: attho pāḷiyam pana ayam gāthā pubbā iva dānā ti gāthāya pacchatas āgatāḥ na atikkamāma ati  attanaḥ bhariyam atikkamitvā bahi aññam micchācāram na karoma aññatra tāhi iti tāḥ attanaḥ
translated: This is the meaning. But this verse in the text comes after the verse beginning, ‘Before the gift is given.’🔽We do not commit adultery with another man’s wife, that is, we do not commit adultery outside with anyone other than our own wives.

original: bhariyā ṭhapetvā sesaitthīsu brahmacariyaṃ carāma, amhākaṃ bhariyāpi sesapurisesu
analyzed: bhariyā ṭhapetvā sesa etthīsu brahmacariyam carāma amhākam bhariyā api sesa purisesu
translated: Except with our own wives, we practice celibacy with other women. Our wives also practice celibacy with other men.

original: evameva vattanti. Jāyareti jāyanti. Suttamāsūti susīlāsu uttamitthīsu. Idaṃ vuttaṃ
analyzed: evam eva vattanti jāyanti suttamāsu iti su sīlāsu uttamitthīsu idam vuttam
translated: In the same way. They give birth. To children. To women who are well-disciplined, to excellent women. This is what is said.

original: hoti – ye etāsu sampannasīlāsu uttamitthīsu amhākaṃ puttā jāyanti, te medhāvinoti
analyzed: hoti ye etāsu sampanna sīlāsu utta mitthīsu amhākam puttāḥ jāyanti te medhāvinaḥ ti
translated: “Our sons are born to such women who are perfect in virtue and are the best of women, and they are wise,

original: evaṃpakārā honti, kuto tesaṃ antarā maraṇaṃ, tasmāpi amhākaṃ kule daharā na marantīti.
analyzed: evaṃpakārāḥ honti kutas tesam antarā maraṇam tasmā api amhākam kule daharāḥ na maranti iti
translated: and they are like this, so how can they die in the middle of their lives? That is why no young people die in our family.”

original: Dhammaṃ carāmāti paralokatthāya tividhasucaritadhammaṃ carāma. Dāsyoti dāsiyo.
analyzed: dhammam carāma ati para lokatthāya tividha su carita dhammam carāma dāsyo ti dāsiyo
translated: “We live by Dhamma”: we live by the Dhamma of the three kinds of good conduct for the sake of the next world. “Maid”: a slave girl.

original: Avasāne –
analyzed: avasāne
translated: At the end:🔽“Dhamma indeed protects one who lives by Dhamma,

original: “Dhammo have rakkhati dhammacāriṃ, dhammo suciṇṇo sukhamāvahati;
analyzed: dhammaḥ have rakkhati dhamma cārim dhammaḥ su ciṇṇaḥ sukham āvahati
translated: Dhamma, when well observed, brings happiness.

original: Esānisaṃso dhamme suciṇṇe, na duggatiṃ gacchati dhammacārī.
analyzed: esa anisaṃsaḥ dhamme su ciṇṇe na duggatim gacchati dhamma cārī
translated: This is the advantage in observing Dhamma: the one who lives by Dhamma does not go to a bad destination.

original: “Dhammo have rakkhati dhammacāriṃ, chattaṃ mahantaṃ viya vassakāle;
analyzed: dhammaḥ have rakkhati dhamma cārim chattam mahantam viya vassa kāle
translated: “Dhamma indeed protects one who lives by Dhamma, like a great umbrella in the rainy season;

original: Dhammena gutto mama dhammapālo, aññassa aṭṭhīni sukhī kumāro”ti. –
analyzed: dhammena guttaḥ mama dhamma pālaḥ aññassa sukhī kumāro ti
translated: Protected by Dhamma, my son Dhammapala, the other boy is happy with his bones.”

original: Imāhi dvīhi gāthāhi dhammacārīnaṃ guṇaṃ kathesi.
analyzed: imāhi dvīhi gāthāhi dhammacārīnam guṇam kathesi
translated: With these two verses he told of the virtue of those who live by Dhamma.

original: Tattha rakkhatīti dhammo nāmeso rakkhito attano rakkhitaṃ paṭirakkhati. Sukhamāvahatīti
analyzed: tattha rakkhati iti dhammaḥ nāma esaḥ rakkhitaḥ attanaḥ rakkhitam paṭirakkhati sukham āvahati iti
translated: Herein, “protects” : this Dhamma, which is called “protection,” protects one who is protected by it.

original: devamanussasukhañceva nibbānasukhañca āvahati. Na duggatinti nirayādibhedaṃ duggatiṃ
analyzed: deva manussa sukham ca iva nibbāna sukham ca āvahati na duggatim ti niraya ādi bhedam duggatim
translated: and it brings the happiness of gods and men and the happiness of Nibbana. ‘You will not go to a bad destination’ means that you will not go to a bad destination such as hell.

original: na gacchati. Evaṃ brāhmaṇa, mayaṃ dhammaṃ rakkhāma, dhammopi amhe rakkhatīti dasseti.
analyzed: na gacchati evam brāhmaṇa mayam dhammam rakkhāma dhammaḥ api amhe rakkhati iti dasseti
translated: Thus he shows that he himself protects the Dhamma and that the Dhamma protects him.

original: Dhammena guttoti mahāchattasadisena attanā gopitadhammena gutto. Aññassa aṭṭhīnīti
analyzed: dhammena gutto ti mahā chatta sadisena attanā gopita dhammena gutto aññassa aṭṭhīni iti
translated: ‘Protected by the Dhamma’ means protected by the Dhamma which he himself protects, which is like a great parasol. ‘The bones of another’ means

original: tayā ānītāni aṭṭhīni aññassa eḷakassa vā sunakhassa vā aṭṭhīni bhavissanti, chaḍḍethetāni,
analyzed: tayā ānītāni aṭṭhīni aññassa eḷakassa vā sunakhassa vā aṭṭhīni bhavissanti chaḍḍetha itāni
translated: the bones you have brought will be the bones of a goat or a dog. Throw them away,

original: mama putto sukhī kumāroti.
analyzed: mama putto sukhī kumāro ti
translated: my son is well, he is a young man.’

original: Taṃ sutvā ācariyo “mayhaṃ āgamanaṃ suāgamanaṃ, saphalaṃ, no nipphala”nti sañjātasomanasso🔽dhammapālassa pitaraṃ khamāpetvā “mayā āgacchantena tumhākaṃ vīmaṃsanatthāya imāni
analyzed: tam sutvā ācariyaḥ mayham āgamanam su āgamanam sa phalam no nipphalanti sañjāta somanasso  dhammapālassa pitaram khamāpetvā mayā āgacchantena tumhākam vīmaṃsana tthāya imāni
translated: Hearing this, the teacher was delighted, thinking, ‘My coming was well-founded, it was not in vain.’🔽He asked the father’s forgiveness, saying, ‘When I came I brought these goat’s bones to test you.

original: eḷakaaṭṭhīni ābhatāni, putto te arogoyeva, tumhākaṃ rakkhitadhammaṃ mayhampi dethā”ti
analyzed: eḷaka aṭṭhīni ābhatāni putto te tumhākam rakkhita dhammam mayham pi detha ati
translated: Your son is well. Give me the Dhamma that you have protected.’

original: paṇṇe likhitvā katipāhaṃ tattha vasitvā takkasilaṃ gantvā dhammapālaṃ sabbasippāni
analyzed: paṇṇe likhitvā katipāham tattha vasitvā takkasilam gantvā dhammapālam sabba sippāni
translated: After writing it on a leaf, he remained there for several days, and then went to Takkasilā, and had Dhammapāla trained in all the arts,

original: sikkhāpetvā mahantena parivārena pesesi.
analyzed: sikkhāpetvā mahantena parivārena pesesi
translated: and sent him back with a large retinue.

original: Satthā suddhodanamahārājassa imaṃ dhammadesanaṃ āharitvā saccāni pakāsetvā jātakaṃ🔽samodhānesi, saccapariyosāne rājā anāgāmiphale patiṭṭhahi. Tadā mātāpitaro mahārājakulāni
analyzed: satthā suddhodana mahārājassa imam dhamma desanam āharitvā saccāni pakāsetvā jātakaṃ  samodhānesi sacca pariyosāne rājā anāgāmi phale tadā mātā pitaraḥ mahā rājakulāni
translated: The Teacher, having related this religious discourse to the great king Suddhodana, and having revealed the Truths,

original: ahesuṃ, ācariyo sāriputto, parisā buddhaparisā, dhammapālakumāro pana ahameva ahosinti.
analyzed: ahesuṃ ācariyo sāriputto parisā buddha parisā dhammapāla kumāraḥ pana aham eva ahosinti
translated: joined the Birth-Story (to the present time), and said, “At that time the father and mother were the parents of the great king, the teacher was Sāriputta, the assembly was the assembly of the Buddha, and I myself was the young man Dhammapāla.”

original: Mahādhammapālajātakavaṇṇanā navamā.
analyzed: mahādhammapāla jātaka vaṇṇanā navamā
translated: The explanation of the Great Dhammapāla Birth-Story is finished.

original: [448] 10. Kukkuṭajātakavaṇṇanā🔽Nāsmase katapāpamhīti idaṃ satthā veḷuvane viharanto devadattassa vadhāya parisakkanaṃ
analyzed: na āsmase kata pāpamhi iti idam satthā veḷuvane viharantaḥ devadattassa vadhāya parisakkanam
translated: The Kukkuṭa Birth-Story🔽“We are guilty of the sin we have committed.” The Teacher told this tale while dwelling in the Bamboo Grove, in reference to the plotting of Devadatta to kill the Buddha.

original: ārabbha kathesi. Dhammasabhāyañhi bhikkhū devadattassa aguṇakathaṃ samuṭṭhāpesuṃ
analyzed: ārabbha kathesi dhamma sabhāyan hi bhikkhū devadattassa aguṇa katham samuṭṭhāpesuṃ
translated: In the Hall of Truth the monks began a discussion of Devadatta’s evil nature,

original: “āvuso, devadatto dhanuggahādipayojanena dasabalassa vadhatthameva upāyaṃ karotī”ti.
analyzed: āvuso devadattaḥ dhanuggaha ādi payojanena dasabalassa vadha ttham eva upāyam karoti iti
translated: saying, “Devadatta, for the sake of the bowman’s fee, is plotting to kill the Buddha.”

original: Satthā āgantvā “kāya nuttha, bhikkhave, etarahi kathāya sannisinnā”ti pucchitvā “imāya
analyzed: satthā āgantvā kāya nuttha bhikkhave etarahi kathāya sannisinnā ati pucchitvā imāya
translated: The Teacher came in and asked, “Monks, what is it that you are sitting here now talking about?” When they told him,

original: nāmā”ti vutte “na, bhikkhave, idāneva, pubbepi esa mayhaṃ vadhāya parisakkiyevā”ti vatvā atītaṃ āhari.🔽Atīte kosambiyaṃ kosambako nāma rājā rajjaṃ kāresi. Tadā bodhisatto ekasmiṃ veḷuvane
analyzed: nāma ati vutte na bhikkhave idānā iva pubbe pi esa mayham vadhāya parisakkiyā iva ati vatvā atītam āhari  atīte kosambiyam kosambakaḥ nāma rājā rajjam kāresi tadā bodhisatto ekasmin veḷuvane
translated: he said, “Monks, this is not the first time he has conspired to kill me; in a previous state of existence also he conspired to kill me.” So saying, he related the following🔽Story of the Past:

original: kukkuṭayoniyaṃ nibbattitvā anekasatakukkuṭaparivāro araññe vasati, tassāvidūre eko🔽seno vasati. So upāyena ekekaṃ kukkuṭaṃ gahetvā khādanto ṭhapetvā bodhisattaṃ sese
analyzed: kukkuṭa yoniyam nibbattitvā aneka sata kukkuṭa parivāraḥ araññe vasati tassa avidūre ekaḥ  senaḥ vasati saḥ upāyena ekekam kukkuṭam gahetvā khādantaḥ ṭhapetvā bodhisattam sese
translated: In the dispensation of the Buddha Kassapa, it seems, he was born in the womb of a hen in a bamboo grove near Kosambī. He had a retinue of many hundreds of chickens, and lived in the forest. Not far from him lived a certain hawk.🔽This hawk, by a trick, caught one chicken after another and ate it, leaving the Bodhisatta alone. The Bodhisatta,

original: khādi, bodhisatto ekakova ahosi. So appamatto velāya gocaraṃ gahetvā veḷuvanaṃ pavisitvā🔽vasati. So seno taṃ gaṇhituṃ asakkonto “ekena naṃ upāyena upalāpetvā gaṇhissāmī”ti
analyzed: bodhisatto ekakaḥ iva ahosi saḥ appamattaḥ velāya gocaram gahetvā veḷuvanam pavisitvā  vasati saḥ senaḥ tam gaṇhitum a sakkontaḥ ekena nam upāyena upalāpetvā gaṇhissāmi iti
translated: alone by himself, lived a life of vigilance. At the proper time he would go out and get food, and then return to the bamboo grove and live there.

original: cintetvā tassāvidūre sākhāya nilīyitvā “samma kukkuṭarāja, tvaṃ mayhaṃ kasmā bhāyasi,
analyzed: cintetvā tassa avidūre sākhāya nilīyitvā samma kukkuṭa rāja tvam mayham kasmai bhāyasi
translated: The hawk, unable to catch him, thought to himself, “I will deceive him by some trick or other and then I will get him.” So he perched on a branch not far from the Bodhisatta and said, “My dear King of the Chickens, why are you afraid of me?

original: ahaṃ tayā saddhiṃ vissāsaṃ kattukāmo, asukasmiṃ nāma padese sampannagocaro, tattha
analyzed: aham tayā saddhim vissāsam kattu kāmo asukasmin nāma padese sampanna gocaraḥ tattha
translated: “I wish to make friends with you. In such and such a place there is an abundance of food. Let us go there,

original: ubhopi gocaraṃ gahetvā aññamaññaṃ piyasaṃvāsaṃ vasissāmā”ti āha. Atha naṃ bodhisatto
analyzed: ubho api gocaram gahetvā aññam aññam piya saṃvāsam vasissāma iti āha atha nam bodhisatto
translated: and we will both get food and live together in mutual affection.” The Bodhisatta replied,

analyzed: saḥ api tāḥ gāthāḥ vatvā senam āmantetvā sace imasmin ṭhāne vasissasi jānissāmi te kattabbanti tat jesi senaḥ tatas palāyitvā aññatra gataḥ  satthā imam dhamma desanam āharitvā evam bhikkhave devadatto pubbe pi mayham vadhāya

translated: The Teacher, surveying the world at dawn, saw that the householder had the capacity to attain the Fruit of Conversion. Therefore on the following day,

original: bhikkhusaṅghaparivuto sāvatthiyaṃ piṇḍāya caritvā katabhattakicco bhikkhū uyyojetvā
analyzed: bhikkhu saṅgha parivutaḥ sāvatthiyam piṇḍāya caritvā kata bhatta kiccaḥ bhikkhū uyyojetvā
translated: surrounded by the company of monks, he entered Sāvatthi for alms. When he had finished his meal, he dismissed the monks and

original: ānandattherena pacchāsamaṇena tassa gharadvāraṃ agamāsi. Satthu āgatabhāvaṃ kuṭumbikassa
analyzed: ānanda ttherena pacchā samaṇena tassa ghara dvāram agamāsi satthu āgata bhāvam kuṭumbikassa
translated: accompanied by the Elder Ānanda, went to the door of the house of the householder. The householder,

original: ārocesuṃ. Athassa gehajano āsanaṃ paññapetvā satthāraṃ nisīdāpetvā kuṭumbikaṃ pariggahetvā
analyzed: ārocesuṃ athassa geha janaḥ āsanam paññapetvā satthāram nisīdāpetvā kuṭumbikam pariggahetvā
translated: and told him. Then the people of the house prepared a seat and caused the Teacher to sit down, and taking the householder,

original: satthu santikaṃ ānesi. Taṃ vanditvā ekamantaṃ nisinnaṃ satthā karuṇāsītalena vacanena
analyzed: satthu santikam ānesi tam vanditvā ekamantam nisinnam satthā karuṇā sītalena vacanena
translated: they brought him into the presence of the Teacher. The householder paid obeisance to the Teacher, and sitting down at one side, the Teacher addressed him in words of sympathy,

original: āmantetvā “kiṃ, upāsaka, puttakaṃ anusocasī”ti pucchitvā “āma, bhante”ti vutte “upāsaka,
analyzed: āmantetvā kim upāsaka puttakam anusocasi iti pucchitvā āma bhante iti vutte upāsaka
translated: and asked him, “Lay disciple, do you grieve for your son?” “Yes, Reverend Sir.” “Lay disciple,” said the Teacher,

original: porāṇakapaṇḍitā putte kālakate sokasamappitā vicarantāpi paṇḍitānaṃ kathaṃ sutvā
analyzed: porāṇaka paṇḍitā putte kāla kate soka samappitā vicarantā api paṇḍitānam katham sutvā
translated: “even the wise men of old, though they wandered about overwhelmed with grief at the death of their sons, when they heard the words of the wise,

original: ‘alabbhanīyaṭṭhāna’nti tathato ñatvā appamattakampi sokaṃ na kariṃsū”ti vatvā tena
analyzed: a labbhanīya ṭṭhānan ti tathatas ñatvā appamattakam pi sokam na kariṃsu iti vatvā tena
translated: came to know that the place where they had been seeking was not to be found, and did not grieve even for a moment.” So saying, the Teacher related the following

original: yācito atītaṃ āhari.
analyzed: yācitaḥ atītam āhari
translated: Story of the Past:

original: Atīte bārāṇasiyaṃ brahmadatte rajjaṃ kārente ekassa mahāvibhavassa brāhmaṇassa putto
analyzed: atīte bārāṇasiyam brahmadatte rajjam kārente ekassa mahā vibhavassa brāhmaṇassa putto
translated: In the days when Brahmadatta was reigning in Benares, a certain Brahman of great wealth had a son.

original: pañcadasasoḷasavassakāle ekena byādhinā phuṭṭho kālaṃ katvā devaloke nibbatti. Brāhmaṇo
analyzed: pañcadasa soḷasa vassa kāle ekena byādhinā phuṭṭhaḥ kālam katvā deva loke nibbatti brāhmaṇaḥ
translated: When the latter was fifteen or sixteen years of age, he fell sick and died, and was reborn in the World of the Gods. The Brahman

original: tassa kālakiriyato paṭṭhāya susānaṃ gantvā chārikapuñjaṃ āvijjhanto paridevati, sabbakammante🔽pariccajitvā sokasamappito vicarati. Tadā devaputto anuvicaranto taṃ disvā “ekaṃ
analyzed: tassa kālakiriyataḥ paṭṭhāya susānam gantvā chārika puñjam āvijjhantaḥ paridevati sabba kammante  pariccajitvā soka samappitaḥ vicarati tadā devaputto anuvicarantaḥ tam disvā ekam
translated: From the time of his death, the brahmin went to the cemetery, dug up the ashes, and lamented. He gave up all his work,

original: upamaṃ katvā sokaṃ harissāmī”ti tassa susānaṃ gantvā paridevanakāle tasseva puttavaṇṇī
analyzed: upamam katvā sokam harissāmi iti tassa susānam gantvā paridevana kāle tassa iva putta vaṇṇī
translated: and wandered about overwhelmed with grief. At that time a god, wandering about, saw him, and thinking, “I will remove his grief by telling him a parable,”

original: hutvā sabbābharaṇapaṭimaṇḍito ekasmiṃ padese ṭhatvā ubho hatthe sīse ṭhapetvā mahāsaddena
analyzed: hutvā sabba ābharaṇa paṭimaṇḍitaḥ ekasmin padese ṭhatvā ubho hatthe sīse ṭhapetvā mahā saddena
translated: went to the cemetery and stood in one place, adorned with all ornaments,

original: paridevi. Brāhmaṇo saddaṃ sutvā taṃ oloketvā puttapemaṃ paṭilabhitvā tassa santike
analyzed: paridevi brāhmaṇaḥ saddam sutvā tam oloketvā putta pemam paṭilabhitvā tassa santike
translated: after the death of his son, and placing both hands on his head, lamented with a loud voice. The brahmin, hearing the sound, looked at him, and obtaining affection for his son,

original: ṭhatvā “tāta māṇava, imasmiṃ susānamajjhe kasmā paridevasī”ti pucchanto paṭhamaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: tāta māṇava imasmin susāna majjhe kasmā paridevasi iti pucchantaḥ paṭhamam gātham āha
translated: stood near him and, asking, “Dear student, why do you lament in the middle of this cemetery?” he spoke the first verse:

original: “Alaṅkato maṭṭhakuṇḍalī, māladhārī haricandanussado;
analyzed: alaṅkataḥ maṭṭha kuṇḍalī māla dhārī hari canda nussadaḥ
translated: “Adorned, with earrings, garlands, and yellow sandalwood paste,

original: Bāhā paggayha kandasi, vanamajjhe kiṃ dukkhito tuva”nti.
analyzed: bāhā paggayha kandasi vana majjhe kim dukkhitaḥ tuvanti
translated: Raising your arms, you lament. Why are you so sorrowful in the middle of the forest?”

original: Tattha alaṅkatoti nānābharaṇavibhūsito. Maṭṭhakuṇḍalīti karaṇapariniṭṭhitehi maṭṭhehi🔽kuṇḍalehi samannāgato. Māladhārīti vicitrakusumamāladharo. Haricandanussadoti suvaṇṇavaṇṇena🔽candanena anulitto. Vanamajjheti susānamajjhe. Kiṃ dukkhito tuvanti kiṃkāraṇā dukkhito
analyzed: tattha alaṅkataḥ ti nānā ābharaṇa vibhūsitaḥ maṭṭha kuṇḍalī iti karaṇa pariniṭṭhitehi maṭṭhehi  kuṇḍalehi samannāgataḥ māladhārī iti vicitra kusuma māla dharaḥ hari canda nussadaḥ ti suvaṇṇa vaṇṇena  candanena anulittaḥ vana majjhe ti susāna majjhe kim dukkhitaḥ tuvanti kiṃkāraṇā dukkhitaḥ
translated: “Adorned” means adorned with various ornaments. “With earrings” means having earrings made of gold. “Wearing garlands” means wearing garlands of various flowers. “Anointed with red sandalwood” means anointed with red sandalwood paste. “In the middle of the forest” means in the middle of a charnel ground. “Why are you suffering?” means for what reason are you suffering?

original: tvaṃ, ācikkha, ahaṃ te yaṃ icchasi, taṃ dassāmīti āha.
analyzed: tvam ācikkha aham te yam icchasi tam dassāmi iti āha
translated: “Adorned” means adorned with various ornaments. “Wearing earrings” means wearing earrings made of gold. “Wearing a garland” means wearing a garland of various flowers. “Anointed with yellow sandalwood” means anointed with yellow sandalwood paste. “In the middle of the forest” means in the middle of a charnel ground. “Why are you suffering?” means for what reason are you suffering? Tell me, I will give you whatever you want.

original: Athassa kathento māṇavo dutiyaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: athassa kathentaḥ māṇavaḥ dutiyam gātham āha
translated: Then the young man, telling him, spoke the second verse:

original: “Sovaṇṇamayo pabhassaro, uppanno rathapañjaro mama;
analyzed: sovaṇṇa mayaḥ pabhassaraḥ uppannaḥ ratha pañjaraḥ mama
translated: “My chariot-cage has appeared, golden and shining,

original: Tassa cakkayugaṃ na vindāmi, tena dukkhena jahāmi jīvita”nti.
analyzed: tassa cakka yugam na vindāmi tena dukkhena jahāmi jīvitan ti
translated: But I cannot find a pair of wheels, so with this sorrow I give up my life.”

original: Brāhmaṇo sampaṭicchanto tatiyaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: brāhmaṇaḥ tatiyam gātham āha
translated: The brahmin, agreeing, spoke the third verse:

original: “Sovaṇṇamayaṃ maṇīmayaṃ, lohamayaṃ atha rūpiyāmayaṃ;
analyzed: sovaṇṇa mayam maṇī mayam loha mayam atha rūpiyā mayam
translated: “Golden, jeweled, iron, or silver,

original: Pāvada rathaṃ karissāmi te, cakkayugaṃ paṭipādayāmi ta”nti.
analyzed: pāvada ratham karissāmi te cakka yugam paṭipādayāmi tanti
translated: I will make you a chariot, I will provide a pair of wheels for you.”

original: Tattha pāvadāti yādisena te attho yādisaṃ rocesi, tādisaṃ vada, ahaṃ te ratha karissāmi. Paṭipādayāmi tanti taṃ pañjarānurūpaṃ cakkayugaṃ adhigacchāpemi.
analyzed: tattha pāvadāti yādisena te atthaḥ yādisam rocesi tādisam vada aham te ratha karissāmi paṭipādayāmi tanti tam pañjara anurūpam cakka yugam adhigaccha apemi
translated: “Now tell me what you want, what you desire, and I will make you a chariot. I will provide you with a pair of wheels suitable for the cage.”

original: Taṃ sutvā māṇavena kathitāya gāthāya paṭhamapādaṃ satthā abhisambuddho hutvā kathesi, sesaṃ māṇavo.
analyzed: tam sutvā māṇavena kathitāya gāthāya paṭhama pādam satthā abhisambuddhaḥ hutvā kathesi sesam māṇavaḥ
translated: When the youth heard this, he repeated the first line of the verse which the Teacher had spoken, and the remainder of the verse the youth himself spoke.

original: “So māṇavo tassa pāvadi, candasūriyā ubhayettha bhātaro;
analyzed: saḥ māṇavaḥ tassa canda sūriyāḥ ubhayā ittha bhātaraḥ
translated: “The youth spoke to the Brahman, ‘The sun and moon are brothers, both of them in the sky.

original: Sovaṇṇamayo ratho mama, tena cakkayugena sobhatī”ti.
analyzed: sovaṇṇa mayaḥ rathaḥ mama tena cakka yugena sobhati iti
translated: My chariot is made of gold, and with a pair of wheels it shines.’

original: Brāhmaṇo tadanantaraṃ āha –
analyzed: brāhmaṇaḥ tad anantaram āha
translated: ” Then the Brahman spoke the second line of the verse,

original: “Bālo kho tvaṃsi māṇava, yo tvaṃ patthayasi apatthiyaṃ;
analyzed: bālo kho tvam māṇava yaḥ tvam patthayasi a patthiyam
translated: “‘You are a fool, O youth, in that you seek what cannot be sought.

original: Maññāmi tuvaṃ marissasi, na hi tvaṃ lacchasi candasūriye”ti. –
analyzed: maññāmi tuvam marissasi na hi tvam lacchasi canda sūriya iti
translated: I think you will die, for you will not obtain the sun and moon.’

original: Brāhmaṇena vuttagāthāya apatthiyanti apatthetabbaṃ.
analyzed: brāhmaṇena vutta gāthāya apatthiyanti apatthetabbam
translated: ” In the line spoken by the Brahman, “cannot be sought” means “cannot be obtained.”

original: Tato māṇavo āha –
analyzed: tatas māṇavaḥ āha
translated: Then the youth spoke the third line of the verse,

original: “Gamanāgamanampi dissati, vaṇṇadhātu ubhayettha vīthiyo;
analyzed: gamana āgamanam pi dissati vaṇṇa dhātu ubhayā ittha vīthiyaḥ
translated: “‘The going and coming are seen, and the colors are seen in both.

original: Peto pana neva dissati, ko nu kho kandataṃ bālyataro”ti.
analyzed: peto pana na iva dissati kaḥ nu kho kandatam bālyataroti
translated: But the dead man is not seen; who is more foolish than I?’”

original: Māṇavena vuttagāthāya gamanāgamananti uggamanañca atthagamanañca. Vaṇṇoyeva vaṇṇadhātu.
analyzed: māṇavena vutta gāthāya gamana āgamananti uggamanam ca attha gamanam vaṇṇo yā iva vaṇṇa dhātu
translated: In the verse spoken by the student, “coming and going” is rising and setting. “ Color” is the color element.

original: Ubhayettha vīthiyoti ettha ākāse “ayaṃ candassa vīthi, ayaṃ sūriyassa vīthī”ti evaṃ
analyzed: ubhayā ittha vīthiyā iti ettha ākāse ayam candassa vīthi ayam sūriyassa vīthi iti evam
translated: “ Path” in both cases: in the sky, “This is the moon’s path, this is the sun’s path” are known thus.

original: ubhayagamanāgamanabhūmiyopi paññāyanti. Peto panāti paralokaṃ gatasatto pana na dissateva.
analyzed: ubhaya gamana āgamana bhūmiyaḥ pi paññāyanti peto pana ati para lokam gata satto pana na dissatā iva
translated: But the departed one: a being who has gone to the other world is not seen at all.

original: Ko nu khoti evaṃ sante amhākaṃ dvinnaṃ kandantānaṃ ko nu kho bālyataroti.
analyzed: kaḥ nu khalu iti evam sante amhākam dvinnam kandantānam kaḥ nu khalu bālyataro ti
translated: Who is more foolish: in that case, who is more foolish of us two who are crying?

original: Evaṃ māṇave kathente brāhmaṇo sallakkhetvā gāthamāha –
analyzed: evam māṇave kathente brāhmaṇaḥ sallakkhetvā gātham āha
translated: When the student was speaking thus, the brahmin, after reflecting, spoke the verse:

original: “Saccaṃ kho vadesi māṇava, ahameva kandataṃ bālyataro;
analyzed: saccam kho vadesi māṇava aham eva kandatam bālyataraḥ
translated: “You speak the truth, student; I am more foolish of the two who are crying;

original: Candaṃ viya dārako rudaṃ, petaṃ kālakatābhipatthaye”ti.
analyzed: candam viya dārakaḥ rudam kālakata abhipatthaya iti
translated: Like a child crying for the moon, I long for the departed one who is dead.”

original: Tattha candaṃ viya dārakoti yathā daharo gāmadārako “candaṃ dethā”ti candassatthāya rodeyya, evaṃ ahampi petaṃ kālakataṃ abhipatthemīti.
analyzed: tattha candam viya dārako iti yathā daharaḥ gāma dārako candam detha ati candassa atthāya rodeyya evam aham pi petam kālakatam abhipatthemi iti
translated: There, like a child: just as a young village child would cry, “Give me the moon,” for the sake of the moon, so also I long for the departed one who is dead.

original: Iti brāhmaṇo māṇavassa kathāya nissoko hutvā tassa thutiṃ karonto sesagāthā abhāsi –
analyzed: iti brāhmaṇaḥ māṇavassa kathāya nissokaḥ hutvā tassa thutim karontaḥ sesa gāthāḥ abhāsi
translated: Thus the Brahman, being consoled by the youth’s words, praised him, and spoke the remaining stanzas,

original: “Ādittaṃ vata maṃ santaṃ, ghatasittaṃva pāvakaṃ;
analyzed: ādittam vata mam santam pāvakam
translated: “As if I were afire, as if I were anointed with oil,

original: Vārinā viya osiñcaṃ, sabbaṃ nibbāpaye daraṃ.
analyzed: vārinā viya osiñcam sabbam nibbāpaye daram
translated: As if I were sprinkled with water, I have quenched all my grief.

original: “Abbahī vata me sallaṃ, yamāsi hadayassitaṃ;
analyzed: vata me sallam yam asi hadayassitam
translated: “The dart that was in my heart, that was piercing my heart,

original: Yo me sokaparetassa, puttasokaṃ apānudi.
analyzed: yaḥ me soka paretassa putta sokam apānudi
translated: That grief of mine, that was so great, you have removed.

original: “Sohaṃ abbūḷhasallosmi, vītasoko anāvilo;
analyzed: saḥ aham vīta sokaḥ anāvilaḥ
translated: “I have drawn out the dart, I am free from grief, I am clear,

original: Na socāmi na rodāmi, tava sutvāna māṇavā”ti.
analyzed: na socāmi na rodāmi tava sutvāna māṇavāti
translated: I do not grieve, I do not weep, having heard your words, young man.”

original: Atha naṃ māṇavo “brāhmaṇa, yassatthāya tvaṃ rodasi, ahaṃ te putto, ahaṃ devaloke
analyzed: atha nam māṇavaḥ brāhmaṇa yad satthāya tvam rodasi aham te putto aham deva loke
translated: Then the youth said, “Brahman, for whose sake you weep, I am your son. I was reborn in the world of the gods.

original: nibbatto, ito paṭṭhāya mā maṃ anusoci, dānaṃ dehi, sīlaṃ rakkhāhi, uposathaṃ karohī”ti
analyzed: nibbatto itas paṭṭhāya mā mama anusoci dānam dehi sīlam rakkhāhi uposatham karohi iti
translated: From this day forth, do not grieve for me. Give gifts, observe morality, and perform the Uposatha ceremony.”

original: ovaditvā sakaṭṭhānameva gato. Brāhmaṇopi tassovāde ṭhatvā dānādīni puññāni katvā
analyzed: ovaditvā saka ṭṭhānam eva gataḥ brāhmaṇaḥ api tassa uvāde ṭhatvā dāna ādīni puññāni katvā
translated: Having thus instructed him, he went to his own place. The Brahman, abiding by his words, performed the meritorious deeds of giving gifts, and so on.

original: kālakato devaloke nibbatti.
analyzed: kālakataḥ deva loke nibbatti
translated: After death he was reborn in the world of the gods.

original: Satthā imaṃ dhammadesanaṃ āharitvā saccāni pakāsetvā jātakaṃ samodhānehi, saccapariyosāne kuṭumbiko sotāpattiphale patiṭṭhahi.Tadā dhammadesakadevaputto ahameva ahosinti.
analyzed: satthā imam dhamma desanam āharitvā saccāni pakāsetvā jātakam samodhānehi sacca pariyosāne kuṭumbikaḥ sotāpatti phale dhammadesaka deva putto aham eva ahosinti
translated: When the Teacher had related this story, he expounded the Truths, and at the conclusion of the Truths the layman was established in the Fruit of Conversion. At that time the deva who listened to the preaching of the Law was myself.

original: Maṭṭhakuṇḍalījātakavaṇṇanā ekādasamā.
analyzed: maṭṭhakuṇḍalījātaka vaṇṇanā ekādasamā
translated: The story of the Matted-hair Ascetic with the Ear-rings is finished.

original: [450] 12. Bilārakosiyajātakavaṇṇanā
translated: The story of the Bilva-fruit

original: Apacantāpīti idaṃ satthā jetavane viharanto ekaṃ dānavittaṃ bhikkhuṃ ārabbha kathesi.
analyzed: apacanta api iti idam satthā jetavane viharantaḥ ekam dāna vittam bhikkhum ārabbha kathesi
translated: This story the Master told, while dwelling in Jetavana, concerning a certain monk who was a miser.

original: So kira bhagavato dhammadesanaṃ sutvā sāsane pabbajitvā pabbajitakālato paṭṭhāya
analyzed: so kira bhagavato dhamma desanam sutvā sāsane pabbajitvā pabbajita kālataḥ paṭṭhāya
translated: This monk, it would appear, had gone forth in the Dispensation of the Buddha, and had listened to the preaching of the Law.

original: dānavitto ahosi dānajjhāsayo, pattapariyāpannampi piṇḍapātaṃ aññassa adatvā na bhuñji,
analyzed: dāna vittaḥ ahosi dāna ajjhāsayo patta pariyāpannam pi piṇḍapātam aññassa a datvā na bhuñji
translated: From the time of his going forth he was a miser, and had a passion for giving. He would not eat any alms that he received in his bowl unless he gave a portion to another.

original: antamaso pānīyampi labhitvā aññassa adatvā na pivi, evaṃ dānābhirato ahosi. Athassa
analyzed: antamasaḥ pānīyam pi labhitvā aññassa a datvā na evam dāna abhirataḥ ahosi
translated: He would not drink any water that he received unless he gave a portion to another. Thus he was devoted to the practice of charity.

original: dhammasabhāyaṃ bhikkhū guṇakathaṃ kathesuṃ. Satthā āgantvā “kāya nuttha, bhikkhave,
analyzed: dhamma sabhāyam bhikkhū guṇa katham kathesuṃ satthā āgantvā kāya nuttha bhikkhave
translated: The monks began a discussion of his virtues in the Hall of Truth. The Master came in and asked, “Monks, what is it that you are sitting here now talking about?

original: etarahi kathāya sannisinnā”ti pucchitvā “imāya nāmā”ti vutte taṃ bhikkhuṃ pakkosāpetvā
analyzed: etarahi kathāya sannisinnā ati pucchitvā imāya nāma ati vutte tam bhikkhum pakkosāpetvā
translated: When they told him, he sent for that monk,🔽and asked him, “Is it true, monk, that you are a giver, devoted to charity?”

original: “saccaṃ kira tvaṃ bhikkhu dānavitto dānajjhāsayo”ti pucchitvā “saccaṃ, bhante”ti
analyzed: saccam kira tvam bhikkhu dāna vittaḥ dāna ajjhāsayo ti pucchitvā saccam bhante iti
translated: “Yes, Reverend Sir.”

original: vutte “bhikkhave ayaṃ pubbe assaddho ahosi appasanno, tiṇaggena telabindumpi uddharitvā
analyzed: vutte bhikkhave ayam pubbe assaddhaḥ ahosi appasannaḥ tiṇaggena tela bindum pi uddharitvā
translated: “Monks, this man was formerly without faith and without confidence. He would not give so much as a drop of oil from his own store.

original: kassaci na adāsi, atha naṃ ahaṃ dametvā nibbisevanaṃ katvā dānaphalaṃ ñāpesiṃ, tameva
analyzed: kassaci na adāsi atha nam aham dametvā nibbisevanam katvā dāna phalam ñāpesim tam eva
translated: But I tamed him and made him a giver, and taught him the fruit of charity.

original: dānaninnaṃ cittaṃ bhavantarepi na pajahatī”ti vatvā bhikkhūhi yācito atītaṃ āhari.
analyzed: dāna ninnam cittam bhavantare pi na pajahati iti vatvā bhikkhūhi yācitaḥ atītam āhari
translated: Even in his next existence he did not abandon his love of charity.”

original: Atīte bārāṇasiyaṃ brahmadatte rajjaṃ kārente bodhisatto seṭṭhikule nibbattitvā vayappatto
analyzed: atīte bārāṇasiyam brahmadatte rajjam kārente bodhisatto seṭṭhi kule nibbattitvā vaya patto
translated: So saying, he expounded the Law by pronouncing the following Stanza,

original: evaṃ jaccā vā nāvajānāti. Rucipaññoti sādhupañño sundarapañño. Atthakāleti kassacideva

translated: He does not despise his friends. He is wise in his choice: he has good wisdom, fine wisdom. He is a helper: when the need for some service arises,

original: atthassa kāraṇassa uppannakāle. Matīmāti taṃ taṃ atthaṃ paricchinditvā vicāraṇasamatthatāya
analyzed: atthassa kāraṇassa uppanna kāle matīmāti tam tam attham paricchinditvā vicāraṇa samattha tāya
translated: he is one who has understanding: he is one who has understanding because he is capable of discerning this or that need and of investigating it.

original: matimā hutvā te sahāye nāvajānāti. Sahāyesūti taṃ tassa anavajānanaṃ sahāyesu sotthānaṃ🔽nāmāti porāṇakapaṇḍitā āhu. Tena hi so niraparādhamaṅgalena idhaloke ca paraloke

translated: He does not despise his friends. He is a friend who is a good guide: the ancient sages have said that a friend who is a good guide is a friend who is a good refuge.🔽Therefore, by this auspicious sign of being free from blame, he is protected in this world and in the next.

original: ca gutto hoti. Tattha paṇḍite sahāye nissāya sotthibhāvo kusanāḷijātakena kathetabbo.
analyzed: ca gutto hoti tattha paṇḍite sahāye nissāya sotthi bhāvaḥ kusanāḷijātakena kathetabbo

original: Santoti paṇḍitā sappurisā yassa mittāni bhavanti. Saṃvissatthāti gharaṃ pavisitvā
analyzed: santaḥ iti paṇḍitā sappurisā yassa mittāni bhavanti gharam pavisitvā

translated: they have gained confidence in him by taking whatever they wish. He is not a deceiver: he is one who has the habit of not deceiving.

original: Na mittadubbhīti yo ca mittadubbhī na hoti. Saṃvibhāgī dhanenāti attano dhanena mittānaṃ
analyzed: na mitta dubbhī iti yaḥ ca mitta dubbhī na hoti saṃvibhāgī dhanena ati attanaḥ dhanena mittānam
translated: He is not a slanderer: he is not one who slanders friends. He is a sharer of gains: he shares his own gains🔽with his friends.

original: saṃvibhāgaṃ karoti. Mittesūti mitte nissāya laddhabbaṃ tassa taṃ mittesu sotthānaṃ🔽nāma hoti. So hi evarūpehi mittehi rakkhito sotthiṃ pāpuṇāti. Tattha mitte nissāya
analyzed: saṃvibhāgam karoti mittesu iti mitte nissāya laddhabbam tassa tam mittesu sa utthānam  nāma hoti saḥ hi evarūpehi mittehi rakkhito sotthim pāpuṇāti tattha mitte nissāya
translated: He shares it with his friends. The safety of what is obtained through friends is in his friends. For he, being protected by such friends, reaches safety. Herein, what is obtained through friends is safety in friends.

original: sotthibhāvo mahāukkusajātakādīhi kathetabbo.🔽Tulyavayāti samānavayā. Samaggāti samaggavāsā. Anubbatāti anuvattitā. Dhammakāmāti🔽tividhasucaritadhammaṃ roceti. Pajātāti vijāyinī, na vañjhā. Dāresūti etehi sīlaguṇehi🔽samannāgate mātugāme gehe vasante sāmikassa sotthi hotīti paṇḍitā kathenti. Tattha
analyzed: sotthi bhāvaḥ mahā ukkusa jātaka ādīhi kathetabbo  tulya vayā ati samāna vayā samaggā ati samagga vāsā anubbatā ati anuvattitā dhamma kāmā ati  tividha su carita dhammam roceti pajātā ati vijāyinī na vañjhā dāresu iti etehi sīla guṇehi  samannāgate mātugāme gehe vasante sāmikassa sotthi hoti iti paṇḍitā kathenti tattha
translated: He shares it with his friends. Friends are those from whom he can get what he needs. The safety of that man is in his friends. For he who is protected by such friends as these will reach safety. Herein, the safety that comes from friends can be illustrated by the Great Ox-duty Jātaka .

original: sīlavantaṃ mātugāmaṃ nissāya sotthibhāvo maṇicorajātaka- sambūlajātaka- khaṇḍahālajātakehi kathetabbo.

translated: Equal in age: of the same age. United: living together. Obedient: compliant. Fond of Dhamma: she likes the Dhamma of the three kinds of good conduct. Fruitful: she bears children, she is not barren. In the home: the wise say that when a woman has these virtues of morality, her husband’s safety is in the home with her. Herein, the safety that comes from a virtuous woman can be illustrated by the Jewel, the Sambūka, and the Khaṇḍa-hāla Jātakas.

original: Soceyyanti sucibhāvaṃ. Advejjhatāti advejjhatāya na esa mayā saddhiṃ bhijjitvā dvidhā
analyzed: suci bhāvam suci bhāvam advejjhatā ati advejjhatāya na esa mayā saddhim bhijjitvā dvidhā

analyzed: ca yam jānāti rājūsu vā iti evam rājūsu sevakānam sotthānam nāma ati paṇḍitā kathenti
translated: “It will be” : he knows thus with confidence. “He is a good friend of mine” : he knows thus. “Among kings” : thus the wise say that the good fortune of servants among kings is this.

original: Dadāti saddhoti kammañca phalañca saddahitvā dadāti. Saggesu veti evaṃ sagge devaloke
analyzed: dadāti saddhā iti kammañca phalañca saddahitvā dadāti saggesu vā iti evam sagge deva loke
translated: “The faithful give” : he gives, having faith in kamma and its fruit. “In the heavens” : thus the wise say that the good fortune in the heavens, in the deva-world, is this.

translated: “The blameless auspicious state” should be told in detail with the stories of the ghosts and the stories of the mansions.🔽“The wise purify the man” : the wise purify the man, they purify him by the noble Dhamma. “By their conduct” :🔽by their right practice. “The learned” : the learned in the higher wisdom. “The virtuous” :

original: ariyasīlena samannāgatā. Arahantamajjheti arahantānaṃ majjhe paṭilabhitabbaṃ taṃ
analyzed: ariya sīlena samannāgatāḥ arahanta majjhe ti arahantānam majjhe paṭilabhitabbam tam
translated: those who have the noble virtue. “The middle state of the arahants” : the middle state to be attained among the arahants is this.

original: sotthānanti paṇḍitā kathenti. Arahanto hi attanā paṭividdhamaggaṃ ācikkhitvā paṭipādentā
analyzed: sa utthānam ti paṇḍitā kathenti arahantaḥ hi attanā paṭividdha maggam ācikkhitvā paṭipādentā

translated: purify the person who practices it by means of the Noble Path, and he too becomes an Arahant.

original: Evaṃ mahāsatto arahattena desanāya kūṭaṃ gaṇhanto aṭṭhahi gāthāhi aṭṭha mahāmaṅgalāni kathetvā tesaññeva maṅgalānaṃ thutiṃ karonto osānagāthamāha –
analyzed: evam mahāsattaḥ arahattena desanāya kūṭam gaṇhantaḥ aṭṭhahi gāthāhi aṭṭha mahāmaṅgalāni kathetvā tesam eva maṅgalānam thutim karontaḥ osānagātham āha
translated: Thus, taking the Arahantship as the climax of the teaching, the Great Being spoke eight verses on the eight great blessings, and in praise of those very blessings, he spoke the ninth verse as a conclusion:

original: “Etāni kho sotthānāni loke, viññuppasatthāni sukhudrayāni;

translated: “These are the things that are for welfare in the world, esteemed by the wise, and productive of happiness;

translated: Herein, the wise man should cultivate them, for in the matter of blessings there is no truth whatever.”

analyzed: tattha na hi maṅgala iti tasmim pana diṭṭha suta muta ppabhede maṅgale kiñcanam eka maṅgalam pi saccam nāma natthi nibbānam eva pana ekam paramattha saccanti
translated: Herein, in the matter of blessings, which are of the kind that is seen, heard, or sensed, there is no truth whatever, not even one blessing, but only Nibbāna is the one truth in the ultimate sense.

original: Isayo tāni maṅgalāni sutvā sattaṭṭhadivasaccayena ācariyaṃ āpucchitvā tattheva agamaṃsu.

translated: The king went to them and asked them. They answered his auspicious questions in the manner taught by his teacher,

original: Satthā imaṃ dhammadesanaṃ āharitvā “na, bhikkhave, idāneva, pubbepāhaṃ maṅgalapañhaṃ🔽kathesi”nti vatvā jātakaṃ samodhānesi – “tadā isigaṇo buddhaparisā ahosi, maṅgalapañhapucchako🔽jeṭṭhantevāsiko sāriputto, ācariyo pana ahameva ahosi”nti.
analyzed: satthā imam dhamma desanam āharitvā na bhikkhave idānā iva pubbepāham maṅgala pañham  kathesin ti vatvā jātakam samodhānesi tadā isi gaṇaḥ buddha parisā ahosi maṅgala pañha pucchako  jeṭṭha antevāsikaḥ sāriputto ācariyo pana aham eva ahosinti
translated: After telling this story, the Master said, “Monks, it was not only on this occasion that I answered auspicious questions;🔽in a previous state of existence also I answered auspicious questions.” And so saying, he related the Mahāmaṅgala Jātaka.

original: Mahāmaṅgalajātakavaṇṇanā pannarasamā.
translated: The company of seers was the company of the Buddha, the questioner of the auspicious questions was Sāriputta, the teacher was myself.

original: [454] 16. Ghaṭapaṇḍitajātakavaṇṇanā

translated: The situation was the same as that of the story of the matted-hair ascetic. Here the Teacher asked the lay disciple, “Why are you sorrowful, lay disciple?”

original: nānusociṃsū”ti vatvā tena yācito atītaṃ āhari.
analyzed: vatvā tena yācitaḥ atītam āhari
translated: “Yes, Reverend Sir,” he replied. “Well then, lay disciple,” said the Teacher, “in days gone by the wise men of old, having heard the words of the wise, did not grieve for a dead son.” So saying, he complied with the request of the lay disciple and related the following

original: Atīte uttarapathe kaṃsabhoge asitañjananagare mahākaṃso nāma rājā rajjaṃ kāresi.
analyzed: atīte uttara pathe kaṃsa bhoge asitañjana nagare mahākaṃsaḥ nāma rājā rajjam kāresi
translated: In the dispensation of the Supremely Enlightened Kassapa, in the city of Asitañjana in the land of Kaṃsabhoga, there reigned a king named Mahākaṃsa.

translated: Somewhere: in some village or town. The goldsmiths: the goldsmiths and the king’s great ministers.

analyzed: bharanti piṇḍena ati ajja mātuposakam nāga rājam bhojanassa su vaḍḍhitena
translated: They will feed him with a lump: they will feed the Nāga king, who is worthy of a king’s food, with a lump of well-cooked

analyzed: piṇḍena posenti yattha ati yasmin nāga rāje rājā nisīditvā kavacam abhihessati iti saṅgāmam
translated: rice. Where: in which Nāga dwelling the king will sit down and

analyzed: pavisitvā pacca amittānam kavacam abhihanissati bhindissati idam vuttam hoti yattha

analyzed: mama putte nisinnaḥ rājā vā rāja kumāraḥ vā a chambhitaḥ hutvā sa pattānam kavacam hanissati

translated: “My son, the king of elephants, is to-day fed with rice by the golden ornaments.”

analyzed: hatthācariyaḥ api antarāmagga iva raññaḥ sāsanam pesesi tam sutvā rājā nagaram alaṅkārāpesi

analyzed: hatthācariyaḥ bodhisattam kata gandha paribhaṇḍam alaṅkata paṭiyattam hatthi sālam netvā

analyzed: vicitra sāṇiyā parikkhipāpetvā raññaḥ ārocāpesi rājā nānagga rasa bhojanam ādāya gantvā
translated: He caused him to be surrounded with a variegated net, and announced it to the king. The king went, taking various kinds of delicious food,

analyzed: bodhisattassa dāpesi saḥ mātaram vinā gocaram na gaṇhissāmi iti piṇḍam na gaṇhi

original: Atha naṃ yācanto rājā tatiyaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: atha nam yācantaḥ rājā tatiyam gātham āha
translated: Then the king, asking him to take it, spoke the third stanza:—

analyzed: gaṇhāhi nāga kabaḷam mā nāga kisakaḥ bhava
translated: “Take food, O elephant, and be not lean,

analyzed: bahūni rāja kiccāni tāni nāga karissasi iti

original: Taṃ sutvā bodhisatto catutthaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: tam sutvā bodhisatto catuttham gātham āha
translated: When he heard that, the Bodhisatta spoke the fourth stanza:—

analyzed: sā nūnasā kapaṇikā andhā apariṇāyikā
translated: “Surely that poor blind creature, who cannot guide herself,

translated: Stumbles against a stump, and falls into a pit.”

analyzed: tattha sā nūnasā ti mahā rāja nūna sā esā kapaṇikā ati putta viyogena kapaṇā khāṇum ti  tattha tattha patitam rukkha kaliṅgaram ghaṭṭeti iti paridevamānā tattha tattha pādena  pothentī nūna pādena hanati girim caṇḍoraṇam pati iti caṇḍoraṇa pabbata abhimukhī pabbata pāde
translated: Herein, ‘Surely, she’: surely, this is she. ‘A beggar’: she is a beggar through being separated from her son. ‘A log’:🔽a piece of tree trunk fallen here and there. ‘Striking’: while lamenting she strikes it here and there with her foot,🔽surely she is killing it with her foot. ‘She has gone to the mountain Caṇḍoraṇa’: she is facing the Caṇḍoraṇa mountain, at the foot of the mountain,🔽🔽

original: paripphandamānāti attho.
analyzed: paripphandamānā iti atthaḥ
translated: “Surely, sire, she is a poor woman, poor through the loss of her child. A stump” means a piece of a tree trunk fallen here and there. “She kicks” means that, while lamenting, she kicks it here and there with her foot. “Surely she kicks it with her foot” means that she certainly strikes it with her foot. “She goes to the mountain Caṇḍoraṇa” means that she goes to the mountain Caṇḍoraṇa. “She wanders about” means that she wanders about at the foot of the mountain.

original: Atha naṃ pucchanto rājā pañcamaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: atha nam pucchantaḥ rājā pañcamam gātham āha
translated: Then the king, asking her, spoke the fifth stanza:

original: “Kā nu te sā mahānāga, andhā apariṇāyikā;
analyzed: kā nu te sā mahā nāga andhā apariṇāyikā
translated: “Who is this, O great Nāga, blind and helpless,

original: Khāṇuṃ pādena ghaṭṭeti, giriṃ caṇḍoraṇaṃ patī”ti.
analyzed: khāṇum pādena ghaṭṭa iti girim caṇḍoraṇam pati iti
translated: Who kicks a stump with her foot and goes to the mountain Caṇḍoraṇa?”

original: Bodhisatto chaṭṭhaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: bodhisatto chaṭṭham gātham āha
translated: The Bodhisatta spoke the sixth stanza:

original: “Mātā me sā mahārāja, andhā apariṇāyikā;
analyzed: mātā me sā mahā rāja andhā apariṇāyikā
translated: “She is my mother, O great king, blind and helpless,

original: Khāṇuṃ pādena ghaṭṭeti, giriṃ caṇḍoraṇaṃ patī”ti.

translated: Who kicks a stump with her foot and goes to the mountain Caṇḍoraṇa.”

analyzed: rājā chaṭṭha gāthāya tam attham sutvā muñcāpento sattamam gātham āha

analyzed: mayham mātā jīvita kkhayam pāpuṇissati tāya vinā mayham issariyena atthaḥ natthi

translated: “The elephant, the great beast, released from his bonds,🔽Having comforted his mother for a moment,

translated: he took a great deal of lotus-fibers and stalks, filled his trunk with water, and came out of the cave.🔽And going to his mother, who was sitting at the mouth of the cave, he sprinkled water on her head, in order that she might feel the touch of water,

analyzed: sarīrassa phassa paṭilābha attham upari udakam siñci tam attham āvikaronto satthā dve

analyzed: tassā sarīra parihāram katvā kāraṇḍakaassamapadam nāma gataḥ tasmin pana ṭhāne himavantato
translated: from the Himalayas,

analyzed: otaritvā pañca satāḥ isayaḥ vasiṃsu tam vattam tesam adāsi rājā bodhisattassa samāna rūpam

translated: The Teacher, having related this Dhamma, revealed the Truths, and identified the Birth, saying, “At that time the king was Ānanda, the wicked man was Devadatta,

analyzed: mātu posaka jātaka vaṇṇanā paṭhamā

translated: Sometimes the Elder Nāgasamāla was the attendant, sometimes Nāgita, sometimes Upavāṇa, sometimes Sunakkhatta, sometimes Cunda,

analyzed: vutte aññena gacchanti ekacce mayham patta cīvaram bhūmiyam nikkhipanti nibaddha upaṭṭhākam
