original: me ekaṃ bhikkhuṃ jānāthā”ti. “Bhante, ahaṃ upaṭṭhahissāmi, ahaṃ upaṭṭhahissāmī”ti
analyzed: me ekam bhikkhum jānātha ati bhante aham upaṭṭhahissāmi aham upaṭṭhahissāmi iti
translated: for me.” “Venerable Sir, I will be the attendant,” “Venerable Sir, I will be the attendant,”

original: sirasi añjaliṃ katvā uṭṭhite sāriputtattherādayo “tumhākaṃ patthanā matthakaṃ pattā,
analyzed: sirasi añjalim katvā uṭṭhite sāriputta thera ādayo tumhākam patthanā matthakam pattā
translated: said the monks, raising their hands in respectful salutation. But the Elder Sāriputta and the others rejected them, saying, “Your wishes have been fulfilled.

original: ala”nti paṭikkhipi. Tato bhikkhū ānandattheraṃ “tvaṃ āvuso, upaṭṭhākaṭṭhānaṃ yācāhī”ti
analyzed: alanti paṭikkhipi tatas bhikkhū ānanda theram tvam āvuso upaṭṭhāka ṭṭhānam yācāhi iti
translated: You are no longer novices.” Then the monks said to the Elder Ānanda, “Friend Ānanda, ask the Teacher to be your attendant.”🔽“Very well,” Ānanda replied, and he went to the Buddha.

original: āhaṃsu. Thero “sace me bhante, bhagavā attanā laddhacīvaraṃ na dassati, piṇḍapātaṃ
analyzed: āhaṃsu theraḥ sace me bhante bhagavā attanā laddha cīvaram na dassati piṇḍapātam
translated: “If the Fortunate One does not give me the robe that he has received, I will not eat, I will not speak.”🔽“If the Fortunate One does not give me the robe that he has received, I will not eat, I will not speak.”

original: na dassati, ekagandhakuṭiyaṃ vasituṃ na dassati, maṃ gahetvā nimantanaṃ na gamissati,🔽sace pana bhagavā mayā gahitaṃ nimantanaṃ gamissati, sace ahaṃ tiroraṭṭhā tirojanapadā
analyzed: na dassati eka gandhakuṭiyam vasitum na dassati mam gahetvā nimantanam na gamissati  sace pana bhagavā mayā gahitam nimantanam gamissati sace aham tiroraṭṭhā tirojanapadā
translated: and they told the Elder. The Elder said, “If, venerable sir, the Blessed One will not give me the robe he has received, will not give me the alms food he has received, will not let me live in his fragrant chamber, will not go to an invitation with me,

original: bhagavantaṃ daṭṭhuṃ āgataṃ parisaṃ āgatakkhaṇeyeva dassetuṃ labhissāmi, yadā me kaṅkhā
analyzed: bhagavantam daṭṭhum āgatam parisam āgata kkhaṇeya iva dassetum labhissāmi yadā me kaṅkhā
translated: but if the Blessed One will go to an invitation with me if I take him, if I will be able to show to the assembly that has come to see the Blessed One when he has come from a far country or a far region, the moment it has come,

original: uppajjati, tasmiṃ khaṇeyeva bhagavantaṃ upasaṅkamituṃ labhissāmi, sace yaṃ bhagavā🔽mama parammukhā dhammaṃ katheti, taṃ āgantvā mayhaṃ kathessati, evāhaṃ bhagavantaṃ
analyzed: uppajjati tasmin khaṇeya iva bhagavantam upasaṅkamitum labhissāmi sace yam bhagavā  mama parammukhā dhammam kathā iti tam āgantvā mayham kathessati eva aham bhagavantam
translated: if I will be able to approach the Blessed One the moment a doubt arises in me, if the Blessed One

original: upaṭṭhahissāmī”ti ime cattāro paṭikkhepe catasso ca āyācanāti aṭṭha vare yāci, bhagavāpissa adāsi.
analyzed: upaṭṭhahissāmi iti ime cattāro paṭikkhepe catasso ca āyācanā ati aṭṭha vare yāci bhagavā api ssa adāsi
translated: will come and tell me what he has taught to others in my absence, then I will attend on the Blessed One.” He asked for eight boons, namely, the four refusals and the four requests. The Blessed One granted them to him.

original: So tato paṭṭhāya pañcavīsati vassāni nibaddhupaṭṭhāko ahosi. So pañcasu ṭhānesu etadagge
analyzed: so tatas paṭṭhāya pañcavīsati vassāni nibaddhupaṭṭhāko ahosi so pañcasu ṭhānesu etad agge
translated: From then on he attended on the Blessed One for twenty-five years. He was pre-eminent in five instances, namely, in long-standing, in seniority, in virtue, in meditation, and in wisdom.

original: ṭhapanaṃ patvā āgamasampadā, adhigamasampadā, pubbahetusampadā, attatthaparipucchāsampadā,🔽titthavāsasampadā, yonisomanasikārasampadā, buddhūpanissayasampadāti imāhi sattahi
analyzed: ṭhapanam patvā āgama sampadā adhigama sampadā pubba hetu sampadā atta attha paripucchā sampadā  titthavāsa sampadā yoniso manasikāra sampadā buddha upanissaya sampadā ti imāhi sattahi
translated: After he had been established in the Faith, he became endowed with seven endowments: the endowment of the Scriptures, the endowment of the Higher Knowledge, the endowment of the root of merit acquired in previous states of existence, the endowment of the opportunity to ask questions concerning the welfare of self and others,🔽the endowment of the opportunity to dwell in a place where the Buddhas dwell, the endowment of the opportunity to reflect in a proper manner, the endowment of the opportunity to rely upon the Buddha.

original: sampadāhi samannāgato buddhassa santike aṭṭhavaradāyajjaṃ labhitvā buddhasāsane paññāto🔽gaganamajjhe cando viya pākaṭo ahosi. Athekadivasaṃ bhikkhū dhammasabhāyaṃ kathaṃ
analyzed: sampadāhi samannāgataḥ buddhassa santike aṭṭhavaradāyajjam labhitvā buddha sāsane paññātaḥ  gagana majjhe candaḥ viya pākaṭaḥ ahosi atha eka divasam bhikkhū dhamma sabhāyam katham
translated: Endowed with these seven endowments, he received the boon of eight boons from the Buddha, and became famous in the Dispensation of the Buddha.

original: samuṭṭhāpesuṃ “āvuso, tathāgato ānandattheraṃ varadānena santappesī”ti. Satthā āgantvā🔽“kāya nuttha, bhikkhave, etarahi kathāya sannisinnā”ti pucchitvā “imāya nāmā”ti vutte🔽“na, bhikkhave, idāneva, pubbepāhaṃ ānandaṃ varena santappesiṃ, pubbepāhaṃ yaṃ yaṃ
analyzed: samuṭṭhāpesum āvuso tathāgataḥ ānanda theram vara dānena santappesi iti satthā āgantvā  kāya nuttha bhikkhave etarahi kathāya sannisinnā ati pucchitvā imāya nāma ati vutte  na bhikkhave idānā iva pubbepāham ānandam varena santappesim pubbepāham yam yam
translated: Like the moon in the midst of the sky, he became conspicuous to all. One day the monks began a discussion in the Hall of Truth: “Brethren, the Tathāgata gratified the Elder Ānanda by granting him a boon.” The Teacher drew near and asked, “Monks, what is the subject that engages your attention now as you sit here all gathered together?” When they told him,

original: esa yāci, taṃ taṃ adāsiṃyevā”ti vatvā atītaṃ āhari.
analyzed: yāci tam tam vatvā atītam āhari
translated: he said, “Monks, this is not the first time I have gratified Ānanda by granting him a boon; in a previous state of existence also whatever Ānanda asked of me, I gave to him.” So saying, he related the following Story of the Past:

original: Atīte bārāṇasiyaṃ brahmadatte rajjaṃ kārente bodhisatto tassa putto juṇhakumāro nāma
analyzed: atīte bārāṇasiyam brahmadatte rajjam kārente bodhisatto tassa putto juṇha kumāraḥ nāma
translated: Once upon a time, when Brahmadatta was reigning in Benares, the Bodhisatta was his son, named Prince Jūjaka.

original: hutvā takkasilāyaṃ sippaṃ uggahetvā ācariyassa anuyogaṃ datvā rattibhāge andhakāre
analyzed: hutvā takkasilāyam sippam uggahetvā ācariyassa anuyogam da tvā ratti bhāge andhakāre
translated: After he had made his offerings, he went to Takkasilā to learn a craft. After he had served his master, he left his house at night in the dark,

original: ācariyassa gharā nikkhamitvā attano nivāsaṭṭhānaṃ vegena gacchanto aññataraṃ brāhmaṇaṃ
analyzed: ācariyassa gharā nikkhamitvā attanaḥ nivāsa ṭṭhānam vegena gacchantaḥ aññataram brāhmaṇam
translated: and while going quickly to his own lodging he saw a certain brāhmaṇa

original: bhikkhaṃ caritvā attano nivāsaṭṭhānaṃ gacchantaṃ apassanto bāhunā paharitvā tassa🔽bhattapātiṃ bhindiṃ, brāhmaṇo patitvā viravi. Kumāro kāruññena nivattitvā taṃ hatthe
analyzed: bhikkham caritvā attanaḥ nivāsa ṭṭhānam gacchantam a passantaḥ bāhunā paharitvā tassa  bhatta pātim bhindim brāhmaṇo patitvā kumāro kāruññena nivattitvā tam hatthe
translated: who was going to his own lodging after begging for alms. Not seeing him, he struck him with his arm,🔽and broke his alms-bowl. The brāhmaṇa fell down and cried out. The prince turned back out of pity, and taking him by the hand,

original: gahetvā uṭṭhāpesi. Brāhmaṇo “tayā, tāta, mama bhikkhābhājanaṃ bhinnaṃ, bhattamūlaṃ
analyzed: gahetvā uṭṭhāpesi brāhmaṇaḥ tayā tāta mama bhikkhā bhājanam bhinnam bhatta mūlam
translated: helped him up. The brāhmaṇa said: “My dear sir, you have broken my alms-bowl. Give me the price of a meal.”

original: me dehī”ti āha. Kumāro “brāhmaṇa, na dānāhaṃ tava bhattamūlaṃ dātuṃ sakkomi, ahaṃ
analyzed: me dehi iti āha kumāraḥ brāhmaṇa na dāna aham tava bhatta mūlam dātum sakkomi aham
translated: The prince said: “Brāhmaṇa, I am not able to give you the price of a meal.

original: kho pana kāsikarañño putto juṇhakumāro nāma, mayi rajje patiṭṭhite āgantvā maṃ dhanaṃ
analyzed: kho pana kāsikaraññaḥ putto juṇha kumāraḥ nāma mayi rajje patiṭṭhite āgantvā mama dhanam
translated: I am the son of the king of Kāsi, named Prince Jūjaka. When I am established in the kingdom, come and ask me for wealth.

original: yāceyyāsī”ti vatvā niṭṭhitasippo ācariyaṃ vanditvā bārāṇasiṃ gantvā pitu sippaṃ dassesi.
analyzed: yāceyyāsi iti vatvā niṭṭhita sippaḥ ācariyam vanditvā bārāṇasim gantvā pitu sippam dassesi
translated: “You may go.” When he had finished his training, he saluted his teacher and went to Bārāṇasī and there exhibited his skill.

original: Pitā “jīvantena me putto diṭṭho, rājabhūtampi naṃ passissāmī”ti rajje abhisiñci.🔽So juṇharājā nāma hutvā dhammena rajjaṃ kāresi. Brāhmaṇo taṃ pavattiṃ sutvā “idāni
analyzed: pitā jīvantena me putto diṭṭhaḥ rāja bhūtam pi nam passissāmi iti rajje abhisiñci  saḥ juṇha rājā nāma hutvā dhammena rajjam kāresi brāhmaṇaḥ tam pavattim sutvā idāni
translated: His father said, “I have seen my son alive. I will see him also as a king.” So he anointed him king.

original: mama bhattamūlaṃ āharissāmī”ti bārāṇasiṃ gantvā rājānaṃ alaṅkatanagaraṃ padakkhiṇaṃ
analyzed: mama bhatta mūlam āharissāmi iti bārāṇasim gantvā rājānam alaṅkata nagaram padakkhiṇam
translated: He became known as King Juṇha, and he ruled righteously. When the brāhmaṇa heard what had happened, he thought, “Now I will get the wages for my teaching.” So he went to Bārāṇasī and saw the king making his round of the city in state.

original: karontameva disvā ekasmiṃ unnatappadese ṭhito hatthaṃ pasāretvā jayāpesi. Atha naṃ
analyzed: karontam eva disvā ekasmin unnata ppadese ṭhitaḥ hattham pasāretvā jayāpesi atha naṃ
translated: He stood on a high place, extended his hand, and called out, “Victory to the king!”

original: rājā anoloketvāva atikkami. Brāhmaṇo tena adiṭṭhabhāvaṃ ñatvā kathaṃ samuṭṭhāpento
analyzed: rājā atikkami brāhmaṇo tena a diṭṭha bhāvam ñatvā katham samuṭṭhāpento
translated: But the king passed on without even looking at him. The brāhmaṇa, realizing that he had not been seen, began to make a disturbance.

original: paṭhamaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: paṭhamam gātham āha
translated: He spoke the first verse:

original: “Suṇohi mayhaṃ vacanaṃ janinda, atthena juṇhamhi idhānupatto;
analyzed: suṇohi mayham vacanam janinda atthena juṇhamhi idha anupatto
translated: “Listen to my words, O lord of men, I have come here for a purpose.

original: Na brāhmaṇe addhike tiṭṭhamāne, gantabbamāhu dvipadinda seṭṭhā”ti.
analyzed: na brāhmaṇe addhike tiṭṭhamāne gantabbam āhu dvipadinda seṭṭha ati
translated: The best of men say that one should not go when the brāhmaṇas are standing in excess.”

original: Tattha juṇhamhīti mahārāja, tayi juṇhamhi ahaṃ ekena atthena idhānuppatto, na nikkāraṇā
analyzed: tattha juṇhamhi iti mahā rāja tayi juṇhamhi aham ekena atthena idha anuppattaḥ na nikkāraṇā
translated: Herein, I have come to you, Great King, for a certain purpose, not without reason, I have come here, he says.

original: idhāgatomhīti dīpeti. Addhiketi addhānaṃ āgate. Gantabbanti taṃ addhikaṃ addhānamāgataṃ
analyzed: idha āgataḥ asi iti dīpe iti addhika iti addhānam āgate gantabbanti tam addhikam addhānam āgatam
translated: Addhi, come on a journey, means come on a journey.

original: yācamānaṃ brāhmaṇaṃ anoloketvāva gantabbanti paṇḍitā na āhu na kathentīti.
analyzed: yācamānam brāhmaṇam anoloketvā ava gantabbanti paṇḍitāḥ na āhu na kathenti iti
translated: The wise do not say, do not speak, that one should go away without looking at a brahmin who has come on a journey and is asking for something.

original: Rājā tassa vacanaṃ sutvā hatthiṃ vajiraṅkusena niggahetvā dutiyaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: rājā tassa vacanam sutvā hatthim vaji raṅkusena niggahetvā dutiyam gātham āha
translated: After hearing his words, the king, having restrained the elephant with the goad, spoke the second stanza:

original: “Suṇomi tiṭṭhāmi vadehi brahme, yenāsi atthena idhānupatto;
analyzed: suṇomi tiṭṭhāmi vadehi brahme yena asi atthena idha anupatto
translated: “I listen, I stand, speak, O brahmin, for what purpose you have come here;

original: Kaṃ vā tvamatthaṃ mayi patthayāno, idhāgamo brahme tadiṅgha brūhī”ti.
analyzed: kam vā tvam attham mayi patthayānaḥ idha agamaḥ brahme tat iṅgha brūhi iti
translated: Or what benefit do you expect from me, O brahmin, having come here, speak of it.”

original: Tattha iṅghāti codanatthe nipāto.
analyzed: tattha iṅghā ati codana tthe nipātaḥ
translated: Herein, iṅgha is an adverb in the sense of urging.

original: Tato paraṃ brāhmaṇassa ca rañño ca vacanapaṭivacanavasena sesagāthā kathitā –
analyzed: tato param brāhmaṇassa ca rañño ca vacana paṭivacana vasena sesa gāthā kathitā
translated: After that, the remaining stanzas were spoken by way of the brahmin’s words and the king’s replies:

original: “Dadāhi me gāmavarāni pañca, dāsīsataṃ satta gavaṃsatāni;
analyzed: dadāhi me gām avarāni pañca dāsī satam satta gavaṃsatāni
translated: “Give me five excellent villages, a hundred female slaves, seven hundred cows,

original: Parosahassañca suvaṇṇanikkhe, bhariyā ca me sādisī dve dadāhi.
analyzed: parosahassañca suvaṇṇa nikkhe bhariyā ca me sādisī dve dadāhi
translated: And more than a thousand gold coins, and give me two wives who are equal to me.

original: “Tapo nu te brāhmaṇa bhiṃsarūpo, mantā nu te brāhmaṇa cittarūpā;
analyzed: tapaḥ nu te brāhmaṇa bhiṃsa rūpaḥ mantā nu te brāhmaṇa citta rūpā
translated: “Is your austerity, Brahmin, fearful? Are your chants, Brahmin, of the mind?

original: Yakkhā nu te assavā santi keci, atthaṃ vā me abhijānāsi kattaṃ.
analyzed: yakkhā nu te assavāḥ santi keci attham vā me abhijānāsi kattam
translated: Are there any yakkhas who are obedient to you? Or do you know my name and clan?

original: “Na me tapo atthi na cāpi mantā, yakkhāpi me assavā natthi keci;
analyzed: na me tapaḥ atthi na ca api mantā yakkhā api me assavā natthi keci
translated: “I have no austerity, nor do I chant, nor are there any yakkhas obedient to me.

original: Atthampi te nābhijānāmi kattaṃ, pubbe ca kho saṅgatimattamāsi.
analyzed: attham pi te na abhijānāmi kattam pubbe ca kho saṅgatimattam āsi
translated: I do not know your name and clan, but we have met before.

original: “Paṭhamaṃ idaṃ dassanaṃ jānato me, na tābhijānāmi ito puratthā;
analyzed: paṭhamam idam dassanam jānataḥ me na tā abhijānāmi itas puratthā
translated: “This is the first time I have seen you, I do not know you from before.

original: Akkhāhi me pucchito etamatthaṃ, kadā kuhiṃ vā ahu saṅgamo no.
analyzed: akkhāhi me pucchitaḥ etam attham kadā kuhim vā ahu saṅgamaḥ naḥ
translated: Please tell me this: where and when did we meet?

original: “Gandhārarājassa puramhi ramme, avasimhase takkasīlāyaṃ deva;
analyzed: gandhāra rājassa puramhi ramme avasimhase takkasīlāyam deva
translated: “In the delightful city of the Gandhāras, in Takkasilā, O King,

original: Tatthandhakāramhi timīsikāyaṃ, aṃsena aṃsaṃ samaghaṭṭayimha.
analyzed: tattha andhakāramhi timīsikāyam aṃsena aṃsam samaghaṭṭayimha
translated: in the darkness of the night, in the gloom, we bumped shoulders.

original: “Te tattha ṭhatvāna ubho janinda, sārāṇiyaṃ vītisārayimha tattha;
analyzed: te tattha ṭhatvānaḥ ubhaḥ janinda sārāṇiyam vītisārayimha tattha
translated: “There, standing, we both, O lord of the people, exchanged greetings.

original: Sāyeva no saṅgatimattamāsi, tato na pacchā na pure ahosi.
analyzed: sāyā iva naḥ saṅgatimattamā asi tatas na pacchā na pure ahosi
translated: That was the extent of our meeting, there was nothing more before or after.

original: “Yadā kadāci manujesu brahme, samāgamo sappurisena hoti;
analyzed: yadā kadāci manujesu brahme samāgamaḥ sappurisena hoti
translated: “When there is a meeting of humans with a good person, O Brahmā,

original: Na paṇḍitā saṅgatisanthavāni, pubbe kataṃ vāpi vināsayanti.
analyzed: na paṇḍitā saṅgati santhavāni pubbe katam vā api vināsayanti
translated: The wise do not destroy the bonds of friendship, nor do they destroy what was done in the past.

original: “Bālāva kho saṅgatisanthavāni, pubbe kataṃ vāpi vināsayanti;
analyzed: bālā ava kho saṅgati santhavāni pubbe katam vā api vināsayanti
translated: The foolish destroy the bonds of friendship, and they destroy what was done in the past.

original: Bahumpi bālesu kataṃ vinassati, tathā hi bālā akataññurūpā.
analyzed: bahum pi bālesu katam vinassati tathā hi bālā akataññu rūpā
translated: Much that is done for the foolish is destroyed, for the foolish are ungrateful.

original: “Dhīrā ca kho saṅgatisanthavāni, pubbe kataṃ vāpi na nāsayanti;
analyzed: dhīrā ca kho saṅgati santhavāni pubbe katam vā api na na āsayanti
translated: The wise do not destroy the bonds of friendship, nor do they destroy what was done in the past.

original: Appampi dhīresu kataṃ na nassati, tathā hi dhīrā sukataññurūpā.
analyzed: appam pi dhīresu katam na nassati tathā hi dhīrā su kataññu rūpā
translated: Little that is done for the wise is destroyed, for the wise are grateful.

original: “Dadāmi te gāmavarāni pañca, dāsīsataṃ satta gavaṃsatāni;
analyzed: dadāmi te gām avarāni pañca dāsī satam satta gavaṃsatāni
translated: I give you five excellent villages, a hundred female slaves, seven hundred cows,

original: Parosahassañca suvaṇṇanikkhe, bhariyā ca te sādisī dve dadāmi.
analyzed: parosahassañca suvaṇṇa nikkhe bhariyā ca te sādisī dve dadāmi
translated: and more than a thousand gold coins. I give you two wives who are your equals.

original: “Evaṃ sataṃ hoti samecca rāja, nakkhattarājāriva tārakānaṃ;
analyzed: evam hoti sametca rāja tārakānam
translated: Thus you will be like a hundred, O King, like the king of the constellations among the stars.

original: Āpūratī kāsipatī tathāhaṃ, tayāpi me saṅgamo ajja laddho”ti.
analyzed: āpūratī kāsipatī tathā aham tayā api me saṅgamaḥ ajja laddhā iti
translated: I am filled with joy, O lord of Kāsi, and today I have obtained union with you.”

original: Tattha sādisīti rūpavaṇṇajātikulapadesena mayā sādisī ekasadisā dve mahāyasā bhariyā
analyzed: tattha sādisī iti rūpa vaṇṇa jāti kula padesena mayā sādisī eka sadisā dve mahā yasā bhariyā
translated: There, “your equals” means two wives of great fame who are my equals, equal to me in beauty, complexion, birth, family, and region.

original: ca me dehīti attho. Bhiṃsarūpoti kiṃ nu te brāhmaṇa balavarūpasīlācāraguṇasaṅkhātaṃ
analyzed: ca me dehi iti atthaḥ bhiṃsarūpaḥ ti kim nu te brāhmaṇa balava rūpa sīla ācāra guṇa saṅkhātam

translated: I am fearless, I am strong. For what reason, today, sir, righteousness, do I give you a path that has never been given before?”

analyzed: pacchā adhammaḥ jeṭṭhaḥ ca ati pure nibbatta bhāvena aham jeṭṭhaḥ ca seṭṭho ca porāṇako
translated: afterwards unrighteousness. “I am the eldest” means by the state of being born first, I am the eldest, the best, the ancient one.

translated: “Having heard this speech, Adhamma, with his head cut off, fell down with his feet up,

translated: “Those who do properly respect their mother and father, ascetics and brahmins, in their own home,

analyzed: ekikā ava nisinnā asi iti vuttam hoti aninditaṅgī iti pāda antataḥ yāva kesaggā  anindita sarīrā tīhi maṇḍalehi pañcahi

translated: which ceased just there like something cut off with an axe. And what occurred yesterday did not reach today,🔽which ceased just there like something cut off with an axe. Therefore you have become more decrepit today. “Thus for me” : set aside yesterday and the day before,

original: Pucchāmi taṃ yakkha mahānubhāva, kathaṃ nu devāna sarīradeho”ti.
analyzed: pucchāmi tam yakkha mahā anubhāva katham nu devāna sarīra dehā uti
translated: I ask you, Yakkha of great power, how is it that the bodies of the gods do not grow old?”

original: Tattha sarīradehoti sarīrasaṅkhāto deho, devānaṃ sarīraṃ kathaṃ na jīrati, idaṃ ahaṃ taṃ pucchāmīti vadati.
analyzed: tattha sarīra deho ti sarīra saṅkhātaḥ dehaḥ devānam sarīram katham na jīrati idam aham tam pucchāmi iti vadati
translated: Herein, bodies means bodies called bodies. How is it that the bodies of the gods do not grow old? I ask you this, is what she said.

original: Athassā kathento sakko itaraṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: kathentaḥ sakkaḥ itaram gātham āha
translated: Then Sakka, telling her, spoke the second verse:

original: “Devā na jīranti yathā manussā, gattesu tesaṃ valiyo na honti;
analyzed: devāḥ na jīranti yathā manussāḥ gattesu tesam valiyaḥ na honti
translated: “As gods do not grow old as men do, and they have no wrinkles,

original: Suve suve bhiyyatarova tesaṃ, dibbo ca vaṇṇo vipulā ca bhogā”ti.
analyzed: suve suve bhiyyataraḥ uva tesam dibbaḥ ca vaṇṇaḥ vipulā ca bhogā ati
translated: Day by day they grow more and more, their divine beauty and their wealth.”

original: Tattha yathā manussāti yathā manussā jīrantā rūpena vaṇṇena bhogena cakkhupasādādīhi
analyzed: tattha yathā manussā ti yathā manussāḥ jīrantāḥ rūpena vaṇṇena bhogena cakkhu pasāda ādīhi
translated: As men grow old, their beauty, complexion, wealth, eye-faculty, etc.,

original: ca jīranti, na evaṃ devā. Tesañhi gattesu valiyopi na santi, maṭṭhakañcanapaṭṭamiva🔽sarīraṃ hoti. Suve suveti divase divase. Bhiyyatarovāti atirekatarova tesaṃ dibbo
analyzed: ca jīranti na evam devā tesam hi gattesu valiyaḥ api na santi maṭṭha kañcana paṭṭam iva  sarīram hoti suve suve iti divase divase bhiyyatarā uvāti atirekatarā uva tesam dibbaḥ
translated: all fade away. But not so with the gods. For in their case there are no wrinkles, and their bodies are like the color of gold.

original: ca vaṇṇo vipulā ca bhogā honti, manussesu hi rūpaparihāni cirajātabhāvassa sakkhi,
analyzed: ca vaṇṇaḥ vipulā ca bhogāḥ honti manussesu hi cira jāta bhāvassa
translated: Day after day, they grow more and more beautiful. Their divine beauty and their wealth increase. For in the case of men, the loss of beauty is a sign of their long life,

original: devesu atirekarūpasampatti ca atirekaparivārasampatti ca. Evaṃ aparihānadhammo nāmesa🔽devaloko. Tasmā tvaṃ jaraṃ appatvāva nikkhamitvā pabbaja, evaṃ parihāniyasabhāvā
analyzed: devesu atireka rūpa sampatti ca atireka parivāra sampatti ca evam a parihāna dhammaḥ nāma īsa  tasmā tvam jaram appatvā ava nikkhamitvā pabbaja evam
translated: while in the case of the gods, the increase of beauty and the increase of wealth are signs of their long life. Thus the world of the gods is not subject to loss.

original: manussalokā cavitvā aparihāniyasabhāvaṃ evarūpaṃ devalokaṃ gamissasīti.
analyzed: cavitvā evarūpam deva lokam gamissasi iti
translated: Therefore, before you grow old, go forth from home into homelessness. Then, having passed away from this world of men, which is subject to loss, you will go to the world of the gods, which is not subject to loss.”

original: Sā devalokassa vaṇṇaṃ sutvā tassa gamanamaggaṃ pucchantī itaraṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: sā deva lokassa vaṇṇam sutvā tassa gamana maggam pucchantī itaram gātham āha
translated: Having heard the description of the world of the gods, she asked about the path that leads to it.

original: “Kiṃsūdha bhītā janatā anekā, maggo ca nekāyatanaṃ pavutto;
analyzed: bhītāḥ janatāḥ anekāḥ maggaḥ ca neka āyatanam pavuttaḥ
translated: “Why is it that many people are afraid, And many paths are spoken of?

original: Pucchāmi taṃ yakkha mahānubhāva, katthaṭṭhito paralokaṃ na bhāye”ti.🔽Tattha kiṃsūdha bhītāti devarāja, ayaṃ khattiyādibhedā anekā janatā kiṃbhītā kassa
analyzed: pucchāmi tam yakkha mahā anubhāva katthaṭṭhitaḥ para lokam na bhāya iti  tattha kiṃsūdha bhīta ati devarāja ayam khattiya ādi bhedā anekā janatā kiṃbhītā kassa
translated: I ask you, Yakkha of great power, Standing where does one not fear the other world?”

original: bhayena parihāniyasabhāvā manussalokā devalokaṃ na gacchatīti pucchati. Maggoti devalokagāmimaggo.🔽Idha pana “ki”nti āharitvā “ko”ti pucchā kātabbā. Ayañhettha attho “anekatitthāyatanavasena🔽paṇḍitehi pavutto devalokamaggo ko kataro”ti vutto. Katthaṭṭhitoti paralokaṃ gacchanto
analyzed: bhayena manussa lokāḥ deva lokam na gacchati iti pucchati maggo ti deva loka gāmi maggo  idha pana kinti āharitvā ko ti pucchā kātabbā ayan ha ittha atthaḥ aneka tittha āyatana vasena  paṇḍitehi pavuttaḥ deva loka maggo kaḥ kataraḥ iti vuttaḥ katthaṭṭhitaḥ ti para lokam gacchantaḥ
translated: Herein, why is it that many people are afraid means, King of the Devas, why is it that this many-folk, which is divided into nobles, brahmans, etc., is afraid? Of what is it afraid? By what is it prevented from going from the human world to the deva world? He asks this. Paths means paths leading to the deva world.

original: katarasmiṃ magge ṭhito na bhāyatīti.
analyzed: katarasmim magge ṭhitaḥ na bhāyati iti
translated: But here the word “why” should be taken as “who” and the question should be taken as “Who is it that is spoken of by the wise as the path leading to the deva world by means of the many kinds of objective supports of the various sects? ” This is the meaning here. Standing where means standing on which path does one who is going to the other world not fear?

original: Athassā kathento sakko itaraṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: kathentaḥ sakkaḥ itaram gātham āha
translated: Then Sakka, answering her, spoke the second verse:

original: “Vācaṃ manañca paṇidhāya sammā, kāyena pāpāni akubbamāno;
analyzed: vācam manañca paṇidhāya sammā kāyena pāpāni a kubbamānaḥ
translated: “One who has rightly directed speech and mind, And who does no evil by body,

original: Bahunnapānaṃ gharamāvasanto, saddho mudū saṃvibhāgī vadaññū;
analyzed: bahunnapānam gharam āvasantaḥ saddhaḥ mudū saṃvibhāgī vadaññū
translated: Who lives in a house with much food and drink, Who is faithful, gentle, generous, and charitable,

original: Saṅgāhako sakhilo saṇhavāco, etthaṭṭhito paralokaṃ na bhāye”ti.🔽Tassattho – bhadde, udaye vācaṃ manañca sammā ṭhapetvā kāyena pāpāni akaronto ime
analyzed: saṅgāhakaḥ sa khilaḥ saṇha vācaḥ ettha ṭṭhitaḥ para lokam na bhāyeti  tassa atthaḥ bhadde udaye vācam manañca sammā ṭhapetvā kāyena pāpāni a karontaḥ ime
translated: A giver, a gatherer, a friend, a man of gentle speech, Standing here, he need not fear the world beyond.”🔽The meaning is: “My dear, if you will set your speech and thought aright, and if you will not do evil with your body, and if you will take upon yourself and observe these ten paths of good conduct,

original: dasa kusalakammapathe samādāya vattanto bahuannapāne pahūtadeyyadhamme ghare vasanto
analyzed: dasa kusala kamma pathe samādāya vattantaḥ bahu anna pāne pahūta deyya dhamme ghare vasantaḥ
translated: and if you will live in a house with plenty of food and drink and with much wealth to give away,

original: “dānassa vipāko atthī”ti saddhāya samannāgato muducitto dānasaṃvibhāgatāya saṃvibhāgī
analyzed: dānassa vipākaḥ atthi iti saddhāya samannāgataḥ mudu cittaḥ dāna saṃvibhāga tāya saṃvibhāgī
translated: and if you will be endowed with faith, thinking, ‘There is a result of giving,’ and if you will be tender-hearted, and if you will be a sharer of your food and drink through the practice of sharing,

original: pabbajitā bhikkhāya caramānā vadanti nāma, tesaṃ paccayadānena tassa vādassa jānanato
analyzed: pabbajitāḥ bhikkhāya caramānāḥ vadanti nāma tesam paccaya dānena tassa vādassa jānanato
translated: and if you will know the words of those who go forth into homelessness and wander about for alms, through giving them the requisites they need,

original: vadaññū catūhi saṅgahavatthūhi saṅgahatāya saṅgāhako piyavāditāya sakhilo maṭṭhavacanatāya
analyzed: vadaññū catūhi saṅgaha vatthūhi saṅgaha tāya saṅgāhakaḥ piya vādi tāya sa khilaḥ maṭṭha vacana tāya
translated: and if you will be a giver, and if you will be a gatherer through the four means of gathering disciples, and if you will be a friend through being a man of pleasant speech, and if you will be a man of gentle speech through being a man of soft words,

original: saṇhavāco ettha ettake guṇarāsimhi ṭhito paralokaṃ gacchanto na bhāyatīti.
analyzed: saṇha vācaḥ ettha ettake guṇa rāsimhi ṭhitaḥ para lokam gacchantaḥ na bhāyati iti
translated: standing here in this heap of virtues, you need not fear the world beyond as you go there.”

original: Tato rājadhītā taṃ tassa vacanaṃ sutvā thutiṃ karontī itaraṃ gāthamāha –🔽“Anusāsasi maṃ yakkha, yathā mātā yathā pitā;
analyzed: tatas rāja dhītā tam tassa vacanam sutvā thutim karontī itaram gātham āha 🔽anusāsasi mam yakkha yathā mātā yathā pitā
translated: Then the king’s daughter, having heard his words, spoke the next verse in praise of him:

original: Uḷāravaṇṇa pucchāmi, ko nu tvamasi subrahā”ti.
analyzed: uḷāra vaṇṇa pucchāmi kaḥ nu tvam asi subrahā ati
translated: I ask thee, O thou of wondrous hue, who art thou, O most excellent one?”

original: Tassattho – yathā mātāpitaro puttake anusāsanti, tathā maṃ anusāsasi. Uḷāravaṇṇa sobhaggappattarūpadāraka ko nu asi tvaṃ evaṃ accuggatasarīroti.
analyzed: tassa atthaḥ yathā mātā pitaraḥ puttake anusāsanti tathā mama anusāsasi uḷāra vaṇṇa sobhagga ppatta rūpa dāraka kaḥ nu asi tvam evam accuggata sarīraḥ ti
translated: The meaning is this: “As parents instruct their children, so dost thou instruct me. Thou of wondrous hue, thou of beautiful form, who art thou, that hast come hither in this exalted shape?”

original: Tato bodhisatto itaraṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: tatas bodhisatto itaram gātham āha
translated: Then the Bodhisatta spoke the second stanza:

original: “Udayohamasmi kalyāṇi, saṅgarattā idhāgato;
analyzed: udayā uham asmi kalyāṇi saṅga rattā idha āgataḥ
translated: “I am Udaya, O my dear, who come hither for the sake of love;

original: Āmanta kho taṃ gacchāmi, muttosmi tava saṅgarā”ti.
analyzed: āmanta kho tam gacchāmi muttaḥ asmi tava saṅgarāti
translated: I will go, I call thee back, I am free from thy bonds of love.”

original: Tassattho – kalyāṇadassane ahaṃ purimabhave tava sāmiko udayo nāma tāvatiṃsabhavane
analyzed: kalyāṇadassane aham purima bhave tava sāmikaḥ udayaḥ nāma tāvatiṃsa bhavane
translated: The meaning is this: “O thou of beautiful eyes, in a previous state of existence I was thy husband, the Thirty-three gods,

original: sakko hutvā nibbatto, idhāgacchanto na kilesavasenāgato, taṃ vīmaṃsitvā pana saṅgaraṃ
analyzed: sakkaḥ hutvā nibbattaḥ idha āgacchantaḥ na kilesa vasena āgataḥ tam vīmaṃsitvā pana saṅgaram
translated: I have come hither, not because of passion, but having tested thee, I will set thee free from the bonds of love.

original: mocessāmīti saṅgarattā pubbe saṅgarassa katattā āgatosmi, idāni taṃ āmantetvā gacchāmi,
analyzed: mocessāmi iti saṅgara ttā pubbe saṅgarassa kata ttā āgataḥ asmi idāni tam āmantetvā gacchāmi
translated: Because in the past I made love, I have come hither for the sake of love. Now I will call thee back and go.

original: muttosmi tava saṅgarāti.
analyzed: muttaḥ asmi tava saṅgarāti
translated: I am free from thy bonds of love.”

original: Rājadhītā assasitvā “sāmi, tvaṃ udayabhaddarājā”ti assudhārā pavattayamānā “ahaṃ
analyzed: rājadhītā sāmi tvam udayabhadda rājā ati assudhārā pavattayamānā aham
translated: The princess, sighing, said: “My lord, thou art King Udaya the Fair.” And she wept, and said:

original: tumhehi vinā vasituṃ na sakkomi, yathā tumhākaṃ santike vasāmi, tathā maṃ anusāsathā”ti
analyzed: tumhehi vinā vasitum na sakkomi yathā tumhākam santike vasāmi tathā mama anusāsatha ati
translated: I cannot live without you. Teach me, Prince, how I may live with you.”

original: vatvā itaraṃ gāthaṃ abhāsi –
analyzed: vatvā itaram gātham abhāsi
translated: And he spoke the second stanza:

original: “Sace kho tvaṃ udayosi, saṅgarattā idhāgato;
analyzed: sace khalu tvam udayosi saṅga rattā idha āgataḥ
translated: “If you, Udaya, have come here, loving union,

original: Anusāsa maṃ rājaputta, yathāssa puna saṅgamo”ti.
analyzed: anusāsa mama rāja putta yathā assa puna saṅgamaḥ ti
translated: Teach me, Prince, how we may meet again.”

original: Atha naṃ anusāsanto mahāsatto catasso gāthā abhāsi –
analyzed: atha nam anusāsantaḥ mahāsatto catassaḥ gāthāḥ abhāsi
translated: Then the Great Being, in teaching him, spoke the four stanzas:

original: “Atipatati vayo khaṇo tatheva, ṭhānaṃ natthi dhuvaṃ cavanti sattā;
analyzed: atipatati vayaḥ khaṇo tathā iva ṭhānam natthi dhuvam cavanti sattā
translated: “Life passes quickly, the moment is fleeting, there is no fixed time, beings are transient;

original: Parijīyati addhuvaṃ sarīraṃ, udaye mā pamāda carassu dhammaṃ.
analyzed: parijīyati addhuvam sarīram udaye mā pamāda carassu dhammaṃ
translated: The body is decaying, not lasting, Udaya, do not be heedless, but live the life of righteousness.

original: “Kasiṇā pathavī dhanassa pūrā, ekasseva siyā anaññadheyyā;
analyzed: kasiṇā pathavī dhanassa pūrā ekassa iva siyā anaññadheyyā
translated: “The earth is full of treasure, enough for all, not to be given to another;

original: Taṃ cāpi jahati avītarāgo, udaye mā pamāda carassu dhammaṃ.
analyzed: tam ca api jahati a vīta rāgaḥ udaye mā pamāda carassu dhammaṃ
translated: But he who dies, not free from passion, leaves it all, Udaya, do not be heedless, but live the life of righteousness.

original: “Mātā ca pitā ca bhātaro ca, bhariyā yāpi dhanena hoti kītā;
analyzed: mātā ca pitā ca bhātaro ca bhariyā yā api dhanena hoti kītā
translated: “Mother and father, brothers, wife, whom one loves with wealth,

original: Te cāpi jahanti aññamaññaṃ, udaye mā pamāda carassu dhammaṃ.
analyzed: te ca api jahanti aññamaññam udaye mā pamāda carassu dhammaṃ
translated: They all leave one another, Udaya, do not be heedless, but live the life of righteousness.

original: “Kāyo parabhojananti ñatvā, saṃsāre sugatiñca duggatiñca;
analyzed: saṃsāre sugatiñca duggatiñca
translated: “Knowing that the body is another’s food, in the round of existences, good and bad states of existence,

analyzed: ittaravāso ti jāniyānaḥ udaye mā pamāda carassu  tattha atipatati iti ativiya patati sīgham atikkamati  vayaḥ khaṇo tathā iva ati uppāda ṭṭhiti bhaṅga khaṇaḥ api tathā iva atipatati ubhayena api bhinnaḥ
translated: “The life span passes quickly, the life span passes swiftly;🔽Do not be negligent, O man, be heedful at the break of day.”🔽Herein, it passes quickly means it passes very quickly, it goes away swiftly. Mā pamādanti tasmā

analyzed: tvam udayabhadde mā pamādam āpajji a pamattā hutvā dasa kusala kammapatha dhammam carāhi iti
translated: You, Udayabhadda, should not fall into negligence. Being heedful, you should live by the Dhamma of the ten courses of wholesome action.”

original: ākāse ṭhatvā ovādaṃ datvā anilapatheneva uttarahimavantaṃ gantvā ramaṇīye padese
analyzed: ākāse ṭhatvā ovādam da tvā anila pathena iva uttara himavantam gantvā ramaṇīye padese
translated: I am going forth into homelessness.” And rising up into the air, he gave them advice, and then went to the Himalayas by the way of the wind.

original: assamaṃ māpetvā isipabbajjaṃ pabbajitvā āyupariyosāne brahmalokaparāyaṇo ahosi.🔽Satthā imaṃ dhammadesanaṃ āharitvā “bhikkhave, kileso khuddako nāma natthi, appamattakopi
analyzed: assamam māpetvā isipabbajjam pabbajitvā āyu pariyosāne brahma loka parāyaṇaḥ ahosi  satthā imam dhamma desanam āharitvā bhikkhave kilesaḥ khuddakaḥ nāma natthi appamattakaḥ api
translated: There he built a hermitage in a delightful spot, and having gone forth as a seer, he passed away and was reborn in the Brahma-world.

original: paṇḍitehi niggahitabboyevā”ti vatvā saccāni pakāsetvā jātakaṃ samodhānesi, saccapariyosāne
analyzed: paṇḍitehi niggahitabbaḥ yā eva ati vatvā saccāni pakāsetvā jātakam samodhānesi sacca pariyosāne
translated: When the Teacher had related this story, he said, “Monks, there is no such thing as a trifling passion. Even the smallest passion must be suppressed by the wise.” So saying, he expounded the Law by pronouncing the following Stanza,

original: pañcasatā bhikkhū arahatte patiṭṭhahiṃsu. Tadā paccekabuddhā parinibbāyiṃsu, devī
analyzed: pañcasatā bhikkhū arahatte patiṭṭhahiṃsu tadā paccekabuddhā parinibbāyiṃsu devī
translated: and established five hundred monks in Arahatship. At that time the Private Buddhas passed into Nibbāna. The queen

original: rāhulamātā ahosi, rājā pana ahameva ahosinti.🔽Pānīyajātakavaṇṇanā pañcamā.
analyzed: rāhula mātā rājā pana aham eva  pānīya jātaka vaṇṇanā pañcamā
translated: was Rāhulamātā, and I myself was the king.”🔽So said the Exalted One, and the monks rejoiced in his words.

original: [460] 6. Yudhañcayajātakavaṇṇanā
translated: The Story of the Elder Yudhañjaya

original: Mittāmaccaparibyūḷhanti idaṃ satthā jetavane viharanto mahābhinikkhamanaṃ ārabbha🔽kathesi. Ekadivasañhi dhammasabhāyaṃ sannipatitā bhikkhū “āvuso, sace dasabalo agāraṃ
analyzed: mitta amacca paribyūḷhanti idam satthāḥ jetavane viharantaḥ mahā abhinikkhamanam ārabbha  kathesi eka divasam hi dhamma sabhāyam sannipatitāḥ bhikkhū āvuso sace dasabalaḥ agāram
translated: “He who is surrounded by friends and relatives” was told by the Master while dwelling in Jetavana, concerning the Great Renunciation.

original: ajjhāvasissa, sakalacakkavāḷagabbhe cakkavattirājā abhavissa sattaratanasamannāgato🔽caturiddhīhi samiddho parosahassaputtaparivāro, so evarūpaṃ sirivibhavaṃ pahāya kāmesu
analyzed: ajjhāvasissa sakala cakkavāḷa gabbhe cakkavatti rājā abhavissa satta ratana samannāgato  catur iddhīhi samiddhaḥ parosahassa putta parivāro saḥ evarūpam siri vibhavam pahāya kāmesu
translated: For one day the monks assembled in the Hall of Truth and said, “Brethren, had the Master remained in the world, he would have become a Universal Monarch, possessing the Seven Treasures and the Four Kinds of Success, with a retinue of a thousand kings, and the sovereignty of the whole world.

original: dosaṃ disvā aḍḍharattasamaye channasahāyova kaṇṭakamāruyha nikkhamitvā anomanadītīre
analyzed: dosam disvā aḍḍha ratta samaye channa sahāyā iva kaṇṭakam āruyha nikkhamitvā anoma nadī tīre
translated: But he renounced such glory and splendor, and beholding the vanity of pleasures of sense, at midnight, with Channa for companion, mounting Kaṇṭhaka, he went forth from home into the homeless state.🔽And on the banks of the river Anomā he took upon himself the vows of a monk, and for six years he practiced the austerities. And then he attained Supreme and Perfect Buddhahood.”

original: pabbajitvā chabbassāni dukkarakārikaṃ katvā sammāsambodhiṃ patto”ti satthu guṇakathaṃ
analyzed: pabbajitvā cha bassāni dukkara kārikam katvā sammāsambodhim patto ti satthu guṇa katham
translated: And they praised the Master’s virtues.

original: kathayiṃsu. Satthā āgantvā “kāya nuttha, bhikkhave, etarahi kathāya sannisinnā”ti
analyzed: kathayiṃsu satthā āgantvā kāya nuttha bhikkhave etarahi kathāya sannisinnā ati
translated: and related the following

original: pucchitvā “imāya nāmā”ti vutte “na, bhikkhave, tathāgato idāneva mahābhinikkhamanaṃ🔽nikkhanto, pubbepi dvādasayojanike bārāṇasinagare rajjaṃ pahāya nikkhantoyevā”ti vatvā atītaṃ āhari.
analyzed: pucchitvā imāya nāma ati vutte na bhikkhave tathāgataḥ idānā iva mahā abhinikkhamanam  nikkhantaḥ pubbe pi dvādasa yojanike bārāṇasi nagare rajjam pahāya nikkhantaḥ yeva ati vatvā atītam āhari
translated: Jātaka: “Monks, this is not the first time the Tathāgata has gone forth into homelessness; in a previous existence also he went forth.”

original: Atīte rammanagare sabbadatto nāma rājā ahosi. Ayañhi bārāṇasī udayajātake surundhananagaraṃ
analyzed: atīte ramma nagare sabbadattaḥ nāma rājā ahosi ayan hi bārāṇasī udaya jātake surundhana nagaram
translated: In the past, in the city of Ramma, there was a king named Sabbadatta. This city of Bārāṇasī was called the city of Surundha in the Udaya Jātaka,

original: nāma jātā, cūḷasutasomajātake sudassanaṃ nāma, soṇanandajātake brahmavaḍḍhanaṃ nāma,
analyzed: nāma jātā cūḷa suta soma jātake sudassanam nāma soṇa nanda jātake brahmavaḍḍhanam nāma
translated: the city of Sudassana in the Cūḷasutasoma Jātaka, the city of Brahmavaḍḍhana in the Soṇanand Jātaka,

original: khaṇḍahālajātake pupphavatī nāma, saṅkhabrāhmaṇajātake moḷinī nāma, imasmiṃ pana
analyzed: khaṇḍahāla jātake pupphavatī nāma saṅkha brāhmaṇa jātake moḷinī nāma imasmin pana
translated: the city of Pupphavatī in the Khaṇḍahāla Jātaka, the city of Moḷi in the Saṅkha Brāhmaṇa Jātaka, and in this

original: yudhañcayajātake rammanagaraṃ nāma ahosi. Evamassā kadāci nāmaṃ parivattati. Tattha
analyzed: yudhañcaya jātake rammanagaram nāma ahosi evam assā kadāci nāmam parivattati tattha
translated: Yudhañjaya Jātaka it was called the city of Ramma. Thus sometimes its name changes.

original: sabbadattarañño puttasahassaṃ ahosi. Yudhañcayassa nāma jeṭṭhaputtassa uparajjaṃ
analyzed: sabbadatta raññaḥ putta sahassam ahosi yudhañcayassa nāma jeṭṭha puttassa uparajjam
translated: There, King Sabbadatta had a thousand sons. The eldest son, named Yudhañjaya, was made crown prince.

original: adāsi. So divase divase mahādānaṃ pavattesi. Evaṃ gacchante kāle bodhisatto ekadivasaṃ🔽pātova rathavaramāruyha mahantena sirivibhavena uyyānakīḷaṃ gacchanto rukkhaggatiṇaggasākhaggamakkaṭakasuttajālādīsu
analyzed: adāsi saḥ divase divase mahādānam pavattesi evam gacchante kāle bodhisattaḥ eka divasam  pāta uva ratha varam āruyha mahantena siri vibhavena uyyāna kīḷam gacchantaḥ rukkhagga tiṇagga sākhagga makkaṭaka sutta jāla ādīsu
translated: and he gave it. He made a great distribution of gifts every day. As time went on, one day the Bodhisatta🔽mounted his chariot in the morning and went to the pleasure garden with great pomp and ceremony. As he went along he saw drops of dew clinging to the tops of trees, grass, and branches, like pearl-nets,

original: muttājālākārena laggitaussavabindūni disvā “samma sārathi, kiṃ nāmeta”nti pucchitvā
analyzed: muttā jāla ākārena laggita aussava bindūni disvā samma sārathi kim nāma etat ti pucchitvā
translated: and asked, “What are these, charioteer?”

original: “ete deva, himasamaye patanakaussavabindūni nāmā”ti sutvā divasabhāgaṃ uyyāne kīḷitvā
analyzed: ete deva hima samaye patana kaussava bindūni nāma ati sutvā divasa bhāgam uyyāne kīḷitvā
translated: “These are drops of dew, your majesty, which fall in the cold weather.” After playing in the garden for the day,

original: sāyanhakāle paccāgacchanto te adisvāva “samma sārathi, kahaṃ nu kho ete ussavabindū,
analyzed: sāyanha kāle paccāgacchanto te a disvāva samma sārathi kaham nu kho ete ussava bindū
translated: he returned in the evening. Not seeing the drops of dew, he asked, “Charioteer, where are those drops of dew?

original: na te idāni passāmī”ti pucchi. “Deva, te sūriye uggacchante sabbeva bhijjitvā pathaviyaṃ
analyzed: na te idāni passāmi iti pucchi deva te sūriye uggacchante sabbā iva bhijjitvā pathaviyam
translated: I do not see them now.” “Your majesty, when the sun rises they all break up and fall to the ground.”

original: patantī”ti sutvā saṃvegappatto hutvā “imesaṃ sattānaṃ jīvitasaṅkhārāpi tiṇagge ussavabindusadisāva,
analyzed: patanti iti sutvā saṃvega pattaḥ hutvā imesam sattānam jīvita saṅkhārā api tiṇagge ussava bindu sadisā ava
translated: Hearing this, he was overcome with emotion and thought, “The life-span of these beings is like the drops of dew on the tips of the grass,

original: mayā byādhijarāmaraṇehi apīḷiteyeva mātāpitaro āpucchitvā pabbajituṃ vaṭṭatī”ti ussavabindumeva
analyzed: mayā byādhi jarā maraṇehi mātā pitaraḥ āpucchitvā pabbajitum vaṭṭati iti ussava bindum eva
translated: “I must go forth, having asked leave of my parents, who are oppressed by sickness, old age, and death.”

original: ārammaṇaṃ katvā āditte viya tayo bhave passanto attano gehaṃ agantvā alaṅkatapaṭiyattāya
analyzed: ārammaṇam katvā āditte viya tayaḥ bhave passantaḥ attanaḥ geham a gantvā alaṅkata paṭiyattāya
translated: And making the drop of the festival his object, he saw the three worlds as if ablaze with fire.🔽Without going to his own house, he went straight to his father, who was seated in the judgment hall,

original: vinicchayasālāya nisinnassa pitu santikaṃyeva gantvā pitaraṃ vanditvā ekamantaṃ ṭhito
analyzed: vinicchaya sālāya nisinnassa pitu santikam yā iva gantvā pitaram vanditvā ekamantam ṭhitaḥ
translated: and after paying obeisance to him, he stood at one side

original: pabbajjaṃ yācanto paṭhamaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: pabbajjam yācantaḥ paṭhamam gātham āha
translated: and asked for the going forth, reciting the first stanza:🔽“I pay my homage to the chariot-borne,

original: “Mittāmaccaparibyūḷhaṃ, ahaṃ vande rathesabhaṃ;
analyzed: aham vande rathesabham
translated: Who is surrounded by his friends and kinsmen;🔽I will go forth, O King,

original: Pabbajissāmahaṃ rāja, taṃ devo anumaññatū”ti.
analyzed: pabbajissāmaham rāja tam devaḥ anumaññatu uti
translated: And may your Majesty give me leave to do so.”

original: Tattha paribyūḷhanti parivāritaṃ. Taṃ devoti taṃ mama pabbajjaṃ devo anujānātūti attho.
analyzed: tattha paribyūḷhanti parivāritam tam devaḥ iti tam mama pabbajjam devaḥ anujānātu iti attho
translated: Here “surrounded” means surrounded by. The meaning is: “May your Majesty give me leave to go forth.”

original: Atha naṃ rājā nivārento dutiyaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: atha nam rājā nivārentaḥ dutiyam gātham āha
translated: Then the King, trying to dissuade him, recited the second stanza:🔽“If there be any lack of sensual pleasures,

original: “Sace te ūnaṃ kāmehi, ahaṃ paripūrayāmi te;
analyzed: sace te ūnam kāmehi aham paripūrayāmi te
translated: I will supply the lack;🔽I will punish him who injures you;

original: Yo taṃ hiṃ sati vāremi, mā pabbaja yudhañcayā”ti.
analyzed: yaḥ tam him sati vāremi mā pabbaja
translated: Do not go forth, but enjoy yourself.”

original: Taṃ sutvā kumāro tatiyaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: tam sutvā kumāraḥ tatiyam gātham āha
translated: On hearing this, the prince recited the third stanza:

original: “Na matthi ūnaṃ kāmehi, hiṃsitā me na vijjati;
analyzed: na matthi ūnam kāmehi hiṃsitā me na vijjati
translated: I have no one who afflicts me.

original: Dīpañca kātumicchāmi, yaṃ jarā nābhikīratī”ti.
analyzed: dīpam ca kātum icchāmi yam jarā na abhikīrati iti
translated: I wish to make an island, one that old age cannot invade.”

original: Tattha dīpañcāti tāta neva mayhaṃ kāmehi ūnaṃ atthi, na maṃ hiṃsanto koci vijjati,
analyzed: tattha dīpam ca ati tāta na iva mayham kāmehi ūnam atthi na mam hiṃsantaḥ koci vijjati
translated: Herein, an island means that, dear Father, I have no lack of sensual pleasures, nor is there anyone who afflicts me,

original: ahaṃ pana paralokagamanāya attano patiṭṭhaṃ kātumicchāmi. Kīdisaṃ? Yaṃ jarā nābhikīrati
analyzed: aham pana para loka gamanāya patiṭṭham kātum icchāmi kīdisam yam jarā na abhikīrati
translated: but I wish to make a support for myself in going to the other world. What sort? One that old age cannot invade,

original: na viddhaṃseti, tamahaṃ kātumicchāmi, amatamahānibbānaṃ gavesissāmi, na me kāmehi
analyzed: na viddhaṃseti tam aham kātum icchāmi amata mahānibbānam gavesissāmi na me kāmehi
translated: one that is not destroyed. I wish to make that, I wish to seek the great deathless Nibbāna, I have no need of sensual pleasures,

original: attho, anujānātha maṃ, mahārājāti vadati.
analyzed: atthaḥ anujānātha mama mahā rāja iti vadati
translated: give me permission, Great King.”

original: Iti punappunaṃ kumāro pabbajjaṃ yāci, rājā “mā pabbajā”ti vāreti. Tamatthamāvikaronto satthā upaḍḍhaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: iti punappunam kumāraḥ pabbajjam yāci rājā mā pabbajāti vāreti tam attham āvikarontaḥ satthā upaḍḍham gātham āha
translated: Thus the prince asked for the going forth again and again, and the king restrained him, saying, “Do not go forth.” Expounding that matter, the Teacher uttered the first half of the stanza:

original: “Putto vā pitaraṃ yāce, pitā vā puttamorasa”nti.
analyzed: puttaḥ vā pitaram yāce pitā vā
translated: “A son may ask his father, or a father may ask his son.”

original: Tattha vā-kāro sampiṇḍanattho. Idaṃ vuttaṃ hoti – “evaṃ, bhikkhave, putto ca pitaraṃ yācati, pitā ca orasaṃ puttaṃ yācatī”ti.
analyzed: tattha vākāraḥ sampiṇḍana atthaḥ idam vuttam hoti evam bhikkhave putto ca pitaram yācati pitā ca orasam puttam yācati iti
translated: Herein, the word vā has the meaning of “and.” This is what is said: “Thus, monks, a son asks his father, and a father asks his son.”

original: Sesaṃ upaḍḍhagāthaṃ rājā āha –
analyzed: sesam upaḍḍha gātham rājā āha
translated: The rest of the verse the king spoke:

original: “Negamo taṃ yāce tāta, mā pabbaja yudhañcayā”ti.
analyzed: negamaḥ tam yāce tāta mā pabbaja
translated: “The village folk beg you, dear son, do not go forth, O you who are dear to me.”

original: Tassattho – ayaṃ te tāta nigamavāsimahājano yācati, nagarajanopi mā tvaṃ pabbajāti.
analyzed: tassa atthaḥ ayam te tāta nigama vāsi mahā janaḥ yācati nagara janaḥ api mā tvam pabbajāti
translated: The meaning is: “This great multitude of village folk here begs you, dear son, and the people of the city also beg you, do not go forth.”

original: Kumāro punapi pañcamaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: pañcamam gātham āha
translated: The prince spoke a fifth verse:

original: “Mā maṃ deva nivārehi, pabbajantaṃ rathesabha;
analyzed: mā mama deva nivārehi pabbajantam rathesabha
translated: “Do not hinder me, O King, as I go forth, O you who are like a chariot;

original: Māhaṃ kāmehi sammatto, jarāya vasamanvagū”ti.🔽Tattha vasamanvagūti mā ahaṃ kāmehi sammatto pamatto jarāya vasagāmī nāma homi, vaṭṭadukkhaṃ
analyzed: mā aham kāmehi sammattaḥ jarāya  tattha mā aham kāmehi sammattaḥ pamattaḥ jarāya vasa gāmī nāma homi vaṭṭa dukkham
translated: Do not let me be overcome by lust, and come under the sway of old age.”

original: pana khepetvā yathā ca sabbaññutaññāṇappaṭivijjhanako homi,. Tathā maṃ olokehīti adhippāyo.🔽Evaṃ vutte rājā appaṭibhāṇo ahosi. Mātā panassa “putto te, devi, pitaraṃ pabbajjaṃ
analyzed: pana khepetvā yathā ca sabbaññu ta ññāṇa paṭivijjhanakaḥ homi tathā mama olokehi iti adhippāyaḥ  evam vutte rājā appaṭibhāṇaḥ ahosi mātā pana assa putto te devi pitaram pabbajjam
translated: Herein, come under the sway means: do not let me be overcome by lust, and come under the sway of old age, and be called one who is heedless. But rather, O King, look on me as one who will put an end to the suffering of the round of rebirths, and as one who will penetrate to the knowledge of omniscience.

original: anujānāpetī”ti sutvā “kiṃ tumhe kathethā”ti nirassāsena mukhena suvaṇṇasivikāya nisīditvā
analyzed: anujānāpeti iti sutvā kim tumhe kathetha iti nirassāsena mukhena suvaṇṇa sivikāya nisīditvā
translated: When this was said, the king was speechless. But his mother, hearing that “Your son, Queen, is asking your permission to go forth,” said: “What are you saying?” and sat down on a golden couch with a sorrowful face.

original: sīghaṃ vinicchayaṭṭhānaṃ gantvā yācamānā chaṭṭhaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: sīgham vinicchaya ṭṭhānam gantvā yācamānā chaṭṭham gātham āha
translated: and going quickly to the place of judgment, she spoke the sixth stanza:

original: “Ahaṃ taṃ tāta yācāmi, ahaṃ putta nivāraye;
analyzed: aham tam tāta yācāmi aham putta nivāraye
translated: “I beg you, father, I entreat you, I pray you, my son, to stay;

original: Ciraṃ taṃ daṭṭhumicchāmi, mā pabbaja yudhañcayā”ti.
analyzed: ciram tam daṭṭhum icchāmi mā pabbaja
translated: I long to see you long, do not go forth, my Yodhañjaya.”

original: Taṃ sutvā kumāro sattamaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: tam sutvā kumāraḥ sattamam gātham āha
translated: When the prince heard this, he spoke the seventh stanza:

original: “Ussāvova tiṇaggamhi, sūriyuggamanaṃ pati;
analyzed: ussāva uva tiṇaggamhi sūri yuj gamanam pati
translated: “As the dew-drop on the tip of the blade of grass🔽cannot endure the rising of the sun,

original: Evamāyu manussānaṃ, mā maṃ amma nivārayā”ti.
analyzed: evamāyu manussānam mā mama amma nivāraya ati
translated: so is the life of men, do not, mother, hinder me.”

original: Tassattho – amma, yathā tiṇagge ussavabindu sūriyassa uggamanaṃ patiṭṭhātuṃ na sakkoti,
analyzed: tassa atthaḥ amma yathā tiṇagge ussava bindu sūriyassa uggamanam patiṭṭhātum na sakkoti
translated: The meaning is this: Mother, as the dew-drop on the tip of the blade of grass cannot endure the rising of the sun,

original: pathaviyaṃ patati, evaṃ imesaṃ sattānaṃ jīvitaṃ parittaṃ tāvakālikaṃ aciraṭṭhitikaṃ,
analyzed: pathaviyam patati evam imesam sattānam jīvitam parittam tāvakālikam aciraṭṭhitikam
translated: but falls to the ground, so is the life of these beings limited, temporary, not lasting long;

original: evarūpe lokasannivāse kathaṃ tvaṃ ciraṃ maṃ passasi, mā maṃ nivārehīti.
analyzed: evarūpe loka sannivāse katham tvam ciram mam passasi mā mama nivārehi iti
translated: in such a world as this, how can you see me long? Do not hinder me.

original: Evaṃ vuttepi sā punappunaṃ yāciyeva. Tato mahāsatto pitaraṃ āmantetvā aṭṭhamaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: evam vutte api sā punappunam yāciyā iva tatas mahāsattaḥ pitaram āmantetvā aṭṭhamam gātham āha
translated: Although she was thus addressed, she still entreated him again and again. Then the Great Being, addressing his father, spoke the eighth stanza:

original: “Taramāno imaṃ yānaṃ, āropetu rathesabha;
analyzed: taramānaḥ imam yānam āropetu rathesabha
translated: “Mount this chariot, O lord of chariots, and cross over this river;

original: Mā me mātā tarantassa, antarāyakarā ahū”ti.
analyzed: mā me mātā tarantassa antarāya karā ahūti
translated: Let not my mother be an obstacle to me as I cross over.”

analyzed: tassa sarīra kiccam kāretvā devī attano puttassa bharata kumārassa chattam

analyzed: ussāpetha iti āha amaccāḥ pana chatta sāmikāḥ araññe vasanti iti na bharata kumāro

analyzed: gahetvā caturaṅginiyā senāya tassa vasanaṭṭhānam patvā avidūre khandhāvāram katvā  tattha nivāsetvā katipayehi amaccehi saddhim lakkhaṇapaṇḍitassa ca sītāya ca araññam
translated: and with an army of four divisions went to the place where Rāma was living. He encamped not far away,

original: gatakāle assamapadaṃ pavisitvā assamapadadvāre ṭhapitakañcanarūpakaṃ viya rāmapaṇḍitaṃ
analyzed: gata kāle assama padam pavisitvā assama pada dvāre ṭhapita kañcana rūpakam rāma paṇḍitam

analyzed: saddhim amaccehi pādesu patitvā rodati rāma paṇḍito pana na iva soci na paridevi
translated: He fell at his feet with his ministers and wept. But the wise Rāma neither grieved nor lamented,

original: indriyavikāramattampissa nāhosi. Bharatassa pana roditvā nisinnakāle sāyanhasamaye
analyzed: indriya vikāra mattam pissa na ahosi bharatassa pana roditvā nisinna kāle sāyanha samaye
translated: but he did not change his expression. When Bharata had sat down and was weeping,

analyzed: itare dve phala aphalam ādāya āgamiṃsu rāma paṇḍito cintesi ime daharāḥ mayham

analyzed: pariggaṇhana paññā etesam na atthi sahasā pitā vaḥ mataḥ iti vutte sokam sandhāretuṃ

analyzed: hotu imam udakam otaritvā tiṭṭhatha iti upaḍḍha gātham tāva āha

analyzed: tassatthaḥ etha lakkhaṇa sītā ca āgacchatha ubho pi otaratha udakanti

analyzed: ahesun ti evam yāvatatiyam visaññitam patte te amaccāḥ ukkhipitvā udakā nīharitvā thale

translated: “What cannot be preserved by the many lamentations of the kinsmen,

translated: “For whether young or whether old, whether foolish or whether wise,

analyzed: pātaḥ eke na dissanti sāyam diṭṭhāḥ bahujjanā
translated: And some are not seen in the morning who were seen in the evening.

analyzed: paridevayamānaḥ ce kiñcid attham
translated: “If, while lamenting, one should find some purpose,

analyzed: sammūḍhaḥ hiṃsa mattānam kayirā tam vicakkhaṇo

translated: “One becomes thin, pale,

analyzed: yathā saraṇam ādittam vārinā parinibbaye
translated: with water,🔽so the wise, learned,

translated: intelligent person

analyzed: na buddha ādīnam paṇḍitānam na cakkavatti ādīnam issarānam na niddhanānam dalidda ādīnam

original: lajjati, sabbepime sattā maccuparāyaṇā maraṇamukhe saṃbhaggavibhaggā bhavantiyevā”ti dassanatthaṃ vuttā.
analyzed: lajjati sabbe pi ime sattāḥ maccu parāyaṇāḥ maraṇa mukhe saṃbhagga vibhaggāḥ bhavantiyā iva ati dassana attham vuttā

analyzed: niccam patanato ti idam vuttam hoti yathā hi tāta bharata pakkānam phalānam pakka kālataḥ

analyzed: paṭṭhāya idāni vaṇṭā chijjitvā patissanti idāni patissanti iti patanataḥ bhayam niccam  dhuvam ekaṃsikam eva bhavati evam āsaṅkanīyataḥ evam jātānam maccānam pi ekaṃsikaṃ yā iva
translated: there is constantly, always, invariably, the danger of their falling, “Now they will be cut from their stalks and fall, now they will fall,”

original: maraṇato bhayaṃ, natthi so khaṇo vā layo vā yattha tesaṃ maraṇaṃ na āsaṅkitabbaṃ bhaveyyāti.🔽Sāyanti vikāle. Iminā rattibhāge ca diṭṭhānaṃ divasabhāge adassanaṃ, divasabhāge
analyzed: maraṇataḥ bhayam natthi saḥ khaṇaḥ vā layaḥ vā yattha tesam maraṇam na āsaṅkitabbam bhaveyya ati  sāyanti vikāle ratti bhāge ca diṭṭhānam divasa bhāge adassanam divasa bhāge
translated: so too, from the time when beings are born, there is invariably the danger of death for them; there is no time or occasion when the fear of death need not be expected for them.

original: ca diṭṭhānaṃ rattibhāge adassanaṃ dīpeti. Kiñcidatthanti “pitā me, putto me”tiādīhi
analyzed: ca diṭṭhānam ratti bhāge adassanam dīpeti kiñcid atthanti pitā me putto mā iti ādīhi
translated: They go in the evening: by this he shows that those seen in the night are not seen in the day and those seen in the day are not seen at night. “For some purpose”: by this he shows that they go for the purpose of seeing their parents, children, etc., and that they do not go for the purpose of seeing other beings.

original: paridevamānova poso sammūḷho attānaṃ hiṃsanto kilamento appamattakampi atthaṃ āhareyya.
analyzed: paridevamānaḥ iva posaḥ sammūḍhaḥ attānam hiṃsantaḥ kilamentaḥ appamattakam pi attham āhareyya
translated: A man who laments, being confused, harms himself, and being distressed, would bring about no benefit at all.

original: Kayirā taṃ vicakkhaṇoti atha paṇḍito puriso evaṃ paridevaṃ kareyya, yasmā pana paridevanto
analyzed: tam vicakkhaṇā ti atha paṇḍitaḥ purisaḥ evam paridevam kareyya yasmai pana paridevanto
translated: One should do this with insight: but a wise man would lament in this way. But because by lamenting

original: mataṃ vā ānetuṃ aññaṃ vā tassa vaḍḍhiṃ kātuṃ na sakkoti, tasmā niratthakattā paridevitassa
analyzed: matam vā ānetum aññam vā tassa vaḍḍhim kātum na sakkoti tasmā niratthaka ttā paridevitassa
translated: he cannot bring back the dead or increase the life of the living, therefore,

original: paṇḍitā na paridevanti.
analyzed: paṇḍitāḥ na paridevanti
translated: because of the uselessness of lamenting, the wise do not lament.

original: Attānamattanoti attano attabhāvaṃ sokaparidevadukkhena hiṃsanto. Na tenāti tena paridevena
analyzed: attānam attanoti attano atta bhāvam soka parideva dukkhena hiṃsantaḥ na tena ati tena paridevena
translated: Harming his own self: his own person, by the sorrow, lamentation, and suffering. By that: by that lamenting.

original: paralokaṃ gatā sattā na pālenti na yāpenti. Niratthāti tasmā tesaṃ matasattānaṃ ayaṃ
analyzed: para lokam gatāḥ sattāḥ na pālenti na yāpenti niratthā ati tasmā tesam mata sattānam ayam
translated: The beings who have gone to the other world are not protected, are not sustained. Useless: therefore this lamenting

original: paridevanā niratthakā. Saraṇanti nivāsagehaṃ. Idaṃ vuttaṃ hoti – yathā paṇḍito puriso
analyzed: paridevanā niratthakā saraṇanti nivāsa geham idam vuttam hoti yathā paṇḍitaḥ puriso
translated: of those dead beings is useless. Home: dwelling place. This is what is said: just as a wise man,

original: attano vasanāgāre āditte muhuttampi vosānaṃ anāpajjitvā ghaṭasatena ghaṭasahassena
analyzed: attanaḥ vasanāgāre āditte muhuttam pi vosānam an āpajjitvā ghaṭa satena ghaṭa sahassena
translated: when his dwelling place is on fire, without delay for a moment, with a thousand pots, with a hundred thousand pots,

original: vārinā nibbāpayateva, evaṃ dhīro uppatitaṃ sokaṃ khippameva nibbāpaye. Tūlaṃ viya
analyzed: vārinā nibbāpayatā iva evam dhīraḥ uppatitam sokam khippam eva nibbāpaye tūlam viya
translated: just as water extinguishes a fire, so the wise man quickly extinguishes the arisen sorrow.

original: ca vāto yathā saṇṭhātuṃ na sakkoti, evaṃ dhaṃsaye viddhaṃseyyāti attho.🔽Macco ekova accetīti ettha tāta bharata, ime sattā kammassakā nāma, tathā hi ito🔽paralokaṃ gacchanto satto ekova acceti atikkamati, khattiyādikule jāyamānopi ekova🔽gantvā jāyati. Tattha tattha pana ñātimittasaṃyogena “ayaṃ me pitā, ayaṃ me mātā,🔽ayaṃ me mitto”ti saṃyogaparamātveva sambhogā sabbapāṇīnaṃ, paramatthena pana tīsupi
analyzed: ca vātaḥ yathā saṇṭhātum na sakkoti evam dhaṃsaye viddhaṃseyya ati atthaḥ  maccaḥ ekaḥ iva accā iti ettha tāta bharata ime sattā kammassakāḥ nāma tathā hi itas  para lokam gacchantaḥ satto ekaḥ iva acceti atikkamati khattiya ādi kule jāyamānaḥ api ekaḥ iva  gantvā jāyati tattha tattha pana ñāti mitta saṃyogena ayam me pitā ayam me mātā  ayam me mittaḥ iti saṃyoga paramā tu eva sambhogā sabba pāṇīnam paramatthena pana tīsupi
translated: just as the wind cannot remain in a hollow, so the meaning is that he would destroy, would smash it.

original: bhavesu kammassakāvete sattāti attho.🔽Tasmāti yasmā etesaṃ sattānaṃ ñātimittasaṃyogaṃ ñātimittaparibhogamattaṃ ṭhapetvā
analyzed: bhavesu sattā ati attho  tasmā ati yasmai etesam sattānam ñāti mitta saṃyogam ñāti mitta paribhoga mattam ṭhapetvā
translated: In the verse, “Alone he goes to the world beyond,” the meaning is this: “Dear Bharata, these beings are the owners of their kamma. For when a being goes from this world to the next, he goes alone; when he is reborn in a khattiya family, etc., he is reborn alone; and there, through the union of relatives and friends, he thinks, ‘This is my father, this my mother, this my friend.’ But the enjoyment of union is only a supreme deception. In the ultimate sense, in the three realms of existence these beings are the owners of their kamma.”🔽Therefore, since there is nothing else for these beings except the union of relatives and friends and the enjoyment of union,

original: ito paraṃ aññaṃ natthi, tasmā. Sampassatoti imañca parañca lokaṃ nānābhāvavinābhāvameva
analyzed: itas param aññam na atthi tasmā sampassato ti imam ca param ca lokam nānābhāva vinābhāvam eva
translated: therefore, “seeing this world and the next” as having the nature of diversity and non-diversity,

analyzed: sammā passataḥ aññāya dhammanti aṭṭhavidha loka dhammam jānitvā hadayam manaṃ ca ati
translated: Having understood the Dhamma: having known the eight worldly conditions.🔽Heart and mind:

original: idaṃ ubhayampi cittasseva nāmaṃ. Idaṃ vuttaṃ hoti –
analyzed: idam ubhayam pi cittassa iva nāmam idam vuttam hoti
translated: both of these are names for consciousness. What is meant is this:🔽Gain, loss, fame, obscurity,

analyzed: lābhaḥ alābhaḥ yaso ayaso ca nindā pasaṃsā ca sukham ca dukkham
translated: blame, praise, pleasure, and pain:🔽these are the impermanent conditions among mankind.

analyzed: ete aniccāḥ manujesu dhammāḥ mā soca kim socasi poṭṭhapāda ati
translated: Do not grieve, why do you grieve, Poṭṭhapāda?🔽When one’s mind is overcome by any one of these eight worldly conditions,

analyzed: imesam aṭṭhannam loka dhammānam yena kenacid cittam pariyādīyati tassa ca anicca taṃ
translated: and one knows their impermanence,

analyzed: ñatvā ṭhitassa dhīrassa pitu putta maraṇa ādi vatthukāḥ mahantā api sokāḥ hadayam na tāpayanti iti  etam vai aṭṭhavidham loka dhammaṃ ñatvā ṭhitassa hadaya vatthuñca manañca mahantā api
translated: the wise one remains firm. Even great sorrows do not torment his heart, as in the case of the father, the son, and the death.🔽Or else, the meaning here can be understood in this way:

analyzed: sokāḥ na tāpayanti iti evam pa ittha atthaḥ daṭṭhabbo
translated: having known the eight worldly conditions, the heart-basis and the mind of the wise one are not tormented by even great sorrows.🔽In the verse “I have seen and tasted,”

analyzed: saḥ ham dassan ca bhokkhan ca ati gāthāya tāta bharata andha bālānam sattānam viya mama
translated: father Bharata, like the beings who are blind and foolish,

analyzed: rodana paridevanam nāma na anucchavikam aham pana pitu accayena tassa ṭhāne ṭhatvā
translated: It is not fitting that I should weep and wail. But after my father’s death I will take his place and

original: kapaṇādīnaṃ dānārahānaṃ dānaṃ, ṭhānantarārahānaṃ ṭhānantaraṃ, yasārahānaṃ yasaṃ dassāmi,
analyzed: kapaṇa ādīnam dāna arahānam dānam ṭhānantara arahānam ṭhānantaram yasa arahānam yasam dassāmi
translated: give gifts to the poor and needy, and to those who are worthy of office I will give office, and to those who are worthy of fame I will give fame.

analyzed: pitarā me issariyam paribhuñjissāmi ñātake ca posessāmi avasesam ca

translated: I will protect the rest of the people, my servants and the rest. And to righteous recluses and brahmans I will render righteous reverence, protection, and support.”

original: karissāmīti evañhi jānato paṇḍitapurisassa anurūpaṃ kiccanti attho.
analyzed: karissāmi iti evam hi jānataḥ paṇḍita purisassa anurūpam kiccanti attho
translated: The meaning is that it is fitting for a wise man to act in this way.

original: Parisā imaṃ rāmapaṇḍitassa aniccatāpakāsanaṃ dhammadesanaṃ sutvā nissokā ahesuṃ.
analyzed: parisāḥ imam rāmapaṇḍitassa anicca tā apakāsanam dhamma desanam sutvā nissokāḥ ahesuṃ
translated: The assembly, having heard this discourse on the Law, which was a revelation of the truth of impermanence, was deeply moved.

analyzed: tatas bharata kumāraḥ rāma paṇḍitam vanditvā bārāṇasi rajjam āha tāta

analyzed: lakkhaṇam ca sītādeviñca gahetvā gantvā rajjam anusāsatha ati tumhe pana deva ati
translated: “Take Lakkhaṇa and Queen Sītā, and go and rule the kingdom.”🔽“But you, Prince?”

original: Tāta, mama pitā “dvādasavassaccayena āgantvā rajjaṃ kāreyyāsī”ti maṃ avoca, ahaṃ🔽idāneva gacchanto tassa vacanakaro nāma na homi, aññānipi tīṇi vassāni atikkamitvā🔽āgamissāmīti. “Ettakaṃ kālaṃ ko rajjaṃ kāressatī”ti? “Tumhe kārethā”ti. “Na mayaṃ🔽kāressāmā”ti. “Tena hi yāva mamāgamanā imā pādukā kāressantī”ti attano tiṇapādukā🔽omuñcitvā adāsi. Te tayopi janā pādukā gahetvā rāmapaṇḍitaṃ vanditvā mahājanaparivutā
analyzed: tāta mama pitā dvādasa vassa cayena āgantvā rajjam kāreyyāsi iti mam avoca aham  idānā iva gacchanto tassa vacanakaraḥ nāma na homi aññāni pi tīṇi vassāni atikkamitvā  āgamissāmi iti ettakam kālam kaḥ rajjam kāressati iti tumhe kāretha ati na mayam  kāressāma ati tena hi yāva mama āgamanā imā pādukā kāressanti iti attanaḥ tiṇa pādukā  omuñcitvā te pādukāḥ gahetvā rāma paṇḍitam vanditvā mahā jana parivutā
translated: “Father, my father said to me, ‘After twelve years have passed, come and take the kingdom.’ I am🔽now going, but I shall not have fulfilled his wish. I shall go after I have passed three more years.”🔽“Who will rule the kingdom during that time?” “You rule.” “We will not rule.” “Well then, let these sandals rule until I come.” And he gave them his grass sandals.🔽The three men took the sandals, saluted the wise Rāma, and surrounded by the people,🔽

original: bārāṇasiṃ agamaṃsu. Tīṇi saṃvaccharāni pādukā rajjaṃ kāresuṃ. Amaccā tiṇapādukā rājapallaṅke🔽ṭhapetvā aḍḍaṃ vinicchinanti. Sace dubbinicchito hoti, pādukā aññamaññaṃ paṭihaññanti.
analyzed: bārāṇasim agamaṃsu tīṇi saṃvaccharāni pādukāḥ rajjam kāresum amaccā tiṇa pādukāḥ rāja pallaṅke  ṭhapetvā aḍḍam vinicchinanti sace dubbinicchitaḥ hoti pādukāḥ aññamaññam paṭihaññanti
translated: “Father, my father said to me, ‘After twelve years have passed, return and take the kingdom.’ I am going now, and I shall not have fulfilled my father’s wish. I will go after three more years have passed.” “Who will rule the kingdom during that time?” “You will rule.” “We will not rule.” “Well then, let these sandals rule until I return.” So saying, he took off his grass sandals and gave them to the king. The three men took the sandals, saluted the wise Rāma, and surrounded by a great crowd of people went to Benares. For three years the sandals ruled the kingdom. The ministers placed the grass sandals on the royal throne and decided cases of dispute. If the decision was a bad one, the sandals would knock against each other.

original: Tāya saññāya puna vinicchinanti. Sammā vinicchitakāle pādukā nissaddā sannisīdanti.
analyzed: tāya saññāya puna vinicchinanti sammā vinicchita kāle pādukāḥ nissaddāḥ sannisīdanti
translated: By this sign they knew that the decision was a bad one, and they decided the case over again. If the decision was a good one, the sandals remained quiet.

original: Rāmapaṇḍito tiṇṇaṃ saṃvaccharānaṃ accayena araññā nikkhamitvā bārāṇasinagaraṃ patvā

original: uyyānaṃ pāvisi. Tassa āgamanabhāvaṃ ñatvā kumārā amaccagaṇaparivutā uyyānaṃ gantvā
analyzed: uyyānam pāvisi tassa āgamana bhāvam ñatvā kumārāḥ amacca gaṇa parivutāḥ uyyānam gantvā
translated: Hearing of his arrival, the princes, accompanied by the ministers, went to the park,

analyzed: sītam agga mahesim katvā ubhinnam pi abhisekam evam abhiseka ppattaḥ mahāsatto
translated: and made the cold-natured queen chief queen, and they anointed both of them. Thus the Great Being, having been anointed,

translated: the best of palaces. From that time on, for sixteen thousand years, he ruled righteously, and at the end of his life he filled the city of heaven.

original: “Dasa vassasahassāni, saṭṭhi vassasatāni ca;
analyzed: dasa vassa sahassāni saṭṭhi vassa satāni ca
translated: “For ten thousand years and for sixty hundred years,

analyzed: kambu gīvaḥ mahā bāhu rāmaḥ rajjam akārayi iti
translated: Kambugīva the mighty-armed Rāma ruled the kingdom.”

analyzed: ayam abhisambuddha gāthā tam attham dīpeti
translated: This verse of the Buddha’s enlightenment shows this meaning.

analyzed: kuṭumbiko sotāpatti phale tadā dasaratha mahā rājā suddhodana mahā rājā ahosi
translated: the householder was established in the Fruit of Conversion. At that time the king Dasaratha was the king Suddhodana,

analyzed: mātā mahāmāyā devī sītā rāhula mātā bharataḥ ānandaḥ lakkhaṇaḥ sāriputto parisā buddha parisā
translated: the mother was the queen Mahāmāyā, Sītā was Rāhulamātā, Bharata was Ānanda, Lakkhaṇa was Sāriputta, the retinue was the retinue of the Buddha,

original: Dasarathajātakavaṇṇanā sattamā.
analyzed: dasa ratha jātaka vaṇṇanā sattamā
translated: The story of Dasaratha is ended.

original: [462] 8. Saṃvarajātakavaṇṇanā
translated: The story of Samvara

analyzed: jānantaḥ naḥ mahā rāja iti idam satthā jetavane viharantaḥ ekam ossaṭṭha vīriyam bhikkhuṃ
translated: When the Teacher was in residence at Jetavana, he told this story about a certain monk who was over-zealous.

original: ārabbha kathesi. So kira sāvatthivāsī kulaputto satthu dhammadesanaṃ sutvā pabbajitvā
analyzed: ārabbha kathesi saḥ kira sāvatthi vāsī kula putto satthu dhamma desanam sutvā pabbajitvā
translated: This monk, it seems, was a young man of good family living at Sāvatthi. He heard the Teacher preach the Law, became a monk,

original: laddhūpasampado ācariyupajjhāyavattaṃ pūrento ubhayāni pātimokkhāni paguṇāni katvā
analyzed: laddha upasampadaḥ ācariya upajjhāya vattam pūrentaḥ ubhayāni pātimokkhāni paguṇāni katvā
translated: and after he had received the full admission, he fulfilled the duties of pupil and novice, and mastered both the Pāṭimokkha rules.

analyzed: paripuṇṇa pañca vassaḥ kammaṭṭhānam gahetvā araññe vasissāmi iti ācariya upajjhāye āpucchitvā
translated: After he had received the full admission, he took up a meditation subject, and thinking, “I shall live in the forest,” he asked his teacher and his preceptor for leave to go.
