translated: He went to a border village in the Kosala country, where he lived on the alms food given by people who had faith in him because of his deportment.

original: katvā upaṭṭhiyamāno vassaṃ upagantvā yuñjanto ghaṭento vāyamanto accāraddhena vīriyena🔽temāsaṃ kammaṭṭhānaṃ bhāvetvā obhāsamattampi uppādetuṃ asakkonto cintesi “addhā ahaṃ
analyzed: katvā upaṭṭhiyamānaḥ vassam upagantvā yuñjantaḥ ghaṭentaḥ vā āyamantaḥ acca āraddhena vīriyena  temāsam kammaṭṭhānam bhāvetvā obhāsa mattam pi uppādetum a sakkontaḥ cintesi addhā aham
translated: They built him a leaf hut and looked after him. He entered upon the rains there and devoted himself to meditation.🔽But he was unable to arouse even the light of a glowworm. He thought, “I am certainly the last of the four kinds of persons described by the Teacher.

original: satthārā desitesu catūsu puggalesu padaparamo, kiṃ me araññavāsena, jetavanaṃ gantvā
analyzed: satthārā desitesu catūsu puggalesu pada paramaḥ kim me arañña vāsena jetavanam gantvā
translated: What have I to do with living in the forest? I shall go to Jeta’s Grove,

original: tathāgatassa rūpasiriṃ passanto madhuradhammadesanaṃ suṇanto vītināmessāmī”ti. So
analyzed: tathāgatassa rūpa sirim passantaḥ madhura dhamma desanam suṇantaḥ vītināmessāmi iti so
translated: and there I shall pass my time looking at the beauty of the Tathāgata’s person and listening to the preaching of the Dhamma.”

original: vīriyaṃ ossajitvā tato nikkhanto anupubbena jetavanaṃ gantvā ācariyupajjhāyehi ceva
analyzed: vīriyam ossajitvā tatas nikkhantaḥ anupubbena jetavanam gantvā ācariya upajjhāyehi ca iva
translated: He gave up his effort, left the forest, and eventually reached Jeta’s Grove.🔽His teacher and his preceptor and his friends and companions asked him why he had come,

original: sandiṭṭhasambhattehi ca āgamanakāraṇaṃ puṭṭho tamatthaṃ kathetvā tehi “kasmā evamakāsī”ti
analyzed: sandiṭṭha sambhattehi ca āgamana kāraṇam puṭṭhaḥ tam attham kathetvā tehi kasmai evam akāsi iti
translated: and when he told them, they asked him, “Why did you do so?”

original: garahitvā satthu santikaṃ netvā “kiṃ, bhikkhave, anicchamānaṃ bhikkhuṃ ānayitthā”ti🔽vutte “ayaṃ, bhante, vīriyaṃ ossajitvā āgato”ti ārocite satthā “saccaṃ kirā”ti pucchitvā
analyzed: garahitvā satthu santikam netvā kim bhikkhave an icchamānam bhikkhum ānayittha ati  vutte ayam bhante vīriyam ossajitvā āgataḥ iti ārocite satthā saccam kirāti pucchitvā
translated: and after rebuking him, he took him to the Teacher and said to him, “Monks, why have you brought this unwilling monk?”🔽When the monks told him, “Reverend Sir, this monk has relaxed his efforts,” the Teacher asked, “Is it true, as men say, that you have relaxed your efforts?”

original: “saccaṃ, bhante”ti vutte “kasmā bhikkhu vīriyaṃ ossaji, imasmiñhi sāsane nibbīriyassa
analyzed: saccam bhante ti vutte kasmā bhikkhu vīriyam ossaji imasmin hi sāsane nibbīriyassa
translated: “Yes, Reverend Sir.”

original: kusītapuggalassa aggaphalaṃ arahattaṃ nāma natthi, āraddhavīriyā imaṃ dhammaṃ ārādhenti,🔽tvaṃ kho pana pubbe vīriyavā ovādakkhamo, teneva kāraṇena bārāṇasirañño puttasatassa
analyzed: kusīta puggalassa agga phalam arahattam nāma natthi āraddha vīriyāḥ imam dhammaṃ ārādhenti  tvam kho pana pubbe vīriyavā ovāda kkhamaḥ tena iva kāraṇena bārāṇasi rañño putta satassa
translated: “Why have you relaxed your efforts? In this Dispensation of mine there is no highest fruit, that of Saint-ship, for one who is devoid of energy and lazy. It is only those who are energetic that attain the goal of this religion.

original: sabbakaniṭṭho hutvāpi paṇḍitānaṃ ovāde ṭhatvā setacchattaṃ pattosī”ti vatvā atītaṃ āhari.
analyzed: sabbaka niṭṭhaḥ hutvā api paṇḍitānam ovāde ṭhatvā seta chattam pattosi iti vatvā atītam āhari
translated: But you, in the past, were energetic and obedient to the admonitions of the wise. For this reason, although you were the youngest of the hundred sons of the king of Bārāṇasī, you attained the white umbrella. ” So saying, he related the following

original: Atīte bārāṇasiyaṃ brahmadatte rajjaṃ kārente saṃvarakumāro nāma puttasatassa sabbakaniṭṭho
analyzed: atīte bārāṇasiyam brahmadatte rajjam kārente saṃvara kumāraḥ nāma putta satassa sabba kaniṭṭhaḥ
translated: Once upon a time, when Brahmadatta was reigning in Bārāṇasī, there was a prince named Saṃvara, who was the youngest of a hundred brothers.

original: ahosi. Rājā ekekaṃ puttaṃ “sikkhitabbayuttakaṃ sikkhāpethā”ti ekekassa amaccassa
analyzed: ahosi rājā ekekam puttam sikkhitabba yuttakam sikkhāpetha ati ekekassa amaccassa
translated: The king said to each of his sons, “Train him who is fit to be trained.”

original: adāsi. Saṃvarakumārassa ācariyo amacco bodhisatto ahosi paṇḍito byatto rājaputtassa
analyzed: adāsi saṃvara kumārassa ācariyaḥ amaccaḥ bodhisatto ahosi paṇḍitaḥ byattaḥ rāja puttassa
translated: and gave it to him. The Bodhisatta was the wise and clever teacher of Prince Saṃvara, who acted as father to the prince.

original: pituṭṭhāne ṭhito. Amaccā sikkhitasippe rājaputte rañño dassesuṃ. Rājā tesaṃ janapadaṃ
analyzed: pitu ṭṭhāne ṭhitaḥ amaccā sikkhita sippe rāja putte raññaḥ dassesum rājā tesam janapadam
translated: The ministers brought the prince, who had been trained in all the arts, to the king. The king gave him a province

original: datvā uyyojesi. Saṃvarakumāro sabbasippassa nipphattiṃ patvā bodhisattaṃ pucchi “tāta,
analyzed: datvā uyyojesi saṃvara kumāraḥ sabba sippassa nipphattim patvā bodhisattam pucchi tāta
translated: and sent him away. Prince Saṃvara, having attained the fruit of all the arts, asked the Bodhisatta, “Father,

original: sace maṃ pitā janapadaṃ peseti, kiṃ karomī”ti? “Tāta, tvaṃ janapade dīyamāne taṃ
analyzed: sace mam pitā janapadam peseti kim karomi iti tāta tvam janapade dīyamāne tam
translated: if my father sends me to a province, what should I do?” “Son, when a province is being given to you,

original: aggahetvā ‘deva ahaṃ sabbakaniṭṭho, mayipi gate tumhākaṃ pādamūlaṃ tucchaṃ bhavissati,
analyzed: aggahetvā deva aham sabba kaniṭṭhaḥ gate tumhākam pāda mūlam tuccham bhavissati
translated: take it, and say, ‘Your Majesty, I am the youngest of all your sons. If I go, your feet will be empty.

original: ahaṃ tumhākaṃ pādamūleyeva vasissāmī’ti vadeyyāsī”ti. Athekadivasaṃ rājā saṃvarakumāraṃ
analyzed: aham tumhākam pāda mūleya iva vasissāmi iti vadeyyāsi iti atha eka divasam rājā saṃvara kumāram
translated: I will live at your feet.’ ” Then one day the king,

original: vanditvā ekamantaṃ nisinnaṃ pucchi “kiṃ tāta, sippaṃ te niṭṭhita”nti? “Āma, devā”ti.
analyzed: vanditvā ekamantam nisinnam pucchi kim tāta sippam te niṭṭhitan ti āma deva ati
translated: after worshipping Prince Saṃvara, asked him as he sat on one side, “What is it, dear son, is your training finished?” “Yes, Your Majesty.”

original: “Tuyhampi janapadaṃ demī”ti. “Deva tumhākaṃ pādamūlaṃ tucchaṃ bhavissati, pādamūleyeva
analyzed: tuyham pi janapadam demi iti deva tumhākam pāda mūlam tuccham bhavissati pāda mūleya iva
translated: “I will give you a province too.” “Your Majesty, your feet will be empty. I will live at your feet.

original: vasissāmī”ti. Rājā tussitvā “sādhū”ti sampaṭicchi. So tato paṭṭhāya rañño pādamūleyeva
analyzed: vasissāmi iti rājā tussitvā sādhu uti sampaṭicchi so tatas paṭṭhāya rañño pāda mūleya iva
translated: “I will live there.” The king was pleased and agreed. From then on he lived at the foot of the king’s bed.

original: hutvā punapi bodhisattaṃ pucchi “tāta aññaṃ kiṃ karomī”ti? “Tāta rājānaṃ ekaṃ purāṇuyyānaṃ
analyzed: hutvā puna api bodhisattam pucchi tāta aññam kim karomi iti tāta rājānam ekam purāṇuyyānam
translated: After making his offering, he asked the Bodhisatta again, “Dear, what else shall I do?” “Dear, ask the king for an old park.”

original: yācāhī”ti. So “sādhū”ti uyyānaṃ yācitvā tattha jātakehi pupphaphalehi nagare issarajanaṃ
analyzed: yācāhi iti saḥ sādhu iti uyyānam yācitvā tattha jātakehi puppha phalehi nagare issara janam
translated: He agreed and asked for the park. He then gathered the people of the city with the flowers and fruits of the park.

original: saṅgaṇhitvā puna “kiṃ karomī”ti pucchi. “Tāta, rājānaṃ āpucchitvā antonagare bhattavetanaṃ
analyzed: saṅgaṇhitvā puna kim karomi iti pucchi tāta rājānam āpucchitvā antonagare bhatta vetanam
translated: He asked again, “What else shall I do?” “Dear, ask the king for the right to give food and wages in the city.”

original: tvameva dehī”ti. So tathā katvā antonagare kassaci kiñci ahāpetvā bhattavetanaṃ datvā
analyzed: tvam eva dehi iti saḥ tathā katvā antonagare kassaci kiñci bhatta vetanam da tvā
translated: He did so, and he gave food and wages in the city, not letting anyone go without.

original: puna bodhisattaṃ pucchitvā rājānaṃ viññāpetvā antonivesane dāsaporisānampi hatthīnampi
analyzed: puna bodhisattam pucchitvā rājānam viññāpetvā antar nivesane dāsa porisānam pi hatthīnam pi
translated: He asked the Bodhisatta again, and after informing the king, he gave food and wages to the slaves and servants in the palace, to the elephants and horses, and to the army.

original: assānampi balakāyassapi vattaṃ aparihāpetvā adāsi, tirojanapadehi āgatānaṃ dūtādīnaṃ
analyzed: assānam pi balakāyassa pi vattam a parihāpetvā adāsi tirojanapadehi āgatānam dūta ādīnam
translated: He did not let the duties of the messengers and so on who came from the outlying districts go undone.

original: nivāsaṭṭhānādīni vāṇijānaṃ suṅkanti sabbakaraṇīyāni attanāva akāsi. Evaṃ so mahāsattassa
analyzed: nivāsa ṭṭhāna ādīni vāṇijānam sabba karaṇīyāni attanā ava akāsi evam so mahāsattassa
translated: and the merchants’ business, the place of residence, and so on, he did all the work himself. Thus he lived according to the advice of the Great Being,

original: ovāde ṭhatvā sabbaṃ antojanañca bahijanañca nāgare ca raṭṭhavāsino ca āgantuke ca
analyzed: ovāde ṭhatvā sabbam antar janam ca bahi janam ca nāgare ca raṭṭha vāsino ca āgantuke ca
translated: and he gathered together all the people in the inner and outer palace, the citizens, the inhabitants of the country, and the visitors,

original: āyavattane ca tena tena saṅgahavatthunā ābandhitvā saṅgaṇhi, sabbesaṃ piyo ahosi manāpo.
analyzed: āya vattane ca tena tena saṅgaha vatthunā ābandhitvā saṅgaṇhi sabbesam piyaḥ ahosi manāpaḥ
translated: and he bound them to himself by the means of gathering them together with the various means of gathering, and he became dear and pleasing to all.

original: Aparabhāge rājānaṃ maraṇamañce nipannaṃ amaccā pucchiṃsu “deva, tumhākaṃ accayena
analyzed: aparabhāge rājānam maraṇa mañce nipannam amaccā deva tumhākam accayena
translated: Later, when the king was lying on his deathbed, the ministers asked him, “Your Majesty, after your death,

original: setacchattaṃ kassa demā”ti? “Tāta, mama puttā sabbepi setacchattassa sāminova. Yo
analyzed: setacchattam kassa dema ati tāta mama puttā sabbe pi setacchattassa yo
translated: to whom shall we give the white parasol?” “Dears, all my sons are the owners of the white parasol. But

original: pana tumhākaṃ manaṃ gaṇhāti, tasseva setacchatthaṃ dadeyyāthā”ti. Te tasmiṃ kālakate🔽tassa sarīraparihāraṃ katvā sattame divase sannipatitvā “raññā ‘yo tumhākaṃ manaṃ
analyzed: pana tumhākam manam gaṇhāti tassa iva tat itacchattham dadeyyātha ati te tasmim kālakate  tassa sarīra parihāram katvā sattame divase sannipatitvā raññā yaḥ tumhākam
translated: the one who wins your hearts, to him you may give the white parasol.” When he died,

original: gaṇhāti, tassa setacchattaṃ ussāpeyyāthā’ti vuttaṃ, amhākañca ayaṃ saṃvarakumāro
analyzed: gaṇhāti tassa seta chattam vuttam amhākam ca ayam saṃvara kumāraḥ
translated: after the funeral rites for his body, on the seventh day they assembled and said, “The king said, ‘You may raise the white parasol for the one who wins your hearts,’ and this Prince Saṃvara

original: manaṃ gaṇhātī”ti ñātakehi parivāritā tassa kañcanamālaṃ setacchattaṃ ussāpayiṃsu.
analyzed: manam gaṇhāti iti ñātakehi parivāritā tassa kañcana mālam seta chattam ussāpayiṃsu
translated: and they placed a golden garland on his head and raised a white sunshade over him.

original: Saṃvaramahārājā bodhisattassa ovāde ṭhatvā dhammena rajjaṃ kāresi. Itare ekūnasatakumārā
analyzed: saṃvara mahā rājā bodhisattassa ovāde ṭhatvā dhammena rajjam kāresi itare ekūnasata kumārā
translated: King Saṃvara, abiding by the Bodhisatta’s advice, ruled righteously. The other ninety-nine princes,

original: “pitā kira no kālakato, saṃvarakumārassa kira setacchattaṃ ussāpesuṃ, so sabbakaniṭṭho,
analyzed: pitā kira no kāla kataḥ saṃvara kumārassa kira seta chattam ussāpesum so sabba kaniṭṭho
translated: “Our father is dead, it seems, and they have raised a white sunshade over Prince Saṃvara. He is the youngest of all,

original: tassa chattaṃ na pāpuṇāti, sabbajeṭṭhakassa chattaṃ ussāpessāmā”ti ekato āgantvā
analyzed: tassa chattam na pāpuṇāti sabbajeṭṭhakassa chattam ussāpessāma ati ekatas āgantvā
translated: but he has obtained the sunshade. We will raise a sunshade over the eldest of all.” They came together

original: “chattaṃ vā no detu, yuddhaṃ vā”ti saṃvaramahārājassa paṇṇaṃ pesetvā nagaraṃ uparundhiṃsu.
analyzed: chattam vā naḥ detu yuddham vā ati saṃvara mahā rājassa paṇṇam pesetvā nagaram uparundhiṃsu
translated: and sent a message to King Saṃvara, saying, “Either give us the sunshade or fight.” They then laid siege to the city.

original: Rājā bodhisattassa taṃ pavattiṃ ārocetvā “idāni kiṃ karomā”ti pucchi. Mahārāja, tava
analyzed: rājā bodhisattassa tam pavattim ārocetvā idāni kim karoma ati pucchi mahā rāja tava
translated: The king told the Bodhisatta what had happened and asked, “What shall I do now?” “Great king,

analyzed: bhātikehi saddhim yujjhana kiccam na atthi tvam pitu santakam dhanam sata koṭṭhāse kāretvā
translated: you have no need to fight with your brothers. Have your father’s wealth divided into a hundred parts

analyzed: ekūnasatam bhātikānam pesetvā imam tumhākam koṭṭhāsam pitu santakam gaṇhatha na aham
translated: and send ninety-nine parts to your brothers, saying, ‘Take this share of your father’s wealth. I will take

analyzed: tumhehi saddhim yujjhāmi iti sāsanam pahiṇāhi iti saḥ tathā akāsi athassa sabba jeṭṭha bhātikaḥ
translated: I will fight with you.” He sent this message. Then his eldest brother,

original: uposathakumāro nāma sese āmantetvā “tātā, rājānaṃ nāma abhibhavituṃ samatthā nāma
analyzed: uposatha kumāraḥ nāma sese āmantetvā tātā rājānam nāma abhibhavitum samatthā nāma
translated: the prince named Uposatha, called the others together and said, “Dears, there is no one able to overcome a king.

original: natthi, ayañca no kaniṭṭhabhātiko paṭisattupi hutvā na tiṭṭhati, amhākaṃ pitu santakaṃ🔽dhanaṃ pesetvā ‘nāhaṃ tumhehi saddhiṃ yujjhāmī’ti pesesi, na kho pana mayaṃ sabbepi
analyzed: natthi ayam ca no kaniṭṭha bhātiko hutvā na tiṭṭhati amhākam pitu santakam  dhanam pesetvā na aham tumhehi saddhim yujjhāmi iti pesesi na kho pana mayam sabbe pi
translated: And this youngest brother of ours does not even stand as our opponent. He has sent us wealth that belonged to our father,

original: ekakkhaṇe chattaṃ ussāpessāma, ekasseva chattaṃ ussāpessāma, ayameva rājā hotu, etha
analyzed: eka khaṇe chattam ussāpessāma ekassa iva chattam ussāpessāma ayam eva rājā hotu etha
translated: saying, ‘I will not fight with you.’ But we will not all raise our umbrellas at the same time. We will raise the umbrella of only one. Let him alone be king. Come,

original: taṃ passitvā rājakuṭumbaṃ paṭicchādetvā amhākaṃ janapadameva gacchāmā”ti āha. Atha
analyzed: tam passitvā rāja kuṭumbam paṭicchādetvā amhākam janapadam eva gacchāma iti āha atha
translated: having seen him, let us cover the royal household and go to our own country.” Then

original: te sabbepi kumārā nagaradvāraṃ vivarāpetvā paṭisattuno ahutvā nagaraṃ pavisiṃsu.
analyzed: te sabbe api kumārāḥ nagara dvāram vivarāpetvā paṭisattunaḥ a hutvā nagaram pavisiṃsu
translated: all those princes had the city gate opened and entered the city without being opposed.

original: Rājāpi tesaṃ amaccehi paṇṇākāraṃ gāhāpetvā paṭimaggaṃ peseti. Kumārā nātimahantena
analyzed: rājā api tesam amaccehi paṇṇa ākāram gāhāpetvā paṭimaggam peseti kumārāḥ na ati mahantena
translated: The king also had a letter brought by his ministers and sent them back. The princes did not go very far,🔽but

original: parivārena pattikāva āgantvā rājanivesanaṃ abhiruhitvā saṃvaramahārājassa nipaccakāraṃ
analyzed: parivārena āgantvā rāja nivesanam abhiruhitvā saṃvara mahā rājassa nipaccakāram
translated: and after entering the royal palace, they paid their respects to King Saṃvara

original: dassetvā nīcāsane nisīdiṃsu. Saṃvaramahārājā setacchattassa heṭṭhā sīhāsane nisīdi,
analyzed: dassetvā nīcāsane nisīdiṃsu saṃvara mahā rājā setacchattassa heṭṭhā sīhāsane nisīdi
translated: and sat down on low seats. King Saṃvara sat on a lion throne under a white parasol,

original: mahanto yaso mahantaṃ sirisobhaggaṃ ahosi, olokitolokitaṭṭhānaṃ kampi. Uposathakumāro
analyzed: mahantaḥ yasaḥ mahantam siri sobhaggam ahosi olokita ulokita ṭṭhānam kampi uposatha kumāro
translated: and there was great glory and a great splendor, and the place where he was looked at trembled. Prince Uposatha

analyzed: saṃvara mahā rājassa sirivibhavam oloketvā amhākam pitā attanaḥ accayena saṃvara kumārassa
translated: looked at the glory and wealth of King Saṃvara and thought, “After our father’s death,

original: rājabhāvaṃ ñatvā maññe amhākaṃ janapade datvā imassa na adāsī”ti cintetvā tena saddhiṃ
analyzed: rāja bhāvam ñatvā maññe amhākam janapade da tvā imassa na adāsi iti cintetvā tena saddhim
translated: it seems he knew that Prince Saṃvara would be king and gave our country to him, but he did not give it to us.” Thus he quarreled with him

original: sallapanto tisso gāthā abhāsi –
analyzed: sallapantaḥ tissaḥ gāthāḥ abhāsi
translated: and spoke three verses:

original: “Jānanto no mahārāja, tava sīlaṃ janādhipo;
analyzed: jānantaḥ naḥ mahā rāja tava sīlam janādhipo
translated: “Knowing your virtue, great king, the people’s lord,

original: Ime kumāre pūjento, na taṃ kenaci maññatha.
analyzed: ime kumāre pūjentaḥ na tam kenacid maññatha
translated: honoring these princes, you think nothing of them.

original: “Tiṭṭhante no mahārāje, adu deve divaṅgate;
analyzed: tiṭṭhante naḥ mahā rāje adu deve divaṅgate
translated: “While you were standing, great king, when the day was ending,

original: Ñātī taṃ samanuññiṃsu, sampassaṃ atthamattano.
analyzed: ñātī tam samanuññiṃsu sampassam attham attanaḥ
translated: your relatives approved of you, seeing their own welfare.

original: “Kena saṃvara vattena, sañjāte abhitiṭṭhasi;
analyzed: kena saṃvara vattena sañjāte abhitiṭṭhasi
translated: “By what restraint do you stand, when they are born?

original: Kena taṃ nātivattanti, ñātisaṅghā samāgatā”ti.🔽Tattha jānanto noti jānanto nu. Janādhipoti amhākaṃ pitā narindo. Imeti ime ekūnasate
analyzed: kena tam na ativattanti ñāti saṅghā samāgatā iti  tattha jānantaḥ naḥ ti jānantaḥ nu janādhipo ti amhākam pitā narindo ime iti ime ekūna sate
translated: By what means do they not transgress him, The kinsmen’s multitude assembled? “

original: kumāre. Pāḷipotthakesu pana “aññe kumāre”ti likhitaṃ. Pūjentoti tena tena janapadena
analyzed: kumāre pāḷi potthakesu pana aññe kumāra iti likhitam pūjento ti tena tena janapadena
translated: Herein, knowing means knowing. The lord of men is our father. These means these one hundred and nine princes. But in the Pali texts it is written “other princes.” Worshipping means honouring with this or that kind of people’s speech.

original: mānento. Na taṃ kenacīti khuddakenāpi kenaci janapadena taṃ pūjetabbaṃ na maññittha,
analyzed: mānentaḥ na tam kenaci iti khuddakena api kenaci janapadena tam pūjetabbam na maññittha
translated: Not by anyone means he did not think that he should be worshipped by anyone even of little importance.

original: “ayaṃ mama accayena rājā bhavissatī”ti ñatvā maññe attano pādamūleyeva vāsesīti.🔽Tiṭṭhante noti tiṭṭhante nu, dharamāneyeva nūti pucchati, adu deveti udāhu amhākaṃ
analyzed: ayam mama accayena rājā bhavissati iti ñatvā maññe attano pāda mūleya iva vāsesi iti  tiṭṭhante no ti tiṭṭhante nu pucchati adu deva iti udāhu amhākam
translated: Thinking, it seems, “After me he will be king,” he kept him at his own feet.

original: pitari divaṅgate attano atthaṃ vuḍḍhiṃ passantā saddhiṃ rājakārakehi negamajānapadehi
analyzed: pitari divaṅgate attanaḥ attham vuḍḍhim passantā saddhim rāja kārakehi negama jānapadehi
translated: While he stands means while he stands, he asks whether he is still alive. After the god means or after our father has gone to heaven, seeing his own welfare and increase together with the royal officials and the people of the town and countryside

original: ñātayo taṃ “rājā hohī”ti samanuññiṃsu. Vattenāti sīlācārena. Sañjāte abhitiṭṭhasīti
analyzed: ñātayaḥ tam rājā hohi iti samanuññiṃsu vattena ati sīla ācārena sañjāte abhitiṭṭhasi iti
translated: the kinsmen approved him, saying “Be king.” Transgress means by virtue and conduct. You stand by means of what you are born with means

original: samānajātike ekūnasatabhātaro abhibhavitvā tiṭṭhasi. Nātivattantīti na abhibhavanti.
analyzed: samāna jātike ekūna sata bhātaraḥ abhibhavitvā tiṭṭhasi na ativattanti iti na abhibhavanti
translated: “They do not outdo me” means they do not overpower me.

original: Taṃ sutvā saṃvaramahārājā attano guṇaṃ kathento cha gāthā abhāsi –
analyzed: tam sutvā saṃvara mahā rājā guṇam kathentaḥ cha gāthāḥ abhāsi
translated: Having heard that, King Saṃvara spoke six verses, extolling his own virtues:

original: “Na rājaputta usūyāmi, samaṇānaṃ mahesinaṃ;
analyzed: na rāja puttaḥ usūyāmi samaṇānam mahesinam
translated: “I, prince, do not envy the ascetics, the great seers;

original: Sakkaccaṃ te namassāmi, pāde vandāmi tādinaṃ.🔽“Te maṃ dhammaguṇe yuttaṃ, sussūsamanusūyakaṃ;
analyzed: sakkaccam te namassāmi pāde vandāmi tādinam  te mam dhamma guṇe yuttam sussūsam anusūyakam
translated: I respectfully revere them, I pay homage at the feet of those of such kind.🔽“The ascetics, the seers delighting in the virtues of the Dhamma,

original: Samaṇā manusāsanti, isī dhammaguṇe ratā.
analyzed: samaṇā manusāsanti isī dhamma guṇe ratā
translated: encourage me who is devoted to the virtues of the Dhamma, who is eager to listen and who follows.

original: “Tesāhaṃ vacanaṃ sutvā, samaṇānaṃ mahesinaṃ;
analyzed: tesāham vacanam sutvā samaṇānam mahesinam
translated: “Having heard the words of the ascetics, the great seers,

original: Na kiñci atimaññāmi, dhamme me nirato mano.
analyzed: na kiñci atimaññāmi dhamme me nirataḥ mano
translated: I do not despise anything, my mind is devoted to the Dhamma.

original: “Hatthārohā anīkaṭṭhā, rathikā pattikārakā;🔽Tesaṃ nappaṭibandhāmi, niviṭṭhaṃ bhattavetanaṃ.

translated: One day, as the monks were sitting in the Hall of Truth, they said, “Brethren, how great is the wisdom of the Teacher! He is possessed of great wisdom, of wide-spread wisdom, of swift wisdom, of keen wisdom, of profound wisdom, of versatile wisdom.

original: mahāsamuddo viya gambhīrāya, ākāso viya vitthiṇṇāya, sakalajambudīpasmiñhi uṭṭhitapañho🔽dasabalaṃ atikkamitvā gantuṃ samattho nāma natthi. Yathā mahāsamudde uṭṭhitaūmiyo

analyzed: satthu pāda mūlam patvā bhijjatā iva ati dasabalassa mahā paññāpāramim vaṇṇesuṃ satthā

analyzed: āgantvā kāya nuttha bhikkhave etarahi kathāya sannisinnā ati pucchitvā imāya nāma ati
translated: and asked them, “Monks, what were you sitting here now talking about?” When they told him,

original: vutte “na, bhikkhave, tathāgato idāneva paññavā, pubbepi aparipakke ñāṇe paññavāva,🔽andho hutvāpi mahāsamudde udakasaññāya ‘imasmiṃ imasmiṃ samudde idaṃ nāma idaṃ nāma
analyzed: vutte na bhikkhave tathāgataḥ idānā iva paññavā pubbe pi aparipakke ñāṇe paññavā ava  andhaḥ hutvā api mahā samudde udaka saññāya imasmin imasmin samudde idam nāma idam nāma

analyzed: suppāraka kumāra utissa nāmam kariṃsu saḥ mahantena parivārena vaḍḍhantaḥ soḷasa vassa kāleya iva

analyzed: akāsi paṇḍitaḥ ñāṇa sampannaḥ ahosi tena āruḷha nāvāya byāpatti nāma natthi tassa

analyzed: aparabhāge loṇa jala pahaṭāni dve pi cakkhūni nassiṃsu so tatas paṭṭhāya niyāmaka jeṭṭhako

analyzed: tasmin pana samudde nīla maṇi ratanam ussannam ahosi saḥ tam pi upāyena iva gāhāpetvā  nāvā ayam pakkhipāpesi nāvā tam pi samuddam atikkamitvā naḷa vanam viya veḷu vanam viya
translated: In that ocean, a blue gem was abundant. He had it brought by some means and

translated: “As the ocean appears like reeds or like bamboo,

analyzed: kurukacchā payātānam vāṇijānam dhanesinam
translated: Where the ship of the merchants of Kuru,

analyzed: nāvāya vippanaṭṭhāya balavāmukhī iti vuccati iti  bodhisattaḥ anantara gāthāya tassa nāmaṃ ācikkhitvā tātāḥ imam balavāmukha samuddaṃ

translated: “Since I have known myself, since I have attained understanding,

analyzed: vatvā jātakam samodhānesi tadā parisāḥ buddha parisāḥ ahesum suppāraka paṇḍitaḥ pana aham eva ahosinti 🔽suppāraka jātaka vaṇṇanā navamā 🔽jātakuddānam 🔽ca dhamma udaya pānīyo 🔽yudhañcayaḥ dasarathaḥ saṃvaro ca suppārakaḥ 🔽saṅgītāḥ nava jātakāḥ 🔽ekādasaka nipāta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā 🔽dvādasaka nipātaḥ 🔽
translated: After giving them this advice, he performed meritorious deeds, such as giving alms, all his life, and filled the city of the gods.

translated: “Who are you, fair one, in your clean garments?” The Master told this tale while dwelling in Jetavana, about a well-known woman.

translated: After he had eaten breakfast, he went to the Teacher and asked, “Reverend Sir, what is the best food?”🔽“The best food, great king, is that which is given in trust. Even if it be only sour gruel, if it be given in trust, it is sweet.”

original: dinnaṃ madhuraṃ hotīti. Bhante, kena pana saddhiṃ bhikkhūnaṃ vissāso hotīti? “Ñātīhi🔽vā sekkhakulehi vā, mahārājā”ti. Tato rājā cintesi “ekaṃ sakyadhītaraṃ ānetvā aggamahesiṃ

translated: “Reverend Sir, with whom do the monks have trust?” “With kinsmen and with the families of probationers, great king.”

analyzed: karissāmi evam mayā saddhim bhikkhūnam ñātake viya vissāsaḥ bhavissati iti saḥ uṭṭhāya āsanā
translated: Thereupon the king thought to himself, “I will bring hither one of the Sakyan maidens and make her my chief consort. In this way the monks will have trust in me as though in a kinsman.” So he rose from his seat,

original: attano nivesanaṃ gantvā kapilavatthuṃ dūtaṃ pesesi “dhītaraṃ me detha, ahaṃ tumhehi🔽saddhiṃ ñātibhāvaṃ icchāmī”ti.

translated: went to his own house, and sent a messenger to Kapilavatthu, saying, “Give me a daughter. I desire to have you for kinsmen.”

original: Sākiyā dūtavacanaṃ sutvā sannipatitvā mantayiṃsu “mayaṃ kosalarañño āṇāpavattiṭṭhāne
analyzed: sākiyāḥ dūta vacanam sutvā sannipatitvā mantayiṃsu mayam kosala raññaḥ āṇāpa vatti ṭṭhāne
translated: The Sakyans, hearing the message, assembled and deliberated: “We live in a place subject to the orders of the king of Kosala.

original: vasāma, sace dārikaṃ na dassāma, mahantaṃ veraṃ bhavissati, sace dassāma, kulavaṃso🔽no bhijjissati, kiṃ nu kho kātabba”nti. Atha ne mahānāmo āha – “mā cintayittha, mama
analyzed: vasāma sace dārikam na dassāma mahantam veram bhavissati sace dassāma kula vaṃso  no bhijjissati kim nu kho kātabbanti atha ne mahānāmaḥ āha mā cintayittha mama
translated: If we do not give the girl, there will be a great war. If we give her, our family line will be broken. What is to be done?”

original: kiṃ nissāya taṃ bhayamāgatanti pucchati.

translated: Herein, thus a thought arose means if such a thought arose in you. Destruction without a body means

analyzed: kasanti vapanti te janāḥ manujā kamma phala upajīvinaḥ
translated: “Those people plow and sow, those men who live on the fruits of their labor;

original: Nayimassa dīpakassa bhāgino, jambudīpā idameva no vara”nti.
analyzed: nayimassa dīpakassa bhāginaḥ jambu dīpāḥ idam eva naḥ varanti
translated: They are not the heirs of this island, this is our choice, the Rose-Apple Island.”

original: Tattha te janāti te jambudīpavāsino janā. Kammaphalūpajīvinoti nānākammānaṃ phalūpajīvino sattā.
analyzed: tattha te janā ati te jambudīpa vāsinaḥ janā kamma phala upajīvinaḥ nānā kammānam phala upajīvinaḥ sattā
translated: Herein, they are the people means those people living in the Rose-Apple Island. They live on the fruit of their deeds means beings who live on the fruit of their various deeds.

original: Atha te dīpakaṃ pariggaṇhantā purisā tassa gītasaddaṃ sutvā “manussasaddo viya suyyati,🔽jānissāma na”nti saddānusārena gantvā taṃ purisaṃ disvā “yakkho bhavissatī”ti bhītatasitā
analyzed: atha te dīpakam pariggaṇhantā purisā tassa gīta saddam sutvā manussa saddaḥ viya  jānissāma nanti sadda anusārena gantvā tam purisam disvā yakkhaḥ bhavissati iti bhīta tasitā
translated: Then, as those men were searching for the island, they heard the sound of the song, thinking “It sounds like a human voice,🔽we shall find out,” they went by the sound and saw that man. Thinking “He will be a demon,” they were frightened and terrified.

original: sare sannahiṃsu. Sopi te disvā attano vadhabhayena “nāhaṃ, sāmi, yakkho, purisomhi,
analyzed: sare sannahiṃsu saḥ upi te disvā attanaḥ vadha bhayena na aham sāmi yakkho purisomhi
translated: They drew their arrows to the ear. He, seeing them, was afraid of being killed. “I am not a demon, sirs, I am a man,

original: jīvitaṃ me dethā”ti yācanto “purisā nāma tumhādisā naggā na hontī”ti vutte punappunaṃ
analyzed: jīvitam me detha iti yācantaḥ purisāḥ nāma tumhādisāḥ naggāḥ na honti iti vutte punappunam
translated: give me my life.” When they said “Men like you are not naked,” he asked again and again,

original: yācitvā manussabhāvaṃ viññāpesi. Te taṃ purisaṃ upasaṅkamitvā sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ
analyzed: yācitvā manussa bhāvam viññāpesi te tam purisam upasaṅkamitvā sammodanīyam katham
translated: and made them understand that he was a man. They approached that man and after exchanging polite and courteous greetings,

original: sutvā tassa tattha āgataniyāmaṃ pucchiṃsu. Sopi sabbaṃ tesaṃ kathetvā “tumhe attano
analyzed: sutvā tassa tattha āgata niyāmam pucchiṃsu saḥ api sabbam tesam kathetvā tumhe attano
translated: they asked him how he had come there. He told them all, and said “You should not go there, sirs,

original: puññasampattiyā idhāgatā, ayaṃ uttamadīpo, na ettha sahatthena kammaṃ katvā jīvanti,
analyzed: puñña sampattiyā idha āgatāḥ ayam uttama dīpaḥ na ettha sa hatthena kammam katvā jīvanti
translated: “We have come here because of the abundance of merit in this place. This is a most excellent island. Here they do not live by working with their own hands.

original: sayaṃjātasālīnañceva ucchuādīnañcettha anto natthīti anukkaṇṭhantā vasathā”ti āha.
analyzed: sayaṃjāta sālīnam ca iva ucchu ādīnam ca ittha antaḥ natthi iti an ukkaṇṭhantāḥ vasatha iti āha
translated: Here there is no rice that grows spontaneously, nor is there any sugarcane. If you are not troubled by this, you may live here.”

original: Idha pana vasantānaṃ amhākaṃ añño paripantho natthi, aññaṃ bhayaṃ ettha natthi, ayaṃ
analyzed: idha pana vasantānam amhākam aññaḥ paripantho natthi aññam bhayam ettha natthi ayam
translated: “We have no other enemies here, nor is there any other danger here. But this island

original: pana amanussapariggahito, amanussā tumhākaṃ uccārapassāvaṃ disvā kujjheyyuṃ, tasmā
analyzed: pana amanussa pariggahitaḥ amanussā tumhākam uccāra passāvam disvā kujjheyyum tasmā
translated: is haunted by demons. If the demons see your excrement and urine, they will become angry. Therefore

original: taṃ karontā vālukaṃ viyūhitvā vālukāya paṭicchādeyyātha, ettakaṃ idha bhayaṃ, aññaṃ
analyzed: tam karontā vālukam viyūhitvā vālukāya paṭicchādeyyātha ettakam idha bhayam aññam
translated: when you void these, you must dig a hole and cover them up again with sand. This is the only danger here.

original: natthi, niccaṃ appamattā bhaveyyāthāti. Te tattha vāsaṃ upagacchiṃsu. Tasmiṃ pana🔽kulasahasse pañcannaṃ pañcannaṃ kulasatānaṃ jeṭṭhakā dve vaḍḍhakī ahesuṃ. Tesu eko
analyzed: natthi niccam appamattāḥ bhaveyyātha ati te tattha vāsam upagacchiṃsu tasmim pana  kula sahasse pañcannam pañcannam kula satānam jeṭṭhakāḥ dve vaḍḍhakī ahesuṃ tesu ekaḥ
translated: There is no other. You must always be on your guard.” They agreed to live there.

original: bālo ahosi rasagiddho, eko paṇḍito rasesu anallīno.
analyzed: bālaḥ ahosi rasa giddhaḥ ekaḥ paṇḍitaḥ rasesu
translated: Now among the five hundred families there were two headmen, both of whom were wealthy. One of them was a fool and a glutton, the other was a wise man who took no delight in sensual pleasures.

original: Aparabhāge sabbepi te tattha sukhaṃ vasantā thūlasarīrā hutvā cintayiṃsu “ciraṃ pītā
analyzed: aparabhāge sabbe api te tattha sukham vasantā thūla sarīrā hutvā cintayiṃsu ciram pītā
translated: After some time, all of them, living there in comfort and having grown fat, thought, “We have drunk beer for a long time.

original: no surā, ucchurasena merayaṃ katvā pivissāmā”ti. Te merayaṃ kāretvā pivitvā madavasena
analyzed: no surāḥ ucchu rasena merayam katvā pivissāma ati te merayam kāretvā pivitvā mada vasena
translated: Let us make it into a strong liquor and drink it.” They made the strong liquor, drank it, and became intoxicated.

original: gāyantā naccantā kīḷantā pamattā tattha tattha uccārapassāvaṃ katvā appaṭicchādetvā🔽dīpakaṃ jegucchaṃ paṭikūlaṃ kariṃsu. Devatā “ime amhākaṃ kīḷāmaṇḍalaṃ paṭikūlaṃ karontī”ti
analyzed: gāyantā naccantā kīḷantā pamattā tattha tattha uccāra passāvam katvā a paṭicchādetvā  dīpakam jeguccham paṭikūlam kariṃsu devatāḥ ime amhākam kīḷā maṇḍalam paṭikūlam karonti iti
translated: Singing, dancing, and playing, they became heedless. They made urine and excrement here and there and did not cover it up.🔽They made the island of Laṅkā disgusting and repulsive. The deities, thinking, “These people are making our playground disgusting,”

original: kujjhitvā “mahāsamuddaṃ uttarāpetvā dīpakadhovanaṃ karissāmā”ti mantetvā “ayaṃ kāḷapakkho,
analyzed: kujjhitvā mahā samuddam uttarāpetvā dīpaka dhovanam karissāma iti mantetvā ayam kāḷapakkhaḥ
translated: became angry and consulted, “Let us flood the ocean and wash away the island of Laṅkā.” “This is the dark fortnight.

original: ajja amhākaṃ samāgamo ca bhinno, ito dāni pannarasame divase puṇṇamīuposathadivase
analyzed: ajja amhākam samāgamaḥ ca bhinnaḥ itas dāni pannarasame divase puṇṇamī uposatha divase
translated: Today our meeting is broken up. From now on, on the fifteenth day of the fortnight, on the Uposatha day of the full moon,

original: candassuggamanavelāya samuddaṃ ubbattetvā sabbepime ghātessāmā”ti divasaṃ ṭhapayiṃsu.
analyzed: candassa uggamana velāya samuddaṃ ubbattetvā sabbe pi me ghātessāma ati divasam ṭhapayiṃsu
translated: at the time of the moon’s rising, we will flood the ocean and kill all of them.” They set the day.

original: Atha nesaṃ antare eko dhammiko devaputto “mā ime mama passantassa nassiṃsū”ti anukampāya
analyzed: atha nesam antare ekaḥ dhammikaḥ deva putto mā ime mama passantassa nassiṃsu iti anukampāya
translated: Then, among them, a righteous deity, thinking, “Let them not perish while I am looking on,”

original: tesu sāyamāsaṃ bhuñjitvā gharadvāre sukhakathāya nisinnesu sabbālaṅkārapaṭimaṇḍito
analyzed: tesu sāyamāsam bhuñjitvā ghara dvāre sukha kathāya nisinnesu sabba alaṅkāra paṭimaṇḍitaḥ
translated: After they had eaten their evening meal, they sat down at the door of their house and talked pleasantly together.

original: sakaladīpaṃ ekobhāsaṃ katvā uttarāya disāya ākāse ṭhatvā “ambho vaḍḍhakī, devatā🔽tumhākaṃ kuddhā. Imasmiṃ ṭhāne mā vasittha, ito aḍḍhamāsaccayena hi devatā samuddaṃ
analyzed: sakala dīpam katvā uttarāya disāya ākāse ṭhatvā ambhaḥ vaḍḍhakī devatā  tumhākam kuddhāḥ imasmin ṭhāne mā vasittha itas aḍḍha māsa cayena hi devatā samuddam
translated: Then, all ablaze with splendor, he stood in the air to the north, and said to the builder, “Builder, the gods are angry with you.

original: ubbattetvā sabbeva tumhe ghātessanti, ito nikkhamitvā palāyathā”ti vatvā dutiyaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: ubbattetvā sabbā iva tumhe ghātessanti itas nikkhamitvā palāyatha ati vatvā dutiyam gātham āha
translated: Do not live in this place. In a fortnight the gods will cause the sea to overflow its banks and will destroy you all. Leave this place and flee.” So saying, he pronounced the following Stanza,

original: “Tipañcarattūpagatamhi cande, vego mahā hehiti sāgarassa;🔽Uplavissaṃ dīpamimaṃ uḷāraṃ, mā vo vadhī gacchatha leṇamañña”nti.
analyzed: ti pañca ratta upagatamhi cande vegaḥ mahā sāgarassa  uplavissam dīpam imam uḷāram mā vaḥ vadhī gacchatha leṇam aññanti
translated: When the moon has reached the fifteenth day, the great flood of the sea rises high;🔽The sea will overflow this fair island. Do not be destroyed. Go and find a cave.

original: Tattha uplavissanti imaṃ dīpakaṃ uplavanto ajjhottharanto abhibhavissati. Mā vo vadhīti so sāgaravego tumhe mā vadhi.
analyzed: tattha uplavissanti imam dīpakam uplavantaḥ ajjhottharantaḥ abhibhavissati mā vaḥ vadhi iti saḥ sāgara vegaḥ tumhe mā vadhi
translated: Here the words uplavissaṃ mean will overflow, will rise over. Do not be destroyed means do not be destroyed by the flood of the sea.

original: Iti so tesaṃ ovādaṃ datvā attano ṭhānameva gato. Tasmiṃ gate aparo sāhasiko kakkhaḷo
analyzed: iti saḥ tesam ovādam da tvā attanaḥ ṭhānam eva gataḥ tasmin gate aparaḥ sāhasikaḥ kakkhaḷo
translated: Having thus admonished them, he returned to his own place. After he had gone, another god, a bold and daring fellow,

original: devaputto “ime imassa vacanaṃ gahetvā palāyeyyuṃ, ahaṃ nesaṃ gamanaṃ nivāretvā sabbepime
analyzed: deva putto ime imassa vacanam gahetvā palāyeyyum aham na isam gamanam nivāretvā sabbe pi me
translated: “These will take his word and flee. I will prevent their going and bring about the destruction of all of them.”

original: mahāvināsaṃ pāpessāmī”ti cintetvā dibbālaṅkārapaṭimaṇḍito sakaladīpaṃ ekobhāsaṃ karonto
analyzed: mahā vināsam pāpessāmi iti cintetvā dibba alaṅkāra paṭimaṇḍitaḥ sakala dīpam eka ubhāsam karonto
translated: So thinking, he adorned himself with celestial ornaments, made the whole island one blaze of light,

original: āgantvā dakkhiṇāya disāya ākāse ṭhatvā “eko devaputto idhāgato, no”ti pucchitvā “āgato”ti🔽vutte “so vo kiṃ kathesī”ti vatvā “imaṃ nāma, sāmī”ti vutte “so tumhākaṃ idha nivāsaṃ
analyzed: āgantvā dakkhiṇāya disāya ākāse ṭhatvā ekaḥ deva putto idha āgataḥ no ti pucchitvā āgataḥ ti  vutte saḥ vaḥ kim kathesi iti vatvā imam nāma sāmi iti vutte saḥ tumhākam nivāsam
translated: came, and standing in the air in the southern direction, asked, “Is a god come here or not?”🔽When he was told, “He has come,” he asked, “What did he say to you?”🔽When he was told, “This,” he said, “He does not wish you to live here. He speaks out of hatred. You should go elsewhere and live here.”

original: na icchati, dosena katheti, tumhe aññattha agantvā idheva vasathā”ti vatvā dve gāthā abhāsi –
analyzed: na icchati dosena kathā iti tumhe aññattha a gantvā idhā iva vasatha iti vatvā dve gāthāḥ abhāsi
translated: And he spoke two stanzas:

original: “Na jātuyaṃ sāgaravārivego, uplavissaṃ dīpamimaṃ uḷāraṃ;
analyzed: na jātuyam sāgara vāri vegaḥ uplavissam dīpam imam uḷāram
translated: “Never will the mighty flood of the ocean overflow this noble island.

original: Taṃ me nimittehi bahūhi diṭṭhaṃ, mā bhetha kiṃ socatha modathavho.
analyzed: tam me nimittehi bahūhi diṭṭham mā bhetha kim socatha modathavho
translated: I have seen it by many signs. Do not be afraid. Why should you grieve? Rejoice.”

original: “Pahūtabhakkhaṃ bahuannapānaṃ, pattattha āvāsamimaṃ uḷāraṃ;
analyzed: pahūta bhakkham bahu anna pānam pattatthe āvāsam imam uḷāram
translated: “There is plenty of food here, and much rice and drink. This is a noble place to live.

original: Na vo bhayaṃ paṭipassāmi kiñci, āputtaputtehi pamodathavho”ti.
analyzed: na vaḥ bhayam paṭipassāmi kiñci āputta puttehi pamodathavho ti
translated: I see no danger at all. Rejoice with your sons and grandsons.”

original: Tattha na jātuyanti na jātu ayaṃ. Mā bhethāti mā bhāyittha. Modathavhoti pamoditā🔽pītisomanassajātā hotha. Āputtaputtehīti yāva puttānampi puttehi pamodatha, natthi
analyzed: tattha na jātuyanti na jātu ayam mā bhetha ati mā bhāyittha modathavha uti pamoditā  pīti somanassa jātāḥ hotha āputta puttehi iti yāva puttānam pi puttehi pamodatha natthi
translated: “Never” means “never at any time.” “Do not be afraid” means “do not be frightened.” “Rejoice” means “be glad, be joyful.” “With sons and grandsons” means “rejoice with your sons and grandsons.” “There is no” means “there is not.”

original: vo imasmiṃ ṭhāne bhayanti.🔽Evaṃ so imāhi dvīhi gāthāhi te assāsetvā pakkāmi. Tassa pakkantakāle dhammikadevaputtassa
analyzed: vaḥ imasmin ṭhāne bhayanti  evam saḥ imāhi dvīhi gāthāhi te assāsetvā pakkāmi tassa pakkanta kāle dhammika deva puttassa
translated: “Here, never” : never, at no time. “Do not be afraid” : do not be frightened. “Rejoice” : be glad, be joyful. “With sons and grandsons” : rejoice with sons and grandsons. “There is no fear for you in this place.”

original: vacanaṃ anādiyanto bālavaḍḍhakī “suṇantu me, bhonto, vacana”nti sesavaḍḍhakī āmantetvā
analyzed: vacanam an ādiyantaḥ bāla vaḍḍhakī suṇantu me bhontaḥ sesa vaḍḍhakī āmantetvā
translated: Having thus reassured them with two verses, he departed. At the time of his departure, the foolish fowler, disregarding the words of the righteous deity, said to the other fowlers, “Let my lords listen to my words.”

original: pañcamaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: pañcamam gātham āha
translated: And he uttered the fifth verse:

original: “Yo devoyaṃ dakkhiṇāyaṃ disāyaṃ, khemanti pakkosati tassa saccaṃ;
analyzed: yaḥ devaḥ iyam dakkhiṇāyam disāyam khemanti pakkosati tassa saccam
translated: “The deity who calls from the south, ‘Fear not,’ his words are true;

original: Na uttaro vedi bhayābhayassa, mā bhetha kiṃ socatha modathavho”ti.
analyzed: na uttaraḥ vedi bhaya abhayassa mā bhetha kim socatha modathavhaḥ iti
translated: The north knows not fear or terror. Do not be afraid. Why grieve? Rejoice!”

original: Tattha dakkhiṇāyanti dakkhiṇāya, ayameva vā pāṭho.
analyzed: tattha dakkhiṇāyanti dakkhiṇāya ayam eva vā pāṭhaḥ
translated: Here, “dakkhiṇāya” is the same as “dakkhiṇāya.”

original: Taṃ sutvā rasagiddhā pañcasatā vaḍḍhakī tassa bālassa vacanaṃ ādiyiṃsu. Itaro pana paṇḍitavaḍḍhakī tassa vacanaṃ anādiyanto te vaḍḍhakī āmantetvā catasso gāthā abhāsi –
analyzed: tam sutvā rasagiddhā pañcasatā vaḍḍhakī tassa bālassa vacanam ādiyiṃsu itaraḥ pana paṇḍita vaḍḍhakī tassa vacanam an ādiyantaḥ te vaḍḍhakī āmantetvā catassaḥ gāthāḥ abhāsi
translated: The five hundred carpenters, greedy for the taste of the bait, took the side of the fool. But the wise carpenter, not taking the side of the fool, addressed the carpenters in four stanzas:

original: “Yathā ime vippavadanti yakkhā, eko bhayaṃ saṃsati khemameko;
analyzed: yathā ime vippavadanti yakkhāḥ ekaḥ bhayam saṃsati khemam ekaḥ
translated: “As these demons speak, one speaks of fear, the other of safety.

original: Tadiṅgha mayhaṃ vacanaṃ suṇātha, khippaṃ lahuṃ mā vinassimha sabbe.
analyzed: tat iṅgha mayham vacanam suṇātha khippam lahum mā vinassimha sabbe
translated: Therefore listen to my words, lest we all perish quickly and suddenly.

original: “Sabbe samāgamma karoma nāvaṃ, doṇiṃ daḷhaṃ sabbayantūpapannaṃ;
analyzed: sabbe samāgamma karoma nāvam doṇim daḷham
translated: “Let us all gather together and build a boat, strong in the bottom, with all the oars.

original: Sace ayaṃ dakkhiṇo saccamāha, moghaṃ paṭikkosati uttaroyaṃ;
analyzed: sace ayam dakkhiṇaḥ saccam āha mogham paṭikkosati uttaraḥ yam
translated: If this man on the right speaks the truth, the one on the left speaks falsely.

original: Sā ceva no hehiti āpadatthā, imañca dīpaṃ na pariccajema.
analyzed: sā ca iva naḥ hehiti āpad atthā imam ca dīpam na pariccajema
translated: That is our danger. Let us not abandon this island.

original: “Sace ca kho uttaro saccamāha, moghaṃ paṭikkosati dakkhiṇoyaṃ;
analyzed: sace ca kho uttaraḥ saccam āha mogham paṭikkosati dakkhiṇaḥ yam
translated: “But if the man on the left speaks the truth, the one on the right speaks falsely.

original: Tameva nāvaṃ abhiruyha sabbe, evaṃ mayaṃ sotthi taremu pāraṃ.
analyzed: tam eva nāvam abhiruyha sabbe evam mayam sotthi taremu pāram
translated: All of us, having boarded that very boat, may thus safely cross to the other shore.

original: “Na ve sugaṇhaṃ paṭhamena seṭṭhaṃ, kaniṭṭhamāpāthagataṃ gahetvā;
analyzed: na veḥ sugaṇham paṭhamena seṭṭham kaniṭṭham āpātha gatam gahetvā
translated: “Do not take the first as the best, having taken the youngest as the best.

original: Yo cīdha tacchaṃ paviceyya gaṇhati, sa ve naro seṭṭhamupeti ṭhāna”nti.
analyzed: yaḥ ci idha taccham paviceyya gaṇhati sa ve naraḥ seṭṭham upeti
translated: Whoever here will go and take it, he will come to the best place.”

original: Tattha vippavadantīti aññamaññaṃ viruddhaṃ vadanti. Lahunti purimassa atthadīpanaṃ.
analyzed: tattha vippavadanti iti aññam aññam viruddham vadanti lahun ti purimassa attha dīpanam
translated: Herein, they are disputing means they are speaking in mutual contradiction. They are saying means they are explaining the meaning of the former.

original: Doṇinti gambhīraṃ mahānāvaṃ. Sabbayantūpapannanti sabbehi phiyārittādīhi yantehi🔽upapannaṃ. Sā ceva no hehiti āpadatthāti sā ca no nāvā pacchāpi uppannāya āpadāya
analyzed: doṇit ti gambhīram mahā nāvam sabba yantu upapannam ti sabbehi phiyāritta ādīhi yantehi  upapannam sā ca iva naḥ hehi iti āpad attha ati sā ca naḥ nāvā pacchā api uppannāya āpadāya
translated: A boat means a deep, large ship. We are all in it means we are all in it together.🔽That is not for us means that boat will not be for us even later on, when a calamity arises.

original: atthā bhavissati, imañca dīpaṃ na pariccajissāma. Taremūti tarissāma. Na ve sugaṇhanti
analyzed: atthā bhavissati iman ca dīpam na pariccajissāma taremu iti tarissāma na ve su gaṇhanti
translated: We will not abandon this island means we will not abandon this island. We will cross over means we will cross over. It is not easily grasped means

original: na ve sukhena gaṇhitabbaṃ. Seṭṭhanti uttamaṃ tathaṃ saccaṃ. Kaniṭṭhanti paṭhamavacanaṃ
analyzed: na ve sukhena gaṇhitabbam seṭṭhanti uttamam tatham saccam kaniṭṭhanti paṭhama vacanam
translated: it is not easily grasped with ease. The best means the highest, the true. The last means

original: upādāya pacchimavacanaṃ kaniṭṭhaṃ nāma. Idhāpi “na ve sugaṇha”nti anuvattateva. Idaṃ
analyzed: upādāya pacchima vacanam kaniṭṭham nāma idha api na idam
translated: the last statement, in comparison with the first statement. Here too, “It is not easily grasped” is repeated.

original: vuttaṃ hoti – ambho vaḍḍhakī, yena kenaci paṭhamena vuttavacanaṃ “idameva seṭṭhaṃ
analyzed: vuttam hoti ambhaḥ vaḍḍhakī yena kenacid paṭhamena vutta vacanam idam eva seṭṭham
translated: This is what is meant: “Good carpenter, whatever statement is first made by someone, ‘This is the best

original: naṭṭhaṃ, mahantenamhi yasena parihīno, ‘neva me paribbayaṃ adāsi, na ca pucchi nivāsaṭṭhāna’nti
analyzed: naṭṭham mahantena amhi yasena parihīnaḥ na iva me paribbayam adāsi na ca pucchi nivāsa ṭṭhānanti
translated: When they reported this, the king was grieved. He thought: “My kingdom in the three cities is lost, I have lost my great glory. He has gone away in anger because I did not give him any reward and did not ask him where he lived.”

original: mayhaṃ kujjhitvā māṇavo anāgato bhavissatī”ti punappunaṃ cintesi. Athassa taṇhāvasikassa
analyzed: mayham kujjhitvā māṇavaḥ anāgataḥ bhavissati iti punappunam cintesi athassa taṇhāvasikassa
translated: Again and again he thought: “He has gone away in anger because I did not give him any reward and did not ask him where he lived.”

original: sarīre ḍāho uppajji, sarīre pariḍayhante udaraṃ khobhetvā lohitapakkhandikā udapādi.
analyzed: sarīre ḍāhaḥ uppajji sarīre pariḍayhante udaram khobhetvā lohita pakkhandikā udapādi
translated: And as he was a slave to craving, a fever arose in his body. As his body was burning, his stomach was upset and a bloody dysentery arose.

original: Ekaṃ bhājanaṃ pavisati, ekaṃ nikkhamati, vejjā tikicchituṃ na sakkonti, rājā kilamati.
analyzed: ekam bhājanam pavisati ekam nikkhamati vejjā tikicchitum na sakkonti rājā kilamati
translated: One bowl went in and another came out. The doctors could not cure him. The king suffered.

original: Athassa byādhitabhāvo sakalanagare pākaṭo ahosi.
analyzed: athassa byādhita bhāvaḥ sakala nagare pākaṭaḥ ahosi
translated: And the king’s illness became known all over the city.

original: Tadā bodhisatto takkasilato sabbasippāni uggaṇhitvā bārāṇasinagare mātāpitūnaṃ santikaṃ🔽āgato taṃ rañño pavattiṃ sutvā “ahaṃ tikicchissāmī”ti rājadvāraṃ gantvā “eko kira🔽taruṇamāṇavo tumhe tikicchituṃ āgato”ti ārocāpesi. Rājā “mahantamahantā disāpāmokkhavejjāpi
analyzed: tadā bodhisattaḥ takkasilataḥ sabba sippāni uggaṇhitvā bārāṇasi nagare mātā pitūnam santikam  āgataḥ tam rañño pavattim sutvā aham tikicchissāmi iti rājadvāram gantvā ekaḥ kira  taruṇa māṇavaḥ tumhe tikicchitum āgataḥ iti ārocāpesi rājā mahanta mahantā
translated: Now the Bodhisatta, having learned all the sciences at Takkasilā, had returned to Bārāṇasī to his parents.🔽Hearing of the king’s illness, he went to the palace gate and sent word to the king, saying, “A young student, it is said, has come to cure you.

original: maṃ tikicchituṃ na sakkonti, kiṃ taruṇamāṇavo sakkhissati, paribbayaṃ datvā vissajjetha
analyzed: mam tikicchitum na sakkonti kim taruṇa māṇavaḥ sakkhissati paribbayam da tvā vissajjetha
translated: ” The king replied, “Great physicians, the foremost in all the world, have failed to cure me. How can a young student succeed? Send him away, giving him a gift.”

original: na”nti āha. Taṃ sutvā māṇavo “mayhaṃ vejjakammena vetanaṃ natthi, ahaṃ tikicchāmi,
analyzed: āha tam sutvā māṇavaḥ mayham vejja kammena vetanam natthi aham tikicchāmi
translated: But the student said, “I do not desire a fee for my services. I will cure you.

original: kevalaṃ bhesajjamūlamattaṃ detū”ti āha. Taṃ sutvā rājā “sādhū”ti pakkosāpesi. Māṇavo
analyzed: kevalam bhesajja mūla mattam detu iti āha tam sutvā rājā sādhu iti pakkosāpesi māṇavaḥ
translated: Give me only the price of the medicine.” The king, hearing this, said, “Very well,” and sent for the student.

original: rājānaṃ vanditvā “mā bhāyi, mahārāja, ahaṃ te tikicchāmi, apica kho pana me rogassa
analyzed: rājānam vanditvā mā bhāyi mahā rāja aham te tikicchāmi apica kho pana me rogassa
translated: The student, after paying obeisance to the king, said, “Do not fear, great king. I will cure you. But first I must know the nature of your illness.

original: samuṭṭhānaṃ ācikkhāhī”ti āha. Rājā harāyamāno “kiṃ te samuṭṭhānena, bhesajjaṃ eva
analyzed: samuṭṭhānam ācikkhāhi iti āha rājā harāyamānaḥ kim te samuṭṭhānena bhesajjam eva
translated: “Tell me the origin of the disease.” The king, ashamed, said, “What is the use of the origin?

original: karohī”ti āha. Mahārāja, vejjā nāma “ayaṃ byādhi imaṃ nissāya samuṭṭhito”ti ñatvā🔽anucchavikaṃ bhesajjaṃ karontīti. Rājā “sādhu tātā”ti samuṭṭhānaṃ kathento “ekena
analyzed: karohi iti āha mahā rāja vejjā nāma ayam byādhi imam nissāya samuṭṭhitaḥ iti ñatvā  anucchavikam bhesajjam karonti iti rājā sādhu tāta ati samuṭṭhānam kathentaḥ ekena
translated: Cure the disease.” “Great king, doctors, knowing that a disease has arisen from a certain cause,

original: māṇavena āgantvā tīsu nagaresu rajjaṃ gahetvā dassāmī”tiādiṃ katvā sabbaṃ kathetvā🔽“iti me tāta, taṇhaṃ nissāya byādhi uppanno, sace tikicchituṃ sakkosi, tikicchāhī”ti
analyzed: māṇavena āgantvā tīsu nagaresu rajjam gahetvā dassāmi iti ādim katvā sabbam kathetvā  iti me tāta taṇham nissāya byādhi uppanno sace tikicchitum sakkosi tikicchāhi iti
translated: cure it with a suitable medicine.” “Very well, dear,” said the king. Telling the origin, he said, “A student came to me and said, ‘I will conquer the three cities and give them to you.’

original: āha. Kiṃ pana mahārāja, socanāya tāni nagarāni sakkā laddhunti? “Na sakkā tātā”ti.
analyzed: āha kim pana mahā rāja socanāya tāni nagarāni sakkā laddhunti na sakkā tāta ati
translated: Thus, dear, the disease arose from craving. If you can cure it, cure it.” “But, great king, can those cities be obtained by grieving?” “No, dear.”

original: “Evaṃ sante kasmā socasi, mahārāja, sabbameva hi saviññāṇakāviññāṇakavatthuṃ attano
analyzed: evam sante kasmā socasi mahā rāja sabbam eva hi sa viññāṇaka aviññāṇaka vatthum attano
translated: “If that is so, why do you grieve, great king? For everything, beginning with one’s own body, which is the basis for consciousness and non-consciousness,

original: kāyaṃ ādiṃ katvā pahāya gamanīyaṃ, catūsu nagaresu rajjaṃ gahetvāpi tvaṃ ekappahāreneva
analyzed: kāyam ādim katvā pahāya gamanīyam catūsu nagaresu rajjam gahetvā api tvam eka ppahārena iva
translated: must be abandoned and gone. Even if you had conquered the four cities, you would have to go forth all at once,

original: na catasso bhattapātiyo bhuñjissasi, na catūsu sayanesu sayissasi, na cattāri vatthayugāni
analyzed: na catassaḥ bhatta pātiyaḥ bhuñjissasi na catūsu sayanesu sayissasi na cattāri vattha yugāni
translated: “You will not eat from four dishes, nor will you sleep in four beds, nor will you wear four suits of garments,

original: acchādessasi, taṇhāvasikena nāma bhavituṃ na vaṭṭati, ayañhi taṇhā nāma vaḍḍhamānā
analyzed: acchādessasi taṇhāvasikena nāma bhavitum na vaṭṭati ayam hi taṇhā nāma vaḍḍhamānā
translated: “You must not be a slave to craving. For craving, when it increases,

original: catūhi apāyehi muccituṃ na detīti.
analyzed: catūhi apāyehi muccitum na deti iti
translated: does not allow one to escape from the four states of suffering.”

original: Iti naṃ mahāsatto ovaditvā athassa dhammaṃ desento imā gāthā abhāsi –
analyzed: iti nam mahāsattaḥ ovaditvā athassa dhammaṃ desentaḥ imāḥ gāthāḥ abhāsi
translated: Having thus admonished him, the Great Being, in order to teach him the Dhamma, spoke these verses:

original: “Kāmaṃ kāmayamānassa, tassa ce taṃ samijjhati;🔽Addhā pītimano hoti, laddhā macco yadicchati.
analyzed: kāmam kāmayamānassa tassa ce tam samijjhati  addhā pītimanaḥ laddhā maccaḥ yat icchati
translated: “If one who desires gains his desire,🔽he is elated, having obtained what he wished for.

original: “Kāmaṃ kāmayamānassa, tassa ce taṃ samijjhati;🔽Tato naṃ aparaṃ kāme, ghamme taṇhaṃva vindati.
analyzed: kāmam kāmayamānassa tassa ce tam samijjhati  tatas nam aparam kāme ghamme taṇham iva vindati
translated: “If one who desires gains his desire,🔽he is elated, having obtained what he wished for.

original: “Gavaṃva siṅgino siṅgaṃ, vaḍḍhamānassa vaḍḍhati;
analyzed: gavam iva siṅginaḥ siṅgam vaḍḍhamānassa vaḍḍhati
translated: “As the horn of a rhinoceros grows along with the body of the rhinoceros,

original: Evaṃ mandassa posassa, bālassa avijānato;
analyzed: evam mandassa posassa bālassa a vijānataḥ
translated: so for a foolish, ignorant person,

original: Bhiyyo taṇhā pipāsā ca, vaḍḍhamānassa vaḍḍhati.
analyzed: bhiyyaḥ taṇhā pipāsā ca vaḍḍhamānassa vaḍḍhati
translated: thirst and craving increase along with his desires.🔽“Having given away land, rice and barley,

original: “Pathabyā sāliyavakaṃ, gavāssaṃ dāsaporisaṃ;
analyzed: pathabyā sāli yavakam gavāssam dāsaporisam
translated: cattle, sheep, and male and female slaves,

original: Datvā ca nālamekassa, iti vidvā samaṃ care.
analyzed: da tvā ca na alam ekaḥ se iti vidvā samam care
translated: the wise man should live in equanimity, without attachment to any of these things.

original: “Rājā pasayha pathaviṃ vijitvā, sasāgarantaṃ mahimāvasanto;
analyzed: rājā pasayha pathavim vijitvā sa sāgarantam
translated: “Having conquered the earth by force, and having dwelt in the land surrounded by the ocean,

original: Oraṃ samuddassa atittarūpo, pāraṃ samuddassapi patthayetha.
analyzed: oram samuddassa pāram samuddassa api patthayetha
translated: He, having crossed over the near shore of the ocean, would seek the far shore of the ocean.

original: “Yāva anussaraṃ kāme, manasā titti nājjhagā;
analyzed: yāva anussaram kāme manasā na ajjhagā
translated: “As long as one remembers sensual pleasures, the mind does not attain satisfaction;

original: Tato nivattā paṭikkamma disvā, te ve sutittā ye paññāya tittā.
analyzed: tatas nivattā paṭikkamma disvā te ve su tittāḥ ye paññāya tittā
translated: But having turned back, having withdrawn, having seen, they are well satisfied who are satisfied with wisdom.

original: “Paññāya tittinaṃ seṭṭhaṃ, na so kāmehi tappati;
analyzed: paññāya tittinam seṭṭham na saḥ kāmehi tappati
translated: “The best of those satisfied with wisdom, he is not tormented by sensual pleasures;

original: Paññāya tittaṃ purisaṃ, taṇhā na kurute vasaṃ.
analyzed: paññāya tittam purisam taṇhā na kurute vasam
translated: The person satisfied with wisdom, craving does not make him its slave.

original: “Apacinetheva kāmānaṃ, appicchassa alolupo;
analyzed: apacinetha iva kāmānam appicchassa a lolupaḥ
translated: “He should abandon sensual pleasures, the one who is of little desire and is not greedy;

original: Samuddamatto puriso, na so kāmehi tappati.
analyzed: samudda mattaḥ purisaḥ na saḥ kāmehi tappati
translated: The person who is intoxicated with the ocean, he is not tormented by sensual pleasures.

original: “Rathakārova cammassa, parikantaṃ upāhanaṃ;
analyzed: rathakāraḥ uva cammassa parikantam upāhanam
translated: “Just as a chariot-maker would make a wheel out of leather,

original: Yaṃ yaṃ cajati kāmānaṃ, taṃ taṃ sampajjate sukhaṃ;
analyzed: yam yam cajati kāmānam tam tam sampajjate sukham
translated: Whatever sensual pleasures one gives up, that is the attainment of happiness;

original: Sabbañce sukhamiccheyya, sabbe kāme pariccaje”ti.
analyzed: sabbañce sukham iccheyya sabbe kāme pariccaja iti
translated: If one desires all happiness, one should give up all sensual pleasures.”

original: Tattha kāmanti vatthukāmampi kilesakāmampi. Kāmayamānassāti patthayamānassa. Tassa
analyzed: tattha kāmanti vatthu kāmam pi kilesa kāmam pi kāmayamānassa ati patthayamānassa tassa
translated: Herein, sensual pleasures are both the sensual pleasure object and the sensual pleasure defilement. One who is longing for sensual pleasures is one who is aspiring for sensual pleasures.

original: ce taṃ samijjhatīti tassa puggalassa taṃ kāmitavatthu samijjhati ce, nipphajjati
analyzed: ce tam samijjhati iti tassa puggalassa tam kāmita vatthu samijjhati ce nipphajjati
translated: If it succeeds, if that object of his desire succeeds, is accomplished,

original: ceti attho. Tato naṃ aparaṃ kāmeti ettha nanti nipātamattaṃ. Aparanti parabhāgadīpanaṃ.
analyzed: ca iti tatas naṃ aparam kāma iti ettha nanti nipāta mattam parabhāga dīpanam
translated: is what is meant. Then he desires another after that: here the word “then” is merely a particle. “Another” shows a different state.

original: Kāmeti upayogabahuvacanaṃ. Idaṃ vuttaṃ hoti – sace kāmaṃ kāmayamānassa taṃ kāmitavatthu🔽samijjhati, tasmiṃ samiddhe tato paraṃ so puggalo kāmayamāno yathā nāma ghamme gimhakāle
analyzed: kāme ti upayoga bahuvacanam idam vuttam hoti sace kāmam kāmayamānassa tam kāmita vatthu  samijjhati tasmin samiddhe tatas param so puggalo kāmayamānaḥ yathā nāma ghamme gimha kāle
translated: “Desires” is a plural form in the sense of use. This is what is meant: if, when he desires sense desires, that object of his desire succeeds,🔽then, when it has succeeded, he desires another after that. Just as when a man is exhausted by heat in the hot season in the middle of the day

original: vātātapena kilanto taṇhaṃ vindati, pānīyapipāsaṃ paṭilabhati, evaṃ bhiyyo kāmataṇhāsaṅkhāte
analyzed: vāta ātapena taṇham vindati pānīya pipāsam paṭilabhati evam bhiyyas kāma taṇhā saṅkhāte
translated: and he finds a thirst, gets a thirst for water, so too, he finds, gets, sense desires called “thirst”

original: kāme vindati paṭilabhati, rūpataṇhādikā taṇhā cassa vaḍḍhatiyevāti. Gavaṃvāti gorūpassa🔽viya. Siṅginoti matthakaṃ padāletvā uṭṭhitasiṅgassa. Mandassāti mandapaññassa. Bālassāti
analyzed: kāme vindati paṭilabhati rūpa taṇhā ādikā taṇhā ca ssa vaḍḍhatiyā iva ati gavam vā ati go rūpassa  viya siṅgino ti matthakam padāletvā uṭṭhita siṅgassa mandassa āti manda paññassa bālassa ati
translated: and his craving for visible forms, etc., increases. Like a cow:

original: bāladhamme yuttassa. Idaṃ vuttaṃ hoti – yathā vacchakassa vaḍḍhantassa sarīreneva
analyzed: bāla dhamme yuttassa idam vuttam hoti yathā vacchakassa vaḍḍhantassa sarīrena iva
translated: like the appearance of a cow. With horns: with horns that have grown up by rubbing against the doorposts, etc. Slow-witted: of little wisdom. Foolish: occupied with the states of a fool. This is what is meant: just as, when a calf is growing,

original: saddhiṃ siṅgaṃ vaḍḍhati, evaṃ andhabālassapi appattakāmataṇhā ca pattakāmapipāsā
analyzed: saddhim siṅgam vaḍḍhati evam andha bālassa api appatta kāma taṇhā ca patta kāma pipāsā
translated: and the horn grows together with it. So too, the blind fool’s craving for what he has not yet obtained and his thirst for what he has already obtained

original: ca aparāparaṃ vaḍḍhatīti.
analyzed: ca apara aparam vaḍḍhati iti
translated: and the blind fool’s craving for what he has not got and his thirst for what he has got increase in turn.

original: Sāliyavakanti sālikhettayavakhettaṃ. Etena sāliyavādikaṃ sabbaṃ dhaññaṃ dasseti,
analyzed: sāli yavakanti sāli khetta yava khettam etena sāli yava ādikam sabbam dhaññam dasseti
translated: Sāliyavakaṃ means rice fields and barley fields. This shows all kinds of grain beginning with rice and barley.

original: dutiyapadena sabbaṃ dvipadacatuppadaṃ dasseti. Paṭhamapadena vā sabbaṃ aviññāṇakaṃ,
analyzed: dutiya padena sabbam dvipada catuppadam dasseti paṭhama padena vā sabbam aviññāṇakam
translated: Or the first line shows all that is not conscious,

original: itarena saviññāṇakaṃ. Datvā cāti datvāpi. Idaṃ vuttaṃ hoti – tiṭṭhantu tīṇi rajjāni,
analyzed: itarena sa viññāṇakam da tvā ca ati da tvā api idam vuttam hoti tiṭṭhantu tīṇi rajjāni
translated: and the second all that is conscious. Datvā ca means even after giving. This is the meaning: let alone three ploughs’ widths,

original: sace so māṇavo aññaṃ vā sakalampi pathaviṃ saviññāṇakāviññāṇakaratanapūraṃ kassaci
analyzed: sace saḥ māṇavaḥ aññam vā sakalam pi pathavim sa viññāṇaka aviññāṇaka ratana pūram kassaci
translated: if that brahmin student or anyone else were to give the whole earth filled with precious stones, both conscious and unconscious,

original: datvā gaccheyya, idampi ettakaṃ vatthu ekasseva apariyantaṃ, evaṃ duppūrā esā taṇhā
analyzed: da tvā gaccheyya idam pi ettakam vatthu ekassa iva a pariyantam evam duppūrā esā taṇhā
translated: to someone, even that much would not be enough to satisfy this craving called “wife.”

original: nāma. Iti vidvā samaṃ careti evaṃ jānanto puriso taṇhāvasiko ahutvā kāyasamācārādīni pūrento careyya.
analyzed: nāma iti vidvā samam cara iti evam jānantaḥ purisaḥ taṇhāvasikaḥ a hutvā kāya samācāra ādīni pūrentaḥ careyya
translated: Iti vidvā samaṃ care: a wise man should conduct himself thus, not making craving the cause, fulfilling bodily good conduct, etc.

original: Oranti orimakoṭṭhāsaṃ patvā tena atittarūpo puna samuddapārampi patthayetha. Evaṃ
analyzed: orima koṭṭhāsam patvā tena puna samudda pāram pi patthayetha evam
translated: and having reached the near shore, he would be still more eager and would seek to cross the further shore of the ocean. So too,🔽great king, beings are called “those who have craving as their core” because they are difficult to satisfy.

original: taṇhāvasikasattā nāma duppūrāti dasseti. Yāvāti aniyāmitaparicchedo. Anussaranti🔽anussaranto. Nājjhagāti na vindati. Idaṃ vuttaṃ hoti – mahārāja, puriso apariyantepi
analyzed: taṇhāvasikasattā nāma duppūrā ti dasseti yāvā ati a niyāmita paricchedaḥ anussaranti  anussarantaḥ na ajjhagāti na vindati idam vuttam hoti mahā rāja purisaḥ a pariyante pi
translated: As far as means without any limit.🔽Remembers means remembering.🔽Does not find satisfaction means does not find contentment. This is what is said:🔽Great king, a man, even while remembering sensual pleasures without limit, does not find satisfaction, but rather becomes all the more eager. So too, in regard to sensual pleasures,

original: kāme manasā anussaranto tittiṃ na vindati, pattukāmova hoti, evaṃ kāmesu sattānaṃ
analyzed: kāme manasā anussarantaḥ tittim na vindati pattu kāmaḥ va hoti evam kāmesu sattānam
translated: the craving of beings increases.

original: taṇhā vaḍḍhateva. Tato nivattāti tato pana vatthukāmakilesakāmato cittena nivattitvā
analyzed: taṇhā vaḍḍhatā iva tatas nivattāti tatas pana vatthu kāma kilesa kāmato cittena nivattitvā
translated: Then he turns away from that means having turned away from the sensual pleasures that are objects and the sensual pleasures that are defilements with his mind,

original: kāyena paṭikkamma ñāṇena ādīnavaṃ disvā ye paññāya tittā paripuṇṇā, te tittā nāma.
analyzed: kāyena paṭikkamma ñāṇena ādīnavam disvā ye paññāya tittā paripuṇṇā te tittā nāma
translated: and having turned away from them with his body, having seen their danger with his knowledge, those who are satisfied with wisdom, who are fulfilled with wisdom, are called “satisfied.”

original: Paññāya tittinaṃ seṭṭhanti paññāya tittīnaṃ ayaṃ paripuṇṇaseṭṭho, ayameva vā pāṭho.
analyzed: paññāya tittinam seṭṭhanti paññāya tittīnam ayam paripuṇṇa seṭṭhaḥ ayam eva vā pāṭho
translated: The best of those satisfied with wisdom means the best of those who are satisfied with wisdom, who are fulfilled with wisdom. This is the reading.

original: Na so kāmehi tappatīti “na hī”tipi pāṭho. Yasmā paññāya titto puriso kāmehi na pariḍayhatīti
analyzed: na saḥ kāmehi tappati iti na hi iti pi pāṭhaḥ yasmā paññāya tittaḥ puriso kāmehi na pariḍayhati iti
translated: He is not burned by sensual pleasures means “he is not” is also a reading. Because a man who is satisfied with wisdom is not scorched by sensual pleasures.

original: attho. Na kurute vasanti tādisañhi purisaṃ taṇhā vase vattetuṃ na sakkoti, sveva🔽pana taṇhāya ādīnavaṃ disvā sarabhaṅgamāṇavo viya ca aḍḍhamāsakarājā viya ca taṇhāvase🔽na pavattatīti attho. Apacinethevāti viddhaṃsetheva. Samuddamattoti mahatiyā paññāya
analyzed: atthaḥ na kurute vasanti tādisam hi purisam taṇhā vase vattetum na sakkoti su eva  pana taṇhāya ādīnavam disvā sarabhaṅga māṇavaḥ viya ca aḍḍhamāsaka rājā viya ca taṇhā vase  na pavattati iti atthaḥ apacinetha iva ati viddhaṃsetha iva samudda matto ti mahatiyā paññāya
translated: The meaning is: He does not come under the sway of such a person, for craving is unable to lead him around. But rather, having seen the danger in craving, he does not come under the sway of craving, just as the young seer Sarabhṅga and King Aḍḍhamāsa did. The meaning is: He destroys, he shatters. With great wisdom: with great understanding.

original: samannāgatattā samuddappamāṇo. So mahantena aggināpi samuddo viya kilesakāmehi na tappati na ḍayhati.🔽Rathakāroti cammakāro. Parikantanti parikantanto. translated: He does not come under the sway of lust. The meaning is: he is not able to bring such a man under the sway of lust. But rather, having seen the danger in lust, he does not come under the sway of lust, like the young seer Sarabhanga and like King Ajātasattu. The meaning is: he does not come under the sway of lust. He should break through: he should pierce through. He is like the ocean: he is like the ocean because he is endowed with great wisdom. He is not heated by sensual pleasures, like the ocean is not heated by a great fire.

original: paññāya kantanto yaṃ yaṃ odhiṃ kāmānaṃ cajati, tena tenassa kāmodhinā rahitaṃ taṃ

translated: The wheelwright: the leather-worker. He should scrape: he should scrape. analyzed: dhanam mahallaka kāle a labhitvā tappati socati pare ca sukhite disvā sayam dukkham  jīvantaḥ pubbe dhanam na pariyesissanti evam pacchā anutappati tasmai mahallaka kāle

Provider of all the taste of sensual pleasure: the provider of all the sensual pleasure of the five strands of sense pleasure. I will despise: I will despise him by not accepting his advice.

original: Na pubbeti ito pubbe dhammikasamaṇabrāhmaṇepi gilānāgilānepi cīvarādīni datvā appaṭijagganena🔽na payirupāsissaṃ. Tapoti sucaritatapo. Santoti tīhi dvārehi upasanto sīlavā. Idaṃ
analyzed: na pubba iti itas pubbe dhammika samaṇa brāhmaṇe pi gilāna agilāne pi cīvara ādīni da tvā a paṭijagganena  na payirupāsissam tapo ti su carita tapo santo ti tīhi dvārehi upasantaḥ sīlavā idam
translated: I have not served: I have not served before this even righteous ascetics and brahmins and the sick and nurses by giving them robes, etc., and by attending on them.🔽This: good conduct and austerity. Peaceful: restrained by virtue in the three doors. This is the meaning.

translated: “It is good, it is well said,” said the king. “In my youth I did not practice such austerities, and now,

analyzed: karotha iti vadati yaḥ ca etāni iti yaḥ pana etāni dasa kāraṇāni paṭhamam eva upāyena paṭipajjati

analyzed: samādāya vattati purisehi kattabbāni dhammika kiccāni karonto saḥ appamāda vihārī puriso
translated: and who, having undertaken them, acts accordingly, and who, doing the duties of a man, does them righteously, such a man, who dwells in heedfulness,

analyzed: pacchā na anutappati somanassa ppattaḥ uva hoti iti
translated: will not repent in the future, but will be filled with joy.”

translated: Thus did the Great Being preach the Law to the multitude every half-month in this manner. And the multitude, obeying his advice, fulfilled those ten things and were reborn in the World of the Gods.

analyzed: satthā imam dhamma desanam āharitvā evam mahā rāja porāṇaka paṇḍitā an ācariyakā api
translated: When the Teacher had related this Jātaka, he said, “Thus, O king, did the wise men of old, though they had no teacher,

analyzed: attanaḥ matiyā iva dhammaṃ desetvā mahājanam sagga pathe patiṭṭhāpesunti vatvā jātakaṃ  tadā parisāḥ buddha parisāḥ ahesum janasandha rājā pana aham eva ahosinti
translated: and by his own wisdom taught the Dhamma and established the multitude in the way to heaven.” So saying, he made the connection with the present, and identified the Birth by saying in conclusion, “At that time the assembly was the present assembly, and I myself was the king who gathered the people.”🔽🔽

original: Janasandhajātakavaṇṇanā pañcamā.
analyzed: janasandha jātaka vaṇṇanā pañcamā
translated: and by his own wisdom taught the Law and established the multitude in the path that leads to heaven.” So saying, he made the connection between the Jātaka and the present time, and identified the Birth by saying in conclusion, “At that time the assembly was the present assembly, and I myself was the king of the multitude.”🔽The Birth of the King of the Multitude.

original: [469] 6. Mahākaṇhajātakavaṇṇanā
translated: The Birth Story of the Great Reed.

original: Kaṇho kaṇho cāti idaṃ satthā jetavane viharanto lokatthacariyaṃ ārabbha kathesi.
analyzed: kaṇhaḥ kaṇhaḥ ca ati idam satthā jetavane viharantaḥ lokattha cariyam ārabbha kathesi
translated: Black and blacker. This story the Master told, while dwelling at Jetavana, about a deed done for the sake of the world.

original: Ekadivasañhi bhikkhū dhammasabhāyaṃ nisīditvā “yāvañcidaṃ, āvuso, satthā bahujanahitāya
analyzed: eka divasam hi bhikkhū dhamma sabhāyam nisīditvā yāvat ca idam āvuso satthā bahu jana hitāya
translated: For one day the monks, after sitting together in the Hall of Truth, said, “Brethren, the Master is indeed devoted to the welfare of the multitude.

original: paṭipanno attano phāsuvihāraṃ pahāya lokasseva atthaṃ carati, paramābhisambodhiṃ🔽patvā sayaṃ pattacīvaramādāya aṭṭhārasayojanamaggaṃ gantvā pañcavaggiyattherānaṃ
analyzed: paṭipannaḥ attanaḥ phāsu vihāram pahāya lokassa iva attham carati parama abhisambodhim  patvā sayam patta cīvaram ādāya aṭṭhārasa yojana maggam gantvā
translated: He has renounced his own comfort and is engaged in the welfare of the world.🔽Having attained the highest enlightenment, he took his bowl and robe and went eighteen leagues,🔽and set rolling the Wheel of the Law for the company of the eighteen Elders.

original: dhammacakkaṃ pavattetvā pañcamiyā pakkhassa anattalakkhaṇasuttaṃ kathetvā sabbesaṃ
analyzed: dhammacakkam pavattetvā pañcamiyā pakkhassa anatta lakkhaṇa suttam kathetvā sabbesam
translated: On the fifth day he preached the Discourse on the Characteristics of Non-self, and converted all the five hundred Arahants.

original: arahattaṃ adāsi. Uruvelaṃ gantvā tebhātikajaṭilānaṃ aḍḍhuḍḍhāni pāṭihāriyasahassāni🔽dassetvā pabbājetvā gayāsīse ādittapariyāyaṃ kathetvā jaṭilasahassānaṃ arahattaṃ
analyzed: arahattam adāsi uruvelam gantvā tebhātika jaṭilānam aḍḍhuḍḍhāni pāṭihāriya sahassāni  dassetvā pabbājetvā gayāsīse āditta pariyāyam kathetvā jaṭila sahassānam arahattam
translated: and gave them arahatship. Going to Uruvelā, he gave the three brothers, the matted-hair ascetics, a thousand miracles,🔽and after giving them the going forth, he gave the thousand matted-hair ascetics arahatship by preaching the Discourse on the Simile of the Poisonous Snake.

original: adāsi, mahākassapassa tīṇi gāvutāni paccuggamanaṃ gantvā tīhi ovādehi upasampadaṃ
analyzed: adāsi mahākassapassa tīṇi gāvutāni paccuggamanam gantvā tīhi ovādehi upasampadam
translated: He gave the going forth to Mahā Kassapa with the three phrases, and after going three leagues to meet him, he gave him arahatship with the three instructions.

original: adāsi. Eko pacchābhattaṃ pañcacattālīsayojanamaggaṃ gantvā pukkusātikulaputtaṃ anāgāmiphale
analyzed: adāsi ekaḥ pacchābhattam pañcacattālīsa yojana maggam gantvā pukkusāti kula puttam anāgāmi phale
translated: One (of the two chief disciples) went fifty-four leagues after the meal, and established the young man Pukkusāti in the fruit of non-return.

original: patiṭṭhāpesi, mahākappinassa vīsayojanasataṃ paccuggamanaṃ katvā arahattaṃ adāsi,
analyzed: patiṭṭhāpesi mahākappinassa vīsa yojana satam paccuggamanam katvā arahattam adāsi
translated: Mahā Moggallāna went two hundred and fifty leagues to meet (the Buddha), and gave him arahatship.

original: eko pacchābhattaṃ tiṃsayojanamaggaṃ gantvā tāva kakkhaḷaṃ pharusaṃ aṅgulimālaṃ arahatte
analyzed: ekaḥ pacchābhattam tiṃsa yojana maggam gantvā tāva kakkhaḷam pharusam aṅguli mālam arahatte
translated: One (of the two chief disciples) went thirty leagues after the meal, and established the very rough and tough Aṅgulimāla in arahatship.

original: patiṭṭhāpesi, tiṃsayojanamaggaṃ gantvā āḷavakaṃ yakkhaṃ sotāpattiphale patiṭṭhāpetvā
analyzed: patiṭṭhāpesi tiṃsa yojana maggam gantvā āḷavakam yakkham sotāpatti phale patiṭṭhāpetvā
translated: After going thirty leagues, he established the demon Āḷavaka in the fruit of stream entry,

original: kumārassa sotthiṃ akāsi. Tāvatiṃsabhavane temāsaṃ vasanto asītiyā devatākoṭīnaṃ dhammābhisamayaṃ
analyzed: kumārassa sotthim akāsi tāvatiṃsa bhavane temāsam vasantaḥ asītiyā devatā koṭīnam dhamma abhisamayam
translated: and made the prince safe. Dwelling in the Tāvatiṃsa (heaven) for three months, he gave eighty koṭis of gods the penetration of the Dhamma.

original: sampādesi, brahmalokaṃ gantvā bakabrahmuno diṭṭhiṃ bhinditvā dasannaṃ brahmasahassānaṃ
analyzed: sampādesi brahma lokam gantvā baka brahmunaḥ diṭṭhim bhinditvā dasannam brahma sahassānam

analyzed: saḥ mayham vasana ṭṭhānam āgantvā tāta mā evam karohi aham tava mātā iti vuccamānaḥ pi

analyzed: ṭhapetvā mam aññaḥ rājā na atthi aham tam gehe karitvā kilesa ratiyā ramissāmi iti maṃ

original: Rājā anupaparikkhitvāva āsīviso viya kuddho purise āṇāpesi “gacchatha, bhaṇe, padumakumāraṃ🔽bandhitvā ānethā”ti. Te nagaraṃ avattharantā viya tassa gehaṃ gantvā taṃ bandhitvā
analyzed: rājā gacchatha bhaṇe paduma kumāram  bandhitvā ānetha iti te nagaram avattharantāḥ viya tassa geham gantvā tam bandhitvā
translated: The king, without further ado, like a snake whose head has been crushed, gave orders to his men, saying, “Go, I say, and bind Prince Paduma🔽and bring him here.” So they went to his house, as if to destroy the city, bound him,

original: paharitvā pacchābāhaṃ gāḷhabandhanaṃ bandhitvā rattakaṇaveramālaṃ gīvāyaṃ paṭimuñcitvā
analyzed: paharitvā pacchābāham gāḍha bandhanam bandhitvā ratta kaṇavera mālam gīvāyam paṭimuñcitvā

original: vajjhaṃ katvā ānayiṃsu. So “deviyā idaṃ kamma”nti ñatvā “bho purisā, nāhaṃ rañño
analyzed: vajjham katvā ānayiṃsu saḥ deviyāḥ idam kamman ti ñatvā bho purisāḥ na aham rañño

original: dosakārako, nipparādhohamasmī”ti vilapanto āgacchati. Sakalanagaraṃ saṃkhubbhitvā
analyzed: dosa kārakaḥ nipparādhaḥ ham asmi iti vilapantaḥ āgacchati sakala nagaram saṃkhubbhitvā

analyzed: atha nam netvā raññaḥ dassesuṃ rājā disvā ava cittam niggaṇhitum a sakkontaḥ ayam a rājā ava
translated: Then they took him and showed him to the king. The king, as soon as he saw him, was unable to restrain his feelings, and said, “This man is not a king,

original: rājalīḷaṃ karoti, mama putto hutvā aggamahesiyā aparajjhati, gacchatha naṃ corapapāte
analyzed: rāja līḷam karoti mama puttaḥ hutvā aggamahesiyā gacchatha nam cora papāte
translated: but acts like a king. He is my son, but he has offended the chief queen. Go, and throw him into the thieves’ prison,

original: pātetvā vināsaṃ pāpethā”ti āha. Mahāsatto “na mayhaṃ, tāta, evarūpo aparādho atthi,
analyzed: vināsam āha mahāsattaḥ na mayham tāta evarūpaḥ aparādhaḥ atthi
translated: and let him perish there.” The Great Being said, “Father, I am not guilty of such an offence.

original: mātugāmassa vacanaṃ gahetvā mā maṃ nāsehī”ti pitaraṃ yāci. So tassa kathaṃ na gaṇhi.
analyzed: mātu gāmassa vacanam gahetvā mā mama na āsehi iti pitaram yāci saḥ tassa katham na gaṇhi

analyzed: tatas soḷasa sahassā antepurikā tāta mahāpaduma kumāra attanaḥ an anucchavikam idam

analyzed: mahā viravam viraviṃsu sabbe khattiya mahāsāla ādayaḥ api amacca parijanā api deva
translated: and they uttered a great cry. All the nobles and the great householders, and the ministers and their retinue, said: “Your Majesty,

original: satta gāthā abhāsiṃsu –

analyzed: yaḥ ca a paṭivekkhitvā daṇḍam kubbati khattiyaḥ
translated: “The noble who punishes without careful consideration,

translated: “He who carefully considers these things, whether they are great or small,

analyzed: na ekanta mudunā sakkā ekanta tikhiṇena vā
translated: “It is not possible with only gentleness, or only sharpness,

original: nāma natthi, pacchā kakkhaḷarājūnaṃyeva kāle etaṃ uppannaṃ, taṃ sandhāya te amaccā

translated: And they said:🔽“The king who, without investigation,🔽inflicts punishment in excess of the offense,

analyzed: samakkhikam bhuñjati nāma a daṇḍiyanti yaḥ a daṇḍiyam a daṇḍa paṇetabbam ca daṇḍetvā daṇḍiyam ca

analyzed: daṇḍapaṇetabbam a daṇḍetvā attanaḥ rucim eva karoti saḥ andhaḥ viya visamam maggam paṭipanno  na jānāti samāsamam tatas pāsāṇa ādīsu pakkhalantaḥ andhaḥ viya catūsu apāyesu mahā dukkham
translated: and who does not punish the punishable and the pardonable, but acts according to his own whim, is like a blind man who has entered a road that is uneven.🔽He does not know what is right and what is wrong, and therefore, like a blind man who stumbles over rocks and so on, he will fall into the four states of deprivation and suffer great suffering.

original: pāpuṇātīti attho. Etāni ṭhānānīti etāni daṇḍiyādaṇḍiyakāraṇāni ceva daṇḍiyakāraṇesupi
analyzed: pāpuṇāti iti etāni daṇḍiya adaṇḍiya kāraṇāni ca iva daṇḍiya kāraṇesu pi
