translated: He is soft: the people of the kingdom despise, disrepect the soft king, he is not able to rule the kingdom without stealing. analyzed: bāhā paggayha kanditvā kese vikirayamānāḥ vilapiṃsu rājā ime imassa papāte khipanam

analyzed: katvā gāhāpetvā papāte khipāpesi athassa mettā anubhāvena pabbate adhivatthā devatā

analyzed: mā bhāyi mahā padumā iti tam samassāsetvā ubhohi hatthehi gahetvā hadaye ṭhapetvā  dibba samphassam pharāpetvā otaritvā pabbata pāde patiṭṭhita nāga rājassa phaṇa gabbhe

translated: “He reveals his secrets, but does not conceal his secrets;

original: Kammaṃ tassa na vaṇṇeti, paññassa nappasaṃsati.
analyzed: kammam tassa na vaṇṇeti paññassa na ppasaṃsati
translated: He does not praise his deeds, nor does he praise his wisdom.

original: “Abhave nandati tassa, bhave tassa na nandati;
analyzed: abhave nandati tassa bhave tassa na nandati
translated: “He rejoices in his misfortune, but does not rejoice in his good fortune;

original: Accheraṃ bhojanaṃ laddhā, tassa nuppajjate sati;
analyzed: accheram bhojanam laddhā tassa na uppajjate sati
translated: Having obtained wonderful food, he does not arouse mindfulness towards him;

original: Tato naṃ nānukampati, aho sopi labheyyito.
analyzed: tatas nam na anukampati aho saḥ api
translated: He does not pity him, but thinks, ‘Oh, that he might get it too!’

original: “Iccete soḷasākārā, amittasmiṃ patiṭṭhitā;
analyzed: id ca ete soḷasa ākārāḥ amittasmin patiṭṭhitā
translated: These sixteen characteristics are found in a foe,

original: Yehi amittaṃ jāneyya, disvā sutvā ca paṇḍito”ti.
analyzed: yehi amittam jāneyya disvā sutvā ca paṇḍita uti
translated: By which a wise man, seeing or hearing of him, should know him for a foe.”

original: Mahāsatto imā pañca gāthā vatvāna puna –
analyzed: mahāsattaḥ imā pañca gāthāḥ vatvāna puna
translated: Having spoken these five verses, the Great Being asked a further question:

original: “Kāni kammāni kubbānaṃ, kathaṃ viññū parakkame;
analyzed: kāni kammāni kubbānam katham viññū parakkame
translated: “What are the deeds that a wise man should do? How should he strive?

original: Mittaṃ jāneyya medhāvī, disvā sutvā ca paṇḍito”ti. –
analyzed: mittam jāneyya medhāvī disvā sutvā ca paṇḍitā uti
translated: How should a wise man know a friend, seeing or hearing of him?”

original: Imāya gāthāya mittalakkhaṇaṃ puṭṭho sesagāthā abhāsi –
analyzed: imāya gāthāya mitta lakkhaṇam puṭṭhaḥ sesa gāthāḥ abhāsi
translated: Being asked this question about the characteristics of a friend, he spoke the following verses:

original: “Pavutthaṃ tassa sarati, āgataṃ abhinandati;
analyzed: pavuttham tassa sarati āgatam abhinandati
translated: “He remembers what he has done, and welcomes him when he comes;

original: Tato kelāyito hoti, vācāya paṭinandati.
analyzed: tatas kelāyitaḥ vācāya paṭinandati
translated: He is pleased to see him, and greets him with speech.

original: “Mitte tasseva bhajati, amitte tassa na sevati;
analyzed: mitte tassa iva bhajati amitte tassa na sevati
translated: “He associates with his friends, and does not associate with his foes;

original: Akkosante nivāreti, vaṇṇakāme pasaṃsati.
analyzed: akkosante nivāreti vaṇṇa kāme pasaṃsati
translated: He stops him from reviling others, and praises him who speaks well.

original: “Guyhañca tassa akkhāti, tassa guyhañca gūhati;
analyzed: guyhañca tassa akkhāti tassa guyhañca gūhati
translated: “He tells his secrets to him, and keeps his own secrets from him;

original: Kammañca tassa vaṇṇeti, paññaṃ tassa pasaṃsati.
analyzed: kammañca tassa vaṇṇeti paññam tassa pasaṃsati
translated: He praises his deeds, and extols his wisdom.

original: “Bhave ca nandati tassa, abhave tassa na nandati;
analyzed: bhave ca nandati tassa abhave tassa na nandati
translated: “He rejoices in his prosperity, and does not rejoice in his adversity;

original: Accheraṃ bhojanaṃ laddhā, tassa uppajjate sati;
analyzed: accheram bhojanam laddhā tassa uppajjate sati
translated: When he gets a wonderful meal, he remembers him.

original: Tato naṃ anukampati, aho sopi labheyyito.
analyzed: tatas nam anukampati aho saḥ api
translated: He pities him, thinking, “Oh, that he too might get it.”

original: “Iccete soḷasākārā, mittasmiṃ suppatiṭṭhitā;
analyzed: id ca ete soḷasa ākārāḥ mittasmin suppatiṭṭhitā
translated: “These sixteen aspects are well established In a friend who is a true friend.

original: Yehi mittañca jāneyya, disvā sutvā ca paṇḍito”ti.
analyzed: yehi mittam ca jāneyya disvā sutvā ca paṇḍitā uti
translated: By them a wise man should know a friend, Having seen him and heard him.”

original: Tattha na naṃ umhayate disvāti taṃ mittaṃ mittapatirūpako disvā sitaṃ na karoti,
analyzed: tattha na nam umhayate disvā ati tam mittam mitta pati rūpakaḥ disvā sitam na karoti
translated: Herein, he does not deceive him by seeing him: he does not make a show of delight by seeing a friend who is a mere semblance of a friend.

original: pahaṭṭhākāraṃ na dasseti. Na ca naṃ paṭinandatīti tassa kathaṃ paggaṇhanto na paṭinandati
analyzed: pahaṭṭha ākāram na dasseti na ca nam paṭinandati iti tassa katham paggaṇhantaḥ na paṭinandati
translated: He does not welcome him: he does not welcome his talk when it is started.🔽He does not give him his eye: he does not look when the other looks.

original: na tussati. Cakkhūni cassa na dadātīti olokentaṃ na oloketi. Paṭilomañcāti tassa🔽kathaṃ paṭippharati paṭisattu hoti. Vaṇṇakāmeti tassa vaṇṇaṃ bhaṇante. Nakkhātīti
analyzed: na tussati cakkhūni ca assa na dadāti iti olokentam na oloketi paṭilomam ca ati tassa  katham paṭippharati paṭisattu hoti vaṇṇa kāmā iti tassa vaṇṇam bhaṇante nakkhāti iti
translated: He is contrary: he contradicts what the other says.🔽He does not listen: he does not listen to what the other says.🔽He does not tell him his secret: he does not reveal his own secret to him.

original: attano guyhaṃ tassa na ācikkhati. Kammaṃ tassāti tena katakammaṃ na vaṇṇayati. Paññassāti
analyzed: attanaḥ guyham tassa na ācikkhati kammam tassa ati tena kata kammam na vaṇṇayati paññassa ati
translated: He does not praise his actions: he does not praise what he has done.🔽He does not praise his wisdom: he does not praise his excellence in knowledge.

original: assa paññaṃ nappasaṃsati, ñāṇasampadaṃ na pasaṃsati. Abhaveti avaḍḍhiyaṃ. Tassa nuppajjate
analyzed: assa paññam nappasaṃsati ñāṇa sampadam na pasaṃsati abhaveti avaḍḍhiyam tassa nu pajjate
translated: He does not further him: he does not promote him. He does not think of him: he does not remember him.

original: satīti tassa mittapatirūpakassa “mama mittassapi ito dassāmī”ti sati na uppajjati.
analyzed: sati iti tassa mitta patirūpakassa mama mittassa api itas dassāmi iti sati na uppajjati
translated: “He has no memory” means that he does not remember his friend and think, “I will give to him.”

original: Nānukampatīti muducittena na cinteti. Labheyyitoti labheyya ito. Ākārāti kāraṇāni.
analyzed: na anukampati iti mudu cittena na cinteti labheyyitoti kāraṇāni
translated: “He has no compassion” means that he does not think with a tender heart. “He would get from him” means that he would get from him. “Modes” means reasons.

original: Pavutthanti videsagataṃ. Kelāyitoti kelāyati mamāyati pattheti piheti icchatīti attho.
analyzed: pavutthanti videsa gatam kelāyitoti kelāyati mamāyati pattheti piheti icchati iti attho
translated: “One who has gone away” means one who has gone to a foreign land. “He would be jealous” means that he would be jealous, would be possessive, would desire, would be greedy. The meaning is that he would wish.

original: Vācāyāti madhuravacanena taṃ samudācaranto paṭinandati tussati. Sesaṃ vuttapaṭipakkhanayena
analyzed: vācāya ati madhura vacanena tam samudācarantaḥ paṭinandati tussati sesam vutta paṭipakkha nayena
translated: “With words” means that he would welcome him and be pleased with him by speaking sweet words. The rest should be understood by the method stated above.

original: veditabbaṃ. Rājā mahāsattassa kathāya attamano hutvā tassa mahantaṃ yasaṃ adāsi.🔽Satthā imaṃ dhammadesanaṃ āharitvā “evaṃ, mahārāja, pubbepesa pañho samuṭṭhahi, paṇḍitāva
analyzed: veditabbam rājā mahāsattassa kathāya atta manaḥ hutvā tassa mahantam yasam adāsi  satthā imam dhamma desanam āharitvā evam mahā rāja pubbe pesa pañhaḥ samuṭṭhahi paṇḍita ava
translated: The king, being pleased with the Great Being’s speech, gave him great honor.

original: naṃ kathayiṃsu, imehi dvattiṃsāya ākārehi mittāmitto jānitabbo”ti vatvā jātakaṃ samodhānesi
analyzed: nam kathayiṃsu imehi dvattiṃsāya ākārehi mitta amittaḥ jānitabbaḥ ti vatvā jātakam samodhānesi
translated: After telling this story, the Teacher said, “Thus, Great King, this question arose in the past, and the wise men answered it. One should know friend and foe by these thirty-two modes.”

original: – “tadā rājā ānando ahosi, paṇḍitāmacco pana ahameva ahosi”nti.
analyzed: tadā rājā ānandaḥ ahosi paṇḍitāmacco pana aham eva ahosinti
translated: Then he identified the Birth Story: “At that time the king was Ānanda, and I myself was the wise man.”

original: Mittāmittajātakavaṇṇanā dasamā.
analyzed: mitta amitta jātaka vaṇṇanā dasamā
translated: The Story of the Birth of Mitta and Amitta is the tenth.

original: Jātakuddānaṃ –
analyzed: jātakuddānam
translated: The Jātaka Commentary is ended.

original: Kuṇālaṃ bhaddasālañca, samuddavāṇija paṇḍitaṃ;
analyzed: kuṇālam bhaddasālam ca samuddavāṇija paṇḍitam
translated: Kuṇāla, Bhaddasāla, the Merchant of the Sea, the Wise Man,

original: Janasandhaṃ mahākaṇhaṃ, kosiyaṃ sirimantakaṃ.
analyzed: janasandham mahākaṇham kosiyam sirimantakam
translated: Janasandha, Mahākaṇha, Kosiya, Sirimantaka,

original: Padumaṃ mittāmittañca, iccete dasa jātake;
analyzed: padumam mitta amittañca it ca ite dasa jātake
translated: Paduma, Mitta and Amitta: these are the ten stories

original: Saṅgāyiṃsu mahātherā, dvādasamhi nipātake.
analyzed: saṅgāyiṃsu mahā therāḥ dvādasamhi nipātake
translated: which the Great Elders have included in the twelfth section.

original: Dvādasakanipātavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: dvādasaka nipāta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The Commentary on the Twelve Sections is ended.

original: 13. Terasakanipāto
analyzed: terasaka nipātaḥ
translated: . The Section of Threes

original: [474] 1. Ambajātakavaṇṇanā
translated: . The Story of the Birth of Amba

analyzed: ahāsi me amba phalāni pubbā iti idam satthā jetavane viharantaḥ devadattam ārabbha kathesi
translated: “He ate my mango fruits first,”—the Master told this tale while dwelling in Jetavana, about Devadatta.

analyzed: devadattaḥ hi aham buddhaḥ bhavissāmi mayham samaṇaḥ gotamaḥ na iva ācariyaḥ na upajjhāyaḥ ti  ācariyam paccakkhāya jhāna parihīnaḥ saṅgham bhinditvā anupubbena sāvatthim āgacchantaḥ
translated: For Devadatta, thinking, “I will become Buddha. The monk Gotama is neither my teacher nor my preceptor,”🔽and having rejected his teacher, and having fallen away from his meditation, and having split the Order, and having come to Sāvatthi by stages,

analyzed: bahijetavane pathaviyāḥ vivare dinne avīcim pāvisi tadā bhikkhū dhamma sabhāyam katham
translated: and having had a hole made in the earth in the Jetavana, entered Avīci. Then the monks, in the Dhamma Hall,

analyzed: samuṭṭhāpesuṃ āvuso devadattaḥ ācariyam paccakkhāya mahā vināsam pattaḥ avīci mahāniraye
translated: and they said, “Brother, Devadatta, having rejected his teacher, has met with destruction, and has been reborn in the Avīci Hell.”

original: nibbatto”ti. Satthā āgantvā “kāya nuttha, bhikkhave, etarahi kathāya sannisinnā”ti🔽pucchitvā “imāya nāmā”ti vutte “na, bhikkhave, idāneva, pubbepi devadatto ācariyaṃ
analyzed: nibbattoti satthā āgantvā kāya nuttha bhikkhave etarahi kathāya sannisinnā ati  pucchitvā imāya nāma ati vutte na bhikkhave idānā iva pubbe pi devadattaḥ ācariyam
translated: The Teacher came in and asked, “Monks, what is it that you are sitting here now talking about?”

original: paccakkhāya mahāvināsaṃ pattoyevā”ti vatvā atītaṃ āhari.
analyzed: paccakkhāya mahā vināsam vatvā atītam āhari
translated: When they told him, he said, “Monks, this is not the first time Devadatta has rejected his teacher and has met with destruction; he did the same thing in a previous state of existence also.” So saying, he related the following

original: Atīte bārāṇasiyaṃ brahmadatte rajjaṃ kārente tassa purohitakulaṃ ahivātarogena vinassi.🔽Ekova putto bhittiṃ bhinditvā palāto. So takkasilaṃ gantvā disāpāmokkhassācariyassa🔽santike tayo vede ca avasesasippāni ca uggahetvā ācariyaṃ vanditvā nikkhanto “desacārittaṃ
analyzed: atīte bārāṇasiyam brahmadatte rajjam kārente tassa purohita kulam ahi vāta rogena vinassi  ekaḥ iva puttaḥ bhittim bhinditvā palātaḥ saḥ takka silam gantvā disāpāmokkhassa ācariyassa  santike tayaḥ vede ca avasesa sippāni ca uggahetvā ācariyam vanditvā nikkhantaḥ desa cārittam
translated: In the dispensation of the Buddha Kassapa, in the city of Bārāṇasī, in the family of the king, there was a great plague.🔽Only one son escaped, and that by breaking through the wall and fleeing. He went to Takkasilā, and in the presence of a teacher who was the foremost man in the whole world,

original: jānissāmī”ti caranto ekaṃ paccantanagaraṃ pāpuṇi. Taṃ nissāya mahācaṇḍālagāmako ahosi.
analyzed: jānissāmi iti carantaḥ ekam paccanta nagaram pāpuṇi tam nissāya mahā caṇḍāla gāmakaḥ ahosi
translated: he learned the three Vedas and all the other branches of learning. When he had paid obeisance to his teacher and was about to depart, the teacher said to him, “Go to such and such a place, and there you will find a village of outcasts.🔽Learn their language and their customs, and then return.”

original: Tadā bodhisatto tasmiṃ gāme paṭivasati, paṇḍito byatto akāle phalaṃ gaṇhāpanamantaṃ🔽jānāti. So pātova vuṭṭhāya kājaṃ ādāya tato gāmā nikkhimitvā araññe ekaṃ ambarukkhaṃ
analyzed: tadā bodhisatto tasmin gāme paṭivasati paṇḍitaḥ byattaḥ akāle phalam  jānāti saḥ pātova vuṭṭhāya kājam ādāya tatas gāmā nikkhimitvā araññe ekam amba rukkham
translated: The Bodhisatta lived in that village. He was wise, clever, and knew how to gather fruit out of season.🔽He rose early in the morning, took his basket, left the village, and went to a mango tree in the forest.

original: upasaṅkamitvā sattapadamatthake ṭhito taṃ mantaṃ parivattetvā ambarukkhaṃ ekena udakapasatena
analyzed: upasaṅkamitvā satta pada matthake ṭhitaḥ tam mantam parivattetvā amba rukkham ekena udaka pasatena
translated: Standing seven steps away from the tree, he recited the spell, and struck the mango tree with a handful of water.

original: paharati. Rukkhato taṅkhaṇaññeva purāṇapaṇṇāni patanti, navāni uṭṭhahanti, pupphāni🔽pupphitvā patanti, ambaphalāni uṭṭhāya muhutteneva paccitvā madhurāni ojavantāni
analyzed: paharati rukkhataḥ purāṇa paṇṇāni patanti navāni uṭṭhahanti pupphāni  pupphitvā patanti amba phalāni uṭṭhāya muhuttena iva paccitvā madhurāni ojavantāni
translated: Immediately the old leaves fell off, new leaves sprang forth, flowers bloomed,

original: dibbarasasadisāni hutvā rukkhato patanti. Mahāsatto tāni uccinitvā yāvadatthaṃ khāditvā
analyzed: dibba rasa sadisāni hutvā rukkhataḥ patanti mahāsatto tāni uccinitvā yāvadattham khāditvā

original: kājaṃ pūrāpetvā gehaṃ gantvā tāni vikkiṇitvā puttadāraṃ posesi.
analyzed: kājam pūrāpetvā geham gantvā tāni vikkiṇitvā putta dāram posesi
translated: filled his basket, went home, sold them, and supported his wife and children.

analyzed: saḥ brāhmaṇa kumāraḥ mahāsattam akāle amba pakkāni āharitvā vikkiṇantam disvā nissaṃsayena
translated: The young brahmin saw the Great Being bringing mangoes out of season and selling them. He thought, “No doubt he has some trick.

analyzed: tehi manta balena uppannehi bhavitabbam imam purisam nissāya idam anaggham antam labhissāmi iti  cintetvā mahāsattassa ambāni āharaṇa niyāmam pariggaṇhantaḥ tathatas ñatvā tasmin araññataḥ
translated: “I will get this priceless treasure by means of this man.”🔽Having thus reflected, he observed the Great Being’s regular practice of bringing mangoes, and having ascertained the truth, he went to his house even before he returned from the forest.

analyzed: tassa geham gantvā a jānantaḥ viya hutvā tassa bhariyam kuhim
translated: Pretending not to know, he asked his wife, “Where is the master, the teacher?”

analyzed: pucchitvā araññam gataḥ iti vutte tam āgatam āgamayamānaḥ iva ṭhatvā āgacchantam disvā

analyzed: bhadde ayam māṇavaḥ manta atthāya āgataḥ tassa hatthe mantaḥ nassati a sappurisaḥ
translated: “Dear, this young man has come for the spell. The spell will be lost in his hands. He is a bad person.”

original: eso”ti. Māṇavopi “ahaṃ imaṃ mantaṃ ācariyassa upakārako hutvā labhissāmī”ti cintetvā
analyzed: esaḥ iti māṇavaḥ api aham imam mantam ācariyassa upakārakaḥ hutvā labhissāmi iti cintetvā
translated: The young man, thinking, “I will get this spell by becoming a benefactor to the teacher,”

analyzed: ayam māṇavaḥ jāti sampannaḥ hutvā mantatthāya amhākam veyyāvaccam karoti etassa hatthe
translated: this student, though he is of noble birth, does us a service in order to learn the scriptures. Whether he gets the scriptures

original: manto tiṭṭhatu vā mā vā, detha tassa manta”nti. So “sādhū”ti sampaṭicchitvā tassa🔽mantaṃ datvā evamāha – “tāta, anagghoyaṃ manto, tava imaṃ nissāya mahālābhasakkāro
analyzed: manto tiṭṭhatu vā mā vā detha tassa mantanti saḥ sādhu iti sampaṭicchitvā tassa  mantam da tvā evam āha tāta manto tava imam nissāya mahā lābha sakkāro
translated: or not, please give him the scriptures.” He agreed, saying, “Very well,” and after giving him the scriptures, he said, “Dear,

original: bhavissati, raññā vā rājamahāmattena vā ‘ko te ācariyo’ti puṭṭhakāle mā maṃ nigūhittho,
analyzed: bhavissati raññā vā rāja mahāmattena vā kaḥ te ācariyaḥ ti puṭṭha kāle mā mamam nigūhittho
translated: this is a priceless scripture. Through it you will receive great gain and honor. If the king or a royal minister should ask you, ‘Who is your teacher?’ do not conceal me,🔽but say, ‘The teacher of the three Vedas, the brahmin student Jotipāla.’

original: sace hi ‘caṇḍālassa me santikā manto gahito’ti lajjanto ‘brāhmaṇamahāsālo me ācariyo’ti
analyzed: sace hi caṇḍālassa me santikā mantaḥ gahito ti lajjantaḥ brāhmaṇa mahāsālaḥ me ācariyo ti
translated: “If you are ashamed to say that you received the charm from a Caṇḍāla, and say instead that your teacher was a Brāhman Mahāsāla,

original: kathessasi, imassa mantassa phalaṃ na labhissasī”ti. So “kiṃ kāraṇā taṃ nigūhissāmi,
analyzed: kathessasi imassa mantassa phalam na labhissasi iti saḥ u kim kāraṇā tam nigūhissāmi
translated: you will not receive the reward of the charm.” The young man replied, “What reason have I to conceal him?

original: kenaci puṭṭhakāle tumheyeva kathessāmī”ti vatvā taṃ vanditvā caṇḍālagāmato nikkhamitvā
analyzed: kenacid puṭṭha kāle kathessāmi iti vatvā tam vanditvā caṇḍāla gāmataḥ nikkhamitvā
translated: Whenever anyone asks me, I will tell them that he is my teacher.” So saying, he paid his respects to the Caṇḍāla and departed from the Caṇḍāla village.

original: mantaṃ vīmaṃsitvā anupubbena bārāṇasiṃ patvā ambāni vikkiṇitvā bahuṃ dhanaṃ labhi.
analyzed: mantam vīmaṃsitvā anupubbena bārāṇasim patvā ambāni vikkiṇitvā bahum dhanam labhi
translated: He recited the charm, and in due course reached Bārāṇasī. There he sold mangoes and obtained much wealth.

original: Athekadivasaṃ uyyānapālo tassa hatthato ambaṃ kiṇitvā rañño adāsi. Rājā taṃ paribhuñjitvā🔽“kuto samma, tayā evarūpaṃ ambaṃ laddha”nti pucchi. Deva, eko māṇavo akālaambaphalāni
analyzed: atha eka divasam uyyāna pālo tassa hatthato ambam kiṇitvā raññaḥ adāsi rājā tam paribhuñjitvā  kutas samma tayā evarūpam ambam pucchi devaḥ ekaḥ māṇavaḥ akāla amba phalāni
translated: Now one day the keeper of the king’s garden bought mangoes from him and presented them to the king. The king ate the mangoes and

original: ānetvā vikkiṇāti, tato me gahitanti. Tena hi “ito paṭṭhāya idheva ambāni āharatū”ti
analyzed: ānetvā vikkiṇāti tatas me tena hi itas paṭṭhāya idha iva ambāni āharatu uti
translated: asked, “My good man, where did you get such mangoes as these?” “Your majesty, a young Brāhman has brought out-of-season mangoes to market and is selling them. I got mine from him.” “Well then, tell him to bring me some mangoes from now on.”

original: naṃ vadehīti. So tathā akāsi. Māṇavopi tato paṭṭhāya ambāni rājakulaṃ harati. Atha
analyzed: nam vadehi iti saḥ tathā māṇavaḥ api tatas paṭṭhāya ambāni rājakulam harati atha
translated: So the king’s man did as the king directed. From that time on the young Brāhman brought mangoes to the palace.

original: raññā “upaṭṭhaha ma”nti vutte rājānaṃ upaṭṭhahanto bahuṃ dhanaṃ labhitvā anukkamena
analyzed: raññā upaṭṭhaha manti vutte rājānam upaṭṭhahantaḥ bahum dhanam labhitvā anukkamena
translated: The king said, “Wait upon me.” So he waited upon the king, and receiving much wealth, he became in time

original: vissāsiko jāto. Atha naṃ ekadivasaṃ rājā pucchi “māṇava, kuto akāle evaṃ vaṇṇagandharasasampannāni
analyzed: vissāsikaḥ jātaḥ atha nam eka divasam rājā pucchi māṇava kutas akāle evam vaṇṇa gandha rasa sampannāni
translated: a man of confidence. One day the king asked him, “Student, how do you get these mangoes, which are so beautiful, fragrant, and delicious, out of season?

original: ambāni labhasi, kiṃ te nāgo vā supaṇṇo vā devo vā koci deti, udāhu mantabalaṃ eta”nti?
analyzed: ambāni labhasi kim te nāgaḥ vā supaṇṇaḥ vā devaḥ vā koci deti
translated: Does a nāga or a supaṇṇa or a god give them to you, or is it the power of a spell?”

original: “Na me mahārāja, koci deti, anaggho pana me manto atthi, tasseva bala”nti. “Tena
analyzed: na me mahā rāja koci deti anagghaḥ pana me mantaḥ atthi tassa iva tena
translated: “Great king, no one gives them to me. I have an incomparable spell, and it is the power of that.” “Well then,

original: hi mayampi te ekadivasaṃ mantabalaṃ daṭṭhukāmā”ti. “Sādhu, deva, dassessāmī”ti. Rājā
analyzed: hi mayam pi te eka divasam mantabalam daṭṭhu kāmā ati sādhu deva dassessāmi iti rājā
translated: we would like to see the power of your spell one day.” “Very well, your majesty, I will show it to you.” The king

original: punadivase tena saddhiṃ uyyānaṃ gantvā “dassehī”ti āha. So “sādhū”ti ambarukkhaṃ
analyzed: puna divase tena saddhim uyyānam gantvā dassehi iti āha saḥ sādhu iti amba rukkham
translated: went to the park with him the next day and said, “Show it to me.” He said, “Very well,” and approaching the mango tree,

original: upagantvā sattapadamatthake ṭhito mantaṃ parivattetvā rukkhaṃ udakena pahari. Taṅkhaṇaññeva
analyzed: upagantvā satta pada matthake ṭhitaḥ mantam parivattetvā rukkham udakena pahari
translated: he stood on the seventh step of the staircase, recited the spell, and struck the tree with water. At that very moment

original: ambarukkho heṭṭhā vuttaniyāmeneva phalaṃ gahetvā mahāmegho viya ambavassaṃ vassi.
analyzed: amba rukkhaḥ heṭṭhā vutta niyāmena iva phalam gahetvā mahā meghaḥ viya amba vassam vassi
translated: the mango tree, as described above, took the fruit and rained down mangoes like a great rain cloud.

original: Mahājano sādhukāraṃ adāsi, celukkhepā pavattiṃsu.
analyzed: mahā janaḥ sādhukāram adāsi celu khepā pavattiṃsu
translated: The multitude applauded, and the king also expressed his approbation.

original: Rājā ambaphalāni khāditvā tassa bahuṃ dhanaṃ datvā “māṇavaka, evarūpo te acchariyamanto🔽kassa santike gahito”ti pucchi. Māṇavo “sacāhaṃ ‘caṇḍālassa santike’ti vakkhāmi,🔽lajjitabbakaṃ bhavissati, mañca garahissanti, manto kho pana me paguṇo, idāni na🔽nassissati, disāpāmokkhaṃ ācariyaṃ apadisāmī”ti cintetvā musāvādaṃ katvā “takkasilāyaṃ
analyzed: rājā amba phalāni khāditvā tassa bahum dhanam da tvā māṇavakaḥ evarūpaḥ te  kassa santike gahito ti pucchi māṇavaḥ sacā aham caṇḍālassa santike iti vakkhāmi  lajjitabbakam bhavissati mañca garahissanti manto kho pana me paguṇaḥ idāni na  nassissati disā pāmokkham ācariyam apadisāmi iti cintetvā musāvādam katvā takkasilāyam
translated: The king, after eating the mangoes, gave the youth a large sum of money and said to him, “Young man, you possess such wonderful knowledge.

original: disāpāmokkhācariyassa santike gahito me”ti vadanto ācariyaṃ paccakkhāsi. Taṅkhaṇaññeva🔽manto antaradhāyi. Rājā somanassajāto taṃ ādāya nagaraṃ pavisitvā punadivase “ambāni
analyzed: disāpāmokkha ācariyassa santike gahitaḥ mā iti vadantaḥ ācariyam paccakkhāsi  mantaḥ antaradhāyi rājā somanassa jātaḥ tam ādāya nagaram pavisitvā puna divase ambāni
translated: From whom did you learn it?” The youth thought to himself, “If I say, ‘From a Caṇḍāla,’ they will laugh at me and say, ‘A Caṇḍāla’s knowledge is worth just so much.’ But my knowledge is not worth just so much. It will not be lost. I will tell them that I learned it from a teacher who is the foremost in the world in that particular branch of knowledge.” Accordingly he told a deliberate falsehood, saying, “I learned it from a teacher who is the foremost in the world in that particular branch of knowledge.” No sooner had he said these words than his knowledge vanished.

original: khādissāmī”ti uyyānaṃ gantvā maṅgalasilāpaṭṭe nisīditvā māṇava, ambāni āharāti āha.
analyzed: khādissāmi iti uyyānam gantvā maṅgala silā paṭṭe nisīditvā āhara āhara
translated: The king was delighted and took the youth with him to the city. The next day the king went to the garden, saying to himself, “I will eat mangoes.” He sat down on a lucky slab of stone and said to the youth, “Young man, bring me some mangoes.”

original: So “sādhū”ti ambaṃ upagantvā sattapadamatthake ṭhito “mantaṃ parivattessāmī”ti mante🔽anupaṭṭhahante antarahitabhāvaṃ ñatvā lajjito aṭṭhāsi. Rājā “ayaṃ pubbe parisamajjheyeva🔽ambāni āharitvā amhākaṃ deti, ghanameghavassaṃ viya ambavassaṃ vassāpeti, idāni thaddho
analyzed: saḥ sādhu iti ambam upagantvā satta pada matthake ṭhitaḥ mantam parivattessāmi iti mante  an upaṭṭhahante antara hita bhāvam ñatvā lajjitaḥ aṭṭhāsi rājā ayam pubbe parisamajjheya iva  ambāni āharitvā amhākam deti ghana megha vassam viya amba vassam idāni thaddhaḥ
translated: “Very well,” he thought, and went to the mango tree. Standing on the seventh step, he said to himself, “I will recite my spell.”

original: viya ṭhito, kiṃ nu kho kāraṇa”nti cintetvā taṃ pucchanto paṭhamaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: viya ṭhitaḥ kim nu kho kāraṇanti cintetvā tam pucchantaḥ paṭhamam gātham āha
translated: But when he found that the spell would not come to him, he realized that he had lost his power. Ashamed, he stood there. The king thought to himself, “Formerly he used to bring us mangoes from the mango tree and give them to us. He rained mangoes upon us like a rain of heavy clouds. But now he stands there as though he were stiff. What can be the reason?” And he asked the ascetic the reason. It was with reference to this that he uttered the first stanza:

original: “Ahāsi me ambaphalāni pubbe, aṇūni thūlāni ca brahmacāri;
analyzed: ahāsi me amba phalāni pubbe aṇūni thūlāni ca brahmacāri
translated: “Formerly thou broughtest me mangoes, small and large, O holy man;

original: Teheva mantehi na dāni tuyhaṃ, dumapphalā pātubhavanti brahme”ti.
analyzed: tehi iva mantehi na dāni tuyham dumapphalā pātubhavanti brahmā iti
translated: But now, with those same spells of thine, thou bringest me no fruit, O holy man.”

original: Tattha ahāsīti āhari. Dumapphalāti rukkhaphalāni.
analyzed: tattha ahāsi iti āhari dumapphalā ati rukkha phalāni
translated: Herein, he brought means he brought and gave. No fruit, O holy man means no tree-fruit.

original: Taṃ sutvā māṇavo “sace ‘ajja ambaphalaṃ na gaṇhāmī’ti vakkhāmi, rājā me kujjhissati, musāvādena naṃ vañcessāmī”ti dutiyaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: tam sutvā māṇavaḥ sace ajja amba phalam na gaṇhāmi iti vakkhāmi rājā me kujjhissati musāvādena nam vañcessāmi iti dutiyam gātham āha
translated: When the ascetic heard this, he thought, “If I say, ‘To-day I did not pick mangoes,’ the king will be angry with me. I will deceive him with a lie.” So he uttered the second stanza:

original: “Nakkhattayogaṃ paṭimānayāmi, khaṇaṃ muhuttañca mante na passaṃ;
analyzed: nakkhatta yogam paṭimānayāmi khaṇam muhuttañca mante na passam
translated: “I’ll observe the conjunction of the stars, I’ll watch for the right moment and the right time;

original: Nakkhattayogañca khaṇañca laddhā, addhā harissambaphalaṃ pahūta”nti.
analyzed: nakkhatta yogam ca khaṇam ca laddhā addhā harissamba phalam
translated: When I’ve got the conjunction of the stars and the right moment and the right time, I’ll surely bring back a lot of mango fruit.”

original: Tattha addhāharissambaphalanti addhā ambaphalaṃ āharissāmi.
analyzed: tattha addhā āharissamba phalanti addhā amba phalam āharissāmi
translated: Herein, he surely will bring back mango fruit means he will surely bring back mango fruit.

original: Rājā “ayaṃ aññadā nakkhattayogaṃ na vadati, kiṃ nu kho eta”nti pucchanto dve gāthā abhāsi –
analyzed: rājā ayam aññadā nakkhatta yogam na vadati kim nu kho etat ti pucchantaḥ dve gāthāḥ abhāsi
translated: The king, thinking “He never before said anything about the conjunction of the stars,” asked him, “Why is it so? “ and uttered two stanzas:

original: “Nakkhattayogaṃ na pure abhāṇi, khaṇaṃ muhuttaṃ na pure asaṃsi;
analyzed: nakkhatta yogam na pure abhāṇi khaṇam muhuttam na pure asaṃsi
translated: “He never before spoke of the conjunction of the stars, He never before mentioned the right moment and the right time;

original: Sayaṃ harī ambaphalaṃ pahūtaṃ, vaṇṇena gandhena rasenupetaṃ.
analyzed: sayam harī amba phalam pahūtam vaṇṇena gandhena rasena upetam
translated: He himself will bring back a lot of mango fruit, Good in color, smell, and taste.

original: “Mantābhijappena pure hi tuyhaṃ, dumapphalā pātubhavanti brahme;🔽Svājja na pāresi jappampi mantaṃ, ayaṃ so ko nāma tavajja dhammo”ti.
analyzed: manta abhijappena pure hi tuyham dumapphalā pātubhavanti brahme  su ājja na pāresi mantam ayam saḥ kaḥ nāma tavajja dhammaḥ ti
translated: “By your incantation of the mantras, O Brahma, The fruit of the trees became manifest to you;🔽But today you cannot even recite the mantras, What is this law of yours today?”

original: Tattha na pāresīti na sakkosi. Jappampīti jappantopi parivattentopi. Ayaṃ soti ayameva so tava sabhāvo ajja ko nāma jātoti.
analyzed: tattha na pāresi iti na sakkosi jappampi iti jappantaḥ api parivattentaḥ api ayam saḥ iti ayam eva saḥ tava sabhāvaḥ ajja kaḥ nāma jātaḥ ti
translated: Herein, cannot even means you are not able to. By your incantation of the mantras, O Brahma, means by your reciting and revolving the mantras. What is this law of yours today means what has this nature of yours become today?

original: Taṃ sutvā māṇavo “na sakkā rājānaṃ musāvādena vañcetuṃ, sacepi me sabhāve kathite āṇaṃ kareyya, karotu, sabhāvameva kathessāmī”ti cintetvā dve gāthā abhāsi –
analyzed: tam sutvā māṇavaḥ na sakkā rājānam musāvādena vañcetum sace pi me sabhāve kathite āṇam kareyya karotu sabhāvam eva kathessāmi iti cintetvā dve gāthāḥ abhāsi
translated: On hearing this, the student thought, “It is not possible to deceive the king with a lie. If he will act on my advice even if I tell him the truth, let him act. I will tell him the truth.” So he spoke two stanzas:

original: “Caṇḍālaputto mama sampadāsi, dhammena mante pakatiñca saṃsi;
analyzed: caṇḍāla puttaḥ mama sampadā asi dhammena mante pakatim ca saṃsi
translated: “I gave the son of a caṇḍāla the treasure, And told him the truth about the mantras.

original: Mā cassu me pucchito nāmagottaṃ, guyhittho atthaṃ vijaheyya manto.
analyzed: mā cassu me pucchitaḥ nāma gottam guyhitthaḥ attham vijaheyya manto
translated: But if he asks me my name and clan, And if I conceal it, the mantras will be lost.

original: “Sohaṃ janindena janamhi puṭṭho, makkhābhibhūto alikaṃ abhāṇiṃ;
analyzed: saḥ aham janindena janamhi puṭṭhaḥ makkha abhibhūtaḥ alikam
translated: “Then I, questioned by the lord of men, Overcome by pride, spoke falsely,

original: ‘Mantā ime brāhmaṇassā’ti micchā, pahīnamanto kapaṇo rudāmī”ti.
analyzed: mantāḥ ime brāhmaṇassa ati micchā pahīna mantaḥ kapaṇaḥ rudāmi iti
translated: ‘These mantras are the brahmin’s.’ Wrong, I lost the mantras, and now I weep in misery.”

original: Tattha dhammenāti samena kāraṇena appaṭicchādetvāva adāsi. Pakatiñca saṃsīti “mā🔽me pucchito nāmagottaṃ guyhittho, sace gūhasi, mantā te nassissantī”ti tesaṃ nassanapakatiñca
analyzed: tattha dhammena ati samena kāraṇena a paṭicchādetvā ava adāsi pakatim ca saṃsi iti mā  me pucchitaḥ nāma gottam guyhitthaḥ sace gūhasi mantā te nassissanti iti tesam nassana pakatiñca
translated: Herein, he gave the treasure to the son of a caṇḍāla by a straight way, without concealing it. And told him the truth about the mantras: he told him the truth about the mantras’ nature.🔽But if he asks me my name and clan, And if I conceal it, the mantras will be lost: he told him the nature of the mantras’ loss if he concealed it.

original: mayhaṃ saṃsi. Brāhmaṇassāti micchāti “brāhmaṇassa santike mayā ime mantā gahitā”ti
analyzed: mayham brāhmaṇassa ati micchā ati brāhmaṇassa santike mayā ime mantāḥ gahitā ati
translated: ‘These mantras are the brahmin’s.’ Wrong: he said, “I received these mantras from a brahmin.”

original: micchāya abhaṇiṃ, tena me te mantā naṭṭhā, svāhaṃ pahīnamanto idāni kapaṇo rudāmīti.
analyzed: micchāya abhaṇim tena me te mantā naṭṭhā svāham pahīna manto idāni kapaṇaḥ rudāmi iti
translated: I spoke wrongly, and so my spells were lost. Now that I have lost my spells I am a poor man and I weep.

original: Taṃ sutvā rājā “ayaṃ pāpadhammo evarūpaṃ ratanamantaṃ na olokesi, evarūpasmiñhi uttamaratanamante laddhe jāti kiṃ karissatī”ti kujjhitvā tassa garahanto –
analyzed: tam sutvā rājā ayam pāpa dhammaḥ evarūpam ratana mantam na olokesi evarūpasmin hi uttama ratana mante laddhe jātī kim karissati iti kujjhitvā tassa garahantaḥ
translated: When the king heard this he thought, “This wicked man did not look at such a precious spell. For if he had obtained such a precious spell, what would his birth have mattered?” And he was angry. And reproaching him, he said:

original: “Eraṇḍā pucimandā vā, atha vā pālibhaddakā;
analyzed: eraṇḍā pucimandā vā atha vā pālibhaddakā
translated: “If a man finds honey in a castor-oil plant, in a puchimanda tree, or in a pālibhaddaka tree,

original: Madhuṃ madhutthiko vinde, so hi tassa dumuttamo.🔽“Khattiyā brāhmaṇā vessā, suddā caṇḍālapukkusā;
analyzed: madhum madhutthikaḥ vinde saḥ hi tassa dumuttamaḥ  khattiyāḥ brāhmaṇāḥ vessāḥ suddāḥ caṇḍālapukkusā
translated: That tree is the worst of trees.🔽“If a man finds out the Dhamma from a noble, a brahmin, a merchant, a worker, an outcast, or a scavenger,

original: Yamhā dhammaṃ vijāneyya, so hi tassa naruttamo.
analyzed: yamhā dhammam vijāneyya saḥ hi tassa naruttamaḥ
translated: That man is the best of men.🔽“Having given him a beating and a whipping,

original: “Imassa daṇḍañca vadhañca datvā, gale gahetvā khalayātha jammaṃ;
analyzed: imassa daṇḍañca vadhañca da tvā gale gahetvā khalaya atha jammam
translated: Take him by the neck and lead him away,🔽He who has obtained the highest good through toil,

original: Yo uttamatthaṃ kasirena laddhaṃ, mānātimānena vināsayitthā”ti. –
analyzed: yaḥ uttamattham kasirena laddham māna atimānena vināsayittha ati
translated: And has destroyed it through pride and conceit.”

original: Imā gāthā āha.
analyzed: imāḥ gāthāḥ āha
translated: He spoke these verses.

original: Tattha madhutthikoti madhuatthiko puriso araññe madhuṃ olokento etesaṃ rukkhānaṃ
analyzed: tattha madhutthiko ti madhuatthikaḥ puriso araññe madhum olokento etesam rukkhānam
translated: Herein, a man who is seeking honey in the forest, looking for honey,

original: yato madhuṃ labhati, sova dumo tassa dumuttamo nāma. Tatheva khattiyādīsu yamhā purisā
analyzed: yatas madhum labhati saḥ uva dumaḥ tassa dumuttamaḥ nāma tathā iva khattiya ādīsu yamhā purisā
translated: and the tree from which he gets honey is called the best of trees. So too, among the nobles, etc., the man

original: dhammaṃ kāraṇaṃ yuttaṃ atthaṃ vijāneyya, sova tassa uttamo naro nāma. Imassa daṇḍañcāti
analyzed: dhammam kāraṇam yuttam attham vijāneyya saḥ uva tassa uttamaḥ naraḥ nāma imassa daṇḍam ca ati
translated: and the tree from which the honey is obtained is the best of trees. So too, among the nobles, etc., the man from whom the nobles, etc., can learn the Dhamma, the reason, the cause, the significance, is the best of men. ‘And his punishment’:

original: imassa pāpadhammassa sabbassaharaṇadaṇḍañca veḷupesikādīhi piṭṭhicammaṃ uppāṭetvā
analyzed: imassa pāpa dhammassa veḷu pesikā ādīhi piṭṭhi cammam uppāṭetvā
translated: and his punishment for all this evil is that the king’s men should tear off his skin and

original: vadhañca datvā imaṃ jammaṃ gale gahetvā khalayātha, khalikārattaṃ pāpetvā niddhamatha
analyzed: vadham ca da tvā imam jammam gale gahetvā khalayātha khalikā rattam niddham atha
translated: kill him and hang him by the neck on a gallows, and that you should then drive him about with a prod, and that he should be left there until he is dead.

original: nikkaḍḍhatha, kiṃ iminā idha vasantenāti.🔽Rājapurisā tathā katvā “tavācariyassa santikaṃ gantvā taṃ ārādhetvāva sace puna mante
analyzed: nikkaḍḍhatha kim iminā idha vasantena ati  rāja purisā tathā katvā tava ācariyassa santikam gantvā tam ārādhetvā ava sace puna
translated: ‘What is the use of his living here any longer?’

original: labhissasi, idha āgaccheyyāsi, no ce, imaṃ disaṃ mā olokeyyāsī”ti taṃ nibbisayamakaṃsu.
analyzed: labhissasi idha āgaccheyyāsi no ce imam disam mā olokeyyāsi iti tam
translated: The king’s men did as they were told. They then said to the student: ‘Go to your teacher and please him. If he teaches you the mantras again, you can come back here. If not, then never set eyes on this place again.’

original: So anātho hutvā “ṭhapetvā ācariyaṃ na me aññaṃ paṭisaraṇaṃ atthi, tasseva santikaṃ
analyzed: saḥ anāthaḥ hutvā ṭhapetvā ācariyam na me aññam paṭisaraṇam atthi tassa iva santikam
translated: They made him so miserable that he thought: ‘Apart from my teacher, I have no other refuge. I shall go to him and

original: gantvā taṃ ārādhetvā puna mantaṃ yācissāmī”ti rodanto taṃ gāmaṃ agamāsi. Atha naṃ
analyzed: gantvā tam ārādhetvā puna mantam yācissāmi iti rodantaḥ tam gāmam agamāsi atha naṃ
translated: I will go and propitiate him, and then I will ask him for the charm.” So saying, he went weeping to the village.

original: āgacchantaṃ disvā mahāsatto bhariyaṃ āmantetvā “bhadde, passa taṃ pāpadhammaṃ parihīnamantaṃ
analyzed: āgacchantam disvā mahāsattaḥ bhariyam āmantetvā bhadde passa tam pāpa dhammam
translated: When the Great Being saw him coming, he addressed his wife, saying, “My dear, see that wicked man coming back, having lost the charm.”

original: puna āgacchanta”nti āha. So mahāsattaṃ upasaṅkamitvā vanditvā ekamantaṃ nisinno “kiṃkāraṇā
analyzed: punar āgacchantanti āha saḥ mahāsattam upasaṅkamitvā vanditvā ekamantam nisinnaḥ kiṃkāraṇā
translated: When he had approached the Great Being, and had paid obeisance to him, and had taken his seat beside him, he was asked, “What is the reason of your coming?”

original: āgatosī”ti puṭṭho “ācariya, musāvādaṃ katvā ācariyaṃ paccakkhitvā mahāvināsaṃ pattomhī”ti
analyzed: āgataḥ asi iti puṭṭhaḥ ācariya musāvādam katvā ācariyam paccakkhitvā mahā vināsam pattomhi iti
translated: “Master, having lied, and having denied my master, I have fallen into great misfortune.”

original: vatvā accayaṃ dassetvā puna mante yācanto –
analyzed: vatvā accayam dassetvā puna mante yācantaḥ
translated: So saying, he confessed his fault, and asked for the charm again.

original: “Yathā samaṃ maññamāno pateyya, sobbhaṃ guhaṃ narakaṃ pūtipādaṃ;
analyzed: yathā samam maññamānaḥ pateyya sobbham guham narakam pūti pādam
translated: “As one who thinks a level place is even, might fall into a pit, a cave, a hell, or a place of corruption;

original: Rajjūti vā akkame kaṇhasappaṃ, andho yathā jotimadhiṭṭhaheyya;
analyzed: rajjū iti vai akkame kaṇha sappam andhaḥ yathā jotim adhiṭṭhaheyya
translated: Or as one who treads on a rope might tread on a black snake, or as a blind man might light on a lamp;

original: Evampi maṃ taṃ khalitaṃ sapañña, pahīnamantassa punappadāhī”ti. – gāthamāha;
analyzed: evam pi mam tam khalitam sa pañña pahīnam antassa punappadāhi iti gātham āha
translated: So have I, O wise one, fallen into misfortune; restore to me the charm I have lost.”

original: Tattha yathā samanti yathā puriso idaṃ samaṃ ṭhānanti maññamāno sobbhaṃ vā guhaṃ
analyzed: tattha yathā samanti yathā puriso idam samam ṭhānanti maññamāno sobbham vā guham
translated: Herein, as one who thinks a level place is even might fall into a pit, a cave, a hell, or a place of corruption;

original: vā bhūmiyā phalitaṭṭhānasaṅkhātaṃ narakaṃ vā pūtipādaṃ vā pateyya. Pūtipādoti himavantapadese
analyzed: vā bhūmiyā phalita ṭṭhāna saṅkhātam narakam vā pūti pādam vā pateyya pūti pādo ti himavanta padese
translated: Or he might fall into a pit of rotting corpses, or into a pit of ashes.

original: mahārukkhe sussitvā mate tassa mūlesu pūtikesu jātesu tasmiṃ ṭhāne mahāāvāṭo hoti,
analyzed: mahā rukkhe sussitvā mate tassa mūlesu pūtikesu jātesu tasmin ṭhāne mahā āvāṭaḥ hoti
translated: A pit of rotting corpses is a place in the Himalayas where a great tree has dried up and died. At its root is a great pit of rotting corpses.🔽That is what it is called.

original: tassa nāmaṃ. Jotimadhiṭṭhaheyyāti aggiṃ akkameyya. Evampīti evaṃ ahampi paññācakkhuno🔽abhāvā andho tumhākaṃ visesaṃ ajānanto tumhesu khalito, taṃ maṃ khalitaṃ viditvā
analyzed: tassa nāmam jotim adhiṭṭhaheyya ati aggim akkameyya evam pi iti evam aham pi paññā cakkhunaḥ  abhāvāḥ andho tumhākam visesam a jānanto tumhesu khalito tam mama khalitam viditvā
translated: If I were to light a fire, I would burn myself.🔽In the same way, because I am blind and do not know your special qualities, I have offended you.

original: sapañña ñāṇasampanna pahīnamantassa mama punapi dethāti.
analyzed: sa pañña ñāṇa sampanna pahīnam antassa mama puna api detha ati
translated: Now that you know that I have offended you, please give me the knowledge you have gained through your wisdom and your attainment of the knowledge of the mantras.”

original: Atha naṃ ācariyo “tāta, kiṃ kathesi, andho hi saññāya dinnāya sobbhādīni pariharati, mayā paṭhamameva tava kathitaṃ, idāni kimatthaṃ mama santikaṃ āgatosī”ti vatvā –
analyzed: atha nam ācariyaḥ tāta kim kathesi andhaḥ hi saññāya dinnāya sobbha ādīni pariharati mayā paṭhamam eva tava kathitam idāni kimattham mama santikam āgataḥ asi iti vatvā
translated: The teacher said, “My dear, what are you saying? A blind man avoids pits and so on by being given information. I told you this from the very beginning. Why have you come to me now?”🔽“I gave you the knowledge of the mantras in accordance with the Dhamma;

original: “Dhammena mantaṃ tava sampadāsiṃ, tuvampi dhammena paṭiggahesi;
analyzed: dhammena mantam tava sampadā asim tuvam pi dhammena paṭiggahesi
translated: you received it in accordance with the Dhamma.🔽I was pleased with you and told you about the mantras;

original: Pakatimpi te attamano asaṃsiṃ, dhamme ṭhitaṃ taṃ na jaheyya manto.
analyzed: pakatim pi te atta manaḥ asaṃsim dhamme ṭhitam tam na jaheyya manto
translated: I would not abandon the mantras to one who is not established in the Dhamma.”

original: “Yo bāla-mantaṃ kasirena laddhaṃ, yaṃ dullabhaṃ ajja manussaloke;
analyzed: yaḥ bāla mantam kasirena laddham yam dullabham ajja manussa loke
translated: What is so hard to get in the world of men,🔽Though he has gained the chance to live, the fool,

original: Kiñcāpi laddhā jīvituṃ appapañño, vināsayī alikaṃ bhāsamāno.
analyzed: kiñca api laddhā jīvitum appa paññaḥ vināsayī alikam bhāsamānaḥ
translated: Speaks falsely and destroys it all.🔽“To the fool, the deluded one, the ungrateful,

original: “Bālassa mūḷhassa akataññuno ca, musā bhaṇantassa asaññatassa;
analyzed: bālassa mūḷhassa a kataññuno ca musā bhaṇantassa a saññatassa
translated: The liar, the undisciplined,🔽We do not give such a spell,

original: Mante mayaṃ tādisake na dema, kuto mantā gaccha na mayhaṃ ruccasī”ti. –
analyzed: mante mayam tādisake na dema kutas mantā gaccha na mayham ruccasi iti
translated: Where can you go? You are not pleasing to me.”

original: Imā gāthā āha.🔽Tattha dhammenāti ahampi tava ācariyabhāgaṃ hiraññaṃ vā suvaṇṇaṃ vā aggahetvā dhammeneva
analyzed: imāḥ gāthāḥ āha  tattha dhammena ati aham pi tava ācariya bhāgam hiraññam vā suvaṇṇam vā aggahetvā dhammena iva
translated: He spoke these verses.🔽Herein, with what is right means I gave you the spell by means of what is right,

original: mantaṃ sampadāsiṃ, tvampi kiñci adatvā dhammena sameneva paṭiggahesi. Dhamme ṭhitanti
analyzed: mantam sampadāsim tvam pi kiñci a datvā dhammena samena iva paṭiggahesi dhamme ṭhitanti
translated: without taking gold or silver as your teacher’s fee. You too received it by means of what is right, without giving anything. Standing by what is right means

original: ācariyapūjakadhamme ṭhitaṃ. Tādisaketi tathārūpe akālaphalagaṇhāpake mante na dema,
analyzed: ācariya pūjaka dhamme ṭhitam tādisakā iti tathārūpe akāla phala gaṇhāpake mante na dema
translated: standing by the right way of honouring a teacher. To such a one means to one of such a kind, to one who takes the fruit out of season. We do not give such a spell.

original: gaccha na me ruccasīti.
analyzed: gaccha na me ruccasi iti
translated: Where can you go? You are not pleasing to me.

original: So evaṃ ācariyena uyyojito “kiṃ mayhaṃ jīvitenā”ti araññaṃ pavisitvā anāthamaraṇaṃ mari.
analyzed: saḥ evam ācariyena uyyojitaḥ kim mayham jīvitena ati araññam pavisitvā anātha maraṇam
translated: Thus dismissed by his teacher, thinking “What is life to me?” he went into the forest and died an inglorious death.

original: Satthā imaṃ dhammadesanaṃ āharitvā “na, bhikkhave, idāneva, pubbepi devadatto ācariyaṃ🔽paccakkhāya mahāvināsaṃ patto”ti vatvā jātakaṃ samodhānesi – “tadā akataññū māṇavo
analyzed: satthā imam dhamma desanam āharitvā na bhikkhave idānā iva pubbe pi devadatto ācariyam  paccakkhāya mahā vināsam patto ti vatvā jātakam samodhānesi tadā akataññū māṇavo
translated: The Teacher related this story, saying, “Monks, this is not the first time Devadatta has left his teacher and met with destruction;

original: devadatto ahosi, rājā ānando, caṇḍālaputto pana ahameva ahosi”nti.
analyzed: devadattaḥ ahosi rājā ānando caṇḍāla putto pana aham eva ahosinti
translated: in a previous state of existence also he did so.” And with this preface he related a Jātaka of the past. “At that time,” said he, “the ungrateful student was Devadatta, the king was Ānanda, and I myself was the son of the Caṇḍāla.”🔽So saying, he pronounced the following Stanza,

original: Ambajātakavaṇṇanā paṭhamā.
analyzed: amba jātaka vaṇṇanā paṭhamā
translated: The Birth Story of Amba, the first.

original: [475] 2. Phandanajātakavaṇṇanā
translated: The Birth Story of Phanda

original: Kuṭhārihattho purisoti idaṃ satthā rohiṇīnadītīre viharanto ñātakānaṃ kalahaṃ ārabbha
analyzed: kuṭhāri hatthaḥ puriso ti idam satthā rohiṇīnadī tīre viharantaḥ ñātakānam kalaham ārabbha
translated: When the Teacher was in residence at the bank of the river Rohini, he related this story concerning the quarrel of his kinsmen.

original: kathesi. Vatthu pana kuṇālajātake āvi bhavissati. Tadā pana satthā ñātake āmantetvā
analyzed: kathesi vatthu pana kuṇāla jātake āvi bhavissati tadā pana satthā ñātake āmantetvā
translated: The story of this Birth will be related in the Kuṇālajātaka.

original: – mahārājā, atīte bārāṇasiyaṃ brahmadatte rajjaṃ kārente bahinagare vaḍḍhakigāmo
analyzed: mahā rājā atīte bārāṇasiyam brahmadatte rajjam kārente bahi nagare vaḍḍhaki gāmaḥ
translated: At that time the Teacher addressed his kinsmen, saying, “Great king, in times past, when Brahmadatta was king of Benares, there was a village of carpenters outside the city.

original: ahosi. Tatreko brāhmaṇavaḍḍhakī araññato dārūni āharitvā rathaṃ katvā jīvikaṃ kappesi.
analyzed: ahosi tatra ikaḥ brāhmaṇa vaḍḍhakī araññataḥ dārūni āharitvā ratham katvā jīvikam kappesi
translated: In this village there lived a certain carpenter. He used to go out into the forest, cut timber, and make carts, and thus he earned his living.

original: Tadā himavantapadese mahāphandanarukkho ahosi. Eko kāḷasīho gocaraṃ pariyesitvā āgantvā
analyzed: tadā himavanta padese mahā phandana rukkhaḥ ahosi ekaḥ kāḷasīhaḥ gocaram pariyesitvā āgantvā
translated: Now in the Himalayas there was a great Phandana tree. A black lion, after seeking his food, came and lay down at its foot.

original: tassa mūle nipajji. Athassa ekadivasaṃ vāte paharante eko sukkhadaṇḍako patitvā khandhe🔽avatthāsi. So thokaṃ khandhena rujantena bhītatasito uṭṭhāya pakkhanditvā puna nivatto
analyzed: tassa mūle nipajji athassa eka divasam vāte paharante ekaḥ sukkha daṇḍako patitvā khandhe  so thokam khandhena rujantena bhīta tasitaḥ uṭṭhāya pakkhanditvā puna nivatto
translated: One day, as the wind was blowing, a dry branch fell down and stuck in his mane.

original: āgatamaggaṃ olokento kiñci adisvā “añño maṃ sīho vā byaggho vā anubandhanto natthi,
analyzed: āgata maggaṃ olokento kiñci a disvā aññaḥ mam sīhaḥ vā byagghaḥ vā anubandhantaḥ natthi
translated: He got up in fear and trembling, with a slight pain in his shoulder, and after running a little way, he turned back and looked along the path by which he had come. Seeing nothing, he thought, “There is no other lion or tiger following me.

original: imasmiṃ pana rukkhe nibbattadevatā maṃ ettha nipajjantaṃ na sahati maññe, hotu jānissāmī”ti🔽aṭṭhāne kopaṃ bandhitvā rukkhaṃ paharitvā “neva tava rukkhassa pattaṃ khādāmi, na
analyzed: imasmin pana rukkhe nibbatta devatā mam ettha nipajjantam na sahati maññe hotu jānissāmi iti  aṭṭhāne kopam bandhitvā rukkham paharitvā na iva tava rukkhassa pattam khādāmi na
translated: But the spirit that dwells in this tree cannot bear to see me lying here. Well, I will find out.”

original: sākhaṃ bhañjāmi, idha aññe mige vasante sahasi, maṃ na sahasi, ko mayhaṃ doso atthi,
analyzed: sākham bhañjāmi idha aññe mige vasante sahasi mam na sahasi kaḥ mayham dosaḥ atthi
translated: He took up a position and, in a rage, struck the tree, saying, “I do not eat the leaves of your tree, nor do I break off your branches. Other animals dwell in you without your being able to bear with them, but you are able to bear with me. What is my fault?

original: katipāhaṃ āgamehi, samūlaṃ te rukkhaṃ uppāṭetvā khaṇḍākhaṇḍikaṃ chedāpessāmī”ti rukkhadevataṃ
analyzed: katipāham āgamehi sa mūlam te rukkham uppāṭetvā khaṇḍākhaṇḍikam chedāpessāmi iti rukkha devatam
translated: Wait a few days, and I will pull up your tree by the roots and have it cut up into pieces.”

original: tajjetvā ekaṃ purisaṃ upadhārento vicari. Tadā so brāhmaṇavaḍḍhakī dve tayo manusse
analyzed: tat jetvā ekam purisam upadhārentaḥ tadā saḥ brāhmaṇa vaḍḍhakī dve tayaḥ manusse
translated: At that time the brahman woodman, taking two or three men with him,

original: ādāya rathadārūnaṃ atthāya yānakena taṃ padesaṃ gantvā ekasmiṃ ṭhāne yānakaṃ ṭhapetvā
analyzed: ādāya ratha dārūnam atthāya yānakena tam padesam gantvā ekasmin ṭhāne yānakam ṭhapetvā
translated: went in a cart to that place to get timber for a chariot. He stopped the cart in one place,

original: vāsipharasuhattho rukkhe upadhārento phandanasamīpaṃ agamāsi. Kāḷasīho taṃ disvā
analyzed: rukkhe upadhārento phandana samīpam agamāsi kāḷasīhaḥ tam disvā
translated: and with an axe and a hatchet in his hand, he went to look for trees, and he came near the trap. The black lion, seeing him,

original: “ajja, mayā paccāmittassa piṭṭhiṃ daṭṭhuṃ vaṭṭatī”ti gantvā rukkhamūle aṭṭhāsi. Vaḍḍhakī🔽ca ito cito oloketvā phandanasamīpena pāyāsi. So “yāva eso nātikkamati, tāvadevassa
analyzed: ajja mayā paccāmittassa piṭṭhim daṭṭhum vaṭṭati iti gantvā rukkha mūle aṭṭhāsi vaḍḍhakī  ca itas citas oloketvā phandana samīpena so yāva esaḥ na atikkamati tāva devassa
translated: thought, “Today I must see the back of my enemy,” and he went and stood at the foot of a tree. The woodman

original: kathessāmī”ti cintetvā paṭhamaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: kathessāmi iti cintetvā paṭhamam gātham āha
translated: looked about him here and there, and he went along near the trap. He thought, “As long as he does not pass beyond this place, I will talk to him,” and he spoke the first stanza:

original: “Kuṭhārihattho puriso, vanamogayha tiṭṭhasi;
analyzed: kuṭhāri hatthaḥ purisaḥ tiṭṭhasi
translated: “With axe in hand a man stands there, seeking the forest;

original: Puṭṭho me samma akkhāhi, kiṃ dāruṃ chetumicchasī”ti.
analyzed: puṭṭhaḥ me samma akkhāhi kim dārum chetum icchasi iti
translated: When asked, good sir, tell me, what tree is it you wish to cut?”

original: Tattha purisoti tvaṃ kuṭhārihattho eko puriso imaṃ vanaṃ ogayha tiṭṭhasīti.
analyzed: tattha puriso ti tvam kuṭhāri hatthaḥ ekaḥ puriso imam vanam ogayha tiṭṭhasi iti
translated: Herein, a man means you are a man with an axe in your hand, seeking this forest and standing there.

original: So tassa vacanaṃ sutvā “acchariyaṃ vata bho, na vata me ito pubbe migo manussavācaṃ
analyzed: saḥ tassa vacanam sutvā acchariyam vata bho na vata me itas pubbe migaḥ manussa vācam
translated: Hearing his words, the king thought: “It is wonderful indeed! Never before have I heard a deer speak the human language.

original: bhāsanto diṭṭhapubbo, esa rathānucchavikaṃ dāruṃ jānissati, pucchissāmi na”nti cintetvā dutiyaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: bhāsantaḥ diṭṭha pubbaḥ esa ratha anucchavikam dārum jānissati pucchissāmi na nti cintetvā dutiyam gātham āha
translated: The man, hearing his words, thought, “It is wonderful indeed! Never before have I seen a deer speaking the human language. He will know the kind of wood suitable for the axle. I will ask him.” So he spoke the second stanza:

original: “Isso vanāni carasi, samāni visamāni ca;
analyzed: issoḥ vanāni carasi samāni visamāni ca
translated: “Deer, you wander through the woods, through the even and the rough;

original: Puṭṭho me samma akkhāhi, kiṃ dāruṃ nemiyā daḷha”nti.
analyzed: puṭṭhaḥ me samma akkhāhi kim dārum nemiyā daḷhanti
translated: Tell me, good deer, what wood is strong enough for the axle?”

original: Tattha issoti tvampi eko kāḷasīho vanāni carasi, tvaṃ rathānucchavikaṃ dāruṃ jānissasīti.
analyzed: tattha isso ti tvam pi ekaḥ kāḷasīhaḥ vanāni carasi tvam ratha anucchavikam dārum jānissasi iti
translated: “Deer” means that you, too, are a deer, a black deer. You will know the kind of wood suitable for the axle.

original: Taṃ sutvā kāḷasīho “idāni me manoratho matthakaṃ pāpuṇissatī”ti cintetvā tatiyaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: tam sutvā kāḷasīhaḥ idāni me manorathaḥ matthakam pāpuṇissati iti cintetvā tatiyam gātham āha
translated: Hearing this, the black deer thought, “Now my wish will be fulfilled.” So he spoke the third stanza:

original: “Neva sālo na khadiro, nāssakaṇṇo kuto dhavo;
analyzed: na iva sālaḥ na khadiraḥ na assakaṇṇaḥ kutas dhavaḥ
translated: “Neither sāl nor khadira, nor askanna, nor dhavo;

original: Rukkho ca phandano nāma, taṃ dāruṃ nemiyā daḷha”nti.
analyzed: rukkhaḥ ca phandanaḥ nāma tam dārum nemiyā daḷhanti
translated: The tree called phandana, that wood is strong enough for the axle.”

original: So taṃ sutvā somanassajāto “sudivasena vatamhi ajja araññaṃ paviṭṭho, tiracchānagato me rathānucchavikaṃ dāruṃ ācikkhati, aho sādhū”ti pucchanto catutthaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: so tam sutvā somanassa jātaḥ sudivasena vatamhi ajja araññam paviṭṭho tiracchāna gataḥ me rathānucchavikam dārum ācikkhati aho sādhu iti pucchantaḥ catuttham gātham āha
translated: On hearing this, the deer was delighted and thought, “What a good day I have had today! I have entered the forest and a wild animal has pointed out to me a tree suitable for my chariot. How good!” and he asked the question in the fourth stanza:

original: “Kīdisānissa pattāni, khandho vā pana kīdiso;
analyzed: pattāni khandhaḥ vā pana kīdisaḥ
translated: “What are its leaves like, and what is its trunk like?

original: Puṭṭho me samma akkhāhi, yathā jānemu phandana”nti.
analyzed: puṭṭhaḥ me samma akkhāhi yathā jānemu phandananti
translated: Tell me, my friend, so that I may know the phandana tree.”

original: Athassa so ācikkhanto dve gāthā abhāsi –
analyzed: athassa saḥ ācikkhantaḥ dve gāthāḥ abhāsi
translated: Then the other deer, in pointing out the tree, spoke the two stanzas:

original: “Yassa sākhā palambanti, namanti na ca bhañjare;
analyzed: yassa sākhā palambanti namanti na ca bhañjare
translated: “The tree whose branches hang down, bend down, and do not break,

original: So rukkho phandano nāma, yassa mūle ahaṃ ṭhito.
analyzed: so rukkhaḥ phandanaḥ nāma yassa mūle aham ṭhitaḥ
translated: That tree is called the phandana tree, at the foot of which I stand.

original: “Arānaṃ cakkanābhīnaṃ, īsānemirathassa ca;
analyzed: arānam cakkanābhīnam īsānemi rathassa ca
translated: “The phandana tree will be suitable for the axle, the hub,

original: Sabbassa te kammaniyo, ayaṃ hessati phandano”ti.
analyzed: sabbassa te kammaniyaḥ ayam hessati phandanaḥ ti
translated: The shaft, and the rim of your chariot.”

original: Tattha “arāna”nti idaṃ so “kadācesa imaṃ rukkhaṃ na gaṇheyya, guṇampissa kathessāmī”ti
analyzed: tattha idam so kadāci isa imam rukkham na gaṇheyya guṇam pi issa kathessāmi iti
translated: Herein, the deer thought, “When will he not take this tree? I will tell him its qualities.”

original: cintetvā evamāha. Tattha īsānemirathassa cāti īsāya ca nemiyā ca sesassa ca rathassa
analyzed: cintetvā evam āha tattha īsā nemi rathassa ca ati īsāya ca nemiyā ca sesassa ca rathassa
translated: And he said this. Herein, the shaft and the rim of your chariot means the shaft and the rim and the rest of your chariot.

original: sabbassa te esa kammaniyo kammakkhamo bhavissatīti.
analyzed: sabbassa te esa kammaniyaḥ kamma kkhamaḥ bhavissati iti
translated: “This tree will be suitable for your work and will be able to bear it.”

original: So evaṃ ācikkhitvā tuṭṭhamānaso ekamante vicari, vaḍḍhakīpi rukkhaṃ chindituṃ ārabhi.
analyzed: saḥ evam ācikkhitvā tuṭṭha mānasaḥ ekamante vicari rukkham chinditum ārabhi
translated: Having thus instructed him, he went away to one side, pleased in mind. The carpenter began to cut down the tree.

original: Rukkhadevatā cintesi “mayā etassa upari na kiñci pātitaṃ, ayaṃ aṭṭhāne āghātaṃ bandhitvā
analyzed: rukkha devatā cintesi mayā etassa upari na kiñci pātitam ayam aṭṭhāne āghātam bandhitvā
translated: The tree-spirit thought, “I have not caused him any harm, but he has become angry for no reason and is destroying my dwelling.

original: mama vimānaṃ nāseti, ahañca vinassissāmi, ekenupāyena imañca issaṃ vināsessāmī”ti.
analyzed: mama vimānam aham ca vinassissāmi ekena upāyena imam ca issam vināsessāmi iti
translated: And I will be destroyed too. There is only one way to destroy this man.”

original: Sā vanakammikapuriso viya hutvā tassa santikaṃ āgantvā pucchi “bho purisa manāpo🔽te rukkho laddho, imaṃ chinditvā kiṃ karissasī”ti? “Rathanemiṃ karissāmī”ti. “Iminā🔽rukkhena ratho bhavissatī”ti kena te akkhātanti. “Ekena kāḷasīhenā”ti. “Sādhu suṭṭhu
analyzed: sā vana kammika purisaḥ viya hutvā tassa santikam āgantvā pucchi bho purisa manāpaḥ  te rukkhaḥ laddhaḥ imam chinditvā kim karissasi iti ratha nemim karissāmi iti iminā  rukkhena rathaḥ bhavissati iti kena te akkhātanti ekena kāḷasīhena ati sādhu suṭṭhu
translated: Disguising herself as a forest-dweller, she went to him and asked, “Sir, is this tree to your liking?🔽What will you do with it after cutting it down?” “I will make a wheel for a chariot.” “With this tree you will have a chariot.

original: tena akkhātaṃ, iminā rukkhena ratho sundaro bhavissati, kāḷasīhassa galacammaṃ uppāṭetvā
analyzed: tena akkhātam iminā rukkhena rathaḥ sundaraḥ bhavissati kāḷasīhassa gala cammam uppāṭetvā
translated: Who told you?” “A black antelope.” “Good, it was well told by him. With this tree you will have a beautiful chariot. Tear off the skin of the black antelope’s neck🔽and

original: caturaṅgulamatte ṭhāne ayapaṭṭena viya nemimaṇḍale parikkhitte nemi ca thirā bhavissati,
analyzed: catur aṅgula matte ṭhāne aya paṭṭena viya nemi maṇḍale parikkhitte nemi ca thirā bhavissati
translated: “If you will make the wheel-rim so that it will be as thin as a razor’s edge, and will have a rim only four inches wide, the wheel will be strong,

original: bahuñca dhanaṃ labhissasī”ti. “Kāḷasīhacammaṃ kuto lacchāmī”ti? “Tvaṃ bālakosi, ayaṃ
analyzed: bahum ca dhanam labhissasi iti kāḷasīha cammam kutas lacchāmi iti tvam bālakā asi ayam
translated: and you will receive much money.” “Where can I get a black lion’s skin?” “You are a fool, Bālakāsi.

original: tava rukkho vane ṭhito na palāyati, tvaṃ yena te rukkho akkhāto, tassa santikaṃ gantvā🔽‘sāmi tayā dassitarukkhaṃ kataraṭṭhāne chindāmī’ti vañcetvā ānehi, atha naṃ nirāsaṅkaṃ
analyzed: tava rukkhaḥ vane ṭhitaḥ na palāyati tvam yena te rukkhaḥ akkhāto tassa santikam gantvā  sāmi tayā dassita rukkham katara ṭṭhāne chindāmi iti vañcetvā ānehi atha nam nirāsaṅkam
translated: This tree of yours stands in the forest; it will not run away. Go to the man who told you of the tree,

original: ‘idha ca ettha ca chindā’ti mukhatuṇḍaṃ pasāretvā ācikkhantaṃ tikhiṇena mahāpharasunā
analyzed: idha ca ettha ca chindāti mukha tuṇḍam pasāretvā ācikkhantam tikhiṇena mahā pharasunā
translated: and deceive him, saying, ‘Sir, where shall I cut the tree which you have pointed out to me?’ When he has shown you the tree without the least hesitation, saying, ‘Cut it here and there,’

original: koṭṭetvā jīvitakkhayaṃ pāpetvā cammaṃ ādāya varamaṃsaṃ khāditvā rukkhaṃ chindā”ti
analyzed: koṭṭetvā jīvita khayam pāpetvā cammam ādāya vara maṃsam khāditvā rukkham chindāti
translated: take your sharp axe and cut off his head. Then take the skin and eat the choice meat, and cut down the tree.”

original: veraṃ appesi. Tamatthaṃ pakāsento satthā imā gāthā āha –
analyzed: veram appesi tam attham pakāsentaḥ satthā imāḥ gāthāḥ āha
translated: Thus did he incite him to commit murder. Expounding this matter, the Teacher pronounced the following Stanza,

original: “Iti phandanarukkhopi, tāvade ajjhabhāsatha;
analyzed: iti tāvade ajjhabhāsatha
translated: Thus did the trembling tree address him,

original: Mayhampi vacanaṃ atthi, bhāradvāja suṇohi me.
analyzed: mayham pi vacanam atthi bhāradvāja suṇohi me
translated: “I have a message for you, Bhāradvāja; listen to me.

original: “Issassa upakkhandhamhā, ukkacca caturaṅgulaṃ;
analyzed: issassa upakkhandhamhā ukkacca catur aṅgulam
translated: Four inches, and then,

original: Tena nemiṃ pasāresi, evaṃ daḷhataraṃ siyā.
analyzed: tena nemim pasāresi evam daḷhataram siyā
translated: With his wheel, he rubbed the tree, and so made it stronger still.🔽“Thus, even a trembling tree,

original: “Iti phandanarukkhopi, veraṃ appesi tāvade;
analyzed: iti veram appesi tāvade
translated: The spirit, for the time being, made his enmity known;

original: Jātānañca ajātānaṃ, issānaṃ dukkhamāvahī”ti.
analyzed: jātānam ca a jātānam issānam dukkham āvahi iti
translated: And he brought suffering to the spirits, both those born and those unborn.”

original: Tattha bhāradvājāti taṃ gottena ālapati. Upakkhandhamhāti khandhato. Ukkaccāti ukkantitvā.
analyzed: tattha bhāradvājāḥ iti tam gottena ālapati upa khandhamhā ati khandhataḥ ukkacca ati ukkantitvā
translated: Herein, Bhāradvāja is a clan name. From the trunk means from the trunk of the tree. With a leap means with a jump.

original: Vaḍḍhakī rukkhadevatāya vacanaṃ sutvā “aho ajja mayhaṃ maṅgaladivaso”ti kāḷasīhaṃ ghātetvā rukkhaṃ chetvā pakkāmi. Tamatthaṃ pakāsento satthā āha –
analyzed: vaḍḍhakī rukkha devatāya vacanam sutvā aho ajja mayham maṅgala divasaḥ ti kāḷasīham ghātetvā rukkham chetvā pakkāmi tam attham pakāsentaḥ satthā āha
translated: Having heard the tree-spirit’s words, the carpenter thought, “Ah, today is an auspicious day for me,” killed the black lion, cut down the tree, and left. Expounding that matter, the Teacher said:🔽“Thus, the spirit and the tree,

original: “Iccevaṃ phandano issaṃ, isso ca pana phandanaṃ;
analyzed: iccā ivam phandanaḥ issam issaḥ ca pana phandanam
translated: And the spirit and the tree,🔽By quarreling with each other,

original: Aññamaññaṃ vivādena, aññamaññamaghātayuṃ.
analyzed: aññam aññam vivādena aññam aññam aghātayum
translated: Sought to kill each other.🔽“Even so, among human beings,

original: “Evameva manussānaṃ, vivādo yattha jāyati;
analyzed: evam eva manussānam vivādaḥ yattha jāyati
translated: Wherever a quarrel arises,🔽They dance the peacock dance,

original: Mayūranaccaṃ naccanti, yathā te issaphandanā.
analyzed: mayūra naccam naccanti yathā te issaphandanā
translated: Just like the spirit and the tree.🔽“Therefore, I say to you, good people,

original: “Taṃ vo vadāmi bhaddaṃ vo, yāvantettha samāgatā;
analyzed: tam vaḥ vadāmi bhaddam vaḥ yāvantā itthā samāgatā
translated: Who have gathered here,🔽Be friendly, do not quarrel,

original: Sammodatha mā vivadatha, mā hotha issaphandanā.
analyzed: sammodatha mā vivadatha mā hotha issaphandanā
translated: Do not be like the spirit and the tree.

original: “Sāmaggimeva sikkhetha, buddhehetaṃ pasaṃsitaṃ;
analyzed: sāmaggim eva sikkhetha buddhehi etam pasaṃsitam
translated: “Let him train for unity, since this is praised by the Enlightened One;

original: Sāmaggirato dhammaṭṭho, yogakkhemā na dhaṃsatī”ti.🔽Tattha aghātayunti ghātāpesuṃ. Mayūranaccaṃ naccantīti mahārājā yattha hi manussānaṃ🔽vivādo hoti, tattha yathā nāma mayūrā naccantā paṭicchādetabbaṃ rahassaṅgaṃ pākaṭaṃ
analyzed: sāmaggi rataḥ dhammaṭṭhaḥ yogakkhemā na dhaṃsati iti  tattha aghātayunti ghātāpesum mayūra naccam naccanti iti mahā rājā yattha hi manussānam  vivādaḥ hoti tattha yathā nāma mayūrā naccantā paṭicchādetabbam rahassaṅgam pākaṭam
translated: Delighting in unity, steadfast in Dhamma, he does not break up the Sangha.”🔽Herein, they had them killed is they had them murdered. They danced the peacock dance is just as peacocks, when they see a place where human beings are quarrelling,

original: karonti, evaṃ manussā aññamaññassa randhaṃ pakāsentā mayūranaccaṃ naccanti nāma.
analyzed: karonti evam manussāḥ añña maññassa randham pakāsentāḥ mayūra naccam naccanti nāma
translated: conceal their private parts, which should be concealed, and make them public, so too, these people, by revealing each other’s faults, danced the peacock dance.

original: Yathā te issaphandanā aññamaññassa randhaṃ pakāsentā nacciṃsu nāma. Taṃ voti tena🔽kāraṇena tumhe vadāmi. Bhaddaṃ voti bhaddaṃ tumhākaṃ hotu. Yāvantetthāti yāvanto🔽ettha issaphandanasadisā mā ahuvattha. Sāmaggimeva sikkhethāti samaggabhāvameva tumhe
analyzed: yathā te issaphandanāḥ aññamaññassa randham pakāsentāḥ nāma tam voti tena  kāraṇena tumhe vadāmi bhaddam vaḥ ti bhaddam tumhākam hotu yāvantā itthā ati yāvanto  ettha issa phandana sadisā mā ahuvattha sāmaggim eva sikkhetha ati samagga bhāvam eva tumhe
translated: As they danced, revealing each other’s faults like those peacocks,

original: sikkhatha, idaṃ paññāvuddhehi paṇḍitehi pasaṃsitaṃ. Dhammaṭṭhoti sucaritadhamme ṭhito.
analyzed: sikkhatha idam paññā vuddhehi paṇḍitehi pasaṃsitam dhammaṭṭho ti su carita dhamme ṭhitaḥ
translated: for that reason I say this to you. Good luck, good luck to you. As many as there are here is as many as there are here. Do not be like this is do not be like this. Let him train for unity is let him train for unity of communion. This is praised by the wise who have developed understanding. Steadfast in Dhamma is steadfast in the Dhamma of good conduct.

original: Yogakkhemā na dhaṃsatīti yogehi khemā nibbānā na parihāyatīti nibbānena desanākūṭaṃ
analyzed: yoga khemā na dhaṃsati iti yogehi khemā nibbānā na parihāyati iti nibbānena desanā kūṭam
translated: “She will not fail in the security of the goal” means that she will not fail in the security of Nibbāna.

original: gaṇhi. Sakyarājāno dhammakathaṃ sutvā samaggā jātā.
analyzed: gaṇhi sakya rājānaḥ dhamma katham sutvā samaggā jātā
translated: The king of the Sakyans, having heard the discourse on the Law, became reconciled.

original: Satthā imaṃ dhammadesanaṃ āharitvā jātakaṃ samodhānesi “tadā taṃ kāraṇaṃ viditvā tasmiṃ vanasaṇḍe nivutthadevatā ahameva ahosi”nti.
analyzed: satthā imam dhamma desanam āharitvā jātakam samodhānesi tadā tam kāraṇam viditvā tasmim vana saṇḍe nivuttha devatā aham eva ahosinti
translated: When the Teacher had related this discourse on the Law, he made the connection and identified the Birth Story, saying, “At that time, knowing the reason, the goddess who dwelt in that forest thicket was myself.”

original: Phandanajātakavaṇṇanā dutiyā.
analyzed: phandana jātaka vaṇṇanā dutiyā
translated: The Story of the Birth as Phandanaka is ended.

original: [476] 3. Javanahaṃsajātakavaṇṇanā
translated: The Story of the Birth as the Swift-Flying Goose

original: Idheva haṃsa nipatāti idaṃ satthā jetavane viharanto daḷhadhammadhanuggahasuttantadesanaṃ ārabbha kathesi. Bhagavatā hi –
analyzed: idhā iva haṃsa nipata ati idam satthā jetavane viharantaḥ daḷha dhamma dhanuggaha suttanta desanam ārabbha kathesi bhagavatā hi
translated: Here, O geese, is your resting-place. This story the Master told, while dwelling in Jetavana, concerning the discourse on the Suttanta of the Great Mainstay of the Law. For the Master said,

original: “Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, cattāro daḷhadhammā dhanuggahā susikkhitā katahatthā katūpāsanā
analyzed: seyyathā api bhikkhave cattāro daḷha dhammāḥ dhanuggahāḥ su sikkhitāḥ kata hatthāḥ kata upāsanāḥ
translated: “Monks, suppose there were four great archers, well-trained, skilled in the use of the bow,

original: catuddisā ṭhitā assu, atha puriso āgaccheyya ‘ahaṃ imesaṃ catunnaṃ daḷhadhammānaṃ
analyzed: catuddisā ṭhitāḥ assu atha purisaḥ āgaccheyya aham imesam catunnam daḷha dhammānam
translated: standing in the four quarters, and a man were to come and say, ‘I will catch the arrows shot by these four great archers,

original: dhanuggahānaṃ susikkhitānaṃ katahatthānaṃ katūpāsanānaṃ catuddisā kaṇḍe khitte apatiṭṭhite🔽pathaviyaṃ gahetvā āharissāmī’ti. “Taṃ kiṃ maññatha, bhikkhave, ‘javano puriso paramena
analyzed: dhanuggahānam su sikkhitānam kata hatthānam kata upāsanānam catuddisā kaṇḍe khitte apatiṭṭhite  pathaviyam gahetvā āharissāmi iti tam kim maññatha bhikkhave javanaḥ puriso paramena
translated: “If four arrows were shot in the four directions,🔽and I were to catch them in the air before they reached the ground,

original: javena samannāgato’ti alaṃ vacanāyā”ti? “Evaṃ bhante”ti. Yathā ca, bhikkhave, tassa
analyzed: javena samannāgataḥ ti alam vacanāya ati evam bhante iti yathā ca bhikkhave tassa
translated: would I be a fast man, endowed with the highest speed?”

original: purisassa javo, yathā ca candimasūriyānaṃ javo, tato sīghataro. Yathā ca, bhikkhave,🔽tassa purisassa javo, yathā ca candimasūriyānaṃ javo, yathā ca yā devatā candimasūriyānaṃ
analyzed: purisassa javaḥ yathā ca candima sūriyānam javaḥ tatas sīghataraḥ yathā ca bhikkhave  tassa purisassa javaḥ yathā ca candima sūriyānam javaḥ yathā ca yā devatā candima sūriyānam
translated: “As fast as that man is, monks, and as fast as the sun and moon are, they are not as fast as the life-force.

original: purato dhāvanti, tāsaṃ devatānaṃ javo, tato sīghataraṃ āyusaṅkhārā khīyanti, tasmātiha,
analyzed: puratas dhāvanti tāsam devatānam sīghataram āyu saṅkhārā tasmāt ati ha
translated: As fast as that man is, and as fast as the sun and moon are, and as fast as the gods who run in front of the sun and moon are, the life-force is even faster.🔽Therefore, monks, you should train the mind to be heedful.

original: bhikkhave, evaṃ sikkhitabbaṃ ‘appamattā viharissāmā’ti. Evañhi vo, bhikkhave, sikkhitabba”nti –
analyzed: bhikkhave evam sikkhitabbam appamattāḥ viharissāma ati evam hi vaḥ bhikkhave sikkhitabbanti
translated: You should train like this.”

original: Imassa suttassa kathitadivasato dutiyadivase bhikkhū dhammasabhāyaṃ kathaṃ samuṭṭhāpesuṃ
analyzed: imassa suttassa kathita divasataḥ dutiya divase bhikkhū dhammasabhāyam katham samuṭṭhāpesuṃ
translated: On the day following the recital of this discourse, the monks began a discussion in the Hall of Truth.

original: “āvuso, satthā attano buddhavisaye ṭhatvā imesaṃ sattānaṃ āyusaṅkhāre ittare dubbale
analyzed: āvuso satthā attanaḥ buddha visaye ṭhatvā imesam sattānam āyu saṅkhāre ittare dubbale
translated: “Brethren, the Teacher, standing in his own domain of knowledge, has made manifest the fact that the life-span of these beings is short, and that the life-span of those beings is long, and that the life-span of still others is short.

original: katvā paridīpento puthujjanabhikkhū ativiya santāsaṃ pāpesi, aho buddhabalaṃ nāmā”ti.
analyzed: katvā paridīpento puthujjana bhikkhū ativiya santāsam pāpesi aho buddha balam nāma ati
translated: In so doing, he has caused the worldlings among the monks to tremble exceedingly. Wonderful is the power of the Buddha!”

original: Satthā āgantvā “kāya nuttha, bhikkhave, etarahi kathāya sannisinnā”ti pucchitvā “imāya🔽nāmā”ti vutte “anacchariyaṃ, bhikkhave, svāhaṃ idāni sabbaññutaṃ patto āyusaṅkhārānaṃ
analyzed: satthā āgantvā kāya nuttha bhikkhave etarahi kathāya sannisinnā ati pucchitvā imāya  nāma ati vutte anacchariyam bhikkhave svāham idāni sabbaññutam pattaḥ āyu saṅkhārānam
translated: The Teacher drew near and asked, “Monks, what are you sitting here now talking about? ” When they told him,

original: ittarabhāvaṃ dassetvā bhikkhū saṃvejetvā dhammaṃ desemi, mayā hi pubbe ahetukahaṃsayoniyaṃ
analyzed: ittara bhāvam dassetvā bhikkhū saṃvejetvā dhammaṃ desemi mayā hi pubbe ahetuka haṃsa yoniyam
translated: he said, “Monks, it is not now only that I have caused the worldlings among the monks to tremble exceedingly by making manifest the fact that the life-span of these beings is short, and that the life-span of those beings is long, and that the life-span of still others is short.

original: nibbattenapi āyusaṅkhārānaṃ ittarabhāvaṃ dassetvā bārāṇasirājānaṃ ādiṃ katvā sakalarājaparisaṃ
analyzed: nibbattena api āyu saṅkhārānam ittara bhāvam dassetvā bārāṇasi rājānam ādim katvā sakala rāja parisam
translated: Even in a previous state of existence, when I was reborn in the womb of a she-duck, which was without cause, I made manifest the fact that the life-span of these beings was short, and that the life-span of those beings was long, and that the life-span of still others was short, and caused the king of Benares and all his court to tremble exceedingly.🔽And in so doing, I preached the Law.” So saying, he related the following

original: saṃvejetvā dhammo desito”ti vatvā atītaṃ āhari.
analyzed: saṃvejetvā dhammaḥ desito ti vatvā atītam āhari
translated: Story of the Past:

original: Atīte bārāṇasiyaṃ brahmadatte rajjaṃ kārente bodhisatto javanahaṃsayoniyaṃ nibbattitvā
analyzed: atīte bārāṇasiyam brahmadatte rajjam kārente bodhisattaḥ javanahaṃsa yoniyam nibbattitvā
translated: Once upon a time, when Brahmadatta was reigning in Benares, the Bodhisatta was born in the race of the swift geese.

original: navutihaṃsasahassaparivuto cittakūṭe paṭivasati. So ekadivasaṃ jambudīpatale ekasmiṃ🔽sare saparivāro sayaṃjātasāliṃ khāditvā ākāse suvaṇṇakilañjaṃ pattharanto viya mahantena
analyzed: navuti haṃsa sahassa parivutaḥ cittakūṭe paṭivasati saḥ eka divasam jambudīpa tale ekasmin  sare sa parivāraḥ sayaṃjāta sālim khāditvā ākāse suvaṇṇa kilañjam pattharantaḥ viya mahantena
translated: He lived on the Citta mountain, surrounded by ninety thousand geese. One day he went with his retinue to a lake on the earth of India,

original: parivārena bārāṇasinagarassa matthakena mandamandāya vilāsagatiyā cittakūṭaṃ gacchati.
