original: hohi, devā”ti ovadi. Atha rājā “sāmi, mayaṃ tumhādisena ñāṇabalasampannena ācariyena
analyzed: atha rājā sāmi mayam tumhādisena ñāṇa bala sampannena ācariyena
translated: Then the king said, “Sir, we cannot live without a teacher as wise and powerful as you.

original: vinā vasituṃ na sakkhissāma, cittakūṭaṃ agantvā mayhaṃ dhammaṃ desento mayhaṃ ovādācariyo
analyzed: vinā vasitum na sakkhissāma cittakūṭam a gantvā mayham dhammaṃ desento mayham ovāda ācariyo
translated: Without going to Cittakūṭa, teaching me the Dhamma and being my advisor,🔽please stay here.”

original: hutvā idheva vasāhī”ti yācanto dve gāthā abhāsi –
analyzed: hutvā idhā iva vasāhi iti yācantaḥ dve gāthāḥ abhāsi
translated: He spoke two verses, asking him to stay:

original: “Savanena ekassa piyā bhavanti, disvā panekassa viyeti chando;
analyzed: savanena ekassa piyāḥ bhavanti disvā panekassa viyā iti chandaḥ
translated: “By hearing one becomes dear to some, but by seeing one loses interest in others.

original: Disvā ca sutvā ca piyā bhavanti, kaccinnu me pīyasi dassanena.
analyzed: disvā ca sutvā ca piyāḥ bhavanti kaccit nu me pīyasi dassanena
translated: By seeing and hearing one becomes dear to some. Are you dear to me by seeing?”🔽“

original: “Savanena piyo mesi, bhiyyo cāgamma dassanaṃ;
analyzed: savanena piyaḥ mā isi bhiyyaḥ ca āgamma dassanam
translated: “By hearing thee I love thee well, And more than ever since I saw;

original: Evaṃ piyadassano me, vasa haṃsa mamantike”ti.
analyzed: evam piya dassanaḥ me vasa haṃsa mama antikā iti
translated: So, being dear to me to see, Stay here, O swan, beside me.”

original: Tāsaṃ attho – samma haṃsarāja savanena ekassa ekacce piyā honti, “evaṃ guṇo nāmā”ti
analyzed: tāsam atthaḥ samma haṃsa rāja savanena ekassa ekacce piyāḥ honti evam guṇaḥ nāma ati
translated: The meaning of this is as follows: “Some, O king of swans, are dear by hearing, that is to say, by hearing of their virtues.

original: sutvā savanena piyāyati, ekassa pana ekacce disvāva chando vigacchati, pemaṃ antaradhāyati,
analyzed: sutvā savanena piyāyati ekassa pana ekacce disvā ava chandaḥ vigacchati pemam antaradhāyati
translated: But some, when seen, arouse desire in one, and love is born;

original: khādituṃ āgatā yakkhā viya upaṭṭhahanti, ekassa ekacce disvā ca sutvā cāti ubhayathāpi
analyzed: khāditum āgatāḥ yakkhāḥ viya upaṭṭhahanti ekassa ekacce disvā ca sutvā ca ati ubhayathā api
translated: but some, when seen and heard, are dear in both ways, like the Yakkhas who came to devour the man.

original: piyā honti, tena taṃ pucchāmi. Kaccinnu me pīyasi dassanenāti kacci nu tvaṃ maṃ piyāyasi,
analyzed: piyāḥ honti tena tam pucchāmi kaccid nu me pīyasi dassanena ati kacci nu tvam mama piyāyasi
translated: Therefore I ask thee: art thou dear to me to see?

original: mayhaṃ pana tvaṃ savanena piyova, dassanaṃ panāgamma atipiyova. Evaṃ mama piyadassano
analyzed: mayham pana tvam savanena piyaḥ uva dassanam pana agamma ati piyaḥ uva evam mama piya dassano
translated: But thou art dear to me by hearing, and more than ever since I saw thee. So being dear to me to see,

original: samāno cittakūṭaṃ agantvā idha mama santike vasāti.
analyzed: samānaḥ cittakūṭam a gantvā idha mama santike vasāti
translated: thou shouldst stay here beside me, without going to Citta’s peak.”

original: Bodhisatto āha –
analyzed: bodhisattaḥ āha
translated: The Bodhisatta replied:

original: “Vaseyyāma tavāgāre, niccaṃ sakkatapūjitā;
analyzed: vaseyyāma tava āgāre niccam sakkata pūjitā
translated: “We would stay in thy house, ever honoured and revered;

original: Matto ca ekadā vajje, haṃsarājaṃ pacantu me”ti.
analyzed: mattaḥ ca ekadā vajje haṃsa rājam pacantu mā iti
translated: But if thou shouldst once commit a fault, let them cook thee, O king of swans.”

original: Tattha matto ca ekadāti mahārāja, mayaṃ tava ghare niccaṃ pūjitā vaseyyāma, tvaṃ
analyzed: tattha matto ca ekadā ati mahā rāja mayam tava ghare niccam pūjitāḥ vaseyyāma tvam
translated: “And I, O King, would live in your house, always honoured, if you would only promise me that you would never drink strong drink.

original: pana kadāci surāmadamatto maṃsakhādanatthaṃ “haṃsarājaṃ pacantu me”ti vadeyyāsi,
analyzed: pana kadāci surā mada mattaḥ maṃsa khādana attham haṃsa rājam pacantu mā iti vadeyyāsi
translated: But if you should ever get drunk and order me to be cooked for your supper, saying, ‘Cook the King of the Geese for me,’

original: atha evaṃ tava anujīvino maṃ māretvā paceyyuṃ, tadāhaṃ kiṃ karissāmīti.
analyzed: atha evam tava anujīvinaḥ mam māretvā paceyyum tadā aham kim karissāmi iti
translated: then what would become of me?”

original: Athassa rājā “tena hi majjameva na pivissāmī”ti paṭiññaṃ dātuṃ imaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: athassa rājā tena hi majjam eva na pivissāmi iti paṭiññam dātum imam gātham āha
translated: Then the King promised that he would never drink strong drink again, and he said this verse:

original: “Dhiratthu taṃ majjapānaṃ, yaṃ me piyataraṃ tayā;
analyzed: tam majja pānam yam me piyataram tayā
translated: “Accursed be that drinking of strong drink, which I preferred to you!

original: Na cāpi majjaṃ pissāmi, yāva me vacchasī ghare”ti.
analyzed: na ca api majjam pissāmi yāva me vacchasī ghara iti
translated: But I will never drink strong drink again, as long as you live in my house.”

original: Tato paraṃ bodhisatto cha gāthā āha –
analyzed: tatas param bodhisatto cha gāthāḥ āha
translated: Then the Bodhisatta said six verses:

original: “Suvijānaṃ siṅgālānaṃ, sakuṇānañca vassitaṃ;
analyzed: suvijānam siṅgālānam sakuṇānam ca
translated: “The cries of jackals and of birds, are easy to understand;

original: Manussavassitaṃ rāja, dubbijānataraṃ tato.
analyzed: manussavassitam rāja dubbijānataram tatas
translated: But the cries of men, O King, are harder to understand than these.

original: “Api ce maññatī poso, ñāti mitto sakhāti vā;
analyzed: api ce maññatī posaḥ ñāti mitto sakhāti vā
translated: “A man may think another dear, and call him friend or kinsman;

original: Yo pubbe sumano hutvā, pacchā sampajjate diso.
analyzed: yaḥ pubbe sumanaḥ hutvā pacchā sampajjate disaḥ
translated: But if the other man is angry, he will turn against his friend.

original: “Yasmiṃ mano nivisati, avidūre sahāpi so;
analyzed: yasmin manaḥ nivisati avidūre saha api saḥ
translated: “Where the mind finds its pleasure, though far away, it is near at hand;

original: Santikepi hi so dūre, yasmiṃ nāvisate mano.
analyzed: santike pi hi saḥ dūre yasmin na āvisate mano
translated: For even if near, he is far away, In whom the mind finds no delight.

original: “Antopi so hoti pasannacitto, pāraṃ samuddassa pasannacitto;
analyzed: antar api saḥ hoti pasanna citto pāram samuddassa pasanna citto
translated: “Within, he is of serene mind, Of serene mind beyond the sea;

original: Antopi so hoti paduṭṭhacitto, pāraṃ samuddassa paduṭṭhacitto.
analyzed: antar api so hoti paduṭṭha citto pāram samuddassa paduṭṭha citto
translated: Within, he is of wicked mind, Of wicked mind beyond the sea.

original: “Saṃvasantā vivasanti, ye disā te rathesabha;
analyzed: saṃvasantā vivasanti ye disā te rathesabha
translated: “Those who live in the directions, O King of Chariots, are happy;

original: Ārā santo saṃvasanti, manasā raṭṭhavaḍḍhana.
analyzed: ārā santaḥ saṃvasanti manasā raṭṭhavaḍḍhana
translated: Those who are secluded live happily, O Enhancer of the Kingdom.

original: “Aticiraṃ nivāsena, piyo bhavati appiyo;
analyzed: aticiram nivāsena piyaḥ bhavati appiyaḥ
translated: “By living too long together, One who is dear becomes not dear;

original: Āmanta kho taṃ gacchāma, purā te homa appiyā”ti.
analyzed: āmanta kho tam gacchāma purā te homa appiya ati
translated: I will call you and we will go, Lest you become not dear to me.”

original: Tattha vassitanti mahārāja, tiracchānagatā ujuhadayā, tena tesaṃ vassitaṃ suvijānaṃ,
analyzed: tattha vassitam ti mahā rāja tiracchāna gatāḥ uju hadayā tena tesam vassitam su vijānam
translated: Herein, “rain” is the straight-forwardness of animals. That is why their rain is easy to understand.

original: manussā pana kakkhaḷā, tasmā tesaṃ vacanaṃ dubbijānataranti attho. Yo pubbeti yo
analyzed: manussā pana kakkhaḷā tasmā tesam vacanam attho yaḥ pubbā iti yaḥ
translated: But people are hard-hearted, and that is why their words are more difficult to understand.

original: puggalo paṭhamameva attamano hutvā “tvaṃ mayhaṃ ñātako mitto pāṇasamo sakhā”ti api
analyzed: puggalaḥ paṭhamam eva atta manaḥ hutvā tvam mayham ñātakaḥ mittaḥ pāṇa samaḥ sakhā api
translated: The person who first thinks “You are my relative, friend, life-companion, and intimate”

original: evaṃ maññati, sveva pacchā diso verī sampajjati, evaṃ dubbijānaṃ nāma manussahadayanti.
analyzed: evam maññati su eva pacchā disaḥ verī sampajjati evam dubbijānam nāma manussa hadayanti
translated: and then later becomes an enemy in a different direction is more difficult to understand, it seems, than the heart of a human being.

original: Nivisatīti mahārāja, yasmiṃ puggale pemavasena mano nivisati, so dūre vasantopi avidūre
analyzed: nivisati iti mahā rāja yasmin puggale pema vasena manaḥ nivisati saḥ dūre vasantaḥ api avidūre
translated: “He dwells with him,” Your Majesty, means that in the person in whom the mind settles down through affection, even though he may live far away, he is not far away.

original: sahāpi vasatiyeva nāma. Yasmiṃ pana puggale mano na nivisati apeti, so santike vasantopi dūreyeva.
analyzed: saha api vasatiyā iva nāma yasmin pana puggale manaḥ na nivisati apeti saḥ santike vasantaḥ api
translated: But in the person in whom the mind does not settle down, even though he may live nearby, he is far away.

original: Antopi so hotīti mahārāja, yo sahāyo pasannacitto, so cittena allīnattā pāraṃ samuddassa
analyzed: antar api saḥ hoti iti mahā rāja yaḥ sahāyo pasanna citto saḥ cittena pāram samuddassa
translated: “Even though he be within,” Your Majesty, means that the friend who is pleased in mind, because his mind is attached, even though he may live beyond the ocean, he is within.

original: vasantopi antoyeva hoti. Yo pana paduṭṭhacitto, so cittena anallīnattā anto vasantopi
analyzed: vasantaḥ api hoti yaḥ pana paduṭṭha citto so cittena antar vasantaḥ api
translated: But the one who is displeased in mind, because his mind is not attached, even though he may live within, he is beyond the ocean.

original: pāraṃ samuddassa nāma. Ye disā teti ye verino paccatthikā, te ekato vasantāpi dūre
analyzed: pāram samuddassa nāma ye disā te iti ye verino paccatthikā te ekatas vasantā api dūre
translated: “Those who are in the quarters,” Your Majesty, means that the enemies, the adversaries, even though they may live together, they live far away.

original: vasantiyeva nāma. Santo pana paṇḍitā ārā ṭhitāpi mettābhāvitena manasā āvajjentā
analyzed: vasantiyā iva nāma santaḥ pana paṇḍitāḥ ārā ṭhitā api mettā bhāvitena manasā āvajjentā
translated: But the peaceful, the wise, even though they may live far away, recollecting with a mind developed with loving-kindness,🔽they live together.

original: saṃvasantiyeva. Purā te homāti yāva tava appiyā na homa, tāvadeva taṃ āmantetvā gacchāmāti vadati.
analyzed: purā te homa ati yāva tava appiyā na tāvat eva tam āmantetvā gacchāma iti vadati
translated: “Before they become your enemies,” means as long as they are not displeasing, just so long do we invite you to go.

original: Atha naṃ rājā āha –
analyzed: atha nam rājā āha
translated: Then the King said:

original: “Evaṃ ce yācamānānaṃ, añjaliṃ nāvabujjhasi;
analyzed: evam ce yācamānānam añjalim na avabujjhasi
translated: “If you do not understand the folded hands of those who are supplicating,

original: Paricārakānaṃ sataṃ, vacanaṃ na karosi no;
analyzed: paricārakānam satam vacanam na karosi no
translated: Thou hearest not the words of those who wait upon thee,

original: Evaṃ taṃ abhiyācāma, puna kayirāsi pariyāya”nti.🔽Tattha evaṃ ceti sace haṃsarāja, evaṃ añjaliṃ paggayha yācamānānaṃ amhākaṃ imaṃ añjaliṃ
analyzed: evam tam abhiyācāma punar kayirāsi pariyāyanti  tattha evam ca iti sace haṃsa rājaḥ evam añjalim paggayha yācamānānam amhākam imam añjalim
translated: Thus do we pray to thee, O King of Swans, that thou wouldst come again.”

original: nāvabujjhasi, tava paricārakānaṃ samānānaṃ vacanaṃ na karosi, atha naṃ evaṃ yācāma.
analyzed: na avabujjhasi tava paricārakānam samānānam vacanam na karosi atha nam evam yācāma
translated: Herein, if, King of Swans, thou dost not understand the meaning of our reverent salutation, thou hearest not the words of those who wait upon thee, then we pray thee thus.

original: Puna kayirāsi pariyāyanti kālena kālaṃ idha āgamanāya vāraṃ kareyyāsīti attho.
analyzed: puna kayirāsi pariyāyanti kālena kālam idha āgamanāya vāram kareyyāsi iti
translated: Puna kayirāsi pariyāya: from time to time make a visit.

original: Tato bodhisatto āha –
analyzed: tatas bodhisattaḥ āha
translated: Then the Bodhisatta said:

original: “Evaṃ ce no viharataṃ, antarāyo na hessati;
analyzed: evam ce naḥ viharatam antarāyaḥ na hessati
translated: “If, while we thus live, no obstacle arise,

original: Tuyhaṃ cāpi mahārāja, mayhañca raṭṭhavaḍḍhana;
analyzed: tuyham ca api mahā rāja mayham ca raṭṭhavaḍḍhana
translated: And if, O King, and I, our kingdom prosper,

original: Appeva nāma passemu, ahorattānamaccaye”ti.🔽Tattha evaṃ ce noti mahārāja, mā cintayittha, sace amhākampi evaṃ viharantānaṃ jīvitantarāyo
analyzed: appā iva nāma passemu  tattha evam ce mahā rāja mā cintayittha sace amhākam pi evam viharantānam jīvita antarāyaḥ
translated: Then, perhaps, we may behold each other, as the days and nights go by.”

original: na bhavissati, appeva nāma ubho aññamaññaṃ passissāma, apica tvaṃ mayā dinnaṃ ovādameva
analyzed: na bhavissati appā iva nāma ubho aññam aññam passissāma apica tvam mayā dinnam ovādam eva
translated: Herein, if, O King, we thus live, no obstacle will arise to our life, then, perhaps, we may behold each other. Moreover, thou must follow the advice which I give thee.

original: mama ṭhāne ṭhapetvā evaṃ ittarajīvite lokasannivāse appamatto hutvā dānādīni puññāni
analyzed: mama ṭhāne ṭhapetvā evam ittara jīvite loka sannivāse appamattaḥ hutvā dāna ādīni puññāni
translated: “Place me in your place, and, in this short life, in this world of men, be not heedless, but do good works,

original: karonto dasa rājadhamme akopetvā dhammena rajjaṃ kārehi, evañhi me ovādaṃ karonto
analyzed: karontaḥ dasa rāja dhamme a kopetvā dhammena rajjam kārehi evam hi me ovādam karontaḥ
translated: and rule your realm righteously, not violating the ten royal virtues. If you do this, you will see me.”

original: maṃ passissatiyevāti. Evaṃ mahāsatto rājānaṃ ovaditvā cittakūṭapabbatameva gato.
analyzed: mam passissatiyā iva ati evam mahāsattaḥ rājānam ovaditvā cittakūṭa pabbatam eva gataḥ
translated: Thus did the Great Being instruct the king, and then he went back to the Citta Mountain.

original: Satthā imaṃ dhammadesanaṃ āharitvā “evaṃ, bhikkhave, pubbe tiracchānayoniyaṃ nibbattenapi
analyzed: satthā imam dhamma desanam āharitvā evam bhikkhave pubbe tiracchānayoniyam nibbattena api
translated: When the Teacher had related this story, he said, “Thus, monks, even when I was reborn in the world of brutes,

original: mayā āyusaṅkhārānaṃ dubbalabhāvaṃ dassetvā dhammo desito”ti vatvā jātakaṃ samodhānesi🔽– “tadā rājā ānando ahosi, kaniṭṭho moggallāno, majjhimo sāriputto, sesahaṃsagaṇā
analyzed: mayā āyu saṅkhārānam dubbala bhāvam dassetvā dhammaḥ desitaḥ ti vatvā jātakam samodhānesi  tadā rājā ānandaḥ ahosi kaniṭṭhaḥ moggallānaḥ majjhimaḥ sāriputto sesa haṃsa gaṇā
translated: I preached the Law, showing the weakness of the conditions of life.” So saying, he joined the connection, and preaching the Law, pronounced the following Stanza,

original: buddhaparisā, javanahaṃso pana ahameva ahosi”nti.🔽Javanahaṃsajātakavaṇṇanā tatiyā.
analyzed: buddha parisā javanahaṃsaḥ pana aham eva  javanahaṃsa jātaka vaṇṇanā tatiyā
translated: “Thus, monks, did I preach the Law, showing the weakness of the conditions of life.”

original: [477] 4. Cūḷanāradajātakavaṇṇanā🔽Na te kaṭṭhāni bhinnānīti idaṃ satthā jetavane viharanto thullakumārikāpalobhanaṃ
analyzed: 🔽na te kaṭṭhāni bhinnāni iti idam satthā jetavane viharantaḥ thulla kumārikā apalobhanam
translated: At the conclusion of the lesson many obtained the Fruit of Conversion and the Fruits of the Second and Third Paths.

original: ārabbha kathesi. Sāvatthivāsino kirekassa kulassa pannarasasoḷasavassuddesikā dhītā
analyzed: ārabbha kathesi sāvatthi vāsinaḥ kira ekassa kulassa pannarasa soḷasa vassuddesikā dhītā
translated: It seems that a certain family living at Sāvatthi had a daughter who was fifteen or sixteen years old.

original: ahosi sobhaggappattā, na ca naṃ koci vāresi. Athassā mātā cintesi “mama dhītā vayappattā,
analyzed: ahosi sobhagga ppattā na ca nam koci vāresi athassā mātā cintesi mama dhītā vaya ppattā
translated: She was very beautiful, but no one asked for her hand. Her mother thought to herself, “My daughter has reached marriageable age,

original: na ca naṃ koci vāreti, āmisena macchaṃ viya etāya ekaṃ sākiyabhikkhuṃ palobhetvā
analyzed: na ca nam koci vāreti āmisena maccham viya etāya ekam sākiya bhikkhum palobhetvā
translated: but no one asks for her hand. I will entice a certain monk of the Sākiya clan with the bait of material gain,🔽and then I will have her go forth under him. In this way she will be able to live in comfort.”

original: uppabbājetvā taṃ nissāya jīvissāmī”ti. Tadā ca sāvatthivāsī eko kulaputto sāsane
analyzed: uppabbājetvā tam nissāya jīvissāmi iti tadā ca sāvatthi vāsī ekaḥ kula putto sāsane
translated: Now at that time a certain young man of Sāvatthi had gone forth in the Dispensation,

original: uraṃ datvā pabbajitvā upasampannakālato paṭṭhāya sikkhākāmataṃ pahāya ālasiyo sarīramaṇḍanamanuyutto
analyzed: uram da tvā pabbajitvā upasampanna kālataḥ paṭṭhāya sikkhā kāma tam pahāya ālasiyaḥ sarīra maṇḍanam anuyuttaḥ
translated: but from the time he received the full admission he had no desire to study the rules of conduct. He was lazy and devoted himself to the adornment of his body.

original: vihāsi. Mahāupāsikā gehe yāgukhādanīyabhojanīyāni sampādetvā dvāre ṭhatvā antaravīthiyā
analyzed: vihāsi mahā upāsikā gehe yāgu khādanīya bhojanīyāni sampādetvā dvāre ṭhatvā antara vīthiyā
translated: The lay devotee prepared rice-gruel, cakes, and other food in her house and stood at the door.

original: gacchantesu bhikkhūsu ekaṃ bhikkhuṃ rasataṇhāya bandhitvā gahetuṃ sakkuṇeyyarūpaṃ
analyzed: gacchantesu bhikkhūsu ekam bhikkhum rasa taṇhāya bandhitvā gahetum sakkuṇeyya rūpam
translated: As the monks passed along the street, she watched for a monk who was so bound by craving for tastes that she could entice him to take food with her.

original: upadhārentī tepiṭakaābhidhammikavinayadharānaṃ mahantena parivārena gacchantānaṃ
analyzed: upadhārentī mahantena parivārena gacchantānam
translated: She saw a certain monk who was a master of the three Piṭakas and of Abhidhamma and Vinaya, surrounded by a large retinue,

original: antare kañci gayhupagaṃ adisvā tesaṃ pacchato gacchantānaṃ madhuradhammakathikānaṃ
analyzed: antare kañci gayhupagam a disvā tesam pacchatas gacchantānam madhura dhamma kathikānam
translated: Not seeing anyone else, he went behind them. He saw some bhikkhus who were preachers of the Dhamma,🔽but they were like a string of pearls. He saw some bhikkhus who were alms gatherers,

original: acchinnavalāhakasadisānaṃ piṇḍapātikānampi antare kañci adisvāva ekaṃ yāva bahi apaṅgā
analyzed: acchinna valāhaka sadisānam antare kañci ekam bahi
translated: but they were like a string of mangoes. Not seeing anyone else, he saw a certain bhikkhu coming from outside.🔽He had anointed his eyes, had combed his hair, had put on an inner and outer garment,

original: akkhīni añjetvā kese osaṇhetvā dukūlantaravāsakaṃ nivāsetvā ghaṭitamaṭṭhaṃ cīvaraṃ
analyzed: akkhīni añjetvā kese osaṇhetvā dukūla antara vāsakam nivāsetvā ghaṭita maṭṭham cīvaram
translated: had put on a patched cloak,

original: pārupitvā maṇivaṇṇapattaṃ ādāya manoramaṃ chattaṃ dhārayamānaṃ vissaṭṭhindriyaṃ kāyadaḷhibahulaṃ

translated: from now on come here only.” From then on the bhikkhu went there only. Later he became a trusted friend.

original: Sā dhītaraṃ āha “imaṃ palobhetvā tava vase vattāpehī”ti. Sā tato paṭṭhāya maṇḍitapasādhitā
analyzed: sā dhītaram āha imam palobhetvā tava vase vattā apehi iti sā tatas paṭṭhāya maṇḍita pasādhitā

analyzed: nibbattitvā uggahita sippaḥ kuṭumbam saṇṭhapesi athassa bhariyā ekam puttam vijāyitvā

analyzed: saḥ yathā iva me piya bhariyāya evam mayi pi maraṇam āgamissati kim me

analyzed: assame ṭhapetvā phala a phala tthāya gata kāle pubbaṇha samaye tam assamam pāpuṇitvā tam  tāpasa kumāram kāma ratiyā palobhetvā sīlam assa bhinditvā attanaḥ vase vattetvā kim

analyzed: pacchā āgaccheyyāsi iti vatvā magga saññam ācikkhitvā pakkāmi so tassāḥ gata kālataḥ

translated: “As I go from here, in whatever country I may live,

translated: Herein, I beg you, Kassapa, to let me go means I beg you, Kassapa, to let me go. To go means to go. Conduct means

analyzed: sace araññam hitvāna vana mūla phalāni ca
translated: “If, leaving the forest, the roots and fruits of the forest,

translated: “Avoid the poison, avoid the pit,🔽Avoid the mire, and with care

translated: ” The ascetic youth, not understanding the meaning of the brief statement, asked, “What is the poison, what the pit,🔽What the mire, and what the serpent?

original: “Sasatthā tāta rājāno, āvasanti mahiṃ imaṃ;
analyzed: sasatthāḥ tāta rājānaḥ āvasanti mahim imam
translated: “The kings, dear sir, with their retinue, live on this earth.

original: Te tādise manussinde, mahante tāta nārada.
analyzed: te tādise manussinde mahante tāta nārada
translated: They are great, dear sir, in the eyes of the people.

original: “Issarānaṃ adhipatīnaṃ, na tesaṃ pādato care;
analyzed: issarānam adhipatīnam na tesam pādataḥ care
translated: “The lords and masters, one should not walk under their feet.

original: Āsīvisoti akkhāto, brahmacariyassa nārada.
analyzed: āsīviso ti akkhātaḥ brahmacariyassa nārada
translated: This is declared to be a snake for the spiritual life, Nārada.

original: “Bhattattho bhattakāle ca, yaṃ gehamupasaṅkame;
analyzed: bhattatthaḥ bhatta kāle ca yam geham upasaṅkame
translated: “When one goes to a house for the sake of alms, at the time of eating,

original: Yadettha kusalaṃ jaññā, tattha ghāsesanaṃ care.
analyzed: yat ittha kusalam tattha ghāsesanam care
translated: one should seek food there, knowing what is wholesome.

original: “Pavisitvā parakulaṃ, pānatthaṃ bhojanāya vā;
analyzed: pavisitvā para kulam pāna attham bhojanāya vā
translated: “Having entered another’s house, for the sake of drink or food,

original: Mitaṃ khāde mitaṃ bhuñje, na ca rūpe manaṃ kare.
analyzed: mitam khāde mitam bhuñje na ca rūpe manam kare
translated: one should eat and drink in moderation, and not pay attention to beauty.

original: “Goṭṭhaṃ majjaṃ kirāṭañca, sabhā nikiraṇāni ca;
analyzed: goṭṭham majjam kirāṭam ca sabhāḥ nikiraṇāni ca
translated: “The tavern, the gambling house, the street corner, the park,

original: Ārakā parivajjehi, yānīva visamaṃ patha”nti.
analyzed: ārakā parivajjehi yāni iva visamam pathanti
translated: one should avoid these from afar, as one does a path with thorns.”

original: Tattha āsavoti pupphāsavādi. Visaṃ tadāhūti taṃ āsavasaṅkhātaṃ suraṃ ariyā “brahmacariyassa🔽visa”nti vadanti. Pamattanti muṭṭhassatiṃ. Tūlaṃ bhaṭṭhaṃvāti rukkhā bhassitvā patitatūlaṃ🔽viya. Akkhātoti buddhādīhi kathito. Silokoti kittivaṇṇo. Sakkāroti añjalikammādi.🔽Pūjāti gandhamālādīhi pūjā. Paṅkoti esa osīdāpanaṭṭhena “paṅko”ti akkhāto. Mahanteti
analyzed: tattha āsavaḥ ti puppha āsava ādi visam tad āhu iti tam āsava saṅkhātam suram ariyāḥ brahmacariyassa  visanti vadanti pamattanti muṭṭhassatim tūlam rukkhāḥ bhassitvā patita tūlam  viya akkhātoti buddha ādīhi kathitaḥ siloko ti kitti vaṇṇo sakkāro ti añjali kamma ādi  pūjā āti gandha mālā ādīhi pūjā paṅko ti esaḥ osīdāpana ṭṭhena paṅko ti akkhātaḥ mahantā iti
translated: Herein, defilement is the defilement of flowers, etc. That poison they call: that liquor called defilement the Noble Ones call “poison to🔽the life of purity.” Careless: forgetful. Like a bird whose wing is clipped: like a bird whose wing is clipped by falling from a tree.🔽Is called: is spoken of by the Enlightened One, etc. Fame: praise. Honour: the act of raising the folded hands, etc.🔽Worship: worship with scents, garlands, etc. Mud: this is called “mud” in the sense of dragging down. Great:🔽

original: mahantabhāvappatte. Na tesaṃ pādato careti tesaṃ santike na care, rājakulūpako na🔽bhaveyyāsīti attho. Rājāno hi āsīvisā viya muhutteneva kujjhitvā anayabyasanaṃ pāpenti.
analyzed: mahanta bhāva patte na tesam pādato careti tesam santike na care rāja kulūpakaḥ na  bhaveyyāsi iti atthaḥ rājānaḥ hi āsīvisāḥ viya muhuttena iva kujjhitvā anaya byasanam pāpenti
translated: Herein, defilement is the defilement of flowers, etc. That is called poison: that liquor called defilement is called by Noble Ones “poison for the holy life” . The heedless: the forgetful. Like a bird’s down: like down from a tree shaken down by the wind . Is called: is spoken of. Fame: praise. Service: the performance of duties such as saluting. Worship: worship with scents, garlands, etc. Mud: this is called “mud” in the sense of dragging down . Great: who have attained greatness. Do not go near their feet: do not go near them; the meaning is, do not become a royal hanger-on. For kings, like snakes, can suddenly get angry and cause misfortune and ruin.

original: Apica antepurappavesane vuttādīnavavasenapettha attho veditabbo.
analyzed: apica antepura ppavesane vutta ādīnava vasena pā ittha atthaḥ veditabbo
translated: Besides, the meaning here can be understood as the danger stated in the passage about entering the royal compound .

original: Bhattatthoti bhattena atthiko hutvā. Yadettha kusalanti yaṃ tesu upasaṅkamitabbesu
analyzed: bhatta atthā ti bhattena atthikaḥ hutvā yat ettha kusalan ti yam tesu upasaṅkamitabbesu
translated: For the sake of food: being in need of food. What is good here: what is good among those who should be approached

original: gehesu kusalaṃ anavajjaṃ pañcaagocararahitaṃ jāneyyāsi, tattha ghāsesanaṃ careyyāsīti
analyzed: gehesu kusalam anavajjam pañca agocara rahitam jāneyyāsi tattha ghāsesanam careyyāsi iti
translated: You should know what is wholesome and blameless in the houses, free from the five kinds of wrong livelihood, and you should go there for alms.

original: attho. Na ca rūpe manaṃ kareti parakule mattaññū hutvā bhojanaṃ bhuñjantopi tattha
analyzed: na ca rūpe manam kareti para kule mattaññū hutvā bhojanam bhuñjantaḥ api tattha
translated: The meaning is: you should go there for alms. And he should not set his mind on form: even when he is eating almsfood after having controlled himself,

original: itthirūpe manaṃ mā kareyyāsi, mā cakkhuṃ ummīletvā itthirūpe nimittaṃ gaṇheyyāsīti🔽vadati. Goṭṭhaṃ majjaṃ kirāṭanti ayaṃ potthakesu pāṭho, aṭṭhakathāyaṃ pana “goṭṭhaṃ
analyzed: itthi rūpe manam mā kareyyāsi mā cakkhum ummīletvā itthi rūpe nimittam gaṇheyyāsi iti  vadati goṭṭham majjam kirāṭanti ayam potthakesu pāṭhaḥ aṭṭhakathā ayam pana goṭṭham
translated: he should not set his mind on the form of women; he should not open his eyes and look at the form of women with lust.

original: majjaṃ kirāsañcā”ti vatvā “goṭṭhanti gunnaṃ ṭhitaṭṭhānaṃ. Majjanti pānāgāraṃ. Kirāsanti🔽dhuttakerāṭikajana”nti vuttaṃ. Sabhā nikiraṇāni cāti sabhāyo ca hiraññasuvaṇṇānaṃ
analyzed: majjam kirāsam ca ati vatvā goṭṭhanti gunnam ṭhita ṭṭhānam majjanti pānāgāram kirāsanti  dhutta kerāṭika jananti vuttam sabhā nikiraṇāni ca ati sabhāyaḥ ca hirañña suvaṇṇānam
translated: The reading in the books is “goṭṭha, majja, kirāṭa,” but in the commentary it is given as “goṭṭha, majja, kirāsañcā.” The meaning is: “Goṭṭha is the place where cattle stand. Majja is a drinking house. Kirāsañcā is a house of thieves and swindlers.”

original: nikiraṇaṭṭhānāni ca. Ārakāti etāni sabbāni dūrato parivajjeyyāsi. Yānīvāti sappitelayānena🔽gacchanto visamaṃ maggaṃ viya.
analyzed: nikiraṇa ṭṭhānāni ca ārakā ati etāni sabbāni dūratas parivajjeyyāsi yāni iva ati sappi tela yānena 🔽gacchantaḥ visamam maggam viya
translated: Sabhā nikiraṇāni ca: sabhā means assemblies, and nikiraṇāni means places for the display of gold and silver. Ārakā: you should avoid all these from afar. Yānīva: as if going on an uneven road with a cart drawn by oxen.

original: Māṇavo pitu kathentasseva satiṃ paṭilabhitvā “tāta, alaṃ me manussapathenā”ti āha.
analyzed: māṇavaḥ pitu kathentassa iva satim paṭilabhitvā tāta alam me manussa pathena ati āha
translated: The young man, while his father was speaking, recovered his memory, and said, “Father, I have no more desire for the path of men.”

original: Athassa pitā mettādibhāvanaṃ ācikkhi. So tassovāde ṭhatvā na cirasseva jhānābhiññā
analyzed: athassa pitā mettā ādi bhāvanaṃ ācikkhi saḥ tassa uvāde ṭhatvā na cirassa iva jhāna abhiññā
translated: Then his father taught him the meditation on loving-kindness. He remained firm in the teaching of his father, and in no long time attained the meditations and the Supernatural Faculties.

original: nibbattesi. Ubhopi pitāputtā aparihīnajjhānā kālaṃ katvā brahmaloke nibbattiṃsu.
analyzed: nibbattesi ubho api pitāputtāḥ a parihīna jjhānā kālam katvā brahmaloke nibbattiṃsu
translated: Both father and son, without losing the meditations, passed from that state of existence and were reborn in the World of Brahmā.

original: Satthā imaṃ dhammadesanaṃ āharitvā jātakaṃ samodhānesi – “tadā sā kumārikā ayaṃ kumārikā ahosi, tāpasakumāro ukkaṇṭhitabhikkhu, pitā pana ahameva ahosi”nti.
analyzed: satthā imam dhamma desanam āharitvā jātakam samodhānesi tadā sā kumārikā ayam kumārikā ahosi tāpasa kumāraḥ ukkaṇṭhita bhikkhu pitā pana aham eva ahosinti
translated: When the Teacher had related this parable, he identified the Birth by saying, “At that time the young woman was the present young woman, the young man was the discontented monk, and I myself was the father.”

original: Cūḷanāradajātakavaṇṇanā catutthā.
analyzed: cūḷa nārada jātaka vaṇṇanā catutthā
translated: This is the story of the Birth of Cūlanārada.

original: [478] 5. Dūtajātakavaṇṇanā
analyzed: dūta jātaka vaṇṇanā
translated: The Story of the Birth of the Messenger

original: Dūte te brahme pāhesinti idaṃ satthā jetavane viharanto attano paññāpasaṃsanaṃ ārabbha
analyzed: dūte te brahme pāhesin ti idam satthā jetavane viharantaḥ attano paññā apasaṃsanam ārabbha
translated: When the Teacher was in residence at Jetavana, he told this story of the past in order to illustrate his own praise of wisdom.

original: kathesi. Dhammasabhāyaṃ bhikkhū kathaṃ samuṭṭhāpesuṃ “passatha, āvuso, dasabalassa
analyzed: kathesi dhammasabhāyam bhikkhū katham samuṭṭhāpesuṃ passatha āvuso dasabalassa
translated: The monks began the discussion in the Hall of Truth, saying, “Brethren, consider the wisdom of the Tathāgata.

original: upāyakosallaṃ, nandassa sakyaputtassa accharāgaṇaṃ dassetvā arahattaṃ adāsi, cūḷapanthakassa
analyzed: upāyakosallam nandassa sakya puttassa accharā gaṇam dassetvā arahattam adāsi cūḷapanthakassa
translated: He gave the fruit of Arahatship to Nanda, the son of the Sakyans, by showing him a company of celestial nymphs.🔽He gave the fruit of Arahatship to Cullapanthaka, together with the Supernatural Faculties, by giving him a cloak.

original: pilotikaṃ datvā saha paṭisambhidāhi arahattaṃ adāsi, kammāraputtassa padumaṃ dassetvā
analyzed: pilotikam da tvā saha paṭisambhidāhi arahattam adāsi kammāra puttassa padumam dassetvā
translated: He gave the fruit of Arahatship to the son of the smith by showing him a lotus-flower.

original: arahattaṃ adāsi, evaṃ nānāupāyehi satte vinetī”ti. Satthā āgantvā “kāya nuttha, bhikkhave,🔽etarahi kathāya sannisinnā”ti pucchitvā “imāya nāmā”ti vutte “na, bhikkhave, tathāgato
analyzed: arahattam adāsi evam nānā upāyehi satte vineti iti satthā āgantvā kāya nuttha bhikkhave  etarahi kathāya sannisinnā ati pucchitvā imāya nāma ati vutte na bhikkhave tathāgataḥ
translated: Thus he trains beings by various means.” The Teacher came in and asked, “Monks, what are you sitting here now talking about? ” When they told him,

original: idāneva ‘iminā idaṃ hotī’ti upāyakusalo, pubbepi upāyakusaloyevā”ti vatvā atītaṃ āhari.🔽Atīte bārāṇasiyaṃ brahmadatte rajjaṃ kārente janapado ahirañño ahosi. So hi janapadaṃ
analyzed: idānā iva iminā idam hoti iti upāya kusalaḥ pubbe pi upāya kusalaḥ yeva ati vatvā atītam āhari  atīte bārāṇasiyam brahmadatte rajjam kārente janapadaḥ ahiraññaḥ ahosi saḥ hi janapadam
translated: he said, “Monks, the Tathāgata is not only now skilled in means, knowing that this or that is the proper means to employ; in the past also he was skilled in means.” So saying, he told a story of the past.🔽Once upon a time, when Brahmadatta was reigning in Benares, there was a certain district called Ahira.

original: pīḷetvā dhanameva saṃkaḍḍhi. Tadā bodhisatto kāsigāme brāhmaṇakule nibbattitvā vayappatto
analyzed: pīḍetvā dhanam eva tadā bodhisatto kāsigāme brāhmaṇa kule nibbattitvā vaya patto
translated: He oppressed the people of that district and gathered up all their wealth. Now the Bodhisatta was reborn in a certain Brāhman family in the country of Kāsi. When he grew up,🔽he learned all the arts and sciences.

original: takkasilaṃ gantvā “pacchā dhammena bhikkhaṃ caritvā ācariyadhanaṃ āharissāmī”ti vatvā
analyzed: takkasilam gantvā pacchā dhammena bhikkham caritvā ācariya dhanam āharissāmi iti vatvā
translated: He went to Takkasilā and said, “After I have gone forth and have done my duties as a monk, I will bring back the teacher’s fee.”

original: sippaṃ paṭṭhapetvā niṭṭhitasippo anuyogaṃ datvā “ācariya, tumhākaṃ dhanaṃ āharissāmī”ti
analyzed: sippam paṭṭhapetvā niṭṭhita sippaḥ anuyogam datvā ācariya tumhākam dhanam āharissāmi iti
translated: He then learned the craft. When he had finished, he gave the teacher his fee and said, “Teacher, I will bring back your fee.”

original: āpucchitvā nikkhamma janapade caranto dhammena samena pariyesitvā satta nikkhe labhitvā
analyzed: āpucchitvā nikkhamma janapade carantaḥ dhammena samena pariyesitvā satta nikkhe labhitvā
translated: He then left. While wandering in the country, he searched for his fee in a proper way and obtained seven nuggets of gold.

original: “ācariyassa dassāmī”ti gacchanto antarāmagge gaṅgaṃ otarituṃ nāvaṃ abhiruhi. Tassa
analyzed: ācariyassa dassāmi iti gacchantaḥ antarāmagge gaṅgam otaritum nāvam tassa
translated: He then thought, “I will give this to my teacher.” While on his way, he boarded a boat to cross the Ganges.

original: tattha nāvāya viparivattamānāya taṃ suvaṇṇaṃ udake pati. So cintesi “dullabhaṃ hiraññaṃ,
analyzed: tattha nāvāya viparivattamānāya tam suvaṇṇam udake pati so cintesi dullabham hiraññaṃ
translated: While the boat was in midstream, the gold fell into the water. He thought, “Gold is hard to obtain.

original: janapade puna ācariyadhane pariyesiyamāne papañco bhavissati, yaṃnūnāhaṃ gaṅgātīreyeva🔽nirāhāro nisīdeyyaṃ, tassa me nisinnabhāvaṃ anupubbena rājā jānissati, tato amacce
analyzed: janapade puna ācariya dhane pariyesiyamāne papañcaḥ bhavissati yat nūna aham gaṅgā tīreya iva  nirāhāraḥ nisīdeyyam tassa me nisinna bhāvam anupubbena rājā jānissati tatas amacce
translated: If I search for my teacher’s fee in the country, it will be troublesome. Why don’t I sit down right here on the bank of the Ganges🔽and fast? The king will gradually learn of my sitting there, and he will send his ministers. I will not consult with them. Then the king will come himself.

original: pesessati, ahaṃ tehi saddhiṃ na mantessāmi, tato rājā sayaṃ āgamissati, iminā upāyena
analyzed: pesessati aham tehi saddhim na mantessāmi tatas rājā sayam āgamissati iminā upāyena
translated: In this way,

original: tassa santike ācariyadhanaṃ labhissāmī”ti. So gaṅgātīre uttarisāṭakaṃ pārupitvā yaññasuttaṃ
analyzed: tassa santike ācariya dhanam labhissāmi iti saḥ gaṅgā tīre uttari sāṭakam pārupitvā yaññasuttam
translated: “I will get my teacher’s fee from him.” He put on his upper robe on the bank of the Ganges,

original: bahi ṭhapetvā rajatapaṭṭavaṇṇe vālukatale suvaṇṇapaṭimā viya nisīdi. Taṃ nirāhāraṃ
analyzed: bahi ṭhapetvā rajata paṭṭa vaṇṇe vāluka tale suvaṇṇa paṭimā viya tam nirāhāram
translated: put his belt in his bag, and sat down on the sand, which was the color of silver, like a golden image. When people saw him sitting there without eating,

original: nisinnaṃ disvā mahājano “kasmā nisinnosī”ti pucchi, kassaci na kathesi. Punadivase
analyzed: nisinnam disvā mahā janaḥ kasmā nisinnaḥ asi iti pucchi kassaci na kathesi puna divase
translated: they asked him, “Why are you sitting here?” But he did not reply to anyone. The next day,

original: dvāragāmavāsino tassa tattha nisinnabhāvaṃ sutvā āgantvā pucchiṃsu, tesampi na kathesi.
analyzed: dvāragāma vāsino tassa tattha nisinna bhāvam sutvā āgantvā pucchiṃsu tesam pi na kathesi
translated: the residents of the village at the gateway heard that he was sitting there, and they came and asked him. He did not reply to them either.

original: Te tassa kilamathaṃ disvā paridevantā pakkamiṃsu. Tatiyadivase nagaravāsino āgamiṃsu,
analyzed: te tassa kilamatham disvā paridevantā pakkamiṃsu tatiya divase nagara vāsinaḥ āgamiṃsu
translated: Seeing that he was exhausted, they left, lamenting. On the third day, the residents of the city came.

original: catutthadivase nagarato issarajanā, pañcamadivase rājapurisā. Chaṭṭhadivase rājā
analyzed: catuttha divase nagarataḥ issara janā pañcama divase rāja purisā chaṭṭha divase rājā
translated: On the fourth day, the most important people from the city came. On the fifth day, the king’s men came. On the sixth day,

original: amacce pesesi, tehipi saddhiṃ na kathesi. Sattamadivase rājā bhayaṭṭito hutvā tassa
analyzed: amacce pesesi tehi pi saddhim na kathesi sattama divase rājā bhayaṭṭitaḥ hutvā tassa
translated: the king sent his ministers. He did not reply to them either. On the seventh day, the king,

original: santikaṃ gantvā pucchanto paṭhamaṃ gāthamāha –🔽“Dūte te brahme pāhesiṃ, gaṅgātīrasmi jhāyato;
analyzed: santikam gantvā pucchantaḥ paṭhamam gātham āha 🔽dūte te brahme gaṅgā tīra asmi jhāyato
translated: terrified, went to him and asked him this question in the first stanza:

original: Tesaṃ puṭṭho na byākāsi, dukkhaṃ guyhamataṃ nu te”ti.
analyzed: tesam puṭṭhaḥ na byākāsi dukkham nu te iti
translated: He did not answer when asked, and his grief was hidden from you.”

original: Tattha dukkhaṃ guyhamataṃ nu teti kiṃ nu kho, brāhmaṇa, yaṃ tava dukkhaṃ uppannaṃ, taṃ te guyhameva mataṃ, na aññassa ācikkhitabbanti.
analyzed: tattha dukkham guyham atam nu te iti kim nu kho brāhmaṇa yat tava dukkham uppannam tam te guyham eva matam na aññassa ācikkhitabbanti
translated: Herein, his grief was hidden from you means: “Brahmin, is it that the grief which has arisen in you is hidden from you alone, and that you should not tell it to anyone else?”

original: Taṃ sutvā mahāsatto “mahārāja, dukkhaṃ nāma harituṃ samatthasseva ācikkhitabbaṃ, na aññassā”ti vatvā satta gāthā abhāsi –
analyzed: tam sutvā mahāsattaḥ mahā rāja dukkham nāma haritum samatthassa iva ācikkhitabbam na aññassa ati vatvā satta gāthāḥ abhāsi
translated: Hearing this, the Great Being said: “Great king, grief should be told to one who is able to remove it, and not to anyone else.” So saying, he spoke seven stanzas:

original: “Sace te dukkhamuppajje, kāsīnaṃ raṭṭhavaḍḍhana;
analyzed: sace te dukkham uppajje kāsīnam raṭṭhavaḍḍhana
translated: “If grief should arise in you, O Enlarger of the Kingdom of Kasi,

original: Mā kho naṃ tassa akkhāhi, yo taṃ dukkhā na mocaye.
analyzed: mā kho nam tassa akkhāhi yaḥ tam dukkhā na mocaye
translated: Do not tell it to him who cannot remove your grief.

original: “Yo tassa dukkhajātassa, ekaṅgamapi bhāgaso;
analyzed: yaḥ tassa dukkha jātassa ekaṅgam api bhāgasaḥ
translated: “If there be one who, in accordance with the Dhamma,

original: Vippamoceyya dhammena, kāmaṃ tassa pavedaya.
analyzed: vippamoceyya dhammena kāmam tassa pavedaya
translated: Can remove even a part of your grief, then tell it to him.

original: “Suvijānaṃ siṅgālānaṃ, sakuṇānañca vassitaṃ;
analyzed: suvijānam siṅgālānam sakuṇānam ca
translated: “The cries of jackals and of birds are easy to understand,

original: Manussavassitaṃ rāja, dubbijānataraṃ tato.
analyzed: manussavassitam rāja dubbijānataram tatas
translated: But, O king, the cry of a man is more difficult to understand.

original: “Api ce maññatī poso, ñāti mitto sakhāti vā;
analyzed: api ce maññatī posaḥ ñāti mitto sakhāti vā
translated: “Even though a man may think, ‘This one is my kinsman, friend, or intimate,’

original: Yo pubbe sumano hutvā, pacchā sampajjate diso.
analyzed: yaḥ pubbe sumanaḥ hutvā pacchā sampajjate disaḥ
translated: He who was formerly well-disposed may later become hostile.

original: “Yo attano dukkhamanānupuṭṭho, pavedaye jantu akālarūpe;
analyzed: yaḥ attanaḥ pavedaye jantu akāla rūpe
translated: Announces it at the wrong time,

original: Ānandino tassa bhavanti mittā, hitesino tassa dukhī bhavanti.
analyzed: ānandinaḥ tassa bhavanti mittāḥ hitesinaḥ tassa dukhī bhavanti
translated: His friends are delighted, and they are concerned for his suffering.

translated: “Wandering in the kingdom, in the towns and the capital,

analyzed: āgama balasāḥ hi mayam buddhāḥ sabbam pajānanti iti  tattha veyyañjanikā ati mahā rāja mayam byañjanam disvā byākaraṇa samatthā suta buddhā  nāma buddhāḥ pana sabbaññū sabba vidū buddhāḥ hi atīta ādi bhedam sabbam jānanti ca iva
translated: We, the Buddhas, know all by the power of the Scriptures.”

original: passanti ca, sabbaññutaññāṇena te sabbaṃ jānanti, na lakkhaṇena. Mayaṃ pana āgamabalasā
analyzed: passanti ca sabbaññu ta ññāṇena te sabbam jānanti na lakkhaṇena mayam pana āgama balasā

original: attano sippabaleneva jānāma, tañca ekadesameva, buddhā pana sabbaṃ pajānantīti.
analyzed: attano sippa balena iva jānāma tat ca eka desam eva buddhāḥ pana sabbam pajānanti iti
translated: by the power of our own craft, and that only in part. But the Buddhas know all.”

original: Rājā buddhaguṇe sutvā somanassappatto hutvā sakalacakkavāḷavāsikehi bahugandhamālaṃ

analyzed: satthā imam gāthā dvayam āha 🔽mahayitvā sambodhim nānā turiyehi vajjamānehi

analyzed: saṭṭhi vāha sahassāni pupphānam sannipātayi

analyzed: tattha manupāyāsi iti mātā pitūnam santikam agamāsi saḥ mahā bodhimaṇḍe aṭṭhārasa hattham

analyzed: suvaṇṇa tthambham ussāpesi tassa satta ratana mayā vedikā kāresi ratana missakam vālukam

translated: only this much is given: “sixty thousand loads of flowers.”

original: Evaṃ mahābodhipūjaṃ katvā mātāpitaro ayyakāyyike ca ādāya dantapurameva ānetvā dānādīni puññāni katvā tāvatiṃsabhavane nibbatti.
analyzed: evam mahā bodhi pūjam katvā mātā pitaraḥ ayya kāyyike ca ādāya dantapuram eva ānetvā dāna ādīni puññāni katvā tāvatiṃsa bhavane nibbatti
translated: After he had thus worshipped the Great Bodhi-tree, he took his parents and his maternal uncle’s wife, brought them to Dantapura, had gifts and other meritorious deeds performed, and was reborn in the Tāvatiṃsa heaven.

original: Satthā imaṃ dhammadesanaṃ āharitvā “na, bhikkhave, idāneva, pubbepi ānando bodhipūjaṃ🔽kāresiyevā”ti vatvā jātakaṃ samodhānesi – “tadā māṇavakakāliṅgo ānando ahosi, kāliṅgabhāradvājo

original: pana ahameva ahosi”nti.
analyzed: pana aham eva
translated: In that Jātaka the student Kāliṅga was Ānanda, and I myself was Kāliṅga Bhāradvāja.

original: Kāliṅgabodhijātakavaṇṇanā chaṭṭhā.🔽[480] 7. Akittijātakavaṇṇanā🔽Akittiṃ disvā sammantanti idaṃ satthā jetavane viharanto ekaṃ sāvatthivāsiṃ dānapatiṃ
analyzed: kāliṅgabodhijātakavaṇṇanā chaṭṭhā         akittim disvā sammantanti idam satthā jetavane viharantaḥ ekam sāvatthi vāsim dānapatim
translated: This is the story of the Bodhi Tree of Kāliṅga.🔽The story of Akitti🔽When the Teacher was in residence at Jetavana, he told this story about a certain layman of Sāvatthi.

original: upāsakaṃ ārabbha kathesi. So kira satthāraṃ nimantetvā sattāhaṃ buddhappamukhassa
analyzed: upāsakam ārabbha kathesi saḥ kira satthāram nimantetvā sattāham buddha ppamukhassa

analyzed: adāsi athassa satthā anumodanam karontaḥ upāsaka mahā te pariccāgaḥ

analyzed: aho dukkaram tayā katam ayam hi dāna vaṃsaḥ nāma porāṇaka paṇḍitānam vaṃsaḥ dānam nāma
translated: What you have done is indeed difficult to do. This tradition of giving alms is a tradition of the wise of old. Giving alms is a tradition of the wise.

analyzed: gihinā api pabbajitena api dātabbam eva porāṇaka paṇḍitā pana pabbajitvā araññe vasantā api

analyzed: a loṇakam vidhūpanam udaka matta sittam kārapaṇṇam khādamānā api sampatta yācakānam yāvadattham  da tvā sayam pīti sukhena vatvā bhante idam tāva sabba parikkhāra dānam
translated: even though they were eating only water-purifying leaves, without salt or condiments, gave to suppliants as much as they wanted,🔽and then themselves lived on the joy and happiness .

original: mahājanassa pākaṭaṃ, tumhehi vuttaṃ apākaṭaṃ, taṃ no kathethā”ti tena yācito atītaṃ āhari.
analyzed: mahājanassa pākaṭam tumhehi vuttam apākaṭam tam no kathetha ati tena yācitaḥ atītam āhari
translated: “Revered sir, this gift of all requisites is well known to the general public, but what you have said is not well known; please tell us that.” When he asked for this story, the Master related the following:

analyzed: kule nibbatti akittītissa nāmam kariṃsu tassa gamana kāle

analyzed: yasavatī itissāḥ nāmam kariṃsu mahāsatto soḷasa vassa kāle takkasilam gantvā sabba sippāni

analyzed: uggaṇhitvā paccāgami athassa mātā pitaro kālam akaṃsu saḥ tesam peta kiccāni kāretvā

analyzed: vacanam sutvā saṃvigga mānasaḥ hutvā idam dhanam eva paññāyati na dhanassa saṃhārakā

analyzed: sabbe imam dhanam pahāya iva gatāḥ aham pana tam ādāya gamissāmi iti bhaginim pakkosāpetvā

analyzed: bhātika aham tumhehi chaḍḍitam kheḷam na sirasā sampaṭicchāmi na me iminā attho

analyzed: kim me dhanakīḷāya atthikā tam gaṇhissanti iti nivesana dvāram vivaritvā dinnaññā iva  harantu uti sa hirañña suvaṇṇam geham pahāya ñāti maṇḍalassa paridevantassa bhaginim
translated: “What have I to do with gambling? analyzed: mahantaḥ mayā ekakena iva viharitum vaṭṭati iti cintetvā avelāya antamasaḥ
translated: So he thought, “I will go away and leave my sister.”

analyzed: a jānāpetvā ekakaḥ iva nikkhamitvā anupubbena damiḷa raṭṭham patvā kāvīra paṭṭana samīpe  uyyāne viharantaḥ jhāna abhiññāyaḥ nibbattesi tatra api ssa mahā lābha sakkāro uppajji so
translated: Without informing anyone, he left alone, and after a time he reached the country of the Damilas. He stayed in a garden near the port of Kāverī,

analyzed: tam jigucchitvā chaḍḍetvā ākāsena gantvā nāgadīpa samīpe kāradīpe otari tadā kāradīpaḥ

original: ahidīpo nāma ahosi. So tattha mahantaṃ kārarukkhaṃ upanissāya paṇṇasālaṃ māpetvā

analyzed: vāsam kappesi tattha tassa vasana bhāvam na koci jānāti athassa bhaginī bhātaram

analyzed: brāhmaṇa vaṇṇena tassa santikam agamāsi bodhisatto kārapaṇṇāni sedetvā otāretvā sītala bhūtāni
translated: and in the guise of a brāhmaṇa he went into his presence. The Bodhisatta, having dried and threshed the leaves, thought, “Now that they are cool,

original: khādissāmī”ti paṇṇasāladvāre nisīdi. Athassa purato sakko bhikkhāya aṭṭhāsi. Mahāsatto
analyzed: khādissāmi iti paṇṇasāla dvāre nisīdi athassa puratas sakkaḥ bhikkhāya aṭṭhāsi mahāsatto

original: taṃ disvā somanassappatto hutvā “lābhā vata me, yohaṃ yācakaṃ passāmi, ajja me manorathaṃ

original: matthakaṃ pāpetvā dānaṃ dassāmī”ti pakkabhājaneneva ādāya gantvā “idaṃ me dānaṃ sabbaññutaññāṇassa🔽paccayo hotū”ti attano asesetvāva tassa bhājane pakkhipi. Brāhmaṇo taṃ gahetvā thokaṃ
analyzed: matthakam pāpetvā dānam dassāmi iti pakka bhājanena iva ādāya gantvā idam me dānam sabbaññuta ññāṇassa  paccayaḥ hotu iti attanaḥ a sesetvā ava tassa bhājane pakkhipi brāhmaṇaḥ tam gahetvā thokam
translated: “I will give it to him after I have made it into a head.” So he took it in a cooking vessel, and saying, “Let this gift of mine be a condition for the knowledge of omniscience,” he poured it into the Brahman’s vessel, not reserving any for himself. The Brahman took it and went a little way.

original: gantvā antaradhāyi. Mahāsattopi tassa datvā puna apacitvā pītisukheneva vītināmetvā
analyzed: gantvā antaradhāyi mahāsattaḥ pi tassa da tvā puna apacitvā pīti sukhena iva
translated: and I will give it to him.” So he took it in a broken dish, and as he went along he said to himself, “May this gift of mine be a condition for the knowledge of omniscience.” And he poured it into the Brahman’s dish, not reserving any for himself. The Brahman took it and went a little way, and then disappeared. The Great Being, having given it to him, again made his offering, and then spent the day in joy and happiness.

original: punadivase pacitvā tattheva paṇṇasāladvāre nisīdi.
analyzed: puna divase pacitvā tattha iva paṇṇasāla dvāre nisīdi
translated: On the following day he cooked again, and sat down in the same place, at the door of the leaf-hut.

analyzed: sakko puna brāhmaṇa vesena agamāsi puna pissa da tvā mahāsatto tathā iva vītināmesi
translated: Sakka again came in the guise of a Brahman. Again the Great Being gave it to him, and again he spent the day in joy and happiness.

original: Tatiyadivasepi tatheva datvā “aho me lābhā vata, kārapaṇṇāni nissāya mahantaṃ puññaṃ🔽pasuta”nti somanassappatto tayo divase anāhāratāya dubbalopi samāno majjhanhikasamaye
analyzed: tatiya divase pi tathā iva da tvā aho me lābhāḥ vata kārapaṇṇāni nissāya mahantam puññam  pasutanti somanassa patto tayaḥ divase anāhāra tāya dubbalaḥ api samānaḥ majjhanhika samaye
translated: On the third day also he gave it in the same way, and was filled with joy, thinking, “Oh, what great merit I have acquired by means of these leaves!”

original: paṇṇasālato nikkhamitvā dānaṃ āvajjento paṇṇasāladvāre nisīdi. Sakkopi cintesi “ayaṃ
analyzed: paṇṇasālataḥ nikkhamitvā dānam āvajjento paṇṇasāla dvāre nisīdi sakkaḥ api cintesi ayam
translated: And although he was weak from fasting for three days, he went out from the leaf-hut at noon and sat down at the door of the leaf-hut, reflecting on his gift. Sakka thought to himself, “This Great Being, although he is weak from fasting for three days, is still filled with joy.

original: brāhmaṇo tayo divase nirāhāro hutvā evaṃ dubbalopi dānaṃ dento tuṭṭhacittova deti,
analyzed: brāhmaṇaḥ tayaḥ divase nirāhāraḥ hutvā evam dubbalaḥ api dānam dentaḥ tuṭṭha cittaḥ uva deti
translated: The Brahman, though he had been fasting for three days and was therefore weak, gave the gift with a glad heart.

original: cittassa aññathattampi natthi, ahaṃ imaṃ ‘idaṃ nāma patthetvā detī’ti na jānāmi,
analyzed: cittassa aññathattam pi natthi aham imam idam nāma patthetvā deti iti na jānāmi
translated: There was not the slightest change in his mind. I do not know whether he gave the gift in the hope of obtaining some reward.

original: pucchitvā ajjhāsayamassa sutvā dānakāraṇaṃ jānissāmī”ti. So majjhanhike vītivatte

analyzed: mahantena siri sobhaggena gagana tale taruṇa sūriyaḥ viya jalamānaḥ āgantvā mahāsattassa  puratas va tāpasaḥ evam uṇha vāte paharante evarūpe loṇa jala parikkhitte
translated: Sakka, King of the Devas, accompanied by a great train of honor, radiant as the newly risen sun, came floating through the air, alighted in the presence of the Great Being,

original: araññe kimatthaṃ tapokammaṃ karosī”ti pucchi. Tamatthaṃ pakāsento satthā paṭhamaṃ gāthamāha –🔽“Akittiṃ disvā sammantaṃ, sakko bhūtapatī bravi;
analyzed: araññe kimattham tapo kammam karosi iti pucchi tam attham pakāsentaḥ satthā paṭhamam gātham āha  akittim disvā sammantam sakkaḥ bhūtapatī bravi
translated: and said to him, “Monk, in the midst of this desert place surrounded by salt water, where the wind blows hot and sultry, what is the purpose of your austerities?” Expounding this matter, the Teacher pronounced the following Stanza,

original: Mahāsatto taṃ sutvā sakkabhāvañcassa ñatvā “nāhaṃ etā sampattiyo patthemi, sabbaññutaṃ pana patthento tapokammaṃ karomī”ti pakāsetuṃ dutiyaṃ gāthamāha –

analyzed: evam ca pana vatvā attanaḥ vacanam rakkhitvā mita bhāṇinaḥ nāma maraṇa dukkhāḥ muccanti iti dassetvā kinnara vatthum āhari
translated: And after saying this, he told the Kinnara story in order to show that those who are moderate in speech and keep their word are free from the sorrow of death.

original: Bārāṇasivāsī kireko luddako himavantaṃ gantvā ekenupāyena jayampatike dve kinnare🔽gahetvā ānetvā rañño adāsi. Rājā adiṭṭhapubbe kinnare disvā tussitvā “ludda, imesaṃ🔽ko guṇo”ti pucchi. “Deva, ete madhurena saddena gāyanti, manuññaṃ naccanti, manussā
analyzed: bārāṇasi vāsī kirekaḥ luddakaḥ himavantam gantvā ekena upāyena jayampatike dve kinnare  gahetvā ānetvā raññaḥ adāsi rājā a diṭṭha pubbe kinnare disvā tussitvā luddaḥ imesam  kaḥ guṇaḥ iti pucchi devaḥ ete madhurena saddena gāyanti manuññam naccanti manussā
translated: It seems that a certain hunter living at Benares went to the Himalayas and by some means or other caught two Kinnaras, a male and a female.🔽He brought them to the king and gave them to him. The king, who had never seen such creatures before, was delighted. “Hunter,” he said, “what are their qualities?”

original: evaṃ gāyituñca naccituñca na jānantī”ti. Rājā luddassa bahuṃ dhanaṃ datvā kinnare
analyzed: evam gāyitum ca naccitum ca na jānanti iti rājā luddassa bahum dhanam da tvā kinnare
translated: “Sire, they sing in sweet voices and dance gracefully. Men do not know how to sing and dance like this.” The king gave the hunter much wealth and said to the Kinnaras,

original: “gāyatha naccathā”ti āha. Kinnarā “sace mayaṃ gāyantā byañjanaṃ paripuṇṇaṃ kātuṃ
analyzed: gāyatha na catha ati āha kinnarā sace mayam gāyantā byañjanam paripuṇṇam kātum
translated: “Sing and dance.” The Kinnaras thought, “If we sing and cannot finish the song,

original: na sakkhissāma, duggītaṃ hoti, amhe garahissanti vadhissanti, bahuṃ kathentānañca
analyzed: na sakkhissāma duggītam hoti amhe garahissanti vadhissanti bahum kathentānam ca
translated: we shall be badly sung and people will blame and kill us. If we speak much,

original: pana musāvādopi hotī”ti musāvādabhayena raññā punappunaṃ vuttāpi na gāyiṃsu na nacciṃsu.
analyzed: pana musāvādaḥ api hoti iti musāvāda bhayena raññā punappunam vuttā api na gāyiṃsu na nacciṃsu
translated: but they are liars.” And because of the fear of lying, they did not sing or dance, even though the king asked them again and again.

original: Rājā kujjhitvā “ime māretvā maṃsaṃ pacitvā āharathā”ti āṇāpento sattamaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: rājā kujjhitvā ime māretvā maṃsam pacitvā āharatha iti āṇāpentaḥ sattamam gātham āha
translated: The king became angry and ordered, “Kill them and cook their flesh for me to eat.” As he gave this order, he spoke the seventh verse:

original: “Ime na devā na gandhabbaputtā, migā ime atthavasaṃ gatā me;
analyzed: ime na devāḥ na gandhabba puttāḥ migāḥ ime attha vasam gatāḥ me
translated: These are not gods, nor are they sons of Gandhabbas; they are deer, and they have come into my power.

original: Ekañca naṃ sāyamāse pacantu, ekaṃ punappātarāse pacantū”ti.
analyzed: ekam ca nam sāyamāse pacantu ekam punappātarāse pacantu uti
translated: Cook one of them at evening time, and cook the other at dawn.

original: Tattha migā imeti ime sace devā gandhabbā vā bhaveyyuṃ, nacceyyuñceva gāyeyyuñca,🔽ime pana migā tiracchānagatā. Atthavasaṃ gatā meti atthaṃ paccāsīsantena luddena
analyzed: tattha migāḥ ime iti ime sace devāḥ gandhabbāḥ vā bhaveyyum nacceyyuṃ ca iva gāyeyyuṃ ca  ime pana migā tiracchāna gatāḥ attha vasam gatāḥ mā iti attham luddena
translated: Herein, they are deer means these, if they were gods or Gandhabbas, would sing and dance,🔽but they are deer, animals. They have come into my power means they have come into my power because of the purpose of my desire for meat.

original: ānītattā atthavasena mama hatthaṃ gatā. Etesu ekaṃ sāyamāse, ekaṃ pātarāse pacantūti.
analyzed: ānīta ttāḥ attha vasena mama hattham gatāḥ etesu ekam sāyamāse ekam pātarāse pacantu uti
translated: Cook one of them at evening time, and cook the other at dawn.

original: Kinnarī cintesi “rājā kuddho nissaṃsayaṃ māressati, idāni kathetuṃ kālo”ti aṭṭhamaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: kinnarī cintesi rājā kuddhaḥ nissaṃsayam māressati idāni kathetum kālaḥ iti aṭṭhamam gātham āha
translated: The Kinnari thought, “The king is angry. He will certainly kill us. Now is the time to speak.” So she spoke the eighth verse:

original: “Sataṃ sahassāni dubhāsitāni, kalampi nāgghanti subhāsitassa;
analyzed: satam sahassāni dubhāsitāni kalampi na agghanti subhāsitassa
translated: are not worth a fraction of a single good word.🔽Evil words are a defilement, a stain;

original: Dubbhāsitaṃ saṅkamāno kileso, tasmā tuṇhī kimpurisā na bālyā”ti.
analyzed: dubbhāsitam kileso tasmā tuṇhī kimpurisāḥ na
translated: therefore, Kinnaras, you are silent, not out of folly.”

original: Tattha saṅkamāno kilesoti kadāci ahaṃ bhāsamāno dubbhāsitaṃ bhāseyyaṃ, evaṃ dubbhāsitaṃ saṅkamāno kilissati kilamati. Tasmāti tena kāraṇena tumhākaṃ na gāyiṃ, na bālabhāvenāti.
analyzed: tattha saṅkamānaḥ kileso ti kadāci aham bhāsamānaḥ dubbhāsitam bhāseyyam evam dubbhāsitam saṅkamānaḥ kilissati kilamati tasmā ati tena kāraṇena tumhākam na na bāla bhāvena ati
translated: Herein, a defilement, a stain means: if I were to speak, I might speak evil words, and so I would be defiled, stained by evil words. Therefore, for that reason, I do not sing, not out of folly.

original: Rājā kinnariyā tussitvā anantaraṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: rājā kinnariyā anantaram gātham āha
translated: The king, pleased with the Kinnarī’s words, spoke the next verse:🔽“Let her be released; let her go;

original: “Yā mesā byāhāsi pamuñcathetaṃ, giriñca naṃ himavantaṃ nayantu;
analyzed: yā mā isā byāhāsi pamuñcatha itam girin ca nam himavantam nayantu
translated: and let them lead her to the Himalayas.🔽And let them give her to the great kitchen;

original: Imañca kho dentu mahānasāya, pātova naṃ pātarāse pacantū”ti.
analyzed: imam ca khalu dentu mahānasāya pāta uva nam pātarāse pacantu iti
translated: let them cook her in the morning for the morning meal.”

original: Tattha yā mesāti yā me esā. Dentūti mahānasatthāya dentu.
analyzed: tattha yā mā isā ati yā me esā dentu uti mahānasa tthāya dentu
translated: Herein, let her be released means: let her be released by me. Let them give her to the great kitchen means: let them give her to the great kitchen for the great kitchen.

original: Kinnaro rañño vacanaṃ sutvā “ayaṃ maṃ akathentaṃ avassaṃ māressati, idāni kathetuṃ vaṭṭatī”ti itaraṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: kinnaraḥ raññaḥ vacanam sutvā ayam mama a kathentam a vassam māressati idāni kathetum vaṭṭati iti itaram gātham āha
translated: The Kinnara, having heard the king’s words, thought: “If I do not speak, he will certainly kill me. Now it is proper for me to speak.” He spoke the next verse:🔽“The cattle are protected by Pajjunna;

original: “Pajjunnanāthā pasavo, pasunāthā ayaṃ pajā;
analyzed: pajjunna nāthā pasavaḥ pasu nāthāḥ ayam pajā
translated: this people are protected by the cattle;

original: Tvaṃ nāthosi mahārāja, nāthohaṃ bhariyāya me;
analyzed: tvam mahā rāja me
translated: You are the protector, great king, I am the protector of my wife;

original: Dvinnamaññataraṃ ñatvā, mutto gaccheyya pabbata”nti.🔽Tattha pajjunnanāthā pasavoti tiṇabhakkhā pasavo meghanāthā nāma. Pasunāthā ayaṃ🔽pajāti ayaṃ pana manussapajā pañcagorasena upajīvantī pasunāthā pasupatiṭṭhā. Tvaṃ🔽nāthosīti tvaṃ mama patiṭṭhā asi. Nāthohanti mama bhariyāya ahaṃ nātho, ahamassā
analyzed: dvinnam aññataram ñatvā muttaḥ gaccheyya pabbatan ti  tattha pajjunnanāthāḥ pasavaḥ ti tiṇabhakkhāḥ pasavaḥ meghanāthāḥ nāma pasu nāthāḥ ayam  pajāti ayam pana manussa pajā pañca gorasena upajīvantī pasu nāthā pasu patiṭṭhā tvam  nātho asi iti tvam mama patiṭṭhā asi mama bhariyāya aham nātho aham assā
translated: Knowing that one of the two is dead, the other may go free and go to the mountains.”

original: patiṭṭhā. Dvinnamaññataraṃ ñatvā, mutto gaccheyya pabbatanti amhākaṃ dvinnaṃ antare🔽eko ekaṃ mataṃ ñatvā sayaṃ maraṇato mutto himavantaṃ gaccheyya, jīvamānā pana mayaṃ
analyzed: patiṭṭhā dvinnam aññataram ñatvā muttaḥ gaccheyya pabbatan ti amhākam dvinnam antare  ekaḥ ekam matam ñatvā sayam maraṇataḥ muttaḥ himavantam gaccheyya jīvamānā pana mayam
translated: Herein, the cattle that have Pajjunna for their protector are the cattle that eat grass; the cattle that have the clouds for their protector are the cattle that eat rain; this human race that has the cattle for its protector is the human race that subsists on the five kinds of food derived from the four-footed animals. You are my support. I am the protector of my wife. I am her support. Knowing that one of the two is dead, the other may go free and go to the mountains.

original: aññamaññaṃ na jahāma, tasmā sacepi imaṃ himavantaṃ pesetukāmo, maṃ paṭhamaṃ māretvā pacchā pesehīti.
analyzed: aññam aññam na jahāma tasmā sace pi imam himavantam pesetu kāmaḥ mam paṭhamam māretvā pacchā pesehi iti
translated: One of us two may go free and go to the Himalayas, knowing that the other is dead. But we do not abandon each other while we are alive. Therefore, if you wish to send him to the Himalayas, kill me first and then send him.”

original: Evañca pana vatvā “mahārāja, na mayaṃ tava vacanaṃ akātukāmatāya tuṇhī ahumha, mayaṃ kathāya pana dosaṃ disvā na kathayimhā”ti dīpento imaṃ gāthādvayamāha –
analyzed: evam ca pana vatvā mahā rāja na mayam tava vacanam a kātu kāma tāya tuṇhī ahumha mayam kathāya pana dosam disvā na kathayimha iti dīpentaḥ imam gāthā dvayam āha
translated: Having said this, in order to show that they had not remained silent because they did not wish to obey his command, but because they had seen faults in the discussion, he uttered the following two stanzas:

original: “Na ve nindā suparivajjayetha, nānā janā sevitabbā janinda;
analyzed: na ve nindā su parivajjayetha nānā janā sevitabbā janinda
translated: “Blame should not be easily avoided, nor should all men be served, O King;

original: Yeneva eko labhate pasaṃsaṃ, teneva añño labhate ninditāraṃ.
analyzed: yena iva ekaḥ labhate pasaṃsam tena iva aññaḥ labhate ninditāram
translated: For by the very virtue by which one man wins praise, another wins blame.

original: “Sabbo loko paricitto aticitto, sabbo loko cittavā samhi citte;
analyzed: sabbo loko paricittaḥ aticitto sabbo loko cittavā samhi citte
translated: “All men are of different minds, all men are of different thoughts;

original: Paccekacittā puthu sabbasattā, kassīdha cittassa vasena vatte”ti.🔽Tattha suparivajjayethāti mahārāja, nindā nāma sukhena parivajjetuṃ na sakkā. Nānā🔽janāti nānāchandā janā. Yenevāti yena sīlādiguṇena eko pasaṃsaṃ labhati, teneva añño
analyzed: paccekacittā puthu sabba sattā kassa idha cittassa vasena vattā iti  tattha su parivajjayetha ati mahā rāja nindā nāma sukhena parivajjetum na sakkā nānā  nānā chandāḥ janā yena iva ati yena sīla ādi guṇena ekaḥ pasaṃsam labhati tena iva aññaḥ
translated: Each man’s mind is different from his neighbor’s. Who then can be trusted? ”

original: ninditāraṃ labhati. Amhākañhi kinnarānaṃ antare kathanena pasaṃsaṃ labhati, manussānaṃ
analyzed: ninditāram labhati amhākam hi kinnarānam antare kathanena pasaṃsam labhati manussānam
translated: Herein, easily avoided means, O King, blame is not easily avoided. Different men means men of different desires. By the very virtue means by the very virtue of virtue, etc. One man wins praise means one man wins praise by virtue, etc. Another wins blame means another wins blame by virtue, etc. For in our Kinnara world one wins praise by discussion, but among men one wins blame by discussion.

original: antare nindaṃ, iti nindā nāma dupparivajjiyā, svāhaṃ kathaṃ tava santikā pasaṃsaṃ labhissāmīti.
analyzed: antare iti nindā nāma dupparivajjiyā svā aham katham tava santikā pasaṃsam labhissāmi iti
translated: in between, criticism. Thus criticism is hard to avoid. How can I get praise from you?”

original: Sabbo loko paricittoti mahārāja, asappuriso nāma pāṇātipātādicittena, sappuriso pāṇātipātā🔽veramaṇi ādicittena aticittoti, evaṃ sabbo loko paricitto aticittoti attho. Cittavā
analyzed: sabbaḥ loko paricitto ti mahā rāja asappurisaḥ nāma pāṇātipāta ādi cittena sappuriso pāṇātipātā  ādi cittena aticitto ti evam sabbo loko paricitto aticitto ti attho cittavā
translated: “The whole world is under a spell,” — the whole world is under a spell, sire, in that the wicked are under the spell of a mind that kills living things, and the good are under the spell of a mind that abstains from killing living things.🔽Thus the whole world is under a spell, is under the influence of a mind. The meaning is: the whole world is under the influence of a mind.

original: samhi citteti sabbo pana loko attano hīnena vā paṇītena vā cittena cittavā nāma.
analyzed: samhi cittā iti sabbaḥ pana lokaḥ attanaḥ hīnena vā paṇītena vā cittena cittavā nāma
translated: The whole world is under the influence of a mind, sire, in that all the world is under the influence of its own mind, whether low or lofty.

original: Paccekacittāti pāṭiyekkacittā puthuppabhedā sabbe sattā. Tesu kassekassa tava vā🔽aññassa vā cittena kinnarī vā mādiso vā añño vā vatteyya, tasmā “ayaṃ mama cittavasena
analyzed: paccekacittā ti pāṭiyekka cittā puthu ppabhedā sabbe sattā tesu kassa ikassa tava vā  aññassa vā cittena kinnarī vā mādisaḥ vā aññaḥ vā vatteyya tasmai ayam mama citta vasena
translated: All beings are under the influence of their own minds, each one separately, each one individually.🔽If anyone, whether a Kinnara or someone like me or anyone else, should behave towards you in accordance with his own mind, then do not be angry with me, thinking: ‘He does not behave in accordance with my mind.’

original: na vattatī”ti, mā mayhaṃ kujjhi. Sabbasattā hi attano cittavasena gacchanti, devāti.
analyzed: na vattati iti mā mayham kujjhi sabba sattāḥ hi attanaḥ citta vasena gacchanti deva ati
translated: For all beings go according to their own minds, O gods.”

original: Kimpuriso rañño dhammaṃ desesi.
analyzed: kimpurisaḥ raññaḥ dhammam desesi
translated: The Kimpuruṣa taught the king the Dhamma.

original: Rājā “sabhāvameva katheti paṇḍito kinnaro”ti somanassappatto hutvā osānagāthamāha –
analyzed: rājā sabhāvam eva katheti paṇḍitaḥ kinnaraḥ ti somanassa pattaḥ hutvā osāna gātham āha
translated: The king, thinking to himself, “The wise Kinnara speaks the truth,” was filled with joy, and he spoke the following Stanza,

original: “Tuṇhī ahū kimpuriso sabhariyo, yo dāni byāhāsi bhayassa bhīto;
analyzed: tuṇhī ahū kimpuriso sa bhariyaḥ yaḥ dāni bhayassa bhītaḥ
translated: The Kinnara and his wife were silent; but he who now speaks was frightened by fear.

original: So dāni mutto sukhito arogo, vācākirevatthavatī narāna”nti.
analyzed: saḥ dāni muttaḥ sukhitaḥ arogaḥ
translated: Now he is set free, happy and well; the speech of men is indeed a blessing.

original: Tattha vācākirevatthavatī narānanti vācāgirā eva imesaṃ sattānaṃ atthavatī hitāvahā hotīti attho.
analyzed: tattha vācākirā iva atthavatī vācā girā eva imesam sattānam atthavatī hita āvahā hoti iti attho
translated: The speech of men is indeed a blessing, that is to say, the speech of men is a blessing, a benefit, to all living beings.

original: Rājā kinnare suvaṇṇapañjare nisīdāpetvā tameva luddaṃ pakkosāpetvā “gaccha bhaṇe,🔽gahitaṭṭhāneyeva vissajjehī”ti vissajjāpesi. Mahāsattopi “ācariya, evaṃ kinnarā vācaṃ
analyzed: rājā kinnare suvaṇṇa pañjare nisīdāpetvā tam eva luddam pakkosāpetvā gaccha bhaṇe  gahita ṭṭhāne iya iva vissajjehi iti vissajjāpesi mahāsattaḥ api ācariye evam kinnarāḥ vācam
translated: The king had the Kinnaras placed in a golden cage, and he summoned the hunter and said to him, “Go,

original: rakkhitvā pattakāle kathitena subhāsiteneva muttā, tvaṃ pana dukkathitena mahādukkhaṃ
analyzed: rakkhitvā patta kāle kathitena su bhāsitena iva muttā tvam pana dukkathitena mahā dukkham
translated: and set them free where you caught them.” The Great Being, pointing to the hunter as an example, said, “Teacher, the Kinnaras kept their speech and were set free at the proper time by their good speech. But you, by your evil speech,

original: patto”ti idaṃ udāharaṇaṃ dassetvā “ācariya, mā bhāyi, jīvitaṃ te ahaṃ dassāmī”ti
analyzed: idam udāharaṇam dassetvā ācariya mā bhāyi jīvitam te aham dassāmi iti
translated: have fallen into great misery.” And he continued, “Teacher, do not fear; I will give you your life.”

original: assāsesi, “apica kho pana tumhe maṃ rakkheyyāthā”tivutte “na tāva nakkhattayogo labbhatī”ti🔽divasaṃ vītināmetvā majjhimayāmasamanantare mataṃ eḷakaṃ āharāpetvā “brāhmaṇa, yattha
analyzed: assāsesi apica kho pana tumhe mam rakkheyyātha ativutte na tāva nakkhatta yogo labbhati iti  divasam vītinām etvā majjhima yāma samanantare matam eḷakam āhara apetvā brāhmaṇa yattha
translated: “But will you protect me?” “We cannot do that until the conjunction of the stars is favorable.”

original: katthaci gantvā jīvāhī”ti kañci ajānāpetvā uyyojetvā eḷakamaṃsena baliṃ katvā dvāraṃ patiṭṭhāpesi.
analyzed: katthaci gantvā jīvāhi iti kañci a jānāpetvā uyyojetvā eḷaka maṃsena balim katvā dvāram patiṭṭhāpesi
translated: So they spent the day in this way. In the middle watch of the night they brought the dead goat, and saying to the Brahman, “Go where you will and live,” sent him away without letting anyone know where he had gone. Then they made a feast of goat’s flesh and set the door free.

original: Satthā imaṃ dhammadesanaṃ āharitvā “na, bhikkhave, idāneva, pubbepi kokāliko vācāya🔽hatoyevā”ti vatvā jātakaṃ samodhānesi – “tadā kaḷārapiṅgalo kokāliko ahosi, takkāriyapaṇḍito🔽pana ahameva ahosi”nti.
analyzed: satthā imam dhamma desanam āharitvā na bhikkhave idānā iva pubbe pi kokālikaḥ vācāya  hatoyā iva iti vatvā jātakam samodhānesi tadā kaḷārapiṅgalaḥ kokālikaḥ ahosi takkāriya paṇḍito  pana aham eva
translated: When the Teacher had related this parable, he said, “Monks, Kokālika was not the first to be ruined by the use of speech;

original: Takkāriyajātakavaṇṇanā aṭṭhamā.
analyzed: takkāriya jātaka vaṇṇanā aṭṭhamā
translated: he was ruined by the use of speech in a previous state of existence also.” So saying, he expounded the Law by pronouncing the following Stanza,

original: [482] 9. Rurumigarājajātakavaṇṇanā
analyzed: ruru miga rāja jātaka vaṇṇanā
translated: In the dispensation of Kassapa, the Supremely Enlightened One,🔽There was a certain wise man who was a teacher of the Law.

original: Tassa gāmavaraṃ dammīti idaṃ satthā veḷuvane viharanto devadattaṃ ārabbha kathesi.
analyzed: tassa gām avaram dammi iti idam satthā veḷuvane viharantaḥ devadattam ārabbha kathesi
translated: This religious instruction was given by the Teacher while he was in residence at Veḷuvana with reference to Devadatta.

original: So kira bhikkhūhi “bahūpakāro te āvuso, devadattasatthā, tvaṃ tathāgataṃ nissāya
analyzed: saḥ kira bhikkhūhi bahu upakāraḥ te āvuso devadatta satthā tvam tathāgatam nissāya
translated: They said to him, “Friend Devadatta, your teacher has been very kind to you.

original: pabbajjaṃ labhi, tīṇi piṭakāni uggaṇhi, lābhasakkāraṃ pāpuṇī”ti vutto “āvuso, satthārā🔽mama tiṇaggamattopi upakāro na kato, ahaṃ sayameva pabbajiṃ, sayaṃ tīṇi piṭakāni
analyzed: pabbajjam labhi tīṇi piṭakāni uggaṇhi lābha sakkāram pāpuṇi iti vuttaḥ āvuso satthārā  mama tiṇagga mattaḥ api upakāraḥ na kataḥ aham sayam eva pabbajim sayam tīṇi piṭakāni
translated: You have received the going forth under the Tathāgata, you have learned the Three Pitakas, and you have obtained gain and honor.”🔽“Friends, the Teacher has not been kind to me to the extent of a blade of grass.

original: uggaṇhiṃ, sayaṃ lābhasakkāraṃ pāpuṇi”nti kathesi. Bhikkhū dhammasabhāyaṃ kathaṃ samuṭṭhāpesuṃ🔽“akataññū āvuso, devadatto akatavedī”ti. Satthā āgantvā “kāya nuttha, bhikkhave,
