translated: and frighten him. If he runs away, I will shoot him and bring him down.” So saying, he strung his bow

original: āropetvā bodhisattābhimukho ahosi. Tamatthaṃ pakāsento satthā imaṃ gāthādvayamāha –
analyzed: āropetvā bodhisatta abhimukhaḥ ahosi tam attham pakāsentaḥ satthā imam gāthā dvayam āha
translated: and stood facing the Bodhisatta. Expounding this matter, the Master pronounced the following Stanza,

original: “Dhanuṃ advejjhaṃ katvāna, usuṃ sannayhupāgami;
analyzed: dhanum advejjham katvānaḥ usum sannayh upāgami
translated: Having strung his unerring bow, he drew it and aimed at the deer.

original: Migo ca disvā rājānaṃ, dūrato ajjhabhāsatha.
analyzed: migaḥ ca disvā rājānam dūratas ajjhabhāsatha
translated: But when the deer saw the king, he spoke to him from a distance, saying,

original: “Āgamehi mahārāja, mā maṃ vijjhi rathesabha;
analyzed: āgamehi mahā rāja mā mama vijjhi rathesabha
translated: “Wait, great king! Do not shoot me, O prince of charioteers!

original: Ko nu te idamakkhāsi, ettheso tiṭṭhate migo”ti.
analyzed: kaḥ nu te idam akkhāsi ettha iso tiṭṭhate migo ti
translated: Who has told you that here is a deer?”

original: Tattha advejjhaṃ katvānāti jiyāya ca sarena ca saddhiṃ ekameva katvā. Sannayhāti
analyzed: advejjham katvā anāti ca sarena ca saddhim ekam eva katvā
translated: Herein, having strung his unerring bow means having made it one with the string and the arrow. He drew it means

original: sannayhitvā. Āgamehīti “tiṭṭha, mahārāja, mā maṃ vijjhi, jīvaggāhameva gaṇhāhī”ti
analyzed: āgamehi iti tiṭṭha mahā rāja mā mama vijjhi jīvaggāham eva gaṇhāhi iti
translated: he drew the bow. Wait means “Stop, great king! Do not shoot me! Take me alive.”

original: madhurāya manussavācāya abhāsi.
analyzed: madhurāya manus savācāya abhāsi
translated: So saying, he spoke to the king in sweet human speech.

original: Rājā tassa madhurakathāya bandhitvā dhanuṃ otāretvā gāravena aṭṭhāsi. Mahāsattopi🔽rājānaṃ upasaṅkamitvā madhurapaṭisanthāraṃ katvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhāsi. Mahājanopi sabbāvudhāni
analyzed: rājā tassa madhura kathāya bandhitvā dhanuṃ otāretvā gāravena aṭṭhāsi mahāsattaḥ pi  rājānam upasaṅkamitvā madhura paṭisanthāram katvā ekamantam aṭṭhāsi mahā janaḥ api sabbāvudhāni
translated: The king, caught by his sweet words, lowered his bow and stood respectfully. The Great Being🔽approached the king, greeted him with sweet words, and stood to one side. The great crowd, too,

original: chaḍḍetvā āgantvā rājānaṃ parivāresi. Tasmiṃ khaṇe mahāsatto suvaṇṇakiṅkiṇikaṃ cālento
analyzed: chaḍḍetvā āgantvā rājānam parivāresi tasmin khaṇe mahāsattaḥ suvaṇṇa kiṅkiṇikam cālentaḥ
translated: threw down their weapons, came up, and surrounded the king. At that moment the Great Being, shaking his golden bells

original: viya madhurena sarena rājānaṃ pucchi “ko nu te idamakkhāsi, ettheso tiṭṭhate migo”ti?
analyzed: viya madhurena sarena rājānam pucchi kaḥ nu te idam akkhāsi etthā īsaḥ tiṭṭhate migo ti
translated: as if, asked the king in a sweet voice, “Who told you this? Here stands the deer.”

original: Tasmiṃ khaṇe pāpapuriso thokaṃ paṭikkamitvā sotapatheva aṭṭhāsi. Rājā “iminā me dassito”ti
analyzed: tasmin khaṇe pāpa puriso thokam paṭikkamitvā sota pathā iva aṭṭhāsi rājā iminā me dassitoti
translated: At that moment the wicked man stepped back a little and stood within hearing. The king, thinking, “He showed me,”

original: kathento chaṭṭhaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: kathentaḥ chaṭṭham gātham āha
translated: said in the sixth stanza:

original: “Esa pāpacaro poso, samma tiṭṭhati ārakā;
analyzed: esa pāpa caraḥ poso samma tiṭṭhati ārakā
translated: “This is the wicked man, my friend, who stands at a distance;

original: Soyaṃ me idamakkhāsi, ettheso tiṭṭhate migo”ti.
analyzed: saḥ ayam me idam akkhāsi ettha iso tiṭṭhate migo ti
translated: He told me this: ‘Here stands the deer.’”

original: Tattha pāpacaroti vissaṭṭhācāro.
analyzed: tattha pāpa caro ti vissaṭṭha ācāro
translated: Herein, wicked man means one of evil conduct.

original: Taṃ sutvā mahāsatto taṃ mittadubbhiṃ garahitvā raññā saddhiṃ sallapanto sattamaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: tam sutvā mahāsatto tam mitta dubbhim garahitvā raññā saddhim sallapanto sattamam gātham āha
translated: Hearing this, the Great Being, reproaching that betrayer of his friend, spoke the seventh stanza in reply to the king:

original: “Saccaṃ kireva māhaṃsu, narā ekacciyā idha;
analyzed: saccam kira iva mā ahaṃsu narāḥ ekacciyāḥ idha
translated: “Is it true, as they say, that men here in this world

original: Kaṭṭhaṃ niplavitaṃ seyyo, na tvevekacciyo naro”ti.
analyzed: kaṭṭham niplavitam seyyaḥ na tu eva ekacciyaḥ
translated: Would rather have a log than a man, even if he be a single man?”

original: Tattha niplavitanti uttāritaṃ. Ekacciyoti ekacco pana mittadubbhī pāpapuggalo udake🔽patantopi uttārito na tveva seyyo. Kaṭṭhañhi nānappakārena upakārāya saṃvattati,
analyzed: tattha niplavitam ti uttāritam ekacciyā iti ekaccaḥ pana mitta dubbhī pāpa puggalaḥ udake  patantaḥ api uttāritaḥ na tu eva seyyaḥ kaṭṭhan hi nānappakārena upakārāya saṃvattati
translated: Herein, “a log” is a piece of wood. “A single man” is a single man who is a wicked friend.🔽Even if he falls into the water and is rescued, he is not better. For a piece of wood is useful in various ways,

original: mittadubbhī pana pāpapuggalo vināsāya, tasmā tato kaṭṭhameva varataranti porāṇakapaṇḍitā
analyzed: pana pāpa puggalaḥ vināsāya tasmai kaṭṭham eva varataranti porāṇaka paṇḍitā
translated: but a wicked friend is not. The ancient wise men therefore

original: kathayiṃsu, mayā pana tesaṃ vacanaṃ na katanti.
analyzed: kathayiṃsu mayā pana tesam vacanam na
translated: said that a piece of wood is better than he. But I did not do as they said.

original: Taṃ sutvā rājā itaraṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: tam sutvā rājā itaram gātham āha
translated: ” When the king heard this, he spoke the second stanza:

original: “Kiṃ nu ruru garahasi migānaṃ, kiṃ pakkhīnaṃ kiṃ pana mānusānaṃ;
analyzed: kim nu ruru garahasi migānam kim pakkhīnam kim pana mānusānam
translated: “Why do you blame the deer, O Ruru? Why the birds? Why men?

original: Bhayaṃ hi maṃ vindatinapparūpaṃ, sutvāna taṃ mānusiṃ bhāsamāna”nti.
analyzed: bhayam hi mam vindatinappa rūpam sutvāna tam mānusim bhāsamānanti
translated: For I am frightened at the sound of your human voice.”

original: Tattha migānanti migānamaññataraṃ garahasi, udāhu pakkhīnaṃ, mānusānanti pucchi.
analyzed: tattha migānam ti migānam aññataram garahasi udāhu pakkhīnam mānusānam ti pucchi
translated: Herein, “deer” means any deer. “Birds” means any birds. “Men” means any men. He asked, “Why do you blame any of these?

original: Bhayañhi maṃ vindatīti bhayaṃ maṃ paṭilabhati, ahaṃ attani anissaro bhayasantako
analyzed: bhayan hi mam vindati iti bhayam mam paṭilabhati aham attani anissaraḥ bhaya santako
translated: Bhayaṃ hi maṃ vindati: “Fear finds me” means “I find fear” . I am as if helpless and fearful in myself.

original: viya homi. Anapparūpanti mahantaṃ.
analyzed: viya homi mahantam
translated: Anapparūpaṃ: “great” .

original: Tato mahāsatto “mahārāja, na migaṃ, na pakkhiṃ garahāmi, manussaṃ pana garahāmī”ti dassento navamaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: tatas mahāsattaḥ mahā rāja na migam na pakkhim garahāmi manussam pana garahāmi iti dassentaḥ navamam gātham āha
translated: Then the Great Being, showing that he did not blame the deer or the bird but only the man, spoke the ninth verse:🔽“The man whom I rescued as he was being carried away

original: “Yamuddhariṃ vāhane vuyhamānaṃ, mahodake salile sīghasote;
analyzed: yam ud harim vāhane vuyhamānam mahā udake salile sīgha sote
translated: on the swift current of the great flood of water,🔽from him has come to me this fear today;

original: Tatonidānaṃ bhayamāgataṃ mama, dukkho have rāja asabbhi saṅgamo”ti.🔽Tattha vāhaneti patitapatite vahituṃ samatthe gaṅgāvahe. Mahodake salileti mahāudake
analyzed: tatonidānam bhayam āgatam mama dukkhaḥ have rāja asabbhi saṅgamaḥ ti  tattha vāhana iti patita patite vahitum samatthe gaṅgā vahe mahā udake salila iti mahā udake
translated: hard is the association, O King, with the unrighteous.”🔽Herein, vāhane means on the current of the Ganges which was able to carry him away as he was sinking and rising again. Mahodake salile means in the great flood of water.

original: mahāsalileti attho. Ubhayenāpi gaṅgāvahasseva bahuudakataṃ dasseti. Tatonidānanti
analyzed: mahā salilā iti atthaḥ ubhayena api gaṅgā vahassa iva bahu udaka tam dasseti tatonidānam ti
translated: The meaning is: in the great flood of water. By both words he shows the great quantity of water in the Ganges current. Tatonidānaṃ means:

original: mahārāja, yo mayhaṃ tayā dassito puriso, eso mayā gaṅgāya vuyhamāno aḍḍharattasamaye
analyzed: mahā rāja yaḥ mayham tayā dassito puriso esaḥ mayā gaṅgāya vuyhamānaḥ aḍḍha ratta samaye
translated: O King, the man whom you showed me, I rescued him at midnight as he was being carried away by the Ganges,

original: kāruññaravaṃ viravanto uddharito, tatonidānaṃ me idamajja bhayaṃ āgataṃ, asappurisehi
analyzed: kāruñña ravam viravantaḥ tatonidānam me idam ajja bhayam āgatam asappurisehi
translated: crying out piteously with compassion. From that cause this fear has come to me today.🔽With the unrighteous

original: samāgamo nāma dukkho, mahārājāti.
analyzed: samāgamaḥ nāma dukkhaḥ mahā rāja ati
translated: Union is a thing of sorrow, Great King.”

original: Taṃ sutvā rājā tassa kujjhitvā “evaṃ bahūpakārassa nāma guṇaṃ na jānāti, vijjhitvā naṃ jīvitakkhayaṃ pāpessāmī”ti dasamaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: tam sutvā rājā tassa kujjhitvā evam bahu upakārassa nāma guṇam na jānāti vijjhitvā naṃ jīvita khayam pāpessāmi iti dasamam gātham āha
translated: When the king heard this he was angry with the bird, and thinking, “He does not know the virtue of one who has been so helpful to him,” he spoke the tenth stanza:

original: “Sohaṃ catuppattamimaṃ vihaṅgamaṃ, tanucchidaṃ hadaye ossajāmi;
analyzed: saḥ aham catuppattam imam vihaṅgamam tanu chidam hadaye ossajāmi
translated: “I will pierce this bird with four wings, And strike him down to the ground.

original: Hanāmi taṃ mittadubbhiṃ akiccakāriṃ, yo tādisaṃ kammakataṃ na jāne”ti.
analyzed: hanāmi tam mitta dubbhim a kicca kārim yaḥ tādisam kamma katam na jāneti
translated: I will kill this one who is false to his friend, who does his work amiss, Who does not know the one who has done his work.”

original: Tattha catuppattanti catūhi vājapattehi samannāgataṃ. Vihaṅgamanti ākāsagāmiṃ. Tanucchidanti sarīrachindanaṃ. Ossajāmīti etassa hadaye vissajjemi.
analyzed: tattha catuppattam ti catūhi vāja pattehi samannāgatam vihaṅgamam ti ākāsagāmim tanucchidam ti sarīra chindanam ossajāmi iti etassa hadaye vissajjemi
translated: Herein, with four wings means with four wings of wind. Bird means one who goes through the air. Strike him down means I will strike him down.

original: Tato mahāsatto “mā esa maṃ nissāya nassatū”ti cintetvā ekādasamaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: tatas mahāsattaḥ mā esa mama nissāya nassatu iti cintetvā ekādasamam gātham āha
translated: Then the Great Being thought, “Let him not be lost through me,” and so he spoke the eleventh stanza:

original: “Dhīrassa bālassa have janinda, santo vadhaṃ nappasaṃsanti jātu;
analyzed: dhīrassa bālassa have janinda santaḥ vadham na ppasaṃsanti jātu
translated: “The wise, O King, and the foolish, too, Never approve of the killing of one who is good.

original: Kāmaṃ gharaṃ gacchatu pāpadhammo, yañcassa bhaṭṭhaṃ tadetassa dehi;
analyzed: kāmam gharam gacchatu pāpa dhammaḥ yat ca assa bhaṭṭham tat etassa dehi
translated: Let the one of evil nature go home again, And give him his wages.

original: Ahañca te kāmakaro bhavāmī”ti.
analyzed: aham ca te kāma karaḥ bhavāmi iti
translated: I will be your obedient servant.”

original: Tattha kāmanti kāmena yathāruciyā attano gharaṃ gacchatu. Yañcassa bhaṭṭhaṃ tadetassa
analyzed: tattha kāmanti kāmena yathāruciyā attanaḥ gharam gacchatu yat ca assa bhaṭṭham tat etassa
translated: “As you like” means: “Go to your own house as you like.” And what is his wage, that is his.

original: dehīti yañca tassa “idaṃ nāma te dassāmī”ti tayā kathitaṃ, taṃ tassa dehi. Kāmakaroti🔽icchākaro, yaṃ icchasi, taṃ karohi, maṃsaṃ vā me khāda, kīḷāmigaṃ vā karohi, sabbattha
analyzed: dehi iti yat ca tassa idam nāma te dassāmi iti tayā kathitam tam tassa dehi kāmakaroti  icchā karaḥ yam icchasi tam karohi maṃsam vā me khāda kīḷāmigam vā karohi sabbattha
translated: “Go, as you like, to your own home, and give him what you promised him.”

original: te anukūlavattī bhavissāmīti attho.
analyzed: te anukūla vattī bhavissāmi iti attho
translated: “Do what you like,” means “Do what you wish, whether you eat my flesh or make me a pet deer, I will be obedient to you in all things.”

original: Taṃ sutvā rājā tuṭṭhamānaso mahāsattassa thutiṃ karonto anantaraṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: tam sutvā rājā tuṭṭha mānasaḥ mahāsattassa thutim karontaḥ anantaram gātham āha
translated: Hearing this, the king, with a glad heart, praised the Great Being, and spoke the next stanza:

original: “Addhā rurū aññataro sataṃ so, yo dubbhato mānusassa na dubbhi;
analyzed: addhā rurū aññataro satam so yaḥ dubbhataḥ mānusassa na dubbhi
translated: “Surely you are one of the hundred sages, who, though twice wronged by a man, are not twice angry.

original: Kāmaṃ gharaṃ gacchatu pāpadhammo, yañcassa bhaṭṭhaṃ tadetassa dammi;
analyzed: kāmam gharam gacchatu pāpa dhammaḥ yat ca assa tat etassa dammi
translated: Go home, you of evil ways, and give him what you promised him.

original: Ahañca te kāmacāraṃ dadāmī”ti.
analyzed: aham ca te kāmacāram dadāmi iti
translated: I give you leave to do what you like.”

original: Tattha sataṃ soti addhā tvaṃ sataṃ paṇḍitānaṃ aññataro. Kāmacāranti ahaṃ tava dhammakathāya
analyzed: tattha satam saḥ ti addhā tvam satam paṇḍitānam aññataraḥ aham tava dhamma kathāya
translated: Here, “one of the hundred sages” means “Surely you are one of the hundred wise men.” “Do what you like” means “I give you leave to do what you wish, whether you eat my flesh or make me a pet deer.”

original: pasīditvā tuyhaṃ kāmacāraṃ abhayaṃ dadāmi, ito paṭṭhāya tumhe nibbhayā yathāruciyā
analyzed: pasīditvā tuyham kāmacāram abhayam dadāmi itas paṭṭhāya tumhe nibbhayā yathāruciyā
translated: and having been pleased, I give you permission to do as you like, from now on you can be fearless and do as you please,

original: viharathāti mahāsattassa varaṃ adāsi.
analyzed: viharatha ati mahāsattassa varam adāsi
translated: and having been pleased, he gave him the boon that he might live in his realm in safety and freedom, and that from that time forth he might live there in safety and freedom, and as he desired.🔽And the Great Being gave him the boon, saying: “Great king, men speak with their mouths in one way, and act with their bodies in another.”

original: Atha naṃ mahāsatto “mahārāja, manussā nāma aññaṃ mukhena bhāsanti, aññaṃ kāyena karontī”ti pariggaṇhanto dve gāthā abhāsi –
analyzed: atha nam mahāsattaḥ mahā rāja manussāḥ nāma aññam mukhena bhāsanti aññam kāyena karonti iti pariggaṇhantaḥ dve gāthāḥ abhāsi
translated: And reflecting on this, he spoke two verses:

original: “Suvijānaṃ siṅgālānaṃ, sakuṇānañca vassitaṃ;
analyzed: suvijānam siṅgālānam sakuṇānam ca
translated: “The cries of jackals and of birds are easy to understand,

original: Manussavassitaṃ rāja, dubbijānataraṃ tato.
analyzed: manussavassitam rāja dubbijānataram tatas
translated: But the cries of men, O king, are harder to understand than these.

original: “Api ce maññatī poso, ñāti mitto sakhāti vā;
analyzed: api ce maññatī posaḥ ñāti mitto sakhāti vā
translated: “Though a man may think, ‘This is my kinsman, friend, or dear companion,’

original: Yo pubbe sumano hutvā, pacchā sampajjate diso”ti.
analyzed: yaḥ pubbe sumanaḥ hutvā pacchā sampajjate disā ti
translated: He who was friendly before may afterwards become an enemy.”

original: Taṃ sutvā rājā “migarāja, mā maṃ evaṃ maññi, ahañhi rajjaṃ jahantopi na tuyhaṃ dinnavaraṃ
analyzed: tam sutvā rājā miga rāja mā mam evam maññi ahañhi rajjam jahantaḥ api na tuyham dinna varam
translated: When the king heard this, he said: “King of Beasts, do not think so of me. Though I give up my kingdom, I will not give up the boon I have given you.

original: jahissaṃ, saddahatha, mayha”nti varaṃ adāsi. Mahāsatto tassa santike varaṃ gaṇhanto
analyzed: jahissam saddahatha mayhanti varam adāsi mahāsatto tassa santike varam gaṇhantaḥ
translated: Believe me.” And he gave him the boon. And the Great Being, accepting the boon in his presence,

original: attānaṃ ādiṃ katvā sabbasattānaṃ abhayadānaṃ varaṃ gaṇhi. Rājāpi taṃ varaṃ datvā
analyzed: attānam ādim katvā sabba sattānam abhaya dānam varam gaṇhi rājā api tam varam da tvā
translated: gave the boon that he might give safety to all creatures, beginning with himself. And the king, having given him the boon,

original: bodhisattaṃ nagaraṃ netvā mahāsattañca nagarañca alaṅkārāpetvā deviyā dhammaṃ desāpesi.
analyzed: bodhisattam nagaram netvā mahāsattam ca nagaram ca alaṅkārāpetvā deviyā dhammam desāpesi
translated: The Bodhisatta was brought into the city, and the king, having caused the city to be decorated, caused the queen to preach the Law.

original: Mahāsatto deviṃ ādiṃ katvā rañño ca rājaparisāya ca madhurāya manussabhāsāya dhammaṃ
analyzed: mahāsattaḥ devim ādim katvā rañño ca rāja parisāya ca madhurāya manussa bhāsāya dhammaṃ
translated: The Great Being, beginning with the queen, preached the Law in sweet human speech to the king and the royal court.

original: desetvā rājānaṃ dasahi rājadhammehi ovaditvā mahājanaṃ anusāsitvā araññaṃ pavisitvā
analyzed: desetvā rājānam dasahi rājadhammehi ovaditvā mahājanam anusāsitvā araññam pavisitvā
translated: Having admonished the king in the ten royal virtues, and instructed the multitude, he retired to the forest,

original: migagaṇaparivuto vāsaṃ kappesi. Rājā “sabbesaṃ sattānaṃ abhayaṃ dammī”ti nagare bheriṃ
analyzed: miga gaṇa parivutaḥ vāsam kappesi rājā sabbesam sattānam abhayam dammi iti nagare bheriṃ
translated: and dwelt there surrounded by a herd of deer. The king caused a proclamation to be made in the city, “I grant immunity to all creatures.”

original: carāpesi. Tato paṭṭhāya migapakkhīnaṃ koci hatthaṃ pasāretuṃ samattho nāma nāhosi.
analyzed: tatas paṭṭhāya miga pakkhīnam koci hattham pasāretum samatthaḥ nāma na ahosi
translated: From that time forth no one dared to stretch forth his hand against deer or birds.

original: Migagaṇo manussānaṃ sassāni khādati, koci vāretuṃ na sakkoti. Mahājano rājaṅgaṇaṃ
analyzed: miga gaṇaḥ manussānam sassāni khādati koci vāretum na sakkoti mahā janaḥ rājaṅgaṇam
translated: The herd of deer ate the crops of the people, and no one was able to prevent them. The multitude went to the royal court

original: gantvā upakkosi. Tamatthaṃ pakāsento satthā imaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: gantvā upakkosi tam attham pakāsentaḥ satthā imam gātham āha
translated: and complained. Expounding this matter, the Master spoke the Stanza,

original: “Samāgatā jānapadā, negamā ca samāgatā;
analyzed: samāgatāḥ jānapadāḥ negamā ca samāgatā
translated: “The people of the provinces have come together, and the people of the city have come together;

original: Migā sassāni khādanti, taṃ devo paṭisedhatū”ti.
analyzed: migā sassāni khādanti tam devaḥ paṭisedhatu uti
translated: The deer eat the crops; may the king restrain them.”

original: Tattha taṃ devoti taṃ migagaṇaṃ devo paṭisedhatūti.
analyzed: tattha tam deva iti tam miga gaṇam devaḥ paṭisedhatu iti
translated: “Let his Majesty forbid the deer.”

original: Taṃ sutvā rājā gāthādvayamāha –
analyzed: tam sutvā rājā gāthā dvayam āha
translated: When the king heard this, he spoke two verses:

original: “Kāmaṃ janapado māsi, raṭṭhañcāpi vinassatu;
analyzed: kāmam janapadaḥ mā asi raṭṭhan ca api vinassatu
translated: “Let my kingdom perish, let my realm be destroyed,

original: Na tvevāhaṃ ruruṃ dubbhe, datvā abhayadakkhiṇaṃ.
analyzed: na tu eva aham rurum da tvā abhaya dakkhiṇam

Tato “purimabuddhā🔽pana pāṭihāriyaṃ katvā kattha gacchantī”ti āvajjento “tāvatiṃsabhavana”nti ñatvā🔽buddhāsanā uṭṭhāya dakkhiṇapādaṃ yugandharamuddhani ṭhapetvā vāmapādena sinerumatthakaṃ🔽akkamitvā pāricchattakamūle paṇḍukambalasilāyaṃ vassaṃ upagantvā antotemāsaṃ devānaṃ
analyzed: nisinnaḥ dhammam desesi vīsati pāṇa koṭiyaḥ amata pānam piviṃsu tatas purima buddhā  pana pāṭihāriyam katvā kattha gacchanti iti ñatvā  buddha āsanā uṭṭhāya dakkhiṇa pādam yugandhara muddhani ṭhapetvā vāma pādena sinerumatthakam  akkamitvā pāricchattaka mūle paṇḍu kambala silāyam vassam upagantvā antotemāsam devānam
translated: and taught the Dhamma to the twenty koṭis of living beings who had assembled there, and they all drank the deathless drink. Then, thinking: “But where do the Buddhas of the past go to when they have done their miracle?” he perceived that they had gone to the Tāvatiṃsa heaven,🔽and so he rose up from his seat, placed his right foot on the Yugandhara mountain, and with his left foot he pressed down on the peak of Sineru.🔽Then he went to the Tāvatiṃsa heaven, and there he entered upon the Rains Retreat in the Paṇḍukambala cave on the Sineru mountain, and for three months he taught the Dhamma to his mother.

original: abhidhammapiṭakaṃ kathesi. Parisā satthu gataṭṭhānaṃ ajānantī “disvāva gamissāmā”ti🔽tattheva temāsaṃ vasi. Upakaṭṭhāya pavāraṇāya mahāmoggallānatthero gantvā bhagavato🔽ārocesi. Atha naṃ satthā pucchi “kahaṃ pana etarahi sāriputto”ti? “Eso, bhante, pāṭihāriye🔽pasīditvā pabbajitehi pañcahi bhikkhusatehi saddhiṃ saṅkassanagaradvāre vasī”ti.
analyzed: abhidhamma piṭakam kathesi parisā satthu gata ṭṭhānam a jānantī disvā ava gamissāma ati 🔽tattha iva temāsam vasi upakaṭṭhāya pavāraṇāya mahāmoggallāna theraḥ gantvā bhagavataḥ 🔽ārocesi atha nam satthā pucchi kaham pana etarahi sāriputto ti eso bhante pāṭihāriye 🔽pasīditvā pabbajitehi pañcahi bhikkhu satehi saddhim saṅkassa nagara dvāre vasīti
translated: and preached the Law to them. Twenty koṭis of living beings drank the deathless draught. Then the Teacher thought to himself, “Where did the Buddhas of old go to spend the rainy season?” Perceiving that they went to the World of the Thirty-three, he rose from his seat, placed his right foot on Mount Yugandhara, and with his left foot pressed down the summit of Mount Sineru. Then he went to the foot of the Coral Tree, entered the Clad in White’s Cave, and there spent the rainy season. For three months he preached the Abhidhamma Piṭaka to the Thirty-three Gods. The multitude, not knowing where the Teacher had gone, thought to themselves, “We will go to him as soon as we have seen the miracle.” Accordingly they spent the three months right there. When the Invitation Festival drew near, the Elder Moggallāna the Great went to the Teacher and told him. The Teacher asked him, “But where is Sāriputta now?” “Reverend Sir,” replied the Elder, “he is now staying at the gate of the city of Saṅkassa with five hundred monks who have been converted by the miracle.”

original: “Moggallāna, ahaṃ ito sattame divase saṅkassanagaradvāre otarissāmi, tathāgataṃ daṭṭhukāmā

translated: Herein, a man should hope is that a man should hope for success in his undertakings without having done the kind of work that cuts off hope.

translated: He should not despair: he should not despair as the man called “Six-Furlong” did. For he was a brahmin who lived at a place six furlongs from Savatthi. He had a field there, and every day he used to go there on foot and return in the evening. One day he fell into a pit in the field and was unable to get out. He shouted for help. People came and asked, “Why are you shouting?” He replied, “I have fallen into a pit and cannot get out.” They asked, “Where are you?” He replied, “I am in the field.” They asked, “Which field?” He replied, “The field of so-and-so.” They asked, “Where is his field?” He replied, “Six furlongs from Savatthi.” They said, “He will come tomorrow or the day after tomorrow. In the meanwhile you will die of hunger. Why did you not ask when you were near a village?” He said, “I did not ask because I was ashamed.” So they left him. He died of hunger. That is how he despaired. But the man who fell into the pit in the story did not despair. He hoped for success in his undertakings. He did not despair. He should not despair like that. Both harmful and helpful is a contact that is painful and a contact that is pleasant. The meaning is that they are contacts that lead to death and contacts that lead to life. For the contact that leads to death is harmful for beings, and the contact that leads to life is helpful. He shows that the contact that leads to death comes to thoughtless beings even though it is not thought of. What is not thought of comes to pass is that I did not think, “I shall fall into a pit,” but I thought, “I shall kill a deer,” and now it has happened.

analyzed: yaḥ tam viduggā narakā samuddhari silāya yoggam sarabho karitvā
translated: The antelope which drew you out of the pit of live coals,

original: Dukkhūpanītaṃ maccumukhā pamocayi, alīnacittaṃ ta migaṃ vadesī”ti.
analyzed: dukkha upanītam maccu mukhā pamocayi alīna cittam ta migam vadesi iti
translated: Dukkhūpanītaṃ maccumukhā pamocayi, alīnacittaṃ ta migaṃ vadesī”ti.

original: Tattha anusarīti anubandhi. Vikkantanti uddharaṇatthāya kataparakkamaṃ. Anujīvasīti
analyzed: tattha anusari iti anubandhi uddharaṇa atthāya kata parakkamam anujīvasi iti
translated: Tattha anusarīti anubandhi. Vikkantanti uddharaṇatthāya kataparakkamaṃ. Anujīvasīti

original: upajīvasi, tassānubhāvena tayā jīvitaṃ laddhanti attho. Samuddharīti uddhari. Ta
analyzed: upajīvasi tassa anubhāvena tayā jīvitam laddhanti samuddhari iti
translated: upajīvasi, tassānubhāvena tayā jīvitaṃ laddhanti attho. Samuddharīti uddhari. Ta

original: migaṃ vadesīti taṃ suvaṇṇasarabhamigaṃ idha sirisayane nisinno vaṇṇesi.
analyzed: migam vadesi iti tam suvaṇṇa sarabha migam idha siri sayane nisinnaḥ vaṇṇesi
translated: migaṃ vadesīti taṃ suvaṇṇasarabhamigaṃ idha sirisayane nisinno vaṇṇesi.

original: Taṃ sutvā rājā “ayaṃ mayā saddhiṃ na migavaṃ gato, sabbaṃ pavattiṃ jānāti, kathaṃ nu kho jānāti, pucchissāmi na”nti cintetvā navamaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: tam sutvā rājā ayam mayā saddhim na migavam gataḥ sabbam pavattim jānāti katham nu kho jānāti pucchissāmi na nti cintetvā navamam gātham āha
translated: Taṃ sutvā rājā “ayaṃ mayā saddhiṃ na migavaṃ gato, sabbaṃ pavattiṃ jānāti, kathaṃ nu kho jānāti, pucchissāmi na”nti cintetvā navamaṃ gāthamāha –

original: “Kiṃ tvaṃ nu tattheva tadā ahosi, udāhu te koci naṃ etadakkhā;
analyzed: kim tvam nu tattha iva tadā ahosi udāhu te koci naṃ
translated: “Kiṃ tvaṃ nu tattheva tadā ahosi, udāhu te koci naṃ etadakkhā;

analyzed: vivaṭa chaddaḥ nusi sabbadassī ñāṇam nu te brāhmaṇa bhiṃsa rūpam ti
translated: Vivaṭacchaddo nusi sabbadassī, ñāṇaṃ nu te brāhmaṇa bhiṃsarūpa”nti.

original: Tattha bhiṃsarūpanti kiṃ nu te ñāṇaṃ balavajātikaṃ, tenetaṃ jānāsīti.
analyzed: tattha bhiṃsa rūpanti kim nu te ñāṇam balava jātikam tena itam jānāsi iti
translated: Tattha bhiṃsarūpanti kiṃ nu te ñāṇaṃ balavajātikaṃ, tenetaṃ jānāsīti.

original: Brāhmaṇo “nāhaṃ sabbaññubuddho, byañjanaṃ amakkhetvā tayā kathitagāthānaṃ pana mayhaṃ attho upaṭṭhātī”ti dīpento dasamaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: brāhmaṇaḥ na aham sabbaññu buddhaḥ byañjanam a makkhetvā tayā kathita gāthānam pana mayham atthaḥ upaṭṭhāti iti dīpentaḥ dasamam gātham āha
translated: The Brahman said, “I am not omniscient. I do not know the words of the verse, but I know the meaning of the verse you have recited.” To make this clear, he spoke the tenth verse:

original: “Na cevahaṃ tattha tadā ahosiṃ, na cāpi me koci naṃ etadakkhā;
analyzed: na ca iva aham tattha tadā ahosim na ca api me koci naṃ etad akkhā
translated: “I was not there at the time, nor did anyone tell me;

original: Gāthāpadānañca subhāsitānaṃ, atthaṃ tadānenti janinda dhīrā”ti.
analyzed: gāthā padānam ca su bhāsitānam attham tadā ānenti janinda dhīrā iti
translated: But the wise, O Lord of men, explain the meaning of the well-spoken words of the verse.”

original: Tattha subhāsitānanti byañjanaṃ amakkhetvā suṭṭhu bhāsitānaṃ. Atthaṃ tadānentīti yo tesaṃ attho, taṃ ānenti upadhārentīti.
analyzed: tattha su bhāsitānam ti byañjanam a makkhetvā suṭṭhu bhāsitānam attham tat ānenti iti yaḥ tesam atthaḥ tam ānenti upadhārenti iti
translated: Herein, the well-spoken words means the words of the verse, without regard to the letters. They explain the meaning of the verse means they explain the meaning of the verse.

original: Rājā tassa tussitvā bahuṃ dhanaṃ adāsi. Tato paṭṭhāya dānādipuññābhirato ahosi, manussāpi
analyzed: rājā tassa tussitvā bahum dhanam adāsi tatas paṭṭhāya dāna ādi puñña abhirato ahosi manussa api
translated: The king was pleased and gave him much wealth. From that time on, he was devoted to the practice of giving and other meritorious deeds. The people,

original: puññābhiratā hutvā matamatā saggameva pūrayiṃsu. Athekadivasaṃ rājā “lakkhaṃ vijjhissāmī”ti
analyzed: puñña abhiratāḥ hutvā mata matā saggam eva pūrayiṃsu atha eka divasam rājā lakkham vijjhissāmi iti
translated: too, became devoted to the practice of meritorious deeds and filled the heavens with the dead. One day the king said, “I will shoot an arrow a hundred leagues.”

original: purohitamādāya uyyānaṃ gato. Tadā sakko devarājā bahū nave deve ca devakaññāyo ca
analyzed: purohitam ādāya uyyānam gataḥ tadā sakkaḥ devarājā bahū nave deve ca deva kaññāyo ca
translated: He took the chaplain with him and went to the pleasure garden. At that time Sakka, king of the gods, took many new gods and goddesses

original: disvā “kiṃ nu kho kāraṇa”nti āvajjento sarabhamigena narakā uddharitvā rañño sīlesu🔽patiṭṭhāpitabhāvaṃ ñatvā “rañño ānubhāvena mahājano puññāni karoti, tena devaloko
analyzed: disvā kim nu kho kāraṇanti āvajjento sarabhamigena narakā uddharitvā raññaḥ sīlesu  patiṭṭhāpita bhāvam ñatvā raññaḥ ānubhāvena mahājanaḥ puññāni karoti tena deva loko
translated: “What is the reason for this?” he asked himself. Then he saw that the deer had been rescued from hell by the king and established in the moral precepts.

original: paripūrati, idāni kho pana rājā lakkhaṃ vijjhituṃ uyyānaṃ gato, taṃ vīmaṃsitvā sīhanādaṃ
analyzed: paripūrati idāni kho pana rājā lakkham vijjhitum uyyānam gataḥ tam vīmaṃsitvā sīha nādam
translated: “The people are making merit through the king’s influence,” he thought. “That is why the world of the gods is being filled. Now the king has gone to the park to shoot an arrow at a target. I will go there and test him.

original: nadāpetvā sarabhamigassa guṇaṃ kathāpetvā attano ca sakkabhāvaṃ jānāpetvā ākāse ṭhito
analyzed: nadāpetvā sarabha migassa guṇam kathāpetvā attanaḥ ca sakka bhāvam jānāpetvā ākāse ṭhitaḥ
translated: After making him roar a lion’s roar and tell the deer’s virtues, I will make him know that I am Sakka. Then I will stand in the air

original: dhammaṃ desetvā mettāya ceva pañcannaṃ sīlānañca guṇaṃ kathetvā āgamissāmī”ti cintetvā
analyzed: dhammaṃ desetvā mettāya ca iva pañcannam sīlānam ca guṇam kathetvā āgamissāmi iti cintetvā
translated: and teach the Dhamma. After telling the virtues of loving-kindness and the five precepts, I will return.”

original: uyyānaṃ agamāsi. Rājāpi “lakkhaṃ vijjhissāmī”ti dhanuṃ āropetvā saraṃ sannayhi. Tasmiṃ
analyzed: uyyānam agamāsi rājā api lakkham vijjhissāmi iti dhanum āropetvā saram tasmin
translated: So he went to the park. The king, too, had gone there, thinking, “I will shoot an arrow at a target.” He strung his bow and fitted an arrow to the string.

original: khaṇe sakko rañño ca lakkhassa ca antare attano ānubhāvena sarabhaṃ dassesi. Rājā
analyzed: khaṇe sakkaḥ raññaḥ ca lakkhassa ca antare attanaḥ ānubhāvena sarabham dassesi rājā
translated: At that moment Sakka, by his own power, made the deer appear between the king and the target. The king,

original: taṃ disvā saraṃ na muñci. Atha naṃ sakko purohitassa sarīre adhimuccitvā gāthaṃ abhāsi –
analyzed: tam disvā saram na muñci atha nam sakko purohitassa sarīre adhimuccitvā gātham abhāsi
translated: seeing the deer, did not shoot the arrow. Then Sakka, having taken possession of the body of the chaplain, spoke this verse:

original: “Ādāya pattiṃ paraviriyaghātiṃ, cāpe saraṃ kiṃ vicikicchase tuvaṃ;
analyzed: ādāya pattim para viriya ghātim cāpe saram kim vicikicchase tuvam
translated: “Taking the arrow, the king’s best weapon, why do you hesitate, O king, to shoot it?

original: Nunno saro sarabhaṃ hantu khippaṃ, annañhi etaṃ varapañña rañño”ti.
analyzed: nunnaḥ saraḥ sarabham hantu khippam annam hi etam vara pañña raññoti
translated: Let the arrow, O king, quickly kill the Sarabha, for this is the king’s best food, O wise one.”

original: Tattha pattinti vājapattehi samannāgataṃ. Paraviriyaghātinti paresaṃ vīriyaghātakaṃ.🔽Cāpe saranti etaṃ pattasahitaṃ saraṃ cāpe ādāya sannayhitvā idāni tvaṃ kiṃ vicikicchasi.
analyzed: tattha pattinti vāja pattehi samannāgatam para viriya ghātinti paresam vīriya ghātakam  cāpe saranti etam patta sahitam saram cāpe ādāya idāni tvam kim vicikicchasi
translated: Here, “the arrow” means the arrow equipped with feathers. “The king’s best weapon” means the weapon that destroys the strength of others.🔽“Taking the arrow” means taking the arrow together with the feathers, fixing it on the bow, and drawing the bowstring. “Why do you hesitate?” means “Why do you hesitate now?”

original: Hantūti tayā vissaṭṭho hutvā esa saro khippaṃ imaṃ sarabhaṃ hanatu. Annañhi etanti
analyzed: hantu uti tayā vissaṭṭhaḥ hutvā esa saraḥ khippam imam sarabham hanatu annam hi etat ti
translated: “Let the arrow” means “Let the arrow, which you have fixed on the bow, quickly kill the Sarabha.” “For this is the king’s best food, O wise one” means

original: varapañña, mahārāja, sarabho nāma rañño āhāro bhakkhoti attho.
analyzed: varapañña mahā rāja sarabhaḥ nāma raññaḥ āhāraḥ bhakkho ti attho
translated: “O wise king, the Sarabha is the king’s best food.”

original: Tato rājā gāthamāha –
analyzed: tatas rājā gātham āha
translated: Then the king spoke this verse:

original: “Addhā pajānāmi ahampi etaṃ, annaṃ migo brāhmaṇa khattiyassa;
analyzed: addhā pajānāmi aham pi etam annam migaḥ brāhmaṇa khattiyassa
translated: “I know this well, O Brahman, the deer is the king’s food.

original: Pubbe katañca apacāyamāno, tasmā migaṃ sarabhaṃ no hanāmī”ti.
analyzed: pubbe katañca apacāyamāno tasmai migam sarabham naḥ hanāmi iti
translated: But remembering the service rendered by him in the past, I do not kill the Sarabha deer.”

original: Tattha pubbe katañcāti brāhmaṇa, ahametaṃ ekaṃsena jānāmi yathā migo khattiyassa annaṃ, pubbe pana iminā mayhaṃ kataguṇaṃ pūjemi, tasmā taṃ na hanāmīti.
analyzed: tattha pubbe katam ca ati brāhmaṇa aham etam ekaṃsena jānāmi yathā migo khattiyassa annam pubbe pana iminā mayham kataguṇam pūjemi tasmā tam na hanāmi iti
translated: “Brahmin, I know for certain that this deer is repaying a debt to me, and therefore I do not kill him.”

original: Tato sakko gāthādvayamāha –
analyzed: tatas sakkaḥ gāthā dvayam āha
translated: Then Sakka spoke two stanzas:

original: “Neso migo mahārāja, asureso disampati;
analyzed: nesaḥ migaḥ mahā rāja asuresaḥ
translated: “This is no deer, great king, but a demon, lord of the quarter.

original: Etaṃ hantvā manussinda, bhavassu amarādhipo.
analyzed: etam hantvā manussinda bhavassu amara adhipaḥ
translated: Kill him, O king, and be lord of the immortals.

original: “Sace ca rājā vicikicchase tuvaṃ, hantuṃ migaṃ sarabhaṃ sahāyakaṃ;
analyzed: sace ca rājā vicikicchase tuvam hantum migam sarabham sahāyakam
translated: “If you hesitate, O king, to kill the deer, your friend,

original: Saputtadāro naravīraseṭṭha, gantā tuvaṃ vetaraṇiṃ yamassā”ti.
analyzed: sa putta dāraḥ nara vīra seṭṭha gantā tuvam vetaraṇim yamassa ati
translated: With your sons and wives, O best of men, you will go to the Vaitarani, the hell of Yama.”

original: Tattha asuresoti asuro eso, asurajeṭṭhako sakko esoti adhippāyena vadati. Amarādhipoti
analyzed: tattha asura isoti asuraḥ esaḥ asura jeṭṭhako sakko esaḥ iti adhippāyena vadati amara adhipo ti
translated: Here “demon” means “demon,” but the intention is that Sakka, the chief of the demons, is meant. “Lord of the immortals” means

original: tvaṃ etaṃ sakkaṃ māretvā sayaṃ sakko devarājā hohīti vadati. Vetaraṇiṃ yamassāti
analyzed: tvam etam sakkam māretvā sayam sakkaḥ deva rājā hohi iti vadati vetaraṇim yamassa ati
translated: “Kill this Sakka and be yourself the Sakka, the king of the gods.” “The Vaitarani, the hell of Yama” means

original: “sace etaṃ ‘sahāyo me’ti cintetvā na māressasi, saputtadāro yamassa vetaraṇinirayaṃ
analyzed: sace etam sahāyaḥ mā iti cintetvā na māressasi sa putta dāraḥ yamassa vā itaraṇi nirayam
translated: “If you think ‘He is my friend’ and do not kill him, with your sons and wives you will go to the Vaitarani, the hell of Yama.”

original: gato bhavissasī”ti naṃ tāsesi.
analyzed: gataḥ bhavissasi iti nam tāsesi
translated: He thus frightened him.

original: Tato rājā dve gāthā abhāsi –
analyzed: tatas rājā dve gāthāḥ abhāsi
translated: Then the king spoke two stanzas:

original: “Kāmaṃ ahaṃ jānapadā ca sabbe, puttā ca dārā ca sahāyasaṅghā;
analyzed: kāmam aham jānapadā ca sabbe puttā ca dārā ca sahāya saṅghā
translated: “I may well go to Yama’s realm, with all my subjects, sons, wives, and friends,

original: Gacchemu taṃ vetaraṇiṃ yamassa, na tveva hañño mama pāṇado yo.
analyzed: gacchemu tam vetaraṇim yamassa na tu eva haññaḥ mama pāṇadaḥ yaḥ
translated: But never will I kill him who gave me life.

original: “Ayaṃ migo kicchagatassa mayhaṃ, ekassa kattā vivanasmi ghore;
analyzed: ayam migaḥ kiccha gatassa mayham ekassa kattā vivanasmi ghore
translated: “This deer has been my helper in this difficult place, a fearful wilderness,

original: Taṃ tādisaṃ pubbakiccaṃ saranto, jānaṃ mahābrahme kathaṃ haneyya”nti.
analyzed: tam tādisam pubba kiccam sarantaḥ jānam mahābrahme katham haneyyanti
translated: Knowing his former kindness, how could I, Great Brahma, kill him?”

original: Tattha mama pāṇado yoti brāhmaṇa, yo mama pāṇadado yena me piyaṃ jīvitaṃ dinnaṃ,
analyzed: mama pāṇadaḥ brāhmaṇa yaḥ mama pāṇadadaḥ yena me piyam jīvitam dinnam
translated: There, mama pāṇado yo, brahmin, he who gave me life, by whom my dear life was given,

original: narakaṃ pavisantena mayā so na tveva hañño na hanitabbo, avajjho esoti vadati. Ekassa
analyzed: narakam pavisantena mayā saḥ na tu eva haññaḥ na hanitabbaḥ avajjhaḥ esaḥ ti vadati ekassa
translated: Entering hell, I will not kill him, he should not be killed, he is blameless, he says. Ekassa,

original: kattā vivanasmi ghoreti dāruṇe araññe paviṭṭhassa sato ekassa asahāyakassa mama kattā
analyzed: kattā vivanasmi ghore iti dāruṇe araññe paviṭṭhassa sataḥ ekassa asahāyakassa mama kattā
translated: kattā vivanasmi ghore, in a fearful wilderness, having entered a fearful forest, of me who is alone, without a companion, kattā,

original: kārako jīvitassa dāyako, svāhaṃ taṃ iminā kataṃ tādisaṃ pubbakiccaṃ sarantoyeva taṃ
analyzed: kārakaḥ jīvitassa dāyakaḥ svāham tam iminā katam tādisam pubba kiccam sarantaḥ yā iva tam
translated: doer, giver of life, I, remembering his former kindness done by him,

original: guṇaṃ jānantoyeva kathaṃ haneyyaṃ.
analyzed: guṇam jānantoyā iva katham haneyyam
translated: knowing his virtue, how could I kill him?

original: Atha sakko purohitassa sarīrato apagantvā sakkattabhāvaṃ māpetvā ākāse ṭhatvā rañño guṇaṃ pakāsento gāthādvayamāha –
analyzed: atha sakkaḥ purohitassa sarīrataḥ apagantvā sakkatta bhāvam māpetvā ākāse ṭhatvā raññaḥ guṇam pakāsentaḥ gāthā dvayam āha
translated: Then Sakka, having departed from the body of the chaplain, assumed his own form, and standing in the air, he spoke two stanzas, proclaiming the king’s virtues:

original: “Mittābhirādhī cirameva jīva, rajjaṃ imaṃ dhammaguṇe pasāsa;
analyzed: mitta abhirādhī ciram eva jīva rajjam imam dhamma guṇe pasāsa
translated: “Please the friends, live long, and in this kingdom, be devoted to the virtues of the Dhamma.

original: Nārīgaṇehi paricāriyanto, modassu raṭṭhe tidiveva vāsavo.
analyzed: nārī gaṇehi modassu raṭṭhe tidivā iva vāsavaḥ
translated: Surrounded by the women, delighting, rejoice in the kingdom, like Vāsava in the Thirty-three.

original: “Akkodhano niccapasannacitto, sabbātithī yācayogo bhavitvā;
analyzed: akkodhanaḥ nicca pasanna cittaḥ sabba atithī yāca yogaḥ bhavitvā
translated: “Without anger, always with a serene mind, having become a giver to all guests,

original: Datvā ca bhutvā ca yathānubhāvaṃ, anindito saggamupehi ṭhāna”nti.
analyzed: da tvā ca bhutvā ca yathā anubhāvam aninditaḥ saggam upehi
translated: having given and eaten according to your ability, go to the heavenly place, uncensured.”

original: Tattha mittābhirādhīti mitte ārādhento tosento tesu adubbhamāno. Sabbātithīti sabbe
analyzed: tattha mitta abhirādhī iti mitte ārādhento tosento tesu a dubbhamāno sabba atithi iti sabbe
translated: There, please the friends means delighting, satisfying, not deceiving them. All guests means all

original: dhammikasamaṇabrāhmaṇe atithī pāhunakeyeva katvā pariharanto yācitabbayuttako hutvā.
analyzed: dhammika samaṇa brāhmaṇe atithī katvā pariharantaḥ yācitabba yuttakaḥ hutvā
translated: monks and brahmans who are righteous. Having become a giver to all guests means having become one who is fit to be asked for, having treated them as guests, as visitors.

original: Aninditoti dānādīni puññāni karaṇena pamudito devalokena abhinandito hutvā saggaṭṭhānaṃ upehīti.
analyzed: aninditaḥ ti dāna ādīni puññāni karaṇena pamuditaḥ deva lokena abhinanditaḥ hutvā sagga ṭṭhānam upehi iti
translated: Uncensured means having become delighted by doing such meritorious deeds as giving, and having become one who is welcomed by the world of the gods, go to the heavenly place.

original: Evaṃ vatvā sakko “ahaṃ mahārājaṃ taṃ pariggaṇhituṃ āgato, tvaṃ attānaṃ pariggaṇhituṃ nādāsi, appamatto hohī”ti taṃ ovaditvā sakaṭṭhānameva gato.
analyzed: evam vatvā sakkaḥ aham mahā rājam tam pariggaṇhitum āgataḥ tvam attānam pariggaṇhitum na adāsi appamattaḥ hohi iti tam ovaditvā saka ṭṭhānam eva gataḥ
translated: Having so spoken, Sakka said, “Great king, I have come to take you, but you have not taken yourself. Be careful.” And having thus admonished him, he returned to his own place.

original: Satthā imaṃ dhammadesanaṃ āharitvā “na, bhikkhave, idāneva, pubbepi sāriputto saṃkhittena
analyzed: satthā imam dhamma desanam āharitvā na bhikkhave idānā iva pubbe pi sāriputto saṃkhittena
translated: When the Teacher had related this story, he said, “Monks, this is not the first time Sāriputta has understood the meaning of a discourse in brief;

original: bhāsitassa vitthārena atthaṃ jānātiyevā”ti vatvā jātakaṃ samodhānesi – “tadā rājā
analyzed: bhāsitassa vitthārena attham jānātiyā iva ati vatvā jātakam samodhānesi tadā rājā
translated: in a previous state of existence also he understood the meaning of a discourse in brief.” And so saying, he related a Jātaka of the past.

original: ānando ahosi, purohito sāriputto, sarabhamigo pana ahameva ahosi”nti.
analyzed: ānandaḥ ahosi purohito sāriputto sarabhamigaḥ pana aham eva ahosinti
translated: At that time the king was Ānanda, the chaplain was Sāriputta, and I myself was the Sarabha deer.

original: Sarabhamigajātakavaṇṇanā dasamā.
analyzed: sarabha miga jātaka vaṇṇanā dasamā
translated: This is the story of the Sarabha deer.

original: Jātakuddānaṃ –🔽Amba phandana javana, nārada dūta kaliṅgā;🔽Akitti takkāriyaṃ ruru, sarabhaṃ dasa terase.
analyzed: jātakuddānam  amba phandana javana nārada dūta kaliṅgā  akitti takkāriyam ruru sarabham dasa terase
translated: The Jātaka collection is concluded.

translated: When I ask you, good fellow, tell me, where do you hide the rice?”

original: Tattha udaraṃ nūnāti aññesaṃ udaraṃ udarameva maññe, tava udaraṃ pana atiudaraṃ.🔽Tatthāti tasmiṃ simbalivane. Pūresīti vassārattatthāya pūresi. Nidāhasīti nidhānaṃ
analyzed: tattha udaram nūna ati aññesam udaram udaram eva maññe tava udaram pana ati udaram  tattha ati tasmin simbali vane pūresi iti pūresi nidāhasi iti nidhānam
translated: Herein, surely the bellies of others are small means the bellies of others are small, I suppose, but your belly is very large.

original: katvā ṭhapesi, “nidhīyasī”tipi pāṭho.
analyzed: katvā nidhīyasi itipi
translated: There means in that simsapa grove. Fill up means you fill it up for the purpose of storing it. Hide means you store it away. The reading nidāhasī is also allowable.

original: Taṃ sutvā suvarājā madhurāya manussabhāsāya sattamaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: tam sutvā suva rājā madhurāya manus sabhāsāya sattamam gātham āha
translated: Having heard this, Suva spoke the seventh stanza in a sweet human voice:

original: “Na me veraṃ tayā saddhiṃ, koṭṭho mayhaṃ na vijjati;
analyzed: na me veram tayā saddhim koṭṭhaḥ mayham na vijjati
translated: “There is no grudge between you and me, and I have no storehouse;

original: Iṇaṃ muñcāmiṇaṃ dammi, sampatto koṭasimbaliṃ;
analyzed: muñcāmi iṇam dammi sampattaḥ koṭasim balim
translated: I pay the debt and give the gift, I lay up treasure in the Simbali wood;

original: Nidhimpi tattha nidahāmi, evaṃ jānāhi kosiyā”ti.
analyzed: nidhim pi tattha nidahāmi evam jānāhi kosiya ati
translated: There I lay up treasure, know this, O Kosiya.”

original: Tattha iṇaṃ muñcāmiṇaṃ dammīti tava sāliṃ haritvā iṇaṃ muñcāmi ceva dammi cāti vadati. Nidhimpīti ekaṃ tattha simbalivane anugāmikanidhimpi nidahāmi.
analyzed: tattha iṇam muñcāmi iṇam dammi iti tava sālim haritvā iṇam muñcāmi ca iva dammi ca ati vadati nidhim pi iti ekam tattha simbali vane anugāmika nidhim pi nidahāmi
translated: Herein, I pay the debt and give the gift means I take your rice and pay the debt and give the gift, he says. I lay up treasure there means I lay up a treasure there in the Simbali wood that will follow you.

original: Atha naṃ brāhmaṇo pucchi –
analyzed: atha nam brāhmaṇaḥ pucchi
translated: Then the brahmin asked him:

original: “Kīdisaṃ te iṇadānaṃ, iṇamokkho ca kīdiso;
analyzed: kīdisam te iṇa dānam iṇa mokkhaḥ ca kīdisaḥ
translated: “What is the debt and gift? What is the debt-remission?

original: Nidhinidhānamakkhāhi, atha pāsā pamokkhasī”ti.
analyzed: nidhi nidhānam akkhāhi atha pāsā pamokkhasi iti
translated: Explain the laying up of treasure, then you may go.”

original: Tattha iṇadānanti iṇassa dānaṃ. Nidhinidhānanti nidhino nidhānaṃ.
analyzed: tattha iṇa dānam ti iṇassa dānam nidhi nidhānam ti nidhinaḥ nidhānam
translated: Herein, debt and gift is the giving of the debt. Laying up of treasure is the laying up of the treasure.

original: Evaṃ brāhmaṇena puṭṭho suvarājā tassa byākaronto catasso gāthā abhāsi –
analyzed: evam brāhmaṇena puṭṭhaḥ suva rājā tassa byākaronto catassaḥ gāthāḥ abhāsi
translated: When asked by the brahmin in this way, King Suv araja uttered four stanzas in his reply:

original: “Ajātapakkhā taruṇā, puttakā mayha kosiya;
analyzed: a jāta pakkhāḥ taruṇāḥ puttakāḥ kosiya
translated: “My young ones, O Kosiya, have not yet fledged;

original: Te maṃ bhatā bharissanti, tasmā tesaṃ iṇaṃ dade.
analyzed: te mam bhatāḥ bharissanti tasmā tesam iṇam dade
translated: They will support me, their father, so I pay the debt to them.

original: “Mātā pitā ca me vuddhā, jiṇṇakā gatayobbanā;
analyzed: mātā pitā ca me vuddhā jiṇṇakā gata yobbanā
translated: “My mother and father are aged, worn out, past their youth;

original: Tesaṃ tuṇḍena hātūna, muñce pubbakataṃ iṇaṃ.
analyzed: tesam tuṇḍena muñce pubba katam iṇam
translated: With their beaks I feed them, I remit the debt I owe them from the past.

original: “Aññepi tattha sakuṇā, khīṇapakkhā sudubbalā;
analyzed: aññe pi tattha sakuṇā khīṇa pakkhā su dubbalā
translated: “Other birds there, with wings clipped, are very weak.

original: Tesaṃ puññatthiko dammi, taṃ nidhiṃ āhu paṇḍitā.
analyzed: tesam puññatthikaḥ dammi tam nidhim āhu paṇḍitā
translated: For their sake, I give this gift. The wise call this a treasure.

original: “Īdisaṃ me iṇadānaṃ, iṇamokkho ca īdiso;
analyzed: īdisam me iṇa dānam iṇa mokkhaḥ ca īdisaḥ
translated: “Such is my debt and gift, my debt-repayment is like this.

original: Nidhinidhānamakkhāmi, evaṃ jānāhi kosiyā”ti.
analyzed: nidhi nidhānam akkhāmi evam jānāhi kosiya ati
translated: I declare the treasure and the treasure-store. Know this, Kosiya.”

original: Tattha hātūnāti haritvā. Taṃ nidhinti taṃ puññakammaṃ paṇḍitā anugāmikanidhiṃ nāma kathenti. Nidhinidhānanti nidhino nidhānaṃ, “nidhānanidhi”ntipi pāṭho, ayamevattho.
analyzed: tattha hātūna ati haritvā tam nidhinti tam puñña kammam paṇḍitāḥ anugāmikanidhim nāma kathenti nidhi nidhānam ti nidhinaḥ nidhānam nidhāna nidhin tipi pāṭhaḥ ayam eva atthaḥ
translated: There, having taken away: having carried off. That treasure: that meritorious deed. The wise call it a treasure that follows one. Treasure-store: the store of the treasure. The reading “treasure-store” is also correct. This is the meaning.

original: Brāhmaṇo mahāsattassa dhammakathaṃ sutvā pasannacitto dve gāthā abhāsi.
analyzed: brāhmaṇaḥ mahāsattassa dhamma katham sutvā pasanna cittaḥ dve gāthāḥ abhāsi
translated: After hearing the Great Being’s Dhamma talk, the brahmin, with a mind full of confidence, spoke two verses:

original: “Bhaddako vatayaṃ pakkhī, dijo paramadhammiko;
analyzed: bhaddakaḥ vatayam pakkhī dijaḥ parama dhammiko
translated: “Excellent indeed is this bird, the divine one, the one with the highest Dhamma!

original: Ekaccesu manussesu, ayaṃ dhammo na vijjati.
analyzed: ekaccesu manussesu ayam dhammaḥ na vijjati
translated: In some humans, this Dhamma is not found.

original: “Bhuñja sāliṃ yathākāmaṃ, saha sabbehi ñātibhi;
analyzed: bhuñja sālim yathākāmam saha sabbehi ñātibhi
translated: “Eat the rice as you wish, together with all your relatives.

original: Punāpi suva passemu, piyaṃ me tava dassana”nti.
analyzed: puna api suva passemu piyam me tava dassananti
translated: Again, may we see the beautiful one. Your sight is dear to me.”

original: Tattha bhuñja sālinti ito paṭṭhāya nibbhayo hutvā bhuñjāti karīsasahassampi tasseva niyyādento evamāha. Passemūti attano ruciyā āgataṃ aññesupi divasesu taṃ passeyyāmāti.
analyzed: tattha bhuñja sālin ti itas paṭṭhāya nibbhayaḥ hutvā bhuñjāti karīsa sahassam pi tassa iva niyyādentaḥ evam āha passemu iti attanaḥ ruciyā āgatam aññesu pi divasesu tam passeyyāma ati
translated: “Eat your rice here,” said he, “and fear not.” And he gave him a thousand pieces of money. “I will see you again,” said he, “some other day, if it please you.”

original: Evaṃ brāhmaṇo mahāsattaṃ yācitvā piyaputtaṃ viya muducittena olokento pādato bandhanaṃ
analyzed: evam brāhmaṇaḥ mahāsattam yācitvā piya puttam viya mudu cittena olokentaḥ pādataḥ bandhanam
translated: And the Brahman, having thus entreated the Great Being, looked upon him with a tender heart, as upon a dear son. He loosed the bonds of his feet,

original: mocetvā satapākatelena pāde makkhetvā bhaddapīṭhe nisīdāpetvā kañcanataṭṭake madhulāje
analyzed: mocetvā sata pāka telena pāde makkhetvā bhaddapīṭhe nisīdāpetvā kañcana taṭṭake madhu lāje
translated: anointed his feet with oil of a hundred ingredients, seated him on a fair seat, and gave him honey and parched grain on a golden platter.

original: khādāpetvā sakkharodakaṃ pāyesi. Athassa suvarājā “appamatto hohi, brāhmaṇā”ti vatvā ovādaṃ dento āha –🔽“Bhuttañca pītañca tavassamamhi, ratī ca no kosiya te sakāse;
analyzed: khādāpetvā sakkhara udakam pāyesi athassa suvarājā appamattaḥ hohi brāhmaṇa iti vatvā ovādam dentaḥ āha  bhuttañca pītañca tavassamamhi ratī ca no kosiya te sakāse
translated: Then the king of the swans, saying, “Be careful, Brahman,” and giving him counsel, spoke the first stanza:

original: Nikkhittadaṇḍesu dadāhi dānaṃ, jiṇṇe ca mātāpitaro bharassū”ti.
analyzed: nikkhitta daṇḍesu dadāhi dānam jiṇṇe ca mātā pitaraḥ bharassu iti
translated: “In my house thou hast eaten and drunk, and thou hast found delight in my company, O Kosiya. Now that thou hast laid aside thy weapons, give alms, and support thy aged parents.”

original: Tattha tavassamamhīti tava nivesane. Ratīti abhirati.
analyzed: tattha tavassamamhi iti tava nivesane rati iti abhirati
translated: Here the king of the swans says to the Brahman, “In my house thou hast eaten and drunk.” “Delight” means pleasure.

original: Taṃ sutvā brāhmaṇo tuṭṭhamānaso udānaṃ udānento gāthamāha –
analyzed: tam sutvā brāhmaṇaḥ tuṭṭha mānasaḥ udānam udānentaḥ gātham āha
translated: When the Brahman heard this, he was delighted, and uttering a cry of joy, he spoke the second stanza:

original: “Lakkhī vata me udapādi ajja, yo addasāsiṃ pavaraṃ dijānaṃ;
analyzed: lakkhī vata me udapādi ajja yaḥ addasā asim pavaram dijānam
translated: “Today, indeed, a lucky omen has appeared to me, that I have seen the best of birds;

original: Suvassa sutvāna subhāsitāni, kāhāmi puññāni anappakānī”ti.
analyzed: suvassa sutvāna su bhāsitāni kāhāmi puññāni anappakāni iti
translated: Having heard the well-spoken words of Suvassa, I will make much merit.”

original: Tattha lakkhīti sirīpi puññampi paññāpi.🔽Mahāsatto brāhmaṇena attano dinnaṃ karīsasahassamattaṃ paṭikkhipitvā aṭṭhakarīsameva
analyzed: tattha lakkhī iti sirī pi puññam pi paññā api  mahāsattaḥ brāhmaṇena attanaḥ dinnam karīsa sahassa mattam paṭikkhipitvā aṭṭha karīsam eva
translated: Herein, lucky omen means glory, merit, and wisdom.🔽The Great Being, having refused the thousand cartloads of dung given by the brahmin,

original: gaṇhi. Brāhmaṇo thambhe nikhanitvā tassa khettaṃ niyyādetvā gandhamālādīhi pūjetvā
analyzed: brāhmaṇaḥ thambhe nikhanitvā tassa khettam niyyādetvā gandha mālā ādīhi pūjetvā
translated: took only eight cartloads. The brahmin, having buried them in a post hole, gave him the field, worshipped him with perfumes, garlands, and so on,

original: khamāpetvā “gaccha sāmi, assumukhe rodamāne mātāpitaro assāsehī”ti vatvā taṃ uyyojesi.
analyzed: khamāpetvā gaccha sāmi assu mukhe rodamāne mātā pitaraḥ assāsehi iti vatvā tam uyyojesi
translated: and after asking his forgiveness, said: “Go, sir, and comfort your parents who are weeping with tearful faces.” And he sent him away.

original: So tuṭṭhamānaso sālisīsaṃ ādāya gantvā mātāpitūnaṃ purato nikkhipitvā “ammatātā,
analyzed: saḥ tuṭṭha mānasaḥ sāli sīsam ādāya gantvā mātā pitūnam puratas nikkhipitvā ammatātā
translated: He, with a joyful mind, took the rice-paddy, went, and placed it in front of his parents, and said: “Mother, Father,

original: uṭṭhethā”ti āha. Te assumukhā rodamānā uṭṭhahiṃsu, tāvadeva suvagaṇā sannipatitvā
analyzed: uṭṭhetha iti āha te assu mukhāḥ rodamānāḥ uṭṭhahiṃsu tāvat eva suvagaṇā sannipatitvā
translated: get up.” They got up, weeping with tearful faces. At that very moment the Suvaga birds assembled

original: “kathaṃ muttosi, devā”ti pucchiṃsu. So tesaṃ sabbaṃ vitthārato kathesi. Kosiyopi
analyzed: katham muttaḥ asi deva iti pucchiṃsu so tesam sabbam vitthārato kathesi kosiyaḥ api
translated: and asked: “How were you freed, Devā?” He told them all in detail. Kosiya too,

original: suvarañño ovādaṃ sutvā tato paṭṭhāya dhammikasamaṇabrāhmaṇānaṃ mahādānaṃ paṭṭhapesi.
analyzed: suvaraññaḥ ovādam sutvā tatas paṭṭhāya dhammika samaṇa brāhmaṇānam mahādānam paṭṭhapesi
translated: After hearing the king’s advice, he thereafter gave great gifts to virtuous recluses and brahmans.

original: Tamatthaṃ pakāsento satthā osānagāthamāha –
analyzed: tam attham pakāsentaḥ satthā osāna gātham āha
translated: Illustrating this matter, the Master recited the following Stanza,

original: “So kosiyo attamano udaggo, annañca pānañcabhisaṅkharitvā;
analyzed: saḥ kosiyaḥ atta manaḥ udaggaḥ annañca pānañca abhisaṅkharitvā
translated: “The king, delighted and glad, prepared food and drink,

original: Annena pānena pasannacitto, santappayi samaṇabrāhmaṇe cā”ti.
analyzed: annena pānena pasanna cittaḥ santappayi samaṇa brāhmaṇe ca ati
translated: And with a serene heart, with food and drink, satisfied recluses and brahmans.”

original: Tattha santappayīti gahitagahitāni bhājanāni pūrento santappesīti.
analyzed: tattha santappayi iti gahita gahitāni bhājanāni pūrentaḥ santappesi iti
translated: “Satisfied” means “filled.”

original: Satthā imaṃ dhammadesanaṃ āharitvā “evaṃ bhikkhu mātāpitūnaṃ posanaṃ nāma paṇḍitānaṃ
analyzed: satthā imam dhamma desanam āharitvā evam bhikkhu mātā pitūnam posanam nāma paṇḍitānam
translated: After the Master had related this Dhamma discourse, he said, “Thus, monks, the care of mother and father is the duty of the wise.🔽The wise man should do as did the king of Suva.”

original: vaṃso”ti vatvā saccāni pakāsetvā jātakaṃ samodhānesi, saccapariyosāne so bhikkhu
analyzed: vaṃso ti vatvā saccāni pakāsetvā jātakam samodhānesi sacca pariyosāne so bhikkhu
translated: After the Master had thus made clear the Four Truths, the monk was established in the Fruit of Conversion.

original: sotāpattiphale patiṭṭhahi. Tadā suvagaṇā buddhaparisā ahesuṃ, mātāpitaro mahārājakulāni,
analyzed: sotāpatti phale tadā suvagaṇāḥ buddha parisāḥ ahesum mātā pitaraḥ mahā rāja kulāni
translated: At that time the assembly of the Buddha was the assembly of Suva, the parents were the great royal families,

original: khettapālo channo, brāhmaṇo ānando, suvarājā pana ahameva ahosinti.
analyzed: khettapālo channaḥ brāhmaṇaḥ ānandaḥ suva rājā pana aham eva
translated: the keeper of the field was Channa, the brahman was Ānanda, and I myself was the king of Suva.

original: Sālikedārajātakavaṇṇanā paṭhamā.
analyzed: sāli kedāra jātaka vaṇṇanā paṭhamā
translated: The commentary on the Sālikedārajātaka is concluded.

original: [485] 2. Candakinnarījātakavaṇṇanā
translated: 2.The Birth-Story of Candakinnara

original: Upanīyatidaṃ maññeti idaṃ satthā kapilavatthupuraṃ upanissāya nigrodhārāme viharanto🔽rājanivesane rāhulamātaraṃ ārabbha kathesi. Idaṃ pana jātakaṃ dūrenidānato paṭṭhāya
analyzed: maññeti idam satthā kapilavatthu puram upanissāya nigrodha ārāme viharantaḥ  rāja nivesane rāhula mātaram ārabbha kathesi idam pana jātakam dūrenidānato paṭṭhāya
translated: “He is led forth, I think,” etc.—This story the Master told, while sojourning at the Banyan Grove near Kapilavatthu, concerning the mother of Rahula.🔽But this Birth-Story should be told beginning with the Distant Introduction.

original: kathetabbaṃ. Sā panesā nidānakathā yāva laṭṭhivane uruvelakassapasīhanādā apaṇṇakajātake
analyzed: kathetabbam sā pana isā nidāna kathā yāva laṭṭhivane uruvela kassapa sīha nādāḥ apaṇṇaka jātake
translated: And this Introduction has been told in the Laṭṭhi-wood, in the Lion’s Roar of Uruvelakassapa, in the Apaṇṇaka Birth-Story,

original: kathitā, tato paraṃ yāva kapilavatthugamanā vessantarajātake āvi bhavissati. Satthā
analyzed: kathitā tato param yāva kapilavatthu gamanā vessantara jātake āvi bhavissati satthā
translated: and from there on to the going to Kapilavatthu will be told in the Vessantara Birth-Story. But the Master,

original: pana pitu nivesane nisīditvā antarabhattasamaye mahādhammapālajātakaṃ kathetvā katabhattakicco
analyzed: pana pitu nivesane nisīditvā antarabhatta samaye mahā dhammapāla jātakam kathetvā kata bhatta kicco
translated: sitting in his father’s house, told the Mahādhammapāla Birth-Story at the time of the midday meal, and after he had finished his meal,

original: “rāhulamātu nivesane nisīditvā tassā guṇaṃ vaṇṇento candakinnarījātakaṃ kathessāmī”ti
analyzed: rāhula mātu nivesane nisīditvā tassāḥ guṇam vaṇṇento canda kinnarī jātakam kathessāmi iti
translated: “I will sit in the house of the mother of Rahula, and praising her virtues, I will tell the Candakinnara Birth-Story.”

original: rājānaṃ pattaṃ gāhāpetvā dvīhi aggasāvakehi saddhiṃ rāhulamātu nivesanaṭṭhānaṃ pāyāsi.
analyzed: rājānam pattam gāhāpetvā dvīhi aggasāvakehi saddhim rāhula mātu nivesana ṭṭhānam pāyāsi
translated: So he had the king take his bowl, and with the two chief disciples went to the place where the mother of Rahula lived.

original: Tadā tassā sammukhā cattālīsasahassanāṭakitthiyo vasanti tāsu khattiyakaññānaṃyeva🔽navutiadhikasahassaṃ. Sā tathāgatassa āgamanaṃ ñatvā “sabbā kāsāvāneva nivāsentū”ti
analyzed: tadā tassā sammukhā cattālīsa sahassa nāṭaka itthiyaḥ vasanti tāsu khattiya kaññānaṃ yeva  navuti adhika sahassam sā tathāgatassa āgamanam ñatvā sabbā kāsāvānā eva nivāsentu uti
translated: At that time forty thousand dancing-girls lived in her palace. Of these, there were nine hundred and twenty who were princesses. When she heard that the Tathāgata was coming, she sent word to them, saying, “Let all of you put on the yellow garments.”

original: tāsaṃ ārocāpesi. Tā tathā kariṃsu. Satthā āgantvā paññattāsane nisīdi. Atha tā sabbāpi
analyzed: tāsam ārocāpesi tāḥ tathā kariṃsu satthā āgantvā paññatta āsane nisīdi atha tāḥ sabbā api
translated: They did so. The Teacher came and sat down on the seat prepared for him. Then all of them,

original: ekappahāreneva viraviṃsu, mahāparidevasaddo ahosi. Rāhulamātāpi paridevitvā sokaṃ🔽vinodetvā satthāraṃ vanditvā rājagatena bahumānena sagāravena nisīdi. Rājā tassā
analyzed: eka pahārena iva viraviṃsu mahā parideva saddaḥ ahosi rāhula mātā api paridevitvā sokam  vinodetvā satthāram vanditvā rāja gatena bahu mānena sa gāravena nisīdi rājā tassā
translated: with one accord, began to weep, and there arose a great lamentation. Rāhulamātā also wept, and after she had overcome her grief, she saluted the Teacher and sat down,

original: guṇakathaṃ ārabhi, “bhante, mama suṇhā ‘tumhehi kāsāvāni nivatthānī’ti sutvā kāsāvāneva🔽nivāsesi, ‘mālādīni pariccattānī’ti sutvā mālādīni pariccaji, ‘bhūmiyaṃ sayatī’ti
analyzed: guṇa katham ārabhi bhante mama suṇhā tumhehi kāsāvāni nivatthāni iti sutvā kāsāvān eva  nivāsesi mālā ādīni pariccattāni iti sutvā mālā ādīni bhūmiyam sayati iti
translated: honoring him with great respect and reverence. The king began to speak of her virtues, saying, “Reverend Sir, when my wife heard that you had put on yellow garments, she put on yellow garments also;

original: sutvā bhūmisayanāva jātā, tumhākaṃ pabbajitakāle vidhavā hutvā aññehi rājūhi pesitaṃ
analyzed: sutvā bhūmi sayanā ava jātā tumhākam pabbajita kāle vidhavā hutvā aññehi rājūhi pesitam
translated: when she heard that you had renounced garlands and the other ornaments, she renounced them also; when she heard that you slept on the ground, she slept on the ground also. When you retired from the world, she became a widow, and although other kings sent her messengers,

original: paṇṇākāraṃ na gaṇhi, evaṃ tumhesu asaṃhīracittā esā”ti nānappakārehi tassā guṇakathaṃ🔽kathesi. Satthā “anacchariyaṃ, mahārāja, yaṃ esā idāni mama pacchime attabhāve mayi🔽sasinehā asaṃhīracittā anaññaneyyā bhaveyya. Esā tiracchānayoniyaṃ nibbattāpi mayi
