analyzed: mitto ti natthi bhadde ti amhākam uppannam bhayam vā dukkham vā haraṇa samattham
translated: friend?” “No, my dear.” “Well, it is proper to get a friend or companion who can help you in the troubles and dangers that may arise; get some friend.” “With whom should I make friends?”

original: mittaṃ vā sahāyaṃ vā laddhuṃ vaṭṭati, mitte tāva gaṇhāhīti. “Kehi saddhiṃ mettiṃ
analyzed: mittam vā sahāyam vā laddhum vaṭṭati mitte tāva gaṇhāhi iti kehi saddhim mettim
translated: “With the lion.” “He is a beast of prey, and I am a little bird; how can I make friends with him?” “Make friends with him.”

original: karomi bhadde”ti? Pācīnapasse vasantena ukkusarājena, uttarapasse sīhena, jātassaramajjhe
analyzed: karomi bhadda iti pācīna passe vasantena ukkusa rājena uttara passe sīhena jātassara majjhe
translated: The king of the crows lived in the east, the lion in the north, and the tortoise in the middle of the lake.

original: kacchapena saddhiṃ mettiṃ karohīti. So tassā vacanaṃ sampaṭicchitvā tathā akāsi.
analyzed: kacchapena saddhim mettim karohi iti saḥ tassā vacanam sampaṭicchitvā tathā akāsi
translated: “Make friends with the tortoise.” He agreed to her suggestion and did as she asked.

original: Tadā te ubhopi saṃvāsaṃ kappetvā tasmiṃyeva sare ekasmiṃ dīpake kadambarukkho atthi
analyzed: tadā te ubho api saṃvāsam kappetvā tasmin yeva sare ekasmin dīpake kadamba rukkhaḥ atthi
translated: The two of them lived together in the lake, in a hollow in a kadamba tree on an island in the middle of the lake,

original: samantā udakena parikkhitto, tasmiṃ kulāvakaṃ katvā paṭivasiṃsu.
analyzed: samantā udakena parikkhittaḥ tasmin kulāvakam katvā paṭivasiṃsu
translated: surrounded on all sides by water.

original: Tesaṃ aparabhāge dve sakuṇapotakā jāyiṃsu. Tesaṃ pakkhesu asañjātesuyeva ekadivasaṃ
analyzed: tesam aparabhāge dve sakuṇa potakāḥ jāyiṃsu tesam pakkhesu eka divasam
translated: Later two young birds were born, and before their wings were fully grown

original: te jānapadā divasaṃ araññe caritvā kiñci alabhitvā “na sakkā tucchahatthena gharaṃ
analyzed: te jānapadāḥ divasam araññe caritvā kiñci a labhitvā na sakkā tuccha hatthena gharam
translated: one day the villagers, after wandering about in the forest all day, caught nothing, and so they said, “We cannot go home empty-handed.

original: gantuṃ, macche vā kacchape vā gaṇhissāmā”ti saraṃ otaritvā taṃ dīpakaṃ gantvā tassa
analyzed: gantum macche vā kacchape vā gaṇhissāma ati saram otaritvā tam dīpakam gantvā tassa
translated: We will catch some fish or turtles.” So they went down to the lake, and when they reached the island

original: kadambassa mūle nipajjitvā makasādīhi khajjamānā tesaṃ palāpanatthāya araṇiṃ manthetvā
analyzed: kadambassa mūle nipajjitvā makasa ādīhi khajjamānā tesam palāpana atthāya araṇim manthetvā
translated: they sat down at the foot of the kadamba tree and began to eat rice and curry. While they were thus engaged, they rubbed sticks together to make a fire in order to smoke out the birds and get them.

original: aggiṃ nibbattetvā dhūmaṃ kariṃsu. Dhumo uggantvā sakuṇe pahari, sakuṇapotakā viraviṃsu.
analyzed: aggim nibbattetvā dhūmam kariṃsu dhumaḥ uggantvā sakuṇe sakuṇa potakāḥ viraviṃsu
translated: and made a fire, and produced smoke. The smoke rose up and smote the birds, and the young birds cried out.

original: Jānapadā taṃ sutvā “ambho, sakuṇapotakānaṃ sūyati saddo, uṭṭhetha ukkā bandhatha,
analyzed: jānapadā tam sutvā ambho sakuṇa potakānam sūyati saddaḥ uṭṭhetha ukkā bandhatha
translated: The people of the country heard the sound, and said, “Ah! the young birds are crying out. Rise up, bind torches,

original: chātā sayituṃ na sakkoma, sakuṇamaṃsaṃ khāditvāva sayissāmā”ti vatvā aggiṃ jāletvā
analyzed: chātā sayitum na sakkoma sakuṇa maṃsam khāditvā ava sayissāma iti vatvā aggim jāletvā
translated: we cannot sleep on an empty stomach; we will eat the flesh of the birds and then go to sleep.” So saying, they kindled a fire

original: ukkā bandhiṃsu. Sakuṇikā tesaṃ saddaṃ sutvā “ime amhākaṃ potake khāditukāmā, mayaṃ
analyzed: ukkā bandhiṃsu sakuṇikā tesam saddam sutvā ime amhākam potake khāditu kāmāḥ mayam
translated: and bound torches. The mother-bird, hearing their voices, said, “They are desirous of eating our young.

original: evarūpassa bhayassa haraṇatthāya mitte gaṇhimha, sāmikaṃ ukkusarājassa santikaṃ pesessāmī”ti
analyzed: evarūpassa bhayassa haraṇa tthāya mitte gaṇhimha sāmikam ukkusa rājassa santikam pesessāmi iti
translated: We have taken a friend to ourselves for the purpose of removing such a danger. I will send my husband to the king of the owls.”

original: cintetvā “gaccha, sāmi, puttānaṃ no uppannabhayaṃ ukkusarājassa ārocehī”ti vatvā
analyzed: cintetvā gaccha sāmi puttānam naḥ uppanna bhayam ukkusa rājassa ārocehi iti vatvā
translated: So thinking, she said, “Go, husband, and tell the king of the owls of the danger that has arisen to our young.”

original: paṭhamaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: paṭhamam gātham āha
translated: And she uttered the first stanza:

original: “Ukkā cilācā bandhanti dīpe, pajā mamaṃ khādituṃ patthayanti;
analyzed: ukkā cilācā bandhanti dīpe pajāḥ mamam khāditum patthayanti
translated: The people bind torches, thinking to eat me, the bird;

original: Mittaṃ sahāyañca vadehi senaka, ācikkha ñātibyasanaṃ dijāna”nti.
analyzed: mittam sahāyam ca vadehi senakaḥ ācikkha ñāti byasanam dijānanti
translated: Tell your friend and companion, Senaka, and tell him of the destruction of the birds.

original: Tattha cilācāti jānapadā. Dīpeti dīpakamhi. Pajā mamanti mama puttake. Senakāti senakasakuṇaṃ
analyzed: tattha cilācā ati jānapadāḥ dīpeti dīpakamhi pajāḥ mamanti mama puttake senakā ati senaka sakuṇam
translated: “Cilaca” means the people of the provinces. “Dīpeti” means he shines. “Pajā mam” means my children. “Senaka” means the bird Senaka.

original: nāmenālapati. Ñātibyasananti puttānaṃ byasanaṃ. Dijānanti amhākaṃ ñātīnaṃ dijānaṃ
analyzed: nāmena ālapati ñāti byasanam ti puttānam byasanam dijānanti amhākam ñātīnam dijānam
translated: He addresses him by name. “Ñātibyasan” means the misfortune of his children. “Dijān” means the birds of our relatives.

original: idaṃ byasanaṃ ukkusarājassa santikaṃ gantvā ācikkhāhīti vadati.
analyzed: idam byasanam ukkusa rājassa santikam gantvā ācikkhāhi iti vadati
translated: He says: “Go to King Ukkusa and tell him of this misfortune.”

original: So vegena tassa vasanaṭṭhānaṃ gantvā vassitvā attano āgatabhāvaṃ jānāpetvā katokāso upasaṅkamitvā vanditvā “kiṃkāraṇā āgatosī”ti puṭṭho āgatakāraṇaṃ dassento dutiyaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: so vegena tassa vasana ṭhānam gantvā vassitvā attanaḥ āgata bhāvam jānāpetvā kata ukāsaḥ upasaṅkamitvā vanditvā kiṃkāraṇā āgataḥ asi iti puṭṭhaḥ āgata kāraṇam dassentaḥ dutiyam gātham āha
translated: He went quickly to his dwelling place, rained down, and having made known his arrival, he approached, paid homage, and asked: “Why have you come?” Being asked, he showed the reason for his coming, and spoke the second verse:

original: “Dijo dijānaṃ pavarosi pakkhima, ukkusarāja saraṇaṃ taṃ upema;
analyzed: dijaḥ dijānam pavaraḥ asi pakkhimaḥ ukkusa rāja saraṇam tam upema
translated: “Bird, you are the best of birds, O bird, we go for refuge to you, O King Ukkusa.

original: Pajā mamaṃ khādituṃ patthayanti, luddā cilācā bhava me sukhāyā”ti.
analyzed: pajāḥ khāditum patthayanti luddā cilācā bhava me sukhāya iti
translated: The people desire to eat me, the hunters, the people of the provinces, be my happiness.”

original: Tattha dijoti tvaṃ dijo ceva dijānaṃ pavaro ca.
analyzed: tattha dija uti tvam ca iva dijānam pavaro ca
translated: Herein, “bird” means you are a bird and the best of birds.

original: Ukkusarājā “senaka mā bhāyī”ti taṃ assāsetvā tatiyaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: ukkusa rājā senaka mā bhāyi iti tam assāsetvā tatiyam gātham āha
translated: “Senaka, do not be afraid,” he comforted him, and spoke the third verse:

original: “Mittaṃ sahāyañca karonti paṇḍitā, kāle akāle sukhamesamānā;
analyzed: mittam sahāyam ca karonti paṇḍitā kāle akāle sukham esamānā
translated: “The wise make friends and comrades, seeking their welfare in season and out of season.

original: Karomi te senaka etamatthaṃ, ariyo hi ariyassa karoti kicca”nti.
analyzed: karomi te senaka etam attham ariyaḥ hi ariyassa karoti kiccanti
translated: I do this for you, Senaka, for the noble do what is to be done for the noble.”

original: Tattha kāle akāleti divā ca rattiñca. Ariyoti idha ācāraariyo adhippeto. Ācārasampanno hi ācārasampannassa kiccaṃ karoteva, kimettha karaṇīyanti vadati.
analyzed: tattha kāle akāle ti divā ca rattiñca ariyaḥ ti idha ācāra ariyaḥ adhippeto ācāra sampannaḥ hi ācāra sampannassa kiccam karotā iva kim ettha karaṇīyanti vadati
translated: Herein, in season and out of season means by day and by night. The noble one is the one who is noble in conduct. For one who is endowed with good conduct does what is to be done for one who is endowed with good conduct. What more is there to do?

original: Atha naṃ pucchi “kiṃ, samma, rukkhaṃ abhiruḷhā cilācā”ti? Na tāva abhiruḷhā, ukkāyeva🔽bandhantīti. Tena hi tvaṃ sīghaṃ gantvā mama sahāyikaṃ assāsetvā mamāgamanabhāvaṃ
analyzed: atha nam pucchi kim samma rukkham abhiruḷhā na abhiruḷhā ukkāya iva  bandhanti iti tena hi tvam sīgham gantvā mama sahāyikam assāsetvā mama āgamana bhāvam
translated: Then he asked, “What are you doing, my dear, up in the tree?” “I am not up yet, but I am binding the creeper.”

original: ācikkhāhīti. So tathā akāsi. Ukkusarājāpi gantvā kadambassa avidūre cilācānaṃ abhiruhanaṃ
analyzed: ācikkhāhi iti saḥ tathā akāsi ukkusa rājā api gantvā kadambassa avidūre cilācānam abhiruhanaṃ
translated: “Well then, you go quickly and comfort my friend and tell her that I am coming.” He did so. King Ukkamsa went and stood watching for the creeper-gatherer not far from the kadamb tree.

original: olokento ekasmiṃ rukkhagge nisīditvā ekassa cilācassa abhiruhanakāle tasmiṃ kulāvakassa
analyzed: olokentaḥ ekasmin rukkha agge nisīditvā ekassa cilācassa abhiruhana kāle tasmin kulāvakassa
translated: Sitting in a tree-top, he saw one of the women climb up to a creeper. At the moment she climbed up to the hollow of the tree,🔽he seized her by the hair.

original: avidūraṃ abhiruḷhe sare nimujjitvā pakkhehi ca mukhena ca udakaṃ āharitvā ukkāya
analyzed: avidūram abhiruḷhe sare nimujjitvā pakkhehi ca mukhena ca udakam āharitvā ukkāya
translated: and after climbing up not far, he plunged in, and after bringing up water with his wings and his beak, he threw it up on the fire,

original: upari āsiñci, sā nibbāyi. Cilācā “imañca senakasakuṇapotake cassa khādissāmī”ti otaritvā
analyzed: upari āsiñci sā nibbāyi cilācā imañca senaka sakuṇa potake ca ssa khādissāmi iti otaritvā
translated: The crow, after flying up to a tree not far away, plunged into the water, brought water in his beak and on his claws, and sprinkled the fire. It was extinguished. The owls, thinking, “We will eat the crow’s young ones,” descended.

original: puna ukkaṃ jālāpetvā abhiruhiṃsu. Puna so ukkaṃ vijjhāpesi. Etenupāyena baddhaṃ baddhaṃ
analyzed: punar ukkam jālāpetvā abhiruhiṃsu punar saḥ ukkam vijjhāpesi etena upāyena baddham baddham
translated: They again kindled the fire and flew up. The crow again extinguished the fire. By this means he extinguished the fire every time it was kindled.

original: vijjhāpentassevassa aḍḍharatto jāto. So ativiya kilami, heṭṭhāudare kilomakaṃ tanutaṃ
analyzed: vijjhāpentassa ivassa aḍḍha rattaḥ jāto saḥ ativiya heṭṭhā udare kilomakam
translated: Half the night had passed while he was thus extinguishing the fire. He became very tired. A thin film of fat appeared on his lower belly.

original: gataṃ, akkhīni rattāni jātāni. Taṃ disvā sakuṇī sāmikaṃ āha – “sāmi, ativiya kilanto🔽ukkusarājā, etassa thokaṃ vissamanatthāya gantvā kacchaparājassa kathehī”ti. So tassā
analyzed: gatam akkhīni rattāni jātāni tam disvā sakuṇī sāmikam āha sāmi kilanto  ukkusa rājā etassa thokam vissamana tthāya gantvā kacchapa rājassa kathehi iti saḥ tassā
translated: His eyes became red. Seeing this, the hen-crow said to her husband, “Husband, you are very tired.

original: vacanaṃ sutvā ukkusaṃ upasaṅkamitvā gāthāya ajjhabhāsi –
analyzed: vacanam sutvā ukkusam upasaṅkamitvā gāthāya ajjhabhāsi
translated: For the sake of his rest, go and tell the king of the turtles.” He, having heard her words, approached the crow and spoke a verse:

original: “Yaṃ hoti kiccaṃ anukampakena, ariyassa ariyena kataṃ tayīdaṃ;
analyzed: yam hoti kiccam anukampakena ariyassa ariyena katam tayi idam
translated: “What should be done by one who is compassionate, this has been done by you, noble one, to a noble one.

original: Attānurakkhī bhava mā aḍayhi, lacchāma putte tayi jīvamāne”ti.
analyzed: attā anurakkhī bhava mā aḍayhi lacchāma putte tayi jīvamāne iti
translated: Protect yourself, be not angry. We will have our young ones if you live.”

original: Tattha tayīdanti tayā idaṃ, ayameva vā pāṭho.
analyzed: tattha tayā idam ayam eva vā pāṭhaḥ
translated: Herein, tayīdanti tayā idaṃ, or the reading may be taken as tayeva.

original: So tassa vacanaṃ sutvā sīhanādaṃ nadanto pañcamaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: saḥ tassa vacanam sutvā sīha nādam nadantaḥ pañcamam gātham āha
translated: Having heard his words, the king roared a lion’s roar and spoke the fifth stanza:

original: “Taveva rakkhāvaraṇaṃ karonto, sarīrabhedāpi na santasāmi;
analyzed: tava iva rakkhā āvaraṇam karonto sarīra bhedā api na santasāmi
translated: “I would not be afraid of death itself, but would protect and guard you;

original: Karonti heke sakhinaṃ sakhāro, pāṇaṃ cajantā satamesa dhammo”ti.
analyzed: karonti ha ike sakhinam sakhāraḥ pāṇam cajantā satamā isa dhammā iti
translated: Some friends are friends to their friends, and this is the duty of the good.”

original: Chaṭṭhaṃ pana satthā abhisambuddho hutvā tassa guṇaṃ vaṇṇento āha –
analyzed: chaṭṭham pana satthā abhisambuddhaḥ hutvā tassa guṇam vaṇṇentaḥ āha
translated: But the Teacher, after attaining Buddhahood, spoke the sixth stanza, extolling his virtue:

original: “Sudukkaraṃ kammamakāsi, aṇḍajāyaṃ vihaṅgamo;
analyzed: su dukkaram kammam akāsi aṇḍa jāyam vihaṅgamaḥ
translated: “A difficult task did the bird perform for the egg-born;

original: Atthāya kuraro putte, aḍḍharatte anāgate”ti.
analyzed: atthāya kuraro putte aḍḍha ratte anāgata iti
translated: For the sake of the young the Kurara bird exerted himself at midnight.”

original: Tattha kuraroti ukkusarājā. Putteti senakassa putte rakkhanto tesaṃ atthāya aḍḍharatte anāgate yāva diyaḍḍhayāmā vāyāmaṃ karonto dukkaraṃ akāsi.
analyzed: tattha kurarā iti ukkusa rājā putta iti senakassa putte rakkhanto tesam atthāya aḍḍharatte anāgate yāva diyaḍḍha yāmā vāyāmam karontaḥ dukkaram akāsi
translated: Herein, Kurara is the name of the king of the crows. For the sake of the young means that, protecting the young of Senaka, he exerted himself for their sake at midnight, that is, for two and a half watches of the night.

original: Senopi ukkusaṃ “thokaṃ vissamāhi, sammā”ti vatvā kacchapassa santikaṃ gantvā taṃ
analyzed: senaḥ api ukkusam thokam sammā iti vatvā kacchapassa santikam gantvā tam
translated: Senaka said to the crow, “Rest a little, friend,” and went to the side of the tortoise and said,

original: uṭṭhāpetvā “kiṃ, samma, āgatosī”ti vutto “evarūpaṃ nāma bhayaṃ uppannaṃ, ukkusarājā
analyzed: uṭṭhāpetvā kim samma āgataḥ asi iti vuttaḥ evarūpam nāma bhayam uppannam ukkusa rājā
translated: and asked him, “What is it, my dear?” He replied, “Such and such a danger has arisen. King Ukkasa,

original: paṭhamayāmato paṭṭhāya vāyamanto kilami, tenamhi tava santikaṃ āgato”ti vatvā sattamaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: paṭhama yāmataḥ paṭṭhāya vāyamanto kilami tenamhi tava santikam āgataḥ iti vatvā sattamam gātham āha
translated: from the first watch of the night, is striving and toiling. Therefore I have come to you.” And he uttered the seventh stanza:

original: “Cutāpi heke khalitā sakammunā, mittānukampāya patiṭṭhahanti;
analyzed: cutā api ha ike khalitā sa kammunā mitta anukampāya patiṭṭhahanti
translated: Some, though fallen, through their own fault, and dead, yet for the sake of friends stand fast.

original: Puttā mamaṭṭā gatimāgatosmi, atthaṃ caretho mama vāricarā”ti.🔽Tassattho – sāmi, ekacce hi yasato vā dhanato vā cutāpi sakammunā khalitāpi mittānaṃ🔽anukampāya patiṭṭhahanti, mama ca puttā aṭṭā āturā, tenāhaṃ taṃ gatiṃ paṭisaraṇaṃ
analyzed: puttā gatim āgataḥ asmi attham carethaḥ mama  tassa atthaḥ sāmi ekacce hi yasataḥ vā dhanataḥ vā cutā api sa kammunā khalitā api mittānam  anukampāya patiṭṭhahanti mama ca puttāḥ aṭṭāḥ āturā tena aham tam gatim paṭisaraṇam
translated: For my sake, my son, I have come to you. Do you fulfil my wish, my friend.

original: katvā āgatosmi, puttānaṃ jīvitadānaṃ dadanto atthaṃ me carāhi vāricarāti.
analyzed: katvā āgataḥ asmi puttānam jīvita dānam dadantaḥ attham me carāhi vāri carāti
translated: The meaning is: Master, some, though fallen through their own fault, and dead, yet for the sake of friends stand fast. And my sons are sick, and therefore I have come to you, making you my refuge. Do you fulfil my wish, giving my sons the gift of life.

original: Taṃ sutvā kacchapo itaraṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: tam sutvā kacchapaḥ itaram gātham āha
translated: Hearing this, the tortoise uttered the next stanza:

original: “Dhanena dhaññena ca attanā ca, mittaṃ sahāyañca karonti paṇḍitā;
analyzed: dhanena dhaññena ca attanā ca mittam sahāyañca karonti paṇḍitā
translated: The wise make friends and comrades for wealth, for corn, and for themselves.

original: Karomi te senaka etamatthaṃ, ariyo hi ariyassa karoti kicca”nti.
analyzed: karomi te senaka etam attham ariyaḥ hi ariyassa karoti kiccanti
translated: I will do this for you, Senaka, for the noble do what is right for the noble.”

original: Athassa putto avidūre nipanno pitu vacanaṃ sutvā “mā me pitā kilamatu, ahaṃ pitu kiccaṃ karissāmī”ti cintetvā navamaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: athassa puttaḥ avidūre nipannaḥ pitu vacanam sutvā mā me pitā kilamatu aham pitu kiccam karissāmi iti cintetvā navamam gātham āha
translated: Then his son, lying not far away, heard his father’s words and thought, “Let not my father die. I will do my father’s bidding.” So he spoke the ninth verse:

original: “Appossukko tāta tuvaṃ nisīda, putto pitu carati atthacariyaṃ;
analyzed: appa ussukkaḥ tāta tuvam nisīda putto carati attha cariyam
translated: “Father, sit down, be not anxious; son will do what is right for father.

original: Ahaṃ carissāmi tavetamatthaṃ, senassa putte paritāyamāno”ti.
analyzed: aham carissāmi tava etam attham senassa putte paritāyamāno ti
translated: I will do this for you, father, protecting the sons of Senaka.”

original: Atha naṃ pitā gāthāya ajjhabhāsi –
analyzed: atha nam pitā gāthāya ajjhabhāsi
translated: Then his father spoke to him in verse:

original: “Addhā hi tāta satamesa dhammo, putto pitu yaṃ care atthacariyaṃ;
analyzed: addhā hi tāta satama isa dhammo putto yam care attha cariyam
translated: “Surely, son, this is the way of the good, that son should do what is right for father.

original: Appeva maṃ disvāna pavaḍḍhakāyaṃ, senassa puttā na viheṭhayeyyu”nti.
analyzed: appā iva mam disvāna pavaḍḍha kāyam senassa puttāḥ na viheṭhayeyyunti
translated: Perhaps, seeing me grown old, the sons of Senaka will not molest me.”

original: Tattha satamesa dhammoti paṇḍitānaṃ esa dhammo. Puttāti senassa putte cilācā na heṭhayeyyunti.
analyzed: tattha satamā esa dhammoti paṇḍitānam esa dhammo putta ati senassa putte cilācāḥ na heṭhayeyyunti
translated: Herein, this is the way of the good is the way of the wise. For the sons of Senaka will not molest me means the sons of Senaka will not harass me.

translated: One day, as he was going to the garden to amuse himself, he saw a beautiful courtesan, and his heart became attached to her.

original: tāya saddhiṃ saṃvāsaṃ kappesi. Sā taṃ paṭicca gabbhaṃ paṭilabhi. Gabbhassa patiṭṭhitabhāvaṃ
analyzed: tāya saddhim saṃvāsam kappesi sā tam paṭicca gabbham paṭilabhi gabbhassa patiṭṭhita bhāvam
translated: He had intercourse with her, and she conceived a child.

original: ñatvā taṃ āha – “sāmi, gabbho me patiṭṭhito, jātakāle nāmaṃ karontī assa kiṃ nāmaṃ
analyzed: ñatvā tam āha sāmi gabbhaḥ me patiṭṭhitaḥ jāta kāle nāmam karontī assa kim nāmam
translated: and when she knew, she said, “Husband, I have conceived, and when the child is born, what name should it be given?”🔽

original: karomī”ti? So “vaṇṇadāsiyā kucchimhi nibbattattā na sakkā kulanāmaṃ kātu”nti cintetvā
analyzed: karomi iti saḥ vaṇṇa dāsiyā kucchimhi nibbatta ttā na sakkā kula nāmam kātunti cintetvā
translated: “My lord,” she said, “I am with child. When the child is born, what name shall I give it?” He thought to himself, “Since this child is born of a slave woman, it is not proper to give it the family name.”

original: “bhadde, ayaṃ vātaghātarukkho uddālo nāma, idha paṭiladdhattā ‘uddālako’tissa nāmaṃ🔽kareyyāsī”ti vatvā aṅgulimuddikaṃ adāsi. “Sace dhītā hoti, imāya naṃ poseyyāsi, sace
analyzed: bhadde ayam vātaghāta rukkho uddālaḥ nāma idha uddālakotissa nāmaṃ  kareyyāsi iti vatvā aṅguli muddikam adāsi sace dhītā hoti imāya nam poseyyāsi sace
translated: Therefore he said to her, “My dear, this tree which is called the Vātaghāta is a tall tree. Since I obtained you here, you may give the child the name Udālaka.”

original: putto, atha naṃ vayappattaṃ mayhaṃ dasseyyāsī”ti āha. Sā aparabhāge puttaṃ vijāyitvā
analyzed: puttaḥ atha nam vaya pattam mayham dasseyyāsi iti āha sā aparabhāge puttam
translated: And he gave her a ring. “If it is a daughter,” said he, “rear it with this ring. If it is a son, when it is grown up, show it to me.”

original: “uddālako”tissa nāmaṃ akāsi.🔽So vayappatto mātaraṃ pucchi – “amma, ko me pitā”ti? “Purohito tātā”ti. “Yadi evaṃ
analyzed: uddālakotissa nāmaṃ akāsi  saḥ vaya pattaḥ mātaram pucchi amma kaḥ me pitā ati purohitaḥ tāta ati yadi evam
translated: In due time she gave birth to a son and gave him the name Udālaka.

original: vede uggaṇhissāmī”ti mātu hatthato muddikañca ācariyabhāgañca gahetvā takkasilaṃ
analyzed: vede uggaṇhissāmi iti mātu hatthataḥ muddikam ca ācariya bhāgam ca gahetvā takkasilam
translated: When he was grown up, he asked his mother, “Mother, who is my father?” “Your father, my son, was the chaplain.” “If that is the case, I will learn the Vedas.” So he took the ring and the fee for the teacher and went to Takkasilā.

original: gantvā disāpāmokkhācariyassa santike sippaṃ uggaṇhanto ekaṃ tāpasagaṇaṃ disvā “imesaṃ
analyzed: gantvā disāpāmokkha ācariyassa santike sippam uggaṇhantaḥ ekam tāpasa gaṇam disvā imesam
translated: He went to the teacher who was chief in the ten directions, and while learning the craft, he saw a group of ascetics.

original: santike varasippaṃ bhavissati, taṃ uggaṇhissāmī”ti sippalobhena pabbajitvā tesaṃ
analyzed: santike vara sippam bhavissati tam uggaṇhissāmi iti sippa lobhena pabbajitvā tesam
translated: He thought, “There is a superior craft among them. I will learn it.” Out of greed for the craft, he went forth in their presence.

original: vattapaṭivattaṃ katvā “ācariyā maṃ tumhākaṃ jānanasippaṃ sikkhāpethā”ti āha. Te attano🔽attano jānananiyāmeneva taṃ sikkhāpesuṃ. Pañcannaṃ tāpasasatānaṃ ekopi tena atirekapañño
analyzed: vatta paṭivattam katvā ācariyāḥ mam tumhākam jānana sippam sikkhāpetha ati āha te attanaḥ  attanaḥ jānana niyāmena iva tam sikkhāpesum pañcannam tāpasa satānam ekaḥ api tena atireka pañño
translated: He did the duties of a pupil and said, “Teachers, teach me the craft you know.” They taught him according to their own

original: nāhosi, sveva tesaṃ paññāya aggo. Athassa te sannipatitvā ācariyaṭṭhānaṃ adaṃsu.
analyzed: na ahosi su eva tesam paññāya aggaḥ athassa te sannipatitvā ācariya ṭṭhānam adaṃsu
translated: knowledge. Not a single one of the five hundred ascetics was more knowledgeable than he. He became their chief in wisdom. Then they gathered together and gave him the position of teacher.

original: Atha ne so āha – “mārisā, tumhe niccaṃ vanamūlaphalāhārā araññeva vasatha, manussapathaṃ
analyzed: atha ne saḥ āha mārisā tumhe niccam vana mūla phala āhārāḥ araññā iva vasatha manussa patham
translated: Then he said to them, “Friends, you always live in the forest, eating forest roots and fruits. Why don’t you go on the human path?”

original: kasmā na gacchathā”ti? “Mārisa, manussā nāma mahādānaṃ datvā anumodanaṃ kārāpenti,
analyzed: kasmā na gacchatha ati mārisa manussāḥ nāma mahā dānam da tvā anumodanam kārāpenti
translated: “Friend, people give great gifts and have the dedication done.

original: dhammiṃ kathaṃ bhaṇāpenti, pañhaṃ pucchanti, mayaṃ tena bhayena tattha na gacchāmā”ti.
analyzed: dhammim katham pañham pucchanti mayam tena bhayena tattha na gacchāma ati
translated: They have a Dhamma talk given. They ask questions. We don’t go there out of fear of that.”

original: “Mārisā, sacepi cakkavattirājā bhavissati, manaṃ gahetvā kathanaṃ nāma mayhaṃ bhāro,
analyzed: mārisā sace pi cakkavatti rājā bhavissati manam gahetvā kathanam nāma mayham bhāraḥ
translated: “Good sirs, if he should become a universal monarch, it is my duty to speak to him with due respect.

original: tumhe mā bhāyathā”ti vatvā tehi saddhiṃ cārikaṃ caramāno anupubbena bārāṇasiṃ patvā🔽rājuyyāne vasitvā punadivase sabbehi saddhiṃ dvāragāme bhikkhāya cari, manussā mahādānaṃ
analyzed: tumhe mā bhāyatha ati vatvā tehi saddhim cārikam caramānaḥ anupubbena bārāṇasim patvā  rājuyyāne vasitvā puna divase sabbehi saddhim dvāragāme bhikkhāya cari manussāḥ mahādānam
translated: Do not be afraid.” And so he went on his way with them, and in due course he reached Bārāṇasī.🔽He lodged in the royal park, and on the following day he went with them all to beg for alms in the village of the gate. The people gave them a great deal of alms.

original: adaṃsu. Tāpasā punadivase nagaraṃ pavisiṃsu manussā mahādānaṃ adaṃsu. Uddālakatāpaso
analyzed: adaṃsu tāpasā puna divase nagaram pavisiṃsu manussāḥ mahā dānam adaṃsu uddālaka tāpaso
translated: The ascetics entered the city on the following day, and the people gave them a great deal of alms. The ascetic Uddaka

original: dānānumodanaṃ karoti, maṅgalaṃ vadati, pañhaṃ vissajjeti, manussā pasīditvā bahupaccaye
analyzed: dāna anumodanam karoti maṅgalam vadati pañham vissajjeti manussā pasīditvā bahu paccaye
translated: recited the benediction, told his fortune, and answered questions. The people were pleased and gave him many requisites.

original: adaṃsu. Sakalanagaraṃ “paṇḍito gaṇasatthā dhammikatāpaso āgato”ti saṅkhubhi, taṃ raññopi kathayiṃsu.
analyzed: sakala nagaram paṇḍitaḥ gaṇasatthā dhammika tāpasaḥ āgataḥ iti saṅkhubhi tam raññaḥ api kathayiṃsu
translated: The whole city was in an uproar, “The wise teacher of a multitude, the ascetic who is righteous, has come.” They told the king.

original: Rājā “kuhiṃ vasatī”ti pucchitvā “uyyāne”ti sutvā “sādhu ajja tesaṃ dassanāya gamissāmī”ti
analyzed: rājā kuhim vasati iti pucchitvā uyyāna iti sutvā sādhu ajja tesam dassanāya gamissāmi iti
translated: The king asked, “Where does he live?” and when he heard that he lived in the park, he said, “Very well, I will go to see him today.”

original: āha. Eko puriso gantvā “rājā kira vo passituṃ āgacchissatī”ti uddālakassa kathesi.
analyzed: āha ekaḥ purisaḥ gantvā rājā kira vaḥ passitum āgacchissati iti uddālakassa kathesi
translated: He said, “One man went and told Uddalaka that the king was coming to see them.

original: Sopi isigaṇaṃ āmantetvā “mārisā, rājā kira āgamissati, issare nāma ekadivasaṃ ārādhetvā
analyzed: saḥ api isi gaṇam āmantetvā mārisā rājā kira āgamissati issare nāma eka divasam ārādhetvā
translated: Uddalaka summoned the group of seers and said, ‘Good sirs, the king is coming. One who is great can be satisfied for a day,

original: yāvajīvaṃ alaṃ hotī”ti. “Kiṃ pana kātabbaṃ ācariyā”ti? So evamāha – “tumhesu ekacce
analyzed: yāvajīvam alam hoti iti kim pana kātabbam ācariya ati saḥ evam āha tumhesu ekacce
translated: but it is enough for a lifetime.’ They said, ‘What should be done, teacher?’ He said, ‘Some of you

original: vaggulivataṃ carantu, ekacce ukkuṭikappadhānamanuyuñjantu, ekacce kaṇṭakāpassayikā🔽bhavantu, ekacce pañcātapaṃ tapantu, ekacce udakorohanakammaṃ karontu, ekacce tattha
analyzed: vaggulivatam carantu ekacce ukkuṭika ppadhānam anuyuñjantu ekacce kaṇṭakāpassayikā  bhavantu ekacce pañca ātapam tapantu ekacce udakorohana kammam karontu ekacce tattha
translated: should practice the vagguli observance, some should practice the ukkuṭik observance, some should practice the kaṇṭakāpassaya observance,

original: tattha mante sajjhāyantū”ti. Te tathā kariṃsu. Sayaṃ pana aṭṭha vā dasa vā paṇḍitavādino🔽gahetvā manorame ādhārake ramaṇīyaṃ potthakaṃ ṭhapetvā antevāsikaparivuto supaññatte
analyzed: tattha mante sajjhāyantu iti te tathā kariṃsu sayam pana aṭṭha vā dasa vā paṇḍita vādinaḥ  gahetvā manorame ādhārake ramaṇīyam potthakam ṭhapetvā antevāsika parivutaḥ su paññatte
translated: some should practice the pañcātapa observance, some should practice the udakorohana observance, and some should recite the mantras here and there.’ They did as he said. He himself, taking eight or ten of the most eloquent,🔽placed a beautiful book on a lovely stand, and sat down on a well-prepared seat surrounded by his pupils. At that moment the king, taking the chaplain with him,

original: sāpassaye āsane nisīdi. Tasmiṃ khaṇe rājā purohitaṃ ādāya mahantena parivārena uyyānaṃ
analyzed: sā apassaye āsane nisīdi tasmin khaṇe rājā purohitam ādāya mahantena parivārena uyyānam
translated: came to the park with a great retinue.

original: gantvā te micchātapaṃ carante disvā “apāyabhayamhā muttā”ti pasīditvā uddālakassa
analyzed: gantvā te micchātapam carante disvā apāya bhayamhā muttā ati pasīditvā uddālakassa
translated: and seeing them practising austerities in the wrong way, they were pleased, thinking: “We are freed from the fear of the lower realms.” They went to Uddalaka,

original: santikaṃ gantvā paṭisanthāraṃ katvā ekamantaṃ nisinno tuṭṭhamānaso purohitena saddhiṃ
analyzed: santikam gantvā paṭisanthāram katvā ekamantam nisinnaḥ tuṭṭha mānasaḥ purohitena saddhim
translated: and after paying their respects, they sat down to one side. With happy minds they conversed with the chief priest.

original: sallapanto paṭhamaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: paṭhamam gātham āha
translated: When they were conversing, he spoke this first verse:

original: “Kharājinā jaṭilā paṅkadantā, dummakkharūpā ye mantaṃ jappanti;
analyzed: khara ajināḥ jaṭilāḥ paṅka dantāḥ dummakkha rūpāḥ ye mantam jappanti
translated: “Rough-skinned, with matted hair, and teeth covered with plaque, with ugly forms, they chant the mantras.

original: Kaccinnu te mānusake payoge, idaṃ vidū parimuttā apāyā”ti.
analyzed: kaccit nu te mānusake payoge idam vidū parimuttā apāyāti
translated: Are they, by human effort, freed from the lower realms, knowing this?”

original: Tattha kharājināti sakhurehi ajinacammehi samannāgatā. Paṅkadantāti dantakaṭṭhassa
analyzed: tattha khara ajinā ati sa khurehi ajina cammehi samannāgatā paṅka dantā ati danta kaṭṭhassa
translated: Here, “rough-skinned” means they are covered with rough antelope skins. “Teeth covered with plaque” means their teeth are covered with plaque

original: akhādanena malaggahitadantā. Dummakkharūpāti anañjitakkhā amaṇḍitarūpā lūkhasaṅghāṭidharā.
analyzed: a khādanena malagga hita dantā dummakkha rūpā ati an añjita kkhā a maṇḍita rūpā lūkha saṅghāṭi dharā
translated: from not chewing tooth wood. “Ugly forms” means they have unkempt faces, unadorned forms, and wear coarse robes.

original: Mānusake payogeti manussehi kattabbavīriye. Idaṃ vidūti idaṃ tapacaraṇañca mantasajjhāyanañca
analyzed: mānusake payoge iti manussehi kattabba vīriye idam vidu iti idam tapa caraṇam ca manta sajjhāyanam ca
translated: “By human effort” means by the effort that should be done by humans. “Knowing this” means knowing this practice of austerities and chanting the mantras.

original: jānantā. Apāyāti kacci ācariya, ime catūhi apāyehi muttāti pucchati.
analyzed: jānantā apāyāti kacci ācariya ime catūhi apāyehi muttā ati pucchati
translated: “Lower realms” means “Teacher, I ask if they are freed from the four lower realms.”

original: Taṃ sutvā purohito “ayaṃ rājā aṭṭhāne pasanno, tuṇhī bhavituṃ na vaṭṭatī”ti cintetvā dutiyaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: tam sutvā purohitaḥ ayam rājā aṭṭhāne pasannaḥ tuṇhī bhavitum na vaṭṭati iti cintetvā dutiyam gātham āha
translated: The chaplain thought to himself, “The king is pleased with the wrong person. I must not remain silent.” So he spoke the second stanza:

analyzed: pāpāni kammāni karetha rāja bahu ssutaḥ ce na careyya dhammaṃ
translated: If, though learned, a man do evil, though he know the Vedas thousandfold,

original: viya kathesi, tena saddhiṃ kathessāmī”ti. So tena saddhiṃ kathento tatiyaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: viya kathesi tena saddhim kathessāmi iti saḥ tena saddhim kathentaḥ tatiyam gātham āha
translated: and I will discuss the matter with him.” So he discussed the matter with him, and recited the third stanza:

original: “Sahassavedopi na taṃ paṭicca, dukkhā pamucce caraṇaṃ apatvā;
analyzed: sahassa vedaḥ api na tam paṭicca dukkhā pamucce caraṇam a patvā
translated: “Though one may know a thousand words, if he live not by the Law,

original: Maññāmi vedā aphalā bhavanti, sasaṃyamaṃ caraṇaññeva sacca”nti.
analyzed: maññāmi vedāḥ aphalāḥ bhavanti sa saṃyamam caraṇaññā iva saccanti
translated: I deem the Vedas profitless; the Law is true, and only that.”

original: Tattha aphalāti tava vāde vedā ca sesasippāni ca aphalāni āpajjanti, tāni kasmā uggaṇhanti, sīlasaṃyamena saddhiṃ caraṇaññeva ekaṃ saccaṃ āpajjatīti.
analyzed: tattha tava vāde vedāḥ ca sesa sippāni ca aphalāni āpajjanti tāni kasmai uggaṇhanti sīla saṃyamena saddhim ekam saccam āpajjati iti
translated: Herein, profitless means that in your doctrine the Vedas and the rest of the sciences are profitless; why are they studied? Only the Law, together with the restraint of virtue, is true, and only that is profitable.

original: Tato purohito catutthaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: tatas purohito catuttham gātham āha
translated: Then the chaplain recited the fourth stanza:

original: “Na heva vedā aphalā bhavanti, sasaṃyamaṃ caraṇaññeva saccaṃ;
analyzed: na ha iva vedāḥ aphalāḥ bhavanti sa saṃyamam caraṇam iva saccam
translated: “Not profitless are Vedas, if one live by the Law, and only that;

original: Kittiñhi pappoti adhicca vede, santiṃ puṇāti caraṇena danto”ti.
analyzed: kittim hi pappoti adhicca vede santim puṇāti caraṇena
translated: For by the Vedas one may win renown, and by the Law, self-restrained, attain to peace.”

original: Tattha na hevāti nāhaṃ “vedā aphalā”ti vadāmi, apica kho pana sasaṃyamaṃ caraṇaṃ
analyzed: tattha na ha iva ati na aham vadā aphalā ati vadāmi apica kho pana sa saṃyamam caraṇam
translated: Herein, not profitless means that I do not say that the Vedas are profitless; rather, the Law, together with the restraint of virtue,

original: saccameva sabhāvabhūtaṃ uttamaṃ. Tena hi sakkā dukkhā muccituṃ. Santiṃ puṇātīti samāpattisaṅkhātena
analyzed: saccam eva sabhāva bhūtam uttamam tena hi sakkā dukkhāḥ muccitum santim puṇāti iti samāpatti saṅkhātena
translated: The truth is the best of all, for by it one can be freed from suffering.

original: caraṇena danto bhayasantikaraṃ nibbānaṃ pāpuṇātīti.🔽Taṃ sutvā uddālako “na sakkā iminā saddhiṃ paṭipakkhavasena ṭhātuṃ, ‘putto tavāha’nti
analyzed: caraṇena dantaḥ bhaya santikaram nibbānam pāpuṇāti iti  tam sutvā uddālakaḥ na sakkā iminā saddhim paṭipakkha vasena ṭhātum putto tava ahanti
translated: By the practice of concentration he attains the peace of Nibbana, which is the allayer of fear.

original: vutte sinehaṃ akaronto nāma natthi, puttabhāvamassa kathessāmī”ti cintetvā pañcamaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: vutte sineham akarontaḥ nāma natthi putta bhāvam assa kathessāmi iti cintetvā pañcamam gātham āha
translated: Hearing this, Uddalaka thought, “I cannot oppose him. When he says, ‘You are my father,’ there is no one who will not feel affection. I will tell him that he is my son.” So he spoke the fifth stanza:

original: “Bhaccā mātā pitā bandhū, yena jāto sayeva so;
analyzed: mātā pitā bandhū yena jātaḥ sayā iva saḥ
translated: Your mother, father, and your kin, by whom you were begotten,

analyzed: bandhitu kāmāḥ attanā samāna jātiya kulataḥ te dārikam ānessāma ghara āvāsam saṇṭhapehi iti  vadiṃsu ammatātā na mayham ghara āvāsena atthaḥ mayham hi tayaḥ bhavāḥ ādittāḥ viya sa paṭibhayā

translated: Then his friends asked him, “My friend, what is it that you desire? Why do you not enjoy the pleasures of sense?”

original: pucchiṃsu. So tesaṃ nekkhammajjhāsayataṃ ārocesi. Taṃ sutvā mātāpitaro sesaputte
analyzed: pucchiṃsu saḥ tesam nekkhamma ajjhāsayatam ārocesi tam sutvā mātā pitaro sesa putte

analyzed: cintesi amhākam asīti koṭi dhanam chaḍḍetvā pabbajitānam evam loluppa cāra vasena

analyzed: idhā iva samaṇa dhammam karontā acchatha aham phala aphalam āharissāmi iti āha atha naṃ  upakañcana ādayaḥ mayam ācariya tumhe nissāya pabbajitā tumhe idha iva samaṇa dhammaṃ

translated: Having eaten, they did the ascetic’s duties. Later, having brought bitter vegetables, they ate them,🔽and they lived doing the preliminary work for the kasiṇa. Then,

analyzed: cintetvā attanaḥ ānubhāvena mahāsattassa koṭṭhāsam tayaḥ divase antaradhāpesi so paṭhama divase

analyzed: koṭṭhāsam a disvā mama koṭṭhāsam pamuṭṭhaḥ bhavissati iti cintesi dutiya divase mama

analyzed: sabbe sannipatitvā kena ghaṇḍi saññā dinnā ati āhaṃsu mayā tāta ati kiṃkāraṇā ācariyā ati  tātā tatiya divase kena phala aphalam tesu ekaḥ uṭṭhāya mayā ācariyā ati  vanditvā aṭṭhāsi koṭṭhāse karontena te mayham koṭṭhāso katoti āmaḥ ācariya jeṭṭhaka koṭṭhāso

original: me kato”ti. “Hiyyo kenābhata”nti? “Mayā”ti aparo uṭṭhāya vanditvā aṭṭhāsi. Koṭṭhāsaṃ
analyzed: me katoti hiyyo kena abhatanti mayā ati aparaḥ uṭṭhāya vanditvā aṭṭhāsi koṭṭhāsam
translated: “Dear friends, who brought the fruit on the third day?” One of them got up, saluted the teacher, and stood before him. “Did you set aside my share when you were setting aside the shares?” “Yes, teacher, I set aside the senior share for you.” “Who brought it yesterday?” Another got up, saluted the teacher, and stood before him.

translated: “When you were dividing the food, you forgot me.” “I have set aside the best portion for you.” “Who cooked today?”

analyzed: mayā iti aparaḥ uṭṭhāya vanditvā aṭṭhāsi koṭṭhāsam karontaḥ mam anussari iti tumhākam

original: me jeṭṭhakakoṭṭhāso kato”ti. “Tātā, ajja mayhaṃ koṭṭhāsaṃ alabhantassa tatiyo divaso,
analyzed: me jeṭṭhaka koṭṭhāso kato ti tātā ajja mayham koṭṭhāsam a labhantassa tatiyaḥ divaso

translated: On the first day, not seeing my portion, I thought, ‘He has forgotten to give me my portion.’

original: dutiyadivase “mama koci doso bhavissatī”ti cintesiṃ, ajja pana “sace me doso atthi,
analyzed: dutiya divase mama koci doso bhavissati iti cintesim ajja pana sace me doso atthi
translated: On the second day I thought, ‘There must be some fault in me.’ But today I thought, ‘If there is any fault in me,

analyzed: khamāpessāmi iti cintetvā ghaṇḍi saññāya tumhe sannipātesiṃ ete bhisa koṭṭhāse tumhe
