original: “karimhā”ti vadatha, ahaṃ na labhāmi, etesaṃ thenetvā khādakaṃ ñātuṃ vaṭṭati, kāme
analyzed: vadatha aham na labhāmi etesam thena itvā khādakam ñātum vaṭṭati kāme
translated: You say, ‘We have received them,’ but I have received none. It is proper that you should confess your theft of my portion. It is unbecoming in you to steal the portion of one who has renounced the world and given up all desire and who is satisfied with a mere pittance.”

original: pahāya pabbajitānaṃ bhisamattaṃ thenanaṃ nāma appatirūpanti. Te tassa kathaṃ sutvā
analyzed: pahāya pabbajitānam bhisa mattam thenanam nāma appatirūpanti te tassa katham sutvā
translated: When they heard his words,

original: “aho sāhasikakamma”nti sabbeva ubbegappattā ahesuṃ.
analyzed: aho sāhasika kamman ti sabbe iva ubbega pattāḥ ahesuṃ
translated: “What a daring deed!” and were all filled with wonder.

original: Tasmiṃ assamapade vanajeṭṭhakarukkhe nibbattadevatāpi otaritvā āgantvā tesaṃyeva🔽santike nisīdi. Āneñjakaraṇaṃ kāriyamāno dukkhaṃ adhivāsetuṃ asakkonto āḷānaṃ bhinditvā🔽palāyitvā araññaṃ paviṭṭho eko vāraṇo kālena kālaṃ isigaṇaṃ vandati, sopi āgantvā🔽ekamantaṃ aṭṭhāsi. Sappakīḷāpanako eko vānaro ahituṇḍikassa hatthato muccitvā palāyitvā
analyzed: tasmin assama pade vana jeṭṭhaka rukkhe nibbatta devatā api otaritvā āgantvā tesam yeva  santike nisīdi āneñja karaṇam kāriyamānaḥ dukkham adhivāsetum a sakkontaḥ āḷānam bhinditvā  palāyitvā araññam paviṭṭhaḥ ekaḥ vāraṇaḥ kālena kālam isi gaṇam vandati saḥ api āgantvā  ekamantam aṭṭhāsi sappakīḷāpanakaḥ ekaḥ vānaraḥ ahituṇḍikassa hatthataḥ muccitvā palāyitvā
translated: The deity who dwelt in the tree which was the chief of the forest, also came down and sat down in their midst.🔽A certain elephant, who had been caught in a trap, and who, unable to bear the pain, had broken the trap and fled into the forest, used to come from time to time and pay his respects to the company of seers. He also came and stood on one side.

original: araññaṃ pavisitvā tattheva assame vasati. Sopi taṃ divasaṃ isigaṇaṃ vanditvā ekamantaṃ
analyzed: araññam pavisitvā tattha iva assame vasati saḥ api tam divasam isi gaṇam vanditvā ekamantam
translated: A certain monkey, who had been a plaything, had escaped from the hands of his keeper, and having fled into the forest, had taken up his abode in that very hermitage. He also paid his respects to the company of seers, and sat down on one side.

original: nisīdi. Sakko “isigaṇaṃ pariggaṇhissāmī”ti tesaṃ santike adissamānakāyo aṭṭhāsi.
analyzed: nisīdi sakkaḥ isi gaṇam pariggaṇhissāmi iti tesam santike a dissamāna kāyaḥ aṭṭhāsi
translated: Sakka, thinking to himself, “I will test the company of seers,” stood in their midst, invisible.

original: Tasmiṃ khaṇeva bodhisattassa kaniṭṭho upakañcanatāpaso uṭṭhāyāsanā bodhisattaṃ vanditvā
analyzed: tasmin khaṇe iva bodhisattassa kaniṭṭhaḥ upakañcana tāpasaḥ uṭṭhāya āsanā bodhisattam vanditvā
translated: At that very moment the younger brother of the Bodhisatta, the ascetic Upakañcana, rose from his seat, and paid obeisance to the Bodhisatta.

original: sesānaṃ apacitiṃ dassetvā “ācariya, ahaṃ aññe apaṭṭhapetvā attānaññeva sodhetuṃ labhāmī”ti
analyzed: sesānam apacitim dassetvā ācariya aham aññe apaṭṭhapetvā attān aññā iva sodhetum labhāmi iti
translated: and then said to his teacher, “Reverend Sir, may I be allowed to clear myself without calling in any other witnesses?”

original: pucchi. “Āma, labhasī”ti. So isigaṇamajjhe ṭhatvā “sace te mayā bhisāni khāditāni,
analyzed: pucchi āma labhasi iti saḥ isi gaṇa majjhe ṭhatvā sace te mayā bhisāni khāditāni
translated: “Yes, you may.” So he stood in the midst of the seers and said, “If I have eaten any of your food,

original: evarūpo nāma hotū”ti sapathaṃ karonto paṭhamaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: evarūpaḥ nāma hotu iti sapatham paṭhamam gātham āha
translated: let me suffer such and such a fate.” And he uttered the first stanza:

original: “Assaṃ gavaṃ rajataṃ jātarūpaṃ, bhariyañca so idha labhataṃ manāpaṃ;
analyzed: assam gavam rajatam jātarūpam bhariyam ca saḥ idha labhatam manāpam
translated: “May I be a horse or an ox, or silver or gold, or a wife dear to my heart,

original: Puttehi dārehi samaṅgi hotu, bhisāni te brāhmaṇa yo ahāsī”ti.
analyzed: puttehi dārehi samaṅgi hotu bhisāni te brāhmaṇa yaḥ ahāsi iti
translated: may I be endowed with sons and daughters, for I have eaten your food, O Brahman.”

original: Tattha “assaṃ gava”nti idaṃ “so ‘yattakāni piyavatthūni honti, tehi vippayoge tattakāni sokadukkhāni uppajjantī’ti vatthukāme garahanto abhāsī”ti veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: tattha assam gavanti idam so yattakāni piya vatthūni honti tehi vippayoge tattakāni soka dukkhāni uppajjanti iti vatthu kāme garahantaḥ abhāsi iti veditabbam
translated: Herein, “a horse or an ox” and so on, he said this in order to show that the objects of sense-desire are the cause of sorrow and grief, and that the more objects of sense-desire there are, the more sorrow and grief there are.

original: Taṃ sutvā isigaṇo “mārisa, mā evaṃ kathetha, atibhāriyo te sapatho”ti kaṇṇe pidahi.
analyzed: tam sutvā isi gaṇaḥ mārisa mā evam kathetha atibhāriyaḥ te sapathā iti kaṇṇe pidahi
translated: When the seers heard this, they said, “Good sir, do not speak thus. Your curse is too heavy.” And they clapped their hands over their ears.

original: Bodhisattopi naṃ “tāta, atibhāriyo te sapatho, na tvaṃ khādasi, tava pattāsane nisīdā”ti
analyzed: bodhisattaḥ api nam tāta ati bhāriyaḥ te sapathaḥ na tvam khādasi tava pattāsane nisīda ati
translated: But the Bodhisatta said to him, “My dear sir, your curse is too heavy. You did not eat the food. Sit down in your own seat.”

original: āha. Tasmiṃ paṭhamaṃ sapathaṃ katvā nisinne dutiyopi bhātā sahasā uṭṭhāya mahāsattaṃ
analyzed: āha tasmin paṭhamam sapatham katvā nisinne dutiyaḥ api bhātā sahasā uṭṭhāya mahāsattam
translated: He said, “Very well,” and sat down. After he had taken the oath, the second brother suddenly rose up, saluted the Great Being,

original: vanditvā sapathena attānaṃ sodhento dutiyaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: vanditvā sapathena attānam sodhentaḥ dutiyam gātham āha
translated: and, in order to clear himself by an oath, spoke the second stanza:

original: “Mālañca so kāsikacandanañca, dhāretu puttassa bahū bhavantu;
analyzed: mālañca saḥ kāsika candanañca dhāretu puttassa bahū bhavantu
translated: “Let him wear garlands and use sandal-wood, and let him have many sons.🔽Let him be full of desire for the pleasures of sense;

original: Kāmesu tibbaṃ kurutaṃ apekkhaṃ, bhisāni te brāhmaṇa yo ahāsī”ti.🔽Tattha tibbanti vatthukāmakilesakāmesu bahalaṃ apekkhaṃ karotūti. Idaṃ so “yassetesu
analyzed: kāmesu tibbam kurutam apekkham bhisāni te brāhmaṇa yaḥ ahāsi iti  tattha vatthu kāma kilesa kāmesu bahalam apekkham karotu iti idam saḥ yassa etesu
translated: I am not afraid of you, O Brāhman.”

original: tibbā apekkhā honti, so tehi vippayoge mahantaṃ dukkhaṃ pāpuṇātī”ti dukkhapaṭikkhepavaseneva āha.
analyzed: tibbāḥ apekkhāḥ honti so tehi vippayoge mahantam dukkham pāpuṇāti iti dukkha paṭikkhepa vasena iva āha
translated: Herein, “full of desire” means let him have a great deal of desire for the pleasures of sense, both the pleasures of sense as objects and the pleasures of sense as passions. This he said in the way of a denial of suffering, “He who has a great deal of desire for these things, when he is separated from them, will come to great suffering.”

original: Tasmiṃ nisinne sesāpi attano attano ajjhāsayānurūpena taṃ taṃ gāthaṃ abhāsiṃsu –
analyzed: tasmin nisinne sesā api attanaḥ attanaḥ ajjhāsayā anurūpena tam tam gātham abhāsiṃsu
translated: After he had sat down, the others also spoke their respective stanzas in accordance with their own thoughts:

original: “Pahūtadhañño kasimā yasassī, putte gihī dhanimā sabbakāme;
analyzed: pahūta dhaññaḥ kasimā yasassī putte gihī dhanimā sabba kāme
translated: “Let him be rich in corn, in fields, in fame, in sons, in houses, in wealth, in all the pleasures of sense.🔽Let him live in the house, not seeing old age;

original: Vayaṃ apassaṃ gharamāvasātu, bhisāni te brāhmaṇa yo ahāsi.
analyzed: vayam apassam gharam āvasātu bhisāni te brāhmaṇa yaḥ ahāsi
translated: I am not afraid of you, O Brāhman.”

original: “So khattiyo hotu pasayhakārī, rājābhirājā balavā yasassī;
analyzed: saḥ khattiyaḥ hotu pasayha kārī rājā abhirājā balavā yasassī
translated: “Let him be a warrior, a doer of deeds, a king over the kings, powerful and glorious.

original: Sa cāturantaṃ mahimāvasātu, bhisāni te brāhmaṇa yo ahāsi.
analyzed: sa cāturantam mahimā avasātu bhisāni te brāhmaṇa yaḥ ahāsi
translated: Let him rule over the four continents, O brahmin, who has taken away your fear.

original: “So brāhmaṇo hotu avītarāgo, muhuttanakkhattapathesu yutto;
analyzed: saḥ brāhmaṇaḥ hotu a vīta rāgaḥ muhutta nakkhatta pathesu yuttaḥ
translated: “Let him be a brahmin, not free from passion, devoted to the momentary path of the stars.

original: Pūjetu naṃ raṭṭhapatī yasassī, bhisāni te brāhmaṇa yo ahāsi.
analyzed: pūjetu nam raṭṭhapatī yasassī bhisāni te brāhmaṇa yaḥ ahāsi
translated: Let the glorious lord of the country worship him, O brahmin, who has taken away your fear.

original: “Ajjhāyakaṃ sabbasamantavedaṃ, tapassinaṃ maññatu sabbaloko;
analyzed: ajjhāyakam sabba samanta vedam tapassinam maññatu sabba lokaḥ
translated: “Let all the world consider him a reciter, all-knowing, an ascetic.

original: Pūjentu naṃ jānapadā samecca, bhisāni te brāhmaṇa yo ahāsi.
analyzed: pūjentu nam jānapadā samet ca bhisāni te brāhmaṇa yaḥ ahā asi
translated: Let the people of the country gather and worship him, O brahmin, who has taken away your fear.

original: “Catussadaṃ gāmavaraṃ samiddhaṃ, dinnañhi so bhuñjatu vāsavena;
analyzed: catur sadam gām avaram samiddham dinnan hi saḥ bhuñjatu vāsavena
translated: “Let him enjoy the prosperous village of four corners, given by Vāsava.

original: Avītarāgo maraṇaṃ upetu, bhisāni te brāhmaṇa yo ahāsi.
analyzed: a vīta rāgaḥ maraṇam upetu bhisāni te brāhmaṇa yaḥ ahāsi
translated: Let him die without being free from passion, O brahmin, who has taken away your fear.

original: “So gāmaṇī hotu sahāyamajjhe, naccehi gītehi pamodamāno;
analyzed: saḥ gāmaṇī hotu sahāya majjhe naccehi gītehi pamodamānaḥ
translated: “Let him be a leader in the midst of his friends, rejoicing with dancing and singing.

original: So rājato byasana mālattha kiñci, bhisāni te brāhmaṇa yo ahāsi.
analyzed: saḥ rājataḥ byasana mā alattha kiñci bhisāni te brāhmaṇa yaḥ ahāsi
translated: Let him not obtain any misfortune from the king, O brahmin, who has taken away your fear.

original: “Yaṃ ekarājā pathaviṃ vijetvā, itthīsahassāna ṭhapetu aggaṃ;
analyzed: yam eka rājā pathavim vijetvā itthī sahassāna ṭhapetu aggam
translated: “Whatever one king conquers the earth, and sets up a thousand women as foremost,

original: Sīmantinīnaṃ pavarā bhavātu, bhisāni te brāhmaṇa yā ahāsi.
analyzed: sīmantinīnam pavarā bhavātu bhisāni te brāhmaṇa yāḥ ahāsi
translated: The fears you have, O Brahmin, are gone.🔽For she, when all the seers have gathered,

original: “Isīnañhi sā sabbasamāgatānaṃ, bhuñjeyya sāduṃ avikampamānā;
analyzed: isīnam hi sā sabba samāgatānam bhuñjeyya sādum a vikampamānā
translated: May eat the sweet food without trembling;🔽May she go about, exulting in her gain,

original: Carātu lābhena vikatthamānā, bhisāni te brāhmaṇa yā ahāsi.
analyzed: carātu lābhena vikatthamānā bhisāni te brāhmaṇa yāḥ ahāsi
translated: The fears you have, O Brahmin, are gone.🔽May he be a resident in the Great Monastery,

original: “Āvāsiko hotu mahāvihāre, navakammiko hotu gajaṅgalāyaṃ;
analyzed: āvāsikaḥ hotu mahāvihāre navakammikaḥ hotu gajaṅgalāyam
translated: May he be a builder of the Gajaṅgalā Monastery;🔽May he make the day a time of light,

original: Ālokasandhiṃ divasaṃ karotu, bhisāni te brāhmaṇa yo ahāsi.
analyzed: āloka sandhim divasam karotu bhisāni te brāhmaṇa yaḥ ahāsi
translated: The fears you have, O Brahmin, are gone.🔽May he be caught in six hundred snares,

original: “So bajjhatū pāsasatehi chabbhi, rammā vanā niyyatu rājadhāniṃ;
analyzed: saḥ bajjhatū pāsa satehi chabbhi rammā vanā niyyatu rājadhānim
translated: May he go forth from the delightful capital;🔽May he be killed by the burning flames,

original: Tuttehi so haññatu pācanehi, bhisāni te brāhmaṇa yo ahāsi.
analyzed: tuttehi saḥ haññatu pācanehi bhisāni te brāhmaṇa yaḥ ahāsi
translated: The fears you have, O Brahmin, are gone.

original: “Alakkamālī tipukaṇṇaviddho, laṭṭhīhato sappamukhaṃ upetu;
analyzed: alakkamālī tipu kaṇṇa viddhaḥ laṭṭhī hataḥ sappa mukham upetu
translated: Wearing a garland of peacock feathers, pierced by a spear,🔽Struck by a stick, he will approach the mouth of a snake;🔽Bound by a rope, may he wander about in the flames,

original: Sakacchabandho visikhaṃ carātu, bhisāni te brāhmaṇa yo ahāsī”ti.
analyzed: sa kaccha bandhaḥ visikham carātu bhisāni te brāhmaṇa yaḥ ahāsi iti
translated: The fears you have, O Brahmin, are gone.”

original: Tattha tatiyena vuttagāthāya kasimāti sampannakasikammo. Putte gihī dhanimā sabbakāmeti
analyzed: tattha tatiyena vutta gāthāya kasimā ati sampanna kasi kammaḥ putte gihī dhanimā sabba kāme iti
translated: Here, in the third verse, “farmer” means one who has completed the farming work. “Sons, householders, and wealthy people in every way” means

original: putte labhatu, gihī hotu, sattavidhena ratanadhanena dhanimā hotu, rūpādibhede sabbakāme
analyzed: putte labhatu gihī hotu sattavidhena ratana dhanena dhanimā hotu rūpa ādi bhede sabba kāme
translated: may he get children, may he be a householder, may he be rich in the seven kinds of wealth beginning with faith, may he get all the sensual desires beginning with beauty,

original: labhatu. Vayaṃ apassanti mahallakakāle pabbajjānurūpampi attano vayaṃ apassanto pañcakāmaguṇasamiddhaṃ🔽gharameva āvasatūti. Idaṃ so “pañcakāmaguṇagiddho kāmaguṇavippayogena mahāvināsaṃ
analyzed: labhatu vayam a passanti mahallaka kāle pabbajja anurūpam pi attanaḥ vayam a passantaḥ pañca kāmaguṇa samiddham  gharam eva āvasatu iti idam saḥ pañca kāmaguṇa giddhaḥ kāma guṇa vippayogena mahā vināsam
translated: and may he not see the five aggregates as long as he lives. When he is old, may he not see his own age suitable for going forth, and may he live in a house full of the five strands of sense pleasure.

original: pāpuṇātī”ti dassetuṃ kathesi.🔽Catutthena vuttagāthāya rājābhirājāti rājūnaṃ antare abhirājāti. Idaṃ so “issarānaṃ
analyzed: pāpuṇāti iti dassetum kathesi  catutthena vutta gāthāya rājā abhirājāti antare abhirājāti idam saḥ issarānam
translated: This he said in order to show that “he who is infatuated with the five strands of sense pleasure will come to great destruction through being separated from the strands of sense pleasure.”

original: nāma issariye parigalite mahantaṃ dukkhaṃ uppajjatī”ti rajje dosaṃ dassento kathesi.🔽Pañcamena vuttagāthāya avītarāgoti purohitaṭṭhānataṇhāya sataṇhoti. Idaṃ so “purohitassa
analyzed: nāma issariye parigalite mahantam dukkham uppajjati iti rajje dosam dassentaḥ kathesi  pañcamena vutta gāthāya avīta rāgaḥ ti purohita ṭṭhāna taṇhāya sa taṇhaḥ ti idam so purohitassa
translated: In the verse spoken by the fourth, rājābhirājā means the chief among kings. This he said in order to show the fault in kingship, saying “Great suffering arises for those who are kings🔽when their sovereignty is taken away.”🔽In the verse spoken by the fifth, avītarāgo means one who is not free from craving, one who is full of craving for the position of a royal priest. This he said in order to show that “great sorrow arises for a royal priest

original: purohitaṭṭhāne parigalite mahantaṃ domanassaṃ uppajjatī”ti dassetuṃ kathesi. Chaṭṭhena
analyzed: purohita ṭṭhāne parigalite mahantam domanassam uppajjati iti dassetum kathesi chaṭṭhena
translated: when his position as a royal priest is taken away.” In the verse spoken by the sixth,

original: vuttagāthāya tapassinanti tapasīlasampannoti taṃ maññatu. Idaṃ so “lābhasakkārāpagamena
analyzed: vutta gāthāya tapassinam ti tapa sīla sampannaḥ ti tam maññatu idam saḥ lābha sakkāra apagamena
translated: In the verse quoted, the ascetic is one who is endowed with the virtue of austerity.

original: mahantaṃ domanassaṃ uppajjatī”ti lābhasakkāragarahavasena kathesi.🔽Sahāyatāpasena vuttagāthāya catussadanti ākiṇṇamanussatāya manussehi, pahūtadhaññatāya
analyzed: mahantam domanassam uppajjati iti lābha sakkāra garaha vasena kathesi  sahāya tāpasena vutta gāthāya ākiṇṇa manussa tāya manussehi pahūta dhañña tāya
translated: This was said by the Elder in order to show that great sorrow arises from the loss of gain and honour.

original: dhaññena, sulabhadārutāya dārūhi, sampannodakatāya udakenāti catūhi ussannaṃ, catussadasamannāgatanti🔽attho. Vāsavenāti vāsavena dinnaṃ viya acalaṃ, vāsavato laddhavarānubhāvena ekaṃ
analyzed: dhaññena sulabha dāru tāya dārūhi sampanna udaka tāya udakena ati catūhi ussannam catussadasam annāgatanti  attho vāsavena ati vāsavena dinnam viya acalam vāsavataḥ laddha vara anubhāvena ekam
translated: In the verse quoted by Sahāyatapa, catussada means “prosperous with the four” — prosperous with people because of its being crowded with people, prosperous with grain because of the abundance of grain, prosperous with timber because of the abundance of timber, and prosperous with water because of the abundance of water. The meaning is that it is endowed with the four.🔽Vāsaveni means “given by Vāsava” as if it were immovable, or it means that it was given by a king who had obtained sovereignty through the power of Vāsava.

original: rājānaṃ ārādhetvā tena dinnantipi attho. Avītarāgoti kaddame sūkaro viya kāmapaṅke🔽nimuggova hutvā. Iti sopi kāmānaṃ ādīnavaṃ kathento evamāha.
analyzed: rājānam ārādhetvā tena attho avīta rāgaḥ iti kaddame sūkaraḥ viya kāma paṅke  nimuggaḥ uva hutvā iti saḥ api kāmānam ādīnavam kathentaḥ evam āha
translated: Avītarāga means “not free from passion” like a pig in the mud,🔽immersed in the mud of sensual pleasures. Thus he said this in order to show the danger in sensual pleasures.

original: Dāsena vuttagāthāya gāmaṇīti gāmajeṭṭhako. Ayampi kāme garahantoyeva evamāha. Kañcanadeviyā
analyzed: dāsena vutta gāthāya ayam pi kāme evam āha kañcana deviyā
translated: In the verse quoted by Dāsaka, gāmaṇī means the head of the village. He too said this in order to censure sensual pleasures.

original: vuttagāthāya yanti yaṃ itthinti attho. Ekarājāti aggarājā. Itthisahassānanti vacanamaṭṭhatāya🔽vuttaṃ, soḷasannaṃ itthisahassānaṃ aggaṭṭhāne ṭhapetūti attho. Sīmantinīnanti sīmantadharānaṃ
analyzed: vutta gāthāya yan ti yam itthin ti atthaḥ eka rājā ati agga rājā itthi sahassānam ti  vuttam soḷasannam itthi sahassānam aggaṭṭhāne ṭhapetu iti attho sīmantinīnam ti sīmanta dharānam
translated: The meaning is: ‘He went to the one who was called thus.’ ‘Sole king’ means ‘foremost king.’ ‘Of the thousand women’ is said because of the number. The meaning is: ‘He placed her in the foremost position of the sixteen thousand women.’ ‘Those who had the sign of a hairline’ means those who had the sign of a hairline.

original: itthīnanti attho. Iti sā itthibhāve ṭhatvāpi duggandhagūtharāsiṃ viya kāme garahantīyeva🔽evamāha. Dāsiyā vuttagāthāya sabbasamāgatānanti sabbesaṃ sannipatitānaṃ majjhe nisīditvā🔽avikampamānā anosakkamānā sādurasaṃ bhuñjatūti attho. Dāsīnaṃ kira sāmikassa santike
analyzed: itthīnanti iti sā itthi bhāve duggandha gūtha rāsim kāme  evam āha dāsiyā vutta gāthāya sabba samāgatānam ti sabbesam sannipatitānam majjhe nisīditvā  a vikampamānā an osakkamānā sādurasam bhuñjatu iti atthaḥ dāsīnam kira sāmikassa santike
translated: In the verse spoken by her, the meaning is: “I go to him” (yanti yaṃ). “Sole king” (ekarājā): chief king. “Of the thousand women” (itthisahassānaṃ): the meaning is: “Having placed her in the foremost position of the sixteen thousand women.” “Women with the sign of pregnancy” (sīmantinīnaṃ): the meaning is: “women who have the sign of pregnancy.” Thus, although she was in the state of a woman, she spoke thus, as if despising sensual pleasures, as if they were a heap of stinking excrement.

original: nisīditvā bhuñjanaṃ nāma appiyaṃ. Iti sā attano appiyatāya evamāha. Carātūti caratu.🔽Lābhena vikatthamānāti lābhahetu kuhanakammaṃ karontī lābhasakkāraṃ uppādentī caratūti
analyzed: nisīditvā bhuñjanam nāma appiyam iti sā evam āha carātu uti caratu  lābhena vikatthamānā ati lābha hetu kuhana kammam karontī lābha sakkāram uppādentī caratu uti
translated: In the verse spoken by the slave, the meaning is: “Having sat down in the midst of all those who have assembled” (sabbasamāgatānaṃ), “may she eat without trembling” (avikampamānā), “without clinging” (anosakkamānā), “with relish” (sādurasaṃ bhuñjatū). It seems that it is unpleasant for a slave to sit down in the presence of her master and eat. Thus, she spoke thus, as if because of her own unpleasantness. “May she go” (carātu): may she go.

original: attho. Iminā sā dāsibhāve ṭhitāpi kilesakāmavatthukāme garahati.
analyzed: sā dāsi bhāve ṭhitā api kilesa kāma vatthu kāme garahati
translated: “Boasting with gain” (lābhena vikatthamānā): the meaning is: “May she go, doing deceitful acts for the sake of gain, generating gain and honour.” By this, although she was in the state of a slave, she despised sensual pleasures and sensual pleasures as a basis for defilements.

original: Devatāya vuttagāthāya āvāsikoti āvāsajagganako. Gajaṅgalāyanti evaṃnāmake nagare.
analyzed: devatāya vutta gāthāya āvāsikā uti āvāsa jagganakaḥ gajaṅgalāyanti evaṃnāmake nagare
translated: In the verse spoken by the deity, “the resident” is the one who looks after the dwelling place. “In Gajaṅgalā” is the name of a city.

original: Tattha kira dabbasambhārā sulabhā. Ālokasandhiṃ divasanti ekadivaseneva vātapānaṃ
analyzed: tattha kira dabba sambhārā sulabhāḥ āloka sandhim eka divasena iva vāta pānam
translated: There, it seems, the requisites for the attainment of absorption were easily available. “Let him make a window” means let him make a window in a single day.

original: karotu. So kira devaputto kassapabuddhakāle gajaṅgalanagaraṃ nissāya yojanike jiṇṇamahāvihāre
analyzed: karotu saḥ kira devaputto kassapa buddha kāle gajaṅgala nagaram nissāya yojanike jiṇṇa mahā vihāre
translated: It seems that this deity was the resident elder of the Sangha in a large dilapidated monastery a yojana in extent near the city of Gajaṅgalā in the time of the Buddha Kassapa.

original: āvāsikasaṅghatthero hutvā jiṇṇavihāre navakammaṃ karontoyeva mahādukkhaṃ anubhavi.
analyzed: āvāsika saṅgha theraḥ hutvā jiṇṇa vihāre nava kammaṃ mahā dukkham
translated: While doing repairs to the dilapidated monastery, he experienced great suffering.

original: Tasmā tadeva dukkhaṃ ārabbha evamāha. Hatthinā vuttagāthāya pāsasatehīti bahūhi pāsehi.
analyzed: tasmā tat eva dukkham ārabbha evam āha hatthinā vutta gāthāya pāsa satehi iti bahūhi pāsehi
translated: Therefore, referring to that very suffering, he said this. In the verse spoken by the elephant, “with a hundred bonds” means with many bonds.

original: Chabbhīti catūsu pādesu gīvāya kaṭibhāge cāti chasu ṭhānesu. Tuttehīti dvikaṇḍakāhi
analyzed: chapbhi iti catūsu pādesu gīvāya kaṭibhāge ca ati chasu ṭhānesu tuttehi iti dvi kaṇḍakāhi
translated: “With six” means in six places: the four feet, the neck, and the waist. “With a hundred bonds” means with two-jointed long sticks.

original: dīghalaṭṭhīhi. Pācanehīti dasapācanehi aṅkusehi vā. So kira attano anubhūtadukkhaññeva ārabbha evamāha.
analyzed: dīgha laṭṭhīhi pācanehi iti dasa pācanehi aṅkusehi vā saḥ kira attanaḥ anubhūta dukkhaññā iva ārabbha evam āha
translated: “With ten goads” means with ten hooks. It seems that he said this referring to the suffering he himself experienced.

original: Vānarena vuttagāthāya alakkamālīti ahituṇḍikena kaṇṭhe parikkhipitvā ṭhapitāya alakkamālāya🔽samannāgato. Tipukaṇṇaviddhoti tipupiḷandhanena piḷandhakaṇṇo. Laṭṭhīhatoti sappakīḷaṃ
analyzed: vānarena vutta gāthāya alakkamālī iti ahituṇḍikena kaṇṭhe parikkhipitvā ṭhapitāya alakkamālāya  samannāgato tipu kaṇṇa viddho ti tipu piḷandhanena piḷandha kaṇṇaḥ laṭṭhī hato ti sappa kīḷam
translated: In the verse spoken by the monkey, “Wearing a garland of bad luck” means that he was wearing a garland of bad luck which the snake-charmer had placed around his neck.🔽“Pierced through the ear-hole with a pin” means that he had his ear-pierced with a pin. “Struck with a stick” means that he was struck with a stick while being trained in playing the game of dice.

original: sikkhāpayamāno laṭṭhiyā hato hutvā. Esopi ahituṇḍikassa hatthe attano anubhūtadukkhameva sandhāya evamāha.🔽Evaṃ tehi terasahi janehi sapathe kate mahāsatto cintesi “kadāci ime ‘ayaṃ anaṭṭhameva
analyzed: sikkhāpayamānaḥ laṭṭhiyā hataḥ hutvā esaḥ api ahituṇḍikassa hatthe attanaḥ anubhūta dukkham eva sandhāya evam āha  evam tehi terasahi janehi sapathe kate mahāsatto cintesi kadāci ime ayam
translated: This one, too, in the hands of the snake-charmer, spoke thus, referring to the suffering he himself had experienced.

original: naṭṭhanti kathetī’ti mayi āsaṅkaṃ kareyyuṃ, ahampi sapathaṃ karomī”ti. Atha naṃ karonto
analyzed: naṭṭhanti katheti iti mayi āsaṅkam kareyyum aham pi sapatham karomi iti atha nam karontaḥ
translated: When the thirteen men had thus taken the oath, the Great Being thought, “If they should suspect me, saying, ‘He speaks as if he were not one of us,’ I, too, will take the oath.” Then, as he took the oath,

original: cuddasamaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: cuddasamam gātham āha
translated: he spoke the fourteenth verse:

original: “Yo ve anaṭṭhaṃva naṭṭhanti cāha, kāmeva so labhataṃ bhuñjatañca;
analyzed: yaḥ ve naṭṭhanti ca āha kāmā iva saḥ labhatam bhuñjatam ca
translated: “He who says, ‘I am not lost,’ though he is lost, and he who enjoys and eats what he has gained through sensual desires,

original: Agāramajjhe maraṇaṃ upetu, yo vā bhonto saṅkati kañcidevā”ti.
analyzed: agāra majjhe maraṇam upetu yaḥ vā bhontaḥ kañcid eva ati
translated: And he who dies in the midst of the household life, or he who, good sirs, would deceive anyone at all” .

original: Tattha bhontoti ālapanaṃ. Idaṃ vuttaṃ hoti – bhavanto yo anaṭṭhe koṭṭhāse “naṭṭhaṃ
analyzed: tattha bhonto ti ālapanam idam vuttam hoti bhavanto yaḥ anaṭṭhe koṭṭhāse naṭṭham
translated: Here, “good sirs” is an address. This is what is said: “Good sirs, he who, in the matter of the lost, says, “I am not lost,”

original: me”ti vadati, yo vā tumhesu kañci āsaṅkati, so pañca kāmaguṇe labhatu ceva bhuñjatu
analyzed: mā iti vadati yaḥ vā so pañca kāmaguṇe labhatu ca iva bhuñjatu
translated: “Or let him who has any desire for you enjoy the five strands of sense pleasures and eat them,

original: ca, ramaṇīyameva pabbajjaṃ alabhitvā agāramajjheyeva maratūti.
analyzed: ca ramaṇīyam eva pabbajjam a labhitvā agāram ajjheyā iva maratu uti
translated: and let him die in the midst of the household life without obtaining the going forth.”

original: Evaṃ isīhi sapathe kate sakko bhāyitvā “ahaṃ ime vīmaṃsanto bhisāni antaradhāpesiṃ.
analyzed: evam isīhi sapathe kate sakkaḥ bhāyitvā aham ime vīmaṃsantaḥ bhisāni antaradhāpesim
translated: When the seers had taken this oath, Sakka was frightened. “I was testing them and made the pleasures disappear.

original: Ime ca chaḍḍitakheḷapiṇḍaṃ viya kāme garahantā sapathaṃ karonti, kāme garahakāraṇaṃ
analyzed: ime ca chaḍḍita kheḍa piṇḍam sa patham karonti kāme garaha kāraṇam
translated: But they are abusing the pleasures as if they were a lump of spit and taking an oath. I will ask them why they are abusing the pleasures.

original: te pucchissāmī”ti cintetvā dissamānarūpo bodhisattaṃ vanditvā pucchanto anantaraṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: te pucchissāmi iti cintetvā dissamāna rūpaḥ bodhisattam vanditvā pucchantaḥ anantaram gātham āha
translated: ” Thinking thus, he appeared in their presence, paid homage to the Bodhisatta, and asked him the reason for their abuse of the pleasures in the next stanza:

original: “Yadesamānā vicaranti loke, iṭṭhañca kantañca bahūnametaṃ;
analyzed: yadā īsamānāḥ vicaranti loke iṭṭhañca kantañca
translated: “When they wander about in the world, this is desired and loved by many,

original: Piyaṃ manuññaṃ cidha jīvaloke, kasmā isayo nappasaṃsanti kāme”ti.🔽Tattha yadesamānāti yaṃ vatthukāmaṃ kilesakāmañca kasigorakkhādīhi samavisamakammehi
analyzed: piyam manuññam cidha jīva loke kasmai isayaḥ na pasaṃsanti kāmā iti  yam vatthu kāmam kilesa kāmam ca kasi gorakkha ādīhi sama visama kammehi
translated: This is dear and pleasing in the world of life. Why do the seers not praise the pleasures?”🔽Herein, when they wander about in the world means when they wander about in the world seeking the pleasures of sense desires and the pleasures of the defilements by means of the same and different kinds of work such as agriculture, cattle-breeding, etc.,

original: pariyesamānā sattā loke vicaranti, etaṃ bahūnaṃ devamanussānaṃ iṭṭhañca kantañca
analyzed: pariyesamānā sattāḥ loke vicaranti etam bahūnam deva manussānam iṭṭham ca kantam ca
translated: this is desired and loved by many gods and men.

original: piyañca manuññañca, kasmā isayo nappasaṃsanti kāmeti attho. “Kāme”ti iminā taṃ vatthuṃ sarūpato dasseti.
analyzed: piyam ca manuññam ca kasmai isayaḥ na ppasaṃsanti kāma iti attho kāma iti iminā tam vatthum sarūpataḥ dasseti
translated: and what is dear and delightful, why do the seers not praise sensual desires? The meaning is: why do they not recommend them? “Sensual desires” : by this he shows the subject matter in its true nature.

original: Athassa pañhaṃ vissajjento mahāsatto dve gāthā abhāsi –
analyzed: athassa pañham vissajjentaḥ mahāsattaḥ dve gāthāḥ abhāsi
translated: Then the Great Being, in answering his question, spoke two stanzas:

original: “Kāmesu ve haññare bajjhare ca, kāmesu dukkhañca bhayañca jātaṃ;
analyzed: kāmesu ve haññare bajjhare ca kāmesu dukkhañca bhayañca jātaṃ
translated: “In sensual desires one is slain and caught, in sensual desires suffering and fear arise;

original: Kāmesu bhūtādhipatī pamattā, pāpāni kammāni karonti mohā.
analyzed: kāmesu bhūta adhipatī pamattā pāpāni kammāni karonti mohā
translated: The lord of creatures, heedless, through delusion commits evil deeds because of sensual desires.

original: “Te pāpadhammā pasavetva pāpaṃ, kāyassa bhedā nirayaṃ vajanti;
analyzed: te pāpa dhammā pasavetva pāpam kāyassa bhedā nirayam vajanti
translated: “Those of evil nature, having produced evil, at the breaking up of the body go to hell;

original: Ādīnavaṃ kāmaguṇesu disvā, tasmā isayo nappasaṃsanti kāme”ti.
analyzed: ādīnavam kāma guṇesu disvā tasmai isayaḥ na pasaṃsanti kāma iti
translated: Seeing the danger in the strands of sensual desire, therefore the seers do not praise sensual desires.”

original: Tattha kāmesūti kāmahetu, kāme nissāya kāyaduccaritādīni karontīti attho. Haññareti
analyzed: tattha kāmesu iti kāma hetu kāme nissāya kāya duccarita ādīni karonti iti atthaḥ
translated: Herein, in sensual desires means because of sensual desires; the meaning is: they commit bodily misconduct, etc., depending on sensual desires. One is slain means

original: daṇḍādīhi haññanti. Bajjhareti rajjubandhanādīhi bajjhanti. Dukkhanti kāyikacetasikaṃ
analyzed: daṇḍa ādīhi haññanti bajjhareti rajju bandhana ādīhi bajjhanti dukkhanti kāyika cetasikam
translated: they are slain by means of sticks, etc. One is caught means they are caught by means of ropes, etc. Suffering means bodily and mental

original: asātaṃ dukkhaṃ. Bhayanti attānuvādādikaṃ sabbampi bhayaṃ. Bhūtādhipatīti sakkaṃ ālapati.
analyzed: asātam dukkham bhayanti atta anuvāda ādikam sabbam pi bhayam bhūta adhipati iti sakkam ālapati
translated: pain, unpleasantness. Fear means all fear, beginning with fear of self-reproach. The lord of creatures means Sakka.

original: Ādīnavanti evarūpaṃ dosaṃ. So panesa ādīnavo dukkhakkhandhādīhi suttehi dīpetabbo.
analyzed: ādīnavanti evarūpam dosam saḥ pana isa ādīnavaḥ dukkhakkhandha ādīhi suttehi dīpetabbo
translated: “The dangers” are such as these. And these dangers should be illustrated by the Suttas beginning with the “Mass of Suffering.”

original: Sakko mahāsattassa kathaṃ sutvā saṃviggamānaso anantaraṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: sakkaḥ mahāsattassa katham sutvā saṃvigga mānasaḥ anantaram gātham āha
translated: Having heard the Great Being’s words, Sakka, his mind agitated, spoke the next stanza:🔽“I, O Sage, in testing your austerities,

original: “Vīmaṃsamāno isino bhisāni, tīre gahetvāna thale nidhesiṃ;
analyzed: vīmaṃsamānaḥ isinaḥ bhisāni tīre gahetvāna thale
translated: Took them and placed them on the shore.🔽Pure and sinless, the sages live;

original: Suddhā apāpā isayo vasanti, etāni te brahmacārī bhisānī”ti.
analyzed: suddhāḥ apāpāḥ isayaḥ vasanti etāni te brahmacārī bhisāni iti
translated: These are your austerities, O Brahma-farer.”

original: Tattha vimaṃsamānoti bhante, ahaṃ “ime isayo kāmādhimuttā vā, no vā”ti vīmaṃsanto.🔽Isinoti tava mahesino santakāni bhisāni. Tīre gahetvānāti tīre nikkhittāni gahetvā🔽thale ekamante nidhesiṃ. Suddhāti idāni mayā tumhākaṃ sapathakiriyāya ñātaṃ “ime
analyzed: tattha vimaṃsamānaḥ ti bhante aham ime isayaḥ kāma adhimuttāḥ vā no vā ati vīmaṃsanto  isino ti tava mahesino santakāni bhisāni tīre tīre tīre nikkhittāni gahetvā  thale eka mante idāni mayā tumhākam sapatha kiriyāya ñātam ime
translated: Herein, “I, O Sage,” means, “Venerable Sir, I, in testing whether these sages were intent on sensual pleasures or not.”

original: isayo suddhā apāpā hutvā vasantī”ti.
analyzed: isayaḥ suddhāḥ apāpāḥ hutvā vasanti iti
translated: “The austerities of the Sage” are yours, O Great Sage. “Took them and placed them on the shore” means, having taken those placed on the shore, I placed them on one side on the land. “Pure” means, now, by my making you swear, I have come to know that “these sages live pure and sinless.”

original: Taṃ sutvā bodhisatto gāthamāha –
analyzed: tam sutvā bodhisattaḥ gātham āha
translated: Having heard that, the Bodhisatta spoke the next stanza:🔽“They are not actors, nor are they for play,

original: “Na te naṭā no pana kīḷaneyyā, na bandhavā no pana te sahāyā;
analyzed: na te naṭāḥ no pana kīḷaneyyāḥ na bandhavāḥ no pana te sahāyā
translated: Nor are they kinsmen, nor are they your friends;

original: Kismiṃ vupatthambha sahassanetta, isīhi tvaṃ kīḷasi devarājā”ti.
analyzed: kismin vupatthambha sahassa nette isīhi tvam kīḷasi deva rājā ati
translated: In what dost thou abide, thou thousand-eyed, thou playest with the seers, thou king of gods?”

original: Tattha na te naṭā noti devarāja, mayaṃ tava naṭā vā kīḷitabbayuttakā vā keci na homa,
analyzed: tattha na te naṭāḥ devarāja mayam tava naṭāḥ vā kīḷitabba yuttakāḥ vā keci na
translated: Herein, thou hast no actors, king of gods, we are not thy actors or thy playmates,

original: nāpi tava ñātakā, na sahāyā, atha tvaṃ kiṃ vā upatthambhaṃ katvā kiṃ nissāya isīhi
analyzed: na api tava ñātakāḥ na sahāyāḥ atha tvam kim vā upatthambham katvā kim nissāya isīhi
translated: nor are we thy kinsmen or thy friends. But in what dost thou abide, in what dost thou rely,

original: saddhiṃ kīḷasīti attho.
analyzed: saddhim kīḷasi iti attho
translated: that thou playest with the seers?

original: Atha naṃ sakko khamāpento vīsatimaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: atha nam sakkaḥ khamāpentaḥ vīsatimam gātham āha
translated: Then Sakka, in order to appease him, spoke the twentieth stanza:

original: “Ācariyo mesi pitā ca mayhaṃ, esā patiṭṭhā khalitassa brahme;
analyzed: ācariyaḥ mā isi pitā ca mayham esā patiṭṭhā khalitassa brahme
translated: “Thou art my teacher, thou art my father, this is my support, O Brahmā, when I have failed.

original: Ekāparādhaṃ khama bhūripañña, na paṇḍitā kodhabalā bhavantī”ti.
analyzed: eka aparādham khama bhūri pañña na paṇḍitāḥ kodha balāḥ bhavanti iti
translated: Forgive me this one fault, O thou of ample wisdom, for the wise are not possessed of strength of anger.”

original: Tattha esā patiṭṭhāti esā tava pādacchāyā ajja mama khalitassa aparaddhassa patiṭṭhā hotu. Kodhabalāti paṇḍitā nāma khantibalā bhavanti, na kodhabalāti.
analyzed: tattha esā patiṭṭhā ati esā tava pādacchāyā ajja mama khalitassa aparaddhassa patiṭṭhā hotu kodha balā ati paṇḍitāḥ nāma khanti balāḥ bhavanti na kodha balā ati
translated: Herein, this is my support, let this shadow of thy feet be my support to-day, when I have failed and offended. Strength of anger, the wise are possessed of strength of patience, not of strength of anger.

original: Atha mahāsatto sakkassa devarañño khamitvā sayaṃ isigaṇaṃ khamāpento itaraṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: atha mahāsattaḥ sakkassa deva raññaḥ khamitvā sayam isi gaṇam khamāpentaḥ itaram gātham āha
translated: Then the Great Being, forgiving Sakka, king of the gods, and himself appeasing the company of seers, spoke the other stanza:

original: “Suvāsitaṃ isinaṃ ekarattaṃ, yaṃ vāsavaṃ bhūtapatiddasāma;
analyzed: su vāsitam isinam eka rattam yam vāsavam bhūtapati dasāma
translated: where we have seen Vāsava, the Lord of Spirits.

original: Sabbeva bhonto sumanā bhavantu, yaṃ brāhmaṇo paccupādī bhisānī”ti.🔽Tattha suvāsitaṃ isinaṃ ekarattanti āyasmantānaṃ isīnaṃ ekarattampi imasmiṃ araññe🔽vasitaṃ suvasitameva. Kiṃkāraṇā? Yaṃ vāsavaṃ bhūtapatiṃ addasāma, sace hi mayaṃ nagare🔽avasimha, imaṃ na addasāma. Bhontoti bhavanto sabbepi sumanā bhavantu, tussantu,
analyzed: sabbe iva bhonto sumanāḥ bhavantu yam brāhmaṇaḥ bhisāni iti  tattha su vāsitam isinam eka rattam ti āyasmantānam isīnam eka rattam pi imasmin araññe  vasitam su vasitam eva kiṃkāraṇāḥ yam vāsavam bhūtapatim addasāma sace hi mayam nagare  avasimha imam na addasāma bhonto ti bhavantaḥ sabbe pi sumanāḥ bhavantu tussantu
translated: Let all of you be glad, since the Brahman has received his boon.”

original: sakkassa devarañño khamantu. Kiṃkāraṇā? Yaṃ brāhmaṇo paccupādī bhisāni, yasmā tumhākaṃ🔽ācariyo bhisāni paṭilabhīti.
analyzed: sakkassa deva raññaḥ khamantu kiṃkāraṇāḥ yam brāhmaṇaḥ bhisāni yasmā tumhākam  ācariyaḥ bhisāni
translated: Herein, the sages have dwelt here one night in a pleasant place means that the venerable sages have dwelt here in this forest for one night in a pleasant place. Why? Because we have seen Vāsava, the Lord of Spirits. For if we had dwelt in the city, we would not have seen him. Let all of you be glad, be satisfied, forgive Sakka, the king of the gods. Why? Since the Brahman has received his boon. Because your teacher has received his boon.

original: Sakko isigaṇaṃ vanditvā devalokameva gato. Isigaṇopi jhānābhiññāyo nibbattetvā brahmalokūpago ahosi.
analyzed: sakkaḥ isi gaṇam vanditvā deva lokam eva gataḥ isi gaṇaḥ api jhāna abhiññāyaḥ nibbattetvā brahma loka upagaḥ ahosi
translated: Sakka paid homage to the group of sages and went to the heavenly world. The group of sages, having produced the jhānas and the higher knowledges, went to the Brahma world.

original: Satthā imaṃ dhammadesanaṃ āharitvā “evaṃ bhikkhu porāṇakapaṇḍitā sapathaṃ katvā kilese
analyzed: satthā imam dhamma desanam āharitvā evam bhikkhu porāṇaka paṇḍitā sapatham katvā kilese
translated: The Teacher, having related this dhamma discourse, “Thus, bhikkhu, the wise of old, having made an oath, destroyed their defilements🔽and attained nibbāna.”

original: pajahiṃsū”ti vatvā saccāni pakāsesi, saccapariyosāne ukkaṇṭhitabhikkhu sotāpattiphale🔽patiṭṭhahi. Jātakaṃ samodhānento puna satthā tisso gāthā abhāsi –🔽“Ahañca sāriputto ca, moggallāno ca kassapo;
analyzed: pajahiṃsu iti vatvā saccāni pakāsesi sacca pariyosāne ukkaṇṭhita bhikkhu sotāpatti phale  patiṭṭhahi jātakam samodhānento puna satthā tissaḥ gāthāḥ abhāsi  aham ca sāriputto ca moggallāno ca kassapo
translated: and they were all destroyed.” So saying, he expounded the Law by pronouncing the following Stanzas,

original: Anuruddho puṇṇo ānando, tadāsuṃ satta bhātaro.
analyzed: anuruddhaḥ puṇṇaḥ ānandaḥ tadā āsum satta bhātaraḥ
translated: At the conclusion of the Truths the discontented Brother was established in the Fruit of Conversion. The Teacher, in concluding the lesson, identified the Birth by saying, “At that time the seven brothers were the seven Brethren, the Elder, the Elder Sāriputta, the Elder Moggallāna, the Elder Kassapa, the Elder Anuruddha, the Elder Puṇṇa, and the Elder Ānanda.

original: “Bhaginī uppalavaṇṇā ca, dāsī khujjuttarā tadā;
analyzed: bhaginī uppala vaṇṇā ca dāsī khujjuttarā tadā
translated: The sister was Uppalavaṇṇā, the slave-woman was Khujjuttarā,

original: Citto gahapati dāso, yakkho sātāgiro tadā.
analyzed: cittaḥ gahapati dāsaḥ yakkhaḥ sātāgiraḥ tadā
translated: the slave was Citta the house-holder, and the Yakkha was Sātāgira.

original: “Pālileyyo tadā nāgo, madhudo seṭṭhavānaro;
analyzed: pālileyyaḥ tadā nāgaḥ madhu daḥ seṭṭha vānaraḥ
translated: The Nāga was Pālileyya, the monkey was Madhu the merchant,

original: Kāḷudāyī tadā sakko, evaṃ dhāretha jātaka”nti.🔽Bhisajātakavaṇṇanā pañcamā.
analyzed: kāḷudāyī tadā sakkaḥ evam dhāretha jātakam ti  bhisajātaka vaṇṇanā pañcamā
translated: and Kāḷudāyī was Sakka. Thus should the Birth be remembered.”🔽So said the Exalted One, and the monks rejoiced at his words.

original: [489] 6. Surucijātakavaṇṇanā🔽Mahesī surucino bhariyāti idaṃ satthā sāvatthiṃ upanissāya migāramātupāsāde viharanto
analyzed: mahesī surucinaḥ bhariyā ti idam satthā sāvatthim upanissāya migāra mātu pāsāde viharantaḥ
translated: The Story of the Birth of Suruci.🔽“The wife of Suruci the Great Seer,” etc. This story the Master, while sojourning at Jetavana, told concerning the eight boons granted to the lay-devotee Visākhā.

original: visākhāya mahāupāsikāya laddhe aṭṭha vare ārabbha kathesi. Sā hi ekadivasaṃ jetavane
analyzed: visākhāya mahā upāsikāya laddhe aṭṭha vare ārabbha kathesi sā hi eka divasam jetavane
translated: One day, in the Jetavana,

original: dhammakathaṃ sutvā bhagavantaṃ saddhiṃ bhikkhusaṅghena svātanāya nimantetvā pakkāmi.
analyzed: dhamma katham sutvā bhagavantam saddhim bhikkhu saṅghena svātanāya nimantetvā pakkāmi
translated: and after hearing the Dhamma-talk, invited the Fortunate One together with the Community of monks for the meal on the morrow, and departed.

analyzed: viya nilloma sarīraḥ hutvā nikkhami saḥ lobham nissāya mayā idam dukkham anubhūtaṃ
translated: He thought, “Because of greed I have experienced this suffering.

original: na dāni imaṃ aniggahetvā gocaraṃ gaṇhissāmī”ti cintetvā taṃ assamaṃ gantvā lobhaniggahatthāya
analyzed: na dāni imam a niggahetvā gocaram gaṇhissāmi iti cintetvā tam assamam gantvā lobha niggaha tthāya
translated: Now I will not take my food without first getting rid of this greed.”

original: uposathaṃ samādiyitvā ekamantaṃ nipajji.
analyzed: uposatham samādiyitvā ekamantam nipajji
translated: He went to his hermitage, observed the Uposatha, and lay down on one side.

original: Acchopi araññā nikkhamitvā atricchābhibhūto mallaraṭṭhe paccantagāmaṃ gato. Gāmavāsino
analyzed: acchopi araññā nikkhamitvā atriccha abhibhūtaḥ mallaraṭṭhe paccantagāmam gataḥ gāma vāsinaḥ
translated: The jackal, too, came out of the forest and, overcome by hunger, went to a village in the border country in the Mallan country.

original: “accho kira āgato”ti dhanudaṇḍādihatthā nikkhamitvā tena paviṭṭhaṃ gumbaṃ parivāresuṃ.
analyzed: acchas kiraḥ āgataḥ iti dhanu daṇḍa ādi hatthāḥ nikkhamitvā tena paviṭṭham gumbam parivāresuṃ
translated: The villagers, hearing that the jackal had come, went out with bows and arrows and clubs in their hands and surrounded the thicket in which he had entered.

original: So mahājanena parivāritabhāvaṃ ñatvā nikkhamitvā palāyi, palāyantameva taṃ dhanūhi
analyzed: saḥ mahājanena parivārita bhāvam ñatvā nikkhamitvā palāyi palāyantam eva tam dhanūhi
translated: The jackal, realizing that he was surrounded by a great crowd, came out and ran away.

original: ceva daṇḍādīhi ca pothesuṃ. So bhinnena sīsena lohitena galantena attano vasanaṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: ca iva daṇḍa ādīhi ca pothesum so bhinnena sīsena lohitena galantena attanaḥ vasana ṭhānam
translated: They struck him with their bows and arrows and with their clubs, and with his head broken and blood flowing, he ran to his own dwelling place.

original: gantvā “idaṃ dukkhaṃ mama atricchālobhavasena uppannaṃ, na dāni imaṃ aniggahetvā
analyzed: gantvā idam dukkham mama a tricchā lobha vasena uppannam na dāni imam a niggahetvā
translated: “This suffering has arisen in me through desire and greed. Now I will not let it go uninvestigated.

original: gocaraṃ gaṇhissāmī”ti cintetvā taṃ assamaṃ gantvā atricchāniggahāya uposathaṃ samādiyitvā ekamantaṃ nipajji.🔽Tāpasopi attano jātiṃ nissāya mānavasiko hutvā jhānaṃ uppādetuṃ na sakkoti. Atheko
analyzed: gocaram gaṇhissāmi iti cintetvā tam assamam gantvā atricchā niggahāya uposatham samādiyitvā ekamantam nipajji  tāpasaḥ api attanaḥ jātim nissāya māna vasikaḥ hutvā jhānam uppādetum na sakkoti atha ekaḥ
translated: “This suffering has arisen in me through my greed and covetousness. I will not now go to the forest to seek my food until I have overcome this greed and covetiness.” So saying, he went to his hermitage, observed the Uposatha, and lay down on his side.

original: paccekabuddho tassa mānanissitabhāvaṃ ñatvā “ayaṃ na lāmakasatto, buddhaṅkuro esa,🔽imasmiṃyeva bhaddakappe sabbaññutaṃ pāpuṇissati, imassa mānaniggahaṃ katvā samāpattinibbattanākāraṃ
analyzed: paccekabuddho tassa māna nissita bhāvam ñatvā ayam na lāmaka satto buddhaṅkuraḥ esa  imasmin yeva bhadda kappe sabbaññu tam pāpuṇissati imassa māna niggaham katvā samāpatti nibbattana ākāram
translated: The ascetic, on the other hand, was so proud of his birth that he was unable to attain absorption. Thereupon a certain Independent Buddha, perceiving that the ascetic was so proud of his birth, thought to himself, “This is not a wicked creature; this is a sprout of a Buddha.

original: karissāmī”ti tasmiṃ paṇṇasālāya nisinneyeva uttarahimavantato āgantvā tassa pāsāṇaphalake
analyzed: karissāmi iti tasmin paṇṇa sālāya nisinneya iva uttara himavantataḥ āgantvā tassa pāsāṇa phalake
translated: In the very same auspicious aeon he will attain omniscience. I will therefore overcome his pride and cause him to attain absorption.” Accordingly he went to the Northland and sat down on a certain rock.

original: nisīdi. So nikkhamitvā taṃ attano āsane nisinnaṃ disvā mānanissitabhāvena anattamano
analyzed: nisīdi saḥ nikkhamitvā tam attanaḥ āsane nisinnam disvā māna nissita bhāvena anatta manaḥ
translated: The ascetic, as soon as he saw him, was filled with pride and thought to himself, “Who is this that sits down on my seat?”

original: hutvā taṃ upasaṅkamitvā accharaṃ paharitvā “nassa, vasala, kāḷakaṇṇi, muṇḍaka, samaṇaka,
analyzed: hutvā tam upasaṅkamitvā accharam paharitvā nassa vasala kāḷakaṇṇi muṇḍaka samaṇaka
translated: and after approaching him, he struck the gong and said, “Die, you black-eared, shaven-headed, ascetic,

original: kimatthaṃ mama nisinnaphalake nisinnosī”ti āha. Atha naṃ so “sappurisa, kasmā mānanissitosi,
analyzed: kimattham mama nisinna phalake nisinnaḥ asi iti āha atha nam saḥ sappurisa kasmā māna nissitaḥ asi
translated: for what purpose do you sit on my seat?” Then he said to him, “Good man, why are you so full of pride?

original: ahaṃ paṭividdhapaccekabodhiñāṇo, tvaṃ imasmiṃyeva bhaddakappe sabbaññubuddho bhavissasi,🔽buddhaṅkurosi, pāramiyo pūretvā āgato aññaṃ ettakaṃ nāma kālaṃ atikkamitvā buddho
analyzed: aham paṭividdha pacceka bodhi ñāṇo tvam imasmin yeva bhadda kappe sabbaññu buddhaḥ bhavissasi  buddhaṅkuro asi pāramiyaḥ pūretvā āgataḥ aññam ettakam nāma kālam atikkamitvā buddhaḥ
translated: I have penetrated the knowledge of Paccekabodhi, and you will become a Buddha in this auspicious aeon,🔽you are a Buddha-sprout, after fulfilling the Perfections you have come, and after passing a certain time you will become a Buddha,

original: bhavissasi, buddhattabhāve ṭhito siddhattho nāma bhavissasī”ti nāmañca gottañca kulañca
analyzed: bhavissasi buddhatta bhāve ṭhitaḥ siddhatthaḥ nāma bhavissasi iti nāmañca gottañca kulañca
translated: you will be established in the state of Buddhahood, and will be called Siddhattha.” And after telling him his name, family, clan,

original: aggasāvakādayo ca sabbe ācikkhitvā “kimatthaṃ tvaṃ mānanissito hutvā pharuso hosi,
analyzed: aggasāvaka ādayaḥ ca sabbe ācikkhitvā kimattham tvam māna nissitaḥ hutvā pharusaḥ hosi
translated: and all his chief disciples, etc., he said, “For what purpose are you so full of pride and so harsh?

original: nayidaṃ tava anucchavika”nti ovādamadāsi. So tena evaṃ vuttopi neva naṃ vandi, na
analyzed: na yidam tava anucchavikam ti ovādam adāsi saḥ tena evam vuttaḥ api na iva nam vandi na
translated: This is not suitable for you.” He gave him this advice. Although he was spoken to in this way, he neither worshipped him, nor asked,

original: ca “kadāhaṃ buddho bhavissāmī”tiādīni pucchi. Atha naṃ paccekabuddho “tava jātiyā
analyzed: ca kadā aham buddhaḥ bhavissāmi iti ādīni pucchi atha nam paccekabuddho tava jātiyā
translated: “When will I become a Buddha?” etc. Then the Paccekabuddha said, “At the time of your birth,

original: mama guṇānaṃ mahantabhāvaṃ jāna, sace sakkosi, ahaṃ viya ākāse vicarāhī”ti vatvā🔽ākāse uppatitvā attano pādapaṃsuṃ tassa jaṭāmaṇḍale vikiranto uttarahimavantameva gato.🔽Tāpaso tassa gatakāle saṃvegappatto hutvā “ayaṃ samaṇo evaṃ garusarīro vātamukhe
analyzed: mama mahanta bhāvam jāna sace sakkosi aham viyas ākāse vicarāhi iti vatvā  ākāse uppatitvā attano pāda paṃsum tassa jaṭā maṇḍale vikirantaḥ uttara himavantam eva gataḥ  tāpaso tassa gata kāle saṃvega ppattaḥ hutvā ayam samaṇaḥ evam garu sarīraḥ vāta mukhe
translated: “If you can, know the greatness of my virtues, and fly through the air as I do.”🔽And having said this, he flew up into the air, and scattering the dust of his feet upon the head of the ascetic, returned to the Himalayas.

original: khittatūlapicu viya ākāse pakkhando, ahaṃ jātimānena evarūpassa paccekabuddhassa
analyzed: khitta tūla picu viya ākāse pakkhandaḥ aham jāti mānena evarūpassa paccekabuddhassa
translated: When the ascetic saw him depart, he was filled with remorse, and said to himself, “This monk, though his body was so heavy, flew through the air like a tuft of cotton carried on the wings of the wind.

original: neva pāde vandiṃ, na ca “kadāhaṃ buddho bhavissāmī’ti pucchiṃ, jāti nāmesā kiṃ karissati,
analyzed: na iva pāde vandim na ca kadā aham buddhaḥ bhavissāmi iti pucchim jāti nāma isā kim karissati
translated: I, though born of a noble family, did not bow down at the feet of such a Paccekabuddha, nor did I ask him, ‘When shall I become a Buddha?’ What is the use of birth?

original: imasmiṃ loke sīlacaraṇameva mahantaṃ, ayaṃ kho pana me māno vaḍḍhanto nirayaṃ upanessati,
analyzed: imasmin loke sīla caraṇam eva mahantam ayam kho pana me mānaḥ vaḍḍhantaḥ nirayam upanessati
translated: In this world the practice of virtue is the most important thing. But this pride of mine, if I allow it to increase, will lead me to hell.

original: na idāni imaṃ mānaṃ aniggahetvā phalāphalatthāya gamissāmī”ti paṇṇasālaṃ pavisitvā
analyzed: na idāni imam mānam a niggahetvā phala a phala tthāya gamissāmi iti paṇṇa sālam pavisitvā
translated: I will not go out to gather fruits until I have subdued this pride.” So saying, he entered his leaf-hut,

original: mānaniggahāya uposathaṃ samādāya kaṭṭhattharikāya nisinno mahāñāṇo kulaputto mānaṃ
analyzed: māna niggahāya uposatham samādāya kaṭṭhattharikāya nisinnaḥ mahāñāṇaḥ kula putto mānam
translated: and taking upon himself the Uposatha observances for the purpose of subduing his pride, he sat down cross-legged upon a bundle of straw.

original: niggahetvā kasiṇaṃ vaḍḍhetvā abhiññā ca samāpattiyo ca nibbattetvā nikkhamitvā caṅkamanakoṭiyaṃ
analyzed: niggahetvā kasiṇam vaḍḍhetvā abhiññā ca samāpattiyo ca nibbattetvā nikkhamitvā caṅkamana koṭiyam
translated: and having expanded the kasiṇa, he produced the direct knowledges and the eight attainments, and having emerged, he went to the end of the walking path.

original: pāsāṇaphalake nisīdi. Atha naṃ kapotādayo upasaṅkamitvā vanditvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu.🔽Mahāsatto kapotaṃ pucchi “tvaṃ aññesu divasesu na imāya velāya āgacchasi, gocaraṃ🔽pariyesasi, kiṃ nu kho ajja uposathiko jātosī”ti? “Āma bhante”ti. Atha naṃ “kena
analyzed: pāsāṇa phalake atha nam kapota ādayaḥ upasaṅkamitvā vanditvā ekamantam nisīdiṃsu  mahāsatto kapotam pucchi tvam aññesu divasesu na imāya velāya āgacchasi gocaram  pariyesasi kim nu kho ajja uposathikaḥ jātaḥ asi iti āma bhante iti atha nam kena
translated: and having emerged, he sat down on a flat stone at the end of the walk. Then the doves and the rest came and paid obeisance to him and sat down on one side.

original: kāraṇenā”ti pucchanto paṭhamaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: kāraṇena ati pucchantaḥ paṭhamam gātham āha
translated: The Great Being asked the dove, “On other days you do not come at this time, but seek your food; why is it that to-day you have become one who observes the fast-day?” “Yes, venerable sir.” Then asking the reason, he spoke the first stanza:

original: “Appossukko dāni tuvaṃ kapota, vihaṅgama na tava bhojanattho;
analyzed: appa ussukkaḥ dāni tuvam kapota vihaṅgama na tava bhojana tthaḥ
translated: “You are now, dove, without a care; you have no need of food, O bird;

original: Khudaṃ pipāsaṃ adhivāsayanto, kasmā bhavaṃposathiko kapotā”ti.
analyzed: khudam pipāsam adhivāsayantaḥ kasmai kapota ati
translated: Putting away hunger and thirst, why, O dove, do you observe the fast-day?”

original: Tattha appossukkoti nirālayo. Na tava bhojanatthoti kiṃ ajja tava bhojanena attho natthi.
analyzed: tattha appossukkaḥ ti nirālayaḥ na tava bhojana attho ti kim ajja tava bhojanena atthaḥ natthi
translated: Herein, without a care means without a support. You have no need of food means have you no need of food to-day?

original: Taṃ sutvā kapoto dve gāthā abhāsi –
analyzed: tam sutvā kapotaḥ dve gāthāḥ abhāsi
translated: Having heard this, the dove spoke two stanzas:

original: “Ahaṃ pure giddhigato kapotiyā, asmiṃ padesasmimubho ramāma;
analyzed: aham pure kapotiyāḥ asmin padesasmin ubhaḥ ramāma
translated: “Formerly, I was a hunter, and I was a snare-setter in this place; I and the dove here both enjoyed ourselves;

original: Athaggahī sākuṇiko kapotiṃ, akāmako tāya vinā ahosiṃ.
analyzed: athaggahī sākuṇikaḥ kapotim akāmako tāya vinā ahosiṃ
translated: The fowler caught the dove, and I was left without my mate.

original: “Nānābhavā vippayogena tassā, manomayaṃ vedana vedayāmi;
analyzed: nānā bhavā vippayogena tassāḥ manaḥ mayam vedana vedayāmi
translated: “I am in a different state, and separated from her; I feel a mental feeling.

original: Tasmā ahaṃposathaṃ pālayāmi, rāgo mamaṃ mā punarāgamāsī”ti.
analyzed: tasmai ahaṃposatham pālayāmi rāgaḥ mamam mā punar āgamāsi iti
translated: Therefore I keep the fast-day; let passion come to me no more.”

original: Tattha ramāmāti imasmiṃ bhūmibhāge kāmaratiyā ramāma. Sākuṇikoti senasakuṇo.
analyzed: tattha ramāma ati imasmin bhūmi bhāge kāma ratiyā ramāma sākuṇikaḥ iti sena sakuṇaḥ
translated: Herein, we delight means we delight in sensual pleasure in this place. Fowler means a bird-catcher.

original: Kapotena attano uposathakamme vaṇṇite mahāsatto sappādīsu ekekaṃ pucchi. Tepi yathābhūtaṃ byākariṃsu –
analyzed: kapotena attanaḥ uposatha kamme vaṇṇite mahāsatto sappa ādīsu ekekam pucchi te pi yathābhūtam byākariṃsu
translated: When the dove had extolled his own fast-day observance, the Great Being asked each of the others, snake and so on, in turn. They too spoke the truth:

original: “Anujjugāmī uragā dujivha, dāṭhāvudho ghoravisosi sappa;
analyzed: uragā dujivha dāṭhāvudhaḥ sappa
translated: “The snakes are double-tongued, the vipers are armed with fangs and have terrible poison;

original: Khudaṃ pipāsaṃ adhivāsayanto, kasmā bhavaṃposathiko nu dīgha.
analyzed: khudam pipāsam adhivāsayantaḥ kasmai bhavaṃposathikaḥ nu dīgha
translated: Bearing hunger and thirst, why do you keep the fast, good sir?

original: “Usabho ahū balavā gāmikassa, calakkakū vaṇṇabalūpapanno;
analyzed: usabhaḥ ahū balavā gāmikassa calakkakū vaṇṇa bala upapanno
translated: “The bull was strong, the lord of the herd, and he was well-grown with a fine coat;

original: So maṃ akkami taṃ kupito aḍaṃsiṃ, dukkhābhituṇṇo maraṇaṃ upāgā.
analyzed: saḥ mam akkami tam kupitaḥ aḍaṃsim dukkha abhituṇṇaḥ maraṇam upāgā
translated: He came to me, and in anger I gored him; he was overcome with pain and died.

original: “Tato janā nikkhamitvāna gāmā, kanditvā roditvā apakkamiṃsu;
analyzed: tatas janāḥ nikkhamitvāna gāmā kanditvā roditvā apakkamiṃsu
translated: “Then the people came out from the village, and after weeping and wailing they left;

original: Tasmā ahaṃposathaṃ pālayāmi, kodho mamaṃ mā punarāgamāsi.
analyzed: tasmai ahaṃposatham pālayāmi kodhaḥ mā punar āgamāsi
translated: Therefore I observe the Uposatha, let anger not come to me again.

original: “Matāna maṃsāni bahū susāne, manuññarūpaṃ tava bhojane taṃ;
analyzed: matāna maṃsāni bahū susāne manuñña rūpam tava bhojane tam
translated: “My own flesh is abundant in the charnel ground, that is your fine food, sir.

original: Khudaṃ pipāsaṃ adhivāsayanto, kasmā bhavaṃposathiko siṅgāla.
analyzed: khudam pipāsam adhivāsayantaḥ kasmai bhavaṃposathikaḥ siṅgāla
translated: Enduring hunger and thirst, why do you observe the Uposatha, O jackal?

original: “Pavisi kucchiṃ mahato gajassa, kuṇape rato hatthimaṃsesu giddho;
analyzed: pavisi kucchim mahataḥ gajassa kuṇape rataḥ hatthi maṃsesu giddhaḥ
translated: “I entered the belly of a great elephant, delighting in offal, greedy for elephant flesh,

original: Uṇho ca vāto tikhiṇā ca rasmiyo, te sosayuṃ tassa karīsamaggaṃ.
analyzed: uṇhaḥ ca vātaḥ tikhiṇā ca rasmiyaḥ te sosayum tassa karīsa maggam
translated: and a hot wind and sharp rays of light, they scorched his path of excrement.

original: “Kiso ca paṇḍū ca ahaṃ bhadante, na me ahū nikkhamanāya maggo;
analyzed: kiso ca paṇḍū ca aham bhadante na me nikkhamanāya maggo
translated: “I am thin and pale, venerable sir, I had no way of escape.

original: Mahā ca megho sahasā pavassi, so temayī tassa karīsamaggaṃ.
analyzed: mahā ca meghaḥ sahasā pavassi saḥ temayī tassa karīsa maggam
translated: And a great cloud suddenly poured down rain, it filled up his path of excrement.

original: “Tato ahaṃ nikkhamisaṃ bhadante, cando yathā rāhumukhā pamutto;
analyzed: tatas aham nikkhamisam bhadante candaḥ yathā rāhu mukhā pamuttaḥ
translated: “Then I came out, venerable sir, like the moon released from Rāhu’s mouth.

original: Tasmā ahaṃposathaṃ pālayāmi, lobho mamaṃ mā punarāgamāsi.
analyzed: tasmai ahaṃposatham pālayāmi lobhaḥ mā punar āgamāsi
translated: Therefore I observe the Uposatha, let greed not come to me again.

original: “Vammīkathūpasmiṃ kipillikāni, nippothayanto tuvaṃ pure carāsi;
analyzed: vammīkathūpasmin kipillikāni nippothayantaḥ tuvam pure carāsi
translated: “On the Vammī hill you used to wander about in the past, crushing ants,

original: Khudaṃ pipāsaṃ adhivāsayanto, kasmā bhavaṃposathiko nu accha.
analyzed: khudam pipāsam adhivāsayantaḥ kasmai bhavaṃposathikaḥ nu accha
translated: enduring hunger and thirst, why do you observe the Uposatha, O mongoose?

original: “Sakaṃ niketaṃ atihīḷayāno, atricchatā mallagāmaṃ agacchiṃ;
analyzed: sakam niketam ati hīḍayānaḥ malla gāmam agacchim
translated: “I left my home and went to Mallagama,

original: Tato janā nikkhamitvāna gāmā, kodaṇḍakena paripothayiṃsu maṃ.
analyzed: tatas janāḥ nikkhamitvāna gāmā kodaṇḍakena paripothayiṃsu mam
translated: And from the village people came forth and beat me with sticks.

original: “So bhinnasīso ruhiramakkhitaṅgo, paccāgamāsiṃ sakaṃ niketaṃ;
analyzed: saḥ bhinna sīsaḥ ruhira makkhitaṅgo paccā agamāsim sakam niketam
translated: “With head split open and body smeared with blood,🔽I returned to my home.

original: Tasmā ahaṃposathaṃ pālayāmi, atricchatā mā punarāgamāsī”ti.🔽Tattha anujjugāmītiādīhi taṃ ālapati. Calakkakūti calamānakakudho. Dukkhābhituṇṇoti🔽so usabho dukkhena abhituṇṇo āturo hutvā. Bahūti bahūni. Pavisīti pāvisiṃ. Rasmiyoti🔽sūriyarasmiyo. Nikkhamisanti nikkhamiṃ. Kipillikānīti upacikāyo. Nippothayantoti
analyzed: tasmai ahaṃposatham pālayāmi mā punar āgamāsi iti  tattha anujjugāmī itiādīhi tam ālapati calakkakūti calamāna kakudhaḥ dukkha abhituṇṇaḥ ti  saḥ usabhaḥ dukkhena abhituṇṇaḥ āturaḥ hutvā bahūti bahūni pavisī iti pāvisim rasmiyā uti  sūriya rasmiyaḥ nikkhamisanti nikkhamim kipillikāni iti upacikāyaḥ nippothayantaḥ iti
translated: Therefore I keep the Uposatha, lest I come again to such a state.”

original: khādamāno. Atihīḷayānoti atimaññanto nindanto garahanto. Kodaṇḍakenāti dhanudaṇḍakehi ceva muggarehi ca.
analyzed: khādamānaḥ ati hīḷayānaḥ iti atimaññantaḥ nindantaḥ garahantaḥ kodaṇḍakena ati dhanu daṇḍakehi ca iva muggarehi ca
translated: Here the king addresses the bull, saying, “You who are restless,” etc. “Restless” means restless-minded. “With pain exceeding great” means with pain exceeding great, with pain that is excessive. “Many” means many kinds of. “I entered” means I went in. “The sun’s rays” means the sun’s rays. “I came forth” means I came out. “Ant-hills” means anthills. “I broke” means I broke them. “I ate” means I ate. “I despised” means I despised, I scorned, I reproved. “With sticks” means with bow-sticks and with beans.

original: Evaṃ te cattāropi attano uposathakammaṃ vaṇṇetvā uṭṭhāya mahāsattaṃ vanditvā “bhante,
analyzed: evam te cattāro api attanaḥ uposatha kammam vaṇṇetvā uṭṭhāya mahāsattam vanditvā bhante
translated: Having thus extolled their own Uposatha observance, the four kings rose up and paid homage to the Great Being, saying, “Venerable Sir,

original: tumhe aññesu divasesu imāya velāya phalāphalatthāya gacchatha, ajja agantvā kasmā

translated: Herein, what you asked us is the matter about which you asked us. According to our knowledge

analyzed: tam mayam byākarimha an upalittaḥ ti sabba kilesehi a littaḥ saḥ mama avedi iti saḥ mama idāni

translated: “The Moon and the Sun, both of them beautiful to behold, go shining through the sky;
