analyzed: imassa lokassa parassa vā te katham nu te āhu manussa loka iti
translated: Do they say that they are of this world or of the other world, or of the world of men?”

original: Tattha imassāti kiṃ nu te imassa lokassa santi, udāhu paralokassāti. Bhummatthe vā🔽etaṃ sāmivacanaṃ. Kathaṃ nu teti etesu vimānesu candimasūriyadevaputte kathaṃ nu
analyzed: tattha imassa ati kim nu te imassa lokassa santi udāhu para lokassa ati bhumma tthe vā  etam sāmi vacanam katham nu te iti etesu vimānesu candima sūriya deva putte katham nu
translated: Herein, of this world means: do they say that they are of this world, or of the other world? Or this is a word of ownership

original: kathenti, kiṃ atthīti kathenti, udāhu natthīti, kiṃ vā devā, udāhu manussāti?
analyzed: kathenti kim atthi iti kathenti udāhu natthi iti kim vā devāḥ udāhu manussā ati
translated: in the sense of object. Do they say that they are of the world of men?

original: Luddaputto gāthamāha –
analyzed: luddaputtaḥ gātham āha
translated: The son of the hunter spoke this verse:

original: “Cando ca suriyo ca ubho sudassanā, gacchanti obhāsayamantalikkhe;
analyzed: cando ca suriyo ca ubho sudassanā gacchanti
translated: “The Moon and the Sun, both of them beautiful to behold, go shining through the sky;

original: Parassa lokassa na te imassa, devāti te āhu manussaloke”ti.
analyzed: parassa lokassa na te imassa deva ati te āhu manussa loka iti
translated: In the world of men they call you ‘god.’ ”

original: Atha naṃ mahāsatto āha –
analyzed: atha nam mahāsattaḥ āha
translated: Then the Great Being said:🔽“Here have been slain the low-voiced ones,

original: “Ettheva te nīhatā hīnavādā, ahetukā ye na vadanti kammaṃ;
analyzed: ettha iva te nīhatāḥ hīna vādāḥ ahetukāḥ ye na vadanti kammaṃ
translated: Who say that there is no such thing as action,🔽And that the fruit of good and evil deeds

original: Tathā phalaṃ sukatadukkaṭānaṃ, dattupaññattaṃ ye ca vadanti dāna”nti.
analyzed: tathā phalam su kata dukkaṭānam dattu paññattam ye ca vadanti dānan ti
translated: Is not a thing that has been made by giving. ”

original: Tattha ettheva te nihatā hīnavādāti sace candimasūriyā devaloke ṭhitā, na manussaloke,
analyzed: tattha ettha iva te nihatāḥ hīna vādāḥ ati sace candima sūriyāḥ deva loke ṭhitāḥ na manussa loke
translated: Herein, here have been slain the low-voiced ones means: if the moon and sun are in the world of the gods, not in the world of men,

original: sace ca te devā, na manussā, ettheva ettake byākaraṇe te tava kulūpakā hīnavādā nīhatā
analyzed: sace ca te devāḥ na manussāḥ etthā iva ettake byākaraṇe te tava kulūpakāḥ hīna vādāḥ nīhatā
translated: and if the gods are not men, then here, in this very explanation, your low-voiced supporters have been slain.

original: honti. Ahetukā “visuddhiyā vā saṃkilesassa vā hetubhūtaṃ kammaṃ natthī”ti evaṃvādā.
analyzed: honti ahetukāḥ visuddhiyā vā saṃkilesassa vā hetu bhūtam kammam natthi iti evaṃvādāḥ
translated: Who say that there is no such thing as action means: those who say that there is no such thing as action which is the cause of either purification or defilement.

original: Dattupaññattanti ye ca dānaṃ “bālakehi paññatta”nti vadanti.
analyzed: dattu paññattanti ye ca dānam bālakehi paññattanti vadanti
translated: And that the fruit of good and evil deeds is not a thing that has been made by giving means: those who say that giving is a thing that has been made by children.

original: So mahāsatte kathente sallakkhetvā gāthādvayamāha –
analyzed: saḥ mahāsatte kathente gāthā dvayam āha
translated: As the Great Being was speaking, the king observed him and spoke two verses:🔽“Surely true is this your word,

original: “Addhā hi saccaṃ vacanaṃ tavedaṃ, kathañhi dānaṃ aphalaṃ bhaveyya;
analyzed: addhā hi saccam vacanam tava idam katham hi dānam aphalam
translated: For how can giving fail to bear fruit?

original: Tathā phalaṃ sukatadukkaṭānaṃ, dattupaññattañca kathaṃ bhaveyya.
analyzed: tathā phalam dattu paññattam ca katham
translated: How can there be the giving of gifts, and the making of merit?

original: “Kathaṃkaro kintikaro kimācaraṃ, kiṃ sevamāno kena tapoguṇena;
analyzed: kathaṃkaraḥ kintikaraḥ kimācaram kim sevamānaḥ kena tapaḥ guṇena
translated: “What is the deed, what is the cause, what is the practice, what is the service, what is the virtue of austerity,

original: Akkhāhi me morarājetamatthaṃ, yathā ahaṃ no nirayaṃ pateyya”nti.
analyzed: akkhāhi me yathā aham naḥ nirayam pateyyanti
translated: By which, O King of Birds, I may not fall into hell?”

original: Tattha dattupaññattañcāti dānañca dattupaññattaṃ nāma kathaṃ bhaveyyāti attho. Kathaṃkaroti
analyzed: tattha dattu paññattam ca ati dānam ca dattu paññattam nāma katham bhaveyya ati attho kathaṃkaroti
translated: Herein, “the giving of gifts” means the giving of gifts and the making of merit.🔽“What is the deed?” means what kind of deed is it that I should do.

original: katarakammaṃ karonto. Kintikaroti kena kāraṇena karonto ahaṃ nirayaṃ na gaccheyyaṃ.
analyzed: katara kammam karontaḥ kinti karoti kena kāraṇena karontaḥ aham nirayam na gaccheyyam
translated: “By what cause” means by what cause should I do it.

original: Itarāni tasseva vevacanāni.
analyzed: itarāni tassa iva vevacanāni
translated: “What is the practice?” and “what is the service?” are synonyms for the same thing.🔽“What is the virtue of austerity?” means what is the virtue of austerity.

original: Taṃ sutvā mahāsatto “sacāhaṃ imaṃ pañhaṃ na kathessāmi, manussaloko tuccho viya kato
analyzed: tam sutvā mahāsatto sacā aham imam pañham na kathessāmi manussa lokaḥ tucchaḥ viya kato
translated: Having heard this, the Great Being thought: “If I do not answer this question, the world of men will be as if emptied.🔽I will therefore tell him about the existence of righteous ascetics and brahmans.”

original: bhavissati, tathevassa dhammikānaṃ samaṇabrāhmaṇānaṃ atthibhāvaṃ kathessāmī”ti cintetvā dve gāthā abhāsi –🔽“Ye keci atthi samaṇā pathabyā, kāsāyavatthā anagāriyā te;
analyzed: bhavissati tathā iva assa dhammikānam samaṇa brāhmaṇānam atthi bhāvam kathessāmi iti cintetvā dve gāthāḥ abhāsi 🔽ye keci atthi samaṇā pathabyā kāsāyavatthāḥ anagāriyā te
translated: And so he spoke two verses:

original: Pātova piṇḍāya caranti kāle, vikālacariyā viratā hi santo.
analyzed: pāta uva piṇḍāya caranti kāle vikāla cariyāḥ viratāḥ hi santaḥ
translated: They go for alms at the proper time, and they have given up going at the wrong time.

original: “Te tattha kālenupasaṅkamitvā, pucchāhi yaṃ te manaso piyaṃ siyā;
analyzed: te tattha kālena upasaṅkamitvā pucchāhi yam te manasaḥ piyam siyā
translated: “Go there at the proper time and ask them, whatever question you may wish to ask;

original: Te te pavakkhanti yathāpajānaṃ, imassa lokassa parassa cattha”nti.
analyzed: te te pavakkhanti yathāpajānam imassa lokassa parassa catthanti
translated: They will answer you according to their knowledge, the meaning of this world and the next.”

original: Tattha santoti santapāpā paṇḍitā paccekabuddhā. Yathāpajānanti te tuyhaṃ attano pajānananiyāmena
analyzed: tattha santā iti santa pāpā paṇḍitā paccekabuddhāḥ yathā apajānanti te tuyham attano pajānana niyāmena
translated: Herein, they are good, i.e. they have quieted evil, they are wise, they are Paccekabuddhas. According to their knowledge: they will answer you according to their own knowledge.

original: vakkhanti, kaṅkhaṃ te chinditvā kathessanti. Imassa lokassa parassa catthanti iminā
analyzed: vakkhanti kaṅkham te chinditvā kathessanti imassa lokassa parassa catthanti iminā
translated: They will cut off your doubt and tell you. The meaning of this world and the next: they will explain the meaning of this world and the next thus:

original: nāma kammena manussaloke nibbattanti, iminā devaloke, iminā nirayādīsūti evaṃ imassa
analyzed: nāma kammena manussa loke nibbattanti iminā deva loke iminā niraya ādīsu iti evam imassa
translated: “By this deed one is reborn in the world of men, by this in the world of the gods, by this in hell, etc.”

original: ca parassa ca lokassa atthaṃ ācikkhissanti, te pucchāti.
analyzed: ca parassa ca lokassa attham ācikkhissanti te pucchāti
translated: Ask them.

original: Evañca pana vatvā nirayabhayena tajjesi. So pana pūritapāramī paccekabodhisatto sūriyarasmisamphassaṃ
analyzed: evañca pana vatvā niraya bhayena tajjesi saḥ pana pūrita pāramī pacceka bodhisatto sūriya rasmi samphassam
translated: Having said this, he admonished him with the fear of hell. But that Paccekabuddha, who had fulfilled the Perfections,

original: oloketvā ṭhitaṃ pariṇatapadumaṃ viya paripākagatañāṇo vicarati. So tassa dhammakathaṃ🔽suṇanto ṭhitapadeneva ṭhito saṅkhāre pariggaṇhitvā tilakkhaṇaṃ sammasanto paccekabodhiñāṇaṃ
analyzed: oloketvā ṭhitam pariṇata padumam viya paripāka gata ñāṇaḥ vicarati saḥ tassa dhamma katham  suṇantaḥ ṭhita padena iva ṭhitaḥ saṅkhāre pariggaṇhitvā ti lakkhaṇam sammasantaḥ pacceka bodhi ñāṇam
translated: His knowledge was ripe, like a lotus that has reached its full development.🔽As he listened to the Dhamma, he stood on the plane of the fruit of conversion. He discerned formations and comprehended the three characteristics.

original: paṭivijjhi. Tassa paṭivedho ca mahāsattassa pāsato mokkho ca ekakkhaṇeyeva ahosi.
analyzed: paṭivijjhi tassa paṭivedhaḥ ca mahāsattassa pāsataḥ mokkho ca eka khaṇeya iva ahosi
translated: He penetrated the knowledge of paccekabodhi. His penetration and the great being’s release from the snare were simultaneous.

original: Paccekabuddho sabbakilese padāletvā bhavapariyante ṭhitova udānaṃ udānanto gāthamāha –
analyzed: paccekabuddhaḥ sabba kilese padāletvā bhava pariyante ṭhitaḥ uva udānam udānantaḥ gātham āha
translated: The paccekabuddha, having burst asunder all the defilements, stood at the end of the round of rebirths and uttered this exalted utterance:🔽“As a snake casts off its old skin,

original: “Tacaṃva jiṇṇaṃ urago purāṇaṃ, paṇḍūpalāsaṃ harito dumova;
analyzed: tacam iva jiṇṇam uragaḥ purāṇam paṇḍū palāsam haritaḥ
translated: As a tree casts off its withered leaves,🔽So have I cast off my state of a hunter,

original: Esappahīno mama luddabhāvo, jahāmahaṃ luddakabhāvamajjā”ti.
analyzed: mama ludda bhāvaḥ jahāmaham luddaka bhāvam ajja ati
translated: I have left behind the state of a hunter.”

original: Tassattho – yathā jiṇṇaṃ purāṇaṃ tacaṃ urago jahati, yathā ca harito sampajjamānanīlapatto
analyzed: tassa atthaḥ yathā jiṇṇam purāṇam tacam uragaḥ jahati yathā ca haritaḥ sampajjamāna nīla pattaḥ
translated: The meaning is this: Just as a snake casts off its old skin, and just as a tree casts off its withered leaves,

original: dumo katthaci ṭhitaṃ paṇḍupalāsaṃ jahati, evaṃ ahampi ajja luddabhāvaṃ dāruṇabhāvaṃ
analyzed: katthaci ṭhitam paṇḍu palāsam jahati evam aham pi ajja ludda bhāvam dāruṇa bhāvam
translated: so also have I today cast off my state of a hunter, my state of cruelty.

original: jahitvā ṭhito, so dāni esa pahīno mama luddabhāvo, sādhu vata jahāmahaṃ luddakabhāvamajjāti.
analyzed: jahitvā ṭhitaḥ saḥ dāni esa pahīnaḥ mama ludda bhāvo sādhu vata jahām aham luddaka bhāvam ajja ati
translated: I have renounced the life of a hunter, and now I have given up the life of a hunter. Excellent, indeed, is the renunciation of the life of a hunter.

original: Jahāmahanti pajahiṃ ahanti attho.🔽So imaṃ udānaṃ udānetvā “ahaṃ tāva sabbakilesabandhanehi mutto, nivesane pana me
analyzed: jahāmahanti pajahim ahanti attho  saḥ imam udānam udānetvā aham tāva sabba kilesa bandhanehi muttaḥ nivesane pana me
translated: Jahāmahaṃ means I shall abandon.

original: bandhitvā ṭhapitā bahū sakuṇā atthi, te kathaṃ mocessāmī”ti cintetvā mahāsattaṃ pucchi
analyzed: bandhitvā ṭhapitāḥ bahū sakuṇāḥ atthi te katham mocessāmi iti cintetvā mahāsattam pucchi
translated: Having uttered this Solemn Utterance, he thought to himself, “I am now freed from all the bonds of sin, but in my house there are many birds which I have caught and confined. How shall I set them free?” And he asked the Great Being,

original: – “morarāja, nivesane me bahū sakuṇā baddhā atthi, te kathaṃ mocessāmī”ti? Paccekabuddhatopi
analyzed: mora rāja nivesane me bahū sakuṇāḥ baddhāḥ atthi te katham mocessāmi iti paccekabuddhataḥ pi
translated: “King of Birds, in my house there are many birds which I have caught and confined. How shall I set them free?” The Paccekabuddha

original: sabbaññubodhisattānaññeva upāyapariggahañāṇaṃ mahantataraṃ hoti, tena naṃ āha “yaṃ
analyzed: upāya pariggaha ñāṇam mahantataram hoti tena nam āha yam
translated: had a greater knowledge of the means of attaining the end in view than even the Omniscient Bodhisatta, and therefore he said to him,

original: vo maggena kilese khaṇḍetvā paccekabodhiñāṇaṃ paṭividdhaṃ, taṃ ārabbha saccakiriyaṃ
analyzed: vaḥ maggena kilese khaṇḍetvā pacceka bodhi ñāṇam paṭividdham tam ārabbha sacca kiriyam
translated: “By the path by which you have broken the bonds of sin and attained the knowledge of a Paccekabuddha, by that very path you must perform the act of truth,

original: karotha, sakalajambudīpe bandhanagato satto nāma na bhavissatī”ti. So bodhisattena
analyzed: karotha sakala jambudīpe bandhana gataḥ satto nāma na bhavissati iti saḥ bodhisattena
translated: and there will not be a single living being in all the world that is bound in prison.” The hunter,

original: dinnanayadvāre ṭhatvā saccakiriyaṃ karonto gāthamāha –
analyzed: dinnanaya dvāre ṭhatvā saccakiriyam karontaḥ gātham āha
translated: standing in the door of the way of salvation given him by the Bodhisatta, and performing the act of truth, uttered the following Stanza,

original: “Ye cāpi me sakuṇā atthi baddhā, satāninekāni nivesanasmiṃ;
analyzed: ye ca api me sakuṇāḥ atthi baddhā nivesanasmin
translated: “And all the birds that I have caught, so many in my house,

original: Tesampahaṃ jīvitamajja dammi, mokkhañca te pattā sakaṃ niketa”nti.
analyzed: tesam paham jīvitam ajja dammi mokkham ca te pattā sakam niketanti
translated: I give them life this day, and let them fly away to their own haunts.”

original: Tattha mokkhañca te pattāti svāhaṃ mokkhaṃ patto paccekabodhiñāṇaṃ paṭivijjhitvā
analyzed: tattha mokkham ca te pattā ati svāham mokkham pattaḥ pacceka bodhi ñāṇam paṭivijjhitvā
translated: Herein, and let them fly away to their own haunts means that I have attained deliverance, having penetrated the knowledge of the individual enlightenment,

original: ṭhito, te satte jīvitadānena anukampāmi, etena saccena. Sakaṃ niketanti sabbepi te
analyzed: ṭhitaḥ te satte jīvita dānena anukampāmi etena saccena sakam sabbe api te
translated: and I have compassion on these creatures by giving them life. By this truth,

original: sattā attano attano vasanaṭṭhānaṃ gacchantūti vadati.
analyzed: sattāḥ attanaḥ attanaḥ vasanaṭṭhānam gacchantu iti vadati
translated: all these creatures go to their own abodes.

original: Athassa saccakiriyāsamakālameva sabbe bandhanā muccitvā tuṭṭhiravaṃ ravantā sakaṭṭhānameva🔽agamiṃsu. Tasmiṃ khaṇe tesaṃ tesaṃ gehesu biḷāle ādiṃ katvā sakalajambudīpe bandhanagato🔽satto nāma nāhosi. Paccekabuddho hatthaṃ ukkhipitvā sīsaṃ parāmasi. Tāvadeva gihiliṅgaṃ
analyzed: athassa sacca kiriyā sama kālam eva sabbe bandhanā muccitvā tuṭṭhi ravam ravantā saka ṭṭhānam eva  tasmin khaṇe tesam tesam gehesu biḷāle ādim katvā sakala jambudīpe bandhana gataḥ  satto nāma na ahosi paccekabuddhaḥ hattham ukkhipitvā sīsam parāmasi tāvat eva gihi liṅgam
translated: And at the moment when he uttered this truth-act, all the creatures in the cage were released from their bonds, and they flew away to their own haunts,🔽crying out in joy. At that moment there was not a single creature in all India bound in prison,🔽beginning with the cats in their houses. The Private Buddha raised his hand and stroked his head. Immediately the lay-disciple’s appearance changed,

original: antaradhāyi, pabbajitaliṅgaṃ pāturahosi. So saṭṭhivassikatthero viya ākappasampanno
analyzed: antaradhāyi pabbajita liṅgam pāturahosi saḥ saṭṭhivassika theraḥ viya ākappa sampannaḥ
translated: and the lay-disciple’s appearance disappeared, and the appearance of a monk appeared in its stead. He was as handsome as a monk of sixty years’ standing.

original: aṭṭhaparikkhāradharo hutvā “tvameva mama patiṭṭhā ahosī”ti morarājassa añjaliṃ paggayha
analyzed: aṭṭha parikkhāra dharaḥ hutvā tvam eva mama patiṭṭhā ahosi iti mora rājassa añjalim paggayha
translated: and, making the eight-fold reverential salutation, he raised his clasped hands in adoration of the king of the peacocks, saying, “You have been my support.”

original: padakkhiṇaṃ katvā ākāse uppatitvā nandamūlakapabbhāraṃ agamāsi. Morarājāpi yaṭṭhiaggato
analyzed: padakkhiṇam katvā ākāse uppatitvā nandamūlaka pabbhāram agamāsi mora rājā api
translated: Then, after walking round him to the right, he rose up into the air and went to the Nandamūlaka mountain. The king of the peacocks also rose up from the top of the stick-house,

original: uppatitvā gocaraṃ gahetvā attano vasanaṭṭhānaṃ gato. Idāni luddassa satta vassāni
analyzed: uppatitvā gocaram gahetvā attanaḥ vasana ṭhānam gataḥ idāni luddassa satta vassāni
translated: took his food, and went to his own dwelling-place. Now the Teacher, in order to show how the hunter, after wandering about for seven years,

original: pāsahatthassa caritvāpi morarājānaṃ nissāya dukkhā muttabhāvaṃ pakāsento satthā osānagāthamāha –
analyzed: pāsa hatthassa caritvā api mora rājānam nissāya dukkhā mutta bhāvam pakāsento satthā osāna gātham āha
translated: was delivered from his suffering through the king of the peacocks, related the following story:

original: “Luddo carī pāsahattho araññe, bādhetu morādhipatiṃ yasassiṃ;
analyzed: luddaḥ carī pāsa hatthaḥ araññe bādhetu mora adhipatim yasassim
translated: “The hunter, with snare in hand, wandered in the forest, seeking to destroy the famous king of the peacocks.

original: Bandhitvā morādhipatiṃ yasassiṃ, dukkhā sa pamucci yathāhaṃ pamutto”ti.
analyzed: bandhitvā mora adhipatim yasassim dukkhā sa pamucci yathā aham pamuttaḥ ti
translated: But when he had caught the famous king of the peacocks, he was delivered from his suffering, even as I have been delivered.”

original: Tattha bādhetūti māretuṃ, ayameva vā pāṭho. Bandhitvāti bandhitvā ṭhitassa dhammakathaṃ
analyzed: tattha bādhetu uti māretum ayam eva vā pāṭhaḥ bandhitvā iti bandhitvā ṭhitassa dhamma katham
translated: Herein, seeking to destroy means either this is the reading, or seeking to kill. But when he had caught means when he had caught him and was standing there, he listened to the Dhamma discourse

original: sutvā paṭiladdhasaṃvego hutvāti attho. Yathāhanti yathā ahaṃ sayambhuñāṇena mutto,
analyzed: sutvā paṭiladdha saṃvegaḥ hutvā iti atthaḥ yathā aham iti yathā aham sayambhu ñāṇena muttaḥ
translated: and was filled with remorse. Even as I have been delivered means just as I have been delivered by my own knowledge,

original: evameva sopi muttoti.
analyzed: evam eva saḥ api
translated: even so was he delivered.

original: Satthā imaṃ dhammadesanaṃ āharitvā saccāni pakāsetvā jātakaṃ samodhānesi, saccapariyosāne ukkaṇṭhitabhikkhu arahattaṃ pāpuṇi. Tadā morarājā ahameva ahosinti.
analyzed: satthā imam dhamma desanam āharitvā saccāni pakāsetvā jātakam samodhānesi sacca pariyosāne ukkaṇṭhita bhikkhu arahattam pāpuṇi tadā mora rājā aham eva ahosinti
translated: The Teacher, having related this Dhamma discourse, revealed the Truths, and identified the Birth by saying, “At that time the king of the peacocks was myself.”

original: Mahāmorajātakavaṇṇanā aṭṭhamā.
analyzed: mahāmora jātaka vaṇṇanā aṭṭhamā
translated: The story of the Great Peacock.

original: [492] 9. Tacchasūkarajātakavaṇṇanā
translated: The story of the True Hog

original: Yadesamānā vicarimhāti idaṃ satthā jetavane viharanto dve mahallakatthere ārabbha🔽kathesi. Mahākosalo kira rañño bimbisārassa dhītaraṃ dento dhītu nhānīyamūlatthāya
analyzed: vicarimha iti idam satthā jetavane viharantaḥ dve mahallaka there ārabbha  kathesi mahākosalaḥ kira raññaḥ bimbisārassa dhītaram dentaḥ dhītu nhānīya mūla atthāya
translated: When the Teacher was in residence at Jetavana, he told this story about two old monks.🔽The king of Kosala, it seems, when he gave his daughter in marriage to King Bimbisāra, gave him the village of Kāsi as a dowry for his daughter.

analyzed: assāsentaḥ vicari tassa ivam karontassa iva sūriyaḥ uggacchati
translated: he wandered about. While he was doing this, the sun rose.

original: Atha byaggharājā kūṭajaṭilassa assamapadā nikkhamitvā pabbatatale aṭṭhāsi. Taṃ disvā
analyzed: atha byaggha rājā kūṭajaṭilassa assama padā nikkhamitvā pabbata tale aṭṭhāsi tam disvā
translated: Then the king of the boars, having come out from the hermitage of the deceitful ascetic, stood on the mountain-top. Seeing him,

original: sūkarā “āgato no bhante verī”ti vadiṃsu. Mā bhāyatha, yaṃ yaṃ esa karoti, taṃ sabbaṃ
analyzed: sūkarāḥ āgataḥ naḥ bhante verī iti vadiṃsu mā bhāyatha yam yam esa karoti tam sabbam
translated: the boars said: “Our lord, the enemy has come.” “Do not be afraid, whatever he does,

original: sarikkhā hutvā karothāti. Byaggho sarīraṃ vidhunitvā osakkanto viya passāvamakāsi,
analyzed: sa rikkhāḥ hutvā karotha ati byagghaḥ sarīram vidhunitvā osakkantaḥ viya passa avamakāsi
translated: do all the same.” The boar shook his body and made water as if he were vomiting,

original: sūkarāpi tatheva kariṃsu. Byaggho sūkare oloketvā mahānadaṃ nadi, tepi tatheva kariṃsu.
analyzed: sūkarāḥ api tathā iva kariṃsu sūkare oloketvā mahā nadam nadi te api tathā iva kariṃsu
translated: and the boars did the same. The boar looked at the boars and made a great noise,

original: So tesaṃ kiriyaṃ disvā cintesi “na ime pubbasadisā, ajja mayhaṃ paṭisattuno hutvā
analyzed: saḥ tesam kiriyam disvā cintesi na ime pubba sadisāḥ ajja mayham paṭisattunaḥ hutvā
translated: and they did the same. Seeing their actions, he thought: “These are not as before, today they have become my adversaries,

original: vaggavaggā ṭhitā, saṃvidahako nesaṃ senānāyakopi atthi, ajja mayā etesaṃ santikaṃ
analyzed: vagga vaggāḥ ṭhitā saṃvidahakaḥ nesam senā nāyakaḥ api atthi ajja mayā etesam santikam
translated: and they are standing in groups, there is also a commander who has made an agreement with them, today I must not fight with them,🔽but I must go to the king and tell him what has happened.”

original: gantuṃ na vaṭṭatī”ti maraṇabhayatajjito nivattitvā kūṭajaṭilassa santikaṃ gato. Atha
analyzed: gantum na vaṭṭati iti maraṇa bhaya tajjitaḥ nivattitvā kūṭajaṭilassa santikam gataḥ atha
translated: and he turned back, terrified by the fear of death, and went to the hermit.🔽Then,

original: naṃ so tucchahatthaṃ disvā navamaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: nam saḥ tucchahattham disvā navamam gātham āha
translated: seeing him with empty hands, the hermit spoke the ninth stanza:

original: “Pāṇātipātā virato nu ajja, abhayaṃ nu te sabbabhūtesu dinnaṃ;
analyzed: pāṇa atipātā virataḥ nu ajja abhayam nu te sabba bhūtesu dinnam
translated: “Do you abstain from taking life today? Have you given safety to all creatures?

original: Dāṭhā nu te migavadhāya na santi, yo saṅghapatto kapaṇova jhāyasī”ti.
analyzed: dāṭhāḥ nu te miga vadhāya na santi yaḥ saṅgha patto kapaṇaḥ uva jhāyasi iti
translated: Have you no tusks for killing deer? Why do you, the chief of the herd, live in misery?”

original: Tattha saṅghapattoti yo tvaṃ sūkarasaṅghapatto hutvā kiñci gocaraṃ alabhitvā kapaṇo viya jhāyasīti.
analyzed: tattha saṅgha patto ti yaḥ tvam sūkara saṅgha patto hutvā kiñci gocaram a labhitvā kapaṇaḥ viya jhāyasi iti
translated: Herein, the chief of the herd is one who, having become chief of a herd of pigs, lives in misery as if he were poor, not getting any food.

original: Atha byaggho tisso gāthā abhāsi –
analyzed: atha byagghaḥ tissaḥ gāthāḥ abhāsi
translated: Then the tiger spoke three stanzas:

original: “Na me dāṭhā na vijjanti, balaṃ kāye samohitaṃ;
analyzed: na me dāṭhāḥ na vijjanti balam kāye
translated: “I have no tusks, my strength is all decayed,🔽and I have seen my kinsmen gathered together in a group;

original: Ñātī ca disvāna sāmaggī ekato, tasmā ca jhāyāmi vanamhi ekako.
analyzed: ñātī ca disvāna sāmaggī ekato tasmā ca jhāyāmi vanamhi ekako
translated: therefore I live alone in the forest.

original: “Imassudaṃ yanti disodisaṃ pure, bhayaṭṭitā leṇagavesino puthu;
analyzed: yanti disodisam pure bhaya ṭṭitāḥ leṇaga vesinaḥ puthu
translated: “Now, in the past, they went in all directions, terrified, seeking a cave, in numbers;

original: Te dāni saṅgamma vasanti ekato, yatthaṭṭhitā duppasahajja te mayā.
analyzed: te dāni saṅgamma vasanti ekatas te mayā
translated: but now they have gathered together and live in one place, and wherever they stand is hard for me to approach.

original: “Pariṇāyakasampannā, sahitā ekavādino;
analyzed: pariṇāyaka sampannā sahitāḥ eka vādinaḥ
translated: “They are well-led, united, speaking with one voice,

original: Te maṃ samaggā hiṃseyyuṃ, tasmā nesaṃ na patthaye”ti.🔽Tattha sāmaggī ekatoti sahitā hutvā ekato ṭhite. Imassudanti ime sudaṃ mayā akkhīni
analyzed: te mama samaggāḥ hiṃseyyum tasmai na īsam na patthaya iti  tattha sāmaggī ekatoti sahitā hutvā ekatas ṭhite imassudanti ime sudan mayā akkhīni
translated: They would harm me if united, therefore I do not seek them.

original: ummīletvā olokitamattāva pubbe disodisaṃ gacchanti. Puthūti visuṃ visuṃ. Yatthaṭṭhitāti🔽yasmiṃ bhūmibhāge ṭhitā. Pariṇāyakasampannāti senānāyakena sampannā. Tasmā nesaṃ
analyzed: ummīletvā olokita mattā ava pubbe disodisam gacchanti puthu uti visum visum yatthaṭṭhitā ti  yasmin bhūmi bhāge ṭhitā pariṇāyaka sampannā ati senānāyakena sampannā tasmāt
translated: Herein, united means standing together in concord. These, etc. means that these, merely by my opening my eyes and looking, used to go hither and thither. Scattered means separately. Where they stand means

original: na patthayeti tena kāraṇena etesaṃ na patthemi.
analyzed: na patthayeti tena kāraṇena etesam na patthemi
translated: in whatever place they stand. Possessed of a general means possessed of a general of the army. Therefore I do not seek them means for that reason I do not seek them.

original: Taṃ sutvā kūṭajaṭilo tassa ussāhaṃ janayanto gāthamāha –
analyzed: tam sutvā kūṭajaṭilaḥ tassa ussāham janayantaḥ gātham āha
translated: Hearing this, the Kūṭa ascetic spoke this verse, arousing his enthusiasm:

original: “Ekova indo asure jināti, ekova seno hanti dije pasayha;
analyzed: ekaḥ iva indo asure jināti ekaḥ iva senaḥ hanti dije pasayha
translated: “Alone the moon conquers the demons, alone the warrior kills the enemy by force;

original: Ekova byaggho migasaṅghapatto, varaṃ varaṃ hanti balañhi tādisa”nti.
analyzed: ekaḥ iva byagghaḥ miga saṅgha pattaḥ varam varam hanti balam hi tādisanti
translated: Alone the tiger, lord of the deer herd, kills the best, for such is the strength of one like him.”

original: Tattha migasaṅghapattoti migagaṇapatto hutvā varaṃ varaṃ migaṃ hanti. Balañhi tādisanti tādisañhi tassa balaṃ.
analyzed: tattha miga saṅgha patto ti miga gaṇa pattaḥ hutvā varam varam migam hanti balam hi tādisanti tādisam hi tassa balam
translated: Herein, lord of the deer herd means being the lord of the deer herd, he kills the best deer. For such is the strength of one like him means such is the strength of one like him.

original: Atha byaggho gāthamāha –
analyzed: atha byagghaḥ gātham āha
translated: Then the tiger spoke this verse:

original: “Na heva indo na seno, napi byaggho migādhipo;
analyzed: na ha iva indo na senaḥ byagghaḥ migādhipaḥ
translated: “Neither the Indra, nor the Sun, nor the tiger, king of beasts,

original: Samagge sahite ñātī, na byagghe kurute vase”ti.
analyzed: samagge sahite ñātī na byagghe kurute vasā iti
translated: Can make the kinsmen, united and in concord, come under his control.”

original: Tattha byaggheti byagghasadise hutvā sarīravidhūnanādīni katvā ṭhite vase na kurute, attano vase vattāpetuṃ na sakkotīti attho.
analyzed: tattha byaggha iti byaggha sadise hutvā sarīra vidhūnana ādīni katvā ṭhite vase na kurute attanaḥ vase vattāpetum na sakkoti iti attho
translated: Herein, “tiger” : he does not make them come under the control of the tiger, that is, he does not make them come under the control of the tiger by making them tear their bodies to pieces, etc., the meaning is that he does not succeed in making them come under his control.

original: Puna jaṭilo taṃ ussāhento dve gāthā abhāsi –
analyzed: puna jaṭilaḥ tam ussāhentaḥ dve gāthāḥ abhāsi
translated: Then the ascetic, encouraging him, spoke two stanzas:

original: “Kumbhīlakā sakuṇakā, saṅghino gaṇacārino;
analyzed: kumbhīlakā sakuṇakā saṅghinaḥ gaṇa cārinaḥ
translated: “The Kumbhīlaka birds, living in flocks, moving in groups,

original: Sammodamānā ekajjhaṃ, uppatanti ḍayanti ca.
analyzed: sammodamānāḥ ekajjham uppatanti ḍayanti ca
translated: In concord and agreement, fly up and alight together.

original: “Tesañca ḍayamānānaṃ, ekettha apasakkati;
analyzed: tesam ca ḍayamānānam ekā itthā apasakkati
translated: “And when they alight, one of them sometimes fails;

original: Tañca seno nitāḷeti, veyyagghiyeva sā gatī”ti.🔽Tattha kumbhīlakāti evaṃnāmakā khuddakasakuṇā. Uppatantīti gocaraṃ carantā uppatanti.
analyzed: tat ca senaḥ nitāḷeti veyyagghiyā iva sā gatī iti  tattha kumbhīlakā ati evaṃnāmakā khuddaka sakuṇā uppatanti iti gocaram carantāḥ uppatanti
translated: The Sun-god seizes him, and that is the end of his independence.”🔽Herein, “Kumbhīlaka” : these are small birds of that name. “Fly up” : they fly up when they go to their feeding-grounds.

original: Ḍayanti cāti gocaraṃ gahetvā ākāsena gacchanti. Ekettha apasakkatīti eko etesu osakkitvā
analyzed: ḍayanti ca ati gocaram gahetvā ākāsena gacchanti eka ittha apasakkati iti ekaḥ etesu osakkitvā
translated: “Alight” : they go through the air, taking their feeding-grounds. “One of them sometimes fails” : one of them fails among them.

original: vā ekapassena vā visuṃ gacchati. Nitāḷetīti paharitvā gaṇhāti. Veyyagghiyeva sā gatīti
analyzed: vai eka passena vā visum gacchati nitāḷeti iti paharitvā gaṇhāti veyyagghiyā iva sā gatī iti
translated: or on one side or the other, or separately. He will catch you and beat you. This is the way of the hyena.

original: byagghānaṃ esāti veyyagghi, samaggānaṃ gacchantānampi esā evarūpā gati byagghānaṃ🔽gatiyeva nāma hoti. Na hi sakkā sabbehi ekatova gantuṃ, tasmā yo evaṃ tattha eko
analyzed: byagghānam esā ati veyyak hi samaggānam gacchantānam pi esā evarūpā gati byagghānam  gatiyā iva nāma hoti na hi sakkā sabbehi ekatas va gantum tasmā yaḥ evam tattha ekaḥ
translated: The way of the hyena is the way of the hyenas.

original: gacchati, taṃ gaṇhāti.
analyzed: gacchati tam gaṇhāti
translated: For it is impossible for all of them to go together. Therefore he catches whoever goes there alone.

original: Evañca pana vatvā “byaggharāja tvaṃ attano balaṃ na jānāsi, mā bhāyi, kevalaṃ tvaṃ
analyzed: evam ca pana vatvā byaggha rāja tvam balam na jānāsi mā bhāyi kevalam tvam
translated: And after saying this, he encouraged him, “O king of the hyenas, you do not know your own strength. Do not be afraid.

original: naditvā pakkhanda, dve ekato gacchantā nāma na bhavissantī”ti ussāhesi. So tathā
analyzed: naditvā pakkhanda dve ekatas gacchantā nāma na bhavissanti iti ussāhesi saḥ tathā
translated: Simply roar and go forward. Two cannot go together.” He did so.

original: akāsi. Tamatthaṃ pakāsento satthā āha –
analyzed: akāsi tam attham pakāsentaḥ satthā āha
translated: Expounding this matter, the Master said:

original: “Ussāhito jaṭilena, luddenāmisacakkhunā;
analyzed: ussāhitaḥ jaṭilena luddena āmisa cakkhunā
translated: “Encouraged by the matted-hair ascetic, the greedy one with the flesh-eye,🔽The hyena, thinking, ‘I will go among the hyenas’ as before,

original: Dāṭhī dāṭhīsu pakkhanti, maññamāno yathā pure”ti.
analyzed: dāṭhī dāṭhīsu pakkhanti maññamānaḥ yathā purā iti
translated: went among the hyenas.

original: Tattha dāṭhīti sayaṃ dāṭhāvudho itaresu dāṭhāvudhesu pakkhandi. Yathā pureti yathā pubbe maññati, tatheva maññamāno.
analyzed: tattha dāṭhī iti sayam dāṭhāvudhaḥ itaresu dāṭhāvudhesu pakkhandi yathā purā iti yathā pubbe maññati tathā iva maññamānaḥ
translated: Herein, the hyena is the one with the flesh-eye. He went among the other hyenas. As before: thinking as he did before, thinking in the same way.

original: So kira gantvā pabbatatale tāva aṭṭhāsi. Sūkarā “punāgato sāmi, coro”ti tacchassa
analyzed: so kira gantvā pabbata tale tāva aṭṭhāsi sūkarā sāmi coro ti tacchassa
translated: He went and stood on the top of the hill. The pigs said, “Our master has come back; he is a thief.”

original: ārocesuṃ. So “mā bhāyathā”ti te assāsetvā uṭṭhāya dvinnaṃ āvāṭānaṃ antare pīṭhakāya
analyzed: ārocesum saḥ mā bhāyatha ati te assāsetvā uṭṭhāya dvinnam āvāṭānam antare pīṭhakāya
translated: The boar said, “Do not be afraid,” and after comforting them he rose up and stood on a seat between the two pits.

original: aṭṭhāsi. Byaggho vegaṃ janetvā tacchasūkaraṃ sandhāya pakkhandi. Tacchasūkaro parivattitvā
analyzed: aṭṭhāsi byagghaḥ vegam janetvā taccha sūkaram sandhāya pakkhandi taccha sūkaraḥ
translated: The tiger, letting out a roar, rushed at the boar. The boar turned around and fell into the front pit.

original: pacchāmukho purimaāvāṭe pati. Byaggho ca vegaṃ sandhāretuṃ asakkonto gantvā suppapabbhāre🔽āvāṭe patitvā puñjakitova aṭṭhāsi. Tacchasūkaro vegena uṭṭhāya tassa antarasatthimhi
analyzed: pacchāmukho purima āvāṭe byagghaḥ ca vegam sandhāretum a sakkontaḥ gantvā suppapabbhāre  āvāṭe patitvā puñja kitaḥ uva aṭṭhāsi taccha sūkaraḥ vegena uṭṭhāya tassa antara satthimhi
translated: The tiger, unable to stop his momentum, went on and fell into the back pit, which was filled with soft mud.

original: dāṭhaṃ otāretvā yāva hadayā phāletvā maṃsaṃ khāditvā mukhena ḍaṃsitvā bahiāvāṭe pātetvā
analyzed: dāṭham otāretvā maṃsam khāditvā mukhena ḍaṃsitvā bahiāvāṭe
translated: The boar quickly rose up and thrust his tusk into the tiger’s belly, tore open his belly, and ate his flesh. After licking his mouth, he threw the tiger out of the pit.

original: “gaṇhathimaṃ dāsa”nti āha. Paṭhamāgatā ekavārameva tuṇḍotāraṇamattaṃ labhiṃsu, pacchā
analyzed: āha paṭhama āgatāḥ eka vāram eva tuṇḍotāraṇa mattam labhiṃsu pacchā
translated: “Catch him, you slaves!” he said. Those who came first got only a blow with the snout, but those who came later

original: āgatā alabhitvā “byagghamaṃsaṃ nāma kīdisa”nti vadiṃsu. Tacchasūkaro āvāṭā uttaritvā
analyzed: āgatāḥ a labhitvā byagghamaṃsam nāma kīdisanti vadiṃsu āvāṭāḥ uttaritvā
translated: got nothing and said, “What is tiger flesh like?” The boar climbed out of the pit and said, “Come, eat the tiger.”

original: sūkare oloketvā “kiṃ nu kho na tussathā”ti āha. “Sāmi, eko tāva byaggho gahito, añño🔽paneko dasabyagghagghanako atthī”ti? “Ko nāmeso”ti? “Byagghena ābhatābhatamaṃsaṃ
analyzed: sūkare oloketvā kim nu kho na tussatha ati āha sāmi ekaḥ tāva byagghaḥ gahitaḥ añño  pana ikaḥ atthi iti kaḥ nāma iso ti byagghena ābhata ābhata maṃsam
translated: and asked them why they were not satisfied. “Master, one tiger has been caught, but there is another

original: khādako kūṭajaṭilo”ti. “Tena hi etha, gaṇhissāma na”nti tehi saddhiṃ vegena pakkhandi.
analyzed: khādako kūṭa jaṭilaḥ iti tena hi etha gaṇhissāma nanti tehi saddhim vegena pakkhandi
translated: tiger, worth ten times as much as the first.” “Who is that?” “A bogus ascetic with matted locks, who eats the flesh of tigers that have been killed by other tigers.” “Well then, come along, we will catch him.” And he quickly set out with them.

original: Jaṭilo “byaggho cirāyatī”ti tassa āgamanamaggaṃ olokento bahū sūkare āgacchante disvā
analyzed: jaṭilaḥ byagghaḥ cirāyati iti tassa āgamana maggaṃ olokentaḥ bahū sūkare āgacchante disvā
translated: The ascetic, thinking, “The tiger is taking too long,” was looking out for his approach, when he saw the many pigs coming.

original: “ime byagghaṃ māretvā mama māraṇatthāya āgacchanti maññe”ti palāyitvā ekaṃ udumbararukkhaṃ
analyzed: ime byaggham māretvā mama māraṇa atthāya āgacchanti maññā iti palāyitvā ekam udumbara rukkhaṃ
translated: “They are coming to kill the tiger and to kill me,” he thought, and fled. He climbed a fig tree.

original: abhiruhi. Sūkarā “esa rukkhaṃ āruḷho”ti vadiṃsu. “Kiṃ rukkha”nti. “Udumbararukkha”nti.
analyzed: sūkarāḥ esa rukkham āruḍhaḥ iti vadiṃsu kim rukkhanti udumbara rukkhanti
translated: The pigs said, “There he is, up in the tree.” “What kind of tree?” “A fig tree.”

original: “Tena hi mā cintayittha, idāni naṃ gaṇhissāmā”ti taruṇasūkare pakkositvā rukkhamūlatā
analyzed: tena hi mā cintayittha idāni nam gaṇhissāma ati taruṇa sūkare pakkositvā rukkha mūla tā
translated: “Well then, don’t worry about it. We will catch him now.” He summoned the young pigs, and they dug up the earth at the foot of the tree.

original: paṃsuṃ apabyūhāpesi, sūkarīhi mukhapūraṃ udakaṃ āharāpesi, mahādāṭhasūkarehi samantā
analyzed: paṃsum apabyūhāpesi sūkarīhi mukhapūram udakam āharāpesi mahā dāṭha sūkarehi samantā
translated: He had the sows bring water in their mouths, and the big tuskers brought up earth from the foot of the tree on all sides.

original: mūlāni chindāpesi. Ekaṃ ujukaṃ otiṇṇamūlameva aṭṭhāsi. Tato sesasūkare “tumhe apethā”ti🔽ussāretvā jaṇṇukehi patiṭṭhahitvā dāṭhāya mūlaṃ pahari, pharasunā pahaṭaṃ viya chijjitvā
analyzed: mūlāni chinda apesi ekam ujukam otiṇṇa mūlam eva aṭṭhāsi tatas sesa sūkare tumhe apetha ati  ussāretvā jaṇṇukehi patiṭṭhahitvā dāṭhāya mūlam pahari pharasunā pahaṭam viya chijjitvā
translated: and had the roots cut. Only one tree, which was straight and had deep roots, remained standing. Then he said to the other pigs, “You go away.”🔽and having them stand on their hind legs, he struck the roots with his tusks. The roots broke as if they had been cut with an axe,

original: gataṃ. Rukkho parivattitvā pati. Taṃ kūṭajaṭilaṃ patantameva sampaṭicchitvā maṃsaṃ
analyzed: gatam rukkhaḥ tam kūṭa jaṭilam patantam eva sampaṭicchitvā maṃsam
translated: and the tree fell over. The tree-spirit accepted the ascetic as he fell, and the pigs ate his flesh.

original: bhakkhesuṃ. Taṃ acchariyaṃ disvā rukkhadevatā gāthamāha –
analyzed: tam acchariyam disvā rukkha devatā gātham āha
translated: Seeing this miracle, the tree-spirit spoke this verse:

original: “Sādhu sambahulā ñātī, api rukkhā araññajā;
analyzed: sādhu sambahulā ñātī api rukkhā arañña jā
translated: “How good it is to have many kinsmen, even trees in the forest!

original: Sūkarehi samaggehi, byaggho ekāyane hato”ti.
analyzed: sūkarehi samaggehi byagghaḥ ekāyane hataḥ iti
translated: The tiger was killed in the one path by the united pigs.”

original: Tattha ekāyane hatoti ekagamanasmiṃyeva hato.
analyzed: tattha ekāyane hato ti eka gamanasmiṃya iva hato
translated: Herein, he was killed in the one path means he was killed in the one way of going.

original: Ubhinnaṃ pana nesaṃ hatabhāvaṃ pakāsento satthā itaraṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: ubhinnam pana nesam hata bhāvam pakāsentaḥ satthā itaram gātham āha
translated: But showing how both of them were killed, the Teacher spoke the second verse:

original: “Brāhmaṇañceva byagghañca, ubho hantvāna sūkarā;
analyzed: brāhmaṇañca iva byagghañca ubhaḥ hantvāna sūkarā
translated: “The pigs, having killed both the brahmin and the tiger,

original: Ānandino pamuditā, mahānādaṃ panādisu”nti.
analyzed: ānandinaḥ pamuditāḥ mahā nādam
translated: Rejoiced and were glad, and they uttered a great roar.”

original: Puna tacchasūkaro te pucchi “aññepi vo amittā atthī”ti? Sūkarā “natthi, sāmī”ti vatvā
analyzed: puna taccha sūkaraḥ te pucchi aññe pi vaḥ amittāḥ atthi iti sūkarāḥ na atthi sāmi iti vatvā

analyzed: atīte bārāṇasi nagare tat eva pana kantāram su eva nigrodhaḥ vāṇijāḥ magga mūḷhāḥ hutvā tam eva nigrodham passiṃsu tam attham satthā abhisambuddhaḥ hutvā kathentaḥ imāḥ gāthāḥ āha
translated: In the dispensation of the Buddha Kassapa, there lived a certain merchant who was a resident of the city of Bārāṇasī. This merchant, in company with five hundred other merchants, set out on an ocean voyage. When they had reached the ocean, a great wind arose and drove their ship to the land of the Sirens. The Sirens, in order to entice the merchants, assumed the most beautiful forms imaginable, and sang and played. The merchants, hearing the songs and music, said to themselves, “We will listen to the music for a time and then return to our ship.” So they remained there and listened to the music. But the Sirens thought to themselves, “If these men return to their ship, they will take their wives and children and depart. We must find some means of preventing them from returning to their ship.” So they said to the merchants, “We are the wives of the merchants of Bārāṇasī. We have been sent by our parents to be the wives of the merchants of this city. We have come to meet you. Come, let us go to the city.”

original: naṃ mātali rathābhiruhanatthaṃ nimantetvā ādāya agamāsi. Tamatthaṃ pakāsento satthā imā gāthā abhāsi –
analyzed: mātali ratha abhiruha nattham nimantetvā ādāya agamāsi tam attham pakāsentaḥ satthā imāḥ gāthāḥ abhāsi
translated: Then Mātali invited him to mount the chariot, and taking him with him, went to the city of the gods. Expounding this matter, the Master uttered these stanzas:

original: “Devaputto mahiddhiko, mātali devasārathi;
analyzed: deva puttaḥ mahiddhikaḥ mātali deva sārathi
translated: “The son of the gods, the mighty one, Mātali, the charioteer of the gods,

original: Nimantayittha rājānaṃ, vedehaṃ mithilaggahaṃ.
analyzed: nimantayittha rājānam vedeham mithila ggaham
translated: Invited the king, the lord of Videha, the ruler of Mithilā.

original: “Ehimaṃ rathamāruyha, rājaseṭṭha disampati;
analyzed: ehi imam ratham āruyha rāja seṭṭha disampati
translated: “Come, mount this chariot, O king, O lord of the earth, O best of kings;

original: Devā dassanakāmā te, tāvatiṃsā saindakā;
analyzed: devā dassana kāmā te tāvatiṃsā saindakā
translated: The gods, the Tāvatiṃsas, the Saindakas,

original: Saramānā hi te devā, sudhammāyaṃ samacchare.
analyzed: saramānā hi te devā sudhammāyam samacchare
translated: The gods, longing for thee, have assembled in Sudhammā.

original: “Tato ca rājā sādhino, vedeho mithilaggaho;
analyzed: tato ca rājā sādhinaḥ vedehaḥ mithila ggahaḥ
translated: “Then the king, the lord of Videha, the ruler of Mithilā,

original: Sahassayuttamāruyha, agā devāna santike;
analyzed: sahassa yuttam āruyha agāḥ devāna santike
translated: Having mounted the chariot with a thousand (chariots), went to the gods;

original: Taṃ devā paṭinandiṃsu, disvā rājānamāgataṃ.
analyzed: tam devā disvā rājānam āgatam
translated: The gods, seeing the king come, rejoiced.

original: “Svāgataṃ te mahārāja, atho te adurāgataṃ;
analyzed: svāgatam te mahā rāja atho te adurāgatam
translated: “Welcome to thee, O great king, and not too long a journey;

original: Nisīda dāni rājīsi, devarājassa santike.
analyzed: nisīda dāni rājīsi devarājassa santike
translated: Now sit down, O king, in the presence of the king of the gods.

original: “Sakkopi paṭinandittha, vedehaṃ mithilaggahaṃ;
analyzed: sakko api mithila ggaham
translated: “Sakka also rejoiced in the lord of Videha, the ruler of Mithilā;

original: Nimantayittha kāmehi, āsanena ca vāsavo.
analyzed: nimantayittha kāmehi āsanena ca vāsavaḥ
translated: He invited him with sensual pleasures, and with a seat, Vāsava.

original: “Sādhu khosi anuppatto, āvāsaṃ vasavattinaṃ;
analyzed: sādhu kho asi an uppattaḥ āvāsam vasa vattinam
translated: “You have come well, indeed, to the abode of the Lord of Vasus;

original: Vasa devesu rājīsi, sabbakāmasamiddhisu;
analyzed: vasa devesu rājīsi sabba kāma samiddhisu
translated: Live among the gods, O King, in the enjoyment of all desires fulfilled;

original: Tāvatiṃsesu devesu, bhuñja kāme amānuse”ti.
analyzed: tāvatiṃsesu devesu bhuñja kāme amānusa iti
translated: Among the Thirty-Three gods, enjoy divine sensual pleasures.”

original: Tattha samacchareti acchanti. Agā devāna santiketi devānaṃ santikaṃ agamāsi. Tasmiñhi
analyzed: tattha samacchara iti acchanti agāḥ devāna santikā iti devānam santikam agamāsi tasmin hi
translated: There, “they shared” means they enjoyed. “He went to the gods’ presence” means he went to the gods’ vicinity. For

original: rathaṃ abhiruhitvā ṭhite ratho ākāsaṃ pakkhandi, so mahājanassa olokentasseva antaradhāyi.
analyzed: ratham abhiruhitvā ṭhite rathaḥ ākāsam pakkhandi saḥ mahā janassa olokentassa iva antaradhāyi
translated: when he had mounted the chariot, the chariot rose into the air, and he disappeared from the sight of the people.

original: Mātali rājānaṃ devalokaṃ nesi. Taṃ disvā devatā ca sakko ca haṭṭhatuṭṭhā paccuggamanaṃ
analyzed: mātali rājānam deva lokam nesi tam disvā devatā ca sakko ca haṭṭha tuṭṭhā paccuggamanam
translated: Mātali led the king to the god-world. Seeing that, the gods and Sakka were delighted. They went out to meet him

original: katvā paṭisanthāraṃ kariṃsu. Tamatthaṃ dassetuṃ “taṃ devā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha paṭinandiṃsūti
analyzed: katvā paṭisanthāram kariṃsu tam attham dassetum tam deva atiādi vuttam tattha paṭinandiṃsu iti
translated: and welcomed him. To show that, it is said, “The gods” and so on. There, “they rejoiced” means

original: punappunaṃ nandiṃsu. Āsanena cāti rājānaṃ āliṅgitvā “idha nisīdā”ti attano paṇḍukambalasilāsanena
analyzed: punappunam nandiṃsu āsanena ca ati rājānam āliṅgitvā idha nisīdāti paṇḍu kambala silā āsanena
translated: they rejoiced again and again. “And with a seat” means he embraced the king and said, “Sit here,” and invited him with his own white-spread seat

original: ca kāmehi ca nimantesi, upaḍḍharajjaṃ datvā ekāsane nisīdāpesīti attho.
analyzed: ca kāmehi ca nimantesi upaḍḍha rajjam da tvā eka āsane nisīdāpesi iti attho
translated: and with sensual pleasures. The meaning is, he gave him half the kingdom and had him sit on the same seat.

original: Tattha sakkena devaraññā dasayojanasahassaṃ devanagaraṃ aḍḍhatiyā ca accharākoṭiyo
analyzed: tattha sakkena deva raññā dasa yojana sahassam devanagaram aḍḍhatiyā ca accharā koṭiyaḥ
translated: There Sakka, King of the Gods, gave him a divine city ten thousand leagues in extent, and a quarter of a billion celestial nymphs,

original: vejayantapāsādañca majjhe bhinditvā dinnaṃ sampattiṃ anubhavantassa manussagaṇanāya
analyzed: vejayanta pāsādam ca majjhe bhinditvā dinnam sampattim anubhavantassa manussa gaṇanāya
translated: and the Vejayanta Palace, which he had built in the middle of the city, and he himself enjoyed the glory of sovereignty.🔽Seven hundred years of human life passed away while he was enjoying this glory.

original: satta vassasatāni atikkantāni. Tenattabhāvena devaloke vasanakaṃ puññaṃ khīṇaṃ, anabhirati
analyzed: satta vassa satāni atikkantāni tenatta bhāvena deva loke vasanakam puññam khīṇam an abhirati
translated: The merit he had acquired by his life in the world of the gods was exhausted, and he became discontented.

original: uppannā, tasmā sakkena saddhiṃ sallapanto gāthamāha –
analyzed: uppannā tasmā sakkena saddhim sallapantaḥ gātham āha
translated: Therefore he spoke this verse in the presence of Sakka:

original: “Ahaṃ pure saggagato ramāmi, naccehi gītehi ca vāditehi;
analyzed: aham pure sagga gataḥ ramāmi naccehi gītehi ca vāditehi
translated: “Formerly I was in heaven, and rejoiced in dancing, song, and music;

original: So dāni ajja na ramāmi sagge, āyuṃ nu khīṇo maraṇaṃ nu santike;
analyzed: saḥ dāni ajja na ramāmi sagge āyum nu khīṇaḥ maraṇam nu santike
translated: But now I do not rejoice in heaven; is my life exhausted, or is death near?

original: Udāhu mūḷhosmi janindaseṭṭhā”ti.
analyzed: udāhu mūḍhaḥ asmi janindaseṭṭha ati
translated: Or am I confused, O best of kings?”🔽Here he asks, “Is my life exhausted?” meaning, “Is my life-faculty exhausted by its own nature, or is death near because of the kamma that cuts off life?”

original: Tattha āyuṃ nu khīṇoti kiṃ nu mama sarasena jīvitindriyaṃ khīṇaṃ, udāhu upacchedakakammavasena maraṇaṃ santike jātanti pucchati. Janindaseṭṭhāti janindānaṃ devānaṃ seṭṭha.
analyzed: tattha āyum nu khīṇoti kim nu mama sa rasena jīvitindriyam khīṇam udāhu upacchedaka kamma vasena maraṇam santike jātanti pucchati janinda seṭṭha ati janindānam devānam seṭṭha
translated: “Best of kings” means best of the kings of men.

original: Atha naṃ sakko āha –
analyzed: atha nam sakkaḥ āha
translated: Then Sakka said:

original: “Na tāyu khīṇaṃ maraṇañca dūre, na cāpi mūḷho naravīraseṭṭha;
analyzed: na khīṇam maraṇam ca dūre na ca api mūḍhaḥ nara vīra seṭṭha
translated: Nor are you confused, O best of men and heroes;

original: Tuyhañca puññāni parittakāni, yesaṃ vipākaṃ idha vedayittho.
analyzed: tuyham ca puññāni parittakāni yesam vipākam idha vedayitthaḥ
translated: But your merits are few, whose result you experience here.

original: “Vasa devānubhāvena, rājaseṭṭha disampati;
analyzed: vasa deva anubhāvena rāja seṭṭha disampati
translated: “Live by the power of the gods, O best of kings, lord of the land;

original: Tāvatiṃsesu devesu, bhuñja kāme amānuse”ti.
analyzed: tāvatiṃsesu devesu bhuñja kāme amānusa iti
translated: Among the Thirty-Three gods, enjoy divine pleasures.”

original: Tattha “parittakānī”ti idaṃ tena attabhāvena devaloke vipākadāyakāni puññāni sandhāya
analyzed: tattha parittakāni iti idam tena atta bhāvena deva loke vipāka dāyakāni puññāni sandhāya
translated: Here, “few” means the merits that give results in the deva world in that existence.

original: vuttaṃ, itarāni panassa puññāni pathaviyaṃ paṃsu viya appamāṇāni. Vasa devānubhāvenāti
analyzed: vuttam itarāni panassa puññāni pathaviyam paṃsu viya appamāṇāni vasa deva anubhāvena ati
translated: But his other merits are immeasurable, like the dust on the earth. “Live by the power of the gods” means

original: ahaṃ te attano puññāni majjhe bhinditvā dassāmi, mamānubhāvena vasāti taṃ samassāsento āha.
analyzed: aham te attanaḥ puññāni majjhe bhinditvā dassāmi mama anubhāvena vasāti tam samassāsentaḥ āha
translated: I will divide your merits in half and give them to you. Live by my power, comforting him.

original: Atha naṃ paṭikkhipanto mahāsatto āha –
analyzed: atha nam paṭikkhipantaḥ mahāsattaḥ āha
translated: Then, rejecting it, the Great Being said:

original: “Yathā yācitakaṃ yānaṃ, yathā yācitakaṃ dhanaṃ;
analyzed: yathā yācitakam yānam yathā yācitakam dhanam
translated: “Just as a borrowed vehicle, just as borrowed wealth,

original: Evaṃsampadamevetaṃ, yaṃ parato dānapaccayā.
analyzed: evaṃsampadam eva etam yam paratas dāna paccayā
translated: So is this attainment, which depends on another for giving.

original: “Na cāhametamicchāmi, yaṃ parato dānapaccayā;
analyzed: na ca aham etam icchāmi yam paratas dāna paccayā
translated: “I do not desire this, which depends on another for giving;

original: Sayaṃkatāni puññāni, taṃ me āveṇikaṃ dhanaṃ.
analyzed: sayaṃkatāni puññāni tam me āveṇikam dhanam
translated: My own merits are my wealth, which is unique to me.

original: “Sohaṃ gantvā manussesu, kāhāmi kusalaṃ bahuṃ;
analyzed: sā uham gantvā manussesu kāhāmi kusalam bahum
translated: “So I will go to the human world, and there will do much good;

original: Dānena samacariyāya, saṃyamena damena ca;
analyzed: dānena sama cariyāya saṃyamena damena ca
translated: By giving, by good conduct, by self-control, by restraint,

original: Yaṃ katvā sukhito hoti, na ca pacchānutappatī”ti.🔽Tattha yaṃ parato dānapaccayāti yaṃ parena dinnattā labbhati, taṃ yācitakasadisameva
analyzed: yam katvā sukhitaḥ hoti na ca pacchā anutappati iti  tattha yam paratas dāna paccayā ati yam parena dinna ttā labbhati tam yācitaka sadisam eva
translated: By doing what is good, one is happy and does not repent afterwards.”

original: hoti. Yācitakañhi tuṭṭhakāle denti, atuṭṭhakāle acchinditvā gaṇhantīti vadati. Samacariyāyāti
analyzed: hoti yācitakam hi tuṭṭha kāle denti a tuṭṭha kāle a chinditvā gaṇhanti iti vadati sama cariyāya ati
translated: Herein, what is received from others as a gift is like what is received by begging. For what is given by beggars is given when they are satisfied; what is not given is taken by force. By good conduct:

original: kāyādīhi pāpassa akaraṇena. Saṃyamenāti sīlasaṃyamena. Damenāti indriyadamanena.
analyzed: kāya ādīhi pāpassa akaraṇena saṃyamena ati sīla saṃyamena damena ati indriya damanena
translated: by not doing evil by body, etc. By self-control: by self-control in virtue. By restraint: by restraint of the faculties.

original: Yaṃ katvāti yaṃ karitvā sukhito ceva hoti na ca pacchānutappati, tathārūpameva kammaṃ karissāmīti.
analyzed: yam katvā iti yam karitvā sukhitaḥ ca iva hoti na ca pacchā anutappati tathārūpam eva kammam karissāmi iti
translated: By doing what is good: by doing only such deeds as will make one happy and not repent afterwards.

original: Athassa vacanaṃ sutvā sakko mātaliṃ āṇāpesi “gaccha, tāta, sādhinarājānaṃ mithilaṃ
analyzed: atha assa vacanam sutvā sakkaḥ mātalim āṇāpesi gaccha tāta sādhina rājānam mithilam
translated: Then Sakka, having heard his words, ordered Matali: “Go, my dear, and bring the king to Mithila

original: netvā uyyāne otārehī”ti. So tathā akāsi. Rājā uyyāne caṅkamati. Atha naṃ uyyānapālo
analyzed: netvā uyyāne otārehi iti saḥ tathā akāsi rājā uyyāne caṅkamati atha naṃ uyyāna pālaḥ
translated: and set him down in the park.” He did so. The king was walking up and down in the park. Then the park-keeper

original: disvā pucchitvā gantvā nāradarañño ārocesi. So rañño āgatabhāvaṃ sutvā “tvaṃ purato
analyzed: disvā pucchitvā gantvā nārada raññaḥ ārocesi saḥ raññaḥ āgata bhāvam sutvā tvam puratas
translated: and having seen them, he asked them, and having gone, he informed King Nārada. He, having heard of the King’s arrival, said: “You go on in front,

original: gantvā uyyānaṃ sajjetvā tassa ca mayhañca dve āsanāni paññāpehī”ti uyyānapālaṃ uyyojesi.
analyzed: gantvā uyyānam sajjetvā tassa ca mayham ca dve āsanāni paññāpehi iti uyyāna pālam uyyojesi
translated: and having prepared the pleasure garden, prepare two seats for me and him.”

original: So tathā akāsi. Atha naṃ rājā pucchi “kassa dve āsanāni paññāpesī”ti? “Ekaṃ tumhākaṃ,
analyzed: saḥ tathā akāsi atha nam rājā pucchi kassa dve āsanāni paññāpesi iti ekam tumhākam
translated: He did so. Then the King asked him: “For whom did you prepare two seats?” “For you,

original: ekaṃ amhākaṃ rañño”ti. Atha naṃ rājā “ko añño satto mama santike āsane nisīdissatī”ti
analyzed: ekam amhākam rañño ti atha nam rājā kaḥ aññaḥ satto mama santike āsane nisīdissati iti
translated: and for our King.” Then the King, saying: “What other being will sit on a seat in my presence?”

original: vatvā ekasmiṃ nisīditvā ekasmiṃ pāde ṭhapesi. Nāradarājā āgantvā tassa pāde vanditvā
analyzed: vatvā ekasmin nisīditvā ekasmin pāde ṭhapesi nārada rājā āgantvā tassa pāde vanditvā
translated: and having sat on one, placed his foot on the other. King Nārada came, and having worshipped his foot,

original: ekamantaṃ nisīdi. So kirassa sattamo panattā. Tadā kira vassasatāyukakālova hoti.
analyzed: ekamantam nisīdi saḥ kirassa sattamaḥ tadā kira hoti
translated: he sat down on one side. He was, it seems, his seventh incarnation. At that time, it seems, the period of life was one hundred years.

original: Mahāsatto pana attano puññabalena ettakaṃ kālaṃ vītināmesi. So nāradaṃ hatthe gahetvā
analyzed: mahāsatto pana attano puñña balena ettakam kālam vītināmesi saḥ nāradam hatthe gahetvā
translated: But the Great Being, by the power of his merit, lived for that length of time. He, taking Nārada by the hand,

original: uyyāne vicaranto tisso gāthā abhāsi –
analyzed: uyyāne vicarantaḥ tissaḥ gāthāḥ abhāsi
translated: while wandering in the pleasure garden, spoke three verses:

original: “Imāni tāni khettāni, imaṃ nikkhaṃ sukuṇḍalaṃ;
analyzed: imāni tāni khettāni imam nikkham su kuṇḍalaṃ
translated: “These are the fields, this is the plough, this is the goad;

original: Imā tā haritānūpā, imā najjo savantiyo.🔽“Imā tā pokkharaṇī rammā, cakkavākapakūjitā;
analyzed: imāḥ tā harita anūpāḥ imāḥ najjaḥ savantiyaḥ  imā tā pokkharaṇī rammā cakkavāka pakūjitā
translated: These are the green meadows, these the flowing streams.🔽“These are the lovely lotus-ponds, resounding with the calls of wild geese;

original: Mandālakehi sañchannā, padumuppalakehi ca;
analyzed: mandālakehi sañchannā paduma uppalakehi ca
translated: Covered with white and blue lotuses,

original: Yassimāni mamāyiṃsu, kiṃ nu te disataṃ gatā.
analyzed: yaḥ simāni mamāyiṃsu kim nu te disatam gatā
translated: To whom do they belong now, who have gone to the other world?

original: “Tānīdha khettāni so bhūmibhāgo, teyeva ārāmavanūpacārā;
analyzed: tāni idha khettāni saḥ bhūmi bhāgaḥ
translated: “These are the fields, that land, those gardens and parks;

original: Tameva mayhaṃ janataṃ apassato, suññaṃva me nārada khāyate disā”ti.
analyzed: tam eva mayham janatam a passataḥ suññam iva me nārada khāyate disā ati
translated: When I see that people are no more, it seems to me as if the world were empty, Nārada.”

original: Tattha khettānīti bhūmibhāge sandhāyāha. Imaṃ nikkhanti imaṃ tādisameva udakaniddhamanaṃ.🔽Sukuṇḍalanti sobhanena musalapavesanakuṇḍalena samannāgataṃ. Haritānūpāti udakaniddhamanassa
analyzed: tattha khettāni iti bhūmi bhāge sandhāya āha imam imam udaka niddhamanam  su kuṇḍalanti sobhanena musala pavesana kuṇḍalena samannāgatam harita anūpāti udaka niddha manassa
translated: Here, “fields” is said in reference to the land. “These are the same” means these are just like the water-drawing machines.

original: ubhosu passesu haritatiṇasañchannā anūpabhūmiyo. Yassimāni mamāyiṃsūti tāta nārada,
analyzed: ubhosu passesu harita tiṇa sañchannāḥ anūpa bhūmiyaḥ yaḥ imāni tāta nārada
translated: “With beautiful earrings” means possessing beautiful earrings made of iron. “Green meadows” means the land covered with green grass on both sides of the water-drawing machines. “To whom do they belong now” means, dear Nārada,

original: ye mama upaṭṭhākā ca orodhā ca imasmiṃ uyyāne mahantena yasena mayā saddhiṃ vicarantā
analyzed: ye mama upaṭṭhākā ca orodhā ca imasmin uyyāne mahantena yasena mayā saddhim vicarantā
translated: those who were my attendants and servants, wandering with me in this garden with great fame,

original: imāni ṭhānāni mamāyiṃsu piyāyiṃsu, kataraṃ nu te disataṃ gatā, kattha te pesitā.🔽Tānīdha khettānīti imasmiṃ uyyāne tāneva etāni uparopanakaviruhanaṭṭhānāni. Teyeva
analyzed: imāni ṭhānāni mamāyiṃsu piyāyiṃsu kataram nu te disatam gatā kattha te pesitā  tāni idha khettāni iti imasmim uyyāne tāni eva etāni uparopanaka viruhana ṭṭhānāni
translated: “These places were mine, they were dear to me. Where have they gone? Where have they been sent?”🔽“These fields here” : in this pleasure garden, these very places for planting the trees.

original: ārāmavanūpacārāti ime teyeva ārāmavanūpacārā, vihārabhūmiyoti attho.
analyzed: ārāma vanūpacārā ti ime ārāma vanūpacārā vihāra bhūmiyo ti attho
translated: “These parks and groves” : these very parks and groves, the grounds for the dwelling places.

original: Atha naṃ nārado āha – “deva, tumhākaṃ devalokagatānaṃ idāni satta vassasatāni, ahaṃ
analyzed: atha nam nāradaḥ āha deva tumhākam deva loka gatānam idāni satta vassa satāni aham
translated: Then Nārada said to him, “Your Majesty, seven hundred years have passed since you went to the world of the gods.

original: vo sattamo panattā, tumhākaṃ upaṭṭhākā ca orodhā ca maraṇamukhaṃ pattā, idaṃ vo attano
analyzed: vaḥ sattamaḥ panattā tumhākam upaṭṭhākā ca orodhā ca maraṇa mukham pattā idam vaḥ attano
translated: I am the seventh king of your line. Your attendants and your subjects have fallen into the mouth of death. This kingdom is yours.

original: santakaṃ rajjaṃ, anubhavatha na”nti. Rājā “tāta nārada, nāhaṃ idhāgacchanto rajjatthāya
analyzed: santakam rajjam anubhavatha nanti rājā tāta nārada na aham idha āgacchantaḥ rajjatthāya
translated: Enjoy it.” The king said, “Dear Nārada, I did not come here for the sake of the kingdom.

original: āgato, puññakaraṇatthāyamhi āgato, ahaṃ puññameva karissāmī”ti vatvā gāthā āha –
analyzed: āgataḥ puñña karaṇa thāyamhi āgataḥ aham puññam eva karissāmi iti vatvā gāthāḥ āha
translated: I came here for the sake of making merit. I will make merit.” Then he spoke this verse:

original: “Diṭṭhā mayā vimānāni, obhāsentā catuddisā;
analyzed: diṭṭhā mayā vimānāni obhāsentā catuddisā
translated: “I have seen the mansions, shining in the four directions,

original: Sammukhā devarājassa, tidasānañca sammukhā.
analyzed: sammukhā devarājassa tidasānam ca sammukhā

Sohaṃ etādisanti tāta🔽nārada, sohaṃ buddhañāṇena aparicchindanīyaṃ evarūpaṃ kāmaguṇasampattiṃ pahāya puññakaraṇatthāya🔽idhāgato. translated: That path I will follow, By which the virtuous ones go.”

original: aṭṭhaṅgikaṃ maggaṃ. Subbatāti yena maggena subbatā sabbaññubuddhā gacchanti, ahampi
analyzed: aṭṭhaṅgikam maggam subbatā ati yena maggena subbatā sabbaññu buddhāḥ gacchanti aham pi
translated: Here, “My divine abode is left behind” refers to the Vejayanta Palace. “So I, having left behind such things” means: Dear Nārada, I, having abandoned such a wealth of sensual pleasures that cannot be measured by the knowledge of the Buddha, have come here to make merit. “The path that is not traveled by the rod” means the eightfold path that is to be practiced by those who are without a rod, who have laid aside the rod of violence, and which is preceded by right view. “By which the virtuous ones go” means: I will follow the path by which the virtuous ones, the omniscient Buddhas, go.

original: agatapubbaṃ disaṃ gantuṃ bodhitale nisīditvā tameva maggaṃ paṭipajjissāmīti.🔽Evaṃ bodhisatto imā gāthāyo sabbaññutaññāṇena saṅkhipitvā kathesi. Nārado punapi
analyzed: a gata pubbam disam gantum bodhi tale nisīditvā tam eva maggam paṭipajjissāmi iti  evam bodhisattaḥ imāḥ gāthāyaḥ sabbaññuta ññāṇena saṅkhipitvā kathesi nāradaḥ puna api
translated: I will go to a place never before visited by a Buddha, and I will follow that very path.”

original: āha – “rajjaṃ, deva, anusāsā”ti. “Tāta, na me rajjenattho, satta vassasatāni vigataṃ🔽dānaṃ sattāheneva dātukāmamhī”ti. Nārado “sādhū”ti tassa vacanaṃ sampaṭicchitvā mahādānaṃ

translated: Thus did the Bodhisatta, by means of his omniscience, briefly tell the story of his life. Nārada said again, “Your Majesty, rule the kingdom.” “Dear friend, I have no desire for the kingdom. I have been away from it for seven hundred years.

original: So “kena kāraṇena nipannosī”ti vutte “aññaṃ kāraṇaṃ natthi, diṭṭhamaṅgalikāya me
analyzed: so kena kāraṇena nipanno asi iti vutte aññam kāraṇam na atthi diṭṭha maṅgalikāya me
translated: When asked, “For what reason do you lie down?” he said, “There is no other reason, I want Diṭṭhamaṅgalikā.”

original: attho”ti āha. Eko divaso atīto, tathā dutiyo, tatiyo, catuttho, pañcamo, chaṭṭho
analyzed: attho ti āha ekaḥ divasaḥ atīto tathā dutiyaḥ tatiyo catuttho pañcamo chaṭṭho
translated: One day passed, and so did a second, a third, a fourth, a fifth, a sixth.

original: ca. Bodhisattānaṃ adhiṭṭhānaṃ nāma samijjhati, tasmā sattame divase diṭṭhamaṅgalikaṃ
analyzed: ca bodhisattānam adhiṭṭhānam nāma samijjhati tasmai sattame divase diṭṭha maṅgalikam
translated: The resolve of Bodhisattas is successful, therefore on the seventh day they took out Diṭṭhamaṅgalikā

original: nīharitvā tassa adaṃsu.
analyzed: nīharitvā tassa adaṃsu
translated: and gave her to him.

original: Atha naṃ sā “uṭṭhehi, sāmi, tumhākaṃ gehaṃ gacchāmā”ti āha. Bhadde, tava parijanenamhi
analyzed: atha nam sā uṭṭhehi sāmi tumhākam geham gacchāma ati āha bhadde tava
translated: “Rise up, my husband,” said she, “let us go home.”

original: supothito dubbalo, maṃ ukkhipitvā piṭṭhiṃ āropetvā ādāya gacchāhīti. Sā tathā katvā
analyzed: su pothitaḥ dubbalaḥ mam ukkhipitvā piṭṭhim āropetvā ādāya gacchāhi iti sā tathā katvā
translated: “Dear wife,” said he, “I am so weak from hunger that I can hardly stand. Lift me up, place me on your back, and carry me along.”

original: nagaravāsīnaṃ passantānaññeva nagarā nikkhamitvā caṇḍālagāmakaṃ gatā. Atha naṃ mahāsatto
analyzed: nagara vāsīnam nagarāḥ nikkhamitvā caṇḍāla gāmakam gatāḥ atha nam mahāsatto
translated: So she did, and taking him with her, went to the village of the outcasts.🔽The Great Being, however, would not allow her to break the rules of caste, but made her remain in the house for several days.

original: jātisambhedavītikkamaṃ akatvāva katipāhaṃ gehe vasāpetvā cintesi “ahametaṃ lābhaggayasaggappattaṃ
analyzed: jāti sambheda vītikkamam a katvā ava katipāham gehe vasāpetvā cintesi aham etam lābha gga yasagga ppattam
translated: Then he thought to himself, “If I am to make her the foremost of all women in the possession of wealth and glory,

original: karonto pabbajitvāva kātuṃ sakkhissāmi, na itarathā”ti. Atha naṃ āmantetvā ‘bhadde,
analyzed: karontaḥ pabbajitvā ava kātum sakkhissāmi na itarathā ati atha nam āmantetvā bhadde
translated: I can do so only by becoming a monk, and in no other way.” So he said to her, “Dear wife,

original: mayi araññato kiñci anāharante amhākaṃ jīvikā nappavattati, yāva mamāgamanā mā ukkaṇṭhi,
analyzed: mayi araññataḥ kiñci an āharante amhākam jīvikā na ppavattati yāva mama āgamanā mā ukkaṇṭhi
translated: since I have brought nothing from the forest, our livelihood is at an end. Do not worry until I return.

original: ahaṃ araññaṃ gamissāmī”ti vatvā gehavāsinopi “imaṃ mā pamajjitthā”ti ovaditvā araññaṃ
analyzed: aham araññam gamissāmi iti vatvā geha vāsinaḥ api imam mā pamajjittha ati ovaditvā araññam
translated: I am going to the forest.” And he gave instructions to the inmates of the house, saying, “Take care of her.”

original: gantvā samaṇapabbajjaṃ pabbajitvā appamatto sattame divase aṭṭha samāpattiyo ca pañca
analyzed: gantvā samaṇapabbajjam pabbajitvā appamattaḥ sattame divase aṭṭha samāpattiyaḥ ca pañca
translated: and after going forth he became a monk. He was diligent, and on the seventh day he attained the eight attainments and the five

original: abhiññāyo ca uppādetvā “idāni diṭṭhamaṅgalikāya avassayo bhavituṃ sakkhissāmī”ti
analyzed: ca uppādetvā idāni diṭṭhamaṅgalikāya avassayaḥ bhavitum sakkhissāmi iti
translated: superknowledges. Then he thought, “Now I can be a support to Diṭṭhamaṅgalikā.”

original: iddhiyā gantvā caṇḍālagāmadvāre otaritvā diṭṭhamaṅgalikāya gehadvāraṃ agamāsi. Sā
analyzed: id dhiyā gantvā caṇḍāla gāma dvāre otaritvā diṭṭha maṅgalikāya geha dvāram sā
translated: By his psychic power he went to the gate of the village of the outcasts and came down. He went to the door of Diṭṭhamaṅgalikā’s house. She

original: tassāgamanaṃ sutvā gehato nikkhamitvā “sāmi, kasmā maṃ anāthaṃ katvā pabbajitosī”ti
analyzed: tassa āgamanam sutvā gehataḥ nikkhamitvā sāmi kasmai mama anātham katvā pabbajito asi iti
translated: heard that he had come, and she came out of the house, saying, “Master, why did you go forth, leaving me helpless?”

original: paridevi. Atha naṃ “bhadde, mā cintayi, tava porāṇakayasato idāni mahantataraṃ yasaṃ
analyzed: atha nam bhadde mā cintayi tava porāṇaka yasataḥ idāni mahantataram yasam
translated: and she lamented. Then he said, “My dear, don’t worry. I will make your fame greater than it was before.

original: karissāmi, apica kho pana ‘na mayhaṃ mātaṅgapaṇḍito sāmiko, mahābrahmā me sāmiko’ti
analyzed: karissāmi apica kho pana na mayham mātaṅga paṇḍito sāmikaḥ mahābrahmā me sāmikaḥ uti
translated: Besides, you will be able to say in the midst of the assembly, ‘The sage Mātaṅga is not my husband, the Great Brahmā is my husband.’ ”

original: ettakaṃ parisamajjhe vattuṃ sakkhissasī’ti āha. “Āma, sāmi, sakkhissāmī”ti. “Tena
analyzed: ettakam parisamajjhe vattum sakkhissasi iti āha āma sāmi sakkhissāmi iti tena
translated: “Yes, master, I will be able to say that.” “Well then,

analyzed: hi idāni te sāmikaḥ kuhinti puṭṭhāḥ brahma lokam gataḥ iti vatvā kadā āgamissati iti
translated: when you are asked, ‘Where is your husband now?’ say, ‘He has gone to the Brahmā world.’ When you are asked, ‘When will he return?’🔽say, ‘When the moon and sun fall to the ground, and the earth goes up into the sky, and the mountains go to the ends of the ocean, then he will return.’ ”

original: vutte ‘ito sattame divase puṇṇamāyaṃ candaṃ bhinditvā āgamissatī’ti vadeyyāsī”ti
analyzed: vutte itas sattame divase puṇṇamāyam candam bhinditvā āgamissati iti vadeyyāsi iti
translated: and when he has gone, say to him, ‘On the seventh day from this time the full moon will burst and come to you.’ ”

original: naṃ vatvā mahāsatto himavantameva gato.
analyzed: nam vatvā mahā sattaḥ himavantam eva gataḥ
translated: Having thus spoken, the Great Being went to the Himālaya.

original: Diṭṭhamaṅgalikāpi bārāṇasiyaṃ mahājanassa majjhe tesu tesu ṭhānesu tathā kathesi.
analyzed: diṭṭha maṅgalikā api bārāṇasiyam mahā janassa majjhe tesu tesu ṭhānesu tathā kathesi
translated: Diṭṭhamaṅgalikā, in the midst of the great crowd in Bārāṇasī, told this story in various places.

original: Mahājano “aho mahābrahmā samāno diṭṭhamaṅgalikaṃ na gacchati, evametaṃ bhavissatī”ti
analyzed: mahājanaḥ aho mahābrahmā samānaḥ diṭṭha maṅgalikam na gacchati evam etam bhavissati iti
translated: The great crowd said, “Oh, the Great Brahmā, though he is in love with Diṭṭhamaṅgalikā, does not go to her; it must be so.”

analyzed: bodhisattaḥ api puṇṇama divase candassa gagana majjhe ṭhita kāle brahmatta bhāvam
translated: And they believed it. The Bodhisatta, on the day of the full moon, when the moon was in the middle of the sky, assumed the form of Brahmā,

analyzed: sakalam kāsiraṭṭham dvādasa yojanikam bārāṇasi nagaram ca eka ubhāsam katvā canda maṇḍalam
translated: and made all the kingdom of Kāsi and the city of Bārāṇasī twelve leagues in extent one blaze of light. He burst the orb of the moon

translated: and descended. He went three times round Bārāṇasī, and was worshipped by the great crowd with perfumes, garlands, etc.

original: pūjiyamāno caṇḍālagāmakābhimukho ahosi. Brahmabhattā sannipatitvā caṇḍālagāmakaṃ
analyzed: pūjiyamānaḥ caṇḍāla gāmaka abhimukhaḥ ahosi brahma bhattā sannipatitvā caṇḍāla gāmakam
translated: Then he went towards the village of the Caṇḍālas. The Brahmans assembled and went to the village of the Caṇḍālas.

original: gantvā diṭṭhamaṅgalikāya gehaṃ suddhavatthehi chādetvā bhūmiṃ catujjātiyagandhehi
analyzed: gantvā diṭṭhamaṅgalikāya geham suddha vatthehi chādetvā bhūmim catujjātiya gandhehi
translated: and having gone there, they covered the house of Diṭṭhamaṅgalikā with pure cloths, and having sprinkled the ground with the four kinds of perfumes,

analyzed: tadā diṭṭha maṅgalikā utunī hoti athassāḥ aṅguṭṭhakena nābhim parāmasi kucchiyam  gabbho patiṭṭhāsi atha nam mahāsattaḥ āmantetvā bhadde gabbhaḥ te patiṭṭhitaḥ tvam
translated: At that time Diṭṭhamaṅgalikā was in season, and then the Great Being, having touched her navel with his thumb, the embryo was established in her womb.

analyzed: puttam vijāyissasi tvam pi puttaḥ api te bhavissatha tava pāda dhovana odakam

translated: will be the water for sprinkling the kings of the whole of India, but the water for bathing you will be the ambrosia of immortality,

analyzed: bhavissati ye tam sīse āsiñcissanti te sabba rogehi muccissanti kāḷakaṇṇim parivajjessanti  tava pāda piṭṭhe sīsam ṭhapetvā vandantā sahassam dassanti sotapathe ṭhatvā vandantā
translated: “There will be those who will sprinkle it on their heads, and they will be cured of all diseases, and they will avoid the Black Nāga.🔽Those who will place their heads on the soles of your feet and worship you will give a thousand; those who will worship you standing in the hearing of your voice will give a hundred;

analyzed: satam dassanti cakkhupathe ṭhatvā vandantā ekam kahāpaṇam datvā vandissanti appamattā

translated: and they obtained eighteen koṭis of treasure.🔽Then they took the city round, brought it, and having had a great pavilion made in the middle of the city, and having surrounded it with a fence,

analyzed: mahā sayanam paññapetvā mahantena siri sobhaggena tattha vasāpesum maṇḍapa santikeya iva
translated: and having prepared a great couch, they caused her to live there with great pomp and beauty. Right near the pavilion

analyzed: satta dvāra koṭṭham satta bhūmikam pāsādam kātum ārabhiṃsu mahantam nava kammam ahosi
translated: they began to build a palace with seven storeys and seven doors, and it was a great new building.

analyzed: diṭṭha maṅgalikā maṇḍapeyā iva puttam vijāyi athassa nāma ggahaṇa divase brāhmaṇā sannipatitvā
translated: Diṭṭhamaṅgalikā gave birth to a son right in the pavilion. Then on the day of naming the child the brahmins assembled and

translated: From that time she lived there with great honour, and Maṇḍabyakumāra with a great retinue,

translated: and he grew up. When he was seven or eight years old, the best teachers in the world of men assembled. They

translated: prepared with care. The young man, adorned with all his ornaments, climbed up onto golden sandals

analyzed: āruyha hatthena kañcana daṇḍam gahetvā idha sappim detha idha madhunti vicārento
translated: and, holding a golden staff in his hand, was going around saying, “Give ghee here, give honey there,”🔽examining (the food).

analyzed: carati tasmin khaṇe mātaṅga paṇḍitaḥ himavante assama pade nisinnaḥ kā nu kho diṭṭha maṅgalikāya

translated: son?” Looking (he saw) that he had fallen into a great abyss. Thinking: “Today I will go,

analyzed: dametvā yattha dinnam mahapphalam hoti tattha dānam dāpetvā āgamissāmi iti cintetvā

analyzed: ākāsena gantvā mukha dhovana ādīni katvā manosilā tale ṭhitaḥ

analyzed: nivāsetvā kāya bandhanam bandhitvā paṃsu kūla saṅghāṭim pārupitvā mattikā pattam ādāya
translated: tied a waistband, put on an outer robe made of rags, took a clay bowl,

analyzed: ākāsena āgantvā catutthe dvāra koṭṭhake otaritvā ekamantam aṭṭhāsi maṇḍabyo

analyzed: kumāraḥ itas citas ca olokentaḥ tam disvā evaṃvirūpaḥ saṅkāra yakkha sadisaḥ ayam pabbajitaḥ
translated: looking here and there, seeing him, (thought): “This ascetic, who is so ugly, like a demon of the rubbish heap,

original: imaṃ ṭhānaṃ āgacchanto kuto nu kho āgacchatī”ti tena saddhiṃ sallapanto paṭhamaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: imam ṭhānam āgacchantaḥ kutas nu kho āgacchati iti tena saddhim sat lapantaḥ paṭhamam gātham āha
translated: where has he come from to this place?” Talking with him, he spoke the first verse:

original: “Kuto nu āgacchasi dummavāsī, otallako paṃsupisācakova;
analyzed: kutas nu āgacchasi dumma vāsī otallakaḥ paṃsu pisācakaḥ uva
translated: “Where do you come from, you who wear a robe of rags, you who are like a ghost in a dust-heap?

original: Saṅkāracoḷaṃ paṭimuñca kaṇṭhe, ko re tuvaṃ hosi adakkhiṇeyyo”ti.🔽Tattha dummavāsīti anañjitaamaṇḍitaghaṭitasaṅghāṭikapilotikavasano. Otallakoti lāmako🔽olambavilambanantakadharo vā. Paṃsupisācakovāti saṅkāraṭṭhāne pisācako viya. Saṅkāracoḷanti🔽saṅkāraṭṭhāne laddhapilotikaṃ. Paṭimuñcāti paṭimuñcitvā. Adakkhiṇeyyoti tvaṃ adakkhiṇeyyo
analyzed: saṅkāra coḷam paṭimuñca kaṇṭhe kaḥ re tuvam hosi a dakkhiṇeyyā ti  tattha dumma vāsī iti anañjita amaṇḍita ghaṭita saṅghāṭika pilotika vasanaḥ otallako ti lāmako  vā saṅkāra ṭṭhāne pisācakaḥ viya saṅkāra coḷanti  saṅkāra ṭṭhāne laddha pilotikam paṭimuñcāti paṭimuñcitvā adakkhiṇeyyaḥ ti tvam adakkhiṇeyyaḥ
translated: Throw over your neck this rag from a dust-heap. Who are you, not fit to receive alms?”

original: imesaṃ paramadakkhiṇeyyānaṃ nisinnaṭṭhānaṃ eko hutvā kuto āgato.
analyzed: imesam parama dakkhiṇeyyānam nisinna ṭṭhānam ekaḥ hutvā kutas āgataḥ
translated: Herein, he who wears a robe of rags is one who wears a robe made of cast-off rags that are unbleached and unwashed and not darned together. He is like a ghost in a dust-heap. Rag from a dust-heap is a rag obtained in a dust-heap. Throw over your neck is throw over your neck and wear. Not fit to receive alms is you are not fit to receive alms from these who are most fit to receive alms. Where do you come from, coming alone to the place where they are sitting?

original: Taṃ sutvā mahāsatto muducitteneva tena saddhiṃ sallapanto dutiyaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: tam sutvā mahāsattaḥ mudu cittena iva tena saddhim sat lapantaḥ dutiyam gātham āha
translated: Hearing this, the Great Being, with a mind softened with pity, spoke this second stanza in reply:

original: “Annaṃ tavedaṃ pakataṃ yasassi, taṃ khajjare bhuñjare piyyare ca;
analyzed: annam tava idam pakatam yasassi tam khajjare bhuñjare piyyare ca
translated: “This food is cooked for you, O famous one. Eat it, drink it, and enjoy it.

original: Jānāsi maṃ tvaṃ paradattūpajīviṃ, uttiṭṭhapiṇḍaṃ labhataṃ sapāko”ti.
analyzed: jānāsi mam tvam para dattu upajīvim uttiṭṭha piṇḍam labhatam sa pākā iti
