original: Tattha pakatanti paṭiyattaṃ. Yasassīti parivārasampanna. Taṃ khajjareti taṃ khajjanti🔽ca bhuñjanti ca pivanti ca. Kiṃkāraṇā mayhaṃ kujjhasi? Uttiṭṭhapiṇḍanti upatiṭṭhitvā🔽labhitabbapiṇḍaṃ, uṭṭhāya ṭhitehi vā dīyamānaṃ heṭṭhā ṭhatvā labhitabbapiṇḍaṃ. Labhataṃ🔽sapākoti sapāko caṇḍālopi labhatu. Jātisampannā hi yattha katthaci labhanti, sapākacaṇḍālassa
analyzed: tattha paṭiyattam yasassi iti tam khajjanti  ca bhuñjanti ca pivanti ca kiṃkāraṇā uttiṭṭha piṇḍanti upatiṭṭhitvā  labhitabba piṇḍam uṭṭhāya ṭhitehi vā dīyamānam heṭṭhā ṭhatvā labhitabba piṇḍam labhataṃ  sa pākaḥ iti sa pākaḥ caṇḍālaḥ api labhatu jāti sampannāḥ hi yattha katthaci labhanti sa pāka caṇḍālassa
translated: Herein, what is prepared is ready. Renowned means possessing a retinue. They eat it and drink it means they eat it and drink it. Why do you get angry with me? The alms that are set out means the alms that are obtained by standing by and waiting for them to be given, or the alms that are given by those who have risen up and are standing, and that are obtained by standing below. Let him obtain means let him obtain. The alms that are cooked means let the cooked alms, even of an outcaste, be obtained. For those who are perfect in birth obtain alms wherever they go, even of an outcaste who has cooked them.

original: pana ko deti, dullabhapiṇḍo ahaṃ, tasmā me jīvitapavattanatthaṃ bhojanaṃ dāpehi, kumārāti.
analyzed: pana kaḥ deti dullabha piṇḍaḥ aham tasmai me jīvita pavattana attham bhojanam dāpehi kumāra ati
translated: Herein, prepared means prepared. Renowned means possessed of a retinue. They eat it means they eat it and drink it. Why do you get angry with me? The alms-food that is to be obtained by standing means the alms-food that is to be obtained by standing and waiting for it to be given by those who are standing and waiting. Let the outcast get it too means let the outcast get it too. For those who are well-born get it wherever they go. But who gives it to the outcast? My alms-food is hard to get. Therefore give me food for the sake of my livelihood, young man.

original: Tato maṇḍabyo gāthamāha –
analyzed: tatas maṇḍabyaḥ gātham āha
translated: Then Maṇḍabyo spoke this verse:

original: “Annaṃ mamedaṃ pakataṃ brāhmaṇānaṃ, attatthāya saddahato mamedaṃ;
analyzed: annam mama idam pakatam brāhmaṇānam attatthāya saddahataḥ mama idam
translated: “This food is prepared for brahmans, this food is for my own benefit;

original: Apehi etto kimidhaṭṭhitosi, na mādisā tumhaṃ dadanti jammā”ti.
analyzed: apehi ettas kim idha ṭṭhitaḥ asi na mā adisā tumham dadanti jammā ati
translated: Go away from here, why do you stand here? No one like me gives to you, you wretch.”

original: Tattha attatthāyāti attano vaḍḍhiatthāya. Apehi ettoti imamhā ṭhānā apagaccha. Na
analyzed: tattha atta tthāya ati attanaḥ vaḍḍhi atthāya apehi ettas ti imamhā ṭhānā apagaccha na
translated: Herein, for my own benefit means for the sake of my own increase. Go away from here means go away from this place. No one like me gives to you, you wretch means no one like me gives to you, you wretch.

translated: “We give alms to those like ourselves, to high-born Ucchakas, not to you, a low-born Caṇḍāla. Go away, you are not fit to receive alms.”

original: Tato mahāsatto gāthamāha –
analyzed: tatas mahāsattaḥ gātham āha
translated: Then the Great Being spoke this verse:

translated: “They sow the seed in the field, in the low-lying and the high, hoping for a fruit in the field that is well-prepared;

analyzed: etāya saddhāya dadāhi dānam appā iva ārādhaye dakkhiṇeyya iti
translated: By this faith give alms, perhaps you will please one worthy of offerings.”

analyzed: tassa atthaḥ kumāra sassa phalam tīsu pi khettesu bījam vapanti tattha ativuṭṭhi kāle  thale sassam sampajjati ninne pūtikam hoti anūpa khette nadiñca taḷākañca nissāya

analyzed: katam oghena vuyhati manda vuṭṭhi kāle thale khette vipajjati ninne thokam sampajjati
translated: made near a river or a lake, it is carried away by the flood. At the time of the light rains, the crop is destroyed in the high field, in the low field it is a little successful,

analyzed: anūpa khette sampajjatā iva samavuṭṭhi kāle thale khette thokam sampajjati itaresu
translated: in the well-prepared field it is successful. At the time of the moderate rains, the crop is a little successful in the high field, in the other two

analyzed: sampajjatā iva tasmai yathā tīsu pi khettesu vapanti tathā tvam pi etāya
translated: it is successful. Therefore, just as they sow the seed in the three fields hoping for a crop, so you also,

original: ārādheyyāsi labheyyāsīti.
analyzed: ārādheyyā asi labheyyā asi iti
translated: Give gifts to all who come, whether they have faith in the fruit or not. Perhaps by giving in this way you will please and win the favour of those worthy of offerings.”

original: Tato maṇḍabyo gāthamāha –
analyzed: tatas maṇḍabyaḥ gātham āha
translated: Then the pavilion-dweller spoke this verse:

original: “Khettāni mayhaṃ viditāni loke, yesāhaṃ bījāni patiṭṭhapemi;

translated: “I know the fields in the world, where I sow my seeds;

analyzed: ye brāhmaṇāḥ tāni idha khettāni su pesalāni iti
translated: Those brahmins who are endowed with birth and mantras, these are the fields that are very good.”

analyzed: tattha yesu aham aham jāti mantu upapannā ati jātiyā ca mantehi ca upapannā
translated: Here, “where I” means “in which.” “Endowed with birth and mantras” means “born with birth and mantras.”

analyzed: tatas mahāsattaḥ dve gāthāḥ abhāsi

original: “Jātimado ca atimānitā ca, lobho ca doso ca mado ca moho;

translated: “Birth-pride, overweening pride, greed, hatred, pride, and delusion;

analyzed: ete aguṇāḥ yesu ca santi sabbe tāni idha khettāni apesalāni
translated: These bad qualities are in all of them, these fields are not good.”

original: “Jātimado ca atimānitā ca, lobho ca doso ca mado ca moho;
analyzed: jāti madaḥ ca atimāni tā ca lobho ca dosaḥ ca madaḥ ca mohaḥ
translated: “Birth-pride, overweening pride, greed, hatred, pride, and delusion;

original: Ete aguṇā yesu na santi sabbe, tānīdha khettāni supesalānī”ti.
analyzed: ete aguṇāḥ yesu na santi sabbe tāni idha khettāni su pesalāni iti
translated: These bad qualities are not in all of them, these fields are very good.”

original: Tattha jātimadoti “ahamasmi jātisampanno”ti evaṃ uppannamāno. Atimānitā cāti “añño
analyzed: tattha jāti mado ti aham asmi jāti sampannaḥ ti evam uppanna mānaḥ atimāni tā ca ati aññaḥ
translated: Here, “birth-pride” means the pride that arises thinking “I am endowed with birth.” “Overweening pride” means “I am superior to others” or “I am equal to others.”

original: mayā saddhiṃ jātiādīhi sadiso natthī”ti atikkamma pavattamāno. Lobhādayo lubbhanadussanamajjanamuyhanamattāva.
analyzed: mayā saddhim jāti ādīhi sadisaḥ natthi iti atikkamma pavattamānaḥ lobha ādayaḥ
translated: “There is no one equal to me in birth, etc.”, and so he goes beyond the bounds of propriety. Greed, etc., are mere lusting, hating, and deluding.

original: Apesalānīti evarūpā puggalā āsīvisabharitā viya vammikā appiyasīlā honti. Evarūpānaṃ
analyzed: apesalāni iti evarūpā puggalā viya vammikāḥ appiya sīlāḥ honti
translated: “They are like stumps”, i.e., such persons are as disagreeable as an anthill infested with snakes.

original: dinnaṃ na mahapphalaṃ hoti, tasmā mā etesaṃ supesalakhettabhāvaṃ maññittha. Na hi
analyzed: dinnam na mahat phalam hoti tasmā mā etesam supesala khetta bhāvam maññittha na hi
translated: What is given to them does not bring great fruit, therefore do not think of them as being good fields.

original: jātimantā saggadāyakā. Ye pana jātimānādirahitā ariyā, tāni khettāni supesalāni,
analyzed: jātimantā sagga dāyakā ye pana jātimān ādi rahitā ariyā tāni khettāni su pesalāni
translated: They are not endowed with birth, etc., and do not give heavenly bliss. But those who are free from birth, etc., and are noble, are good fields,

original: tesu dinnaṃ mahapphalaṃ, te saggadāyakā hontīti.
analyzed: tesu dinnam mahapphalam te sagga dāyakāḥ honti iti
translated: for what is given to them brings great fruit. They are givers of heavenly bliss.

original: Iti so mahāsatte punappunaṃ kathente kujjhitvā “ayaṃ ativiya bahuṃ vippalapati, kuhiṃ gatā ime dovārikā, nayimaṃ caṇḍālaṃ nīharantī”ti gāthamāha –
analyzed: iti saḥ mahāsatte punappunam kathente kujjhitvā ayam bahum vippalapati kuhim gatāḥ ime dovārikāḥ na imam caṇḍālam nīharanti iti gātham āha
translated: Thus, as the Great Being spoke again and again, the king became angry and said, “He talks too much. Where have the doorkeepers gone? They do not drag this caṇḍāla away!” And he spoke this verse:

original: “Kvettha gatā upajotiyo ca, upajjhāyo atha vā gaṇḍakucchi;
analyzed: kva ittha gatā upajotiyaḥ ca upajjhāyaḥ atha vā gaṇḍakucchi
translated: “Where have the Upajotiyas gone, the Upajjhāyas, and the Gaṇḍakucchis?

original: Imassa daṇḍañca vadhañca datvā, gale gahetvā khalayātha jamma”nti.
analyzed: imassa daṇḍañca vadhañca da tvā gale gahetvā khalayā atha
translated: Give him punishment and death, and having seized him by the neck, drag him away!”

original: Tattha kvettha gatāti imesu tīsu dvāresu ṭhapitā upajotiyo ca upajjhāyo ca gaṇḍakucchi cāti tayo dovārikā kuhiṃ gatāti attho.
analyzed: tattha kva ittha gatā ati imesu tīsu dvāresu ṭhapitā upajotiyo ca upajjhāyo ca gaṇḍakucchi ca ati tayo dovārikā kuhim gatā ati attho
translated: “Where are they?” means: “Where are the three door-keepers, the Upajoti, the Upajjhāya, and the Gaṇḍakucchi, who were placed at the three gates?”

original: Tepi tassa vacanaṃ sutvā vegenāgantvā vanditvā “kiṃ karoma devā”ti āhaṃsu. “Ayaṃ
analyzed: te pi tassa vacanam sutvā vegena āgantvā vanditvā kim karoma deva ati āhaṃsu ayam
translated: They, too, having heard his words, came quickly, saluted him, and said: “What shall we do, your majesty?”🔽“Have you seen this pariah, my son?”

original: vo jammo caṇḍālo diṭṭho”ti? “Na passāma deva, kutoci āgatabhāvaṃ na jānāmā”ti. “Ko
analyzed: vaḥ jammo caṇḍālo diṭṭho ti na passāma deva kutoci āgata bhāvam na jānāma ati ko
translated: “We have not seen him, your majesty, we do not know from where he has come.”🔽“Who can he be, a magician or a sorcerer? What are you doing now?”

original: cesa māyākāro vā vijjādharo vā bhavissati, idāni kiṃ tiṭṭhathā”ti. “Kiṃ karoma devā”ti?
analyzed: māyākāraḥ vā vijjādharaḥ vā bhavissati idāni kim tiṭṭhatha ati kim karoma deva ati
translated: “What shall we do, your majesty?”

original: “Imassa mukhameva pothetvā bhindantā daṇḍaveḷupesikāhi piṭṭhicammaṃ uppāṭentā vadhañca
analyzed: imassa mukham eva pothetvā bhindantā daṇḍa veḷu pesikāhi piṭṭhi cammam uppāṭentā vadham ca
translated: “Having torn his face to pieces, having torn his skin with sticks and rods, having killed him,

original: datvā gale gahetvā etaṃ jammaṃ khalayātha, ito nīharathā”ti.
analyzed: da tvā gale gahetvā etam jammam khalayātha itas nīharatha ati
translated: and having seized him by the neck, you must take this pariah away from here.”

original: Mahāsatto tesu attano santikaṃ anāgatesveva uppatitvā ākāse ṭhito gāthamāha –
analyzed: mahāsatto tesu attano santikam anāgatesu eva uppatitvā ākāse ṭhitaḥ gātham āha
translated: Even before they had come near him, the Great Being rose up into the air and standing there, spoke this stanza:

original: “Giriṃ nakhena khaṇasi, ayo dantehi khādasi;
analyzed: girim nakhena khaṇasi ayaḥ dantehi khādasi
translated: “You dig the mountain with your nails, you eat iron with your teeth,

original: Jātavedaṃ padahasi, yo isiṃ paribhāsasī”ti.
analyzed: jātavedam padahasi yaḥ isim paribhāsasi iti
translated: You kick the fire, you who revile the seer.”

original: Tattha jātavedaṃ padahasīti aggiṃ gilituṃ vāyamasi.
analyzed: tattha jātavedam padahasi iti aggim gilitum vāyamasi
translated: You are trying to swallow the fire.

original: Imañca pana gāthaṃ vatvā mahāsatto passantasseva māṇavassa ca brāhmaṇānañca ākāse pakkhandi. Tamatthaṃ pakāsento satthā āha –
analyzed: iman ca pana gātham vatvā mahāsatto passantassa iva māṇavassa ca brāhmaṇānam ca ākāse pakkhandi tam attham pakāsentaḥ satthā āha
translated: Having spoken this verse, the Great Being flew up into the air before the eyes of the young brāhman and the brāhmans. Expounding this matter, the Master said:

original: “Idaṃ vatvāna mātaṅgo, isi saccaparakkamo;
analyzed: idam vatvāna mātaṅgaḥ isi sacca parakkamaḥ
translated: Having spoken this, Mātaṅga, the seer of true prowess,

original: Antalikkhasmiṃ pakkāmi, brāhmaṇānaṃ udikkhata”nti.
analyzed: antalikkhasmin pakkāmi brāhmaṇānam udikkhatanti

translated: At that moment a boy was gathering wood, singing that song. Citta the Wise called to him.

original: āgantvā vanditvā aṭṭhāsi. Atha naṃ āha – “tvaṃ pātova paṭṭhāya imameva gītaṃ gāyasi,
analyzed: āgantvā vanditvā aṭṭhāsi atha nam āha tvam pātova paṭṭhāya imam eva gītam gāyasi
translated: and stood before the king after paying obeisance. Then the king said to him, “You have been singing this same song since morning.

original: kiṃ aññaṃ na jānāsī”ti. “Bhante, aññānipi bahūni jānāmi, imāni pana dve rañño piyagītāni,🔽tasmā imāneva gāyāmī”ti. “Atthi pana rañño gītassa paṭigītaṃ gāyanto”ti? “Natthi
analyzed: kim aññam na jānāsi iti bhante aññāni api bahūni jānāmi imāni pana dve raññaḥ piya gītāni  tasmai imān eva gāyāmi iti atthi pana raññaḥ gītassa paṭigītam gāyanto ti natthi
translated: Do you know any other?” “Reverend Sir, I know many others, but these two songs are the king’s favorite songs,

original: bhante”ti. “Sakkhissasi pana tvaṃ paṭigītaṃ gāyitu”nti? “Jānanto sakkhissāmī”ti.
analyzed: bhante ti sakkhissasi pana tvam paṭigītam gāyitun ti jānantaḥ sakkhissāmi iti
translated: and therefore I sing them.” “But is there anyone who can sing a song in reply to the king’s song?” “There is not, Reverend Sir.” “But can you sing a song in reply to the king’s song?” “If I know it, I can.”

original: “Tena hi tvaṃ raññā dvīsu gītesu gāyitesu idaṃ tatiyaṃ katvā gāyassū”ti gītaṃdatvā
analyzed: tena hi tvam raññā dvīsu gītesu gāyitesu idam tatiyam katvā gāyassu uti gītam datvā
translated: “Well then, when the king has sung two songs, you sing this third song in reply.” And with that he gave him the song.

original: “gantvā rañño santike gāyissasi, rājā te pasīditvā mahantaṃ issariyaṃ dassatī”ti uyyojesi.
analyzed: gantvā rañño santike gāyissasi rājā te pasīditvā mahantam issariyam dassati iti uyyojesi
translated: “Go and sing it in the presence of the king. The king will be pleased with you and will give you great wealth.”

original: So sīghaṃ mātu santikaṃ gantvā attānaṃ alaṅkārāpetvā rājadvāraṃ gantvā “eko kira
analyzed: saḥ sīgham mātuḥ santikam gantvā attānam alaṅkārāpetvā rājadvāram gantvā ekaḥ kira
translated: He went quickly to his mother and had himself adorned with ornaments. Then he went to the palace gate and had it announced, “A certain youth will sing a song in reply to the king’s song.”

original: dārako tumhehi saddhiṃ paṭigītaṃ gāyissatī”ti rañño ārocāpetvā “āgacchatū”ti vutte
analyzed: dārako tumhehi saddhim paṭigītam gāyissati iti raññaḥ ārocāpetvā āgacchatu uti vutte
translated: When the king heard this, he said, “Let him come in.”

original: gantvā vanditvā “tvaṃ kira, tāta, paṭigītaṃ gāyissasī”ti puṭṭho “āma, deva, sabbaṃ🔽rājaparisaṃ sannipātethā”ti sannipatitāya parisāya rājānaṃ āha “tumhe tāva, deva,
analyzed: gantvā vanditvā tvam kira tāta paṭigītam gāyissasi iti puṭṭhaḥ deva sabbam  rāja parisam sannipātetha ati sannipatitāya parisāya rājānam āha tumhe tāva deva
translated: and after worshipping him, asked, “Father, it is said that you will sing a song that you have composed, is that right?” “Yes, your majesty,🔽and after the whole royal assembly had assembled, he said to the king, “Your majesty,🔽

original: tumhākaṃ gītaṃ gāyatha, athāhaṃ paṭigītaṃ gāyissāmī”ti. Rājā gāthādvayamāha –
analyzed: tumhākam gītam gāyatha atha aham paṭigītam gāyissāmi iti rājā gāthā dvayam āha
translated: and after paying homage, asked, “Dear sir, it is said that you will sing a song in reply to the king’s song. Is that so?” “Yes, sire.” “Then assemble the whole royal retinue.” When the assembly had met, he said to the king, “Sire, you sing your song first. Then I will sing a song in reply.” The king sang two stanzas:🔽“All men’s deeds bear fruit,

original: “Sabbaṃ narānaṃ saphalaṃ suciṇṇaṃ, na kammunā kiñcana moghamatthi;
analyzed: sabbam sa phalam su ciṇṇam na kammunā kiñcana mogham atthi
translated: No deed is fruitless;🔽I see the mighty Sambhūta,

original: Passāmi sambhūtaṃ mahānubhāvaṃ, sakammunā puññaphalūpapannaṃ.
analyzed: passāmi sambhūtam mahā anubhāvam sa kammunā puñña phala upapannam
translated: The fruit of his merit has come to pass.🔽“All men’s deeds bear fruit,

original: “Sabbaṃ narānaṃ saphalaṃ suciṇṇaṃ, na kammunā kiñcana moghamatthi;
analyzed: sabbam sa phalam su ciṇṇam na kammunā kiñcana mogham atthi
translated: No deed is fruitless;🔽Is it so with Citta too?

original: Kaccinnu cittassapi evamevaṃ, iddho mano tassa yathāpi mayha”nti.🔽Tattha na kammunā kiñcana moghamatthīti sukatadukkaṭesu kammesu kiñcana ekakammampi
analyzed: kaccit nu cittassa api evam evam iddhaḥ manaḥ tassa yathā api  tattha na kammunā kiñcana mogham atthi iti su kata dukkaṭesu kammesu kiñcana eka kammam pi
translated: Is his mind as powerful as mine?”🔽Herein, no deed is fruitless means that there is no such thing as a fruitless deed, whether good or bad;

original: moghaṃ nāma natthi, nipphalaṃ na hoti, vipākaṃ datvāva nassatīti aparāpariyavedanīyakammaṃ
analyzed: mogham nāma natthi nipphalam na hoti vipākam da tvā ava nassati iti apara apariya vedanīya kammaṃ
translated: no deed is fruitless, no deed is wasted, for it does not vanish without yielding its result. It is only when it has given its result that it vanishes.

original: sandhāyāha. Sambhūtanti attānaṃ vadati, passāmahaṃ āyasmantaṃ sambhūtaṃ sakena kammena
analyzed: sandhāya āha sambhūtanti attānam vadati passāmaham āyasmantam sambhūtam sakena kammena
translated: and said:🔽“I see you, Sir, as one who has attained to a state of bliss through his own deeds.🔽I see you as one who has attained to a state of bliss through the fruit of his own deeds, through his own actions.

original: puññaphalūpapannaṃ, sakammaṃ nissāya puññaphalena upapannaṃ taṃ passāmīti attho.
analyzed: puñña phala upapannam sa kammam nissāya puñña phalena upapannam tam passāmi iti attho
translated: Have you, too, attained to a state of bliss through your own deeds?

original: Kaccinnu cittassapīti mayañhi dvepi janā ekato hutvā na ciraṃ sīlaṃ rakkhimha, ahaṃ
analyzed: kaccit nu cittassa api iti mayan hi dve pi janāḥ ekatas hutvā na ciram sīlam rakkhimha aham
translated: We two were together, and for a long time we both kept the precepts.🔽I have attained to a state of great bliss through the fruit of my own deeds.

original: tāva tassa phalena mahantaṃ yasaṃ patto, kacci nu kho me bhātikassa cittassapi evameva🔽mano iddho samiddhoti.
analyzed: tāva tassa phalena mahantam yasam patto kacci nu kho me bhātikassa cittassa api evam eva  manaḥ iddhaḥ samiddhaḥ iti
translated: Have you, too, attained to a state of bliss through your own deeds?🔽Have you, too, attained to a state of bliss through the fruit of your own deeds?”

original: Tassa gītāvasāne dārako gāyanto tatiyaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: tassa gīta avasāne dārakaḥ gāyantaḥ tatiyam gātham āha
translated: At the end of the song the boy sang the third stanza:

original: “Sabbaṃ narānaṃ saphalaṃ suciṇṇaṃ, na kammunā kiñcana moghamatthi;
analyzed: sabbam sa phalam su ciṇṇam na kammunā kiñcana mogham atthi
translated: “All men reap the fruit of their good deeds; there is nothing in vain in the world of men.

original: Cittampi jānāhi tatheva deva, iddho mano tassa yathāpi tuyha”nti.
analyzed: cittam pi jānāhi tathā iva devaḥ iddhaḥ mano tassa yathā api tuyhanti
translated: Know, O King, that the mind is the same; the mind of this boy is as strong as yours.”

original: Taṃ sutvā rājā catutthaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: tam sutvā rājā catuttham gātham āha
translated: When the King heard this, he sang the fourth stanza:

original: “Bhavaṃ nu citto sutamaññato te, udāhu te koci naṃ etadakkhā;
analyzed: bhavam nu cittaḥ suta maññataḥ te udāhu te koci naṃ etad akkhā
translated: “Is it your mind, Sir, that knows what you have heard, or has someone else told you this?

original: Gāthā sugītā na mamatthi kaṅkhā, dadāmi te gāmavaraṃ satañcā”ti.🔽Tattha sutamaññato teti ahaṃ sambhūtassa bhātā citto nāmāti vadantassa cittasseva
analyzed: gāthā su gītā na mamatthi kaṅkhā dadāmi te gām avaram  tattha suta maññataḥ te ti aham sambhūtassa bhātā cittaḥ nāma ati vadantassa cittassa iva
translated: I have no doubt that the verse was well sung; I give you a hundred villages and the best village.”🔽Herein, I have heard from someone else means I have heard this from Citta, who is the brother of the king who has been reborn.

original: nu te santikā sutanti attho. Koci nanti udāhu mayā sambhūtassa rañño bhātā citto🔽diṭṭhoti koci te etamatthaṃ ācikkhi. Sugītāti sabbathāpi ayaṃ gāthā sugītā, natthettha
analyzed: nu te santikā sutanti attho koci nanti udāhu mayā sambhūtassa raññaḥ bhātā citto  diṭṭhaḥ ti koci te etam attham ācikkhi su gītā ti sabbathā api ayam gāthā su gītā nattha ittha
translated: The meaning is: I have heard it from him. Has anyone told you this, or have I seen your brother Citta,

original: mama kaṅkhā. Gāmavaraṃ satañcāti gāmavarānaṃ te sataṃ dadāmīti vadati.
analyzed: mama kaṅkhā gām avaram te tam dadāmi iti vadati
translated: the king who has been reborn? Well sung means the verse was well sung in every way; I have no doubt about it. A hundred villages and the best village means I give you a hundred of the best villages.

original: Tato dārako pañcamaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: tatas dārakaḥ pañcamam gātham āha
translated: Then the boy spoke the fifth verse:

original: “Na cāhaṃ citto sutamaññato me, isī ca me etamatthaṃ asaṃsi;
analyzed: na ca aham cittaḥ suta maññataḥ me isī ca me etam attham asaṃsi
translated: “I am not Citta, I have heard from someone else; a seer told me this;

original: Gantvāna rañño paṭigāhi gāthaṃ, api te varaṃ attamano dadeyyā”ti.
analyzed: gantvāna raññaḥ paṭigāhi gātham api te varam atta manaḥ dadeyya ati
translated: Go and tell the king the verse; perhaps he will give you a boon that will please you.”

original: Tattha etamatthanti tumhākaṃ uyyāne nisinno eko isi mayhaṃ etamatthaṃ ācikkhi.
analyzed: tattha etam attham ti tumhākam uyyāne nisinnaḥ ekaḥ isi mayham etam attham ācikkhi
translated: Herein, a seer told me this means a seer sitting in your park told me this.

original: Taṃ sutvā rājā “so mama bhātā citto bhavissati, idāneva naṃ gantvā passissāmī”ti purise āṇāpento gāthādvayamāha –
analyzed: tam sutvā rājā saḥ mama bhātā cittaḥ bhavissati idānā iva nam gantvā passissāmi iti purise āṇāpentaḥ gāthā dvayam āha
translated: When the king heard this, he thought to himself, “He is my brother. He must be Citta. I will go and see him.” So he gave orders to his men, saying, “Yoke the royal chariots,” and uttered the following two stanzas,

original: “Yojentu ve rājarathe, sukate cittasibbane;
analyzed: yojentu ve rāja rathe su kate citta sibbane
translated: Yoke the royal chariots, well-made, well-adorned,

original: Kacchaṃ nāgānaṃ bandhatha, gīveyyaṃ paṭimuñcatha.
analyzed: kaccham nāgānam bandhatha gīveyyam paṭimuñcatha
translated: Harness the elephants, and let the horses be saddled.

original: “Āhaññantu bherimudiṅgasaṅkhe, sīghāni yānāni ca yojayantu;
analyzed: āhaññantu bheri mudiṅga saṅkhe sīghāni yānāni ca yojayantu
translated: Let the drums and the tabors and the conches be beaten, and let the swift chariots be yoked.

original: Ajjevahaṃ assamaṃ taṃ gamissaṃ, yattheva dakkhissamisiṃ nisinna”nti.
analyzed: ajja iva aham assamam tam gamissam yatthā iva dakkhissam isim nisinnanti
translated: This very day I will go to the hermitage, and there I will see the lion seated.

original: Tattha āhaññantūti āhanantu. Assamaṃ tanti taṃ assamaṃ.
analyzed: tattha āhaññantu uti āhanantu assamam tam assamam
translated: Herein, let the drums be beaten means let them be beaten. To the hermitage means to that hermitage.

original: So evaṃ vatvā rathaṃ abhiruyha sīghaṃ gantvā uyyānadvāre rathaṃ ṭhapetvā cittapaṇḍitaṃ upasaṅkamitvā vanditvā ekamantaṃ nisinno tuṭṭhamānaso aṭṭhamaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: saḥ evam vatvā ratham abhiruyha sīgham gantvā uyyāna dvāre ratham ṭhapetvā cittapaṇḍitam upasaṅkamitvā vanditvā ekamantam nisinnaḥ tuṭṭha mānasaḥ aṭṭhamam gātham āha
translated: After the king had thus spoken, he mounted his chariot and went quickly to the hermitage. At the gate of the hermitage he alighted from his chariot and approached Citta the youth. He saluted Citta the youth and sat down respectfully on one side. With a glad heart he uttered the following stanza,

original: “Suladdhalābho vata me ahosi, gāthā sugītā parisāya majjhe;
analyzed: su laddha lābhaḥ vata me ahosi gāthā su gītā parisāya majjhe
translated: How well have I succeeded! In the midst of the assembly a well-spoken stanza has been uttered.

original: Svāhaṃ isiṃ sīlavatūpapannaṃ, disvā patīto sumanohamasmī”ti.
analyzed: svāham isim sīlavatu upapannam disvā sumanaḥ ham asmi iti
translated: I have seen the seer who is endowed with virtue. I am filled with joy and gladness.

original: Tassattho – suladdhalābho vata mayhaṃ chattamaṅgaladivase parisāya majjhe gītagāthā sugītāva ahosi, svāhaṃ ajja sīlavatasampannaṃ isiṃ disvā pītisomanassappatto jātoti.
analyzed: tassa atthaḥ su laddha lābhaḥ vata mayham chatta maṅgala divase parisāya majjhe gīta gāthā su gītā ava ahosi svāham ajja sīlavata sampannam isim disvā pīti somanassa pattaḥ jātaḥ iti
translated: The meaning is: “How well sung was the song and verse in the midst of the assembly on the day of the festival of the parasol! Today I have seen a sage endowed with virtue and have become filled with joy and gladness.”

original: So cittapaṇḍitassa diṭṭhakālato paṭṭhāya somanassappatto “bhātikassa me pallaṅkaṃ attharathā”tiādīni āṇāpento navamaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: so cittapaṇḍitassa diṭṭha kālataḥ paṭṭhāya somanassa ppattaḥ bhātikassa me pallaṅkam attharatha ati ādīni āṇāpentaḥ navamam gātham āha
translated: From the time he saw Citta the Wise, he was filled with joy. Ordering them to spread a couch for his brother, etc., he spoke the ninth verse:🔽“Seat, water, and a bath,

original: “Āsanaṃ udakaṃ pajjaṃ, paṭiggaṇhātu no bhavaṃ;
analyzed: āsanam udakam pajjam paṭiggaṇhātu naḥ bhavam
translated: may the lord accept from us;🔽We ask the lord for a price,

original: Agghe bhavantaṃ pucchāma, agghaṃ kurutu no bhava”nti.
analyzed: agghe bhavantam pucchāma aggham kurutu naḥ bhavanti
translated: may the lord fix a price for us.”

original: Tattha aggheti atithino dātabbayuttakasmiṃ agghe bhavantaṃ āpucchāma. Kurutu noti imaṃ no agghaṃ bhavaṃ paṭiggaṇhātu.
analyzed: tattha aggha iti atithinaḥ dātabba yuttakasmin agghe bhavantam āpucchāma kurutu no ti imam naḥ aggham bhavam paṭiggaṇhātu
translated: Herein, price means the price of a guest. We ask the lord for a price. Fix means may the lord accept this price of ours.

original: Evaṃ madhurapaṭisanthāraṃ katvā rajjaṃ majjhe bhinditvā dento itaraṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: evam madhura paṭisanthāram katvā rajjam majjhe bhinditvā itaram gātham āha
translated: Having thus welcomed him with sweet words, and dividing his kingdom in the middle, he gave it to him, speaking the second verse:🔽“Let them make a delightful dwelling for you,

original: “Rammañca te āvasathaṃ karontu, nārīgaṇehi paricārayassu;
analyzed: ramman ca te āvasatham karontu nārī gaṇehi paricārayassu
translated: let them serve you with a crowd of women,

original: Karohi okāsamanuggahāya, ubhopimaṃ issariyaṃ karomā”ti.
analyzed: karohi okāsam anuggahāya ubho pimam issariyam karoma ati
translated: Make room for me to do so. Let us both rule this kingdom.”

original: Tattha imaṃ issariyanti kapilaraṭṭhe uttarapañcālanagare rajjaṃ majjhe bhinditvā dvepi janā karoma anubhavāma.
analyzed: tattha imam kapila raṭṭhe uttara pañcāla nagare rajjam majjhe bhinditvā dve api janā karoma anubhavāma
translated: Thereupon Citta, the son of an elephant trainer, said to him, “Let us divide the kingdom of the Kāsi people in the middle of the city of Uttarapañcāla and rule it.”

original: Tassa taṃ vacanaṃ sutvā cittapaṇḍito dhammaṃ desento cha gāthā abhāsi –
analyzed: tassa tam vacanam sutvā citta paṇḍitaḥ dhammaṃ desento cha gāthāḥ abhāsi
translated: Having heard his words, Citta, the son of a counselor, taught the Dhamma in six stanzas:

original: “Disvā phalaṃ duccaritassa rāja, attho suciṇṇassa mahāvipākaṃ;
analyzed: disvā phalam duccaritassa rāja attho su ciṇṇassa mahā vipākam
translated: “Having seen the fruit of evil conduct, O King, the great result of well-practiced good conduct,

original: Attānameva paṭisaṃyamissaṃ, na patthaye putta pasuṃ dhanaṃ vā.
analyzed: attānam eva paṭisaṃyamissam na patthaye putta pasum dhanam vā
translated: I will restrain myself alone; I do not desire children, cattle, or wealth.

original: “Dasevimā vassadasā, maccānaṃ idha jīvitaṃ;
analyzed: dasevimā vassadasā maccānam idha jīvitam
translated: “These ten or twelve years are the life span of mortals here;

original: Apattaññeva taṃ odhiṃ, naḷo chinnova sussati.
analyzed: a pattaññā iva tam odhim naḷaḥ chinnaḥ uva sussati
translated: Before one reaches that limit, one dries up like a cut reed.

original: “Tattha kā nandi kā khiḍḍā, kā ratī kā dhanesanā;
analyzed: tattha kā nandi kā khiḍḍā kā ratī kā dhanesanā
translated: “What joy, what play, what delight, what pursuit of wealth is there for me?

original: Kiṃ me puttehi dārehi, rāja muttosmi bandhanā.
analyzed: kim me puttehi dārehi rāja muttaḥ asmi bandhanā
translated: O King, I am freed from bonds, what do I have to do with children or wife?

original: “Sohaṃ evaṃ pajānāmi, maccu me nappamajjati;
analyzed: saḥ aham evam pajānāmi mat cu me na ppamajjati
translated: “Thus I understand: death does not neglect me.

original: Antakenādhipannassa, kā ratī kā dhanesanā.
analyzed: antakena adhipannassa kā ratī kā dhana īsanā
translated: For one who has fallen into the mouth of the Destroyer, what joy, what pursuit of wealth?

original: “Jāti narānaṃ adhamā janinda, caṇḍālayoni dvipadākaniṭṭhā;
analyzed: jāti caṇḍāla yoni dvipadā kaniṭṭhā
translated: “Birth is the worst for humans, O King, the lowest of the two-footed, the womb of a caṇḍāla;

original: Sakehi kammehi supāpakehi, caṇḍālagabbhe avasimha pubbe.
analyzed: sakehi kammehi su pāpakehi caṇḍāla gabbhe avasimha pubbe
translated: By our own evil deeds, we were born in the womb of a caṇḍāla woman.

original: “Caṇḍālāhumha avantīsu, migā nerañjaraṃ pati;
analyzed: avantīsu migāḥ nerañjaram pati
translated: “We were caṇḍālas in Avantī, deer at Nerañjarā,

original: Ukkusā nammadātīre, tyajja brāhmaṇakhattiyā”ti.🔽Tattha duccaritassāti mahārāja, tvaṃ sucaritasseva phalaṃ jānāsi, ahaṃ pana duccaritassapi
analyzed: ukkusā nammadā tīre tyajja brāhmaṇa khattiyā ati  tattha duccaritassa ati mahā rāja tvam su caritassa iva phalam jānāsi aham pana duccaritassa api
translated: And cranes on the banks of the Madā river; now we are abandoned by brahmins and khattiyas.”

original: phalaṃ passāmiyeva. Mayañhi ubho duccaritassa phalena ito catutthe attabhāve caṇḍālayoniyaṃ
analyzed: phalam mayan hi ubho duccaritassa phalena ito catutthe atta bhāve caṇḍāla yoniyam
translated: Herein, “of evil conduct”: Your Majesty, you know the fruit of good conduct, but I see the fruit of evil conduct. For we both were reborn in our fourth existence in the womb of a caṇḍāla woman

original: nibbattā. Tattha na ciraṃ sīlaṃ rakkhitvā tassa phalena tvaṃ khattiyakule nibbatto,
analyzed: nibbattā tattha na ciram sīlam rakkhitvā tassa phalena tvam khattiya kule nibbatto
translated: as a result of evil conduct. There I guarded my virtue for a long time, and as a result of that I was reborn in a khattiya family,

original: ahaṃ brāhmaṇakule, evāhaṃ duccaritassa ca phalaṃ suciṇṇassa ca mahāvipākaṃ disvā
analyzed: aham brāhmaṇa kule eva aham duccaritassa ca phalam su ciṇṇassa ca mahā vipākam disvā
translated: and you were reborn in a brahmin family. Thus I see the great result of evil conduct and of well-observed virtue.

original: attānameva sīlasaṃyamena paṭisaṃyamissaṃ, puttaṃ vā pasuṃ vā dhanaṃ vā na patthemi.
analyzed: attānam eva sīla saṃyamena paṭisaṃyamissam puttam vā pasum vā dhanam vā na patthemi
translated: Therefore I will restrain myself by virtue and self-control; I do not desire a son, cattle, or wealth.

original: Dasevimā vassadasāti mahārāja, mandadasakaṃ khiḍḍādasakaṃ vaṇṇadasakaṃ baladasakaṃ
analyzed: mahā rāja manda dasakam khiḍḍā dasakam vaṇṇa dasakam bala dasakam
translated: “Ten times ten years”: Your Majesty, ten times ten years is the period of the tenfold decadence.

original: paññādasakaṃ hānidasakaṃ pabbhāradasakaṃ vaṅkadasakaṃ momūhadasakaṃ sayanadasakanti
analyzed: paññādasakam hānidasakam pabbhāra dasakam vaṅka dasakam momūha dasakam sayana dasakanti
translated: Ten sets of ten years, namely, the ten sets of ten beginning with the ten kinds of understanding, the ten kinds of loss, the ten kinds of effacement, the ten kinds of crookedness, the ten kinds of stagnation, and the ten kinds of slumbers,

original: imesañhi dasannaṃ dasakānaṃ vasena daseva vassadasā imesaṃ maccānaṃ idha manussaloke🔽jīvitaṃ. Tayidaṃ na niyamena sabbā eva etā dasā pāpuṇāti, atha kho appattaññeva taṃ
analyzed: imesam hi dasannam dasakānam vasena dasā iva vassa dasā imesam maccānam idha manussa loke  jīvitam tayidam na niyamena sabbāḥ eva etāḥ dasā pāpuṇāti atha kho appattaññā iva tam
translated: for these mortals here in the human world,🔽life is only ten sets of ten years. But it does not happen that all these ten sets of ten are reached by everyone.

original: odhiṃ naḷo chinnova sussati. Yepi sakalaṃ vassasataṃ jīvanti, tesampi mandadasake🔽pavattā rūpārūpadhammā vicchinditvā ātape khittanaḷo viya tattheva sussanti antaradhāyanti,
analyzed: odhim naḷaḥ chinnaḥ uva sussati ye pi sakalam vassa satam jīvanti tesam pi manda dasake  pavattāḥ rūpa arūpa dhammāḥ vicchinditvā ātape khitta naḷaḥ viya tattha iva sussanti antaradhāyanti
translated: For even before reaching that age, he dries up and fades like a headless trunk, and the material and immaterial states occurring in the ten years of the slow decline

original: taṃ odhiṃ atikkamitvā khiḍḍādasakaṃ na pāpuṇanti, tathā khiṭṭādasakādīsu pavattā vaṇṇadasakādīni.
analyzed: tam odhim atikkamitvā khiḍḍādasakam na pāpuṇanti tathā khiṭṭādasaka ādīsu pavattā vaṇṇa dasaka ādīni
translated: dry up and fade there too like a palm leaf scorched by a flame, and he does not reach the ten years of play. So too, the ten years of beauty, etc.,

original: Tatthāti tasmiṃ evaṃ sussamāne jīvite kā pañca kāmaguṇe nissāya abhinandī, kā kāyakīḷādivasena
analyzed: tattha ati tasmin evam sussamāne jīvite kā pañca kāmaguṇe nissāya abhinandī kā kāya kīḷā ādi vasena
translated: Herein, what is the “here” in the phrase “Here, bhikkhus, a bhikkhu does not delight in and enjoy …” ? It is this: while life is thus fading and drying up, what five cords of sensual pleasure does he delight in and enjoy? What five kinds of bodily and mental pleasure? What five kinds of play?

original: khiḍḍā, kā somanassavasena rati, kā dhanesanā, kiṃ me puttehi, kiṃ dārehi, muttosmi
analyzed: khiḍḍā kā somanassa vasena rati kā dhana īsanā kim me puttehi kim dārehi muttaḥ asmi
translated: What is the use of children, what of wife, I am free

original: tamhā puttadārabandhanāti attho. Antakenādhipannassāti jīvitantakarena maccunā abhibhūtassa.
analyzed: tamhā putta dāra bandhanā ti attho antakena adhipannassa ati jīvitanta karena maccunā abhibhūtassa
translated: from that bondage of children and wife. Antakenādhipannassa: to one overcome by the destroyer of life, by death.

original: Dvipadākaniṭṭhāti dvipadānaṃ antare lāmakā. Avasimhāti dvepi mayaṃ vasimha.
analyzed: dvipadā kaniṭṭhā ati dvipadānam antare lāmakāḥ avasimha ati dve api mayam vasimha
translated: Dvipadākaniṭṭhāti: among bipeds, the lowest. Avasimhāti: we both lived.

original: Caṇḍālāhumhāti mahārāja, ito pubbe catutthaṃ jātiṃ avantiraṭṭhe ujjeninagare caṇḍālā
analyzed: mahā rāja itas pubbe catuttham jātim avantiraṭṭhe ujjeni nagare caṇḍālāḥ
translated: Caṇḍālāhumhāti: O great king, in the past, in the fourth birth, in the Avanti country, in the city of Ujjeni, we were

original: ahumha, tato cavitvā nerañjarāya nadiyā tīre ubhopi migā ahumha. Tattha dvepi amhe
analyzed: ahumha tatas cavitvā nerañjarāya nadiyā tīre ubho pi migā ahumha tattha dve pi amhe
translated: caṇḍāla. After that, having died, on the bank of the river Nerañjarā, we were both deer. There, both of us

original: ekasmiṃ rukkhamūle aññamaññaṃ nissāya ṭhite eko luddako ekeneva sattipahārena jīvitā
analyzed: ekasmim rukkha mūle aññamaññam nissāya ṭhite ekaḥ luddakaḥ ekena iva satti pahārena jīvitā
translated: standing at the foot of a tree, depending on each other, a hunter with a single blow of an arrow deprived us of life,

original: voropesi, tato cavitvā nammadānadītīre kurarā ahumha. Tatrāpi no nissāya ṭhite eko
analyzed: voropesi tatas cavitvā nammadā nadī tīre kurarāḥ ahumha tatra api no nissāya ṭhite ekaḥ
translated: having died from there, on the bank of the river Nammadā, we were kurara birds. There too, while we were standing depending on each other, a hunter

original: nesādo ekappahāreneva bandhitvā jīvitakkhayaṃ pāpesi, tato cavitvā te mayaṃ ajja
analyzed: nesādaḥ eka pahārena iva bandhitvā jīvita kkhayam pāpesi tatas cavitvā te mayam ajja
translated: having bound us with a single snare, brought us to the destruction of life, having died from there, we today

original: brāhmaṇakhattiyā jātā. Ahaṃ kosambiyaṃ brāhmaṇakule nibbatto, tvaṃ idha rājā jātoti.
analyzed: brāhmaṇa khattiyāḥ jātāḥ aham kosambiyam brāhmaṇa kule nibbatto tvam idha rājā jātaḥ iti
translated: I was born in a brahmin family in Kosambī, and you were born here as a king.”

original: Evamassa atīte lāmakajātiyo pakāsetvā idāni imissāpi jātiyā āyusaṅkhāraparittataṃ dassetvā puññesu ussāhaṃ janento catasso gāthā abhāsi –
analyzed: evam assa atīte lāmaka jātiyaḥ pakāsetvā idāni imissā api jātiyāḥ āyu saṅkhāra paritta tam dassetvā puññesu ussāham janentaḥ catassaḥ gāthāḥ abhāsi
translated: Having thus revealed his former births, he now spoke four verses, showing the shortness of the life-span in this birth, and encouraging him to strive in merit:

original: “Upanīyati jīvitamappamāyu, jarūpanītassa na santi tāṇā;
analyzed: upanīyati jīvitam appamāyu jaru upanītassa na santi tāṇā
translated: “Life is carried away, the life-span is short, for one carried away by old age there is no refuge.

original: Karohi pañcāla mameta vākyaṃ, mākāsi kammāni dukkhudrayāni.
analyzed: karohi pañcāla mama ita vākyam mākā asi kammāni
translated: Do as I say, Pañcāla, do not do deeds that bring suffering.

original: “Upanīyati jīvitamappamāyu, jarūpanītassa na santi tāṇā;
analyzed: upanīyati jīvitam appamāyu jaru upanītassa na santi tāṇā
translated: “Life is carried away, the life-span is short, for one carried away by old age there is no refuge.

original: Karohi pañcāla mameta vākyaṃ, mākāsi kammāni dukkhapphalāni.
analyzed: karohi pañcāla mama ita vākyam mā akāsi kammāni dukkha pphalāni
translated: Do as I say, Pañcāla, do not do deeds that bring suffering.

original: “Upanīyati jīvitamappamāyu, jarūpanītassa na santi tāṇā;
analyzed: upanīyati jīvitam appamāyu jaru upanītassa na santi tāṇā
translated: “Life is carried away, the life-span is short, for one carried away by old age there is no refuge.

original: Karohi pañcāla mameta vākyaṃ, mākāsi kammāni rajassirāni.
analyzed: karohi pañcāla mama ita vākyam mākā asi kammāni rajaḥsirāni
translated: Do as I say, Pañcāla, do not do deeds that bring suffering.

original: “Upanīyati jīvitamappamāyu, vaṇṇaṃ jarā hanti narassa jiyyato;
analyzed: upanīyati jīvitam appamāyu vaṇṇam jarā hanti narassa jiyyataḥ
translated: “Life is carried away, the life-span is short, old age destroys a man’s beauty.

original: Karohi pañcāla mameta vākyaṃ, mākāsi kammaṃ nirayūpapattiyā”ti.
analyzed: karohi pañcāla mama ita vākyam mākā asi kammam
translated: Do as I say, Pañcāla, do not do deeds that lead to rebirth in hell.”

original: Tattha upanīyatīti mahārāja, idaṃ jīvitaṃ maraṇaṃ upagacchati. Idañhi imesaṃ sattānaṃ
analyzed: tattha upanīyati iti mahā rāja idam jīvitam maraṇam upagacchati idam hi imesam sattānam
translated: “Herein, ‘is led on’ means, sire, that this life is led on to death. For this life of beings

original: appamāyu sarasaparittatāyapi ṭhitiparittatāyapi parittakaṃ, sūriyuggamane tiṇagge
analyzed: appamāyu sarasa paritta tāya pi ṭhiti paritta tāya pi parittakam sūri yuj gamane tiṇagge
translated: is short and limited in duration, whether it be limited by the time of life or by the time of illness. It is as limited as the dewdrop on the tip of a blade of grass

original: ussāvabindusadisaṃ. Na santi tāṇāti na hi jarāya maraṇaṃ upanītassa puttādayo tāṇā
analyzed: ussāva bindu sadisam na santi tāṇā ati na hi jarāya maraṇam upanītassa putta ādayo tāṇā
translated: at sunrise. ‘There is no protection’ means that when one is led on to death by old age, sons and so on are not a protection.

original: nāma honti. Mameta vākyanti mama etaṃ vacanaṃ. Mākāsīti mā rūpādikāmaguṇahetu pamādaṃ
analyzed: nāma honti mama etam vacanam mā rūpa ādi kāma guṇa hetu
translated: ‘This is my word’ means this is my statement. ‘Do not’ means do not fall into heedlessness

original: āpajjitvā nirayādīsu dukkhavaḍḍhanāni kammāni kari. Dukkhapphalānīti dukkhavipākāni.
analyzed: āpajjitvā niraya ādīsu dukkha vaḍḍhanāni kammāni dukkha pphalāni iti dukkha vipākāni
translated: through the objects of sensual pleasure such as visible forms and so on. ‘Actions that increase suffering’ means actions that have suffering as their fruit.

original: Rajassirānīti kilesarajena okiṇṇasīsāni. Vaṇṇanti jīramānassa narassa sarīravaṇṇaṃ
analyzed: rajaḥ sirāni iti kilesa rajena okiṇṇa sīsāni vaṇṇanti jīramānassa narassa sarīra vaṇṇam
translated: ‘Heads covered with dust’ means heads covered with the dust of defilements. ‘Beauty’ means the beauty of the body of a man who is growing old.

original: jarā hanti. Nirayūpapattiyāti nirassāde niraye uppajjanatthāya.🔽Evaṃ mahāsatte kathente rājā tussitvā tisso gāthā abhāsi –🔽“Addhā hi saccaṃ vacanaṃ tavetaṃ, yathā isī bhāsasi evametaṃ;
analyzed: jarā hanti niraya upapattiyā ati nirassāde niraye uppajjana tthāya 🔽evam mahāsatte kathente rājā tussitvā tissaḥ gāthāḥ abhāsi 🔽addhā hi saccam vacanam tava etam yathā isī bhāsasi evam etam
translated: Old age destroys it. ‘For rebirth in hell’ means for rebirth in hell which is without any satisfaction.

original: Kāmā ca me santi anapparūpā, te duccajā mādisakena bhikkhu.
analyzed: kāmā ca me santi anapparūpā te duccajāḥ mādisakena bhikkhu
translated: I have desires, not few, hard to be born for one like me, a monk.

original: “Nāgo yathā paṅkamajjhe byasanno, passaṃ thalaṃ nābhisambhoti gantuṃ;
analyzed: nāgaḥ yathā paṅka majjhe byasannaḥ passam thalam na abhisambhoti gantum
translated: As an elephant in the mud, in a bog, sees the dry land but cannot get there,

original: Evampahaṃ kāmapaṅke byasanno, na bhikkhuno maggamanubbajāmi.
analyzed: evam paham kāma paṅke byasannaḥ na bhikkhunaḥ maggam anubbajāmi
translated: So I, in the mud of desire, in a bog, see the monk’s path but cannot follow it.

original: “Yathāpi mātā ca pitā ca puttaṃ, anusāsare kinti sukhī bhaveyya;
analyzed: yathā api mātā ca pitā ca puttam anusāsare kinti sukhī bhaveyya
translated: As a mother and father advise their son, “How can he be happy? “

original: Evampi maṃ tvaṃ anusāsa bhante, yathā ciraṃ pecca sukhī bhaveyya”nti.🔽Tattha anapparūpāti aparittajātikā bahū aparimitā. Te duccajā mādisakenāti bhātika,
analyzed: evam pi mam tvam anusāsa bhante yathā ciram sukhī  tattha anapparūpā ati aparitta jātikā bahū aparimitā te duccajā mādisakena ati bhātika
translated: So advise me, Reverend Sir, so that I may be happy long after you have gone.

original: tvaṃ kilese pahāya ṭhito, ahaṃ pana kāmapaṅke nimuggo, tasmā mādisakena te kāmā duccajā.
analyzed: tvam kilese pahāya ṭhitaḥ aham pana kāma paṅke nimuggo tasmā mādisakena te kāmāḥ duccajāḥ
translated: There, not few means not few kinds, many, unlimited. Hard to be born for one like me, a monk means, brother, you have stood aside from the defilements, but I am sunk in the mud of desire, therefore for one like me, a monk, these desires are hard to be born.

original: “Nāgo yathā”ti iminā attano kāmapaṅke nimuggabhāvassa upamaṃ dasseti. Tattha byasannoti
analyzed: nāgaḥ yathā iti iminā attano kāma paṅke nimugga bhāvassa upamam dasseti tattha byasannaḥ ti
translated: As an elephant in the mud means he shows the simile for his own sinking in the mud of desire. There, in a bog means

original: visanno anupaviṭṭho ayameva vā pāṭho. Magganti tumhākaṃ ovādānusāsanīmaggaṃ nānubbajāmi
analyzed: visannaḥ an upaviṭṭhaḥ ayam eva vā pāṭhaḥ magganti tumhākam ovāda anusāsanī maggam na anubbajāmi
translated: disappointed, fallen into, or this is the reading: the path means I do not follow the path of your advice and instruction.

original: pabbajituṃ na sakkomi, idheva pana me ṭhitassa ovādaṃ dethāti. Anusāsareti anusāsanti.
analyzed: pabbajitum na sakkomi idha iva pana me ṭhitassa ovādam detha ati anusāsara iti anusāsanti
translated: I am unable to go forth, but please give me instruction right here where I stand.”

original: Atha naṃ mahāsatto āha –
analyzed: atha nam mahāsattaḥ āha
translated: Then the Great Being said:

original: “No ce tuvaṃ ussahase janinda, kāme ime mānusake pahātuṃ;
analyzed: no ce tuvam ussahase janinda kāme ime mānusake pahātum
translated: “If you are unable, O King, to abandon these human pleasures,

original: Dhammiṃ baliṃ paṭṭhapayassu rāja, adhammakāro tava māhu raṭṭhe.
analyzed: dhammim balim paṭṭha payassu rāja adhamma kāro tava mā āhu raṭṭhe
translated: Then, O King, establish a righteous sacrifice, and let there be no unrighteousness in your kingdom.

original: “Dūtā vidhāvantu disā catasso, nimantakā samaṇabrāhmaṇānaṃ;
analyzed: dūtāḥ vidhāvantu disā catassaḥ nimantakā samaṇa brāhmaṇānam
translated: “Let messengers run in the four directions, inviting ascetics and brahmans;

original: Te annapānena upaṭṭhahassu, vatthena senāsanapaccayena ca.
analyzed: te anna pānena upaṭṭhahassu vatthena senāsana paccayena ca
translated: And serve them with food and drink, with clothing and with bedding.

original: “Annena pānena pasannacitto, santappaya samaṇabrāhmaṇe ca;
analyzed: annena pānena pasanna cittaḥ santappaya samaṇa brāhmaṇe ca
translated: “With a serene heart, with food and drink, serve ascetics and brahmans;

original: Datvā ca bhutvā ca yathānubhāvaṃ, anindito saggamupehi ṭhānaṃ.
analyzed: da tvā ca bhutvā ca yathā anubhāvam aninditaḥ saggam upehi ṭhānam
translated: And after giving and eating according to your ability, go to heaven, blameless.

original: “Sace ca taṃ rāja mado saheyya, nārīgaṇehi paricārayantaṃ;
analyzed: sace ca tam rāja mado saheyya nārī gaṇehi paricārayantam
translated: “And if, O King, you are overcome by intoxication, while enjoying the company of women,

original: Imameva gāthaṃ manasī karohi, bhāsesi cenaṃ parisāya majjhe.
analyzed: imam eva gātham manasī karohi bhāsesi ca enam parisāya majjhe
translated: Then remember this verse, and if you should recite it in the midst of your assembly:

original: “Abbhokāsasayo jantu, vajantyā khīrapāyito;
analyzed: vajantyā khīra pāyitaḥ
translated: “A creature who sleeps in the open air, who wanders about, who drinks water,

original: Parikiṇṇo suvānehi, svājja rājāti vuccatī”ti.
analyzed: parikiṇṇaḥ suvānehi svājja rājā ati vuccati iti
translated: Who is surrounded by good people, is called a king today.”

original: Tattha ussahaseti ussahasi. Dhammiṃ balinti dhammena samena anatirittaṃ baliṃ gaṇhāti🔽attho. Adhammakāroti porāṇakarājūhi ṭhapitaṃ vinicchayadhammaṃ bhinditvā pavattā🔽adhammakiriyā. Nimantakāti dhammikasamaṇabrāhmaṇe nimantetvā pakkosakā. Yathānubhāvanti
analyzed: tattha ussahasā iti ussahasi dhammim balin ti dhammena samena anatirittam balim gaṇhāti  atthaḥ adhamma kāro ti porāṇaka rājūhi ṭhapitam vinicchaya dhammam bhinditvā pavattā  a dhamma kiriyā nimantakā ati dhammika samaṇa brāhmaṇe nimantetvā pakkosakāḥ yathā anubhāvanti
translated: Herein, ‘Will you strive?’ means ‘Will you strive?’ ‘A righteous tribute’ means a tribute that is taken by means of what is right and proper and is not excessive.🔽The meaning is: ‘a tribute that is not excessive.’ ‘Unrighteousness’ means the practice of unrighteousness that occurs by breaking the law of justice established by the ancient kings.

original: yathābalaṃ yathāsattiṃ. Imameva gāthanti idāni vattabbaṃ sandhāyāha. Tatrāyaṃ adhippāyo🔽– “mahārāja, sace taṃ mado abhibhaveyya, sace te nārīgaṇaparivutassa rūpādayo vā
analyzed: yathābalam yathāsattim imam eva gāthan ti idāni vattabbam sandhāya āha tatra ayam adhippāyaḥ  mahā rāja sace tam madaḥ abhibhaveyya sace te nārī gaṇa parivutassa rūpa ādayaḥ vā
translated: ‘Inviting’ means inviting, summoning righteous ascetics and brahmans. ‘According to their power’ means according to their strength, according to their ability. ‘This very verse’ he says referring to what is to be said now. Herein, this is the intention:

original: kāmaguṇe rajjasukhaṃ vā ārabbha māno uppajjeyya, athevaṃ cinteyyāsi ‘ahaṃ pure caṇḍālayoniyaṃ
analyzed: kāma guṇe rajja sukham vā ārabbha mānaḥ uppajjeyya atha ivam cinteyyāsi aham pure caṇḍāla yoniyam
translated: ‘Great king, if that intoxication should overcome you, if conceit should arise in you on account of the forms, etc., or the happiness of kingship, while you are surrounded by a crowd of women, then you should think thus: “Formerly, when I was reborn in the womb of a female outcast,

original: nibbatto channassa tiṇakuṭimattassapi abhāvā abbhokāsasayo ahosiṃ, tadā hi me mātā
analyzed: nibbattaḥ channassa tiṇa kuṭi mattassa api abhāvā abbhokāsa sayaḥ ahosim tadā hi me mātā
translated: I was lying in the open air because I had no hut of grass even as much as a mat, and my mother,

original: caṇḍālī araññaṃ dārupaṇṇādīnaṃ atthāya gacchantī maṃ kukkuragaṇassa majjhe abbhokāse
analyzed: caṇḍālī araññam dāru paṇṇa ādīnam atthāya gacchantī mam kukkura gaṇassa majjhe abbhokāse
translated: an outcast woman, going to the forest for wood, leaves, etc., left me in the open air in the midst of a pack of dogs.

original: nipajjāpetvā attano khīraṃ pāyetvā gacchati, sohaṃ kukkurehi parivārito tehiyeva
analyzed: nipajjāpetvā attanaḥ khīram pāyetvā gacchati so ham kukkurehi parivārito
translated: and then she would go away. I was surrounded by dogs, and

original: saddhiṃ sunakhiyā khīraṃ pivitvā vaḍḍhito, evaṃ nīcajacco hutvā ajja rājā nāma jāto’ti.
analyzed: saddhim sunakhiyā khīram pivitvā vaḍḍhitaḥ evam nīcajaccaḥ hutvā ajja rājā nāma jātaḥ iti
translated: I grew up drinking milk with the bitch. Thus, though of low birth, I am now called king.’

original: ‘Iti kho, tvaṃ mahārāja, iminā atthena attānaṃ ovadanto yo so pubbe abbhokāsasayo
analyzed: iti kho tvam mahā rāja iminā atthena attānam ovadantaḥ yaḥ saḥ pubbe abbhokāsa sayaḥ
translated: ‘Therefore, great king, when you are reproaching yourself, you should recite this verse: “That being who formerly slept in the open air,

original: jantu araññe vajantiyā caṇḍāliyā ito cito ca anusañcarantiyā sunakhiyā ca khīraṃ
analyzed: jantu araññe vajantiyā caṇḍāliyā ito cito ca anusañcarantiyā su nakhiyā ca khīraṃ

translated: Which they say is hard for a man to give up.”🔽“For the sake of which you have come,

translated: For the sake of which you desire,🔽May your wishes be fulfilled,

original: Rājā ettakaṃ kathetvā “idheva mayā akkhīni uppāṭetvā dātuṃ asāruppa”nti cintetvā

translated: Give us wealth, great king, much pearl and beryl.

original: “Yutte deva rathe dehi, ājānīye calaṅkate;
analyzed: yutte deva rathe dehi ājānīye calaṅkate
translated: “Give us, King, thy chariot harnessed with thy well-trained, fleet,

original: Nāge dehi mahārāja, hemakappanavāsase.
analyzed: nāge dehi mahā rāja hema kappana vāsase
translated: steeds, with its trappings of gold.

original: “Yathā taṃ sivayo sabbe, sayoggā sarathā sadā;

translated: “As all the Śibis, with their waggons and chariots,

original: Tattha parākarīti pariccaji. Akkhīsu hi dinnesu rajjaṃ tvaṃ na kāressasi, añño rājā

analyzed: bhavissati evam tayā mayam pariccattāḥ nāma bhavissāma ati adhippāyena ivam āhaṃsu parikireyyunti  parivāreyyuṃ evam dehi iti yathā tam avikala cakkhum sivayo parivāreyyuṃ evam bāhira dhana mevassa

original: dehi, mā akkhīni. Akkhīsu hi dinnesu na taṃ sivayo parivāressantīti.
analyzed: dehi mā akkhīni akkhīsu hi dinnesu na tam sivayaḥ parivāressanti iti
translated: “Abandon us” means “surround us.” “Give us” means “give us your external wealth in such a way that the jackals will surround you, a man without eyes.” For if he were to give his eyes, the jackals would not surround him.

original: Atha rājā tisso gāthā abhāsi –
analyzed: atha rājā tissaḥ gāthāḥ abhāsi
translated: Then the king spoke three stanzas:

original: “Yo ve dassanti vatvāna, adāne kurute mano;

translated: “He who, having promised to give, changes his mind,

original: “Yo ve dassanti vatvānaṃ, adāne kurute mano;
analyzed: yaḥ ve dassanti vatvānam adāne kurute manaḥ
translated: “He who, having promised to give, changes his mind,

analyzed: pāpā pāpataraḥ hoti sampattaḥ yama sādhanam
translated: becomes more sinful, and comes to Yama’s presence.

original: “Yañhi yāce tañhi dade, yaṃ na yāce na taṃ dade;
analyzed: yam hi yāce tam hi dade yam na yāce na tam dade
translated: “What one asks for, one should give; what one does not ask for, one should not give.

original: Svāhaṃ tameva dassāmi, yaṃ maṃ yācati brāhmaṇo”ti.
analyzed: svāham tam eva dassāmi yam mama yācati brāhmaṇaḥ uti
translated: I myself will give him what the brahmin asks for.”

original: Tattha paṭimuñcatīti paveseti. Pāpā pāpataroti lāmakāpi lāmakataro nāma hoti. Sampatto
analyzed: tattha paṭimuñcati iti pāpā pāpatarā iti lāmakā api lāmakataro nāma hoti sampatto
translated: “There he gives up” means he inserts them. “The worse for the worse” means the more wicked for the more wicked.

analyzed: yama sādhanam ti yamassa āṇā pavatti ṭhānam ussada nirayam nāma hoti yat hi
translated: “He has reached the place of Yama’s punishment” means he has reached the place of Yama’s punishment, the hell of the uprise. For

analyzed: yāca iti yam yācakaḥ yāceyya dāyakaḥ upi tam eva dadeyya na a yācitam ayam ca brāhmaṇaḥ

translated: “Life, beauty, happiness, strength, what did he ask for, O Lord of men, that you give?

translated: Herein, for the sake of the other world means, “Great king, how can a wise man like you, abandoning present sovereignty, give his eyes for the sake of the other world?”

original: Atha nesaṃ kathento rājā gāthamāha –
analyzed: atha nesam kathentaḥ rājā gātham āha
translated: Then the king, speaking to them, spoke this verse:

original: “Na vāhametaṃ yasasā dadāmi, na puttamicche na dhanaṃ na raṭṭhaṃ;

analyzed: satañca dhammo carito purāṇo iccā iva dāne ramate manaḥ mama ati
translated: The ancient way of the good is this: my mind delights in giving.”

original: Tattha na vāhanti na ve ahaṃ. Yasasāti dibbassa vā mānusassa vā yasassa kāraṇā. Na
analyzed: tattha na vā ahanti na aham yasasā ati dibbassa vā mānusassa vā yasassa kāraṇā na

analyzed: puttam iccha iti imassa cakkhudānassa phalena na iva aham puttam icchāmi na dhanam na raṭṭham
translated: Na puttamicchāmi means I do not desire a son as the fruit of this eye-giving. Nor do I desire wealth or a kingdom.

translated: Apica means moreover. Sataṃ dhammo carito purāṇo means this ancient way, this ancient path, is practised by the good, by the wise, by the omniscient Bodhisattas.

original: yadidaṃ pāramīpūraṇaṃ nāma. Na hi pāramiyo apūretvā bodhipallaṅke sabbaññutaṃ pāpuṇituṃ

analyzed: samatthaḥ nāma atthi ahañca pāramiyaḥ pūretvā buddhaḥ bhavitu kāmaḥ iccā iva dāne ramate
translated: And I, desiring to become a Buddha by fulfilling the pāramīs, say: Icceva dāne ramate mano mamā.

original: mano mamāti iminā kāraṇena mama mano dāneyeva niratoti vadati.
analyzed: manaḥ mama ati iminā kāraṇena mama manaḥ vadati
translated: For this reason, my mind delights in giving.

original: Sammāsambuddhopi dhammasenāpatisāriputtattherassa cariyāpiṭakaṃ desento “mayhaṃ dvīhi cakkhūhipi sabbaññutaññāṇameva piyatara”nti dīpetuṃ āha –
analyzed: sammāsambuddhaḥ api dhammasenāpati sāriputta therassa cariyāpiṭakam desentaḥ mayham dvīhi cakkhūhi pi sabbaññuta ññāṇam eva piyataram ti dīpetum āha
translated: The Fully Enlightened One, too, when he was teaching the Cariyāpiṭaka to the Elder Sāriputta, the General of the Dhamma, said:

analyzed: sabbaññutam piyam mayham tasmā cakkhum a dāsahanti
translated: I prize omniscience, and so I gave my eyes.”

translated: The meaning is: “Good Jīvaka, you are my friend and companion, and you are well trained in the art of medicine.

analyzed: sādhu me vacanam karohi mama jigīsataḥ upadhārentassa olokentassa iva tālamiñjam viya

analyzed: me akkhīni uddharitvā imassa yācakassa hatthesu ṭhapehi iti  atha nam sīvikaḥ āha cakkhudānam nāma bhāriyam upadhārehi deva ati sīvika upadhāritam
translated: and take out my eyes and place them in the hands of this beggar.”

analyzed: mayā tvam mā papañcam karohi mā mayā saddhim bahum kathehi iti saḥ cintesi ayuttam  mādisassa su sikkhitassa vejjassa raññaḥ akkhīsu satthapātananti saḥ nānā bhesajjāni  ghaṃsitvā bhesajja cuṇṇena nīluppalam paribhāvetvā dakkhiṇa kkhim upasiṅghāpesi akkhi  parivatti dukkha vedanā uppajji sat lakkhehi mahā rāja paṭipāka tika karaṇam mayham  bhāroti alañhi tāta mā papañcam kari iti saḥ paribhāvetvā puna upasiṅghāpesi akkhi
translated: Then Sīvi said, “The gift of eyes is a heavy one, Your Majesty. Consider it well.” “I have considered it well, Sīvi. Don’t make me say it again. Don’t make me say it again.”

analyzed: akkhikūpataḥ mucci balavatarā vedanā udapādi sallakkhehi mahā rāja sakkomaham paṭipākatikam

I’m able to do the operation.”

analyzed: akkhi osadha balena paribbhamitvā akkhi kūpataḥ nikkhamitvā nhāru suttakena olambamānam

original: aṭṭhāsi. Sallakkhehi narinda, puna pākatikakaraṇaṃ mayhaṃ balanti. Mā papañcaṃ karīti.🔽Adhimattā vedanā udapādi, lohitaṃ pagghari, nivatthasāṭakā lohitena temiṃsu. Orodhā
analyzed: aṭṭhāsi narinda puna pākatika karaṇam mayham mā papañcam kari iti  adhimattā vedanā udapādi lohitam pagghari nivattha sāṭakā lohitena temiṃsu orodhā
translated: Look, O king, and see if my eye is as it was before. Do not make a fuss.”

translated: The king bore the pain and said, “Dear sir, do not make a fuss.” The physician said, “Very well, your majesty,” and with his left hand he held the eye🔽and with his right hand he took up a knife, cut the optic nerve, and taking out the eye,

analyzed: mahāsattassa hatthe ṭhapesi saḥ vāma kkhinā dakkhiṇa kkhim oloketvā vedanam adhivāsetvā
translated: placed it in the hand of the Great Being. The Great Being looked at the right eye with his left eye, bore the pain,🔽and said to the physician, “Dear sir, do not make a fuss.”

original: “ehi brāhmaṇā”ti brāhmaṇaṃ pakkositvā “mama ito akkhito sataguṇena sahassaguṇena
analyzed: ehi brāhmaṇa ati brāhmaṇam pakkositvā mama itas sataguṇena sahassaguṇena
translated: “Come, Brahman,” said he, summoning the Brahman, “a hundred times, a thousand times, a hundred thousand times,

analyzed: sata sahassa guṇena piyataram tassa me idam paccayaḥ hotu uti

original: vatvā brāhmaṇassa akkhiṃ adāsi. So taṃ ukkhipitvā attano akkhimhi ṭhapesi. Taṃ tassānubhāvena

translated: the Teacher pronounced the following Stanza,

analyzed: sa cakkhu brāhmaṇaḥ āsi andhaḥ rājā upāvisi iti  raññaḥ na cirassa iva akkhīni ruhiṃsu ruhamānāni ca āvāṭa bhāvam appatvā kambala geṇḍukena

analyzed: viya uggatena maṃsa piṇḍena pūretvā citta kamma rūpassa viya akkhīni ahesum vedanā  atha mahāsatto katipāham pāsāde vasitvā kim andhassa rajjena
translated: Soon after, the king’s eyes began to swell, and as they swelled, they did not form cavities, but were filled with lumps of flesh that rose up like pieces of wool, and his eyes became like artificial eyes. The pain

original: pakkosāpetvā tesaṃ tamatthaṃ ārocetvā “eko mukhadhovanādidāyako kappiyakārakova mayhaṃ🔽santike bhavissati, sarīrakiccaṭṭhānesupi me rajjukaṃ bandhathā”ti vatvā sārathiṃ

They made a litter of gold,

analyzed: nisinnaḥ attanaḥ dānam āvajjesi tasmin khaṇe sakkassa āsanam uṇham ahosi saḥ āvajjentaḥ

analyzed: varam varassu rājīsi yam kiñci manasi icchasi iti

translated: So make an act of truth’. After rousing the story he said

analyzed: etena saccavajjena dutiyam me upapajjatha ati  tattha yam manti yaḥ mam yācati saḥ iti saḥ cakkhu vikalaḥ brāhmaṇaḥ dehi me cakkhunti

analyzed: yācitum āgataḥ vanibbato ti yācantassa bhiyyas mama āvisi iti brāhmaṇassa cakkhūni da tvā  andhakālataḥ paṭṭhāya tasmin andhakāle tathārūpam vedanam a gaṇetvā aho su dinnam me

translated: joy entered me more than ever, it entered my heart,

translated: then what I have said is true. By this truth may a second eye appear to me.”

translated: Immediately a second eye appeared. But these eyes of his were neither ordinary eyes nor

analyzed: dibbāni sakka brāhmaṇassa hi dinnam cakkhum puna pākatikam kātum na sakkā upahata vatthunaḥ  ca dibba cakkhu nāma na uppajjati tāni panassa sacca pāramitā anubhāvena sambhūtāni
translated: divine eyes. For when the eye of a man is given to Sakka, it cannot be made ordinary again,🔽and a divine eye does not arise in one whose physical basis is impaired. But these eyes of his were called

analyzed: cakkhūni iti vuttāni tesam uppatti sama kālam eva sakka anubhāvena sabbā rāja parisā sannipatitā ava

translated: “The stanzas spoken by Dhammapada

analyzed: tirokuṭṭam tiroselam samatiggayha pabbatam
translated: “Over walls and over ramparts, over hills and over mounds,

analyzed: tattha dhammena bhāsitā ati mahā rāja imāḥ te gāthāḥ dhammena sabhāvena iva bhāsitāḥ dibbāni iti  dibba anubhāva yuttāni paṭidissanti tirokuṭṭanti mahā rāja imāni te
