original: bhātu jīvitaṃ dento pañcannampi janānaṃ jīvitadāyakosī”ti vatvā gāthamāha –
analyzed: bhātu jīvitam dentaḥ vatvā gātham āha
translated: and if you kill such a righteous deer, you will be killing five persons, namely, his parents and his sister and myself. But if you give him his life, you will be giving life to five persons.” So saying, he recited the following Stanza,

original: “Te hi nūna marissanti, andhā apariṇāyakā;
analyzed: te hi nūna marissanti andhāḥ apariṇāyakā
translated: “They will surely die, the blind, without a guide;

original: Pañcannaṃ jīvitaṃ dehi, bhātaraṃ muñca luddakā”ti.
analyzed: pañca annam jīvitam dehi bhātaram muñca luddaka ati
translated: Give life to five, set free the king of deer.”

original: So tassa dhammakathaṃ sutvā pasannacitto “mā bhāyi sāmī”ti vatvā anantaraṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: saḥ tassa dhamma katham sutvā pasanna cittaḥ mā bhāyi sāmi iti vatvā anantaram gātham āha
translated: The king, hearing the Dhamma, was pleased, and said, “Do not fear, my good man.” And he added this verse:

original: “So vo ahaṃ pamokkhāmi, mātāpettibharaṃ migaṃ;
analyzed: saḥ vaḥ aham pamokkhāmi mātā petti bharam migam
translated: “I set you free, I set you free, O deer, who supportest mother and father.

original: Nandantu mātāpitaro, muttaṃ disvā mahāmiga”nti.
analyzed: nandantu mātā pitaraḥ muttam disvā
translated: Let mother and father rejoice, beholding their son set free.”

original: Tattha voti nipātamattaṃ. Muttanti bandhanā muttaṃ passitvā.
analyzed: tattha vā ti nipāta mattam muttan ti bandhanā muttam passitvā
translated: Here the word “vo” is merely a particle. “Set you free” means “beholding you set free from your bonds.”

original: Evañca pana vatvā cintesi “raññā dinnayaso mayhaṃ kiṃ karissati, sacāhaṃ imaṃ migarājānaṃ
analyzed: evam ca pana vatvā cintesi raññā dinna yasaḥ mayham kim karissati sacā aham imam miga rājānam
translated: And having said this, he thought, “What will the glory gained by me through the king profit me? If I slay this king of deer,

original: vadhissāmi, ayaṃ vā me pathavī bhijjitvā vivaraṃ dassati, asani vā me matthake patissati,
analyzed: vadhissāmi ayam vā me pathavī bhijjitvā vivaram dassati asani vā me matthake patissati
translated: either the earth will cleave asunder and show me its infernal regions, or a thunderbolt will fall upon my head.

original: vissajjessāmi na”nti. So mahāsattaṃ upasaṅkamitvā yaṭṭhiṃ pātetvā cammayottaṃ chinditvā🔽migarājānaṃ āliṅgitvā udakapariyante nipajjāpetvā muducittena saṇikaṃ pāsā mocetvā
analyzed: vissajjessāmi nanti saḥ mahāsattam upasaṅkamitvā yaṭṭhim pātetvā camma yottam chinditvā  miga rājānam āliṅgitvā udaka pariyante nipajjāpetvā mudu cittena saṇikam pāsā mocetvā
translated: I will set him free.” So he approached the Great Being, threw down his staff, cut the thongs of his leathern bag,🔽embraced the king of deer, and laid him down on the bank of the stream. With a gentle heart he slowly untied the noose,

original: nhārūhi nhāruṃ, maṃsena maṃsaṃ, cammena cammaṃ samodhānetvā udakena lohitaṃ dhovitvā
analyzed: nhārūhi nhārum maṃsena maṃsam cammena cammam samodhānetvā udakena lohitam dhovitvā
translated: and with sinew for sinew, with flesh for flesh, with hide for hide, he bound him up again. Then he washed the blood from his body with water,🔽and

original: mettacittena punappunaṃ parimajji. Tassa mettānubhāveneva mahāsattassa pāramitānubhāvena
analyzed: metta cittena punappunam parimajji tassa metta anubhāvena iva mahāsattassa pāramitā anubhāvena
translated: and anointed him again and again with a mind full of love. By the power of his love and by the power of the Great Being’s perfections,

original: ca sabbāni nhārumaṃsacammāni sandhīyiṃsu, pādo sañchannachavi sañchannalomo ahosi,
analyzed: ca sabbāni nhāru maṃsa cammāni sandhīyiṃsu pādo sañchanna chavi sañchanna lomaḥ ahosi
translated: all the flesh, sinews, and skin healed up, and the foot became covered with skin and hair as before.

original: asukaṭṭhāne baddho ahosītipi na paññāyi. Mahāsatto sukhappatto hutvā aṭṭhāsi. Taṃ
analyzed: asuka ṭṭhāne baddhaḥ ahosi iti pi na paññāyi mahāsatto sukha ppatto hutvā aṭṭhāsi taṃ
translated: There was not even a mark to show where it had been cut. The Great Being, now happy, stood up.

original: disvā cittamigo somanassajāto luddassa anumodanaṃ karonto gāthamāha –
analyzed: disvā cittamigaḥ somanassa jātaḥ luddassa anumodanam karontaḥ gātham āha
translated: Seeing this, the monkey-king, filled with joy, spoke this verse in praise of the hunter:

original: “Evaṃ luddaka nandassu, saha sabbehi ñātibhi;
analyzed: evam luddaka nandassu saha sabbehi ñātibhi
translated: “Rejoice, O hunter, with all your kinsmen!

original: Yathāhamajja nandāmi, muttaṃ disvā mahāmiga”nti.
analyzed: yathā aham ajja nandāmi muttam disvā
translated: As I rejoice today, seeing the great beast set free.”

original: Atha mahāsatto “kiṃ nu kho esa luddo maṃ gaṇhanto attano kāmena gaṇhi, udāhu aññassa🔽āṇattiyā”ti cintetvā gahitakāraṇaṃ pucchi. Luddaputto āha – “sāmi, na mayhaṃ tumhehi
analyzed: atha mahāsatto kim nu kho esa luddaḥ mam gaṇhantaḥ attanaḥ kāmena gaṇhi udāhu aññassa  āṇattiyā iti cintetvā gahita kāraṇam pucchi ludda puttaḥ āha sāmi na mayham tumhehi
translated: Then the Great Being thought: “Why did this hunter take me? Was it out of his own will, or by the command of another?”

original: kammaṃ atthi, rañño pana aggamahesī khemā nāma tumhākaṃ dhammakathaṃ sotukāmā, tadatthāya
analyzed: kammam atthi raññaḥ pana agga mahesī khemā nāma tumhākam dhamma katham sotu kāmā tad atthāya
translated: And he asked the reason for his capture. The hunter’s son replied: “Sir, I have no business with you. But the king’s chief queen, Khema by name, is desirous of hearing your preaching of the Law. For that purpose

original: rañño āṇattiyā tvaṃ mayā gahito”ti. Samma, evaṃ sante maṃ vissajjento atidukkaraṃ🔽karosi, ehi maṃ netvā rañño dassehi, deviyā dhammaṃ kathessāmīti. Sāmi, rājāno nāma
analyzed: raññaḥ āṇattiyā tvam mayā gahitaḥ iti samma evam sante mama vissajjentaḥ ati dukkaram  karosi ehi mama netvā raññaḥ dassehi deviyā dhammam kathessāmi iti sāmi rājānaḥ nāma
translated: “I was seized by you at the King’s command.” “Well, then, in letting me go you are doing what is very difficult. Come, take me and show me to the King, and I will teach the Queen the Dhamma.” “My lord, kings are hard to serve.

original: kakkhaḷā, ko jānāti, kiṃ bhavissati, mayhaṃ raññā dinnayasena kammaṃ natthi, gaccha🔽tvaṃ yathāsukhanti. Puna mahāsatto “iminā maṃ vissajjentena atidukkaraṃ kataṃ, yasapaṭilābhassa
analyzed: kakkhaḷā kaḥ jānāti kim bhavissati mayham raññā dinna yasena kammam natthi gaccha  tvam yathāsukham ti puna mahāsatto iminā mama vissajjentena ati dukkaram katam yasa paṭilābhassa
translated: “I was taken by the king’s command.” “If it is so, then you do me a great favour by letting me go. Come, take me to the king, and I will preach the Law to the queen.” “My lord, kings are cruel; who knows what will happen? I have nothing to do with the king’s gift to you. Go,🔽and be happy.” Then the Great Being thought, “By letting me go he has done me a great service. I will do him a service in return,

original: upāyamassa karissāmī”ti cintetvā “samma, piṭṭhiṃ tāva me hatthena parimajjā”ti āha.
analyzed: upāyam assa karissāmi iti cintetvā samma piṭṭhim tāva me hatthena parimajja ati āha
translated: so that he may obtain fame.” And he said, “My friend, rub my back with your hand.”

original: “So parimajji, hattho suvaṇṇavaṇṇehi lomehi pūri”. “Sāmi, imehi lomehi kiṃ kāromī”ti.🔽“Samma, imāni haritvā rañño ca deviyā ca dassetvā ‘imāni tassa suvaṇṇavaṇṇamigassa
analyzed: saḥ parimajji hatthaḥ suvaṇṇa vaṇṇehi lomehi pūri sāmi imehi lomehi kim kāromi iti  samme imāni haritvā raññaḥ ca deviyā ca dassetvā imāni tassa suvaṇṇa vaṇṇa migassa
translated: He did so, and his hand was filled with golden-coloured hair. “My lord, what am I to do with this hair?”

original: lomānī’ti vatvā mama ṭhāne ṭhatvā imāhi gāthāhi deviyā dhammaṃ desehi, taṃ sutvāyeva
analyzed: lomāni iti vatvā mama ṭhāne ṭhatvā imāhi gāthāhi deviyā dhammam desehi tam sutvāya iva
translated: “My friend, take it and show it to the king and the queen, saying, ‘This is the hair of the golden-hued deer.’ Then stand in my place and preach the Law to the queen with these verses. As soon as she hears them,🔽she will conceive a desire for you.

original: cassā dohaḷo paṭippassambhissatī”ti. “Dhammaṃ cara mahārājā”ti dasa dhammacariyagāthā
analyzed: dhammam cara mahā rāja ati dasa dhamma cariya gāthā
translated: and his fever will be allayed.” “Act righteously, great king!” and had him learn the ten verses on righteous conduct.

original: uggaṇhāpetvā pañca sīlāni datvā appamādena ovaditvā uyyojesi. Luddaputto mahāsattaṃ
analyzed: uggaṇhāpetvā pañca sīlāni da tvā appamādena ovaditvā uyyojesi ludda puttaḥ mahāsattam
translated: He gave him the five precepts, exhorted him to heedfulness, and sent him away. The son of the hunter placed the Great Being in the position of teacher,

original: ācariyaṭṭhāne ṭhapetvā tikkhattuṃ padakkhiṇaṃ katvā catūsu ṭhānesu vanditvā lomāni
analyzed: ācariya ṭṭhāne ṭhapetvā tikkhattum padakkhiṇam katvā catūsu ṭhānesu vanditvā lomāni
translated: circumambulated him three times, bowed to him in the four places, took his hair

original: paduminipattena gahetvā pakkāmi. Tepi tayo janā thokaṃ anugantvā mukhena gocarañca
analyzed: padumini pattena gahetvā te api tayaḥ janāḥ thokam anugantvā mukhena gocaram ca
translated: in the hollow of his hand, and departed. The three people followed him a short distance, took food and water in their mouths,

original: pānīyañca gahetvā mātāpitūnaṃ santikaṃ gamiṃsu. Mātāpitaro “tāta rohaṇa, tvaṃ kira
analyzed: pānīyam ca mātā pitūnam santikam gamiṃsu mātā pitarā tāta rohaṇa tvam kira
translated: and went to their parents. The parents asked, “Dear Rohaṇa, it is said that

original: pāse baddho kathaṃ muttosī”ti pucchantā gāthamāhaṃsu –
analyzed: pāse baddhaḥ katham muttaḥ asi iti pucchantā gātham āhaṃsu
translated: you were caught in a snare. How did you escape?” and spoke this verse:

original: “Kathaṃ tvaṃ pamokkho āsi, upanītasmi jīvite;
analyzed: katham tvam pamokkhaḥ āsi upanītasmi jīvite
translated: “How did you escape, when you were brought to death?

original: Kathaṃ putta amocesi, kūṭapāsamha luddako”ti.
analyzed: katham putta amocesi kūṭa pāsamha luddakaḥ ti
translated: How did you free your son, O hunter, from the noose?”

original: Tattha upanītasmīti tava jīvite maraṇasantikaṃ upanīte kathaṃ pamokkho āsi.
analyzed: tattha upanītasmi iti tava jīvite maraṇa santikam upanīte katham pamokkhaḥ āsi
translated: Here, “brought to death” means when you were brought to the brink of death.

original: Taṃ sutvā bodhisatto tisso gāthā abhāsi –
analyzed: tam sutvā bodhisatto tissaḥ gāthāḥ abhāsi
translated: Having heard that, the Bodhisatta spoke three verses:

original: “Bhaṇaṃ kaṇṇasukhaṃ vācaṃ, hadayaṅgaṃ hadayassitaṃ;
analyzed: kaṇṇa sukham vācam hadayaṅgam hadaya ssitam
translated: “I spoke words that were pleasant to the ear, that went to the heart and touched the heart.

original: Subhāsitāhi vācāhi, cittako maṃ amocayi.
analyzed: su bhāsitāhi vācāhi cittakaḥ mam amocayi
translated: By means of these well-spoken words, Cittaka set me free.

original: “Bhaṇaṃ kaṇṇasukhaṃ vācaṃ, hadayaṅgaṃ hadayassitaṃ;
analyzed: kaṇṇa sukham vācam hadayaṅgam hadaya ssitam
translated: “I spoke words that were pleasant to the ear, that went to the heart and touched the heart.

original: Subhāsitāhi vācāhi, sutanā maṃ amocayi.
analyzed: su bhāsitāhi vācāhi sutanā mama amocayi
translated: By means of these well-spoken words, Sutanā set me free.

original: “Sutvā kaṇṇasukhaṃ vācaṃ, hadayaṅgaṃ hadayassitaṃ;
analyzed: sutvā kaṇṇa sukham vācam hadayaṅgam hadayassitam
translated: “Having heard words that were pleasant to the ear, that went to the heart and touched the heart,

original: Subhāsitāni sutvāna, luddako maṃ amocayī”ti.
analyzed: su bhāsitāni sutvāna luddakaḥ mam amocayi iti
translated: having heard these well-spoken words, the hunter set me free.”

original: Tattha bhaṇanti bhaṇanto. Hadayaṅganti hadayaṅgamaṃ. Dutiyagāthāya bhaṇanti bhaṇamānā. Sutvāti so imesaṃ ubhinnaṃ vācaṃ sutvā.
analyzed: tattha bhaṇanti bhaṇantaḥ hadayaṅganti hadayaṅgamam dutiya gāthāya bhaṇanti bhaṇamānā sutvā iti saḥ imesam ubhinnam vācam sutvā
translated: Herein, he spoke means he spoke. That which goes to the heart means that which touches the heart. In the second stanza, they spoke means they spoke. Having heard means having heard the words of both of them.

original: Athassa mātāpitaro anumodantā āhaṃsu –
analyzed: athassa mātā pitaraḥ anumodantau āhaṃsu
translated: Then his parents, rejoicing, said:

original: “Evaṃ ānandito hotu, saha dārehi luddako;
analyzed: evam ānanditaḥ hotu saha dārehi luddakaḥ
translated: “Thus let the hunter rejoice together with his wife,

original: Yathā mayajja nandāma, disvā rohaṇamāgata”nti.
analyzed: yathā nandāma disvā
translated: as we rejoice today on seeing Rohaṇa come.”

original: Luddopi araññā nikkhamitvā rājakulaṃ gantvā rājānaṃ vanditvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhāsi. Taṃ disvā rājā gāthamāha –
analyzed: luddaḥ api araññā nikkhamitvā rājakulam gantvā rājānam vanditvā ekamantam aṭṭhāsi tam disvā rājā gātham āha
translated: The hunter too, having come out of the forest, went to the royal palace, saluted the king, and stood at one side. Seeing him, the king spoke this verse:

original: “Nanu tvaṃ avaca ludda, ‘migacammāni āhariṃ’;
analyzed: nanu tvam avaca ludda miga cammāni āharim
translated: “Did you not say, ‘hunter,’ ‘I will bring deer skins’?

original: Atha kena nu vaṇṇena, migacammāni nāharī”ti.
analyzed: atha kena nu vaṇṇena miga cammāni na āhari iti
translated: “But why is it that you have brought neither deer nor hide?”

original: Tattha migacammānīti migaṃ vā cammaṃ vā. Āharinti āharissāmi. Idaṃ vuttaṃ hoti –
analyzed: tattha miga cammāni iti migam vā cammam vā āharinti āharissāmi idam vuttam hoti
translated: Herein, deer or hide means either a deer or a hide. I will bring means I will bring. What is meant is this:

original: ambho ludda, nanu tvaṃ evaṃ avaca “migaṃ ānetuṃ asakkonto cammaṃ āharissāmi, taṃ
analyzed: ambho ludda nanu tvam evam avaca migam ānetum a sakkontaḥ cammam āharissāmi taṃ
translated: “Good hunter, did you not say ‘If I cannot bring a deer, I will bring a hide;

original: asakkonto lomānī”ti, so tvaṃ kena kāraṇena neva migaṃ, na migacammaṃ āharīti?
analyzed: a sakkontaḥ lomāni iti saḥ tvam kena kāraṇena na iva migam na miga cammam āhari iti
translated: if I cannot do that, I will bring some hair’? Why is it that you have brought neither a deer nor a hide?”

original: Taṃ sutvā luddo gāthamāha –
analyzed: tam sutvā luddaḥ gātham āha
translated: On hearing this, the hunter spoke this verse:

original: “Āgamā ceva hatthatthaṃ, kūṭapāsañca so migo;
analyzed: āgamā ca iva hatthattham kūṭapāsam ca saḥ migaḥ
translated: “He came within reach of my hand, And the deer caught the noose;

original: Abajjhi taṃ migarājaṃ, tañca muttā upāsare.
analyzed: abajjhi tam miga rājam tam ca muttāḥ upāsare
translated: He broke the noose, the king of deer, And the released ones worship him.

original: “Tassa me ahu saṃvego, abbhuto lomahaṃsano;
analyzed: tassa me ahu saṃvegaḥ abbhutaḥ loma haṃsano
translated: “I was overcome with wonder, With a thrill running through my body;

original: Imañcāhaṃ migaṃ haññe, ajja hissāmi jīvita”nti.
analyzed: iman ca aham migam haññe ajja hissāmi jīvitanti
translated: I will kill this deer, Today I will give up my life.”

original: Tattha āgamāti mahārāja, so migo mama hatthatthaṃ hatthapāsañceva mayā oḍḍitaṃ kūṭapāsañca🔽āgato, tasmiñca kūṭapāse abajjhi. Tañca muttā upāsareti tañca baddhaṃ apare muttā
analyzed: tattha āgama ati mahā rāja saḥ migaḥ mama hatthattham hattha pāsam ca iva mayā oḍḍitam kūṭa pāsam ca 🔽āgataḥ tasmin ca kūṭa pāse abajjhi tat ca muttā tat ca baddham apare muttā
translated: Herein, he came within reach of my hand means, great king, that deer came within reach of my hand and within reach of the noose that I had stretched out.🔽And the deer caught the noose means he caught that noose that I had stretched out. He broke the noose, the king of deer means he broke that noose. And the released ones worship him means the other released deer worship him.

original: abaddhāva dve migā assāsentā taṃ nissāya aṭṭhaṃsu. Abbhutoti pubbe abhūtapubbo. Imañcāhanti
analyzed: a baddhā ava dve migā assāsentā tam nissāya aṭṭhaṃsu abbhuta uti pubbe abhūta pubbaḥ imañca ahanti
translated: Two deer, unfettered, came and stood there, trusting him. “Wonderful” means “never before seen.” “And this” means

original: atha me saṃviggassa etadahosi “sace ahaṃ imaṃ migaṃ hanissāmi, ajjeva imasmiṃyeva🔽ṭhāne jīvitaṃ jahissāmī”ti.
analyzed: atha me saṃviggassa etat ahosi sace aham imam migam hanissāmi ajjā iva imasmin yā iva  ṭhāne jīvitam jahissāmi iti
translated: “Then, being stirred, I thought: ‘If I were to kill this deer, I would die right here today.”

original: Taṃ sutvā rājā āha –
analyzed: tam sutvā rājā āha
translated: Hearing this, the king said:

original: “Kīdisā te migā ludda, kīdisā dhammikā migā;
analyzed: kīdisā te migāḥ ludda kīdisā dhammikāḥ migā
translated: “What are deer like, hunter? What are righteous deer like?

original: Kathaṃvaṇṇā kathaṃsīlā, bāḷhaṃ kho ne pasaṃsasī”ti.
analyzed: kathaṃvaṇṇā kathaṃsīlā bāḷham khalu ne pasaṃsasi iti
translated: What are they like in color and character? You praise them so highly.”

original: Idaṃ so rājā vimhayavasena punappunaṃ pucchati. Taṃ sutvā luddo gāthamāha –
analyzed: idam saḥ rājā vimhaya vasena punappunam pucchati tam sutvā luddaḥ gātham āha
translated: This is the king asking again and again out of wonder. Hearing this, the hunter spoke this verse:

original: “Odātasiṅgā sucivālā, jātarūpatacūpamā;
analyzed: odāta siṅgā su civālā jātarūpa tacūpamā
translated: “Their antlers are white, their coats are pure, they are like gold leaf;

original: Pādā lohitakā tesaṃ, añjitakkhā manoramā”ti.🔽Tattha odātasiṅgāti rajatadāmasadisasiṅgā. Sucivālāti cāmarivālasadisena sucinā vālena
analyzed: pādā lohitakā tesam añjitakkhāḥ manoramā ati  tattha odāta siṅgā ati rajata dāma sadisa siṅgā suci vālā ati cāmari vāla sadisena sucinā vālena
translated: Their feet are red, their eyes are dark, they are delightful.”🔽Here, “white antlers” means antlers like a silver garland. “Pure coat” means having a pure coat like a yak’s tail.

original: samannāgatā. Lohitakāti rattanakhā pavāḷasadisā. Pādāti khurapariyantā. Añjitakkhāti
analyzed: samannāgatā lohitakā ati ratta nakhā pavāḷa sadisā pādāti khura pariyantā añjitakkhā ati
translated: “Red feet” means red hooves like coral. “Dark eyes” means

original: añjitehi viya visuddhapañcapasādehi akkhīhi samannāgatā.
analyzed: añjitehi viya visuddha pañca pasādehi akkhīhi samannāgatā
translated: and with eyes as pure as the five-coloured lotus.

original: Iti so kathentova mahāsattassa suvaṇṇavaṇṇāni lomāni rañño hatthe ṭhapetvā tesaṃ migānaṃ sarīravaṇṇaṃ pakāsento gāthamāha –
analyzed: iti saḥ kathentaḥ iva mahāsattassa suvaṇṇa vaṇṇāni lomāni rañño hatthe ṭhapetvā tesam migānam sarīra vaṇṇam pakāsentaḥ gātham āha
translated: As he spoke thus, he placed the golden-coloured hairs of the Great Being in the king’s hand, and in order to show the colour of the bodies of those deer, he spoke the stanza:

original: “Edisā te migā deva, edisā dhammikā migā;
analyzed: edisā te migāḥ deva edisā dhammikāḥ migāḥ
translated: “Such are your deer, O King, such are your righteous deer;

original: Mātāpettibharā deva, na te so abhihāritu”nti.
analyzed: mātāpetti bharāḥ deva na te saḥ
translated: They support their parents, O King, he is not worthy to be taken by you.”

original: Tattha mātāpettibharāti jiṇṇe andhe mātāpitaro posenti, etādisā nesaṃ dhammikatā.
analyzed: tattha jiṇṇe andhe mātā pitaro posenti etādisā na esam dhammika tā
translated: Herein, they support their parents means they support their aged and blind parents, such is their righteousness.

original: Na te so abhihāritunti so migarājā na sakkā kenaci tava paṇṇākāratthāya abhiharitunti
analyzed: na te saḥ abhihāritunti saḥ miga rājā na sakkā kenacid tava paṇṇākāra atthāya abhiharitunti
translated: He is not worthy to be taken by you means that king of deer is not worthy to be taken by anyone for the sake of your leaf-hut.

original: attho. “Abhihārayi”ntipi pāṭho, so ahaṃ taṃ te paṇṇākāratthāya nābhihārayiṃ na āharinti attho.
analyzed: so aham tam te paṇṇa ākāra atthāya na abhihārayim na āharinti
translated: The meaning is this. “Abhihārayi” is also a reading, the meaning of which is this: I did not take him for the sake of your leaf-hut, I did not bring him.

original: Iti so mahāsattassa ca cittamigassa ca sutanāya migapotikāya ca guṇaṃ kathetvā “mahārāja,
analyzed: iti saḥ mahāsattassa ca cittamigassa ca sutanāya miga potikāya ca guṇam kathetvā mahā rāja
translated: Thus, having told the virtues of the Great Being and of the doe Cittā and of the young fawn Sutanā, he said: “Great King,

original: ahaṃ tena migaraññā ‘attano lomāni dassetvā mama ṭhāne ṭhatvā dasahi rājadhammacariyagāthāhi
analyzed: aham tena miga raññā attanaḥ lomāni dassetvā mama ṭhāne ṭhatvā dasahi rāja dhamma cariya gāthāhi
translated: I was instructed by that king of deer, who said, ‘Show me your hair, and then stand in my place and preach the Dhamma to the queen with the ten royal virtues.’

original: deviyā dhammaṃ katheyyāsī’ti uggaṇhāpito āṇatto”ti āha. Taṃ sutvā rājā naṃ nhāpetvā
analyzed: deviyā dhammam katheyyāsi iti uggaṇhāpitaḥ āṇattaḥ iti āha tam sutvā rājā nam nhāpetvā

original: ahatavatthāni nivāsetvā sattaratanakhacite pallaṅke nisīdāpetvā sayaṃ deviyā saddhiṃ
analyzed: ahata vatthāni nivāsetvā satta ratana khacite pallaṅke nisīdāpetvā sayam deviyā saddhim
translated: dressed in new clothes, and seated on a couch decorated with the seven precious gems. Then he and the queen

original: nīcāsane ekamantaṃ nisīditvā taṃ añjaliṃ paggayha yācati. So dhammaṃ desento āha –
analyzed: nīca āsane ekamantam nisīditvā tam añjalim paggayha yācati saḥ dhammam desentaḥ āha
translated: sat down on a low seat beside the deer and implored it to preach the Dhamma. The deer preached the Dhamma as follows:

original: “Dhammaṃ cara mahārāja, mātāpitūsu khattiya;

translated: “Practice the Dhamma, great king, toward your mother and father,

analyzed: idha dhammam caritvāna rāja saggam gamissasi
translated: and having practiced the Dhamma here, great king, you will go to heaven.

original: “Dhammaṃ cara mahārāja, puttadāresu khattiya;
analyzed: dhammam cara mahā rāja putta dāresu khattiya
translated: “Practice the Dhamma, great king, toward your children and wife,

translated: and having practiced the Dhamma here, great king, you will go to heaven.

analyzed: dhammam cara mahā rāja mittāmaccesu khattiya
translated: “Practice the Dhamma, great king, toward your friends and companions,

original: Idha dhammaṃ caritvāna, rāja saggaṃ gamissasi.
analyzed: idha dhammam caritvāna rāja saggam gamissasi
translated: and having practiced the Dhamma here, great king, you will go to heaven.

original: “Dhammaṃ cara mahārāja, vāhanesu balesu ca;
analyzed: dhammam cara mahā rāja vāhanesu balesu ca
translated: “Practice the Dhamma, great king, toward your vehicles and beasts of burden,

original: Idha dhammaṃ caritvāna, rāja saggaṃ gamissasi.
analyzed: idha dhammam caritvāna rāja saggam gamissasi
translated: Having practiced the Dhamma here, O King, you will go to heaven.

original: “Dhammaṃ cara mahārāja, gāmesu nigamesu ca;
analyzed: dhammam cara mahā rāja gāmesu nigamesu ca
translated: “Practice the Dhamma, great king, in the villages and towns;

original: Idha dhammaṃ caritvāna, rāja saggaṃ gamissasi.

translated: Having practiced the Dhamma here, O King, you will go to heaven.

analyzed: dhammam cara mahā rāja raṭṭhesu janapadesu ca

original: Idha dhammaṃ caritvāna, rāja saggaṃ gamissasi.
analyzed: idha dhammam caritvāna rāja saggam gamissasi
translated: Having practiced the Dhamma here, O King, you will go to heaven.

original: “Dhammaṃ cara mahārāja, samaṇabrāhmaṇesu ca;
analyzed: dhammam cara mahā rāja samaṇa brāhmaṇesu ca
translated: “Practice the Dhamma, great king, with ascetics and brahmins;

analyzed: idha dhammam caritvāna rāja saggam gamissasi
translated: Having practiced the Dhamma here, O King, you will go to heaven.

original: “Dhammaṃ cara mahārāja, migapakkhīsu khattiya;
analyzed: dhammam cara mahā rāja miga pakkhīsu khattiya
translated: “Practice the Dhamma, great king, with deer and birds, O Warrior;

original: Idha dhammaṃ caritvāna, rāja saggaṃ gamissasi.

analyzed: dhammam cara mahā rāja dhammaḥ ciṇṇaḥ sukha āvahaḥ
translated: “Practice the Dhamma, great king, for the Dhamma, when practiced, brings happiness;

analyzed: idha dhammam caritvāna rāja saggam gamissasi
translated: Having practiced the Dhamma here, O King, you will go to heaven.

analyzed: dhammam cara mahā rāja saindā devā sa brahmakā
translated: “Practice the Dhamma, great king, with the devas headed by Saindā and Brahmā;

analyzed: su ciṇṇena divam pattā mā dhammam rāja pāmadaḥ ti
translated: Having well practiced it, they have attained heaven. Do not be heedless of the Dhamma, O King.”

original: Iti nesādaputto mahāsattena desitaniyāmena ākāsagaṅgaṃ otārento viya buddhalīlāya
analyzed: iti nesāda puttaḥ mahāsattena desita niyāmena ākāsagaṅgam otārentaḥ viya buddha līlāya
translated: Thus the son of the Nāga, as if pouring down the celestial Ganges in accordance with the method taught by the Great Being,

original: dhammaṃ desesi. Mahājano sādhukārasahassāni pavattesi. Dhammakathaṃ sutvāyeva deviyā
analyzed: dhammam desesi mahā janaḥ sādhukāra sahassāni pavattesi dhamma katham sutvāya iva deviyā
translated: and he preached the Dhamma. The multitude gave a thousand shouts of “bravo!” and the queen’s

original: dohaḷo paṭippassambhi. Rājā tussitvā luddaputtaṃ mahantena yasena santappento tisso gāthā abhāsi –
analyzed: dohaḷaḥ paṭippassambhi rājā tussitvā ludda puttam mahantena yasena santappentaḥ tissaḥ gāthāḥ abhāsi
translated: pain was relieved as soon as she had heard the preaching of the Dhamma. The king was pleased, and in order to comfort the hunter’s son he spoke three stanzas:

original: “Dammi nikkhasataṃ ludda, thūlañca maṇikuṇḍalaṃ;
analyzed: dammi nikkhasatam ludda thūlam ca maṇi kuṇḍalam
translated: “I give you a hundred coins, hunter, and a heavy gem-studded earring,

original: Catussadañca pallaṅkaṃ, umāpupphasarinnibhaṃ.

translated: and a couch with four legs, like a flower of the umā plant.

original: “Dve ca sādisiyo bhariyā, usabhañca gavaṃ sataṃ;
analyzed: dve ca bhariyāḥ usabham ca gavam satam
translated: “And two wives to match you, and a bull and a hundred cows;

original: Dhammena rajjaṃ kāressaṃ, bahukāro mesi luddaka.
analyzed: dhammena rajjam kāressam bahu kāraḥ mā asi luddaka
translated: I will rule righteously, you have been very helpful, hunter.

original: “Kasivāṇijjā iṇadānaṃ, ucchācariyā ca luddaka;
analyzed: kasi vāṇijjāḥ iṇa dānam ucchā cariyā ca
translated: “Agriculture, trade, lending money, and service, hunter,

original: Etena dāraṃ posehi, mā pāpaṃ akarī punā”ti.🔽Tattha thūlanti mahagghaṃ maṇikuṇḍalapasādhanañca te dammi. Catussadanti caturussadaṃ,
analyzed: etena dāram posehi mā pāpam a karī punāti  tattha mahaggham maṇi kuṇḍala pasādhanam ca te dammi catussadam ti
translated: by these means support your wife, and do not sin again.”🔽Herein, heavy means valuable. Gem-studded earring and adornment means I give you a valuable gem-studded earring and adornment. With four legs means with four legs and four corners.

original: catuussīsakanti attho. Umāpupphasarinnibhanti nīlapaccattharaṇattā umāpupphasadisāya
analyzed: catu ussīsakanti atthaḥ umā puppha sarit nibhanti nīla paccattharaṇa ttā umā puppha sadisāya
translated: Like a flower of the umā plant means like a blue bedspread.

original: nibhāya obhāsena samannāgataṃ, kāḷavaṇṇadārusāramayaṃ vā. Sādisiyoti aññamaññaṃ rūpena🔽ca bhogena ca sadisā. Usabhañca gavaṃ satanti usabhaṃ jeṭṭhakaṃ katvā gavaṃ satañca🔽te dammi. Kāressanti dasa rājadhamme akopento dhammeneva rajjaṃ kāressāmi. Bahukāro
analyzed: nibhāya obhāsena samannāgatam kāḷavaṇṇa dāru sāra mayam vā aññam aññam rūpena  ca bhogena ca sadisāḥ usabham ca gavam satanti usabham jeṭṭhakam katvā gavam satam ca  te dammi kāressanti dasa rājadhamme a kopentaḥ dhammena iva rajjam kāressāmi bahu kāro
translated: and is endowed with a lustre that shines forth, like a piece of heartwood of the acacia tree. Like to like: similar to each other in form and in wealth. And a bull and a hundred oxen: making the bull the chief, I give you a hundred oxen. Will rule: not transgressing the ten royal duties, I will rule righteously.

original: mesīti suvaṇṇavaṇṇassa migarañño ṭhāne ṭhatvā dhammassa desitattā tvaṃ mama bahupakāro,🔽migarājena vuttaniyāmeneva te ahaṃ pañcasu sīlesu patiṭṭhāpito. Kasivāṇijjāti samma
analyzed: mesi iti suvaṇṇa vaṇṇassa miga rañño ṭhāne ṭhatvā dhammassa desita ttā tvam mama bahu pakāraḥ  miga rājena vutta niyāmena iva te aham pañcasu sīlesu patiṭṭhāpito kasi vāṇijjāti samma
translated: and is endowed with a beautiful lustre, like a piece of heartwood of black ebony. ‘Like me’ means similar to me in form and in wealth. ‘The bull and the herd of a hundred cows’ means having made the bull the chief, I give you the herd of a hundred cows. ‘Will rule’ means without transgressing the ten royal duties I will rule righteously. ‘You have been very helpful to me’ means because you have stood in the place of the golden-coloured king of deer and taught the Dhamma you have been very helpful to me,

original: luddaka, ahampi migarājānaṃ adisvā tassa vacanameva sutvā pañcasu sīlesu patiṭṭhito,
analyzed: luddaka aham pi miga rājānam a disvā tassa vacanam eva sutvā pañcasu sīlesu patiṭṭhitaḥ
translated: and just as the king of deer said, I have been established in the five precepts. ‘Agriculture, trade, and debt’ means, my dear hunter, I, not having seen the king of deer, having only heard his words, have been established in the five precepts,

original: tvampi ito paṭṭhāya sīlavā hohi, yāni tāni kasivāṇijjāni iṇadānaṃ uñchācariyāti ājīvamukhāni,
analyzed: tvam pi itas paṭṭhāya sīlavā hohi yāni tāni kasi vāṇijjāni iṇa dānam ājīva mukhāni
translated: and from now on you also should be virtuous, and those means of livelihood such as agriculture, trade, debt, and begging,

original: eteneva sammāājīvena tava puttadāraṃ posehi, mā puna pāpaṃ karīti.
analyzed: etena iva sammāājīvena tava putta dāram posehi mā puna pāpam kari iti
translated: by this right livelihood you should support your wife and children, and do not do evil again.’

original: So rañño kathaṃ sutvā “na me gharāvāsenattho, pabbajjaṃ me anujānātha devā”ti anujānāpetvā
analyzed: saḥ raññaḥ katham sutvā na me gharāvāsena atthaḥ pabbajjam me anujānātha deva ati anujānāpetvā
translated: When he heard the king’s words, he said, “I have no desire for the life of a householder. Grant me permission, your majesty, to retire from the world.”

original: raññā dinnadhanaṃ puttadārassa datvā himavantaṃ pavisitvā isipabbajjaṃ pabbajitvā
analyzed: raññā dinna dhanam putta dārassa da tvā himavantam pavisitvā isipabbajjam pabbajitvā
translated: He obtained the king’s permission, gave the wealth the king had given him to his son and wife, entered the Himalayas, retired from the world according to the custom of the Seer,

original: aṭṭha samāpattiyo nibbattetvā brahmalokaparāyaṇo ahosi. Rājāpi mahāsattassa ovāde
analyzed: aṭṭha samāpattiyaḥ nibbattetvā brahma loka parāyaṇaḥ ahosi rājā api mahāsattassa ovāde
translated: and attained the eight meditations. He passed into the World of Brahmā. The king, abiding in the admonition of the Great Being,

original: ṭhatvā saggapuraṃ pūresi, tassa ovādo vassasahassaṃ pavatti.
analyzed: ṭhatvā saggapuram pūresi tassa ovādaḥ vassa sahassam pavatti
translated: filled the city of the gods. His admonition continued for a thousand years.

original: Satthā imaṃ dhammadesanaṃ āharitvā “evaṃ bhikkhave pubbepi mamatthāya ānandena jīvitaṃ
analyzed: satthā imam dhamma desanam āharitvā evam bhikkhave pubbe pi ānandena jīvitam
translated: The Teacher, having related this Dhamma, said, “Thus, monks, in the past also Ānanda gave up his life for my sake.”

original: pariccattamevā”ti vatvā jātakaṃ samodhānesi – “tadā luddo channo ahosi, rājā sāriputto,
analyzed: pariccattam evā ti vatvā jātakam samodhānesi tadā luddaḥ channaḥ ahosi rājā sāriputto
translated: And when he had related the Jātaka, he identified the characters as follows: “At that time Channa was the hunter, Sāriputta was the king,

original: devī khemā bhikkhunī, mātāpitaro mahārājakulāni, sutanā uppalavaṇṇā, cittamigo ānando,
analyzed: devī khemā bhikkhunī mātā pitaraḥ mahā rāja kulāni sutanā uppalavaṇṇā cittamigaḥ ānandaḥ
translated: Khemā was the queen, the parents of the Great Being were the royal families, Uppalavaṇṇā was Sutanā, Ānanda was the jackal,

original: asīti migasahassāni sākiyagaṇo, rohaṇo migarājā pana ahameva ahosi”nti.
analyzed: asīti miga sahassāni sākiya gaṇaḥ rohaṇaḥ miga rājā pana aham eva
translated: the eighty-thousand deer were the Sākiyas, and I myself was the king of the deer, Rohaṇa.”

original: Rohaṇamigajātakavaṇṇanā pañcamā.
analyzed: rohaṇa miga jātaka vaṇṇanā pañcamā
translated: The Story of the Deer Rohaṇa.

original: [502] 6. Cūḷahaṃsajātakavaṇṇanā
translated: 6. The Story of the Little Goose.

original: Ete haṃsā pakkamantīti idaṃ satthā veḷuvane viharanto ānandatherassa jīvitapariccāgameva
analyzed: ete haṃsā pakkamanti iti idam satthā veḷuvane viharantaḥ ānanda therassa jīvita pariccāgam eva
translated: “These geese are flying away.” The Master told this story while dwelling at Veḷuvana, about the Elder Ānanda’s giving up his life.

original: ārabbha kathesi. Tadāpi hi dhammasabhāyaṃ therassa guṇakathaṃ kathentesu bhikkhūsu
analyzed: ārabbha kathesi tadā api hi dhammasabhāyam therassa guṇa katham kathentesu bhikkhūsu
translated: For at that time, as the monks were sitting in the Hall of Truth telling the praises of the Elder,

original: satthā āgantvā “kāya nuttha, bhikkhave, etarahi kathāya sannisinnā”ti pucchitvā “imāya
analyzed: satthā āgantvā kāya nuttha bhikkhave etarahi kathāya sannisinnā ati pucchitvā imāya
translated: the Master came and asked, “Monks, what is it that you are sitting here now talking about?” When they told him,

original: nāmā”ti vutte “na, bhikkhave, idāneva, pubbepi ānandena mamatthāya jīvitaṃ pariccattamevā”ti vatvā atītaṃ āhari.
analyzed: nāma ati vutte na bhikkhave idānā iva pubbe pi ānandena mama atthāya jīvitam pariccattam eva ati vatvā atītam āhari
translated: he said, “Monks, this is not the first time that Ānanda has given up his life for me; he did the same thing in a previous state of existence also.” So saying, he told a story of the past.

original: Atīte bārāṇasiyaṃ bahuputtako nāma rājā rajjaṃ kāresi. Khemā nāmassa aggamahesī ahosi.
analyzed: atīte bārāṇasiyam bahuputtakaḥ nāma rājā rajjam kāresi khemā nāmassa agga mahesī ahosi
translated: Once upon a time, when Brahmadatta was reigning in Benares, the Bodhisatta was reborn as a golden goose in the womb of the chief queen, Khemā by name.

original: Tadā mahāsatto suvaṇṇahaṃsayoniyaṃ nibbattitvā navutihaṃsasahassaparivuto cittakūṭe
analyzed: tadā mahāsattaḥ suvaṇṇa haṃsa yoniyam nibbattitvā navuti haṃsa sahassa parivutaḥ cittakūṭe
translated: The Bodhisatta, surrounded by ninety thousand geese, dwelt on Cittakuṭa.

original: vasi. Tadāpi devī vuttanayeneva supinaṃ disvā rañño suvaṇṇavaṇṇahaṃsassa dhammadesanāsavanadohaḷaṃ
analyzed: tadā api devī vutta nayena iva supinam disvā raññaḥ suvaṇṇa vaṇṇa haṃsassa dhamma desanā savana dohaḷam
translated: Then the queen, as in the story of the past, saw the dream, and told it to the king. The king, in order to hear the golden goose preach the Law,

original: ārocesi. Rājāpi amacce pucchitvā “suvaṇṇavaṇṇahaṃsā nāma cittakūṭapabbate vasantī”ti🔽ca sutvā khemaṃ nāma saraṃ kāretvā nānappakārāni nivāpadhaññāni ropāpetvā catūsu
analyzed: ārocesi rājā api amacce pucchitvā suvaṇṇa vaṇṇa haṃsāḥ nāma cittakūṭa pabbate vasanti iti  ca sutvā khemam nāma saram kāretvā nānappakārāni nivāpa dhaññāni ropāpetvā catūsu
translated: and told the king. The king asked his ministers, and hearing that “golden-hued geese” lived on Cittakuṭa mountain,🔽he had a lake called Khemā made, and had various kinds of grain and rice planted on the four sides of it,

original: kaṇṇesu devasikaṃ abhayaghosanaṃ ghosāpesi, ekañca luddaputtaṃ haṃsānaṃ gahaṇatthāya
analyzed: kaṇṇesu devasikam abhaya ghosanam ghosāpesi ekam ca ludda puttam haṃsānam gahaṇa tthāya
translated: and had a proclamation of safety made every day on the four sides of the lake. He also sent a hunter’s son to catch the geese.

original: payojesi. Tassa payojitākāro ca, tena tattha sakuṇānaṃ upaparikkhitabhāvo ca, suvaṇṇahaṃsānaṃ
analyzed: payojesi tassa payojita ākāro ca tena tattha sakuṇānam upaparikkhita bhāvo ca suvaṇṇa haṃsānam
translated: The way in which he was sent, and the way in which the birds were watched, and the way in which the golden geese came,

original: āgatakāle rañño ārocetvā pāsānaṃ oḍḍitaniyāmo ca, mahāsattassa pāse baddhaniyāmo🔽ca, sumukhassa haṃsasenāpatino tīsu haṃsaghaṭāsu taṃ adisvā nivattanañca sabbaṃ mahāhaṃsajātake
analyzed: āgata kāle raññaḥ ārocetvā pāsānam oḍḍita niyāmo ca mahāsattassa pāse baddha niyāmo  ca sumukhassa haṃsa senāpatino tīsu haṃsa ghaṭāsu tam a disvā nivattanam ca sabbam mahā haṃsa jātake
translated: and the way in which the king was informed, and the way in which the net was spread, and the way in which the Great Being was caught in the net,🔽and the way in which Sumukha, the general of the geese, returned after not seeing him in the three flocks of geese, all this will be related in the Mahāhamsa Jātaka.

original: āvi bhavissati. Idhāpi mahāsatto yaṭṭhipāse bajjhitvā pāsayaṭṭhiyaṃ olambantoyeva
analyzed: āvi bhavissati idha api mahāsattaḥ yaṭṭhi pāse bajjhitvā pāsa yaṭṭhiyam olambantaḥ yā iva
translated: Here the Great Being, caught in the net, hanging from the net-rope,

original: gīvaṃ pasāretvā haṃsānaṃ gatamaggaṃ olokento sumukhaṃ āgacchantaṃ disvā “āgatakāle
analyzed: gīvam pasāretvā haṃsānam gata maggam olokentaḥ su mukham āgacchantam disvā āgata kāle
translated: stretched out his neck and looked for the path taken by the geese. Seeing Sumukha coming, he said: “When he comes,

original: naṃ vīmaṃsissāmī”ti cintetvā tasmiṃ āgate tisso gāthā abhāsi –🔽“Ete haṃsā pakkamanti, vakkaṅgā bhayameritā;
analyzed: nam vīmaṃsissāmi iti cintetvā tasmin āgate tissaḥ gāthāḥ abhāsi  ete haṃsā pakkamanti vakkaṅgāḥ bhayam eritā
translated: “I will test him,” and when he came, he spoke three stanzas:🔽These geese are flying away,🔽With their green necks and golden hue,

original: Harittaca hemavaṇṇa, kāmaṃ sumukha pakkama.
analyzed: harittaca hema vaṇṇa kāmam su mukha pakkama
translated: O fair-faced one, fly away if you wish.🔽Abandoning me, a kinsman,

original: “Ohāya maṃ ñātigaṇā, ekaṃ pāsavasaṃ gataṃ;
analyzed: ohāya mam ñāti gaṇāḥ ekam pāsavasam gatam
translated: Gone to one place,

original: Anapekkhamānā gacchanti, kiṃ eko avahiyyasi.
analyzed: an apekkhamānāḥ gacchanti kim ekaḥ avahiyyasi
translated: They go without concern; why do you tarry alone?🔽Fly away, O best of fliers,

original: “Pateva patataṃ seṭṭha, natthi baddhe sahāyatā;
analyzed: pata iva patatam seṭṭha natthi baddhe sahāya tā
translated: There is no friendship with one bound;🔽Do not abandon me, O fearless one;

original: Mā anīghāya hāpesi, kāmaṃ sumukha pakkamā”ti.
analyzed: mā anīghāya hāpesi kāmam su mukha pakkamāti
translated: O fair-faced one, fly away if you wish.

original: Tattha bhayameritāti bhayeritā bhayatajjitā bhayacalitā. Harittaca hemavaṇṇāti dvīhipi
analyzed: tattha bhayameritā ati bhaya īritā bhaya tajjitā bhaya calitā hema vaṇṇā ati dvīhipi
translated: Herein, bhayameritā means frightened by fear, terrified by fear, shaken by fear. Harittaca hemavaṇṇā means with both

original: vacanehi tamevālapati. Kāmanti suvaṇṇattaca, suvaṇṇavaṇṇa, sundaramukha ekaṃsena🔽pakkamāhiyeva, kiṃ te idhāgamanenāti vadati. Ohāyāti maṃ jahitvā uppatitā. Anapekkhamānāti
analyzed: vacanehi tam eva ālapati sundara mukhaḥ ekaṃsena  kim te idha āgamanena ati vadati ohāya ati mama jahitvā uppatitā an apekkhamānā iti
translated: sayings he addresses him. Kāmaṃ means O golden-skinned one, O golden-hued one, O fair-faced one, fly away by all means,🔽what is the use of your coming here? He says. Ohāya means having left me, they have flown up. Anapekkhamānā means

original: te mama ñātakā mayi anapekkhāva gacchanti. Patevāti uppateva. Mā anīghāyāti ito gantvā
analyzed: te mama ñātakāḥ mayi an apekkhāva gacchanti pateva ati uppateva mā anīghāya ati itas gantvā
translated: my kinsmen go without concern for me. Pateva means fly up. Mā anīghāyāti means having gone from here

original: pattabbāya niddukkhabhāvāya vīriyaṃ mā hāpesi.
analyzed: pattabbāya niddukkha bhāvāya vīriyam mā hāpesi
translated: Do not relax your effort for the sake of the happiness that is to be attained by the removal of suffering.

original: Tato sumukho paṅkapiṭṭhe nisīditvā gāthamāha –
analyzed: tatas sumukhaḥ paṅka piṭṭhe nisīditvā gātham āha
translated: Then Sumukha sat down on the back of the elephant and spoke this verse:

original: “Nāhaṃ dukkhaparetoti, dhataraṭṭha tuvaṃ jahe;
analyzed: na aham dukkha paretaḥ iti dhataraṭṭha tuvam jahe
translated: “I am not abandoning you, O Dhataraṭṭha, because of the suffering;

original: Jīvitaṃ maraṇaṃ vā me, tayā saddhiṃ bhavissatī”ti.
analyzed: jīvitam maraṇam vā me tayā saddhim bhavissati iti
translated: My life or death will be with you.”

original: Tattha dukkhaparetoti mahārāja, “tvaṃ maraṇadukkhapareto”ti ettakeneva nāhaṃ taṃ jahāmi.
analyzed: tattha dukkha paretā iti mahā rāja tvam maraṇa dukkha paretā iti ettakena iva na aham tam jahāmi
translated: Herein, I am not abandoning you because of the suffering means, “Great king, I am not abandoning you merely because of the suffering of death.”

original: Evaṃ sumukhena sīhanāde kathite dhataraṭṭho gāthamāha –
analyzed: evam sumukhena sīha nāde kathite dhataraṭṭhaḥ gātham āha
translated: When Sumukha had thus roared the lion’s roar, Dhataraṭṭha spoke this verse:

original: “Etadariyassa kalyāṇaṃ, yaṃ tvaṃ sumukha bhāsasi;
analyzed: etat ariyassa kalyāṇam yam tvam su mukha bhāsasi
translated: “This is the noble one’s virtue, O Sumukha, that you speak thus;

original: Tañca vīmaṃsamānohaṃ, patatetaṃ avassaji”nti.🔽Tattha etadariyassāti yaṃ tvaṃ “nāhaṃ taṃ jahe”ti bhāsasi, etaṃ ācārasampannassa🔽ariyassa kalyāṇaṃ uttamavacanaṃ. Patatetanti ahañca na taṃ vissajjetukāmova evaṃ
analyzed: tat ca vīmaṃsamānā ūham patata itam  tattha etad ariyassa ati yam tvam na aham tam jaha iti bhāsasi etam ācāra sampannassa  ariyassa kalyāṇam uttama vacanam aham ca na tam evam
translated: But I was testing you, and so I let fall this thunderbolt.”🔽Herein, this is the noble one’s virtue means, “That you speak thus, ‘I am not abandoning you,’ is the supreme statement of virtue of a noble one endowed with good conduct.”

original: avacaṃ, atha kho taṃ vīmaṃsamāno “patatū”ti etaṃ vacanaṃ avassajiṃ, gacchāti taṃ avocanti attho.
analyzed: avacam atha kho tam vīmaṃsamānaḥ patatu uti etam vacanam avassajim gacchāti tam avocanti attho
translated: I let fall this thunderbolt means I said this not because I wanted to let you fall, but rather because I was testing you. I let fall this statement, “Let it fall,” I spoke thus, “Go,” is the meaning.

original: Evaṃ tesaṃ kathentānaññeva luddaputto daṇḍamādāya vegenāgato. Sumukho dhataraṭṭhaṃ
analyzed: evam tesam kathentānam aññā iva ludda puttaḥ daṇḍam ādāya vegena āgataḥ sumukhaḥ dhataraṭṭham
translated: While they were thus conversing, the hunter’s son came up with his stick. Sumukha comforted Dhataraṭṭha,

original: assāsetvā tassābhimukho gantvā apacitiṃ dassetvā haṃsarañño guṇe kathesi. Tāvadeva
analyzed: assāsetvā tassa abhimukhaḥ gantvā apacitim dassetvā haṃsa raññaḥ guṇe kathesi tāvat eva
translated: and then went and stood before the hunter, showing his contempt, and told the virtues of the king of the geese.

original: luddo muducitto ahosi. So tassa muducittakaṃ ñatvā puna gantvā haṃsarājameva assāsento
analyzed: luddaḥ mudu cittaḥ ahosi saḥ tassa mudu cittakam ñatvā puna gantvā haṃsa rājam eva assāsento
translated: At once the hunter became tender-hearted. Knowing that he was tender-hearted, he went back and stood comforting the king of the geese.

original: aṭṭhāsi. Luddopi haṃsarājānaṃ upasaṅkamitvā chaṭṭhaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: aṭṭhāsi luddaḥ api haṃsa rājānam upasaṅkamitvā chaṭṭham gātham āha
translated: The hunter approached the king of the geese and spoke the sixth verse:

original: “Apadena padaṃ yāti, antalikkhacaro dijo;
analyzed: a padena padam yāti antalikkha caraḥ dijaḥ
translated: “Without feet he goes on foot, the bird that flies through the air;

original: Ārā pāsaṃ na bujjhi tvaṃ, haṃsānaṃ pavaruttamā”ti.
analyzed: ārā pāsam na bujjhi tvam haṃsānam pavaruttama ati
translated: You did not see the snare, best of the geese.”

original: Tattha apadena padanti mahārāja, tumhādiso antalikkhacaro dijo apade ākāse padaṃ katvā yāti. Na bujjhi tvanti so tvaṃ evarūpo dūratova imaṃ pāsaṃ na bujjhi na jānīti pucchati.
analyzed: tattha apadena mahā rāja tumhādisaḥ antalikkha caraḥ dijaḥ apade ākāse padam katvā yāti na so tvam evarūpaḥ dūratas vā imam pāsam na bujjhi na jāni iti pucchati
translated: Here, “without feet” means, “Great king, a bird that flies through the air like you goes on foot without feet in the sky.” “You did not see” means, “You did not see this snare from afar. You did not know it.” He asks this.

original: Mahāsatto āha –
analyzed: mahāsattaḥ āha
translated: The Great Being said:

original: “Yadā parābhavo hoti, poso jīvitasaṅkhaye;
analyzed: yadā parābhavaḥ posaḥ jīvita saṅkhaye
translated: “When a man is defeated, when his life is at an end,

original: Atha jālañca pāsañca, āsajjāpi na bujjhatī”ti.
analyzed: atha jālañca pāsañca āsajja api na bujjhati iti
translated: Then he does not see the net and the snare, even when he is caught in them.”

original: Tattha yadā parābhavoti samma luddaputta, yadā parābhavo avuḍḍhi vināso sampatto hoti, atha poso jīvitasaṅkhaye patte jālañca pāsañca patvāpi na jānātīti attho.
analyzed: tattha yadā parābhavaḥ ti samma ludda putta yadā parābhavaḥ vināso sampatto hoti atha posaḥ jīvita saṅkhaye patte jālam ca pāsam ca patvā api na jānāti iti attho
translated: Herein, when defeat is come, dear son of a hunter, when defeat, non-prosperity, destruction, has come to pass, then the man, when his life is at an end, will not know even if he were to come upon a net and a snare. The meaning is that he will not know.

original: Luddo haṃsarañño kathaṃ abhinanditvā sumukhena saddhiṃ sallapanto tisso gāthā abhāsi –
analyzed: luddaḥ haṃsa raññaḥ katham abhinanditvā sumukhena saddhim sallapantaḥ tissaḥ gāthāḥ abhāsi
translated: The hunter, delighting in the royal swan’s speech, spoke three stanzas in reproach of Sumukha:

original: “Ete haṃsā pakkamanti, vakkaṅgā bhayameritā;
analyzed: ete haṃsā pakkamanti vakkaṅgāḥ bhayam eritā
translated: These swans are flying off, the geese are flying off in fear,

original: Harittaca hemavaṇṇa, tvaññeva avahiyyasi.
analyzed: harittaca hema vaṇṇa tvaññā iva avahiyyasi
translated: You alone are staying behind, yellow-skinned, golden-coloured.

original: “Ete bhutvā ca pivitvā ca, pakkamanti vihaṅgamā;
analyzed: ete bhutvā ca pivitvā ca pakkamanti vihaṅgamā
translated: These birds, having eaten and drunk, are flying off,

original: Anapekkhamānā vakkaṅgā, tvaññeveko upāsasi.
analyzed: an apekkhamānā vakkaṅgā tvañc eva ikaḥ upāsasi
translated: The geese are flying off without a care, you alone are staying behind.

original: “Kiṃ nu tyāyaṃ dijo hoti, mutto baddhaṃ upāsasi;
analyzed: kim nu tyāyam dijaḥ muttaḥ baddham upāsasi
translated: What is this? Are you a deity? You are staying behind, bound,

original: Ohāya sakuṇā yanti, kiṃ eko avahiyyasī”ti.
analyzed: ohāya sakuṇāḥ yanti kim ekaḥ avahiyyasi iti
translated: The birds are flying off, why do you alone stay behind?

original: Tattha tvaññevāti tvameva ohiyyasīti pucchati. Upāsasīti payirupāsasi.
analyzed: tattha tvañc eva ati tvam eva ohiyyasi iti pucchati upāsasi iti payis upāsasi
translated: Herein, you alone is asking: you are staying behind. You are staying behind is: you are attending on him.

original: Sumukho āha –
analyzed: sumukhaḥ āha
translated: Sumukha spoke:

original: “Rājā me so dijo mitto, sakhā pāṇasamo ca me;
analyzed: rājā me saḥ dijaḥ mittaḥ sakhā pāṇa samaḥ ca me
translated: He is my king, my deity, my friend, my life-companion,

analyzed: na iva nam vijahissāmi yāva kālassa pariyāyanti
translated: I shall not abandon him, until the time comes to an end.

original: Tattha yāva kālassa pariyāyanti luddaputta, yāva jīvitakālassa pariyosānaṃ ahaṃ etaṃ na vijahissāmiyeva.
analyzed: tattha yāva kālassa pariyāyanti ludda putta yāva jīvita kālassa pariyosānam aham etam na vijahissāmi iya eva
translated: “As long as there is time, my friend,” said the king, “as long as there is time, I will not abandon you.”

original: Taṃ sutvā luddo pasannacitto hutvā “sacāhaṃ evaṃ sīlasampannesu imesu aparajjhissāmi,
analyzed: tam sutvā luddaḥ pasanna cittaḥ hutvā sacā aham evam sīla sampannesu imesu aparajjhissāmi
translated: When the fowler heard this, he was filled with joy, and he thought to himself, “If I should do violence to these birds, who are so virtuous,

original: pathavīpi me vivaraṃ dadeyya, kiṃ me rañño santikā laddhena dhanena, vissajjessāmi
analyzed: pathavīpi me vivaram dadeyya kim me rañño santikā laddhena dhanena vissajjessāmi
translated: the very earth would open and swallow me up. What have I to do with the wealth I have received from the king? I will set them free.”

original: na”nti cintetvā gāthamāha –
analyzed: cintetvā gātham āha
translated: And he spoke the first stanza:

original: “Yo ca tvaṃ sakhino hetu, pāṇaṃ cajitumicchasi;
analyzed: ca tvam sakhinaḥ pāṇam cajitum icchasi
translated: If for the sake of one friend, You would abandon all your friends,

analyzed: saḥ te sahāyam muñcāmi hotu rājā tava anugā iti
translated: I set your friend at liberty: Let him be your companion still.

analyzed: tattha yaḥ ca tvanti yaḥ nāma tvam saḥ iti saḥ aham tava anugaḥ iti esa haṃsa rājā tava vasam anugataḥ hotu tayā saddhim eka ṭṭhāne vasatu
translated: “If” means “since.” “Your friend” means “this friend of yours.” “Let him be your companion still” means “Let this king of swans be your companion, let him live with you in the same place.”

original: Evañca pana vatvā dhataraṭṭhaṃ yaṭṭhipāsato otāretvā saratīraṃ netvā pāsaṃ muñcitvā
analyzed: evam ca pana vatvā dhataraṭṭham yaṭṭhi pāsataḥ otāretvā sara tīram netvā pāsam muñcitvā
translated: Having thus spoken, he drew Dhataraṭṭha from the noose, carried him to the bank of the lake, and loosed the noose from his neck.

original: muducittena lohitaṃ dhovitvā nhāruādīni paṭipādesi. Tassa muducittatāya mahāsattassa
analyzed: mudu cittena lohitam dhovitvā nhāru ādīni paṭipādesi tassa mudu citta tāya mahāsattassa
translated: With a tender heart he washed the blood from his wounds, and bound up his bruised limbs. Because of the tender heart of the Great Being,

original: pāramitānubhāvena ca tāvadeva pādo sacchavi ahosi, baddhaṭṭhānampi na paññāyi. Sumukho
analyzed: pāramitā anubhāvena ca tāvat eva pādo sa chavi ahosi baddha ṭṭhānam pi na paññāyi su mukho
translated: and by the power of his perfection of charity his foot was immediately restored to its former condition, and the place where the arrow had entered could not be discovered. Sumukha

original: bodhisattaṃ oloketvā tuṭṭhacitto anumodanaṃ karonto gāthamāha –
analyzed: bodhisattam oloketvā tuṭṭha cittaḥ anumodanam karontaḥ gātham āha
translated: looked at the Bodhisatta, and with a glad heart, as he was returning thanks, he spoke this verse:

original: “Evaṃ luddaka nandassu, saha sabbehi ñātibhi;
analyzed: evam luddaka nandassu saha sabbehi ñātibhi
translated: “Rejoice, O hunter, with all thy kinsfolk,

original: Yathāhamajja nandāmi, muttaṃ disvā dijādhipa”nti.
analyzed: yathā aham ajja nandāmi muttam disvā
translated: As I rejoice to-day, beholding the king of birds set free.”

original: Taṃ sutvā luddo “gacchatha, sāmī”ti āha. Atha naṃ mahāsatto “kiṃ pana tvaṃ samma,
analyzed: tam sutvā luddaḥ gacchatha sāmi iti āha atha nam mahāsatto kim pana tvam
translated: When the hunter heard this, he said, “Go, my lord.” Then the Great Being asked him, “But why did you bind me, my friend?

original: maṃ attano atthāya bandhi, udāhu aññassa āṇattiyā”ti pucchitvā tena tasmiṃ kāraṇe
analyzed: mam attanaḥ atthāya bandhi udāhu aññassa āṇattiyā ati pucchitvā tena tasmim kāraṇe
translated: Was it for your own sake, or by the command of another?” When the hunter told him the reason, he reflected,

original: ārocite “kiṃ nu kho me itova cittakūṭaṃ gantuṃ seyyo, udāhu nagara”nti vimaṃsanto
analyzed: ārocite kim nu khalu me itas iva cittakūṭam gantum vimaṃsantaḥ
translated: “Which is better for me to do, to go from here to Cittakūṭa, or to the city?”

original: “mayi nagaraṃ gate luddaputto dhanaṃ labhissati, deviyā dohaḷo paṭippassambhissati,
analyzed: mayi nagaram gate ludda puttaḥ dhanam labhissati deviyā dohaḷaḥ paṭippassambhissati
translated: “If I go to the city,” he thought, “the hunter’s son will get the money, the queen’s charge will be removed,

original: sumukhassa mittadhammo pākaṭo bhavissati, tathā mama ñāṇabalaṃ, khemañca saraṃ abhayadakkhiṇaṃ
analyzed: sumukhassa mitta dhammo pākaṭaḥ bhavissati tathā mama ñāṇa balam khemam ca saram abhaya dakkhiṇam
translated: Sumukha’s friendship will be made manifest, and so will my knowledge and power and my gift of safety and security.

original: katvā labhissāmi, tasmā nagarameva gantuṃ seyyo”ti sanniṭṭhānaṃ katvā “ludda, tvaṃ
analyzed: katvā labhissāmi tasmai nagaram eva gantum seyyaḥ iti sanniṭṭhānam katvā ludda tvam
translated: I shall get them back. Therefore it is better for me to go to the city.” Having thus resolved, he said to the fowler, “Fowler,

original: amhe kājenādāya rañño santikaṃ nehi, sace no rājā vissajjetukāmo bhavissati, vissajjessatī”ti
analyzed: amhe kājena ādāya rañño santikam nehi sace naḥ rājā vissajjetu kāmaḥ bhavissati vissajjessati iti
translated: take us to the king. If the king wishes to set us free, he will do so.”

original: āha. Rājāno nāma sāmi, kakkhaḷā, gacchatha tumheti. Mayaṃ tādisaṃ luddampi mudukaṃ
analyzed: āha rājānaḥ nāma sāmi kakkhaḷāḥ gacchatha tumhā iti mayam tādisam luddam pi mudukam
translated: Kings are hard-hearted. Go, take them. We have made even a fowler as gentle as a mother.

original: karimha, rañño ārādhane amhākaṃ bhāro, nehiyeva no, sammāti. So tathā akāsi. Rājā
analyzed: karimha raññaḥ ārādhane amhākam bhāraḥ nehiyā iva no sammā iti saḥ tathā akāsi rājā
translated: It is our duty to please the king. Take us, good fowler.” He did so. The king,

original: haṃse disvāva somanassajāto hutvā dvepi haṃse kañcanapīṭhe nisīdāpetvā madhulāje
analyzed: haṃse disvā ava somanassajātaḥ hutvā dve api haṃse kañcana pīṭhe nisīdāpetvā madhu lāje
translated: seeing the geese, was delighted. He had the two geese seated on golden seats, fed them with honey and parched rice,

original: khādāpetvā madhurodakaṃ pāyetvā añjaliṃ paggayha dhammakathaṃ āyāci. Haṃsarājā tassa
analyzed: khādāpetvā madhura udakam pāyetvā añjalim paggayha dhamma katham āyāci haṃsa rājā tassa
translated: and made them drink honey-water. Then he raised his clasped hands in adoration and asked for a discourse on the Law. The king of the geese,

original: sotukāmataṃ viditvā paṭhamaṃ tāva paṭisanthāramakāsi. Tatrimā haṃsassa ca rañño ca
analyzed: sotu kāma tam viditvā paṭhamam tāva paṭisanthāram akāsi tatrimā haṃsassa ca rañño ca
translated: knowing that he was desirous of hearing the Law, first of all made him welcome. Here are the verses of the geese and the king,

original: vacanapaṭivacanagāthāyo honti –
analyzed: vacana paṭivacana gāthāyaḥ honti
translated: the one speaking and the other replying:—

original: “Kaccinnu bhoto kusalaṃ, kacci bhoto anāmayaṃ;
analyzed: kaccit nu bhotaḥ kusalam kacci bhotaḥ anāmayam
translated: “Are you well, good sir? Are you in health, good sir?

original: Kacci raṭṭhamidaṃ phītaṃ, dhammena manusāsasi.
analyzed: kacci raṭṭham idam phītam dhammena manu sāsasi

analyzed: nipajji tassa pāde sambāhantaḥ nisīdi rājā antarantarā niddāyati ca iva pabujjhati ca  cora gāma vāsino corā api raññaḥ ārakkhaṇa tthāya araññam eva pavisiṃsu cora gāmake

translated: There, the deer hunter is called “deer hunter” because he searches for deer like a hunter. “Without a group” means

translated: Attha. Sāhasā means “I will take by force, by violence.” Nisīthepi rahodānīti🔽means “at night, even now, in secret.” He says this: “Just as at night, at midnight, people are tired

translated: Another novice welcomed him, a novice with a red beak.🔽“Welcome, O king,” said he, “and good fortune to you.

original: Issarosi anuppatto, yaṃ idhatthi pavedaya.
analyzed: issarā asi an uppattaḥ yam idha atthi pavedaya
translated: You are the lord of this place. Tell me what you desire.”

original: “Tiṇḍukāni piyālāni, madhuke kāsumāriyo;
analyzed: tiṇḍukāni piyālāni madhuke
translated: “Here are tinduka fruits, here are piyal fruits, here are madhu fruits, here are kāsumāra fruits,

original: Phalāni khuddakappāni, bhuñja rāja varaṃ varaṃ.
analyzed: phalāni khudda kappāni bhuñja rāja varam varam
translated: Here are various kinds of small fruits. Eat, O king, the best of the fruits.”

original: “Idampi pānīyaṃ sītaṃ, ābhataṃ girigabbharā;
analyzed: idam pi pānīyam giri gabbharā
translated: “Here is cool water brought from the mountain stream.

original: Tato piva mahārāja, sace tvaṃ abhikaṅkhasi.
analyzed: tatas piva mahā rāja sace tvam abhikaṅkhasi
translated: Drink thereof, O king, if you desire.”

original: “Araññaṃ uñchāya gatā, ye asmiṃ paricārakā;
analyzed: araññam uñchāya gatāḥ ye asmin paricārakā
translated: “They have gone to the forest for alms, those who are my attendants here;

original: Sayaṃ uṭṭhāya gaṇhavho, hatthā me natthi dātave”ti.
analyzed: sayam uṭṭhāya gaṇhavhaḥ hatthāḥ me na atthi dātave iti
translated: Rise up and gather them yourselves, I have no hands to give to you.”

original: Tattha paṭinanditthāti rājānaṃ disvāva tussi. Lohitatuṇḍakoti rattatuṇḍo sobhaggappatto.
analyzed: tattha paṭinandittha ati rājānam disvā ava tussi lohita tuṇḍako ti ratta tuṇḍo sobhagga ppatto
translated: There, having seen the king, he was delighted. “Red-beaked” means red-beak, having attained beauty.

original: Madhuketi madhukaphalāni. Kāsumāriyoti evaṃnāmakāni phalāni, kāraphalāni vā. Tato
analyzed: madhuka iti madhuka phalāni evaṃnāmakāni phalāni kāra phalāni vā
translated: “Honey” means honey fruits. “Kāsumāri” means fruits of that name, or sour fruits. From there

original: pivāti tato pānīyamāḷato gahetvā pānīyaṃ piva. Ye asmiṃ paricārakāti mahārāja, ye
analyzed: pivāti pānīyam āḍataḥ pānīyam piva ye mahā rāja ye
translated: drink, having taken water from the drinking water shed, drink water. “Those who are my attendants here” means great king, those

original: imasmiṃ assame vicaraṇakā isayo, te araññaṃ uñchāya gatā. Gaṇhavhoti phalāphalāni
analyzed: imasmin assame vicaraṇakāḥ isayo te araññam uñchāya gatāḥ gaṇhavhoti phala aphalāni
translated: seers who wander in this hermitage have gone to the forest for alms. “Gather them” means gather the fruits and

original: gaṇhatha. Dātaveti dātuṃ.
analyzed: gaṇhatha dātave iti dātum
translated: take them. “To give” means to give.

original: Rājā tassa paṭisanthāre pasīditvā gāthādvayamāha –
analyzed: rājā tassa paṭisanthāre pasīditvā gāthā dvayam āha
translated: The king, being pleased with his hospitality, spoke two verses:

original: “Bhaddako vatayaṃ pakkhī, dijo paramadhammiko;
analyzed: bhaddakaḥ vatayam pakkhī dijaḥ parama dhammiko
translated: “This bird is indeed excellent, a divine one of the highest dharma;

original: Atheso itaro pakkhī, suvo luddāni bhāsati.
analyzed: atha iso itaraḥ pakkhī suvar luddāni bhāsati
translated: And this other bird, the son, speaks so well to the hunter.

original: “‘Etaṃ hanatha bandhatha, mā vo muñcittha jīvataṃ’;
analyzed: etam hanatha bandhatha mā vaḥ muñcittha jīvatam
translated: “‘Kill him, bind him, do not let him go free from life’;

original: Iccevaṃ vilapantassa, sotthiṃ pattosmi assama”nti.
analyzed: icca ivam vilapantassa sotthim pattaḥ asmi
translated: So, as he thus bewailed, I reached the hermitage in safety.”

original: Tattha itaroti corakuṭiyaṃ suvako. Iccevanti ahaṃ pana tassa evaṃ vilapantasseva imaṃ assamaṃ sotthinā patto.
analyzed: tattha itaro ti cora kuṭiyam suvakaḥ aham pana tassa evam vilapantassa iva imam assamam sotthinā patto
translated: Herein, the other is the cleverer of the two thieves. So, as he thus bewailed, I reached the hermitage in safety.

original: Rañño kathaṃ sutvā pupphako dve gāthā abhāsi –
analyzed: raññaḥ katham sutvā pupphakaḥ dve gāthāḥ abhāsi
translated: When the King heard his story, Pupphaka spoke two more stanzas:

original: “Bhātarosma mahārāja, sodariyā ekamātukā;
analyzed: bhātaraḥ asma mahā rāja sodariyāḥ eka mātukā
translated: “We are brothers, sire, and of the same mother,

original: Ekarukkhasmiṃ saṃvaḍḍhā, nānākhettagatā ubho.
analyzed: eka rukkhasmim saṃvaḍḍhāḥ nānā khetta gatāḥ ubho
translated: And we grew up together in the same tree, though we went to different fields.

original: “Sattigumbo ca corānaṃ, ahañca isinaṃ idha;
analyzed: ca corānam aham ca isinam idha
translated: “The thorn-apple tree is for the thieves, and here is the fig tree for the seers.

original: Asataṃ so, sataṃ ahaṃ, tena dhammena no vinā”ti.🔽Tattha bhātarosmāti mahārāja, so ca ahañca ubho bhātaro homa. Corānanti so corānaṃ
analyzed: asatam saḥ satam aham tena dhammena naḥ vinā ati  mahā rāja saḥ ca ahan ca ubho bhātaraḥ saḥ cora ananti saḥ
translated: He is the bad one, I am the good one, and by this truth may I be safe.”

original: santike saṃvaḍḍho, ahaṃ isīnaṃ santike. Asataṃ so, sataṃ ahanti so asādhūnaṃ dussīlānaṃ
analyzed: santike saṃvaḍḍhaḥ aham isīnam santike asatam saḥ satam ahanti saḥ asādhūnam dussīlānam
translated: Herein, we are brothers, sire: we two are brothers. For the thieves: he grew up in the presence of thieves, I in the presence of seers. He is the bad one, I am the good one: he went into the company of the bad, the unvirtuous,

original: santikaṃ upagato, ahaṃ sādhūnaṃ sīlavantānaṃ. Tena dhammena no vināti mahārāja, taṃ
analyzed: santikam upagataḥ aham sādhūnam sīlavantānam tena dhammena naḥ vinā ati mahā rāja tam
translated: I into the company of the good, the virtuous. And by this truth may I be safe: by this truth, great king,

original: sattigumbaṃ corā coradhammena corakiriyāya vinesuṃ, maṃ isayo isidhammena isisīlācārena,
analyzed: satti gumbam corā cora dhammena cora kiriyāya vinesum mam isayaḥ isi dhammena isi sīla ācārena
translated: The seers trained me in the way of seers, in the conduct and way of life of seers.

original: tasmā sopi tena coradhammena no vinā hoti, ahampi isidhammena no vinā homīti.
analyzed: tasmā saḥ api tena cora dhammena no vinā hoti ahampi isi dhammena no vinā homi iti
translated: Therefore, I am not without that way of seers, just as you are not without that way of thieves.”

original: Idāni taṃ dhammaṃ vibhajanto gāthādvayamāha –
analyzed: idāni tam dhammam vibhajantaḥ gāthā dvayam āha
translated: Now, in order to analyze that Dhamma, he spoke two verses:

original: “Tattha vadho ca bandho ca, nikatī vañcanāni ca;
analyzed: tattha vadho ca bandho ca nikatī vañcanāni ca
translated: “There, killing, binding, imprisoning, and cheating,

original: Ālopā sāhasākārā, tāni so tattha sikkhati.
analyzed: ālopā sāhasa ākārā tāni so tattha sikkhati
translated: and plundering, and violence—there he trains.

original: “Idha saccañca dhammo ca, ahiṃsā saṃyamo damo;
analyzed: idha saccaṃ ca dhammo ca ahiṃsā saṃyamaḥ damo
translated: “Here, truth, Dhamma, harmlessness, restraint, and self-control,

original: Āsanūdakadāyīnaṃ, aṅke vaddhosmi bhāradhā”ti.
analyzed: aṅke vaddhaḥ asmi bhāradhāti
translated: and giving a seat and water—I am a debtor to those, Bharadvaja.”

original: Tattha nikatīti patirūpakena vañcanā. Vañcanānīti ujukavañcanāneva. Ālopāti divā
analyzed: tattha divā
translated: There, “imprisoning” is cheating with what is suitable. “Cheating” is just cheating straightforward people. “Plundering” is plundering by day

original: gāmaghātā. Sāhasākārāti gehaṃ pavisitvā maraṇena tajjetvā sāhasikakammakaraṇāni.
analyzed: gāma ghātā sāhasa ākārā ati geham pavisitvā maraṇena tat jetvā sāhasika kamma karaṇāni
translated: in the village. “Violence” is committing violent acts by entering the house and threatening with death.

original: Saccanti sabhāvo. Dhammoti sucaritadhammo. Ahiṃsāti mettāpubbabhāgo. Saṃyamoti sīlasaṃyamo.
analyzed: saccanti sabhāvaḥ dhammo ti su carita dhammo ahiṃsā ati mettā pubbabhāgo saṃyamo ti sīla saṃyamo
translated: “Truth” is the intrinsic nature. “Dhamma” is the Dhamma of good conduct. “Harmlessness” is the precursor to loving-kindness. “Restraint” is the restraint of virtue.

original: Damoti indriyadamanaṃ. Āsanūdakadāyīnanti abbhāgatānaṃ āsanañca udakañca dānasīlānaṃ.
analyzed: indriya damanam abbhāga tānam āsanam ca udakam ca dāna sīlānam
translated: “Taming” is taming of the faculties. “Who give seats and water” are those who are virtuous in giving seats and water to those who come.

original: Bhāradhāti rājānaṃ ālapati.
analyzed: bhāradhāti rājānam ālapati
translated: Bhāradvāja addressed the king.

original: Idāni rañño dhammaṃ desento imā gāthā abhāsi –
analyzed: idāni raññaḥ dhammam desentaḥ imāḥ gāthāḥ abhāsi
translated: Now, teaching the Dhamma to the king, he spoke these verses:

original: “Yaṃ yañhi rāja bhajati, santaṃ vā yadi vā asaṃ;
analyzed: yam yat hi rāja bhajati santam vā yadi vā asam
translated: “Whatever one associates with, whether good or bad,

original: Sīlavantaṃ visīlaṃ vā, vasaṃ tasseva gacchati.
analyzed: sīlavantam visīlam vā vasam gacchati
translated: whether virtuous or unvirtuous, one comes under his sway.

original: “Yādisaṃ kurute mittaṃ, yādisaṃ cūpasevati;
analyzed: yādisam kurute mittam yādisam cūpasevati
translated: “Whatever kind of friend one makes, whatever kind one serves,

original: Sopi tādisako hoti, sahavāso hi tādiso.
analyzed: saḥ api tādisakaḥ hoti sahavāsaḥ hi tādisaḥ
translated: one becomes just like that; for one’s character is shaped by one’s companions.

original: “Sevamāno sevamānaṃ, samphuṭṭho samphusaṃ paraṃ;
analyzed: sevamānaḥ sevamānam samphuṭṭhaḥ samphusam param
translated: “One who associates with the bad, who touches the bad with the body,

original: Saro diddho kalāpaṃva, alittamupalimpati;
analyzed: saraḥ diddhaḥ kalāpam iva alittam upalimpati
translated: is smeared like a lump of dough with mud; he is smeared and defiled.

original: Upalepabhayā dhīro, neva pāpasakhā siyā.
analyzed: upalepa bhayā dhīraḥ nā iva pāpa sakhā siyā
translated: But the wise one, fearing defilement, should not have bad friends.

original: “Pūtimacchaṃ kusaggena, yo naro upanayhati;
analyzed: pūtimat śam kusaggena yaḥ naraḥ upanayhati
translated: “The man who carries a piece of rotten fish wrapped in a leaf of nāgakesara flowers

original: Kusāpi pūti vāyanti, evaṃ bālūpasevanā.
analyzed: pūti vāyanti evam bālūpasevanā
translated: smells bad himself, as does one who associates with fools.

original: “Tagarañca palāsena, yo naro upanayhati;
analyzed: tagaram ca palāsena yaḥ naraḥ upanayhati
translated: “The man who carries a piece of fragrant agaru wood wrapped in a leaf of tagara flowers

original: Pattāpi surabhi vāyanti, evaṃ dhīrūpasevanā.
analyzed: surabhi vāyanti evam dhī rūpa sevanā
translated: smells sweet himself, as does one who associates with the virtuous.

original: “Tasmā pattapuṭasseva, ñatvā sampākamattano;
analyzed: tasmā patta puṭassa iva ñatvā sampāka mattano
translated: “Therefore, knowing one’s own measure, like the measure of a bushel or a basket,

original: Asante nopaseveyya, sante seveyya paṇḍito;
analyzed: a sante na upaseveyya sante seveyya paṇḍito
translated: But should serve the good;🔽The bad lead to hell,

original: Asanto nirayaṃ nenti, santo pāpenti suggati”nti.
analyzed: asantaḥ nirayam nenti santaḥ pāpenti
translated: The good lead to heaven.”🔽Herein, whether good or bad, whether a good person or a bad person,

original: Tattha santaṃ vā yadi vā asanti sappurisaṃ vā asappurisaṃ vā. Sevamāno sevamānanti🔽seviyamāno ācariyo sevamānaṃ antevāsikaṃ. Samphuṭṭhoti antevāsinā vā phuṭṭho ācariyo.🔽Samphusaṃ paranti paraṃ ācariyaṃ samphusanto antevāsī vā. Alittanti taṃ antevāsikaṃ
analyzed: tattha santam vā yadi vā asanti sappurisam vā a sappurisam vā sevamāno sevamānanti  seviyamānaḥ ācariyaḥ sevamānam antevāsikam samphuṭṭhaḥ iti antevāsinā vā phuṭṭhaḥ ācariyaḥ  samphusam paranti param ācariyam samphusantaḥ antevāsī vā tam antevāsikam
translated: “Serving, serving” :🔽the teacher, being served, serves the pupil. “Touched” : the teacher is touched by the pupil.🔽“Touching, touching” : the pupil touches the teacher. “Not a drop” :

original: pāpadhammena alittaṃ so ācariyo visadiddho saro sesaṃ sarakalāpaṃ viya limpati. Evaṃ🔽bālūpasevanāti bālūpasevī hi pūtimacchaṃ upanayhanakusaggaṃ viya hoti, pāpakammaṃ
analyzed: pāpa dhammena a littam saḥ ācariyaḥ visadiddhaḥ saraḥ sesam sara kalāpam viya limpati evam  bāla upasevanā ati bāla upasevī hi pūtima cham upanayhana kusaggam viya hoti pāpa kammam
translated: the teacher is not touched by the pupil, just as a water drop does not stick to a well-polished lotus leaf. “The rest” : the rest of the water sticks to the rest of the leaf.🔽Thus,🔽“Serving fools” : one who serves fools is like a man who carries a rotten fish wrapped in a leaf of the kusagrass. Even though he does not do evil,

original: akarontopi avaṇṇaṃ akittiṃ labhati. Dhīrūpasevanāti dhīrūpasevī puggalo tagarādigandhajātipaliveṭhanapattaṃ
analyzed: a karontaḥ api a vaṇṇam akittim labhati dhī rūpa sevanā ati dhī rūpa sevī puggalo tagara ādi gandha jāti paliveṭhana pattam
translated: he gets a bad name and a bad reputation. “Serving the wise” : a person who serves the wise is like a man who carries a fragrant flower wrapped in a leaf of the tagara-tree.

original: viya hoti, paṇḍito bhavituṃ asakkontopi kalyāṇamittasevī guṇakittiṃ labhati. Pattapuṭassevāti
analyzed: viya hoti paṇḍitaḥ bhavitum a sakkontaḥ api kalyāṇa mitta sevī guṇa kittim labhati patta puṭassa iva ati
translated: and he becomes like a tree that is the resort of birds. Even if he is unable to be wise, he who associates with good friends gains a reputation for virtue. As a container for leaves:

original: duggandhasugandhapaliveṭhanapaṇṇasseva. Sampākamattanoti kalyāṇamittasaṃsaggavasena
analyzed: duggandha sugandha paliveṭhana paṇṇassa iva sampākam attanoti kalyāṇa mitta saṃsagga vasena
translated: as a container for leaves that are both foul-smelling and fragrant. His own maturity:

original: attano paripākaṃ paribhāvanaṃ ñatvāti attho. Pāpenti suggatinti santo sammādiṭṭhikā
analyzed: attanaḥ paripākam paribhāvanam ñatvā ati attho suggatinti santaḥ sammādiṭṭhikā
translated: by the association with good friends, he should know his own maturity, his own development. They lead to good destinations:

original: attānaṃ nissite satte saggameva pāpentīti desanaṃ yathānusandhimeva pāpesi.
analyzed: attānam nissite satte saggam eva pāpenti iti desanam yathā anusandhim eva pāpesi
translated: the virtuous, who have right view, lead themselves and those who are dependent on them to the heavenly state. He led them to the destination in accordance with the outcome of their kamma.

original: Rājā tassa dhammakathāya pasīdi, isigaṇopi āgato. Rājā isayo vanditvā “bhante, maṃ
analyzed: rājā tassa dhamma kathāya pasīdi isi gaṇaḥ api āgataḥ rājā isayaḥ vanditvā bhante maṃ
translated: The king was pleased with his Dhamma talk, and the group of seers also came. The king worshipped the seers and said, “Venerable sirs,

original: anukampamānā mama vasanaṭṭhāne vasathā”ti vatvā tesaṃ paṭiññaṃ gahetvā nagaraṃ gantvā🔽suvānaṃ abhayaṃ adāsi. Isayopi tattha agamaṃsu. Rājā isigaṇaṃ uyyāne vasāpento yāvajīvaṃ
analyzed: anukampamānāḥ mama vasana ṭṭhāne vasatha ati vatvā tesam paṭiññam gahetvā nagaram gantvā  suvānam abhayam adāsi tattha agamaṃsu rājā isi gaṇam uyyāne yāvajīvam
translated: out of compassion for me, please live in my dwelling place.” After receiving their assent, he went to the city and🔽gave the seers safety and security. The seers came there. The king, causing the group of seers to live in the pleasure garden, served them

original: upaṭṭhahitvā saggapuraṃ pūresi. Athassa puttopi chattaṃ ussāpento isigaṇaṃ paṭijaggiyevāti
analyzed: upaṭṭhahitvā sagga puram pūresi atha assa puttaḥ api chattam ussāpentaḥ isi gaṇam paṭijaggiya iva ati
translated: as long as he lived and filled the city of the gods. Then his son also protected the group of seers, holding up the royal parasol.

original: tasmiṃ kulaparivaṭṭe satta rājāno isigaṇassa dānaṃ pavattayiṃsu. Mahāsatto araññe
analyzed: tasmim kula parivaṭṭe satta rājānaḥ isi gaṇassa dānam pavattayiṃsu mahāsattaḥ araññe
translated: In this family-circle seven kings gave alms to the company of seers. The Great Being,

original: vasantoyeva yathākammaṃ gato.
analyzed: yathākammam gataḥ
translated: while dwelling in the forest, passed away according to his deeds.

original: Satthā imaṃ dhammadesanaṃ āharitvā “evaṃ, bhikkhave, pubbepi devadatto pāpo pāpaparivāroyevā”ti
analyzed: satthā imam dhamma desanam āharitvā evam bhikkhave pubbe pi devadatto pāpaḥ pāpa parivāraḥ yā iva ati
translated: The Teacher, having related this dhamma discourse, “Thus, monks, formerly also Devadatta was wicked and had a wicked retinue,”

original: vatvā jātakaṃ samodhānesi – “tadā sattigumbo devadatto ahosi, corā devadattaparisā,
analyzed: vatvā jātakam samodhānesi tadā sattigumbaḥ devadattaḥ ahosi corāḥ devadatta parisā
translated: and having thus explained the Jātaka, identified the Birth: “At that time the seven seers were the company of the Buddha, the robber-gang was Devadatta’s retinue,

original: rājā ānando, isigaṇā buddhaparisā, pupphakasuvo pana ahameva ahosi”nti.🔽Sattigumbajātakavaṇṇanā sattamā.
analyzed: rājā ānandaḥ isi gaṇāḥ buddha parisā pupphakasuvaḥ pana aham eva ahosinti  sattigumba jātaka vaṇṇanā sattamā
translated: the king was Ānanda, and I myself was the seer Pupphakasuva.”🔽The commentary on the Sattigumba Jātaka is finished.

original: [504] 8. Bhallātiyajātakavaṇṇanā
translated: The commentary on the Bhallātiya Jātaka is finished.🔽Bhallātiya, a king was named,

original: Bhallātiyo nāma ahosi rājāti idaṃ satthā jetavane viharanto mallikaṃ deviṃ ārabbha
analyzed: bhallātiyaḥ nāma ahosi rājā iti idam satthā jetavane viharantaḥ mallikam devim ārabbha
translated: The Teacher, while dwelling at Jetavana, told this story of Queen Mallikā.

original: kathesi. Tassā kira ekadivasaṃ raññā saddhiṃ sayanaṃ nissāya kalaho ahosi. Rājā kujjhitvā
analyzed: kathesi tassā kira eka divasam raññā saddhim sayanam nissāya kalahaḥ ahosi rājā kujjhitvā
translated: One day, it seems, she had a quarrel with the king over a bed. The king, being angry,

original: naṃ na olokesi. Sā cintesi “nanu tathāgato rañño mayi kuddhabhāvaṃ na jānātī”ti.
analyzed: naṃ na olokesi sā cintesi nanu tathāgataḥ raññaḥ mayi kuddha bhāvam na jānāti iti
translated: did not look at her. She thought, “Does not the Tathāgata know that the king is angry with me?”

original: Satthā taṃ kāraṇaṃ ñatvā punadivase bhikkhusaṅghaparivuto sāvatthiṃ piṇḍāya pavisitvā
analyzed: satthā tam kāraṇam ñatvā puna divase bhikkhu saṅgha parivutaḥ sāvatthim piṇḍāya pavisitvā
translated: The Teacher, understanding the reason, on the following day entered Sāvatthi for alms with the company of the monks.

original: rañño gehadvāraṃ gato. Rājā paccuggantvā pattaṃ gahetvā satthāraṃ pāsādaṃ āropetvā
analyzed: raññaḥ geha dvāram gataḥ rājā paccuggantvā pattam gahetvā satthāram pāsādam āropetvā
translated: The king went out to meet him, took his bowl, and led him to the palace.

original: paṭipāṭiyā bhikkhusaṅghaṃ nisīdāpetvā dakkhiṇodakaṃ datvā paṇītenāhārena parivisitvā
analyzed: paṭipāṭiyā bhikkhu saṅgham nisīdāpetvā dakkhiṇa udakam datvā paṇītena āhārena parivisitvā

analyzed: puna na bhavissati na āgamissati iti socāma dhanam va naṭṭham pitaram va petanti dhanam  vā naṭṭham pitaram vā mātaram vā apetam kālakatam kim nu kho tumhe cintayamānā kena
translated: we sorrowed that it would not happen again, that it would not occur again. “As if we had lost our wealth, as if our father had died”: as if we had lost our wealth,

original: kāraṇena taṃ ekarattaṃ vinā vāsaṃ akappayittha, idaṃ me ācikkhathāti pucchati. Yamimanti🔽yaṃ imaṃ. Selakūlanti dvinnaṃ selānaṃ antare sandamānaṃ. Vassakāleti ekassa meghassa
analyzed: kāraṇena tam eka rattam vinā vāsam akappayittha idam me ācikkhatha ati pucchati yam imanti  yam imam selakūlanti dvinnam selānam antare sandamānam vassa kāle iti ekassa meghassa
translated: or as if our father or mother had died. “What did you think about?” “For what reason did you not arrange to spend that night apart?” He asks them to explain this to him. “The one”:🔽the one. “Between the rocks”: between two rocks, in the middle. “At the time of the rains”:

analyzed: uṭṭhāya vassana kāle amhākam hi imasmin vana saṇḍe rati vasena carantānam ekaḥ meghaḥ

analyzed: uṭṭhahi atha me piya sāmikaḥ kinnara umam pacchatas āgacchati iti maññamānaḥ etam nadim āha
translated: for us. Then my dear husband, thinking, ‘She is coming from behind,’ crossed this river.”

original: Ahañcāti ahaṃ panetassa paratīraṃ gatabhāvaṃ ajānantī supupphitāni aṅkolakādīni pupphāni
analyzed: aham ca ati aham pana itassa para tīram gata bhāvam a jānantī su pupphitāni aṅkolaka ādīni pupphāni
translated: And I, not knowing that he had reached the further shore, plucked the flowers, the aṅkolika, etc., in full bloom,

original: ocināmi. Tattha sattaliyothikañcāti kundālapupphañca suvaṇṇayothikañca ocinantī pana
analyzed: ocināmi tattha kundāla puppham ca suvaṇṇa yothikam ca ocinantī pana
translated: and the two kinds of yuthika, the sattali and the suvaṇṇayuthika.

original: “piyo ca me mālabhārī bhavissati, ahañca naṃ mālinī hutvā ajjhupessa”nti iminā kāraṇena🔽ocināmi. Uddālakā pāṭalisindhuvārakāti tepi mayā ocitāyevāti vadati. Oceyyāti ocinitvā.
analyzed: piyaḥ ca me mālabhārī bhavissati aham ca nam mālinī hutvā ajjhupessanti iminā kāraṇena  ocināmi uddālakā pāṭali sindhuvārakā iti te pi mayā ocitāya iva ati vadati oceyya iti ocinitvā
translated: Pluck them, thinking: ‘He will be my dear garland-maker, and I will serve him as a garland-maker.’🔽Uddālaka, pāṭali, sindhuvāra, I plucked them too. Pluck them means: having plucked them.

original: Agaḷuṃ candanañcāti kāḷāgaḷuñca rattacandanañca. Rositaṅgoti vilittasarīro. Rositāti🔽vilittā hutvā. Ajjhupessanti sayane upagamissāmi. Nudaṃ sāle salaḷe kaṇṇikāreti etāni
analyzed: agaḷum candanam ca ati kāḷāgaḷum ca ratta candanam ca vilitta sarīraḥ  vilittāḥ hutvā ajjhupessanti sayane upagamissāmi nudam sāle salaḷe kaṇṇikāre iti etāni
translated: The kāḷāgaḷu and the rattacandana, I anointed myself with them. Rositaṅga means: with my body anointed. Rositā means:

original: mayā ocinitvā tīre ṭhapitāni pupphāni nudantaṃ harantaṃ. Suduttarāti tassā hi orimatīre
analyzed: mayā ocinitvā tīre ṭhapitāni pupphāni nudantam harantam tassā hi orima tīre
