original: ṭhitakāleyeva nadiyā udakaṃ āgataṃ, taṅkhaṇaññeva sūriyo atthaṅgato, vijjulatā niccharanti,
analyzed: ṭhita kāleyā iva nadiyāḥ udakam āgatam taṅkhaṇaññā iva sūriyaḥ atthaṅgataḥ vijju latāḥ niccharanti
translated: At the time of standing, the water of the river had come up, and at that moment the sun had set, and lightning flashes were falling down.

original: kinnarā nāma udakabhīrukā honti, iti sā otarituṃ na visahi. Tenāha “sāyaṃ nadī āsi mayā suduttarā”ti.
analyzed: kinnarāḥ nāma udaka bhīrukāḥ honti iti sā otaritum na tena āha sāyam nadī āsi mayā suduttarā iti

original: Sampassantāti vijjulatāniccharaṇakāle passantā. Rodāmāti andhakārakāle apassantā
analyzed: sampassantā ati vijju latā niccharaṇa kāle passantā rodāma ati andhakāra kāle a passantā
translated: Sampassantā = “Seeing.” At the time of the falling down of lightning flashes. Rodāmā = “We weep.” At the time of darkness.

original: rodāma, vijjulatāniccharaṇakāle passantā hasāma. Saṃvarīti ratti. Catukkanti tucchaṃ.
analyzed: rodāma passantā hasāma saṃvari tuccham
translated: Passantā = “Seeing.” At the time of the falling down of lightning flashes. Hasāma = “We laugh.” Saṃvarī = “Night.” Catukkan = “Empty.”

original: Uttariyānāti uttaritvā. Tīhūnakanti tīhi ūnāni satta vassasatāni. Yamidha mayanti
analyzed: uttaritvā tīhi ūnakanti tīhi ūnāni satta vassa satāni yam idha mayanti

original: yaṃ kālaṃ idha mayaṃ vippavasimha, so ito tīhi ūnakāni satta vassasatāni hontīti
analyzed: yam kālam idha mayam vippavasimha saḥ itas tīhi ūnakāni satta vassa satāni honti iti
translated: “The time we lived here, that is three less than seven hundred years.”

original: vadati. Ko nīdhāti evaṃ parittake jīvite ko nu idha kantāya vinā bhaveyya, ayuttaṃ
analyzed: vadati kaḥ evam parittake jīvite kaḥ nu idha kantāya vinā bhaveyya ayuttam
translated: Ko nīdhāti = “Who is the beloved one?” In such a short life, who would be without a beloved one? It is not proper to live without a beloved one.

original: tava piyabhariyāya vinā bhavitunti dīpeti.
analyzed: tava piya bhariyāya vinā dīpa iti
translated: means: I shall live without your beloved wife.

original: Kīvatako nūti rājā kinnariyā vacanaṃ sutvā “imesaṃ āyuppamāṇaṃ pucchissāmī”ti cintetvā
analyzed: kīvatakaḥ nu iti rājā kinnariyāḥ vacanam sutvā imesam āyu pamāṇam pucchissāmi iti cintetvā

translated: and he asks: “How long is your life?” Anussavāti means: if you have heard anyone say,

analyzed: mātā pitūnam vā vuḍḍhānam mahallakānam santikā āgamaḥ atthi atha me tatas anussavā  vuḍḍhataḥ āgamā vai etam a vikampamānāḥ akkhātha na cantarāti amhākam vassa sahassam
translated: or if you have received information from your parents who are old and aged, then from that tradition🔽or from the information of the elders, you may tell me without hesitation. Na cantarāti means: our life-span is one thousand years,

analyzed: āyu antarā ca no pāpakaḥ jīvita antarāya karo rogo pi natthi a vīta rāgā ati aññamaññam

analyzed: tam sutvā rājā ime hi nāma tiracchāna gatāḥ hutvā eka rattim vippayogena satta vassa satāni

translated: “Oh, we have done a bad thing!” and he turned back and went to Bārāṇasī.🔽“What did you see, Great King?”

analyzed: acchariyam diṭṭhanti amaccehi puṭṭho sabbam ārocetvā tatas paṭṭhāya dānāni dadantaḥ
translated: “Ah, what a fool I have been!” and he turned back and went to Benares. When the ministers asked him, “What marvelous things did you see in the Himalayas, great king?” he told them all that had happened. From that time forth he gave gifts and

analyzed: bhoge tam attham pakāsentaḥ satthā  idam ca sutvāna amānusānam bhallātiyaḥ ittaram

translated: “Hearing this from the spirits, Bhallatīya turned back and went not hunting. He gave gifts and enjoyed his wealth.”

translated: Let not your own fault burn you, as it did the king of the Kimpurushas.”

translated: Therein, “Bhante, I listen with great respect” means: I listen with a mind of great respect to the Dhamma teaching that you have expounded with various reasons. “Words” means

analyzed: tumhehi vuttam vividha vacanam muñcam giram nudasā iva me kaṇṇa sukham madhuram

analyzed: giram muñcantaḥ mama hadaye sokada ratham nudasiyā iva harasiyā iva samaṇa sukha āvaha jīva
translated: As you speak, you remove the dart of sorrow from my heart, you take it away. O ascetic, bringer of happiness,

translated: live long. O Lord Buddha, ascetic, bringer of happiness, both divine and human, both in this world and in the world beyond, my lord, king of the Law, live long.”

analyzed: kosala rājā tatas paṭṭhāya tāya saddhim samagga vāsam vasi
translated: From that time on the king of Kosala lived in peace and harmony with her.

analyzed: satthā imam dhamma desanam āharitvā jātakam samodhānesi tadā kinnaraḥ kosala rājā ahosi kinnarī mallikā devī bhallātiya rājā aham eva ahosinti
translated: When the Teacher had related this story, he identified the Birth: “At that time the Kinnara was the king of Kosala, the Kinnarī was Queen Mallikā, and I myself was King Bhallāṭa.”

original: Bhallātiyajātakavaṇṇanā aṭṭhamā.
analyzed: bhallātiya jātaka vaṇṇanā aṭṭhamā
translated: The Jātaka of Bhallāṭa.

original: [505] 9. Somanassajātakavaṇṇanā

translated: The Jātaka of Somanassa

analyzed: kaḥ tam hiṃsati heṭheti iti idam satthā jetavane viharantaḥ devadattassa vadhāya parisakkanam
translated: Who is it that injures you, that harms you? The Teacher told this story while dwelling at Jetavana, about Devadatta’s attempt to kill him.🔽“Monks, this is not the first time he has tried to kill me; he did the same thing in a previous state of existence.”

original: ārabbha kathesi. Tadā hi satthā “na, bhikkhave, idāneva, pubbepesa mama vadhāya parisakkiyevā”ti vatvā atītaṃ āhari.

analyzed: cārikam carantaḥ uttarapañcāla nagaram patvā rāja uyyāne vasitvā sa parisaḥ piṇḍāya carantaḥ

analyzed: tehi saddhim uyyānam gantvā vasanaṭṭhānāni kāretvā pabbajita parikkhāre datvā vanditvā

original: Ko nīdhāti ko nu idha mama aparādho, yena maṃ tvaṃ māresīti pucchi.
analyzed: kaḥ kaḥ nu mama aparādhaḥ yena mama tvam māresi iti pucchi
translated: “What is the reason? What is my fault, that you should call me ‘householder’? ”

original: Rājā “bhavaggaṃ atinīcaṃ, tava doso atimahanto”ti tassa dosaṃ kathento gāthamāha –
analyzed: rājā bhavaggam ati nīcam tava doso ati mahanto ti tassa dosam kathentaḥ gātham āha
translated: The king, saying, “You have transgressed the highest state; your fault is very great,” spoke this verse to him, telling him of his fault:

original: “Sāyañca pāto udakaṃ sajāti, aggiṃ sadā pāricaratappamatto;
analyzed: sāyam ca pāto udakam sajāti aggim sadā pāricara tappa mattaḥ
translated: “You rise early and prepare the water, you always tend the fire with careful attention;

original: Taṃ tādisaṃ saṃyataṃ brahmacāriṃ, kasmā tuvaṃ brūsi gahappatī”ti.
analyzed: tam tādisam saṃyatam brahmacārim kasmai tuvam brūsi gahappati iti
translated: Why do you call that one, so self-controlled and chaste, a ‘householder,’ my lord?”

original: Tattha udakaṃ sajātīti udakorohaṇakammaṃ karoti. Taṃ tādisanti taṃ tathārūpaṃ mama sāmiṃ dibbacakkhutāpasaṃ kasmā tvaṃ gahapativādena samudācarasīti vadati.
analyzed: tattha udakam sajātīti udakorohaṇa kammam karoti tam tādisanti tam tathārūpam mama sāmim dibba cakkhu tāpasam kasmā tvam gahapati vādena samudācarasi iti vadati
translated: Here, “you prepare the water” means you do the work of bathing. “That one” means that one of such a kind. “My lord,” he says, “why do you address my master, the ascetic with the divine eye, as a ‘householder’? ”

original: Tato kumāro “deva, mayhaṃ gahapatiññeva ‘gahapatī’ti vadantassa ko doso”ti vatvā gāthamāha –
analyzed: tatas kumāraḥ deva mayham gahapatiñca iva gahapati iti vadantassa kaḥ doso ti vatvā gātham āha
translated: Then the prince, saying, “Your majesty, what is my fault in calling him ‘householder’ when he is a householder?” spoke this verse:

original: “Tālā ca mūlā ca phalā ca deva, pariggahā vividhā santimassa;
analyzed: tālā ca mūlā ca phalā ca deva pariggahā vividhā
translated: “He has palm trees, roots, and fruits, your majesty, and various kinds of property;

original: Te rakkhati gopayatappamatto, tasmā ahaṃ brūmi gahappatī”ti.
analyzed: te rakkhati gopayata appamatto tasmai aham brūmi gahappati iti
translated: He guards them and tends them with careful attention; therefore I call him a ‘householder.’ ”

original: Tattha mūlāti mūlakādimūlāni. Phalāti nānāvidhāni valliphalāni. Te rakkhati gopayatappamattoti🔽te esa tava kulūpakatāpaso paṇṇikakammaṃ karonto nisīditvā rakkhati, vatiṃ katvā
analyzed: tattha mūlā ati mūlaka ādi mūlāni phalā ati nānāvidhāni valli phalāni te rakkhati gopaya tappamatto ti  te esa tava kulūpaka tāpasaḥ paṇṇika kammam karontaḥ nisīditvā rakkhati vatim katvā
translated: “Here, ‘roots’ means roots of trees and other roots. ‘Fruits’ means various kinds of fruits of vines. He guards and protects them carefully.

original: gopayati appamatto, tena kāraṇena so tava brāhmaṇo gahapati nāma hoti.
analyzed: gopayati appamattaḥ tena kāraṇena saḥ tava brāhmaṇaḥ gahapati nāma hoti
translated: He guards and protects them carefully, sitting down and making a fence of leaves as a forest-dwelling ascetic. For this reason, he is called a householder, a brahmin.

original: Iti naṃ ahampi “gahapatī”ti kathesiṃ. Sace na saddahasi, catūsu dvāresu paṇṇike pucchāpehīti.
analyzed: iti nam aham pi gahapati iti kathesim sace na saddahasi catūsu dvāresu paṇṇike puccha apehi iti
translated: I also called him a householder. If you do not believe me, ask the leaf-sellers at the four gates.”

original: Rājā pucchāpesi. Te “āma, mayaṃ imassa hatthato paṇṇañca phalāphalāni ca kiṇāmā”ti
analyzed: rājā pucchāpesi te āma mayam imassa hatthato paṇṇam ca phalāphalāni ca kiṇāma ati
translated: The king asked them, and they said, “Yes, we buy leaves and fruits from him.”

original: āhaṃsu. Paṇṇavatthumpi upadhārāpetvā paccakkhamakāsi. Paṇṇasālampissa pavisitvā kumārassa
analyzed: āhaṃsu paṇṇa vatthumpi upadhārāpetvā paccakkham akāsi paṇṇasālampissa pavisitvā kumārassa
translated: He had the leaf-seller’s house searched and confirmed the truth. His men entered the prince’s leaf-seller’s house,

original: purisā paṇṇavikkayaladdhaṃ kahāpaṇamāsakabhaṇḍikaṃ nīharitvā rañño dassesuṃ. Rājā
analyzed: purisā paṇṇa vikkaya laddham kahāpaṇa māsaka bhaṇḍikam nīharitvā raññaḥ dassesum rājā
translated: took out the money and valuables he had received from selling leaves, and showed them to the king. The king

original: mahāsattassa niddosabhāvaṃ ñatvā gāthamāha –
analyzed: mahāsattassa niddosa bhāvam ñatvā gātham āha
translated: knew the Great Being was innocent and spoke this verse:

original: “Saccaṃ kho etaṃ vadasi kumāra, pariggahā vividhā santimassa;
analyzed: saccam kho etam vadasi kumāra pariggahāḥ vividhāḥ santimassa
translated: “It is true, Prince, that you say this: there are many kinds of possessions for the rich.

original: Te rakkhati gopayatappamatto, sa brāhmaṇo gahapati tena hotī”ti.
analyzed: te rakkhati gopayata appamattaḥ sa brāhmaṇaḥ gahapati tena hoti iti
translated: He guards and protects them, ever watchful: he is a Brahman, he is a householder.”

original: Tato mahāsatto cintesi “evarūpassa bālassa rañño santike vāsato himavantaṃ pavisitvā
analyzed: tatas mahāsatto cintesi evarūpassa bālassa rañño santike vāsataḥ himavantam pavisitvā
translated: Then the Great Being thought: “It is better for me to enter the Himalayas and go forth into homelessness than to live in the presence of such a foolish king.

original: pabbajituṃ varaṃ, parisamajjheyevassa dosaṃ āvikatvā āpucchitvā ajjeva nikkhamitvā
analyzed: pabbajitum varam dosam āvikatvā āpucchitvā ajja iva nikkhamitvā
translated: I will reveal his fault in the midst of the assembly, ask for his permission, and leave this very day.

original: pabbajissāmī”ti. So parisāya namakkāraṃ katvā gāthamāha –
analyzed: pabbajissāmi iti saḥ parisāya namakkāram katvā gātham āha
translated: After going forth, I will attain omniscience and then return to teach the Dhamma to the king.” He paid homage to the assembly and spoke this verse:

original: “Suṇantu mayhaṃ parisā samāgatā, sanegamā jānapadā ca sabbe;
analyzed: suṇantu mayham parisā samāgatā sa negamāḥ jānapadā ca sabbe
translated: “Let the assembly gathered here, and all the people of the country, listen to me.

original: Bālāyaṃ bālassa vaco nisamma, ahetunā ghātayate maṃ janindo”ti.
analyzed: bālāyam bālassa vacaḥ nisamma ahetunā ghātayate mama janindo ti
translated: This foolish king, hearing the words of this foolish ascetic, will kill me without reason.”

original: Tattha bālāyaṃ bālassāti ayaṃ rājā sayaṃ bālo imassa bālassa kūṭajaṭilassa vacanaṃ sutvā ahetunāva maṃ ghātayateti.
analyzed: tattha bāla ayam bālassa ati ayam rājā sayam bālaḥ imassa bālassa kūṭa jaṭilassa vacanam sutvā ahetunā ava mama ghātayata iti
translated: Here, “this foolish king” means that this king, being himself foolish, will kill me without reason, having heard the words of this foolish ascetic.

original: Evañca pana vatvā pitaraṃ vanditvā attānaṃ pabbajjāya anujānāpento itaraṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: evam ca pana vatvā pitaram vanditvā attānam pabbajjāya anujānāpentaḥ itaram gātham āha
translated: Having spoken thus, he paid homage to his father and asked for his permission to go forth, speaking another verse:

original: “Daḷhasmi mūle visaṭe virūḷhe, dunnikkayo veḷu pasākhajāto;
analyzed: mūle visaṭe virūḍhe dunnikkayaḥ
translated: “Deep-rooted, well-grown, with spreading branches, hard to uproot is the bamboo that has grown;

original: Vandāmi pādāni tava janinda, anujāna maṃ pabbajissāmi devā”ti.
analyzed: vandāmi pādāni tava janinda anujāna mama pabbajissāmi deva ati
translated: I pay homage at your feet, O Lord of the People; allow me, I will go forth.”

original: Tattha visaṭeti visāle mahante jāte. Dunnikkayoti dunnikkaḍḍhiyo.
analyzed: tattha visaṭā iti visāle mahante jāte
translated: Herein, well-grown means grown in a wide place, in a big place. Hard to uproot means hard to pull out.

original: Tato parā rañño ca puttassa ca vacanapaṭivacanagāthā honti –
analyzed: tatas parā rañño ca puttassa ca vacana paṭivacana gāthāḥ honti
translated: From here on are the verses of the king and his son’s reply.

original: “Bhuñjassu bhoge vipule kumāra, sabbañca te issariyaṃ dadāmi;
analyzed: bhuñjassu bhoge vipule kumāra sabbañca te issariyam dadāmi
translated: “Enjoy the vast wealth, Prince; I give you all my sovereignty;

original: Ajjeva tvaṃ kurūnaṃ hohi rājā, mā pabbajī pabbajjā hi dukkhā.
analyzed: ajjā iva tvam kurūnam hohi rājā mā pabbajī pabbajjā hi dukkhā
translated: Today you be king of the Kurus; do not go forth, for the going forth is hard.

original: “Kinnūdha deva tavamatthi bhogā, pubbevahaṃ devaloke ramissaṃ;
analyzed: kin nu udha deva tavam atthi bhogā pubbe vā aham deva loke ramissam
translated: “What have you to do with wealth, O King? I will delight in the deva-world first;

original: Rūpehi saddehi atho rasehi, gandhehi phassehi manoramehi.
analyzed: rūpehi saddehi atho rasehi gandhehi phassehi manoramehi
translated: With forms, sounds, and also tastes, scents, and tangibles that are delightful.

original: “Bhuttā ca me bhogā tidivasmiṃ deva, parivārito accharānaṃ gaṇena;
analyzed: bhuttā ca me bhogā tidivasmin deva parivāritaḥ accharānam gaṇena
translated: “And I have enjoyed wealth for three days, O King, surrounded by a throng of celestial nymphs;

original: Tuvañca bālaṃ paraneyyaṃ viditvā, na tādise rājakule vaseyyaṃ.
analyzed: tuvam ca bālam paraneyyam viditvā na tādise rāja kule vaseyyam
translated: And knowing that you are a fool to be led by others, I would not live in a royal family like yours.

original: “Sacāhaṃ bālo paraneyyo asmi, ekāparādhaṃ khama putta mayhaṃ;
analyzed: sacā aham bālaḥ para neyyaḥ asmi eka aparādham khama putta mayham
translated: “If I am a fool to be led by others, forgive me this one offence, my son;

original: Punapi ce edisakaṃ bhaveyya, yathāmatiṃ somanassa karohī”ti.
analyzed: puna api ce edisakam bhaveyya yathāmatim somanassa karohi iti
translated: If you should ever be like this again, then do as you wish, and be happy.”

original: Tattha dukkhāti tāta, pabbajjā nāma parapaṭibaddhajīvikattā dukkhā, mā pabbaji, rājā🔽hohīti taṃ yāci. Kinnūdha devāti deva, ye tava bhogā, tesu kiṃ nāma bhuñjitabbaṃ🔽atthi. Parivāritoti paricārito, ayameva vā pāṭho. Tassa kira jātissarañāṇaṃ uppajji,🔽tasmā evamāha. Paraneyyanti andhaṃ viya yaṭṭhiyā parena netabbaṃ. original: “Anisamma kataṃ kammaṃ, anavatthāya cintitaṃ;
analyzed: a nisamma katam kammam anavatthāya cintitam
translated: “A legal procedure that’s illegitimate, that’s badly done,

original: Bhesajjasseva vebhaṅgo, vipāko hoti pāpako.
analyzed: bhesajjassa iva vebhaṅgaḥ vipākaḥ hoti pāpakaḥ
translated: The result is the destruction of medicine.

original: “Nisamma ca kataṃ kammaṃ, sammāvatthāya cintitaṃ;
analyzed: nisamma ca katam kammam sammāvatthāya cintitam
translated: “A legal procedure that’s legitimate, that’s well done,

original: Bhesajjasseva sampatti, vipāko hoti bhadrako.
analyzed: bhesajjassa iva sampatti vipākaḥ hoti bhadrakaḥ
translated: The result is the acquisition of medicine.

original: “Alaso gihī kāmabhogī na sādhu, asaññato pabbajito na sādhu;
analyzed: alasaḥ gihī kāma bhogī na sādhu asaññataḥ pabbajitaḥ na sādhu
translated: “It’s not good for a householder to enjoy sensual pleasures, it’s not good for a monastic to be unrestrained,

original: Rājā na sādhu anisammakārī, yo paṇḍito kodhano taṃ na sādhu.
analyzed: rājā na sādhu a nisamma kārī yaḥ paṇḍito kodhano tam na sādhu
translated: It’s not good for a king to be unmindful, it’s not good for a wise person to be angry.

original: “Nisamma khattiyo kayirā, nānisamma disampati;
analyzed: nisamma khattiyaḥ kayirā na anisamma disampati
translated: “A noble should act mindfully, not unmindfully.

original: Nisammakārino rāja, yaso kitti ca vaḍḍhati.
analyzed: nisamma kārino rāja yaso kitti ca vaḍḍhati
translated: For one who acts mindfully, the king’s glory and fame increase.

original: “Nisamma daṇḍaṃ paṇayeyya issaro, vegā kataṃ tappati bhūmipāla;
analyzed: nisamma daṇḍam paṇayeyya issaraḥ vegā katam tappati bhūmipāla
translated: “The lord should mete out punishment mindfully, for one who acts in haste regrets it later, O king.

original: Sammāpaṇīdhī ca narassa atthā, anānutappā te bhavanti pacchā.
analyzed: ca narassa atthā anānutappā te bhavanti pacchā
translated: For one who acts mindfully, his aims are not regretted later.

original: “Anānutappāni hi ye karonti, vibhajja kammāyatanāni loke;
analyzed: anānutappāni hi ye karonti vibhajja kamma āyatanāni loke
translated: “For those who act without regret, having analyzed the fields of action in the world,

original: Viññuppasatthāni sukhudrayāni, bhavanti buddhānumatāni tāni.
analyzed: viññuppasatthāni su khudrayāni bhavanti buddha anumatāni tāni
translated: Those aims are approved by the wise and are fruitful, and they are approved by the Buddha.

original: “Āgacchuṃ dovārikā khaggabandhā, kāsāviyā hantu mamaṃ janinda;
analyzed: āgacchum dovārikā khaggabandhā kāsāviyā hantu janinda
translated: “The door-keepers with swords came, sire, to kill me, the yellow-robed one;

original: Mātuñca aṅkasmimahaṃ nisinno, ākaḍḍhito sahasā tehi deva.
analyzed: mātuḥ ca aṅkasmin aham nisinnaḥ ākaḍḍhitaḥ sahasā tehi deva
translated: I was sitting on my mother’s lap, and suddenly I was dragged away by them, sire.”

original: “Kaṭukañhi sambādhaṃ sukicchaṃ patto, madhurampi yaṃ jīvitaṃ laddha rāja;
analyzed: kaṭukam hi sambādham su kiccham pattaḥ madhuram pi yam jīvitam rāja
translated: “For bitter is the narrow way, and hard to tread, O King, is the life that is sweet;

original: Kicchenahaṃ ajja vadhā pamutto, pabbajjamevābhimanohamasmī”ti.🔽Tattha anisammāti anoloketvā anupadhāretvā. Anavatthāya cintitanti anavatthapetvā
analyzed: kicchena aham ajja vadhā pamuttaḥ pabbajjam eva abhimanaḥ ham asmi iti  tattha anisammā iti an oloketvā an upadhāretvā anavatthāya cintitanti an avatthapetvā
translated: Today I have escaped from death with difficulty, and I am resolved on going forth.”

original: atuletvā atīretvā cintitaṃ. Vipāko hoti pāpakoti tassa hi yathā nāma bhesajjassa🔽vebhaṅgo vipatti, evamevaṃ vipāko hoti pāpako. Asaññatoti kāyādīhi asaññato dussīlo.🔽Taṃ na sādhūti taṃ tassa kodhanaṃ na sādhu. Nānisammāti anisāmetvā kiñci kammaṃ na
analyzed: a tuletvā a tīretvā cintitam vipākaḥ hoti pāpakaḥ ti tassa hi yathā nāma bhesajjassa  vebhaṅgaḥ vipatti evam evam vipākaḥ hoti pāpakaḥ asaññato ti kāya ādīhi asaññataḥ dussīlaḥ  tam na sādhu iti tam tassa kodhanam na sādhu a nisāmetvā kiñci kammam na
translated: Herein, without reflection is without looking, without consideration. Without determining is without determining, without measuring, without judging. The outcome is evil is as follows. Just as the breaking up of a certain medicine is a misfortune,

original: kareyya. Paṇayeyyāti paṭṭhapeyya pavatteyya. Vegāti vegena sahasā. Sammāpaṇīdhī cāti
analyzed: kareyya paṇayeyya ati paṭṭhapeyya pavatteyya vega ati vegena sahasā sammāpaṇīdhī ca ati
translated: so too the outcome of that is evil. Unrestrained is unbridled, unvirtuous. That is not good is that anger of his is not good. Without reflection is without reflection. He should not do any deed is what is meant. He should restrain is should establish, should instigate. With speed is with speed, suddenly. With right reflection is

original: yoniso ṭhapitena cittena katā narassa atthā pacchā anānutappā bhavantīti attho. Vibhajjāti
analyzed: yonisaḥ ṭhapitena cittena katāḥ narassa atthā pacchā anānutappāḥ bhavanti iti atthaḥ vibhajjāti
translated: with a mind well-directed, a man’s aims are not regretted later on. Vibhajjāti

original: “imāni kātuṃ yuttāni, imāni ayuttānī”ti evaṃ paññāya vibhajitvā. Kammāyatanānīti
analyzed: imāni kātum yuttāni imāni ayuttāni iti evam paññāya vibhajitvā kamma āyatanāni iti
translated: “These are suitable to do, these are not suitable to do,” thus having divided them by means of wisdom. Kammāyatanānīti🔽are actions. Buddhānumatānīti

original: kammāni. Buddhānumatānīti paṇḍitehi anumatāni anavajjāni honti. Kaṭukanti deva, kaṭukaṃ
analyzed: kammāni buddha anumatāni iti paṇḍitehi anumatāni anavajjāni honti kaṭukam ti deva kaṭukam
translated: are approved by the wise, they are blameless. Kaṭukanti deva, kaṭukaṃ🔽is difficult, it is hard to do, I have come to fear death. Laddhāti

original: sambādhaṃ sukicchaṃ maraṇabhayaṃ pattomhi. Laddhāti attano ñāṇabalena labhitvā. Pabbajjamevābhimanohamasmīti
analyzed: sambādham sukiccham maraṇa bhayam pattaḥ amhi laddhā ati attanaḥ ñāṇa balena labhitvā pabbajjam eva abhimanoham asmi iti
translated: having obtained by means of his own knowledge and strength. Pabbajjamevābhimanohamasmīti

original: pabbajjābhimukhacittoyevasmi.
analyzed: pabbajja abhimukha cittaḥ yā iva asmi
translated: I am one whose mind is turned towards the going forth.

original: Evaṃ mahāsattena dhamme desite rājā deviṃ āmantetvā gāthamāha –
analyzed: evam mahāsattena dhamme desite rājā devim āmantetvā gātham āha

original: ñatvā nāgabhavanā nikkhamitvā vammikasantikaṃ gantvā mahāsattassa gahitaṭṭhānañca
analyzed: ñatvā nāga bhavanā nikkhamitvā vammika santikam gantvā mahāsattassa gahita ṭṭhānañca
translated: ” She left the abode of the Nāgas, went to the ant-hill, and saw the place where the Great Being had been caught,🔽and the place where he had been bound.

original: kilamitaṭṭhānañca disvā roditvā kanditvā paccantagāmaṃ gantvā pucchitvā taṃ pavattiṃ
analyzed: kilamita ṭṭhānañca disvā roditvā kanditvā paccanta gāmam gantvā pucchitvā tam pavattim
translated: and seeing the place where he had been tired out, she wept and wailed, and went to the village beyond the frontier, and asked about it.

original: sutvā bārāṇasiṃ gantvā rājaṅgaṇe parisamajjhe ākāse rodamānā aṭṭhāsi. Mahāsatto naccantova
analyzed: sutvā bārāṇasim gantvā rājaṅgaṇe parisamajjhe ākāse rodamānā aṭṭhāsi mahā sattaḥ naccantaḥ uva
translated: Hearing what had happened, she went to Bārāṇasī, and stood in the royal court, weeping in the air in the midst of the assembly. The Great Being, dancing as before,

original: ākāsaṃ oloketvā taṃ disvā lajjito peḷaṃ pavisitvā nipajji. Rājā tassa peḷaṃ paviṭṭhakāle
analyzed: ākāsam oloketvā tam disvā lajjitaḥ peḷam pavisitvā nipajji rājā tassa peḷam paviṭṭha kāle
translated: looked up into the air, and seeing her, ashamed, he entered his house and lay down. When the king saw him enter his house,

original: “kiṃ nu kho kāraṇa”nti ito cito ca olokento taṃ ākāse ṭhitaṃ disvā paṭhamaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: kim nu kho itas citas ca olokentaḥ tam ākāse ṭhitam disvā paṭhamam gātham āha
translated: he looked here and there, thinking, “What is the reason?” and seeing her standing in the air, he spoke the first stanza:

original: “Kā nu vijjurivābhāsi, osadhī viya tārakā;
analyzed: kā nu vijjuḥ iva ābhāsi osadhī tārakā
translated: “Who is she that shines like lightning, like a star, like a herb?

original: Devatā nusi gandhabbī, na taṃ maññāmī mānusi”nti.
analyzed: devatā nusi gandhabbī na tam maññāmi mā anusinti
translated: Is she a goddess or a gandhabbī? I do not think she is a human.”

original: Tattha na taṃ maññāmi mānusinti ahaṃ taṃ mānusīti na maññāmi, tayā ekāya devatāya gandhabbiyā vā bhavituṃ vaṭṭatīti vadati.
analyzed: tattha na tam maññāmi mānusin ti aham tam mānusī iti na maññāmi tayā ekāya devatāya gandhabbiyā vā bhavitum vaṭṭati iti vadati
translated: Herein, I do not think she is a human means I do not think she is a human; it is proper for her to be a goddess or a gandhabbī.

original: Idāni tesaṃ vacanapaṭivacanagāthā honti –
analyzed: idāni tesam vacana paṭivacana gāthāḥ honti
translated: Now there are stanzas of their conversation and reply:

original: “Namhi devī na gandhabbī, na mahārāja mānusī;
analyzed: devī na gandhabbī na mahā rāja mānusī
translated: “I am not a goddess, nor a gandhabbī, nor, O great king, a human;

original: Nāgakaññāsmi bhaddante, atthenamhi idhāgatā.
analyzed: nāga kaññā asmi bhaddante atthenamhi idha āgatā
translated: I am a Naga-maiden, Blessed One, I have come here for a reason.

original: “Vibbhantacittā kupitindriyāsi, nettehi te vārigaṇā savanti;
analyzed: vibbhanta cittā kupita indriyā asi na ittehi te vāri gaṇā savanti
translated: Your eyes are troubled, your senses are disturbed, and from your eyes a stream of tears flows.

original: Kiṃ te naṭṭhaṃ kiṃ pana patthayānā, idhāgatā nāri tadiṅgha brūhi.
analyzed: kim te naṭṭham kim pana patthayānā idha āgatā nāri tat iṅgha brūhi
translated: What have you lost? What are you seeking? Why have you come here? Tell me, woman.

original: “Yamuggatejo uragoti cāhu, nāgoti naṃ āhu janā janinda;
analyzed: uragā iti ca āhu nāgā iti nam āhu janāḥ janinda
translated: People call him “the one with the splendor of a twin,” “the one with the chest of a bull,” “the one with the gait of an elephant,” “the one with the strength of a Naga.”

original: Tamaggahī puriso jīvikattho, taṃ bandhanā muñca patī mameso.
analyzed: tam aggahī purisaḥ jīvi katthaḥ tam bandhanā muñca patī mama iso
translated: A man caught him for the sake of his livelihood. He is my husband. Release him from his bonds.

original: “Kathaṃ nvayaṃ balaviriyūpapanno, hatthattamāgacchi vanibbakassa;
analyzed: katham nu ayam bala viriya upapannaḥ hatthattam āgacchi vanibbakassa
translated: How did he, who is endowed with strength and energy, come to be caught by a hunter?

original: Akkhāhi me nāgakaññe tamatthaṃ, kathaṃ vijānemu gahītanāgaṃ.
analyzed: akkhāhi me nāga kaññe tam attham katham vijānemu gahīta nāgam
translated: Tell me, Naga-maiden, the reason for this. How can we know that the Naga has been caught?

original: “Nagarampi nāgo bhasmaṃ kareyya, tathā hi so balaviriyūpapanno;
analyzed: nagaram pi nāgaḥ bhasmam kareyya tathā hi saḥ bala viriya upapannaḥ
translated: The Naga could reduce a city to ashes, for he is endowed with strength and energy.

original: Dhammañca nāgo apacāyamāno, tasmā parakkamma tapo karotī”ti.
analyzed: dhammañca nāgaḥ apacāyamānaḥ tasmai parakkamma tapaḥ karoti iti
translated: But the Naga, out of respect for the Dhamma, is exerting himself in austerities.

original: Tattha atthenamhīti ahaṃ ekaṃ kāraṇaṃ paṭicca idhāgatā. Kupitindriyāti kilantindriyā.
analyzed: tattha aham ekam kāraṇam paṭicca idha āgatā kupit indriyā ati kilanta indriyā
translated: Herein, I have come here for a reason means I have come here for a reason. Your senses are disturbed means your senses are exhausted.

original: Vārigaṇāti assubindughaṭā. Uragoti cāhūti uragoti cāyaṃ mahājano kathesi. Tamaggahī
analyzed: vārigaṇā ati uragā iti ca ayam mahājanaḥ kathesi
translated: “A herd of elephants” means a herd of elephants. “The people call it” means the people call it “the elephant’s path.” “He caught”

original: purisoti ayaṃ puriso taṃ nāgarājānaṃ jīvikatthāya aggahesi. Vanibbakassāti imassa
analyzed: purisaḥ ti ayam purisaḥ tam nāga rājānam jīvika tthāya aggahesi vanibbakassa ati imassa
translated: means this man caught that king of elephants for the sake of his livelihood. “The merchant” means

original: vanibbakassa kathaṃ nu esa mahānubhāvo samāno hatthattaṃ āgatoti pucchati. Dhammañcāti
analyzed: vanibbakassa katham nu esa mahā anubhāvaḥ samānaḥ hatthattam āgataḥ iti pucchati dhammam ca ati
translated: this merchant asks, “How did this one of great power come to be in the hands of another?” “The Dhamma”

original: pañcasīladhammaṃ uposathavāsadhammañca garuṃ karonto viharati, tasmā iminā purisena
analyzed: pañca sīla dhammam uposatha vāsa dhammañca garum karontaḥ viharati tasmai iminā purisena
translated: means he lives honoring the Dhamma of the five precepts and the Dhamma of the observance day. Therefore, even though he was caught by this man,

original: gahitopi “sacāhaṃ imassa upari nāsavātaṃ vissajjessāmi, bhasmamuṭṭhi viya vikirissati,
analyzed: gahitaḥ api sacā aham imassa upari nāsa vātam vissajjessāmi bhasma muṭṭhi viya vikirissati
translated: thinking, “If I let out a breath on him, he will scatter like a handful of ashes,

original: evaṃ me sīlaṃ bhijjissatī”ti sīlabhedabhayā parakkamma taṃ dukkhaṃ adhivāsetvā tapo
analyzed: evam me sīlam bhijjissati iti sīla bheda bhayā parakkamma tam dukkham adhivāsetvā tapaḥ
translated: and my virtue will be broken,” out of fear of breaking his virtue he persevered and endured that suffering,

original: karoti, vīriyameva karotīti āha.
analyzed: karoti vīriyam eva karoti iti āha
translated: and he practiced austerities, and he did only what was energetic.

original: Rājā “kahaṃ paneso iminā gahito”ti pucchi. Athassa sā ācikkhantī gāthamāha –
analyzed: rājā kaham pana esaḥ iminā gahitaḥ iti pucchi athassa sā ācikkhantī gātham āha
translated: The king asked, “But where was he caught by this man?” Then she, explaining, spoke this verse:

original: “Cātuddasiṃ pañcadasiñca rāja, catuppathe sammati nāgarājā;
analyzed: cātuddasim pañcadasiñca rāja catuppathe sammati nāga rājā
translated: “On the fourteenth and fifteenth days, king, at the crossroads the king of elephants was seen;

original: Tamaggahī puriso jīvikattho, taṃ bandhanā muñca patī mameso”ti.
analyzed: tam aggahī purisaḥ jīvi katthaḥ tam bandhanā muñca patī mama iso ti
translated: The man who caught him, for the sake of life, let him go free from bonds, he is my husband.”

original: Tattha catuppatheti catukkamaggassa āsannaṭṭhāne ekasmiṃ vammike caturaṅgasamannāgataṃ
analyzed: tattha catuppatha iti catukka maggassa āsanna ṭhāne ekasmin vammike caturaṅga samannāgatam
translated: Herein, at the crossroads: in a certain anthill near a four-road-crossing.

original: adhiṭṭhānaṃ adhiṭṭhahitvā uposathavāsaṃ vasanto nipajjatīti attho. Taṃ bandhanāti🔽taṃ evaṃ dhammikaṃ guṇavantaṃ nāgarājānaṃ etassa dhanaṃ datvā peḷabandhanā pamuñca.
analyzed: adhiṭṭhānam adhiṭṭhahitvā uposatha vāsam vasantaḥ nipajjati iti tam bandhanā ti  tam evam dhammikam guṇavantam nāga rājānam etassa dhanam da tvā peḷa bandhanā pamuñca
translated: He lies down, is the meaning. Let him go free from bonds: having given him a reward, let him go free from the bonds of the basket.

original: Evañca pana vatvā punapi taṃ yācantī dve gāthā abhāsi –
analyzed: evañca pana vatvā punar api tam yācantī dve gāthāḥ abhāsi
translated: After saying this, she asked him again in two more stanzas:

original: “Soḷasitthisahassāni, āmuttamaṇikuṇḍalā;
analyzed: soḷa sitthi sahassāni āmutta maṇi kuṇḍalā
translated: “Sixteen thousand women, with their earrings of finest gems,

original: Vārigehasayā nārī, tāpi taṃ saraṇaṃ gatā.
analyzed: vāri geha sayā nārī tā api tam saraṇam gatā
translated: And the women of the water-palace have gone for refuge to you.

original: “Dhammena mocehi asāhasena, gāmena nikkhena gavaṃ satena;
analyzed: dhammena mocehi asāhasena gāmena nikkhena gavam satena
translated: “Set him free by right, not by violence, for a village, for a house, for a hundred head of cattle;

original: Ossaṭṭhakāyo urago carātu, puññatthiko muñcatu bandhanasmā”ti.
analyzed: ossaṭṭha kāyaḥ uragaḥ carātu puññatthikaḥ muñcatu bandhanasma ati
translated: Let the snake go about with his body restored, let him go free from bonds for the sake of merit.”

original: Tattha soḷasitthisahassānīti mā tvaṃ esa yo vā so vā daliddanāgoti maññittha. Etassa
analyzed: tattha soḷasitthi sahassāni iti mā tvam esa yaḥ vā saḥ vā dalidda nāgaḥ ti maññittha etassa
translated: Herein, sixteen thousand women: do not think that he is poor or needy. This

original: hi ettakā sabbālaṅkārapaṭimaṇḍitā itthiyova, sesā sampatti aparimāṇāti dasseti. Vārigehasayāti
analyzed: hi ettakā sabba alaṅkāra paṭimaṇḍitā itthiyā uva sesā sampatti aparimāṇā ti dasseti vāri geha sayā ti
translated: for thus he shows that there are just so many women adorned with all the ornaments, but that the rest of the fortune is immeasurable. In the words Vārigehasaya ,

original: udakacchadanaṃ udakagabbhaṃ katvā tattha sayanasīlā. Ossaṭṭhakāyoti nissaṭṭhakāyo
analyzed: udaka chadanam udaka gabbham katvā tattha sayana sīlā ossaṭṭha kāyo ti nissaṭṭha kāyo
translated: the word vāri means water; thus, making a water-bed, a water-chamber, she is in the habit of lying there. In the words Ossaṭṭhakāyo ,🔽the word ossaṭṭha means cast off, discarded. In the words Carātu ,

original: hutvā. Carātūti caratu.
analyzed: hutvā carātu uti caratu
translated: the word caratu means let him go.

original: Atha naṃ rājā tisso gāthā abhāsi –
analyzed: atha nam rājā tissaḥ gāthāḥ abhāsi
translated: Then the king spoke three stanzas:

original: “Dhammena mocemi asāhasena, gāmena nikkhena gavaṃ satena;
analyzed: dhammena mocemi asāhasena gāmena nikkhena gavam satena
translated: “I set him free by the Dhamma, not by violence, for a village, for a hundred head of cattle;

original: Ossaṭṭhakāyo urago carātu, puññatthiko muñcatu bandhanasmā.
analyzed: ossaṭṭha kāyaḥ uragaḥ carātu puññatthikaḥ muñcatu bandhanasmā
translated: Let the snake go, his body cast off, let him go from bondage for the sake of merit.”

original: “Dammi nikkhasataṃ ludda, thūlañca maṇikuṇḍalaṃ;
analyzed: dammi nikkhasatam ludda thūlam ca maṇi kuṇḍalam
translated: “I give a hundred head of cattle, a thick gem earring,

original: Catussadañca pallaṅkaṃ, umāpupphasarinnibhaṃ.
analyzed: catur sadam ca pallaṅkam umā puppha sarit nibham
translated: and a four-legged couch, like a bed of umā flowers.

original: “Dve ca sādisiyo bhariyā, usabhañca gavaṃ sataṃ;
analyzed: dve ca bhariyāḥ usabham ca gavam satam
translated: “And two wives to match, and a bull and a hundred head of cattle;

original: Ossaṭṭhakāyo urago carātu, puññatthiko muñcatu bandhanasmā”ti.
analyzed: ossaṭṭha kāyaḥ uragaḥ carātu puññatthikaḥ muñcatu bandhanasma ati
translated: Let the snake go, his body cast off, let him go from bondage for the sake of merit.”

original: Tattha luddāti rājā uragaṃ mocetuṃ ahituṇḍikaṃ āmantetvā tassa dātabbaṃ deyyadhammaṃ dassento evamāha. Gāthā pana heṭṭhā vuttatthāyeva.
analyzed: tattha luddāti rājā uragam mocetum ahituṇḍikam āmantetvā tassa dātabbam deyya dhammam dassentaḥ evam āha gāthā pana heṭṭhā vutta tthāya eva
translated: Herein, luddā means the snake-charmer; the king, summoning him to set the snake free, said this, showing the gift to be given to him. But the meaning of the stanzas is given below.

original: Atha naṃ luddo āha –
analyzed: atha nam luddaḥ āha
translated: The hunter said:

original: “Vināpi dānā tava vacanaṃ janinda, muñcemu naṃ uragaṃ bandhanasmā;
analyzed: vinā api dānā tava vacanam janinda muñca imu naḥ uragam
translated: “Without a gift, O king, yet through your word, I set him free, the serpent from his bonds.

original: Ossaṭṭhakāyo urago carātu, puññatthiko muñcatu bandhanasmā”ti.
analyzed: ossaṭṭha kāyaḥ uragaḥ carātu puññatthikaḥ muñcatu bandhanasma ati
translated: Let the serpent go, his body freed from bonds, and let him go to do good deeds.”

original: Tattha tava vacananti mahārāja, vināpi dānena tava vacanameva amhākaṃ garu. Muñcemu nanti muñcissāmi etanti vadati.
analyzed: tattha tava vacananti mahā rāja vinā api dānena tava vacanam eva amhākam garu muñcissāmi etanti vadati
translated: Herein, yet through your word means, O king, without a gift, yet through your word alone we esteem you greatly. I set him free means I will set him free.

original: Evañca pana vatvā mahāsattaṃ peḷato nīhari. Nāgarājā nikkhamitvā pupphantaraṃ pavisitvā🔽taṃ attabhāvaṃ vijahitvā māṇavakavaṇṇena alaṅkatasarīro hutvā pathaviṃ bhindanto
analyzed: evañca pana vatvā mahāsattam peḷataḥ nīhari nāga rājā nikkhamitvā pupphantaram pavisitvā  tam atta bhāvam vijahitvā māṇavaka vaṇṇena alaṅkata sarīraḥ hutvā pathavim bhindantaḥ
translated: After saying this, the Great Being took the serpent from the basket. The king of serpents came forth, entered the flower-bed,

original: viya nikkhanto aṭṭhāsi. Sumanā ākāsato otaritvā tassa santike ṭhitā. Nāgarājā añjaliṃ
analyzed: viya nikkhantaḥ aṭṭhāsi sumanāḥ ākāsataḥ otaritvā tassa santike ṭhitā nāga rājā añjaliṃ
translated: and casting off his serpent form, appeared in the guise of a young man, adorned with all the marks of beauty, and stood there as if he had pierced the earth and come forth. Sumanā descended from the sky and stood beside him. The king of serpents, raising his clasped hands in reverent salutation,

original: paggayha rājānaṃ namassamāno aṭṭhāsi. Tamatthaṃ pakāsento satthā dve gāthā abhāsi –
analyzed: paggayha rājānam namassamānaḥ aṭṭhāsi tam attham pakāsentaḥ satthā dve gāthāḥ abhāsi
translated: stood there paying homage to the king. Expounding this matter, the Master pronounced the following Stanza,

original: “Mutto campeyyako nāgo, rājānaṃ etadabravi;
analyzed: muttaḥ campeyyakaḥ nāgaḥ rājānam etat abravi
translated: “The serpent of Campā, set free, thus spake to the king:

original: Namo te kāsirājatthu, namo te kāsivaḍḍhana;
analyzed: namaḥ te kāsirājatthu namaḥ te kāsivaḍḍhana
translated: ‘Homage to thee, O king of Kāsi, homage to thee, O increaser of Kāsi!’

original: Añjaliṃ te paggaṇhāmi, passeyyaṃ me nivesanaṃ.
analyzed: añjalim te paggaṇhāmi passeyyam me nivesanam
translated: I offer you my hands in supplication, that I may see your dwelling-place.

original: “Addhā hi dubbissasametamāhu, yaṃ mānuso vissase amānusamhi;
analyzed: addhā hi dubbissasam etam āhu yam mānusaḥ vissase amānusamhi
translated: “Surely they say that it is hard to trust a human being in a non-human being;

original: Sace ca maṃ yācasi etamatthaṃ, dakkhemu te nāga nivesanānī”ti.
analyzed: sace ca mamam yācasi etam attham dakkhemu te nāga nivesanāni iti
translated: If you ask me for this thing, O Nāga, we will see your dwelling-places.”

original: Tattha passeyyaṃ me nivesananti mama nivesanaṃ campeyyanāgabhavanaṃ ramaṇīyaṃ passitabbayuttakaṃ.
analyzed: tattha passeyyam me nivesanam ti mama nivesanam campeyya nāga bhavanam ramaṇīyam passitabba yuttakam
translated: There, passeyyaṃ me nivesanaṃ means: “I will see your dwelling-place, the delightful abode of the Nāga king Campeyya, which is fit to be seen.”

original: Taṃ te ahaṃ dassetukāmo, taṃ sabalavāhano tvaṃ āgantvā passa, narindāti vadati. Dubbissasanti🔽duvissāsanīyaṃ. Sace cāti sace maṃ yācasi, passeyyāma te nivesanāni, api ca kho pana
analyzed: tam te aham dassetu kāmo tam sa bala vāhanaḥ tvam āgantvā passa narinda iti vadati dubbissasanti  du vissāsanīyam sace ca ati sace mama yācasi passeyyāma te nivesanāni api ca kho pana
translated: I wish to show it to you, therefore, come with your army and see it, O king, is what is said. Dubbissā means

original: taṃ na saddahāmīti vadati.
analyzed: tam na sat dahāmi iti vadati
translated: hard to trust. Sace ca maṃ yācasi means: if you ask me, we will see your dwelling-places, but I do not believe it, is what is said.

original: Atha naṃ saddahāpetuṃ sapathaṃ karonto mahāsatto dve gāthā abhāsi –
analyzed: atha nam saddahāpetum sapatham karontaḥ mahāsattaḥ dve gāthāḥ abhāsi
translated: Then, in order to make him believe, the Great Being made a vow and spoke two verses:

original: “Sacepi vāto girimāvaheyya, cando ca suriyo ca chamā pateyyuṃ;
analyzed: sace ipi vātaḥ girim āvaheyya cando ca suriyo ca chamā pateyyum
translated: “Even if the wind were to carry away the mountain, and the moon and the sun were to fall down to the earth,

original: Sabbā ca najjo paṭisotaṃ vajeyyuṃ, na tvevahaṃ rāja musā bhaṇeyyaṃ.
analyzed: sabbā ca najjo paṭisotam vajeyyum na tu eva aham rāja musā bhaṇeyyam
translated: And all the rivers were to flow backwards, I would not, O king, tell a lie.

original: “Nabhaṃ phaleyya udadhīpi susse, saṃvaṭṭaye bhūtadharā vasundharā;
analyzed: nabham susse bhūta dharā vasundharā
translated: The earth with its mountains might fly away,🔽The moon and sun might fall to the ground,

original: Siluccayo meru samūlamuppate, na tvevahaṃ rāja musā bhaṇeyya”nti.🔽Tattha saṃvaṭṭaye bhūtadharā vasundharāti ayaṃ bhūtadharāti ca vasundharāti ca saṅkhaṃ🔽gatā mahāpathavī kilañjaṃ viya saṃvaṭṭeyya. Samūlamuppateti evaṃ mahāsinerupabbato
analyzed: na tu eva aham rāja musā  tattha bhūtadharā vasundharā ati ayam bhūtadharā ati ca vasundharā ati ca saṅkham  gatā mahā pathavī kilañjam viya saṃvaṭṭeyya sa mūlam uppata iti evam mahā sineru pabbataḥ
translated: But I, O King, would never tell a lie.”🔽Herein, the earth with its mountains might fly away like a piece of wood means that the great earth, which is called “the earth with its mountains” and “the bearer of treasures,” might fly away like a piece of wood.

original: samūlo uṭṭhāya purāṇapaṇṇaṃ viya ākāse pakkhandeyya.
analyzed: sa mūlaḥ uṭṭhāya purāṇa paṇṇam viya ākāse pakkhandeyya
translated: The great Sineru might rise up with its roots means that the great Sineru might rise up with its roots and fly away like an old leaf.

translated: A human being when it comes to non-humans.🔽If you ask me to do this,

translated: and exert energy, and practise austerities, and observe the Uposatha days.

original: Evaṃ vutte rājā āha –
analyzed: evam vutte rājā āha
translated: When this had been said, the king replied:

original: “Tvaṃ lohitakkho vihatantaraṃso, alaṅkato kappitakesamassu;
analyzed: tvam lohitakkhaḥ vihatanta raṃsaḥ alaṅkataḥ kappita kesa massu
translated: “You are red-eyed, with a body all blotched, and your hair and beard are unkempt;

original: Surosito lohitacandanena, gandhabbarājāva disā pabhāsasi.
analyzed: surā usitaḥ lohita candanena gandhabbarājā ava disā pabhāsasi
translated: You are smeared with red sandal-wood paste, and you shine like a king of the Gandhabbas.

original: “Deviddhipattosi mahānubhāvo, sabbehi kāmehi samaṅgibhūto;
analyzed: deviddhipatto asi mahā anubhāvaḥ sabbehi kāmehi samaṅgi bhūtaḥ
translated: “You have divine power and great influence, and you are endowed with all the pleasures of sense;

original: Pucchāmi taṃ nāgarājetamatthaṃ, seyyo ito kena manussaloko”ti.
analyzed: pucchāmi tam nāga rāja itamattham itas kena manussa loko ti
translated: I ask you, O king of the Nāgas, the meaning of this: is the world of men better than this?”

original: Tattha surositoti suvilitto.
analyzed: tattha su rosito ti su vilitto
translated: Herein, smeared with is anointed with.

original: Athassa ācikkhanto nāgarājā āha –
analyzed: athassa ācikkhantaḥ nāga rājā āha
translated: Then the Nāga king, in explaining, said:🔽“O lord of men, nowhere else than in the world of men

original: “Janinda nāññatra manussalokā, suddhīva saṃvijjati saṃyamo vā;
analyzed: janinda na aññatra manussa lokā suddhī iva saṃvijjati saṃyamaḥ vā
translated: is there such purity or self-control.🔽Having obtained a human state of existence,

original: Ahañca laddhāna manussayoniṃ, kāhāmi jātimaraṇassa anta”nti.
analyzed: aham ca manussa yonim jāti maraṇassa antam ti
translated: what can I do to end birth and death?”

original: Tattha suddhī vāti mahārāja, aññatra manussalokā amatamahānibbānasaṅkhātā suddhi
analyzed: tattha suddhī vāti mahā rāja aññatra manussa lokāḥ amata mahānibbāna saṅkhātā suddhi
translated: Herein, purity is the great deathless Nibbāna called “purity” which is apart from the world of men.

original: vā sīlasaṃyamo vā natthi. Antanti manussayoniṃ laddhā jātimaraṇassa antaṃ karissāmīti tapo karomīti.
analyzed: vā sīla saṃyamaḥ vā na atthi antam ti manussa yonim laddhā jāti maraṇassa antam karissāmi iti tapo karomi iti
translated: And there is no end to birth and death except by attaining the human state and making an end of it by means of austerities.

original: Taṃ sutvā rājā āha –
analyzed: tam sutvā rājā āha
translated: On hearing this, the king said:

original: “Addhā have sevitabbā sapaññā, bahussutā ye bahuṭhānacintino;
analyzed: addhā have sevitabbā sa paññā bahu ssutāḥ ye bahu ṭhāna cintino
translated: “Surely the wise should be attended on, the learned who think of many a matter,

original: Nāriyo ca disvāna tuvañca nāga, kāhāmi puññāni anappakānī”ti.
analyzed: nāriyaḥ ca disvāna tuvam ca nāga kāhāmi puññāni anappakāni iti
translated: And having seen the women and thee, too, Nāga, I will make much merit.”

original: Tattha nāriyo cāti imā tava nāgakaññāyo ca tuvañca disvā bahūni puññāni karissāmīti vadati.
analyzed: tattha nāriyaḥ ca ati imā tava nāga kaññāyo ca tuvam ca disvā bahūni puññāni karissāmi iti vadati
translated: Herein, having seen the women and thee, too, means “I will make much merit having seen these your Nāga women and you.”

original: Atha naṃ nāgarājā āha –
analyzed: atha nam nāga rājā āha
translated: Then the Nāga king said:

original: “Addhā have sevitabbā sapaññā, bahussutā ye bahuṭhānacintino;
analyzed: addhā have sevitabbā sa paññā bahu ssutāḥ ye bahu ṭhāna cintino
translated: “Surely the wise should be attended on, the learned who think of many a matter,

original: Nāriyo ca disvāna mamañca rāja, karohi puññāni anappakānī”ti.
analyzed: nāriyaḥ ca disvāna mamañca rāja karohi puññāni anappakāni iti
translated: And having seen the women and me, too, king, make much merit.”

original: Tattha karohīti kareyyāsi, mahārājāti.
analyzed: tattha karohi iti kareyyāsi mahā rāja ati
translated: Herein, make means you should make, great king.

original: Evaṃ vutte uggaseno gantukāmo hutvā “nāgarāja, ciraṃ vasimha, gamissāmā”ti āpucchi. Atha naṃ mahāsatto “tena hi mahārāja, yāvadicchakaṃ dhanaṃ gaṇhāhī”ti dhanaṃ dassento āha –
analyzed: evam vutte uggasenaḥ gantu kāmaḥ hutvā nāga rāja ciram vasimha gamissāma iti āpucchi atha nam mahāsatto tena hi mahā rāja yāvadicchakam dhanam gaṇhāhi iti dhanam dassentaḥ āha
translated: When this had been said, Uggasena, who was desirous of going, said, “King of the Nāgas, we have stayed here a long time; we will go.” Then the Great Being, saying, “Very well, Great King, take as much treasure as you desire,” gave him treasure, and spoke as follows:

original: “Idañca me jātarūpaṃ pahūtaṃ, rāsī suvaṇṇassa ca tālamattā;
analyzed: idam ca me jātarūpam pahūtam rāsī suvaṇṇassa ca tāla mattā
translated: When this had been said, Uggasena, who was desirous of going, said: “King of Nāgas, we have stayed here a long time, we will be going.” Then the Great Being, saying: “Well then, Great King, take as much wealth as you desire,” gave him wealth, saying: “This gold of mine is abundant, and there are heaps of gold the size of a tāla tree;

original: Ito haritvāna suvaṇṇagharāni, karassu rūpiyapākāraṃ karontu.
analyzed: itas suvaṇṇa gharāni karassu rūpiya pākāram karontu
translated: Taking from here, build golden houses, and let them make a silver rampart.

original: “Muttā ca vāhasahassāni pañca, veḷuriyamissāni ito haritvā;
analyzed: muttā ca vāha sahassāni pañca veḷuriya missāni itas haritvā
translated: Five thousand strings of pearls mixed with cat’s eyes, taking from here,

original: Antepure bhūmiyaṃ santharantu, nikkaddamā hehiti nīrajā ca.
analyzed: antepure bhūmiyam santharantu nikkaddamā hehiti nīrajā ca
translated: let them spread on the ground in the inner palace, and let them throw out the water-lilies.

original: “Etādisaṃ āvasa rājaseṭṭha, vimānaseṭṭhaṃ bahu sobhamānaṃ;
analyzed: etādisam āvasa rāja seṭṭha vimāna seṭṭham bahu sobhamānam
translated: Live in such a place, Best of Kings, a best of palaces, with much beauty;

original: Bārāṇasiṃ nagaraṃ iddhaṃ phītaṃ, rajjañca kārehi anomapaññā”ti.
analyzed: bārāṇasim nagaram iddham phītam rajjam ca kārehi
translated: Bārāṇasī, a city with power and prosperity, and rule there, you of incomparable wisdom.”

original: Tattha rāsīti tesu tesu ṭhānesu tālapamāṇā rāsiyo. Suvaṇṇagharānīti suvaṇṇagehāni.
analyzed: tattha rāsi iti tesu tesu ṭhānesu tālapamāṇāḥ rāsiyaḥ suvaṇṇa gharāni iti suvaṇṇa gehāni
translated: Herein, heaps means heaps the size of a tāla tree in various places. Golden houses means golden houses.

original: Nikkaddamāti evaṃ te antepure bhūmi nikkaddamā ca nirajā ca bhavissati. Etādisanti🔽evarūpaṃ suvaṇṇamayaṃ rajatapākāraṃ muttāveḷuriyasanthatabhūmibhāgaṃ. Phītanti phītaṃ
analyzed: nikkaddamā ati evam te antepure bhūmi nikkaddamā ca nirajā ca bhavissati  evarūpam suvaṇṇa mayam rajata pākāram muttā veḷuriya santhata bhūmi bhāgam phītanti phītam
translated: Such as this.🔽“You will dwell in the city of Bārāṇasī.”

original: bārāṇasinagarañca āvasa. Anomapaññāti alāmakapaññā.🔽Rājā tassa kathaṃ sutvā adhivāsesi. Atha mahāsatto nāgabhavane bheriṃ carāpesi “sabbā🔽rājaparisā yāvadicchakaṃ hiraññasuvaṇṇādikaṃ dhanaṃ gaṇhantū”ti. Rañño ca anekehi🔽sakaṭasatehi dhanaṃ pesesi. Rājā mahantena yasena nāgabhavanā nikkhamitvā bārāṇasimeva
analyzed: bārāṇasi nagaram ca āvasa anomapaññā ati alāmakapaññā  rājā tassa katham sutvā adhivāsesi atha mahāsattaḥ nāga bhavane bherim carāpesi sabbā  rāja parisāḥ yāvadicchakam hirañña suvaṇṇa ādikam dhanam gaṇhantu uti raññaḥ ca anekehi  sakaṭa satehi dhanam pesesi rājā mahantena yasena nāga bhavanā nikkhamitvā bārāṇasim eva
translated: “Of incomparable wisdom.”

original: gato. Tato paṭṭhāya kira jambudīpatalaṃ sahiraññaṃ jātaṃ.
analyzed: gataḥ tatas paṭṭhāya kira jambudīpa talam sa hiraññam jātam
translated: The king assented. Then the Great Being caused a drum to be beaten in the Nāga world, and made the following proclamation: “Let all the king’s retinue take as much gold and silver and other wealth as they desire.” And he sent the king many hundreds of carts filled with treasure. The king departed from the Nāga world with great pomp and returned to Bārāṇasī. From that time forth, it is said, the surface of the earth was covered with gold.

original: Satthā imaṃ dhammadesanaṃ āharitvā “evaṃ porāṇakapaṇḍitā nāgasampattiṃ pahāya uposathavāsaṃ
analyzed: satthā imam dhamma desanam āharitvā evam porāṇaka paṇḍitāḥ nāga sampattim pahāya uposatha vāsam
translated: When the Teacher had related this story, he said, “Thus did the wise men of old, renouncing the glory of the Nāgas, observe the Uposatha days.

original: vasiṃsū”ti vatvā jātakaṃ samodhānesi – “tadā ahituṇḍiko devadatto ahosi, sumanā rāhulamātā,
analyzed: vasiṃsu iti vatvā jātakam samodhānesi tadā ahituṇḍikaḥ devadattaḥ ahosi sumanāḥ rāhula mātā
translated: and when they had so done, he related the Jātaka, saying, “At that time Devadatta was the snake-charmer, Sumana was Rāhulamātā,

original: uggaseno sāriputto, campeyyanāgarājā pana ahameva ahosi”nti.
analyzed: uggasenaḥ sāriputto campeyya nāga rājā pana aham eva ahosinti
translated: Uggasena was Sāriputta, and I myself was the king of the snakes.”🔽So saying, he identified the Birth, “At that time Devadatta was the snake-charmer, Sumana was Rāhulamātā,🔽Uggasena was Sāriputta, and I myself was the king of the snakes.”

original: Campeyyajātakavaṇṇanā dasamā.
analyzed: campeyya jātaka vaṇṇanā dasamā
translated: The story of Campeyya is ended.

original: [507] 11. Mahāpalobhanajātakavaṇṇanā
translated: The Great Temptation

analyzed: idam satthā jetavane viharantaḥ visuddha saṃkilesam ārabbha
translated: When the Teacher was in residence at Jetavana, he related this story concerning a certain monk who was defiled by lust.

original: kathesi. Vatthu heṭṭhā vitthāritameva. Idha pana satthā “bhikkhu mātugāmo nāmesa
analyzed: kathesi vatthu heṭṭhā vitthāritam eva idha pana satthā bhikkhu mātugāmaḥ nāma īsa
translated: The story is told in detail below. Here the Teacher said, “Monks, women will defile even a pure-hearted man,

original: visuddhasattepi saṃkiliṭṭhe karotī”ti vatvā atītaṃ āhari.
analyzed: visuddhasatte api saṃkiliṭṭhe karoti iti vatvā atītam āhari
translated: and so they defile a defiled man.” So saying, he related the following story of the past.

original: Atīte bārāṇasiyanti cūḷapalobhane vuttanayeneva atītavatthu vitthāritabbaṃ. Tadā
analyzed: atīte bārāṇasiyanti cūḷa palobhane vutta nayena iva atīta vatthu vitthāritabbam tadā
translated: In the past, at Benares, the story of the past is to be related in detail in the same manner as in the story of the Lesser Temptation.

original: pana mahāsatto brahmalokā cavitvā kāsirañño putto hutvā nibbatti, anitthigandhakumāro
analyzed: pana mahāsattaḥ brahma lokā cavitvā kāsi raññaḥ puttaḥ hutvā nibbatti anitthigandha kumāraḥ
translated: But on that occasion the Great Being, passing from the World of Brahmā, was reborn as the son of the king of Kāsi, and was called Prince Anitthigandha.

original: nāma ahosi. Itthīnaṃ hatthe na saṇṭhāti, purisavesena naṃ thaññaṃ pāyenti, jhānāgāre
analyzed: nāma ahosi itthīnam hatthe na saṇṭhāti purisa vesena nam thaññam pāyenti jhānāgāre
translated: He would not take the breast of a woman, but they gave him milk in a man’s hand. In a chamber of meditation

original: vasati, itthiyo na passati. Tamatthaṃ pakāsento satthā catasso gāthā abhāsi –
analyzed: vasati itthiyaḥ na passati tam attham pakāsentaḥ satthā catassaḥ gāthāḥ abhāsi
translated: and he did not see women. Expounding that situation, the Teacher recited four stanzas:

original: “Brahmalokā cavitvāna, devaputto mahiddhiko;
analyzed: brahma lokā cavitvāna deva puttaḥ mahiddhiko
translated: “Having fallen from the Brahma-world, a deva-son of great power

original: Rañño putto udapādi, sabbakāmasamiddhisu.
analyzed: raññaḥ puttaḥ udapādi sabba kāma samiddhisu
translated: was born as the son of a king, in the midst of all desires.

original: “Kāmā vā kāmasaññā vā, brahmaloke na vijjati;
analyzed: kāmāḥ vā kāma saññā vā brahma loke na vijjati
translated: “Neither desire nor the perception of desire exists in the Brahma-world;

original: Svāssu tāyeva saññāya, kāmehi vijigucchatha.
analyzed: su āssu tāya iva saññāya kāmehi vijigucchatha
translated: but he, with that very perception, was disgusted with desire.

original: “Tassa cantepure āsi, jhānāgāraṃ sumāpitaṃ;
analyzed: tassa cantepure āsi jhānāgāram su māpitam
translated: “In his father’s inner palace, a meditation-room was well built;

original: So tattha paṭisallīno, eko rahasi jhāyatha.
analyzed: saḥ tattha paṭisallīnaḥ ekaḥ rahasi jhāyatha
translated: there he was secluded, alone, meditating in secret.

original: “Sa rājā paridevesi, puttasokena aṭṭito;
analyzed: sa rājā paridevesi putta sokena aṭṭitaḥ
translated: “The king lamented, afflicted with grief for his son:

original: Ekaputto cayaṃ mayhaṃ, na ca kāmāni bhuñjatī”ti.
analyzed: eka putto cayam mayham na ca kāmāni bhuñjati iti
translated: ‘This only son of mine does not enjoy desires.’

original: Tattha sabbakāmasamiddhisūti sabbakāmānaṃ samiddhīsu sampattīsu ṭhitassa rañño putto🔽hutvā eko devaputto nibbatti. Svāssūti so kumāro. Tāyevāti tāya brahmaloke nibbattitāya
analyzed: tattha sabba kāma samiddhisu iti sabba kāmānam samiddhīsu sampattīsu ṭhitassa rañño putto  hutvā ekaḥ deva putto nibbatti svāssu iti saḥ kumāraḥ tāya iva ati tāya brahmaloke nibbattitāya
translated: There, in the midst of all desires, the son of a king was born.

original: jhānasaññāya eva. Sumāpitanti pitarā suṭṭhu manāpaṃ katvā māpitaṃ. Rahasi jhāyathāti
analyzed: jhāna saññāyaḥ eva su māpitanti pitarā suṭṭhu manāpam katvā māpitam rahasi jhāyatha ati
translated: Having fallen from the Brahma-world, a deva-son was reborn. He, with that very perception of meditation that arose in the Brahma-world, was disgusted with desire. Well built: well built by his father, pleasing. Meditating in secret:

original: mātugāmaṃ apassanto vasi. Paridevesīti vilapi.
analyzed: mātugāmam a passantaḥ vasi paridevesi iti vilapi
translated: and he lived without seeing a woman. He lamented, he cried.

original: Pañcamā rañño paridevanagāthā –
analyzed: pañcamā rañño paridevana gāthā
translated: The fifth lament of the King is:

original: “Ko nu khvettha upāyo so, ko vā jānāti kiñcanaṃ;
analyzed: kaḥ nu khu ettha upāyaḥ saḥ kaḥ vā jānāti kiñcanaṃ
translated: “What is the means here, who knows what,

original: Yo me puttaṃ palobheyya, yathā kāmāni patthaye”ti.🔽Tattha ko nu khvettha upāyoti ko nu kho ettha etassa kāmānaṃ bhuñjanaupāyo. “Ko nu🔽kho idhupāyo so”tipi pāṭho, aṭṭhakathāyaṃ pana “ko nu kho etaṃ upavasitvā upalāpanakāraṇaṃ
analyzed: yaḥ me puttam palobheyya yathā kāmāni patthaya iti  tattha kaḥ nu khu ettha upāyaḥ ti kaḥ nu kho ettha etassa kāmānam bhuñjana upāyaḥ kaḥ nu  kho idhupāyo so tipi pāṭho aṭṭhakathā ayam pana kaḥ nu kho etam upavasitvā upalāpana kāraṇam
translated: who will entice my son, so that he may desire sensual pleasures?”

original: jānātī”ti vuttaṃ. Ko vā jānāti kiñcananti ko vā etassa palibodhakāraṇaṃ jānātīti attho.
analyzed: jānāti iti vuttam kaḥ vā jānāti kiñcana nti kaḥ vā etassa palibodha kāraṇam jānāti iti attho
translated: Herein, what is the means here? What is the means for his enjoying sensual pleasures here? “What is the means here, that?” is also a reading. But in the Commentary it is said, “Who knows the reason for his living here and his being enticed?” Who knows what? The meaning is, who knows the reason for his being obstructed?

original: Tato paraṃ diyaḍḍhagāthā abhisambuddhagāthā –
analyzed: tatas param diyaḍḍha gāthā abhisambuddha gāthā
translated: The next two and a half stanzas are the stanzas of the Buddha’s enlightenment:🔽“There was a girl there, too,

original: “Ahu kumārī tattheva, vaṇṇarūpasamāhitā;
analyzed: ahu kumārī tattha iva vaṇṇa rūpa samāhitā
translated: endowed with beauty and complexion,🔽skilled in dancing and singing,

original: Kusalā naccagītassa, vādite ca padakkhiṇā.
analyzed: kusalā nacca gītassa vādite ca padakkhiṇā
translated: and dexterous in playing the instrument.🔽“She approached him there

original: “Sā tattha upasaṅkamma, rājānaṃ etadabravī”ti;
analyzed: sā tattha upasaṅkamma rājānam etat abravīti
translated: and spoke thus to the King.”

original: Tattha ahūti bhikkhave, tattheva antepure cūḷanāṭakānaṃ antare ekā taruṇakumārikā ahosi. Padakkhiṇāti susikkhitā.
analyzed: tattha ahu uti bhikkhave tattha iva antepure cūḷa nāṭakānam antare ekā taruṇa kumārikā ahosi padakkhiṇā ati su sikkhitā
translated: Herein, there was a young girl in the inner palace there, monks, among the junior dancers. She was skilled, she was well-trained.

original: “Ahaṃ kho naṃ palobheyyaṃ, sace bhattā bhavissatī”ti. –
analyzed: aham kho nam palobheyyam sace bhattā bhavissati iti
translated: “I would seduce him, if he were my husband.”

original: Upaḍḍhagāthā kumārikāya vuttā.
analyzed: upaḍḍha gāthā kumārikāya vuttā
translated: This half-verse was spoken by the young girl.

original: Tattha sace bhattāti sace esa mayhaṃ pati bhavissatīti.
analyzed: tattha sace bhattā ati sace esa mayham pati bhavissati iti
translated: Herein, if he were my husband means if this one were to be my husband.

original: “Taṃ tathāvādiniṃ rājā, kumāriṃ etadabravi;
analyzed: tam tathāvādinim rājā kumārim etat abravi
translated: “The King, speaking thus, said this to the girl:

original: Tvaññeva naṃ palobhehi, tava bhattā bhavissatīti.
analyzed: tvaññā eva nam palobhehi tava bhattā bhavissati iti
translated: You yourself seduce him, he will be your husband.”

original: Tattha tava bhattāti tavesa pati bhavissati, tvaññeva tassa aggamahesī bhavissasi, gaccha naṃ palobhehi, kāmarasaṃ jānāpehīti.
analyzed: tattha tava bhattā ati tava isa pati bhavissati tvañc eva tassa agga mahesī bhavissasi gaccha nam palobhehi kāma rasam jānāpehi iti
translated: Herein, he will be your husband means this one will be your husband, you will be his chief queen, go and seduce him, make him know the taste of sensual pleasure.

original: Evaṃ vatvā rājā “imissā kira okāsaṃ karontū”ti kumārassa upaṭṭhākānaṃ pesesi. Sā
analyzed: evam vatvā rājā imissā kira okāsam karontu uti kumārassa upaṭṭhākānam pesesi sā
translated: After saying this the King sent a message to the Prince’s attendants: “Let her have an opportunity.” She

original: paccūsakāle vīṇaṃ ādāya gantvā kumārassa sayanagabbhassa bahi avidūre ṭhatvā agganakhehi
analyzed: paccūsa kāle vīṇam ādāya gantvā kumārassa sayana gabbhassa bahi avidūre ṭhatvā agga nakhehi
translated: at the time of dawn, taking her lute, went and stood not far from the Prince’s sleeping room, and with her best fingers

original: vīṇaṃ vādentī madhurasarena gāyitvā taṃ palobhesi. Tamatthaṃ pakāsento satthā āha –
analyzed: vīṇam vādentī madhura sarena gāyitvā tam palobhesi tam attham pakāsentaḥ satthā āha
translated: and while playing the lute, you tempted him with your sweet voice. Expounding this matter, the Teacher said:

original: “Sā ca antepuraṃ gantvā, bahuṃ kāmupasaṃhitaṃ;
