analyzed: arahattam patto tadā anitthigandha kumāraḥ aham eva
translated: become defiled because of women,” and after telling the Truths, he identified the Birth Story: “At that time the woman was the woman of today, and I myself was the man.”

original: Mahāpalobhanajātakavaṇṇanā ekādasamā.
analyzed: mahāpalobhana jātaka vaṇṇanā ekādasamā
translated: The Commentary on the Great Birth Story of the Enticing of Māra is finished.

original: [508] 12. Pañcapaṇḍitajātakavaṇṇanā
translated: The Commentary on the Birth Story of the Five Wise Men

original: 315-336. Pañcapaṇḍitajātakaṃ mahāumaṅge āvi bhavissati.
analyzed: pañca paṇḍita jātakam mahāumaṅge bhavissati
translated: The Birth Story of the Five Wise Men will be found in the Great Ummagga Jātaka.

original: Pañcapaṇḍitajātakavaṇṇanā dvādasamā.
analyzed: pañca paṇḍita jātaka vaṇṇanā dvādasamā
translated: The Commentary on the Birth Story of the Five Wise Men is finished.

original: [509] 13. Hatthipālajātakavaṇṇanā
translated: The Commentary on the Birth Story of the Elephant’s Foot

original: Cirassaṃ vata passāmāti idaṃ satthā jetavane viharanto mahābhinikkhamanaṃ ārabbha
analyzed: cirassam vata passāma ati idam satthā jetavane viharantaḥ mahābhinikkhamanam ārabbha
translated: “At last we see him!” This story the Master told, while dwelling at Jetavana, concerning the Great Renunciation.

original: kathesi. Tadā hi satthā “na, bhikkhave, idāneva, pubbepi tathāgato mahābhinikkhamanaṃ
analyzed: kathesi tadā hi satthā na bhikkhave idānā iva pubbe pi tathāgataḥ mahā abhinikkhamanam
translated: For at that time the Master said, “Monks, this is not the first time the Tathāgata has gone forth from home into the homeless state;

original: nikkhantoyevā”ti vatvā atītaṃ āhari.🔽Atīte bārāṇasiyaṃ esukārī nāma rājā ahosi. Tassa purohito daharakālato paṭṭhāya piyasahāyo.🔽Te ubhopi aputtakā ahesuṃ. Te ekadivasaṃ sukhasayane nisinnā mantayiṃsu “amhākaṃ
analyzed: vatvā atītam āhari  atīte bārāṇasiyam esukārī nāma rājā ahosi tassa purohitaḥ dahara kālataḥ paṭṭhāya piya sahāyo  te ubhaḥ api a puttakāḥ ahesum te eka divasam sukha sayane nisinnāḥ mantayiṃsu amhākam
translated: in a previous state of existence also he went forth.” And with this he related the story of the past.🔽In the dispensation of the Buddha Kassapa, said he, there were two friends, one a king named Esukārī, the other a priest.

original: issariyaṃ mahantaṃ, putto vā dhītā vā natthi, kiṃ nu kho kattabba”nti. Tato rājā
analyzed: issariyam mahantam puttaḥ vā dhītā vā natthi kim nu kho kattabbanti tatas rājā
translated: Both were childless. One day as they sat together in their palace, they said to one another, “Our power is great, but we have neither son nor daughter.

original: purohitaṃ āha – “samma, sace tava gehe putto jāyissati, mama rajjassa sāmiko bhavissati,
analyzed: purohitam āha samma sace tava gehe puttaḥ jāyissati mama rajjassa sāmikaḥ bhavissati
translated: What shall we do?” The king said to the priest, “My good friend, if a son is born to you, he shall be the lord of my kingdom;

original: sace mama putto jāyissati, tava gehe bhogānaṃ sāmiko bhavissatī”ti. Evaṃ ubhopi aññamaññaṃ saṅkariṃsu.
analyzed: sace mama puttaḥ jāyissati tava gehe bhogānam sāmikaḥ bhavissati iti evam ubhaḥ api aññam aññam saṅkariṃsu
translated: if a son is born to me, he shall be the lord of your wealth.” So saying, they exchanged their children’s portions.

original: Athekadivasaṃ purohito bhogagāmaṃ gantvā āgamanakāle dakkhiṇadvārena nagaraṃ pavisanto
analyzed: atha eka divasam purohitaḥ bhogagāmam gantvā āgamana kāle dakkhiṇa dvārena nagaram pavisantaḥ
translated: One day the chaplain went to the village of Bhogā, and on his return entered the city by the southern gate.

original: bahinagare ekaṃ bahuputtikaṃ nāma duggatitthiṃ passi. Tassā satta puttā sabbeva arogā,
analyzed: bahi nagare ekam bahuputtikam nāma dugga titthim passi tassā satta puttā sabbā iva arogā
translated: Outside the city he saw a certain poor woman named Bahuputtikā, who had seven sons, all of whom were healthy and strong.

original: eko pacanabhājanakapallaṃ gaṇhi, eko sayanakaṭasārakaṃ, eko purato gacchati, eko
analyzed: ekaḥ pacana bhājanaka pallam ekaḥ sayana kaṭasārakam ekaḥ puratas gacchati ekaḥ
translated: One of the boys carried a cooking pot, another a bedstead, another went in front, another

original: pacchato, eko aṅguliṃ gaṇhi, eko aṅke nisinno, eko khandhe. Atha naṃ purohito pucchi
analyzed: pacchatas ekaḥ aṅgulim gaṇhi ekaḥ aṅke nisinnaḥ ekaḥ khandhe atha nam purohitaḥ pucchi
translated: followed behind, another took hold of her finger, another sat on her lap, and another rode on her shoulders. The chaplain asked her,

original: “bhadde, imesaṃ dārakānaṃ pitā kuhi”nti? “Sāmi, imesaṃ pitā nāma nibaddho natthī”ti.
analyzed: bhadde imesam dārakānam pitā kuhinti sāmi imesam pitā nāma nibaddhaḥ natthi iti
translated: “Good woman, where is the father of these children?” “Master, these children have no regular father.”

original: “Evarūpe satta putte kinti katvā alatthā”ti? Sā aññaṃ gahaṇaṃ apassantī nagaradvāre🔽ṭhitaṃ nigrodharukkhaṃ dassetvā “sāmi etasmiṃ nigrodhe adhivatthāya devatāya santike
analyzed: evarūpe satta putte kinti katvā alattha ati sā aññam gahaṇam a passantī nagara dvāre  ṭhitam nigrodha rukkham dassetvā sāmi etasmin nigrodhe adhivatthāya devatāya santike
translated: “How is it that you have so many children?” She, seeing no other way of escape, pointed to a banyan tree🔽standing at the city gate and said, “Master, I obtained these children through the favor of a deity who resides in this banyan tree.”

original: patthetvā labhiṃ, etāya me puttā dinnā”ti āha. Purohito “tena hi gaccha tva”nti rathā
analyzed: patthetvā labhim etāya me puttāḥ dinnāḥ iti āha purohito tena hi gaccha tvanti rathā
translated: “Very well, then, go,” said the chaplain, and he drove on in his chariot.

original: oruyha nigrodhamūlaṃ gantvā sākhāya gahetvā cāletvā “ambho devate, tvaṃ rañño santikā
analyzed: āruyha nigrodha mūlam gantvā sākhāya gahetvā cāletvā ambho devate tvam rañño santikā
translated: and descending, went to the foot of the banyan tree, and taking hold of a branch, shook it, and said, “O goddess, what is it you do not get from the king?

original: kiṃ nāma na labhasi, rājā te anusaṃvaccharaṃ sahassaṃ vissajjetvā balikammaṃ karoti,
analyzed: kim nāma na labhasi rājā te anusaṃvaccharam sahassam vissajjetvā bali kammam karoti
translated: The king gives you a thousand pieces of money every year and makes you offerings.

original: tassa puttaṃ na desi, etāya duggatitthiyā tava ko upakāro kato, yenassā satta putte
analyzed: tassa puttam na desi etāya dugga titthiyā tava kaḥ upakāraḥ kataḥ yena assā satta putte
translated: You do not give him a son. What service has this wretched woman done for you that you should give her seven sons?

original: adāsi. Sace amhākaṃ rañño puttaṃ na desi, ito taṃ sattame divase samūlaṃ chindāpetvā
analyzed: adāsi sace amhākam rañño puttam na desi ito tam sattame divase sa mūlam chindāpetvā
translated: If you do not give my king a son, on the seventh day from this I will have you cut down root and all

original: khaṇḍākhaṇḍikaṃ kāressāmī”ti rukkhadevataṃ tajjetvā pakkāmi. So etena niyāmeneva
analyzed: khaṇḍākhaṇḍikam kāressāmi iti rukkha devatam tat jetvā pakkāmi saḥ etena niyāmena iva
translated: and made into firewood.” With these words he threatened the tree-spirit and departed. In the same way he went on

original: punadivasepīti paṭipāṭiyā cha divase kathesi. Chaṭṭhe pana divase sākhāya gahetvā🔽“rukkhadevate ajjekarattimattakameva sesaṃ, sace me rañño puttaṃ na desi, sve taṃ
analyzed: puna divase pi iti paṭipāṭiyā cha divase kathesi chaṭṭhe pana divase sākhāya gahetvā  rukkha devate ajja eka ratti mattakam eva sesam sace me rañño puttam na desi sve tam
translated: to the next day and the next, and so on, until he had spoken for six days. But on the sixth day he took hold of a branch

original: niṭṭhāpessāmī”ti āha.
analyzed: niṭṭhāpessāmi iti āha
translated: and said, “O tree-spirit, there is only one night left. If you do not give my king a son, tomorrow I will carry out my threat.”

original: Rukkhadevatā āvajjetvā taṃ kāraṇaṃ tathato ñatvā “ayaṃ brāhmaṇo puttaṃ alabhanto
analyzed: rukkha devatā āvajjetvā tam kāraṇam tathatas ñatvā ayam brāhmaṇaḥ puttam a labhanto
translated: The tree-spirit reflected, and realizing the truth of the matter, said to herself, “This brahman will not get a son.

original: mama vimānaṃ nāsessati, kena nu kho upāyena tassa puttaṃ dātuṃ vaṭṭatī”ti catunnaṃ
analyzed: mama vimānam na āsessati kena nu kho upāyena tassa puttam dātum vaṭṭati iti catunnam
translated: “He will destroy my palace. By what means can I get him a son?”

original: mahārājānaṃ santikaṃ gantvā tamatthaṃ ārocesi. Te “mayaṃ tassa puttaṃ dātuṃ na sakkhissāmā”ti
analyzed: mahā rājānam santikam gantvā tam attham ārocesi te mayam tassa puttam dātum na sakkhissāma ati
translated: He went to the four Great Kings and told them the matter. They said, “We are not able to give him a son.”

original: vadiṃsu. Aṭṭhavīsatiyakkhasenāpatīnaṃ santikaṃ agamāsi, tepi tathevāhaṃsu. Sakkassa
analyzed: vadiṃsu aṭṭhavīsati yakkha senāpatīnam santikam agamāsi te pi tathā iva ahaṃsu sakkassa
translated: He went to the twenty-eight Yakkha generals. They also said the same thing. He went to Sakka,

original: devarañño santikaṃ gantvā kathesi. Sopi “labhissati nu kho rājā anucchavike putte,🔽udāhu no”ti upadhārento puññavante cattāro devaputte passi. Te kira purimabhave bārāṇasiyaṃ🔽pesakārā hutvā tena kammena laddhakaṃ pañcakoṭṭhāsaṃ katvā cattāro koṭṭhāse paribhuñjiṃsu.
analyzed: deva rañño santikam gantvā kathesi saḥ api labhissati nu kho rājā anucchavike putte  udāhu no ti upadhārento puññavante cattāraḥ deva putte passi te kira purima bhave bārāṇasiyam  pesakārāḥ hutvā tena kammena laddhakam pañca koṭṭhāsam katvā cattāraḥ koṭṭhāse paribhuñjiṃsu
translated: the king of the gods, and told him the matter. He thought, “Will the king get suitable sons or not?”🔽He saw four very meritorious gods. They had been, it seems, weavers in a previous existence at Bārāṇasī. By that craft they had earned five hundred pieces of money. They divided them into four parts and used three parts for their livelihood.

original: pañcamaṃ gahetvā ekatova dānaṃ adaṃsu. Te tato cutā tāvatiṃsabhavane nibbattiṃsu,
analyzed: pañcamam gahetvā ekatas iva dānam te tatas cutā tāvatiṃsa bhavane nibbattiṃsu
translated: They took the fourth part and gave it as a gift. They died and were reborn in the Tāvatiṃsa heaven.

original: tato yāmabhavaneti evaṃ anulomapaṭilomaṃ chasu devalokesu sampattiṃ anubhavantā vicaranti.
analyzed: tatas yāma bhavana iti evam anuloma paṭilomam chasu deva lokesu sampattim anubhavantāḥ vicaranti
translated: From there they went to the Yāma heaven. Thus they wandered through the six divine worlds, experiencing the bliss of the heavens in the order of succession and in the reverse order.

original: Tadā pana nesaṃ tāvatiṃsabhavanato cavitvā yāmabhavanaṃ gamanavāro hoti. Sakko tesaṃ🔽santikaṃ gantvā pakkositvā “mārisā, tumhehi manussalokaṃ gantuṃ vaṭṭati, esukārīrañño
analyzed: tadā pana nesam tāvatiṃsa bhavanataḥ cavitvā yāma bhavanam gamana vāro hoti sakko tesam  santikam gantvā pakkositvā mārisā tumhehi manussa lokam gantum vaṭṭati esukārī rañño
translated: But at that time the period had arrived for their passing away from the World of the Thirty-three and their rebirth in the World of the Yāma gods. Sakka went to them,

original: aggamahesiyā kucchimhi nibbattathā”ti āha. Te tassa vacanaṃ sutvā “sādhu deva, gamissāma,🔽na panamhākaṃ rājakulenattho, purohitassa gehe nibbattitvā daharakāleyeva kāme pahāya🔽pabbajissāmā”ti vadiṃsu. Sakko “sādhū”ti tesaṃ paṭiññaṃ gahetvā āgantvā rukkhadevatāya
analyzed: aggamahesiyāḥ kucchimhi āha te tassa vacanam sutvā sādhu deva gamissāma  na pana amhākam rāja kulena atthaḥ purohitassa gehe nibbattitvā dahara kāleya iva kāme pahāya  pabbajissāma ati vadiṃsu sakko sādhu iti tesam paṭiññam gahetvā āgantvā rukkha devatāya
translated: summoned them, and said, “Good sirs, it is time for you to go to the human world and be reborn in the womb of the chief queen of King Esukārī.” When they heard his words, they said, “Very well, Lord, we will go.

original: tamatthaṃ ārocesi. Sā tuṭṭhamānasā sakkaṃ vanditvā attano vimānameva gatā.
analyzed: tam attham ārocesi sā tuṭṭha mānasā sakkam vanditvā attanaḥ vimānam eva gatā
translated: But we have no use for a royal family. We will be reborn in the house of the royal chaplain and, as soon as we are old enough, we will renounce the world and go forth from home into homelessness.” Sakka said, “Very well,” and accepted their promise. He then returned and told the tree-spirit what had happened. She was delighted and, after paying homage to Sakka, returned to her own abode.

original: Purohitopi punadivase balavapurise sannipātāpetvā vāsipharasuādīni gāhāpetvā rukkhamūlaṃ
analyzed: purohitaḥ api puna divase balava purise sannipātāpetvā vāsi pharasu ādīni gāhāpetvā rukkha mūlaṃ
translated: The royal chaplain, on the following day, assembled a number of strong men, had them bring axes, hatchets, and other tools, and went to the foot of the tree.

original: gantvā rukkhasākhāya gahetvā “ambho devate, ajja mayhaṃ taṃ yācantassa sattamo divaso,
analyzed: gantvā rukkha sākhāya gahetvā ambhaḥ devate ajja mayham tam yācantassa sattamaḥ divasaḥ
translated: He seized a branch and said, “O tree-spirit, today is the seventh day that I have been asking you to go away.

original: idāni te niṭṭhānakālo”ti āha. Tato rukkhadevatā mahantenānubhāvena khandhavivarato🔽nikkhamitvā madhurasarena taṃ āmantetvā ‘brāhmaṇa, tiṭṭhatu eko putto, cattāro te🔽putte dassāmī”ti āha. “Mama puttenattho natthi, amhākaṃ rañño puttaṃ dehī”ti. “Tuyhaṃyeva
analyzed: idāni te niṭṭhāna kālo ti āha tatas rukkha devatā mahantena anubhāvena khandha vivarato  nikkhamitvā madhurasarena tam āmantetvā brāhmaṇa tiṭṭhatu ekaḥ putto cattāro te  putte dassāmi iti āha mama puttena atthaḥ natthi amhākam rañño puttam dehi iti tuyhaṃ yeva
translated: “Now is the time for you to be repaid.” Then the tree-spirit, with great majesty, came forth from the hollow of the tree,

original: demī”ti. “Tena hi mama dve, rañño dve dehī”ti. “Rañño na demi, cattāropi tuyhameva🔽dammi, tayā ca laddhamattāva bhavissanti, agāre pana aṭṭhatvā daharakāleyeva pabbajissantī”ti.
analyzed: demi iti tena hi mama dve raññaḥ dve dehi iti raññaḥ na demi cattāraḥ api tuyham eva  dammi tayā ca laddha mattā ava bhavissanti agāre pana aṭṭhatvā dahara kāleya iva pabbajissanti iti
translated: and addressing the Brahman in a sweet voice, said, “Brahman, let one son alone be given you; I will give you four sons.” “I have no use for sons; give me the son of our king.” “I will give him to you.” “Then give me two, and let the king have two.” “I will not give him to the king; I will give you all four; and as soon as you receive them, they will go forth from the world and will not remain in your house even in childhood.”

original: “Tvaṃ me kevalaṃ putte dehi, apabbajanakāraṇaṃ pana amhākaṃ bhāro”ti. Sā tassa puttavaraṃ
analyzed: tvam me kevalam putte dehi a pabbajana kāraṇam pana amhākam bhāraḥ iti sā tassa putta varaṃ
translated: “Give me the sons, and let the responsibility of causing them to go forth from the world rest with you.” The tree-spirit gave him the choice of sons,

original: datvā attano bhavanaṃ pāvisi. Tato paṭṭhāya devatāya sakkāro mahā ahosi.
analyzed: da tvā attanaḥ bhavanam pāvisi tato paṭṭhāya devatāya sakkāro mahā ahosi
translated: and then returned to her own abode. From that time forth the honor paid to the tree-spirit was very great.

original: Jeṭṭhakadevaputto cavitvā purohitassa brāhmaṇiyā kucchimhi nibbatti. Tassa nāmaggahaṇadivase
analyzed: jeṭṭhaka deva putto cavitvā purohitassa brāhmaṇiyā kucchimhi nibbatti tassa nāma ggahaṇa divase
translated: The eldest of the sons of the tree-spirit died and was reborn in the womb of the wife of the family priest. On the day when the child was born

original: “hatthipālo”ti nāmaṃ katvā apabbajanatthāya hatthigopake paṭicchāpesuṃ. So tesaṃ
analyzed: hatthipālo ti nāmam katvā a pabbajana tthāya hatthi gopake paṭicchāpesum saḥ tesam
translated: and they had the elephant-keepers bring him up.

original: santike vaḍḍhati. Tassa padasā gamanakāle dutiyo cavitvā assā kucchimhi nibbatti,
analyzed: santike vaḍḍhati tassa padasā gamana kāle dutiyaḥ cavitvā assā kucchimhi nibbatti
translated: When he was able to walk, the second died and was reborn in the womb of a mare.

original: tassapi jātakāle “assapālo”ti nāmaṃ kariṃsu. So assagopakānaṃ santike vaḍḍhati. Tatiyassa
analyzed: tassa api jāta kāle assapālaḥ iti nāmam kariṃsu saḥ assa gopakānam santike vaḍḍhati tatiyassa
translated: When he was born, they gave him the name “Assapāla.” He was brought up by the horse-keepers. When the third was born,

original: jātakāle “gopālo”ti nāmaṃ kariṃsu. So gopālehi saddhiṃ vaḍḍhati. Catutthassa jātakāle
analyzed: jāta kāle gopālaḥ iti nāmam kariṃsu saḥ gopālehi saddhim vaḍḍhati catutthassa jāta kāle
translated: they gave him the name “Goppāla.” He was brought up by the cow-herds. When the fourth was born,

original: “ajapālo”ti nāmaṃ kariṃsu. So ajapālehi saddhiṃ vaḍḍhati. Te vuḍḍhimanvāya sobhaggappattā ahesuṃ.🔽Atha nesaṃ pabbajitabhayena rañño vijitā pabbajite nīhariṃsu. Sakalakāsiraṭṭhe ekapabbajitopi
analyzed: ajapālaḥ iti nāmam kariṃsu saḥ ajapālehi saddhim vaḍḍhati te vuḍḍhim anvāya sobhagga ppattāḥ ahesuṃ  atha nesam pabbajita bhayena raññaḥ vijitā pabbajite nīhariṃsu sakala kāsiraṭṭhe eka pabbajitaḥ api
translated: they gave him the name “Ajapāla.” He was brought up by the goat-herds. They all grew up and became very strong.🔽Then, fearing that they would go forth, they took away from the king’s realm all who had gone forth. Not a single one remained in the whole kingdom of Kāsi.

original: nāhosi. Te kumārā atipharusā ahesuṃ, yāya disāya gacchanti, tāya āhariyamānaṃ paṇṇākāraṃ
analyzed: te kumārāḥ ati pharusāḥ ahesum yāya disāya gacchanti tāya āhariyamānam paṇṇa ākāram
translated: These princes were very cruel. Wherever they went, they took with them all the tribute of the country.

original: vilumpanti. Hatthipālassa soḷasavassakāle kāyasampattiṃ disvā rājā ca purohito ca
analyzed: vilumpanti hatthipālassa soḷasa vassa kāle kāya sampattim disvā rājā ca purohito ca
translated: and were plundering the country. When Hatthipāla was sixteen years old, the king and the chaplain,

original: “kumārā mahallakā jātā, chattussāpanasamayo, tesaṃ kiṃ nu kho kātabba”nti mantetvā
analyzed: kumārāḥ mahallakāḥ jātā chattussāpana samayaḥ tesam kim nu kho kātabbanti mantetvā
translated: seeing his physical beauty, thought: “The princes are now grown up; it is time to set up the umbrella (of sovereignty). What is to be done with them?”

original: “ete abhisittakālato paṭṭhāya atissarā bhavissanti, tato tato pabbajitā āgamissanti,
analyzed: ete abhisitta kālataḥ paṭṭhāya atissarāḥ bhavissanti tatas tatas pabbajitāḥ āgamissanti
translated: And they discussed the matter, and said: “From the time of their consecration they will be very powerful. From here and there they will come (to the throne).

original: te disvā pabbajissanti, etesaṃ pabbajitakāle janapado ulloḷo bhavissati, vīmaṃsissāma
analyzed: te disvā pabbajissanti etesam pabbajita kāle janapadaḥ ulloḷaḥ bhavissati vīmaṃsissāma
translated: Seeing them, they will go forth. At the time of their going forth the people will be excited. We will test them

original: tāva ne, pacchā abhisiñcissāmā”ti cintetvā ubhopi isivesaṃ gahetvā bhikkhaṃ carantā

analyzed: pabbajissāmi deva ti deva putta dāra bandhanasmin hi uppanne tam bandhanam ducchedanīyam  hoti tena aham puretaraññeva kāme ca gehañca hitvā idānā iva pabbajissāmi anujāna manti  evañca pana vatvā tiṭṭhatha tumhe tumhehi saddhim kathentam eva mama byādhi jarā maraṇāni
translated: For when a son and wife are born, that bondage is hard to break. Therefore I will renounce sense pleasures and leave the house even now. Give me permission.

original: upagacchantī”ti te ubhopi vanditvā yojanikaṃ parisaṃ gahetvā nikkhamitvā gaṅgātīrameva🔽agamāsi. Hatthipālo tassapi ākāse nisīditvā dhammaṃ desetvā “samāgamo mahā bhavissatī”ti
analyzed: upagacchanti iti te ubhaḥ api vanditvā yojanikam parisam gahetvā nikkhamitvā gaṅgā tīram eva  agamāsi hatthipālo tassa api ākāse nisīditvā dhammam desetvā samāgamaḥ mahā bhavissati iti
translated: Having said this, “You stay here. While I am talking with you, sickness, old age, and death will overtake me,” he paid homage to them both, took his retinue of a yojana, and left. He went to the bank of the Ganges.

original: tattheva nisīdi. Punadivase purohito pallaṅkavaramajjhagato nisīditvā cintesi “mama
analyzed: tattha iva nisīdi puna divase purohitaḥ pallaṅka vara majjha gataḥ nisīditvā cintesi mama
translated: Hatthipāla sat down in the air and preached the Dhamma. “The gathering will be great,” he thought, and he sat down right there. On the next day the chaplain sat down in the middle of his fine couch and thought, “My son is going forth.

original: puttā pabbajitā, idānāhaṃ ekakova manussakhāṇuko jātomhi, ahampi pabbajissāmī”ti.
analyzed: puttāḥ pabbajitāḥ idāna aham ekakaḥ va manussa khāṇukaḥ jātaḥ amhi aham pi pabbajissāmi iti
translated: “My sons have gone forth, and now I am alone, a human being without a companion. I too will go forth.”

original: So brāhmaṇiyā saddhiṃ mantento gāthamāha –
analyzed: saḥ brāhmaṇiyā saddhim mantentaḥ gātham āha
translated: And he spoke this verse to his wife:

original: “Sākhāhi rukkho labhate samaññaṃ, pahīnasākhaṃ pana khāṇumāhu;
analyzed: sākhāhi rukkhaḥ labhate samaññam pahīna sākham pana khāṇum āhu
translated: “A tree is called a tree as long as it has branches; but when it is stripped of branches, they call it a stump.

original: Pahīnaputtassa mamajja bhoti, vāseṭṭhi bhikkhācariyāya kālo”ti.
analyzed: pahīna puttassa mamajja bhoti vāseṭṭhi bhikkhā cariyāya kālo ti
translated: Now I am like a stump, having lost my sons. It is time for me, Vasetthi, to go forth and live on alms.”

original: Tattha labhate samaññanti rukkhoti vohāraṃ labhati. Vāseṭṭhīti brāhmaṇiṃ ālapati. Bhikkhācariyāyāti mayhampi pabbajjāya kālo, puttānaṃ santikameva gamissāmīti.
analyzed: tattha labhate samaññanti rukkho ti vohāram labhati vāseṭṭhī iti brāhmaṇim ālapati bhikkhā cariyāya ati mayham pi pabbajjāya kālo puttānam santikam eva gamissāmi iti
translated: Herein, he is called a tree as long as he has branches is a term for a tree. Vasetthi: he spoke this to his wife. It is time for me to go forth and live on alms means it is time for me to go forth and live on alms. I will go to my sons.

original: So evaṃ vatvā brāhmaṇe pakkosāpesi, saṭṭhi brāhmaṇasahassāni sannipatiṃsu. Atha ne🔽āha – “tumhe kiṃ karissathā”ti tumhe pana ācariyāti. “Ahaṃ mama puttassa santike
analyzed: saḥ evam vatvā brāhmaṇe pakkosāpesi saṭṭhi brāhmaṇa sahassāni sannipatiṃsu atha ne  āha tumhe kim karissatha ati tumhe pana ācariya ati aham mama puttassa santike
translated: After saying this, he summoned the brahmans, and sixty thousand brahmans assembled. Then he said to them:

original: pabbajissāmī”ti. “Na tumhākameva nirayo uṇho, mayampi pabbajissāmā”ti. So asītikoṭidhanaṃ
analyzed: pabbajissāmi iti na tumhākam eva nirayaḥ uṇhaḥ mayam pi pabbajissāma ati saḥ asīti koṭi dhanam
translated: “What will you do?” “But you, teacher?” “I will go forth in the presence of my son.” “The hell realm is not hot just for you. We too will go forth.” He gave away sixty koṭis of🔽wealth and went forth in the presence of his son. The brahmans also went forth in the presence of his sons.

original: brāhmaṇiyā niyyādetvā yojanikaṃ brāhmaṇaparisaṃ ādāya nikkhamitvā puttānaṃ santikaññeva
analyzed: brāhmaṇiyā niyyādetvā yojanikam brāhmaṇa parisam ādāya nikkhamitvā puttānam santikam ca eva
translated: and after entrusting her to the care of the brāhmaṇī, he set out with a retinue of brāhmaṇas numbering a thousand, and went to his sons.

original: gato. Hatthipālo tāyapi parisāya ākāse ṭhatvā dhammaṃ desesi. Punadivase brāhmaṇī
analyzed: gataḥ hatthipālo parisāya ākāse ṭhatvā dhammam desesi puna divase brāhmaṇī
translated: Hatthipāla, too, rose up into the air and preached the Law to the assembly. On the following day the brāhmaṇī

original: cintesi “mama cattāro puttā setacchattaṃ pahāya ‘pabbajissāmā’ti gatā, brāhmaṇopi
analyzed: cintesi mama cattāro puttā seta chattam pahāya pabbajissāma ati gatā brāhmaṇaḥ api
translated: thought, “My four sons have gone away, leaving behind the white parasol, and have become monks. The brāhmaṇa,

original: purohitaṭṭhānena saddhiṃ asītikoṭidhanaṃ chaḍḍetvā puttānaññeva santikaṃ gato, ahameva
analyzed: purohita ṭṭhānena saddhim asīti koṭi dhanam chaḍḍetvā puttān aññā iva santikam gataḥ aham eva
translated: too, has abandoned his position as chaplain and his eighty koṭis of treasure, and has gone to his sons. I alone am

original: ekā kiṃ karissāmi, puttānaṃ gatamaggeneva gamissāmī”ti. Sā atītaṃ udāharaṇaṃ āharantī udānagāthamāha –
analyzed: ekā kim karissāmi puttānam gata maggena iva gamissāmi iti sā atītam udāharaṇam āharantī udāna gātham āha
translated: left. What shall I do? I will go by the same road that my sons have taken.” And she recited the following Stanza of the Ancients:

original: “Aghasmi koñcāva yathā himaccaye, katāni jālāni padāliya haṃsā;
analyzed: yathā himaccaye katāni jālāni haṃsā
translated: “I am like a bird, like a swan in the Himalayas when the snows have melted;

original: Gacchanti puttā ca patī ca mayhaṃ, sāhaṃ kathaṃ nānuvaje pajāna”nti.
analyzed: gacchanti puttā ca patī ca mayham sā aham katham na anuvaje pajānanti
translated: My sons and my husband have gone away, leaving me behind; how can I follow them?”

original: Tattha aghasmi koñcāva yathāti yatheva ākāse koñcasakuṇā asajjamānā gacchanti. Himaccayeti
analyzed: tattha aghasmi yathā ati yathā iva ākāse koñca sakuṇāḥ a sajjamānāḥ gacchanti himaccayā iti
translated: Herein, “I am like a bird, like a swan in the Himalayas when the snows have melted” means that she was like a bird in the air, moving without touching the ground.

original: vassānaccaye. Katāni jālāni padāliya haṃsāti atīte kira channavutisahassā suvaṇṇahaṃsāvassārattapahonakaṃ
analyzed: katāni jālāni atīte kira channavuti sahassā
translated: In the past, it seems, ten thousand golden geese, having gathered rice in the Honaka forest during the hot season,

original: sāliṃ kañcanaguhāyaṃ nikkhipitvā vassabhayena bahi anikkhamitvā catumāsaṃ tattha
analyzed: sālim kañcana guhāyam nikkhipitvā vassa bhayena bahi a nikkhamitvā catu māsam tattha
translated: put it in a golden cave and, not going out because of the fear of the rains, stayed there for four months.

original: vasanti. Atha nesaṃ uṇṇanābhi nāma makkaṭako guhādvāre jālaṃ bandhati. Haṃsā dvinnaṃ
analyzed: vasanti atha uṇṇanābhi nāma makkaṭakaḥ guhā dvāre jālam bandhati haṃsāḥ dvinnam
translated: Then a monkey named Uṇṇanābhi tied a net at the entrance to the cave. The geese

original: taruṇahaṃsānaṃ dviguṇaṃ vaṭṭaṃ denti. Te thāmasampannatāya taṃ jālaṃ chinditvā purato
analyzed: dviguṇam vaṭṭam denti te thāma sampanna tāya tam jālam chinditvā puratas
translated: gave a double portion to two young geese. They, being strong, tore the net and went forward,

original: gacchanti, sesā tesaṃ gatamaggena gacchanti. Sā tamatthaṃ pakāsentī evamāha. Idaṃ
analyzed: gacchanti sesā tesam gata maggena gacchanti sā tam attham pakāsentī evam āha idam
translated: and the others went by the path they had gone. Pointing out that situation, she said this.

original: vuttaṃ hoti – yatheva ākāse koñcasakuṇā asajjamānā gacchanti, tathā himaccaye vassānātikkame
analyzed: vuttam hoti yathā iva ākāse koñca sakuṇāḥ a sajjamānāḥ gacchanti tathā himaccaye vassa an atikkame
translated: This is what is meant: Just as the birds called koñcasakuna fly through the air without touching the ground,

original: dve taruṇahaṃsā katāni jālāni padāletvā gacchanti, atha nesaṃ gatamaggena itare haṃsā.
analyzed: dve taruṇa haṃsā katāni jālāni padāletvā gacchanti atha gata maggena itare haṃsā
translated: so at the end of the rains, at the end of the cold season, two young geese tore the nets and went forward, and then the other geese by the path they had gone.

original: Idāni pana mama puttā taruṇahaṃsā jālaṃ viya kāmajālaṃ chinditvā gatā, mayāpi tesaṃ
analyzed: idāni pana mama puttāḥ taruṇa haṃsāḥ jālam viya kāma jālam chinditvā gatāḥ mayā api tesam
translated: But now my sons, young geese, have broken the net of lusts as if it were a net of reeds, and have gone away. I too must go

original: gatamaggena gantabbanti iminādhippāyena “gacchanti puttā ca patī ca mayhaṃ, sāhaṃ
analyzed: gata maggena gantabbanti iminā adhippāyena gacchanti puttā ca patī ca mayham sā aham
translated: by the way they have gone. ” With this thought she said, “My sons and my husband have gone away.

original: kathaṃ nānuvaje pajāna”nti āha.
analyzed: katham na anuvaje pajānanti āha
translated: How can I, understanding, not follow them? ”

original: Iti sā “kathaṃ ahaṃ evaṃ pajānantī na pabbajissāmi, pabbajissāmi yevā”ti sanniṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: iti sā katham aham evam pajānantī na pabbajissāmi pabbajissāmi yā iva ati sanniṭṭhānam
translated: Thus she made up her mind, “How can I, understanding, not go forth? I will go forth. ”

original: katvā brāhmaṇiyo pakkosāpetvā evamāha “tumhe kiṃ karissathā”ti? “Tumhe pana ayye”ti.🔽“Ahaṃ pabbajissāmī”ti. “Mayampi pabbajissāmā”ti. Sā taṃ vibhavaṃ chaḍḍetvā yojanikaṃ
analyzed: katvā brāhmaṇiyaḥ pakkosāpetvā evam āha tumhe kim karissatha ati tumhe pana ayyā iti  aham pabbajissāmi iti mayam pi pabbajissāma ati sā tam vibhavam chaḍḍetvā yojanikam
translated: And she summoned the Brahman women and said to them, “What will you do?” “And you, ladies?”

original: parisaṃ gahetvā puttānaṃ santikameva gatā. Hatthipālo tāyapi parisāya ākāse nisīditvā
analyzed: parisam gahetvā puttānam santikam eva gatā hatthi pālaḥ tāya api parisāya ākāse nisīditvā
translated: “I will go forth.” “We will go forth.” She abandoned her wealth, took her retinue of a thousand, and went to her sons. Hatthipāla,

original: dhammaṃ desesi. Punadivase rājā “kuhiṃ purohito”ti pucchi. “Deva, purohito ca brāhmaṇī
analyzed: dhammam desesi puna divase rājā kuhim purohito ti pucchi deva ca brāhmaṇī
translated: sitting in the air, preached the Law to them also. On the following day the king asked, “Where is the chaplain?” “Your majesty, the chaplain🔽and his wife have gone forth into the homeless state.” “What! Have they?”

original: ca sabbaṃ dhanaṃ chaḍḍetvā dviyojanikaṃ parisaṃ gahetvā puttānaṃ santikaṃ gatā”ti.
analyzed: ca sabbam dhanam chaḍḍetvā dvi yojanikam parisam gahetvā puttānam santikam gatā ati
translated: and she abandoned all her wealth, and taking with her a retinue of two hundred, went to her sons.”

original: Rājā “asāmikaṃ dhanaṃ amhākaṃ pāpuṇātī”ti tassa gehato dhanaṃ āharāpesi. Athassa
analyzed: rājā asāmikam dhanam amhākam pāpuṇāti iti tassa gehataḥ dhanam āhara āpesi athassa
translated: The king thought, “Wealth without an owner will come to me,” and he had the wealth brought from the house of the chaplain.

original: aggamahesī “rājā kiṃ karotī”ti pucchitvā “purohitassa gehato dhanaṃ āharāpetī”ti
analyzed: aggamahesī rājā kim karoti iti pucchitvā purohitassa gehataḥ dhanam āhara apeti iti
translated: Then the chief queen asked, “What is the king doing?” and when she was told, “He is having the wealth brought from the house of the chaplain,”

original: vutte “purohito kuhi”nti vatvā “sapajāpatiko pabbajjatthāya nikkhanto”ti sutvā “ayaṃ🔽rājā brāhmaṇena ca brāhmaṇiyā ca catūhi puttehi ca jahitaṃ ukkāraṃ mohena mūḷho attano🔽gharaṃ āharāpeti, upamāya naṃ bodhessāmī”ti sūnato maṃsaṃ āharāpetvā rājaṅgaṇe rāsiṃ
analyzed: vutte purohitaḥ kuhin ti vatvā sa pajāpatikaḥ pabbajja atthāya nikkhantaḥ iti sutvā ayam  rājā brāhmaṇena ca brāhmaṇiyā ca catūhi puttehi ca jahitam ukkāram mohena mūḷhaḥ attanaḥ  gharam āhara apa iti upamāya nam bodhessāmi iti sūnataḥ maṃsam āhara apetvā rājaṅgaṇe rāsim
translated: she asked, “Where is the chaplain?” and when she was told, “He has gone forth with his wife,” she thought,🔽“This king, deluded by delusion, is having brought to his house the refuse that has been abandoned by the chaplain and the chaplain’s wife,” and she said, “I will instruct him by means of a simile.”

original: kāretvā ujumaggaṃ vissajjetvā jālaṃ parikkhipāpesi. Gijjhā dūratova disvā tassatthāya
analyzed: kāretvā uju maggam vissajjetvā jālam parikkhipāpesi gijjhāḥ dūratas va disvā tassa atthāya
translated: So she had meat brought from the shambles, had it piled up in a heap in the royal courtyard, had a straight path prepared, and had a net spread over it. The vultures, seeing it from afar,

original: otariṃsu. Tattha sappaññā jālaṃ pasāritaṃ ñatvā atibhārikā hutvā “ujukaṃ uppatituṃ
analyzed: otariṃsu tattha sappaññāḥ jālam pasāritam ñatvā atibhārikāḥ hutvā ujukam uppatitum
translated: came down for the purpose. There the clever ones, knowing that the net was spread, became overburdened and could not rise straight up.

original: na sakkhissāmā”ti attanā khāditamaṃsaṃ chaḍḍetvā vamitvā jālaṃ anallīyitvā ujukameva🔽uppatitvā gamiṃsu. Andhabālā pana tehi chaḍḍitaṃ vamitaṃ khāditvā bhāriyā hutvā ujukaṃ
analyzed: na sakkhissāma ati attanā khādita maṃsam chaḍḍetvā vamitvā jālam an allīyitvā ujukam eva  uppatitvā gamiṃsu andha bālā pana tehi chaḍḍitam vamitam khāditvā bhāriyā hutvā ujukam
translated: “We cannot.” So they dropped the flesh they had eaten, vomited up the rest, and without entering the net flew straight away. The foolish birds, however, ate the flesh they had dropped and vomited up, and so became too heavy to fly straight away.

original: uppatituṃ asakkontā āgantvā jāle bajjhiṃsu. Athekaṃ gijjhaṃ ānetvā deviyā dassayiṃsu.
analyzed: uppatitum a sakkontāḥ āgantvā jāle bajjhiṃsu atha ekam gijjham ānetvā deviyā dassayiṃsu
translated: Unable to rise, they came back and were caught in the net. Then they brought one of the vultures to the queen.

original: Sā taṃ ādāya rañño santikaṃ gantvā “etha tāva, mahārāja, rājaṅgaṇe ekaṃ kiriyaṃ passissāmā”ti
analyzed: sā tam ādāya rañño santikam gantvā etha tāva mahā rāja rājaṅgaṇe ekam kiriyam passissāma ati
translated: She took it and went to the king, saying, “Come, your majesty, let us see a spectacle in the royal courtyard.”

original: sīhapañjaraṃ vivaritvā “ime gijjhe olokehi mahārājā”ti vatvā dve gāthā abhāsi –
analyzed: sīha pañjaram vivaritvā ime gijjhe mahā rāja iti vatvā dve gāthāḥ abhāsi
translated: Opening the door of the lion-house, she said, “Look at these vultures, your majesty,” and then she uttered the following two stanzas:

original: “Ete bhutvā vamitvā ca, pakkamanti vihaṅgamā;
analyzed: ete bhutvā vamitvā ca pakkamanti vihaṅgamā
translated: “Having eaten and vomited up, the birds fly away;

original: Ye ca bhutvā na vamiṃsu, te me hatthattamāgatā.
analyzed: ye ca bhutvā na vamiṃsu te me hatthattama āgatā
translated: But those that have eaten and not vomited up, have come into my power.

original: “Avamī brāhmaṇo kāme, so tvaṃ paccāvamissasi;
analyzed: avamī brāhmaṇaḥ kāme saḥ tvam paccāvamissasi
translated: “The Brahman vomits up his pleasures, but you will vomit up your pleasures in return.

original: Vantādo puriso rāja, na so hoti pasaṃsiyo”ti.
analyzed: purisaḥ rāja na saḥ hoti pasaṃsiyaḥ iti
translated: The man who vomits up his food, O king, is not to be commended.”

original: Tattha bhutvā vamitvā cāti maṃsaṃ khāditvā vamitvā ca. Paccāvamissasīti paṭibhuñjissasi.
analyzed: tattha bhutvā vamitvā ca ati maṃsam khāditvā vamitvā ca paccāvamissasi iti paṭibhuñjissasi
translated: “Having eaten and vomited there” means having eaten and vomited flesh. “You will mix it again” means you will eat it again.

original: Vantādoti parassa vamitakhādako. Na pasaṃsiyoti so taṇhāvasiko bālo buddhādīhi paṇḍitehi
analyzed: parassa vamita khādakaḥ na so taṇhāvasikaḥ bālaḥ buddha ādīhi paṇḍitehi
translated: “A vomiter” means one who eats the vomit of another. “Is not praised” means that fool who is a slave to craving is not to be praised by the wise, by the Buddhas and so on.

original: pasaṃsitabbo na hoti.
analyzed: pasaṃsitabbaḥ na hoti
translated: He is not to be praised.

original: Taṃ sutvā rājā vippaṭisārī ahosi, tayo bhavā ādittā viya upaṭṭhahiṃsu. So “ajjeva rajjaṃ pahāya mama pabbajituṃ vaṭṭatī”ti uppannasaṃvego deviyā thutiṃ karonto gāthamāha –
analyzed: tam sutvā rājā vippaṭisārī ahosi tayaḥ bhavāḥ ādittāḥ viya upaṭṭhahiṃsu saḥ ajjā iva rajjam pahāya mama pabbajitum vaṭṭati iti uppanna saṃvegaḥ deviyā thutim karontaḥ gātham āha
translated: Having heard this, the king was remorseful, and the three worlds appeared to him as if they were on fire. He thought: “Today it is right for me to renounce the kingdom and go forth.” With a sense of urgency he praised the queen, saying:🔽“As a strong man would pull out of the mud

original: “Paṅke ca posaṃ palipe byasannaṃ, balī yathā dubbalamuddhareyya;
analyzed: paṅke ca posam palipe byasannam balī yathā dubbalam uddhareyya
translated: A weak man who is sinking and drowning,🔽So you have pulled me out, my lady,

original: Evampi maṃ tvaṃ udatāri bhoti, pañcāli gāthāhi subhāsitāhī”ti.🔽Tattha byasannanti nimuggaṃ, “visanna”ntipi pāṭho. Uddhareyyāti kesesu vā hatthesu
analyzed: evam pi mam tvam udatāri bhoti pañcāli  tattha byasannam ti nimuggam visannam tipi pāṭhaḥ uddhareyya ati kesesu vā hatthesu
translated: With five well-spoken verses.”

original: vā gahetvā ukkhipitvā thale ṭhapeyya. Udatārīti kāmapaṅkato uttārayi. “Udatāsī”tipi
analyzed: vā gahetvā ukkhipitvā thale ṭhapeyya udatāri iti kāma paṅkataḥ uttārayi udatāsi iti pi
translated: Here “drowning” means sinking. “Visanna” is another reading. “Would pull out” means he would pull him out by the hair or by the hand, lift him up, and place him on dry land. “You have pulled me out” means you have pulled me out of the mud of sensual pleasures. “Udatāsī” is another reading.

original: pāṭho, ayamevattho. “Uddhaṭāsī”tipi pāṭho, uddharīti attho. Pañcālīti pañcālarājadhīte.
analyzed: pāṭhaḥ ayam eva atthaḥ uddhaṭā asi iti pi pāṭhaḥ uddharī iti pañcālī iti pañcāla rāja dhīte
translated: The reading is the same. The reading is “Uddhatasī,” which means “one who has lifted up.” “Pañcālī” means the daughter of the king of Pañcāla.

original: Evañca pana vatvā taṅkhaṇaññeva pabbajitukāmo hutvā amacce pakkosāpetvā āha – “tumhe

analyzed: khittaḥ viya ahosim yakkhiniyā hatthataḥ muttaḥ api pana aham na iva ajaraḥ na amaraḥ homi  kim me rajjena rajje ṭhita kālataḥ paṭṭhāya dunnikkhamanam hoti ajja iva mama pitaram
translated: Though I have escaped from the clutches of the she-devil, yet I am neither immortal nor exempt from death.

original: pabbajjaṃ anujānāpetvā himavantaṃ pavisitvā pabbajissāmī”ti. So nagaraṃ padakkhiṇaṃ
analyzed: pabbajjam anujānāpetvā himavantam pavisitvā pabbajissāmi iti so nagaram padakkhiṇam
translated: What have I to do with a kingdom? From the time I have been in the kingdom, I have been unable to get out. This very day I will obtain my father’s permission to retire from the world, and will enter the Himalayas and become a recluse.” He circumambulated the city,

original: katvā rājakulaṃ pavisitvā rājānaṃ vanditvā aṭṭhāsi.
analyzed: katvā rājakulam pavisitvā rājānam vanditvā aṭṭhāsi
translated: and having done so, he entered the royal palace, and after worshipping the king, he stood there.

original: Rājā tassa sarīrasobhaṃ oloketvā balavasinehena amacce olokesi. Te “kiṃ karoma, devā”ti
analyzed: rājā tassa sarīra sobham oloketvā balava sinehena amacce olokesi te kim karoma deva ati
translated: The king, after looking at the beauty of his body, looked at his ministers with a strong desire. They said: “What shall we do, your majesty?”🔽“After placing my son in the midst of a heap of jewels, and after consecrating him with three conches, I will

original: vadiṃsu. Puttaṃ me ratanarāsimhi ṭhapetvā tīhi saṅkhehi abhisiñcitvā kañcanamālaṃ
analyzed: vadiṃsu puttam me ratana rāsimhi ṭhapetvā tīhi saṅkhehi abhisiñcitvā kañcana mālam
translated: raise up a golden garland

original: setacchattaṃ ussāpethāti. Mahāsatto pitaraṃ vanditvā “na mayhaṃ rajjenattho, ahaṃ
analyzed: seta chattam ussāpetha iti mahāsattaḥ pitaram vanditvā na mayham aham
translated: and a white parasol.” The Great Being, after worshipping his father, said: “I have no desire for the kingdom, I will

original: pabbajissāmi, pabbajjaṃ me anujānāthā”ti āha. Tāta rajjaṃ paṭikkhipitvā kiṃkāraṇā
analyzed: pabbajissāmi pabbajjam me anujānātha ati āha tāta rajjam paṭikkhipitvā kiṃkāraṇā
translated: go forth, please give me permission to go forth.” (The king said:) “Dear, after rejecting the kingdom, for what reason

original: pabbajissasīti. “Deva ahaṃ mātukucchimhi dasa māse gūthaniraye viya vasitvā mātukucchito
analyzed: pabbajissasi iti deva aham mātukucchimhi dasa māse gūthaniraye viya vasitvā mātukucchitaḥ
translated: will you go forth?” (The Great Being said:) “Your Majesty, after living in my mother’s womb for ten months, as if in a cesspit, and after

original: nikkhanto yakkhinibhayena soḷasa vassāni bandhanāgāre vasanto bahi oloketumpi na
analyzed: nikkhantaḥ yakkhini bhayena soḷasa vassāni bandhanāgāre vasantaḥ bahi oloketum pi na
translated: coming out from my mother’s womb, living for sixteen years in a prison through the fear of the demoness, not being able to look

original: alabhiṃ, ussadaniraye khitto viya ahosiṃ, yakkhiniyā hatthato muttomhītipi ajaro
analyzed: alabhim ussada niraye khittaḥ viya ahosim yakkhiniyā hatthataḥ mutto mhi iti pi ajaraḥ
translated: outside, as if thrown into a hell of burning embers, I was freed from the hands of the demoness.”

original: amaro na homi. Maccu nāmesa na sakkā kenaci jinituṃ, bhave ukkaṇṭhitomhi, yāva me
analyzed: amaraḥ na homi maccu nāma isa na sakkā kenacid jinitum bhave ukkaṇṭhitaḥ asmi yāva me
translated: I am not immortal. Death is something that no one can conquer. I am disgusted with existence.

original: byādhijarāmaraṇāni nāgacchanti, tāvadeva pabbajitvā dhammaṃ carissāmi, alaṃ me rajjena,
analyzed: byādhi jarā maraṇāni na āgacchanti tāvat eva pabbajitvā dhammam carissāmi alam me rajjena
translated: As long as disease, old age, and death do not come to me, so long I will go forth and live the holy life. I have had enough of kingship.🔽Give me permission, your majesty.”

original: anujānātha maṃ, devā”ti vatvā pitu dhammaṃ desento āha –
analyzed: anujānātha mama deva iti vatvā pitu dhammaṃ desentaḥ āha
translated: Having spoken thus, he taught the Dhamma to his father, saying:

original: “Yamekarattiṃ paṭhamaṃ, gabbhe vasati māṇavo;
analyzed: yam eka rattim paṭhamam gabbhe vasati māṇavaḥ
translated: “The moment a child is born, he begins to grow old;

original: Abbhuṭṭhitova so yāti, sa gacchaṃ na nivattati.
analyzed: abbhuṭṭhitaḥ uva saḥ yāti sa gaccham na nivattati
translated: He goes on to death, and never turns back.

original: “Na yujjhamānā na balenavassitā, narā na jīranti na cāpi mīyare;
analyzed: na yujjhamānāḥ na narāḥ na jīranti na ca api mīyare
translated: “Men do not grow old and die because they are engaged in battle;

original: Sabbaṃ hidaṃ jātijarāyupaddutaṃ, taṃ me matī hoti carāmi dhammaṃ.
analyzed: sabbam hi dam jāti jarāyu paddutam tam me matī hoti carāmi dhammaṃ
translated: All are subject to birth, old age, and death. Therefore I think thus and live the holy life.🔽“Kings, lords of the land, with their four-constituent army,

original: “Caturaṅginiṃ senaṃ subhiṃsarūpaṃ, jayanti raṭṭhādhipatī pasayha;
analyzed: caturaṅginim senam su bhiṃsa rūpam jayanti raṭṭha adhipatī pasayha
translated: Victorious, with their enemies subdued,

original: Na maccuno jayitumussahanti, taṃ me matī hoti carāmi dhammaṃ.
analyzed: na maccunaḥ jayitum ussahanti tam me matī hoti carāmi dhammaṃ
translated: Do not dare to conquer Death. Therefore I think thus and live the holy life.

original: “Hatthīhi assehi rathehi pattibhi, parivāritā muccare ekacceyyā;
analyzed: hatthīhi assehi rathehi pattibhi parivāritā muccare ekacceyyā
translated: “Some are surrounded by elephants, horses, chariots, and infantry,

original: Na maccuno muccitumussahanti, taṃ me matī hoti carāmi dhammaṃ.
analyzed: na maccunaḥ muccitum ussahanti tam me matī hoti carāmi dhammaṃ
translated: They cannot escape the power of Death. I have this insight, and so I live the holy life.

original: “Hatthīhi assehi rathehi pattibhi, sūrā pabhañjanti padhaṃsayanti;
analyzed: hatthīhi assehi rathehi pattibhi sūrā pabhañjanti padhaṃsayanti
translated: “With elephants, horses, chariots, and infantry, the brave attack and destroy,

original: Na maccuno bhañjitumussahanti, taṃ me matī hoti carāmi dhammaṃ.
analyzed: na maccunaḥ bhañjitum ussahanti tam me matī hoti carāmi dhammaṃ
translated: But they cannot destroy the power of Death. I have this insight, and so I live the holy life.

original: “Mattā gajā bhinnagaḷā pabhinnā, nagarāni maddanti janaṃ hananti;
analyzed: mattāḥ gajāḥ bhinna gaḷā pabhinnāḥ nagarāni maddanti janam hananti
translated: “Drunk elephants, with broken tusks and shattered temples, destroy the cities and kill the people,

original: Na maccuno madditumussahanti, taṃ me matī hoti carāmi dhammaṃ.
analyzed: na maccunaḥ madditum ussahanti tam me matī hoti carāmi dhammaṃ
translated: But they cannot destroy the power of Death. I have this insight, and so I live the holy life.

original: “Issāsino katahatthāpi vīrā, dūrepātī akkhaṇavedhinopi;
analyzed: issa asino kata hatthā api vīrā dūrepātī akkhaṇa vedhino pi
translated: “Archers, with their well-aimed arrows, their powerful arms, and their ability to shoot from a distance,

original: Na maccuno vijjhitumussahanti, taṃ me matī hoti carāmi dhammaṃ.
analyzed: na maccunaḥ vijjhitum ussahanti tam me matī hoti carāmi dhammaṃ
translated: Cannot shoot down the power of Death. I have this insight, and so I live the holy life.🔽“The nets of the fowlers are destroyed, as are the forests with their deer,

original: “Sarāni khīyanti saselakānanā, sabbaṃ hidaṃ khīyati dīghamantaraṃ;
analyzed: sarāni khīyanti sa sela kānanā sabbam hi dam khīyati dīgham antaram
translated: And all this is destroyed in the course of time.

original: Sabbaṃ hidaṃ bhañjare kālapariyāyaṃ, taṃ me matī hoti carāmi dhammaṃ.
analyzed: sabbam hi dam bhañjare kāla pariyāyam tam me matī hoti carāmi dhammaṃ
translated: All this is destroyed. I have this insight, and so I live the holy life.

original: “Sabbesamevañhi narāna nārinaṃ, calācalaṃ pāṇabhunodha jīvitaṃ;
analyzed: sabbesam evam hi nārinam calācalam jīvitam
translated: “For all men and women, the life of those who live by the use of their hands,

original: Paṭova dhuttassa, dumova kūlajo, taṃ me matī hoti carāmi dhammaṃ.
analyzed: paṭaḥ uva dhuttassa dumaḥ uva kūla jo tam me matī hoti carāmi dhammaṃ
translated: Like a thief with a cloak, like a reed with a thorn, that is my thought, I live by the Dhamma.

original: “Dumapphalāneva patanti māṇavā, daharā ca vuddhā ca sarīrabhedā;
analyzed: patanti māṇavāḥ daharā ca vuddhā ca sarīra bhedā
translated: “Young men, old men, and those in between, their bodies break up and fall like fruit from a tree.

original: Nāriyo narā majjhimaporisā ca, taṃ me matī hoti carāmi dhammaṃ.
analyzed: nāriyaḥ narāḥ majjhimaporisāḥ ca tam me matī hoti carāmi dhammaṃ
translated: Women, men, and those in between, that is my thought, I live by the Dhamma.

original: “Nāyaṃ vayo tārakarājasannibho, yadabbhatītaṃ gatameva dāni taṃ;
analyzed: na ayam tāraka rāja sannibhaḥ gatam eva tam
translated: “This age is not like the one that is past, that has gone by and is no more.

original: Jiṇṇassa hī natthi ratī kuto sukhaṃ, taṃ me matī hoti carāmi dhammaṃ.
analyzed: jiṇṇassa hi natthi ratī kutas sukham tam me matī hoti carāmi dhammaṃ
translated: For an old man there is no joy, how much less pleasure, that is my thought, I live by the Dhamma.

original: “Yakkhā pisācā athavāpi petā, kupitā te assasanti manusse;
analyzed: yakkhā pisācā athavā api petā kupitā te assasanti manusse
translated: “If spirits, demons, or ghosts are angry, they can kill people with their breath.

original: Na maccuno assasitussahanti, taṃ me matī hoti carāmi dhammaṃ.
analyzed: na maccunaḥ tam me matī hoti carāmi dhammaṃ
translated: But they cannot kill the one who is dead, that is my thought, I live by the Dhamma.

original: “Yakkhe pisāce athavāpi pete, kupitepi te nijjhapanaṃ karonti;
analyzed: yakkhe pisāce athavā api pete kupite api te nijjhapanam karonti
translated: “If spirits, demons, or ghosts are angry, they can make one’s breath stop.

original: Na maccuno nijjhapanaṃ karonti, taṃ me matī hoti carāmi dhammaṃ.
analyzed: na maccunaḥ nijjhapanam karonti tam me matī hoti carāmi dhammaṃ
translated: But they cannot make the one who is dead breathe again, that is my thought, I live by the Dhamma.

original: “Aparādhake dūsake heṭhake ca, rājāno daṇḍenti viditvāna dosaṃ;
analyzed: aparādhake dūsake heṭhake ca rājānaḥ daṇḍenti dosam
translated: “Kings punish those who have offended, who have done wrong, and who are enemies, after they have found out about their offense.

original: Na maccuno daṇḍayitussahanti, taṃ me matī hoti carāmi dhammaṃ.
analyzed: na maccunaḥ daṇḍayituḥ sahanti tam me matī hoti carāmi dhammaṃ
translated: They cannot withstand the rod of Death. I have this insight, and so I live by the Dhamma.

original: “Aparādhakā dūsakā heṭhakā ca, labhanti te rājino nijjhapetuṃ;
analyzed: aparādhakāḥ dūsakāḥ heṭhakā ca labhanti te rājinaḥ nijjhapetum
translated: “Those who offend, those who harm, and those who destroy, they can be punished by the king.

original: Na maccuno nijjhapanaṃ karonti, taṃ me matī hoti carāmi dhammaṃ.
analyzed: na maccunaḥ nijjhapanam karonti tam me matī hoti carāmi dhammaṃ
translated: But they cannot punish Death. I have this insight, and so I live by the Dhamma.

original: “Na khattiyoti na ca brāhmaṇoti, na aḍḍhakā balavā tejavāpi;
analyzed: na khattiyā uti na ca brāhmaṇā uti na aḍḍhakā balavā tejavā api
translated: “Not because of being a noble or a brahmin, not because of being rich, powerful, or brilliant,

original: Na maccurājassa apekkhamatthi, taṃ me matī hoti carāmi dhammaṃ.
analyzed: na maccu rājassa apekkham atthi tam me matī hoti carāmi dhammaṃ
translated: does one escape the king of Death. I have this insight, and so I live by the Dhamma.

original: “Sīhā ca byagghā ca athopi dīpiyo, pasayha khādanti vipphandamānaṃ;
analyzed: sīhā ca byagghā ca pasayha khādanti vipphandamānam
translated: “Lions, tigers, and leopards, with great force, devour a struggling prey.

original: Na maccuno khāditumussahanti, taṃ me matī hoti carāmi dhammaṃ.
analyzed: na maccuno khāditum ussahanti tam me matī hoti carāmi dhammaṃ
translated: But they cannot devour Death. I have this insight, and so I live by the Dhamma.

original: “Māyākārā raṅgamajjhe karontā, mohenti cakkhūni janassa tāvade;
analyzed: māyākārāḥ raṅga majjhe karontāḥ mohenti cakkhūni janassa tāvade
translated: “Magicians in the middle of a stage deceive people’s eyes.

original: Na maccuno mohayitussahanti, taṃ me matī hoti carāmi dhammaṃ.
analyzed: na maccunaḥ mohayituḥ sahanti tam me matī hoti carāmi dhammaṃ
translated: But they cannot deceive Death. I have this insight, and so I live by the Dhamma.

original: “Āsīvisā kupitā uggatejā, ḍaṃsanti mārentipi te manusse;
analyzed: kupitāḥ ugga tejāḥ ḍaṃsanti mārenti pi te manusse
translated: “Angry, poisonous snakes with raised crests bite and kill people.

original: Na maccuno ḍaṃsitumussahanti, taṃ me matī hoti carāmi dhammaṃ.
analyzed: na maccunaḥ ḍaṃsitum ussahanti tam me matī hoti carāmi dhammaṃ
translated: But they cannot bite Death. I have this insight, and so I live by the Dhamma.

original: “Āsīvisā kupitā yaṃ ḍaṃsanti, tikicchakā tesa visaṃ hananti;
analyzed: kupitāḥ yam ḍaṃsanti tikicchakāḥ visam hananti
translated: “The angry snakes that bite, the doctors cure their poison,

original: Na maccuno daṭṭhavisaṃ hananti, taṃ me matī hoti carāmi dhammaṃ.
analyzed: na maccunaḥ daṭṭha visam hananti tam me matī hoti carāmi dhammaṃ
translated: But not the poison of the look of Death: I think of this, and so I wander forth.🔽“The man who knows the herbs, the man who knows the snakes,

original: “Dhammantarī vettaraṇī ca bhojo, visāni hantvāna bhujaṅgamānaṃ;
analyzed: dhammantarī vettaraṇī ca bhojaḥ visāni hantvāna bhujaṅgamānam
translated: The man who knows the poison of the snakes,

original: Suyyanti te kālakatā tatheva, taṃ me matī hoti carāmi dhammaṃ.
analyzed: te kālakatā tathā iva tam me matī hoti carāmi dhammaṃ
translated: When he is dead, they say, he is just the same: I think of this, and so I wander forth.🔽“The men who know the spells, the men who know the charms,

original: “Vijjādharā ghoramadhīyamānā, adassanaṃ osadhehi vajanti;
analyzed: vijjādharāḥ ghoram adhīyamānāḥ adassanam osadhehi vajanti
translated: The men who know the herbs, they drive away the poison,

original: Na maccurājassa vajantadassanaṃ, taṃ me matī hoti carāmi dhammaṃ.
analyzed: na maccu rājassa vajanta dassanam tam me matī hoti carāmi dhammaṃ
translated: But not the poison of the look of Death: I think of this, and so I wander forth.🔽“The Dhamma protects the man who lives by it,

original: “Dhammo have rakkhati dhammacāriṃ, dhammo suciṇṇo sukhamāvahāti;
analyzed: dhammaḥ have rakkhati dhamma cārim dhammaḥ su ciṇṇaḥ sukham āvahāti
translated: The Dhamma, when well-practised, brings happiness.🔽This is the fruit of practising the Dhamma:

original: Esānisaṃso dhamme suciṇṇe, na duggatiṃ gacchati dhammacārī.
analyzed: esa anisaṃsaḥ dhamme su ciṇṇe na duggatim gacchati dhamma cārī
translated: The man who lives by Dhamma goes not to a bad destination.🔽“The Dhamma and the non-Dhamma,

original: “Na hi dhammo adhammo ca, ubho samavipākino;
analyzed: na hi dhammo adhammo ca ubho sama vipākino
translated: Both do not have the same result.🔽The non-Dhamma leads to hell,

original: Adhammo nirayaṃ neti, dhammo pāpeti suggati”nti.
analyzed: adhammaḥ nirayam neti dhammaḥ pāpeti suggatin ti
translated: The Dhamma leads to a good destination.”

original: Tattha yamekarattinti yebhuyyena sattā mātukucchimhi paṭisandhiṃ gaṇhantā rattiyaṃyeva
analyzed: tattha yam eka rattim ti yebhuyyena sattāḥ mātukucchimhi paṭisandhim gaṇhantāḥ
translated: Herein, as to “in one night”: for the most part, beings who take rebirth-linking in a mother’s womb do so in the night.

analyzed: gaṇhanti tasmai evam āha ayam pana itthā atthaḥ yam eka rattim vā divā vā paṭhamam eva  paṭisandhim gaṇhitvā mātukucchi saṅkhāte gabbhe vasati māṇavaḥ ti satto kalala bhāvena  patiṭṭhāti abbhuṭṭhitaḥ iva saḥ yāti iti saḥ māṇavaḥ yathā nāma valāhaka saṅkhātaḥ abbhas uṭṭhitaḥ
translated: and so he says ‘he goes on’. But the meaning here is this. What is meant is that he who has taken rebirth-linking in the first place, either by night or by day,🔽and who then dwells in the womb, which is called ‘the belly’, is a ‘foetus’. The ‘being’ is established in the state of the ‘morsel’

analyzed: nibbattaḥ vāyu vega āhataḥ paṭigacchati tathā iva
translated: . ‘As soon as it is born it goes’: just as a cloud called ‘the rain-cloud’ that is born, that comes into existence, goes by the force of the wind,

original: “Paṭhamaṃ kalalaṃ hoti, kalalā hoti abbudaṃ;🔽Abbudā jāyate pesi, pesi nibbattatī ghano;
analyzed: paṭhamam kalalam hoti kalalā hoti abbudam  abbudā jāyate pesi pesi nibbattatī ghanaḥ
translated: ‘First there is the morsel, from the morsel the blister,🔽From the blister the lump, from the lump the oblong,

original: Ghanā pasākhā jāyanti, kesā lomā nakhāpi ca.
analyzed: ghanā pasākhāḥ jāyanti kesāḥ lomāḥ nakhāḥ api ca
translated: From the oblong the limbs appear, the head-hairs, body-hairs, and nails.

original: “Yañcassa bhuñjatī mātā, annaṃ pānañca bhojanaṃ;
analyzed: yat ca assa bhuñjatī mātā annam pānam ca bhojanam
translated: ‘Whatever food and drink his mother takes,

original: Tena so tattha yāpeti, mātukucchigato naroti. ;🔽Imaṃ mātukucchiyaṃ kalalādibhāvaṃ, mātukucchito ca nikkhanto mandadasakādibhāvaṃ
analyzed: tena saḥ tattha yāpeti mātukucchi gataḥ  imam mātukucchiyam kalala ādi bhāvam mātukucchitaḥ ca nikkhantaḥ manda dasaka ādi bhāvam
translated: Thereby that man in the mother’s womb is sustained’ .🔽So the being in the mother’s womb goes on constantly and always undergoing change in the states of morsel, and so on, and on leaving the womb he goes on undergoing change in the states of the infant, and so on,

original: āpajjamāno satataṃ samitaṃ gacchati. Sa gacchaṃ na nivattatīti sacāyaṃ evaṃ gacchanto
analyzed: āpajjamānaḥ satatam samitam gacchati sa gaccham na nivattati iti sacā ayam evam gacchantaḥ
translated: ‘He goes on, he does not return’: this being who goes on in this way

original: puna abbudato kalalabhāvaṃ, pesiādito vā abbudādibhāvaṃ, khiḍḍādasakato mandadasakabhāvaṃ,🔽vaṇṇadasakādito vā khiḍḍādasakādibhāvaṃ pāpuṇituṃ na nivattati. original: hatthato muccanti, maccuno pana santikā muccituṃ na sakkonti. Pabhañjantīti etehi

original: hatthiādīhi paccatthikarājūnaṃ nagarāni pabhañjanti. Padhaṃsayantīti mahājanaṃ dhaṃsentā

original: padhaṃsentā jīvitakkhayaṃ pāpenti. Na maccunoti tepi maraṇakāle patte maccuno bhañjituṃ na sakkonti.

original: Bhinnagaḷā pabhinnāti tīsu ṭhānesu pabhinnā hutvā madaṃ gaḷantā, paggharitamadāti

analyzed: atthaḥ na maccunā iti te api mahā maccum madditum na sakkonti issāsinaḥ iti issāsāḥ dhanuggahāḥ

translated: ‘The life of breathing things’ here means the life of these breathing things in this world. ‘Like a cloth on a post, like a tree on a river bank’ : for the drunkard Suradhutta, when he sees liquor, takes off the cloth tied round his belly and drinks it; and like the tree growing on the river bank which falls down when the bank collapses, so too, the life of beings is unsteady like the cloth and the tree. ‘Gods’ : ‘Like fruits from a tree’ : just as ripe fruits fall from a tree when struck by the wind, so too, these young men, struck by the wind of ageing, fall from life and drop on the ground of death. ‘Young’ : even those who are only in the state of a foetus. ‘Middle-aged’ : those who are in the middle of the life-span of women and men, i.e. hermaphrodites.

original: Tārakarājasannibhoti yathā tārakarājā kāḷapakkhe khīṇo, puna juṇhapakkhe pūrati,
analyzed: tāraka rāja sannibhaḥ ti yathā tāraka rājā kāḷa pakkhe khīṇaḥ puna juṇha pakkhe pūrati
translated: ‘The life of breathing things’ is the life of these breathing things in this world. ‘Like a cloth to a drunkard’ : for the drunkard Suradhutta, when he sees liquor, takes off the cloth tied round his belly and drinks. ‘Like a tree to a river bank’ : for the tree grows on the bank of a river, and when the bank collapses it collapses too. Just as this cloth and this tree are unsteady, so too is the life of beings, gods. ‘Like fruits from a tree’ : just as ripe fruits, when shaken by the wind, fall from the tree to the ground, so too these young men, shaken by the wind of old age, fall from life to the ground of death. ‘Young’ : even those who are only in the state of a foetus. ‘Middle-aged’ : those who are in the middle of the life-span of women and men, i.e. hermaphrodites. ‘Like the king of stars’ : just as the king of stars, the moon, wanes in the dark fortnight and waxes in the bright fortnight,

original: na evaṃ sattānaṃ vayo. Sattānañhi yaṃ abbhatītaṃ, gatameva dāni taṃ, na tassa punāgamanaṃ
analyzed: na evam sattānam vayaḥ sattānam hi yam abbhatītam gatam eva dāni tam na tassa puna āgamanam
translated: so too is not the life of beings. For what has passed for beings is gone and does not return.

original: atthi. Kuto sukhanti jarājiṇṇassa kāmaguṇesu ratipi natthi, te paṭicca uppajjanakasukhaṃ
analyzed: atthi kutas sukhanti jarā jiṇṇassa kāma guṇesu rati pi na atthi te paṭicca uppajjanaka sukham
translated: There is no delight. Where is happiness? In one who is worn out by old age there is no delight in the strands of sensual pleasure,

original: kutoyeva. Yakkhāti mahiddhikā yakkhā. Pisācāti paṃsupisācakā. Petāti pettivisayikā.
analyzed: kutoyā iva yakkhā ati mahiddhikāḥ yakkhā pisācā ati paṃsupisācakā petā ati pettivisayikā
translated: and how much less so the happiness that arises in dependence on them. Yakkhas: powerful yakkhas. Pisacas: pisacas of the dust. Petas: those who are in the realm of petas.

original: Assasantīti assāsavātena upahananti, āvisantīti vā attho. Na maccunoti maccuṃ pana
analyzed: assasanti iti assāsa vātena upahananti āvisanti iti vā atthaḥ na maccunā iti maccum pana
translated: Assasanti: they attack with the wind of their breath; the meaning is, they enter into. Not even the King of Death

original: tepi assāsena upahanituṃ vā āvisituṃ vā na sakkonti. Nijjhapanaṃ karontīti balikammavasena🔽khamāpenti pasādenti. Aparādhaketi rājāparādhakārake. Dūsaketi rajjadūsake. Heṭhaketi
analyzed: te api assāsena upahanitum vā āvisitum vā na sakkonti nijjhapanam karonti iti bali kamma vasena  khamāpenti pasādenti aparādhaka iti rāja aparādha kārake dūsaka iti rajja dūsake heṭhaka iti
translated: can they attack or enter with their breath. Nijjhapanam: they make a confession;

original: sandhicchedādīhi lokaviheṭhake. Rājānoti rājāno. Viditvāna dosanti dosaṃ jānitvā
analyzed: loka viheṭhake rājānaḥ iti rājānaḥ dosanti dosam jānitvā
translated: by way of a sacrifice they ask for forgiveness and win over. Aparadha: those who have offended the king. Dūsaka: those who have offended the realm. Heṭha: those who have harmed the world by cutting the joints, etc. Rājā: the kings. Viditvāna dosam: having known the offence;

original: yathānurūpena daṇḍena daṇḍentīti attho. Na maccunoti tepi maccuṃ daṇḍayituṃ na sakkonti.
analyzed: yathā anurūpena daṇḍena daṇḍenti iti atthaḥ na maccunoti te api maccum daṇḍayitum na sakkonti
translated: the meaning is, having punished them with a fitting punishment. Not even the King of Death

analyzed: nijjhapetum ti sakkhīhi attanaḥ niraparādha bhāvam pakāsetvā pasādetum na aḍḍhakā balavā

original: tejavāpīti “ime aḍḍhā, ayaṃ kāyabalañāṇabalādīhi balavā, ayaṃ tejavā”ti evampi na🔽paccurājassa apekkhaṃ atthi, ekasmimpi satte apekkhaṃ pemaṃ sineho natthi, sabbameva
analyzed: tejavāpī iti ime aḍḍhā ayam kāya bala ñāṇa bala ādīhi balavā ayam evam pi na  paccurājassa apekkham atthi ekasmim pi satte apekkham pemam sinehaḥ natthi sabbam eva
translated: “Tejavā” : “These are rich, this one is powerful by virtue of his physical strength, knowledge, etc., this one is tejavā” .🔽He has no regard for a king who has come after him; he has no regard, no love, no affection for any being; he shows that he tramples down everything.

original: abhimaddatīti dasseti. Pasayhāti balakkārena abhibhavitvā. Na maccunoti tepi maccuṃ
analyzed: abhimaddati iti dasseti pasayhāti balakkārena abhibhavitvā na maccunoti te pi maccum
translated: “Pasayha” : having overcome by force. “Na maccuno” : they cannot eat death.

original: khādituṃ na sakkonti. Karontāti māyaṃ karontā. Mohentīti abhūtaṃ bhūtaṃ katvā dassentā
analyzed: khāditum na sakkonti karontā ati māyam karontā mohenti iti abhūtam bhūtam katvā dassentā

original: mohenti. Uggatejāti uggatena visatejena samannāgatā. Tikicchakāti visavejjā. Dhammantarī
analyzed: mohenti uggatejā ati uggatena visatejena samannāgatā tikicchakā ati visavejjā dhammantarī
translated: “Uggatejā” : endowed with risen, spread-out brilliance. “Tikicchakā” : physicians. “Dhammantarī” : a kind of medicine.

analyzed: evam mahāsatto catuvīsatiyā gāthāhi pitu dhammam desetvā mahā rāja tumhākam rajjam

analyzed: mama api rajjena atthaḥ natthi iti rajjam pahāya tena saddhiñca eva nikkhami tasmin nikkhante
translated: saying: “I too have no use for the kingdom,” left home and departed with him. When he had left home,

analyzed: brāhmaṇa gahapatika ādayaḥ api iti sakala nagara vāsinaḥ gehāni chaḍḍetvā nikkhamiṃsu
translated: the queen, the ministers, the brahmins, the householders, and so on, all the inhabitants of the city, abandoned their homes and departed.

translated: The meeting was a great one, and the assembly was twelve leagues in extent. Taking this assembly with him, the Great Being entered the Himalayas.

analyzed: itas param mahāsattassa pabbajjā ca ovāda dānam ca brahma loka parāyaṇa tā ca parisāya
translated: From this point on, the going forth of the Great Being, the giving of the advice, the going up to the Brahma-world,

translated: Mātaṅga, Cittasambhūta, Sivi, Sirī, and Rohaṇa,

translated: Haṃsa, Sattigumba, Bhallā, Somanassa, and Campeyyaka,

analyzed: sādhu vaḥ katam uposatham karontehi porāṇakāḥ upaḍḍhūposatha kammassa nissandena mahantam
translated: “It is good that you have performed the Uposatha ceremony. As a result of the Uposatha ceremony performed by the ancients, they obtained great

analyzed: yasam paṭilabhiṃsu iti vatvā tehi yācitaḥ atītam āhari  atīte bārāṇasiyam brahmadattaḥ dhammena rajjam kārentaḥ saddhaḥ ahosi dāna sīla uposatha kammesu
translated: fame.” When they asked him to tell the story, he related the following:🔽In the past, while Brahmadatta was righteously ruling Benares, he was faithful and diligent in giving alms, observing the precepts, and performing the Uposatha ceremony.

original: appamatto. So sesepi amaccādayo dānādīsu samādapesi. Purohito panassa parapiṭṭhimaṃsiko
analyzed: appamatto so sese pi amacca ādayaḥ dāna ādīsu samādapesi purohitaḥ panassa para piṭṭhimaṃsiko

analyzed: lañja khādakaḥ kūṭa vinicchayikaḥ ahosi rājā uposatha divase amacca ādayaḥ pakkosāpetvā

analyzed: kūṭaḍḍam katvā upaṭṭhānam āgatam rājā tumhe uposathikā ati amacce pucchanto tvam pi
translated: and perverted justice. When he came to the audience hall, the king asked his ministers, “Are you Uposatha-observers?” and asked,

analyzed: ācariyaḥ uposathikaḥ iti pucchi saḥ musāvādam katvā pāsādāḥ otari atha naṃ ekaḥ
translated: “Teacher, are you an Uposatha-observer?” He lied, saying, “Yes,” and descended from the palace. Then one of his

analyzed: amaccaḥ nanu tumhe na uposathikā ati codesi saḥ āha aham geham  pana gantvā mukham vikkhāletvā uposatham adhiṭṭhāya sāyam na bhuñjissāmi rattim
translated: The minister asked him, “Did you not observe the Uposatha?” He replied, “I ate at the proper time, but after returning home I washed my face, observed the Uposatha, and will not eat in the evening.🔽I will observe the Uposatha all night.”

original: sīlaṃ rakkhissāmi, evaṃ me upaḍḍhūposathakammaṃ bhavissatī”ti? “Sādhu, ācariyā”ti.
analyzed: sīlam rakkhissāmi evam me upaḍḍhūposatha kammam bhavissati iti sādhu ācariya ati
translated: The minister asked him, “Are you not observing the Uposatha?” He replied, “I have eaten at the proper time, but I have gone home, washed my mouth, and undertaken the Uposatha. I will not eat in the evening. I will observe the precepts during the night. In this way I will have half-observed the Uposatha.” “Very well, teacher.”🔽He went home and did as he had said.

translated: On another occasion, while the king was sitting in the judgment hall, a virtuous woman who was carrying a load

analyzed: kāle mukham vikkhāletum ārabhi tasmin khaṇe brāhmaṇassa su pakkānam amba phalānam  saḥ tassāḥ uposathika bhāvam ñatvā imāni khāditvā uposathikā

translated: Knowing that she was observing the Uposatha, he gave her the mangoes, saying, “Eat these and then observe the Uposatha.” She did as he said. This was the brahmin’s deed.

original: So aparabhāge kālaṃ katvā himavantapadese kosikigaṅgāya tīre tiyojanike ambavane🔽ramaṇīye bhūmibhāge sobhaggappatte kanakavimāne alaṅkatasirisayane suttappabuddho
analyzed: saḥ aparabhāge kālam katvā himavanta padese kosikigaṅgāya tīre ti yojanike amba vane  ramaṇīye bhūmi bhāge sobhagga ppatte kanaka vimāne alaṅkata siri sayane sutta ppabuddhaḥ
translated: Later, when he died, he was reborn in a golden mansion, three leagues in extent, in a delightful spot in a mango grove on the banks of the Kosi River in the Himalayas.

original: viya nibbatti alaṅkatapaṭiyatto uttamarūpadharo soḷasasahassadevakaññāparivāro. So🔽rattiññeva taṃ sirisampattiṃ anubhoti. Vemānikapetabhāvena hissa kammasarikkhako🔽vipāko ahosi, tasmā aruṇe uggacchante ambavanaṃ pavisati, paviṭṭhakkhaṇeyevassa dibbattabhāvo
analyzed: viya nibbatti alaṅkata paṭiyatto uttama rūpa dharo soḷasa sahassa deva kaññā parivāro so  rattiñca eva tam siri sampattim anubhoti vemānika peta bhāvena hissa kamma sarikkhako  vipākaḥ ahosi tasmai aruṇe uggacchante ambavanam pavisati dibba tta bhāvaḥ
translated: He was reborn as a god, endowed with the thirty-two marks of a Great Man, surrounded by sixteen thousand celestial nymphs, and dressed in celestial garments.🔽He enjoyed this glory only during the night. For the result of his deed as a ghost of a vampire was in accordance with the deed itself. Therefore, when the dawn broke, he entered the mango grove, and the moment he entered, his celestial form disappeared, and he was reborn in a body eighty cubits tall.

original: antaradhāyati, asītihatthatālakkhandhappamāṇo attabhāvo nibbattati, sakalasarīraṃ
analyzed: antaradhāyati asīti hattha tāla kkhandha ppamāṇaḥ atta bhāvaḥ nibbattati sakala sarīram

analyzed: jhāyati su pupphita kiṃsukaḥ viya hoti dvīsu hatthesu ekekā ava tattha mahā kuddāla ppamāṇā

analyzed: nakhāḥ honti tehi nakhehi attanaḥ piṭṭhi maṃsam phāletvā uppāṭetvā khādantaḥ vedanā appattaḥ
translated: With those nails he tore the flesh from his back and ate it, and in his agony he cried out.

original: mahāravaṃ ravanto dukkhaṃ anubhoti. Sūriye atthaṅgate taṃ sarīraṃ antaradhāyati,
analyzed: mahā ravam ravantaḥ dukkham anubhoti sūriye atthaṅgate tam sarīram antaradhāyati
translated: and he suffers pain, crying out with a loud voice. When the sun sets, his body disappears,

analyzed: dibba sarīram nibbattati alaṅkata paṭiyattāḥ dibba nāṭakitthiyaḥ nānā tūriyāni gahetvā
translated: and a divine body appears, and celestial dancing-girls, adorned and decorated, taking various musical instruments,

analyzed: parivārenti saḥ mahā sampattim anubhavantaḥ ramaṇīye amba vane dibba pāsādam abhiruhati
translated: surround him. And he, enjoying great prosperity, ascends a divine palace in a delightful mango-grove.

original: Iti so uposathikāya itthiyā ambaphaladānassa nissandena tiyojanikaṃ ambavanaṃ paṭilabhati,
analyzed: iti saḥ uposathikāya itthiyāḥ amba phala dānassa nissandena ti yojanikam ambavanam paṭilabhati

analyzed: nissandena rattim sampattim anubhoti soḷasa sahassa nāṭaka itthīhi parivutaḥ paricāresi  tasmin kāle bārāṇasi rājā kāmesu dosam disvā isipabbajjam pabbajitvā adhogaṅgāya ramaṇīye
translated: he enjoys prosperity by night, and he sports surrounded by sixteen thousand dancing-girls.🔽At that time the king of Bārāṇasī, seeing the danger in sensual pleasures, went forth into the homeless life of a seer, and he lived by gleaning, having a leaf-hut made for him on a delightful piece of land on the Adhogaṅgā.

original: bhūmipadese paṇṇasālaṃ kāretvā uñchācariyāya yāpento vihāsi. Athekadivasaṃ tamhā
analyzed: bhūmi padese paṇṇasālam kāretvā uñchā cariyāya yāpentaḥ vihāsi atha eka divasam tamhā
translated: One day, after he had gone out for alms,

translated: A ripe mango, the size of a large water-pot, fell from a tree into the Ganges, and was carried down by the current.🔽It came to the bathing-place of the ascetic,🔽and he, while washing his mouth, saw it coming down the middle of the river.
