translated: He went into the water, and taking it, brought it to his hermitage, and placing it in the fire-house, he cut it open with his knife,

original: divase yāva parikkhayā khādi. Tasmiṃ pana khīṇe aññaṃ phalāphalaṃ khādituṃ nāsakkhi,
analyzed: divase yāva parikkhayā khādi tasmin pana khīṇe aññam phalāphalam khāditum na asakkhi
translated: and ate as much as he needed for his support. The rest he covered with plantain leaves, and day after day he ate it until it was all gone. When it was all gone, he could not eat any other fruit,

original: rasataṇhāya bajjhitvā “tameva ambapakkaṃ khādissāmī”ti nadītīraṃ gantvā nadiṃ olokento
analyzed: rasa taṇhāya bajjhitvā tam eva amba pakkam khādissāmi iti nadī tīram gantvā nadim olokento
translated: and being overcome by a craving for the taste of that mango, he went to the bank of the river and looked at the river,

original: “ambaṃ alabhitvā na uṭṭhahissāmī”ti sanniṭṭhānaṃ katvā nisīdi. So tattha nirāhāro
analyzed: ambam a labhitvā na uṭṭhahissāmi iti sanniṭṭhānam katvā nisīdi saḥ tattha nirāhāraḥ
translated: and made a vow, saying, “I will not rise up until I get the mango.” And he sat down. There he remained without food,

original: ekampi divasaṃ, dvepi, tīṇi, catu, pañca, cha divasāni vātātapena parisussanto ambaṃ
analyzed: ekam pi divasam dve pi tīṇi catu pañca cha divasāni vāta ātapena parisussantaḥ ambam
translated: and for one day, and for two days, and for three, four, five, and six days, drying up with the wind and the heat, thinking of the mango.

original: olokento nisīdi. Atha sattame divase nadīdevatā āvajjamānā taṃ kāraṇaṃ ñatvā “ayaṃ🔽tāpaso taṇhāvasiko hutvā sattāhaṃ nirāhāro gaṅgaṃ olokento nisīdi, imassa ambapakkaṃ🔽adātuṃ na yuttaṃ, alabhanto marissati, dassāmi tassā”ti āgantvā gaṅgāya upari ākāse
analyzed: olokentaḥ nisīdi atha sattame divase nadī devatā āvajjamānā tam kāraṇam ñatvā ayam  tāpasaḥ taṇhāvasikaḥ hutvā satta aham nirāhāraḥ gaṅgam olokentaḥ nisīdi imassa amba pakkam  a dātum na yuttam a labhantaḥ marissati dassāmi tassa ati āgantvā gaṅgāya upari ākāse
translated: and sat down looking at it. Then on the seventh day the river-goddess, remembering, understood the reason, and thinking, “This ascetic, being subject to craving, has sat down looking at the Ganges for seven days without eating,🔽it is not right for me not to give him the ripe mango, if he does not get it he will die, I will give it to him,” she came and stood in the sky above the Ganges,🔽and having taken a ripe mango, she said this to the ascetic: “Take this ripe mango, ascetic.”

original: ṭhatvā tena saddhiṃ sallapantī paṭhamaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: ṭhatvā tena saddhim sat lapantī paṭhamam gātham āha
translated: and sat down looking at the river. Then on the seventh day the river goddess, remembering, understood the reason, and thinking, “This ascetic, being subject to craving, has sat down looking at the Ganges for seven days without eating. It is not right for me not to give him a ripe mango. If he does not get it he will die. I will give it to him,” she came and stood in the air above the Ganges and spoke this first verse to him:

original: “Kiṃchando kimadhippāyo, eko sammasi ghammani;
analyzed: kiṃchandaḥ kimadhippāyaḥ ekaḥ sammasi ghammani
translated: “What do you desire, what do you intend, that you alone are sitting in the heat?

original: Kiṃpatthayāno kiṃ esaṃ, kena atthena brāhmaṇā”ti.
analyzed: kiṃpatthayāno kim kena atthena brāhmaṇa ati
translated: What do you seek, what do you want, for what purpose, O ascetic?”

original: Tattha chandoti ajjhāsayo. Adhippāyoti cittaṃ. Sammasīti acchasi. Ghammanīti gimhe.
analyzed: tattha chandaḥ iti ajjhāsayaḥ adhippāyaḥ ti cittam sammasi iti acchasi ghammani iti gimhe
translated: Herein, desire is intention. Intend is thought. Sitting is lying down. Heat is summer.

original: Esanti esanto. Brāhmaṇāti pabbajitattā tāpasaṃ ālapati. Idaṃ vuttaṃ hoti – brāhmaṇa,🔽tvaṃ kiṃ adhippāyo kiṃ cintento kiṃ patthento kiṃ gavesanto kenatthena imasmiṃ gaṅgātīre
analyzed: esanti esantaḥ brāhmaṇa ati pabbajita ttā tāpasam ālapati idam vuttam hoti brāhmaṇa  tvam kim adhippāyaḥ kim cintento kim patthento kim gavesanto kena atthena imasmin gaṅgā tīre
translated: Want is seeking. Ascetic, she addresses the ascetic because he is a monk. This is what is said: O ascetic,

original: gaṅgaṃ olokento nisinnoti.
analyzed: gaṅgam olokentaḥ nisinnoti
translated: what do you intend, what do you think, what do you seek, what do you want, for what purpose are you sitting looking at the Ganges on this bank of the Ganges?

original: Taṃ sutvā tāpaso nava gāthā abhāsi –
analyzed: tam sutvā tāpasaḥ nava gāthāḥ abhāsi
translated: When the ascetic heard this, he spoke nine verses:

original: “Yathā mahā vāridharo, kumbho supariṇāhavā;
analyzed: yathā mahā vāridharaḥ kumbhaḥ su pariṇāhavā
translated: “Just as a great rain-cloud, a pot well-shaped,

original: Tathūpamaṃ ambapakkaṃ, vaṇṇagandharasuttamaṃ.
analyzed: tathūpamam amba pakkam vaṇṇa gandhara suttamam
translated: So was the ripe mango, best in colour, smell and taste.

original: “Taṃ vuyhamānaṃ sotena, disvānāmalamajjhime;
analyzed: tam vuyhamānam sotena disvānām alam ajjhime
translated: “Seeing it being carried away by the current, I, the pure one, the middle one,

original: Pāṇībhi naṃ gahetvāna, agyāyatanamāhariṃ.
analyzed: pāṇībhiḥ nam agya āyatanam āharim
translated: Having taken it with my hands, brought it to the sacrificial fire.

original: “Tato kadalipattesu, nikkhipitvā sayaṃ ahaṃ;
analyzed: tatas kadali pattesu nikkhipitvā sayam aham
translated: “Then, having placed it on the plantain leaves, I myself

original: Satthena naṃ vikappetvā, khuppipāsaṃ ahāsi me.
analyzed: satthena nam vikappetvā khuppipāsam ahāsi me
translated: Having cut it with a knife, hunger and thirst were removed.

original: “Sohaṃ apetadaratho, byantībhūto dukhakkhamo;
analyzed: saḥ ham apeta darathaḥ byantībhūtaḥ dukha kkhamaḥ
translated: “I, free from sickness, having become calm, able to endure suffering,

original: Assādaṃ nādhigacchāmi, phalesvaññesu kesuci.
analyzed: assādam na adhigacchāmi phalesu aññesu kesuci
translated: I do not attain satisfaction in any other fruit.

original: “Sosetvā nūna maraṇaṃ, taṃ mamaṃ āvahissati;
analyzed: sosetvā nūna maraṇam tam mamam āvahissati
translated: “Surely, having remembered death, it will come to me;

original: Ambaṃ yassa phalaṃ sādu, madhuraggaṃ manoramaṃ;
analyzed: ambam yassa phalam sādu madhuraggam manoramam
translated: The mango, whose fruit is sweet, with a delicious taste, delightful,

original: Yamuddhariṃ vuyhamānaṃ, udadhismā mahaṇṇave.
analyzed: yam ud harim vuyhamānam udadhisma mahaṇṇave
translated: Which I rescued from being carried away by the great ocean.

original: “Akkhātaṃ te mayā sabbaṃ, yasmā upavasāmahaṃ;
analyzed: akkhātam te mayā sabbam yasmai upavasāmaham
translated: “All that has been told to you by me, because I am fasting,

original: Rammaṃ pati nisinnosmi, puthulomāyutā puthu.
analyzed: nisinnaḥ asmi puthu loma ayutā puthu
translated: I am sitting in a delightful place, surrounded by a multitude of many thousands.

original: “Tvañca kho meva akkhāhi, attānamapalāyini;
analyzed: tvañca kho mā iva akkhāhi attānam apalāyini
translated: “And you also tell me about yourself, who does not flee,

original: Kā vā tvamasi kalyāṇi, kissa vā tvaṃ sumajjhime.
analyzed: kā vā tvam asi kalyāṇi kissa vā tvam su majjhime
translated: “What are you, lady? What is your business, fair lady?”

original: “Ruppapaṭṭapalimaṭṭhīva, byagghīva girisānujā;
analyzed: ruppa paṭṭa palimaṭṭhī iva byagghī iva giri sānu jā
translated: “Like a figure in bas-relief, like a tigress in a mountain-cave,

original: Yā santi nāriyo devesu, devānaṃ paricārikā.
analyzed: yāḥ santi nāriyaḥ devesu devānam paricārikāḥ
translated: The women who are in the heavens, the attendants of the gods,

original: “Yā ca manussalokasmiṃ, rūpenānvāgatitthiyo;
analyzed: yā ca manussa lokasmim rūpena anvāgatitthiyaḥ
translated: And those in the world of men who are comely in their beauty,

original: Rūpena te sadisī natthi, devesu gandhabbamanussaloke;
analyzed: rūpena te sadisī na atthi devesu gandhabba manussa loke
translated: In beauty you are their equal, among gods, gandhabbas, and men.

original: Puṭṭhāsi me cārupubbaṅgi, brūhi nāmañca bandhave”ti.🔽Tattha vāridharo kumbhoti udakaghaṭo. Supariṇāhavāti susaṇṭhāno. Vaṇṇagandharasuttamanti🔽vaṇṇagandharasehi uttamaṃ. Disvānāti disvā. Amalamajjhimeti nimmalamajjhe. Devataṃ
analyzed: puṭṭhā asi me cāru pubbaṅgi brūhi nāmañca bandhava iti  tattha vāridharaḥ kumbho ti udaka ghaṭaḥ su pariṇāha vāti su saṇṭhānaḥ  vaṇṇa gandha rasehi uttamam amala majjhimā iti nimmala majjhe devatam
translated: You are asked, O you with the lovely brow, tell me your name and your lineage.”

original: ālapanto evamāha. Pāṇībhīti hatthehi. Agyāyatanamāharinti attano aggihutasālaṃ āhariṃ.
analyzed: ālapantaḥ evam āha pāṇībhi iti hatthehi agi āyatanam āharinti attanaḥ aggi hutasālam āharin
translated: Herein, a water-bearing pot is a water-jar. Well-shaped means well-formed. In color, scent, and taste is supreme means it is supreme in color, scent, and taste. Having seen means having seen. With a pure middle means with a stainless middle. Addressing the deity he said: With my hands means with my hands. I brought the sacrificial fire means I brought my sacrificial fire.

original: Vikappetvāti vicchinditvā. “Vikantetvā”tipi pāṭho. “Khādi”nti pāṭhaseso. Ahāsi meti
analyzed: vikappetvā iti vicchinditvā pāṭhaḥ khādinti pāṭha sesaḥ ahāsi mā iti
translated: Having cut it up means having divided it. There is also the reading “having opened it.” The reading “I ate” is a variant. I ate means I ate it.

original: taṃ jivhagge ṭhapitamattameva satta rasaharaṇisahassāni pharitvā mama khudañca pipāsañca
analyzed: tam jivhagge ṭhapita mattam eva satta rasaharaṇi sahassāni pharitvā mama khudan ca pipāsan ca
translated: As soon as it was placed in his mouth, it spread out through the seven thousand taste-buds and removed his hunger and thirst.

original: hari. Apetadarathoti vigatakāyacittadaratho. Sudhābhojanaṃ bhuttassa viya hi tassa
analyzed: sudhā bhojanam bhuttassa viya hi tassa
translated: Free from distress: free from bodily and mental distress. For it removed all his distress as though he had eaten a nourishing meal.

original: sabbadarathaṃ apahari. Byantībhūtoti tassa ambapakkassa vigatanto jāto, parikkhīṇaambapakko
analyzed: sabbadaratham apahari byantībhūto ti tassa amba pakkassa vigata antaḥ jātaḥ parikkhīṇa amba pakkaḥ
translated: It became exhausted: the fruit’s sap was exhausted, the fruit was fully ripe.🔽It was burnt up: the meaning is, it was digested.

original: hutvāti attho. Dukhakkhamoti dukkhena asātena kāyakkhamena ceva cittakkhamena ca
analyzed: hutvā iti atthaḥ dukha kkhamaḥ ti dukkhena asātena kāya kkhamena ca iva citta kkhamena ca
translated: Able to endure pain: endowed with bodily and mental strength that could not be overcome by pain.

original: samannāgato. Aññesu pana kadalipanasādīsu phalesu parittakampi assādaṃ nādhigacchāmi,
analyzed: samannāgataḥ aññesu pana kadali panasa ādīsu phalesu parittakam pi assādam na adhigacchāmi
translated: But in the other fruits, such as the breadfruit and the jackfruit, I found no taste at all,

original: sabbāni me jivhāya ṭhapitamattāni tittakāneva sampajjantīti dīpeti.
analyzed: sabbāni me jivhāya ṭhapita mattāni tittakāna eva sampajjanti iti dīpeti
translated: and as soon as they were placed in my mouth they became bitter.”🔽Having dried it up: having dried it up and withered it by fasting.

original: Sosetvāti nirāhāratāya sosetvā sukkhāpetvā. Taṃ mamanti taṃ mama. Yassāti yaṃ assa,
analyzed: sosetvā ati nirāhāra tāya sosetvā sukkhāpetvā tam mamanti tam mama yassa ati yam assa
translated: That was my food: that was the food which,🔽was sweet to me.🔽What was sweet to me: what was sweet for me.

original: ahosīti attho. Idaṃ vuttaṃ hoti – yaṃ phalaṃ mama sādu ahosi, yamahaṃ gambhīre puthulaudakakkhandhasaṅkhāte
analyzed: ahosi iti attho idam vuttam hoti yam phalam mama sādu ahosi yam aham gambhīre puthula odaka kkhandha saṅkhāte
translated: The meaning is: “What fruit was sweet to me, which I ate in the deep, wide, vast expanse of water called the ocean,

original: mahaṇṇave vuyhamānaṃ tato udadhismā uddhariṃ, taṃ ambaṃ mama maraṇaṃ āvahissatīti🔽maññāmi, mayhaṃ taṃ alabhantassa jīvitaṃ nappavattissatīti. Upavasāmīti khuppipāsāhi
analyzed: mahaṇṇave vuyhamānam tatas udadhismai uddharim tam ambam mama maraṇam āvahissati iti  maññāmi mayham tam a labhantassa jīvitam na pavattissati iti upavasāmi iti khuppipāsāhi
translated: I thought: ‘If I do not get that mango, my life will not continue.’🔽I am living, I am staying, having approached, with hunger and thirst.

original: upagato vasāmi. Rammaṃ pati nisinnosmīti ramaṇīyaṃ nadiṃ pati ahaṃ nisinno. Puthulomāyutā
analyzed: upagataḥ vasāmi nisinnaḥ asmi iti ramaṇīyam nadim pati aham nisinnaḥ
translated: I am sitting facing the delightful river.

original: puthūti ayaṃ nadī puthulomehi macchehi āyutā puthu vipulā, api nāma me ito sotthi
analyzed: ayam nadī puthulomehi macchehi āyutā puthu vipulā api nāma me itas
translated: The river is full of many fishes with many streams.🔽I hope I will be safe from this.

original: bhaveyyāti adhippāyo. Apalāyinīti apalāyitvā mama sammukhe ṭhiteti taṃ devataṃ ālapati.
analyzed: bhaveyya ati adhippāyaḥ apalāyinī iti a palāyitvā mama sammukhe ṭhitā iti tam devatam ālapati
translated: The meaning is: not having fled, standing in front of me.🔽The reading is also ‘apalasini’. The meaning is: not having fled, with a faultless body.

original: “Apalāsinī”tipi pāṭho, palāsarahite anavajjasarīreti attho. Kissa vāti kissa vā kāraṇā
analyzed: apalāsinī iti pi pāṭhaḥ palāsa rahite anavajja sarīrā iti attho kissa vā ati kissa vā kāraṇā
translated: For what? For what reason?

original: idhāgatāsīti pucchati.
analyzed: idha āgatā asi iti pucchati
translated: I ask: ‘Why have you come here?’🔽Like a golden plate well polished: like a golden plate well rubbed.

original: Rūpapaṭṭapalimaṭṭhīvāti suṭṭhu parimajjitakañcanapaṭṭasadisī. Byagghīvāti līlāvilāsena
analyzed: rūpa paṭṭa palim aṭṭhīvāti suṭṭhu parimajjita kañcana paṭṭa sadisī byagghī iva ati līlā vilāsena
translated: Like a peacock: with the gracefulness of a peacock.

original: taruṇabyagghapotikā viya. Devānanti channaṃ kāmāvacaradevānaṃ. Yā ca manussalokasminti🔽yā ca manussaloke. Rūpenānvāgatitthiyoti rūpena anvāgatā itthiyo natthīti attano
analyzed: taruṇa byaggha potikāḥ channam kāmāvacara devānam yā ca manussa lokasmin ti  yā ca manussa loke rūpena anvāgata itthiyā ti rūpena anvāgatā itthiyaḥ na atthi iti attanaḥ
translated: Like a young tigress. Gods: of the six kinds of sensual-sphere gods. And in the human world:🔽And in the human world. No woman has come up to me in beauty:

original: sambhāvanāya evamāha. Tava rūpasadisāya nāma na bhavitabbanti hissa adhippāyo. Gandhabbamanussaloketi🔽mūlagandhādinissitesu gandhabbesu ca manussaloke ca. Cārupubbaṅgīti cārunā pubbaṅgena
analyzed: sambhāvanāya evam āha tava rūpa sadisāya nāma na bhavitabbanti hissa adhippāyaḥ gandhabba manussa loka iti  mūla gandha ādi nissitesu gandhabbesu ca manussa loke ca cāru pubbaṅgī iti cārunā pubbaṅgena
translated: thinking “There is no woman who has come up to me in beauty,” he said this. The idea is that “There should not be one who is like you in beauty.” In the world of gandhabbas and men:

original: ūrulakkhaṇena samannāgate. Nāmañca bandhaveti attano nāmagottañca bandhave ca mayhaṃ akkhāhīti vadati.
analyzed: ūru lakkhaṇena samannāgate nāmañca bandhave iti attanaḥ nāma gottañca bandhave ca mayham akkhāhi iti vadati
translated: in the gandhabbas who are based on root-odours, etc., and in the human world. Charmingly-limbed: endowed with a charming thigh, a distinguishing mark. Name and clan: he says, “Tell me your name and clan and your lover.”

original: Tato devadhītā aṭṭha gāthā abhāsi –
analyzed: tatas deva dhītāḥ aṭṭha gāthāḥ abhāsi
translated: Then the devatā spoke eight stanzas:

original: “Yaṃ tvaṃ pati nisinnosi, rammaṃ brāhmaṇa kosikiṃ;
analyzed: yam tvam pati nisinnaḥ asi rammam brāhmaṇa kosikim
translated: “The lovely Kosi, brahmin, that you sit upon,

original: Sāhaṃ bhusālayāvutthā, varavārivahoghasā.
analyzed: sā aham bhusa ālayau utthā vara vāri vaha ughasā
translated: I am she, arisen from the Bhusālaya, a stream of the best of waters.

original: “Nānādumagaṇākiṇṇā, bahukā girikandarā;
analyzed: nānā duma gaṇa ākiṇṇā bahukā giri kandarā
translated: “Filled with various animal groups, many are the mountain caves,

original: Mameva pamukhā honti, abhisandanti pāvuse.
analyzed: mama iva pamukhāḥ honti abhisandanti pāvuse
translated: I am their chief, and in the cold weather they gather round me.

original: “Atho bahū vanatodā, nīlavārivahindharā;
analyzed: atho bahū vana todā nīla vāri vahindharā
translated: “And many forest-streams, too, with blue waters, and water-catchers,

original: Bahukā nāgavittodā, abhisandanti vārinā.
analyzed: bahukāḥ nāga vitta udāḥ abhisandanti vārinā
translated: And many elephant-streams, too, flow together with water.

original: “Tā ambajambulabujā, nīpā tālā cudumbarā;
analyzed: tāḥ amba jambu labu jāḥ nīpā tālā cudumbarā
translated: “And mango-trees, rose-apple trees, and breadfruit trees, and coconut trees, and palm trees, and citron trees,

original: Bahūni phalajātāni, āvahanti abhiṇhaso.
analyzed: bahūni phala jātāni āvahanti
translated: And many kinds of fruit trees bear fruit again and again.

original: “Yaṃ kiñci ubhato tīre, phalaṃ patati ambuni;
analyzed: yam kiñci ubhatas tīre phalam patati ambuni
translated: “Whatever fruit falls on both banks in the water,

original: Asaṃsayaṃ taṃ sotassa, phalaṃ hoti vasānugaṃ.
analyzed: asaṃsayam tam sotassa phalam hoti vasā anugam
translated: Undoubtedly that is the water’s fruit, following its will.

original: “Etadaññāya medhāvi, puthupañña suṇohi me;
analyzed: etat aññāya medhāvi puthu pañña suṇohi me
translated: “Understanding this, the wise one, the one of wide wisdom, listen to me:

original: Mā rocaya mabhisaṅgaṃ, paṭisedha janādhipa.
analyzed: mā rocaya mā abhisaṅgam paṭisedha janādhipa
translated: Do not delight in, do not be attached to, do not oppose the people, lord of the people.

original: “Na vāhaṃ vaḍḍhavaṃ maññe, yaṃ tvaṃ raṭṭhābhivaḍḍhana;
analyzed: na vā aham vaḍḍhavam maññe yam tvam raṭṭha abhivaḍḍhana
translated: “I do not think you are increasing, that you are increasing the kingdom,

original: Āceyyamāno rājisi, maraṇaṃ abhikaṅkhasi.
analyzed: āceyyamānaḥ rājisi maraṇam abhikaṅkhasi
translated: Being asked, king, you long for death.

original: “Tassa jānanti pitaro, gandhabbā ca sadevakā;
analyzed: tassa jānanti pitaraḥ gandhabbā ca sa devakā
translated: “His fathers know, and the Gandhabbas, and the gods,

original: Ye cāpi isayo loke, saññatattā tapassino;
analyzed: ye ca api isayaḥ loke saññatattā tapassino
translated: And those who are seers in the world, who are self-controlled and have attained to heat .

original: Asaṃsayaṃ tepi jānanti, paṭṭhabhūtā yasassino”ti.
analyzed: asaṃsayam te api jānanti paṭṭha bhūtāḥ yasassino ti
translated: Undoubtedly they too know, the famous ones who have attained to the highest.”

original: Tattha kosikinti yaṃ tvaṃ, brāhmaṇa, rammaṃ kosikiṃ gaṅgaṃ pati nisinno. Bhusālayāvutthāti
analyzed: tattha kosikinti yam tvam brāhmaṇa rammam kosikim gaṅgam pati nisinnaḥ bhusa ālayau uttha ati
translated: Herein, Kosikin means the delightful Kosi river, brahmin, which you are sitting by. Bhusālayāvutth means

original: bhuse caṇḍasote ālayo yassa vimānassa, tasmiṃ adhivatthā, gaṅgaṭṭhakavimānavāsinīti
analyzed: bhuse caṇḍasote ālayaḥ yassa vimānassa tasmin adhivatthā gaṅgaṭṭhaka vimāna vāsinī iti
translated: The meaning is: she who dwells in the mansion that is situated on the bank of the Bhusa River.

original: attho. Varavārivahoghasāti varavārivahena oghena samannāgatā. Pamukhāti tā vuttappakārā
analyzed: atthaḥ vara vāri vaha ogha sā ti vara vāri vahena oghena samannāgatā pamukhā ati tā vutta ppakārā
translated: Possessing a flood of excellent water: possessing a flood of excellent water.

original: girikandarā maṃ pamukhaṃ karonti, ahaṃ tāsaṃ pāmokkhā homīti dasseti. Abhisandantīti
analyzed: giri kandarāḥ mam pamukham karonti aham tāsam pāmokkhā homi iti dasseti abhisandanti iti
translated: Foremost: she shows that the mountain caves of the aforementioned kind make her foremost, that she is their chief.

original: sandanti pavattanti, tato tato āgantvā maṃ kosikigaṅgaṃ pavisantīti attho. Vanatodāti
analyzed: sandanti pavattanti tatas tatas āgantvā mam kosikigaṅgam pavisanti iti atthaḥ vana todā ti
translated: Flowing together: they flow, they proceed; the meaning is: coming from here and there, they enter the Kosi River.

original: na kevalaṃ kandarāva, atha kho bahū vanatodā tamhā tamhā vanamhā udakānipi maṃ bahūni🔽pavisanti. Nīlavārivahindharāti maṇivaṇṇena nīlavārinā yutte udakakkhandhasaṅkhāte
analyzed: na kevalam atha kho bahū tamhā tamhā udakāni bahūni  maṇi vaṇṇena nīla vārinā yutte udaka kkhandha saṅkhāte
translated: From the forest: not only the caves, but also many forest streams from this and that forest enter me,🔽many enter the Kosi River.🔽Bearing blue water: they bear, they carry, the flood called the mass of water, which is connected with blue water of the color of gems.

original: vahe dhārayantiyo. Nāgavittodāti nāgānaṃ vittikārena dhanasaṅkhātena vā udakena samannāgatā.
analyzed: vahe dhārayantiyaḥ nāga vittā udāti nāgānam vitti kārena dhana saṅkhātena vā udakena samannāgatā
translated: Possessing the wealth of the Nāgas: possessing the wealth called water, or the wealth called the Nāgas.

original: Vārināti evarūpā hi bahū nadiyo maṃ vārināva abhisandanti pūrentīti dasseti.
analyzed: evarūpāḥ hi bahū nadiyaḥ mam abhisandanti pūrenti iti dassa iti
translated: Waters: she shows that many rivers of this kind enter the Kosi River, filling it with water.

original: Tāti tā nadiyo. Āvahantīti etāni ambādīni ākaḍḍhanti. Sabbāni hi etāni upayogatthe🔽paccattavacanāni. Atha vā tāti upayogabahuvacanaṃ. Āvahantīti imāni ambādīni tā nadiyo
analyzed: tā ati tāḥ nadiyaḥ āvahanti iti etāni amba ādīni ākaḍḍhanti sabbāni hi etāni upayoga tthe  paccatta vacanāni atha vā tā ati upayoga bahuvacanam āvahanti iti imāni ambā ādīni tāḥ nadiyaḥ
translated: ‘They’: those rivers. ‘Bring’: they bring these mangoes, etc. For all these words are in the instrumental case in the sense of ‘means’.

original: āgacchanti, upagacchantīti attho, evaṃ upagatāni pana mama sotaṃ pavisantīti adhippāyo.
analyzed: āgacchanti upagacchanti iti atthaḥ evam upagatāni pana mama sotam pavisanti iti adhippāyaḥ
translated: Or alternatively, ‘they’ is a plural word for the means. ‘Bring’: these mangoes, etc., come to these rivers, approach them, is the meaning. The intention is that when they have approached in this way, they enter my ear.

original: Sotassāti yaṃ ubhato tīre jātarukkhehi phalaṃ mama ambuni patati, sabbaṃ taṃ mama
analyzed: sotassa ati yam ubhatas tīre jāta rukkhehi phalam mama ambuni patati sabbam tam mama
translated: ‘Of the river’: whatever fruit falls into my mango grove from trees growing on both banks, all that

original: sotasseva vasānugaṃ hoti. Natthettha saṃsayoti evaṃ ambapakkassa nadīsotena āgamanakāraṇaṃ kathesi.
analyzed: sotassa iva vasā anugam hoti nattha ittha saṃsayo ti evam amba pakkassa nadī sotena āgamana kāraṇam kathesi
translated: is subject to my river. There is no doubt about it. So he explained the reason why the mango fruit came to him by way of the river.

original: Medhāvi puthupaññāti ubhayaṃ ālapanameva. Mā rocayāti evaṃ taṇhābhisaṅgaṃ mā rocaya.
analyzed: medhāvi puthu paññā ati ubhayam ālapanam eva mā rocaya ati evam taṇhā abhisaṅgam mā rocaya
translated: ‘Wise, of wide understanding’: both terms are terms of address. ‘Do not delight’: do not delight in such craving and attachment.

original: Paṭisedhāti paṭisedhehi nanti rājānaṃ ovadati. Vaḍḍhavanti paññāvaḍḍhabhāvaṃ paṇḍitabhāvaṃ.
analyzed: paṭisedha ati paṭisedhehi nanti rājānam ovadati vaḍḍhavanti paññāvaḍḍha bhāvam paṇḍita bhāvam
translated: ‘Stop’: he advises the king thus: ‘Stop, stop!’ ‘Increase’: the state of increase of understanding, the state of being wise.

original: Raṭṭhābhivaḍḍhanāti raṭṭhassa abhivaḍḍhana. Āceyyamānoti maṃsalohitehi āciyanto vaḍḍhanto,
analyzed: raṭṭha abhivaḍḍhanā ati raṭṭhassa abhivaḍḍhane āceyyamāno ti maṃsa lohitehi āciyantaḥ vaḍḍhantaḥ
translated: ‘For the growth of the kingdom’: for the increase of the kingdom. ‘Who is being fed’: who is being nourished and grown by flesh and blood,🔽the meaning being ‘who is still young’. ‘King’s seer’: he addresses him thus. The meaning is: ‘I do not think you are wise, since you,

original: taruṇova hutvāti attho. Rājisīti taṃ ālapati. Idaṃ vuttaṃ hoti – yaṃ tvaṃ nirāhāratāya
analyzed: taruṇaḥ iva hutvā iti tam ālapati idam vuttam hoti yam tvam nirāhāra tāya
translated: being dried up by fasting,🔽and still young,

original: sussamāno taruṇova samāno ambalobhena maraṇaṃ abhikaṅkhasi, na ve ahaṃ tava imaṃ🔽paṇḍitabhāvaṃ maññāmīti.🔽Tassāti yo puggalo taṇhāvasiko hoti, tassa taṇhāvasikabhāvaṃ “pitaro”ti saṅkhaṃ gatā
analyzed: su samānaḥ taruṇaḥ uva samānaḥ amba lobhena maraṇam abhikaṅkhasi na ve aham tava imam  paṇḍita bhāvam maññāmi iti  tassa ati yaḥ puggalo taṇhāvasikaḥ hoti tassa taṇhāvasika bhāvam pitaraḥ ti saṅkham gatā
translated: are longing for death through greed for a mango.’

original: brahmāno ca saddhiṃ kāmāvacaradevehi gandhabbā ca vuttappakārā dibbacakkhukā isayo🔽ca asaṃsayaṃ jānanti. Anacchariyañcetaṃ, yaṃ te iddhimanto jāneyyuṃ, “asuko hi nāma
analyzed: brahmānaḥ ca saddhim kāmāvacara devehi gandhabbā ca vutta ppakārāḥ dibba cakkhukāḥ isayo  ca asaṃsayam jānanti yam te iddhimantaḥ jāneyyum asukaḥ hi nāma
translated: ‘They’: the brahmas who are called ‘fathers’ and the gandhabbas of the kind already described, and the seers who have the divine eye, know without doubt the state of being ruled by craving of the person who is ruled by craving.

original: taṇhāvasiko hotī”ti. Puna tesaṃ bhāsamānānaṃ vacanaṃ sutvā yepi tesaṃ paṭṭhabhūtā
analyzed: taṇhāvasikaḥ hoti iti puna tesam bhāsamānānam vacanam sutvā ye pi tesam paṭṭha bhūtā
translated: And this is not surprising that they should know, ‘So-and-so is ruled by craving.’ Moreover, having heard them speaking thus, even those who are their subjects

original: yasassino paricārakā, tepi jānanti. Pāpakammaṃ karontassa hi raho nāma natthīti tāpasassa
analyzed: yasassino paricārakā te api jānanti pāpa kammam karontassa hi rahaḥ nāma natthi iti tāpasassa
translated: and his attendants, who are famous, will know. For one who does evil has no secret.

original: saṃvegaṃ uppādentī evamāha.
analyzed: saṃvegam uppādentī evam āha
translated: So she spoke, arousing remorse in the ascetic.

original: Tato tāpaso catasso gāthā abhāsi –
analyzed: tato tāpasaḥ catassaḥ gāthāḥ abhāsi
translated: Then the ascetic spoke four stanzas:

original: “Evaṃ viditvā vidū sabbadhammaṃ, viddhaṃsanaṃ cavanaṃ jīvitassa;
analyzed: evam viditvā vidū sabba dhammam viddhaṃsanam cavanam jīvitassa
translated: “Thus knowing all things, the wise one, the destruction, the passing away, of life,

original: Na cīyatī tassa narassa pāpaṃ, sace na ceteti vadhāya tassa.
analyzed: na cīyatī tassa narassa pāpam sace na cetā iti vadhāya tassa
translated: The evil of that man does not increase, if he does not intend his death.

original: “Isipūgasamaññāte, evaṃ lokyā viditā sati;
analyzed: isi pūga samaññāte evam lokyā viditā sati
translated: “In the assembly of seers, thus is the world known, by the truth;

original: Anariyaparisambhāse, pāpakammaṃ jigīsasi.
analyzed: anariya parisambhāse pāpa kammam jigīsasi
translated: In the assembly of the ignoble, you seek to do evil.

original: “Sace ahaṃ marissāmi, tīre te puthusussoṇi;
analyzed: sace aham marissāmi tīre te puthusussoṇi
translated: “If I should die, on your bank, O Puthusōṇi,

original: Asaṃsayaṃ taṃ asiloko, mayi pete āgamissati.
analyzed: asaṃsayam tam asi lokaḥ mayi pete āgamissati
translated: No doubt the world of the good will come to me, when I am dead.

original: “Tasmā hi pāpakaṃ kammaṃ, rakkhasseva sumajjhime;
analyzed: tasmā hi pāpakam kammam rakkhassa iva su majjhime
translated: “Therefore, O Rakkhas, I will hide my evil deed well,

original: Mā taṃ sabbo jano pacchā, pakuṭṭhāyi mayi mate”ti.
analyzed: mā tam sabbaḥ janaḥ pacchā pakuṭṭhāyi mayi matā iti
translated: Lest all the people, after my death, should blame me.”

original: Tattha evaṃ viditvāti yathā ahaṃ sīlañca aniccatañca jānāmi, evaṃ jānitvā ṭhitassa.
analyzed: tattha evam viditvā iti yathā aham sīlam ca aniccatam ca jānāmi evam jānitvā ṭhitassa
translated: Herein, thus knowing means: standing thus knowing as I know virtue and impermanence.

original: Vidūti viduno. Sabbadhammanti sabbaṃ sucaritadhammaṃ. Tividhañhi sucaritaṃ idha sabbadhammoti
analyzed: vidu iti viduno sabba dhammam ti sabbam su carita dhammam tividham hi su caritam idha sabba dhammaḥ ti
translated: Vidūti viduno: to the wise. Sabbadhamman: all good conduct is meant here by the word sabbadhamma. For good conduct is threefold.

original: adhippetaṃ. Viddhaṃsananti bhaṅgaṃ. Cavananti cutiṃ. Jīvitassāti āyuno. Idaṃ vuttaṃ
analyzed: adhippetam viddhaṃsananti bhaṅgam cavananti cutim jīvitassa ti āyunaḥ idam vuttam
translated: Vidūti viduno: the wise. Sabbadhamman: all good conduct dhammas. For good conduct is threefold, and here it is intended as all good conduct dhammas. Viddhaṃsan: destruction. Cavan: death. Jīvitassāti āyuno: of life. This is said:

original: hoti – evaṃ viditvā ṭhitassa paṇḍitassa sabbaṃ sucaritadhammaṃ jīvitassa ca aniccataṃ
analyzed: hoti evam viditvā ṭhitassa paṇḍitassa sabbam su carita dhammam jīvitassa ca anicca tam
translated: Having known thus, for the wise one who knows the impermanence of all good conduct dhammas and of life,

original: jānantassa evarūpassa narassa pāpaṃ na cīyati na vaḍḍhati. Sace na ceteti vadhāya
analyzed: jānantassa evarūpassa narassa pāpam na cīyati na vaḍḍhati sace na ceteti vadhāya
translated: for such a man evil does not increase, does not grow. If he does not intend to kill

translated: tassāti: for him, for the person who has gone to that state, he does not intend to kill, does not plan to kill,

analyzed: para puggalam vadhāya ceteti na api para santakam vināseti aham ca kassaci vadhāya a cetetvā
translated: he does not intend to kill another person, nor does he destroy another’s property, I, not intending to kill anyone,

original: kevalaṃ ambapakke āsaṅgaṃ katvā gaṅgaṃ olokento nisinno, tvaṃ mayhaṃ kiṃ nāma akusalaṃ passasīti.
analyzed: kevalam amba pakke āsaṅgam katvā gaṅgaṃ olokento nisinno tvam mayham kim nāma akusalam passasi iti
translated: having merely taken hold of a ripe mango, am sitting looking at the Ganges, what evil do you see in me?

original: Isipūgasamaññāteti isigaṇena suṭṭhu aññāte isīnaṃ sammate. Evaṃ lokyāti tvaṃ nāma
analyzed: isi pūga samaññātā iti isi gaṇena suṭṭhu aññāte isīnam sammate evam lokyāti tvam nāma
translated: Isipūgasamaññāte: well known by the multitude of sages, approved by the sages. Evaṃ lokyā ti tvaṃ nāma

analyzed: pāpa pavāhanena lokassa hitā ati evam viditā satī iti sati sobhane uttamā iti ālapanam etam
translated: and that you are doing this for the welfare of the world. “ ‘You are a woman of good memory, a woman of good memory indeed,

original: Anariyaparisambhāseti “tassa jānanti pitaro”tiādikāya asundarāya paribhāsāya samannāgate.
analyzed: anariya parisambhāse ti tassa jānanti pitaraḥ iti ādikāya asundarāya paribhāsāya samannāgate
translated: “ ‘You are a woman who is reproached by the unrighteous,

original: Jigīsasīti mayi pāpe asaṃvijjantepi maṃ evaṃ paribhāsantī ca paramaraṇaṃ ajjhupekkhantī🔽ca attano pāpakammaṃ gavesasi uppādesi. Tīre teti tava gaṅgātīre. Puthusussoṇīti
analyzed: jigīsasi iti mayi pāpe a saṃvijjante api mam evam paribhāsantī ca para maraṇam ajjhupekkhantī  ca attanaḥ pāpa kammam gavesasi uppādesi tīre te iti tava gaṅgā tīre puthusussoṇi iti
translated: “ ‘You are a woman who is seeking to find fault with me, a woman who is seeking to find fault with me indeed,

original: puthulāya sundarāya soṇiyā samannāgate. Peteti ambapakkaṃ alabhitvā paralokaṃ gate,
analyzed: puthulāya sundarāya soṇiyā samannāgate peta iti amba pakkam a labhitvā para lokam gate
translated: “ ‘You are a woman who has a broad and beautiful forehead, a woman who has a broad and beautiful forehead indeed,

analyzed: mata iti attho pakuṭṭhāyī iti akkosi garahi nindi pakvatthāsi iti pi pāṭhaḥ
translated: “ ‘You are a woman who is reproaching and reviling and censuring the dead,

analyzed: tam sutvā deva dhītā pañca gāthāḥ abhāsi 🔽aññātam etam attānam ambañca dadāmi te tam 🔽yaḥ dubbaje kāma guṇe pahāya santiñca dhammañca adhiṭṭhitaḥ asi
translated: “ ‘Having heard this, the goddess spoke five stanzas:

original: “Yo hitvā pubbasaññogaṃ, pacchāsaṃyojane ṭhito;
analyzed: yaḥ hitvā pubba saññogam pacchā saṃyojane ṭhitaḥ
translated: “He who, having given up the former fetter, stands in the later fetter,

original: Adhammañceva carati, pāpañcassa pavaḍḍhati.
analyzed: adhammañca iva carati pāpam cassa pavaḍḍhati
translated: And who acts contrary to the Dhamma, his evil increases.

original: “Ehi taṃ pāpayissāmi, kāmaṃ appossuko bhava;
analyzed: ehi tam pāpayissāmi kāmam appa ussukaḥ bhava
translated: “Come, I will make you happy; be not anxious.

original: Upanayāmi sītasmiṃ, viharāhi anussuko.
analyzed: upanayāmi sītasmim viharāhi anussukaḥ
translated: I will bring you cool water; be not anxious.

original: “Taṃ puppharasamattebhi, vakkaṅgehi arindama;🔽Koñcā mayūrā diviyā, kolaṭṭhimadhusāḷikā;
analyzed: tam puppha rasa mattebhi vakkaṅgehi arindama
translated: “With the best of flowers, O bull among men,🔽With geese, peacocks, and celestial birds, with kola, rice, honey, and sugarcane,

analyzed: kūjitā haṃsa pūgehi kokila ittha pabodhare
translated: With the cries of flocks of swans, and here the kokila awakens.

original: “Ambettha vippasākhaggā, palālakhalasannibhā;
analyzed: ambā ittha palāla khala sannibhā
translated: “Here the mango trees are laden with fruit, with branches and twigs,

original: Kosambasalaḷā nīpā, pakkatālavilambino”ti.🔽Tattha aññātametanti “garahā te bhavissatīti vadanto ambapakkatthāya vadasī”ti etaṃ
analyzed: kosamba salaḷāḥ nīpāḥ pakka tāla vilambinaḥ ti  tattha aññātam etat ti garahā te bhavissati iti vadantaḥ amba pakka atthāya vadasi iti etam
translated: With Kosambī, salaḷa, and nipa trees, and with ripe palmyra fruits hanging down.”🔽Herein, unknown to me is “I am speaking for the sake of the mango fruit, saying ‘There will be blame for you.’ ”

original: kāraṇaṃ mayā aññātaṃ. Avisayhasāhīti rājāno nāma dussahaṃ sahanti, tena naṃ ālapantī
analyzed: kāraṇam mayā aññātam rājānaḥ nāma dussaham sahanti tena nam ālapantī
translated: Unsurpassed in strength means that kings are unsurpassed in strength, so he speaks thus, addressing him.

original: evamāha. Attānanti taṃ āliṅgitvā ambavanaṃ nayantī attānañca te dadāmi tañca ambaṃ.
analyzed: evam āha tam āliṅgitvā ambavanam nayantī tam dadāmi tam ca ambam
translated: Myself means “I will take you by the arm and lead you to the mango grove. I will give you myself and the mangoes.”

original: Kāmaguṇeti kañcanamālāsetacchattapaṭimaṇḍite vatthukāme. Santiñca dhammañcāti dussīlyavūpasamena🔽santisaṅkhātaṃ sīlañceva sucaritadhammañca. Adhiṭṭhitosīti yo tvaṃ ime guṇe upagato,
analyzed: kāma guṇa iti kañcana mālā seta chatta paṭimaṇḍite vatthu kāme santim ca dhammam ca ati dussīlya vūpasamena  santi saṅkhātam sīlam ca iva su carita dhammam ca adhiṭṭhito asi iti yaḥ tvam ime guṇe upagato
translated: “The pleasures of sense” : the sense-desires of material form, which are like a golden garland or a white parasol. “And peace and the Dhamma”: the virtue called “peace” which is the stilling of unvirtuousness, and the Dhamma of good conduct. “You have undertaken”: you have approached these qualities.

original: etesu vā patiṭṭhitoti attho.
analyzed: etesu vā patiṭṭhitaḥ ti attho
translated: “The pleasures of the senses” : the sensual pleasures of material things, which are like a golden garland or a white parasol. “Peace and the Dhamma” : the virtue called “peace” and the Dhamma of good conduct. “You have resolved upon” : you have gone to these qualities, or you are established in them.

original: Pubbasaññoganti purimabandhanaṃ. Pacchāsaṃyojaneti pacchimabandhane. Idaṃ vuttaṃ
analyzed: pubba saññogam ti purima bandhanam pacchā saṃyojanā iti pacchima bandhane idam vuttam
translated: “Your former friendship” : your former bond. “In a later bond” : in a later bond. This is what is meant.

original: hoti – ambho tāpasa yo mahantaṃ rajjasirivibhavaṃ pahāya ambapakkamatte rasataṇhāya
analyzed: hoti tāpasa yaḥ mahantam rajja siri vibhavam pahāya amba pakka matte rasa taṇhāya
translated: “Good Recluse, you are like a man who, having abandoned a great kingdom and its glory, is overcome by craving for the taste of a single mango

original: bajjhitvā vātātapaṃ agaṇetvā nadītīre sussamāno nisīdati, so mahāsamuddaṃ taritvā
analyzed: bajjhitvā vāta ātapam a gaṇetvā nadī tīre sussamānaḥ nisīdati saḥ mahā samuddam taritvā
translated: and sits on the bank of a river, disregarding wind and sun, while his clothes dry.” He is like a man who, having crossed the great ocean,

original: velante saṃsīdanapuggalasadiso. Yo puggalo rasataṇhāvasiko adhammañceva carati, rasataṇhāvasena
analyzed: saṃsīdana puggala sadisaḥ yaḥ puggalaḥ rasa taṇhā vasikaḥ adhammam ca iva carati rasa taṇhā vasena
translated: sinks in shallow water. The person who, because of craving for taste, practices the Dhamma and increases his evil through craving for taste.

original: kariyamānaṃ pāpañcassa pavaḍḍhatīti. Iti sā tāpasaṃ garahantī evamāha.
analyzed: kariyamānam pāpam cassa pavaḍḍhati iti iti sā tāpasam garahantī evam āha
translated: Thus, reproaching the Recluse, she said this.

original: Kāmaṃ appossuko bhavāti ekaṃseneva ambapakke nirālayo hohi. Sītasminti sītale ambavane.🔽Tanti evaṃ vadamānāva devatā tāpasaṃ āliṅgitvā ure nipajjāpetvā ākāse pakkhantā tiyojanikaṃ🔽dibbaambavanaṃ disvā sakuṇasaddañca sutvā tāpasassa ācikkhantī “ta”nti evamāha. analyzed: tidhākappaḥ ahosi tassa tiṇṇam kappānam antare cāṭippamāṇaḥ āvāṭaḥ ahosi saḥ deve vassante  udakena pūritaḥ tam parivāretvā harītakī āmalakī maricagaccho ca ahosi tesam pakkāni

analyzed: phalāni chijjitvā tattha patanti tassa avidūre sayaṃjāta sāli jātaḥ tatas sāli sīsāni

original: thokaṃ niddāyitvā vikūjamānā pakkamanti. Rukkhasunakhamakkaṭādīsupi eseva nayo. Vanacarako🔽taṃ disvā “sace idaṃ visaṃ bhaveyya, ime mareyyuṃ, ime pana thokaṃ niddāyitvā yathāsukhaṃ

translated: The forester saw this and thought, “If this were poison, they would die. But after sleeping a little they go away as they please. This is not poison.” So he drank it himself. When he was drunk, he wanted to eat meat.

analyzed: hatthena naccantaḥ ekena maṃsam khādantaḥ ekāha dvīham tattha iva ahosi  tato pana avidūre ekaḥ varuṇaḥ nāma tāpasaḥ vasati vana carakaḥ aññadā api tassa santikam  gacchati atha assa etat ahosi idam pānam tāpasena saddhim pivissāmi iti saḥ ekam

analyzed: pivatha iti vatvā ubho pi maṃsam khādantā iti surena ca varuṇena ca diṭṭhattā

analyzed: paggharantam suram pivitvā mattāḥ mūsikāḥ āgantvā tesam kaṇṇa nāsika dāṭhika naṅguṭṭhe  khāditvā agamaṃsu biḷārā suram pivitvā matā ati āyuttaka purisāḥ raññaḥ ārocesum rājā  visa kārakāḥ ete bhavissanti iti tesam dvinnam pi janānam sīsāni te suram

analyzed: sakala jambudīpaḥ yathā na pivissati tathā nam karissāmi iti ekam surā puṇṇam  kumbham hattha tale ṭhapetvā brāhmaṇa vesena āgantvā rañño sammukha ṭṭhāne ākāse ṭhatvā
translated: all the people of the Rose-Apple Island will be lost. I will so act that he shall not drink it.” So he placed a jar full of strong drink in the palm of his hand,

analyzed: ākāse ṭhitam disvā kutas nu kho brāhmaṇaḥ āgacchati iti tena saddhim sallapantaḥ tissaḥ gāthāḥ abhāsi
translated: standing in the air, asked him, “Whence do you come?” and in reply to his question, he recited three stanzas:

analyzed: kaḥ tidivā nabhamhi obhāsayam saṃvarim candim āva

analyzed: gattehi te rasmiyaḥ niccharanti
translated: From your limbs rays of light are shed forth, like the lightning flash in the sky at evening time.

original: “So chinnavātaṃ kamasī aghamhi, vehāyasaṃ gacchasi tiṭṭhasī ca;
analyzed: saḥ chinna vātam kamasī aghamhi vehāyasam gacchasi tiṭṭhasi ca
translated: “You, having gone beyond the wind, in the sky, you go and stand,

analyzed: iddhi nu te vatthukatā su bhāvitā anaddhagūnam api devatānam
translated: Are your psychic powers well-developed, beautiful, not inferior to the gods?

analyzed: vehāyasam gammam āgamma tiṭṭhasi kumbham kiṇātha ati yam etam attham
translated: “You, having gone in the sky, you go and stand, ‘Buy a pot,’ is what you say,

original: Ko vā tuvaṃ kissa vā tāya kumbho, akkhāhi me brāhmaṇa etamattha”nti.🔽Tattha ko pāturāsīti kuto pātubhūtosi, kuto āgatosīti attho. Chinnavātanti valāhakopi tāva vātena🔽kamati, tassa pana sopi vāto natthi, tenevamāha. Kamasīti pavattesi. Aghamhīti appaṭighe
analyzed: kaḥ vā tuvam kissa vā tāya kumbhaḥ akkhāhi me brāhmaṇa etam attham ti  tattha kaḥ pāturāsi iti kutas pātubhūtaḥ asi kutas āgataḥ asi iti attho tidivā nabhamhi iti kim  tāvatiṃsa bhavanāḥ āgantvā idha nabhamhi ākāse pākaṭaḥ jātaḥ asi iti pucchati  evaṃnāmikā evaṃnāmikā saḥ iti saḥ tvam vātena  kamati tassa pana saḥ api vātaḥ natthi tena ivam āha kamasi iti pavattesi aghamhi iti appaṭighe
translated: Who are you, and why is there a pot? Tell me, brahmin, this matter.”

original: ākāse. Vatthukatāti vatthu viya patiṭṭhā viya katā. Anaddhagūnaṃ api devatānanti
analyzed: ākāse vatthu katā ati vatthu viya patiṭṭhā viya katā anaddhagūnam api devatānanti
translated: Here, “Who is it that has appeared?” means “From where have you become manifest? From where have you come?” is the meaning. “In the sky of the heavens” means “Have you come from the Tāvatiṃsa heaven and become manifest here in the sky?” is what he asks. “In the night” means “In the night.” “Sateratā” is the name of a woman. “You” means “You.” “Having gone beyond the wind” means “Even a cloud moves by the wind, but you have no such wind, therefore I say so.” “You go” means “You move.” “In the sky” means “In the sky that is not an obstacle.” “Well-developed” means “Well-established.” “Not inferior to the gods” means “Not inferior to the gods.”

original: yā padasā addhānaṃ agamanena anaddhagūnaṃ devatānaṃ iddhi, sā api tava subhāvitāti
analyzed: yā devatānam a gamanena anaddhagūnam devatānam id hi sā api tava su bhāvitā ati
translated: The first line of the verse means: “The power of the gods is not equal to a quarter of the power of your meditation.”

original: pucchati. Vehāyasaṃ gammamāgammāti ākāse pavattaṃ padavītihāraṃ paṭicca nissāya.
analyzed: pucchati vehāyasam gammam āgamma ati ākāse pavattam padavī tihāram paṭicca nissāya
translated: The second line means: “You go and come by means of the air in space.”🔽The third line means: “Who are you, standing there?”

original: “Tiṭṭhasī”ti imassa “ko vā tuva”nti iminā sambandho, evaṃ tiṭṭhamāno ko vā tvanti🔽attho. Yametamatthanti yaṃ etaṃ vadasi. Imassa “kissa vā tāya”nti iminā sambandho,

original: tattha gamissāmi, tvaṃ rajjaṃ kārehīti vadati.
analyzed: tattha gamissāmi tvam rajjam kārehi iti vadati
translated: I say: “I will go there again. You rule the kingdom.”

original: Taṃ sutvā kumāro gāthamāha –
analyzed: tam sutvā kumāraḥ gātham āha
translated: Hearing this, the prince spoke this verse:

original: “Ahaṃ gamissāmi idheva hohi, natthi tato jīvato vippamokkho;
analyzed: aham gamissāmi idha iva hohi natthi tatas jīvataḥ vippamokkhaḥ
translated: “I will go; you stay here. There is no escape for you alive from this.

original: Sace tuvaṃ gacchasiyeva rāja, ahampi gacchāmi ubho na homā”ti.
analyzed: sace tuvam gacchasi yā iva rāja aham pi gacchāmi ubhau na
translated: If you go, O king, I too will go. We will not be left behind.”

original: Tattha idhevāti tvaṃ idheva hoti. Tatoti tassa santikā jīvantassa mokkho nāma natthi. Ubhoti evaṃ sante ubhopi na bhavissāma.
analyzed: tattha idhā iva ati tvam idhā iva hoti tatoti tassa santikā jīvantassa mokkhaḥ nāma natthi ubho ti evam sante ubho api na bhavissāma
translated: “Here” means “here you will be.” “From that” means “there is no escape from him while he is alive.” “Both” means “in that case we will both be no more.”

original: Taṃ sutvā rājā gāthamāha –
analyzed: tam sutvā rājā gātham āha
translated: When he heard this, the king spoke this verse:

original: “Addhā hi tāta satānesa dhammo, maraṇā ca me dukkhataraṃ tadassa;
analyzed: addhā hi tāta satāna esa dhammaḥ maraṇā ca me dukkhataram tat assa
translated: “Surely, my dear, this is the law of the wise, and it would be more painful for me to die

original: Kammāsapādo taṃ yadā pacitvā, pasayha khāde bhidā rukkhasūle”ti.
analyzed: kammāsapādaḥ tam yadā pacitvā pasayha khāde bhidā rukkha sūlā iti
translated: than to have that foot of yours cooked and eaten by that man, after you have been pierced and torn with a tree-stake.”

original: Tassattho – addhā ekaṃsena esa, tāta, satānaṃ paṇḍitānaṃ dhammo sabhāvo, yuttaṃ tvaṃ🔽vadasi, api ca kho pana mayhaṃ maraṇatopetaṃ dukkhataraṃ assa, yadā taṃ so kammāsapādo.
analyzed: tassa atthaḥ addhā ekaṃsena esa tāta satānam paṇḍitānam dhammo sabhāvaḥ yuttam tvam  vadasi api ca kho pana mayham maraṇa tā upetam dukkhataram assa yadā tam so kammāsapādo
translated: The meaning is: “Surely, my dear, this is the law, this is the nature of the wise, of the discerning; you say what is right.

original: Bhidā rukkhasūleti tikhiṇarukkhasūle bhitvā pacitvā pasayha balakkārena khādeyyāti.🔽Taṃ sutvā kumāro gāthamāha –
analyzed: bhidā rukkha sūle iti tikhiṇa rukkha sūle bhitvā pacitvā pasayha balakkārena khādeyya ati  tam sutvā kumāraḥ gātham āha
translated: But it would be more painful for me to die than to have that foot of yours cooked and eaten by that man, after you have been pierced and torn with a tree-stake.”

original: “Pāṇena te pāṇamahaṃ nimissaṃ, mā tvaṃ agā porisādassa ñatte;
analyzed: pāṇena te pāṇa maham nimissam mā tvam agāḥ porisādassa ñatte
translated: “I would give my life for your life, so do not go to the executioner’s place.

original: Evañca te pāṇamahaṃ nimissaṃ, tasmā mataṃ jīvitassa vaṇṇemī”ti.
analyzed: evam ca te pāṇam aham nimissam tasmai matam jīvitassa vaṇṇemi iti
translated: I would give my life for your life, and therefore I praise life.”

original: Tattha nimissanti ahaṃ idheva tava pāṇena mama pāṇaṃ parivattessaṃ. Tasmāti yasmā🔽etaṃ pāṇaṃ tava pāṇenāhaṃ nimissaṃ, tasmā tava jīvitassatthāya mama maraṇaṃ vaṇṇemi
analyzed: tattha aham idha iva tava pāṇena mama pāṇam parivattessam tasmā iti yasmā  etam pāṇam tava pāṇena aham nimissam tasmā tava jīvitassatthāya mama maraṇam vaṇṇemi
translated: “There” means: “I will exchange my life for yours.” “Therefore” means: “Since I will exchange my life for yours, therefore I recommend death for the sake of your life.”

original: maraṇameva varemi, icchāmīti attho.
analyzed: maraṇam eva varemi icchāmi iti
translated: “Death itself I prefer” means: “I wish for death itself.”

original: Taṃ sutvā rājā puttassa balaṃ jānanto “sādhu tāta, gacchāhī”ti sampaṭicchi. So mātāpitaro vanditvā nagaramhā nikkhami. Tamatthaṃ pakāsento satthā upaḍḍhagāthamāha –
analyzed: tam sutvā rājā puttassa balam jānantaḥ sādhu tāta gacchāhi iti sampaṭicchi saḥ mātā pitaraḥ vanditvā nagaramhā nikkhami tam attham pakāsento satthā upaḍḍha gātham āha
translated: Having heard that, the king, knowing his son’s strength, consented, saying: “Well, my dear, go.” He saluted his parents and left the city. Expounding that matter, the Teacher spoke the first half of the stanza:

original: “Tato have dhitimā rājaputto, vanditvā mātu ca pitu ca pāde”ti.
analyzed: tatas have dhitimā rāja puttaḥ vanditvā mātu ca pitu ca
translated: “Then the wise prince, having saluted the feet of his mother and father.”

original: Tattha pādeti pāde vanditvā nikkhantoti attho;
analyzed: tattha pāde iti pāde vanditvā nikkhanto ti attho
translated: There, “having saluted the feet” means: having saluted his parents’ feet, he left.

original: Athassa mātāpitaropi bhaginīpi bhariyāpi amaccaparijanehi saddhiṃyeva nikkhamiṃsu.
analyzed: athassa mātā pitaraḥ api bhaginī pi bhariyā api amacca parijanehi saddhiṃya iva nikkhamiṃsu
translated: Then his parents, his sister, his wife, and his retinue of ministers also left.

original: So nagarā nikkhamitvā pitaraṃ maggaṃ pucchitvā suṭṭhu vavatthapetvā mātāpitaro vanditvā
analyzed: saḥ nagarā nikkhamitvā pitaram maggam pucchitvā suṭṭhu vavatthapetvā mātā pitaraḥ vanditvā
translated: Having left the city, he asked his father the way, and having well determined it, he saluted his parents and left.

original: sesānaṃ ovādaṃ datvā acchambhito kesarasīho viya maggaṃ āruyha yakkhāvāsaṃ pāyāsi.
analyzed: sesānam ovādam da tvā a chambhito kesarasīhaḥ viya maggam āruyha yakkha āvāsam pāyāsi
translated: After giving them advice, he went on his way, fearlessly like a lion, and came to the abode of the Yakkha.

original: Taṃ gacchantaṃ disvā mātā sakabhāvena saṇṭhātuṃ asakkontī pathaviyaṃ pati. Pitā bāhā
analyzed: tam gacchantam disvā mātā saka bhāvena saṇṭhātum a sakkontī pathaviyam pati pitā bāhā
translated: When the Yakkha saw him coming, his mother, unable to contain herself, fell to the ground. His father, stretching out his arms,

original: paggayha mahantena saddena kandi. Tampi atthaṃ pakāsento satthā –
analyzed: paggayha mahantena saddena kandi tam pi attham pakāsento satthā
translated: cried out with a loud voice. Expounding this situation, the Teacher related the following four verses:

original: “Dukhinissa mātā nipatā pathabyā, pitāssa paggayha bhujāni kandatī”ti. –
analyzed: dukhinissa mātā nipatā pathabyā pitā assa paggayha bhujāni kandati iti
translated: “The mother of the sorrowful one falls to the ground, the father stretches out his arms and cries out.”

original: Upaḍḍhagāthaṃ vatvā tassa pitarā payuttaṃ āsīsavādaṃ abhivādanavādaṃ mātarā bhaginībhariyāhi ca kataṃ saccakiriyaṃ pakāsento aparāpi catasso gāthā abhāsi –
analyzed: upaḍḍha gātham vatvā tassa pitarā payuttam āsīsa vādam abhivādana vādam mātarā bhaginī bhariyāhi ca katam saccakiriyam pakāsentaḥ aparā api catassaḥ gāthāḥ abhāsi
translated: Having recited the first half of the verse, he related the following four verses, expounding the words of counsel spoken by the father, the words of salutation spoken by the mother, and the words of truth spoken by the sister and the wife:

original: “Taṃ gacchantaṃ tāva pitā viditvā, parammukho vandati pañjalīko;
analyzed: tam gacchantam tāva pitā viditvā parammukhaḥ vandati pañjalīkaḥ
translated: “The father, seeing him go, salutes him with joined hands, turning his back.

original: Somo ca rājā varuṇo ca rājā, pajāpatī candimā sūriyo ca;
analyzed: somaḥ ca rājā varuṇaḥ ca rājā pajāpatī candimā sūriyaḥ ca
translated: King Soma, King Varuna, Pajapati, the moon, and the sun,

original: Etehi gutto purisādakamhā, anuññāto sotthi paccehi tāta.
analyzed: etehi guttaḥ purisādakamhā anuññāto so tthi paccehi tāta
translated: Protected by these, O son, from the man-eating Yakkhas, you are permitted to go in safety.”

original: “Yaṃ daṇḍakirañño gatassa mātā, rāmassakāsi sotthānaṃ suguttā;
analyzed: yam daṇḍakiraññaḥ gatassa mātā sotthānam su guttā
translated: the blessing that the one from the Rammaka clan gave to the one well-guarded,

original: Taṃ te ahaṃ sotthānaṃ karomi, etena saccena sarantu devā;
analyzed: tam te aham sa utthānam karomi etena saccena sarantu devāḥ
translated: I give that blessing to you. By this truth may the gods rejoice.

original: Anuññāto sotthi paccehi putta.
analyzed: anuññātaḥ sotthi paccehi putta
translated: You are permitted to return safely, my son.”

original: “Āvī raho vāpi manopadosaṃ, nāhaṃ sare jātu malīnasatte;
analyzed: āvīḥ rahaḥ vā api manaḥ upadosam na aham sare jātu malīna satte
translated: “I never remember, even in secret, harboring ill will towards anyone with a defiled mind.

original: Etena saccena sarantu devā, anuññāto sotthi paccehi bhātika.
analyzed: etena saccena sarantu devāḥ anuññātaḥ sotthi paccehi bhātika
translated: By this truth may the gods rejoice. You are permitted to return safely, my brother.”

original: “Yasmā ca me anadhimanosi sāmi, na cāpi me manasā appiyosi;
analyzed: yasmai ca me sāmi na ca api me manasā appiyā asi
translated: “Since I have never been displeased with you, my lord, and you have never been unloved by me in my mind,

original: Etena saccena sarantu devā, anuññāto sotthi paccehi sāmī”ti.
analyzed: etena saccena sarantu devāḥ anuññātaḥ sotthi paccehi sāmi iti
translated: by this truth may the gods rejoice. You are permitted to return safely, my lord.”

original: Tattha parammukhoti ayaṃ me putto parammukho mātāpitaro vanditvā gacchati, iti etaṃ
analyzed: tattha parammukhaḥ ti ayam me putto parammukhaḥ mātā pitaraḥ vanditvā gacchati iti etam
translated: Here, “with his face turned away” means: “My son, with his face turned away, is paying homage to his mother and father and leaving.” Thus,🔽having seen and understood him going with his face turned away,

original: parammukhaṃ gacchantaṃ disvā viditvā. Pañjalīkoti tasmiṃ kāle sirasi añjaliṃ ṭhapetvā
analyzed: parammukham gacchantam disvā viditvā tasmin kāle sirasi añjalim ṭhapetvā
translated: “with his hands raised in reverential salutation” means: at that time, placing his hands on his head,

original: vandati devatā namassati. Purisādakamhāti purisādassa santikā tena anuññāto sotthinā paccehi.
analyzed: vandati devatā namassati purisādakamhā ati purisādassa santikā tena anuññātaḥ sotthinā paccehi
translated: he pays homage, he worships the gods. “From the one who leads men” means: permitted by him, he returned safely.

original: Rāmassakāsīti rāmassa akāsi. Eko kira bārāṇasivāsī rāmo nāma mātuposako mātāpitaro
analyzed: rāmassa kāsi iti ekaḥ kira bārāṇasi vāsī rāmaḥ nāma mātuposakaḥ mātā pitaraḥ
translated: Rāmassakāsīti rāmassa akāsi. Eko kira bārāṇasivāsī rāmo nāma mātuposako mātāpitaro

original: paṭijagganto vohāratthāya gato daṇḍakirañño vijite kumbhavatīnagaraṃ gantvā navavidhena
analyzed: paṭijaggantaḥ vohāra atthāya gataḥ daṇḍakiraññaḥ vijite kumbhavatī nagaram gantvā navavidhena
translated: paṭijagganto vohāratthāya gato daṇḍakirañño vijite kumbhavatīnagaraṃ gantvā navavidhena

original: vassena sakalaraṭṭhe vināsiyamāne mātāpitūnaṃ guṇaṃ sari. Atha naṃ mātupaṭṭhānakammassa
analyzed: vassena sakala raṭṭhe vināsiyamāne mātā pitūnam guṇam atha nam mātu upaṭṭhāna kammassa
translated: vassena sakalaraṭṭhe vināsiyamāne mātāpitūnaṃ guṇaṃ sari. Atha naṃ mātupaṭṭhānakammassa

original: phalena devatā sotthinā ānayitvā mātu adaṃsu. Taṃ kāraṇaṃ sutavasenāharitvā evamāha.
analyzed: phalena devatā sotthinā ānayitvā tam kāraṇam suta vasena āharitvā evam āha
translated: phalena devatā sotthinā ānayitvā mātu adaṃsu. Taṃ kāraṇaṃ sutavasenāharitvā evamāha.

original: Sotthānanti sotthibhāvaṃ. Taṃ pana kiñcāpi devatā kariṃsu, mātupaṭṭhānaṃ nissāya
analyzed: sa utthānam ti sotthi bhāvam tam pana kiñcā api devatā kariṃsu mātupaṭṭhānam nissāya
translated: Sotthānanti sotthibhāvaṃ. Taṃ pana kiñcāpi devatā kariṃsu, mātupaṭṭhānaṃ nissāya

original: nibbattattā pana mātā akāsīti vuttaṃ. Taṃ te ahanti ahampi te tameva sotthānaṃ karomi,
analyzed: nibbatta ttā pana mātā akāsi iti vuttam tam te aham ti aham pi te tam eva sotthānam karomi
translated: nibbattattā pana mātā akāsīti vuttaṃ. Taṃ te ahanti ahampi te tameva sotthānaṃ karomi,

analyzed: mam nissāya tathā iva tava sotthi bhāvaḥ hotu uti atthaḥ atha vā karomi iti icchāmi etena
translated: maṃ nissāya tatheva tava sotthibhāvo hotūti attho. Atha vā karomīti icchāmi. Etena

analyzed: saccena ati sace devatāhi tassa ānīta bhāvo sacco etena saccena mama api puttam
translated: saccenāti sace devatāhi tassa sotthinā ānītabhāvo sacco, etena saccena mamapi puttaṃ

original: sarantu devā, rāmaṃ viya tampi āharitvā mama dassantūti attho. Anuññātoti porisādena
analyzed: sarantu devāḥ rāmam viya tam pi āharitvā mama dassantu iti atthaḥ anuññātaḥ ti porisādena
translated: Let the gods send him to me, as they did Rāma. ”

original: “gacchā”ti anuññāto devatānaṃ ānubhāvena sotthi paṭiāgaccha puttāti vadati.🔽Jātu malīnasatteti jātu ekaṃsena alīnasatte mama bhātike ahaṃ sammukhā vā parammukhā
analyzed: gaccha ati anuññātaḥ devatānaṃ ānubhāvena sotthi paṭiāgaccha putta ati vadati  jātu malīna sattā iti jātu ekaṃsena alīna satte mama bhātike aham sammukhā vā parammukhā
translated: “Granted” : Pāyāsi granted him permission, saying “Go”, and by the power of the gods he returned safely.🔽“My brother” : at one time, my brother, I do not remember any resentment, either in his presence or in his absence,

original: vā manopadosaṃ na sarāmi, na mayā tamhi manopadoso katapubboti evamassa kaniṭṭhā
analyzed: vā manaḥ upadosam na sarāmi na mayā tamhi manaḥ upadoso kata pubbaḥ ti evam assa kaniṭṭhā
translated: against him. I have never harbored resentment against him. Thus did his younger brother🔽make an affirmation.

original: saccamakāsi. Yasmā ca me anadhimanosi, sāmīti mama, sāmi alīnasattu yasmā tvaṃ anadhimanosi,
analyzed: saccamakā asi yasmai ca me an adhimanāḥ usi sāmi iti mama sāmi alīna sattu yasmai tvam
translated: “Since you are not disaffected” : since you are not disaffected, my lord,

original: maṃ abhibhavitvā atikkamitvā aññaṃ manena na patthesi. Na cāpi me manasā appiyosīti
analyzed: mam abhibhavitvā atikkamitvā aññam manena na patthesi na ca api me manasā appiyosi iti
translated: since you do not seek another woman in your mind, having overcome and surpassed me. “Nor am I disaffected in my mind” :

original: mayhampi ca manasā tvaṃ appiyo na hosi, aññamaññaṃ piyasaṃvāsāva mayanti evamassa
analyzed: mayham pi ca manasā tvam appiyaḥ na hosi aññam aññam evam assa
translated: I am not disaffected in my mind either. We live together in mutual affection. Thus did his chief consort

original: aggamahesī saccamakāsi.
analyzed: agga mahesī saccam akāsi
translated: make an affirmation.

original: Kumāropi pitarā akkhātanayena rakkhāvāsamaggaṃ paṭipajji. Yakkhopi “khattiyā nāma
analyzed: kumāraḥ api pitarā akkhā tanayena rakkhā vāsa maggam paṭipajji yakkhaḥ api khattiyā nāma
translated: The prince set out on the road to Rākkhāvāsa in the manner indicated by his father. The yakkha thought: “Kshatriyas are

original: bahumāyā honti, ko jānāti, kiṃ bhavissatī”ti rukkhaṃ abhiruhitvā rañño āgamanaṃ olokento
analyzed: bahu māyāḥ honti kaḥ jānāti kim bhavissati iti rukkham abhiruhitvā raññaḥ āgamanam olokento
translated: “They are full of tricks; who knows what will happen?” So he climbed a tree and sat watching for the King’s approach.

original: nisīdi. So kumāraṃ āgacchantaṃ disvā “pitaraṃ nivattetvā putto āgato bhavissati,
analyzed: nisīdi saḥ kumāram āgacchantam disvā pitaram nivattetvā putto āgataḥ bhavissati
translated: When he saw the prince coming, he thought, “He will turn back his father and come as a son.

original: natthi me bhaya”nti otaritvā tassa piṭṭhiṃ dassento nisīdi. So āgantvā tassa purato
analyzed: natthi me bhayanti otaritvā tassa piṭṭhim dassento nisīdi saḥ āgantvā tassa puratas
translated: There is no danger for me.” So he climbed down, showed his back, and sat down. The prince came up and stood

original: aṭṭhāsi. Atha yakkho gāthamāha –
analyzed: aṭṭhāsi atha yakkhaḥ gātham āha
translated: in front of him. Then the ogre spoke the first stanza:

original: “Brahā ujū cārumukho kutosi, na maṃ pajānāsi vane vasantaṃ;
analyzed: brahāḥ uju cāru mukhaḥ kutas asi na mama vane vasantam
translated: Brahmā, upright, fair of face, whence come you? You know me not, me who dwell in the forest.

original: Luddaṃ maṃ ñatvā ‘purisādako’si, ko sotthimājānamidhāvajeyyā”ti.
analyzed: luddam mama ñatvā purisādakaḥ asi kaḥ
translated: Knowing me a hunter, you call me “man-slayer.” Who, knowing safety, would come here?

original: Tattha ko sotthimājānamidhāvajeyyāti kumāra ko nāma puriso attano sotthibhāvaṃ jānanto icchanto idhāgaccheyya, tvaṃ ajānanto āgato maññeti.
analyzed: tattha kaḥ sotthim ājānam idha avajeyya ati kumāra kaḥ nāma purisaḥ attano sotthi bhāvam jānantaḥ icchantaḥ idha āgaccheyya tvam a jānantaḥ āgataḥ mañña iti
translated: Here “who, knowing safety, would come here?” means, “Prince, what man, knowing his own safety, desiring it, would come here? You have come, I think, not knowing.”

original: Taṃ sutvā kumāro gāthamāha –
analyzed: tam sutvā kumāraḥ gātham āha
translated: Hearing this, the prince spoke the second stanza:

original: “Jānāmi ludda purisādako tvaṃ, na taṃ na jānāmi vane vasantaṃ;
analyzed: jānāmi ludda purisādako tvam na tam na jānāmi vane vasantam
translated: I know you, hunter, man-slayer, I know you not, me who dwell in the forest.

original: Ahañca puttosmi jayaddisassa, mamajja khāda pituno pamokkhā”ti.
analyzed: aham ca putto asmi jayaddisassa mamajja khāda pitunā
translated: I am the son of Jayaddisa; today, after my father’s release, eat me.”

original: Tattha pamokkhāti pamokkhahetu ahaṃ pitu jīvitaṃ datvā idhāgato, tasmā taṃ muñca, maṃ khādāhīti attho.
analyzed: tattha pamokkhā ati pamokkha hetu aham pitu jīvitam da tvā idha āgataḥ tasmā tam muñca mam khādāhi iti attho
translated: Here “release” means “for the sake of release.” “I have come here after giving my life for my father’s release; therefore release him and eat me.”

original: Tato yakkho gāthamāha –
analyzed: tatas yakkhaḥ gātham āha
translated: Then the ogre spoke this verse:

original: “Jānāmi puttoti jayaddisassa, tathā hi vo mukhavaṇṇo ubhinnaṃ;
analyzed: jānāmi putto iti jayaddisassa tathā hi vaḥ mukha vaṇṇaḥ ubhinnam
translated: “I know you are the son of Jayaddisa, for the color of your face is the same as his;

original: Sudukkaraññeva kataṃ tavedaṃ, yo mattumicche pituno pamokkhā”ti.
analyzed: su dukkaraññā iva katam tava idam yaḥ mattum icche pitunā
translated: This thing you have done is very difficult, that you would give yourself for your father’s release.”

original: Tattha tathā hi voti tādiso vo tumhākaṃ. Ubhinnampi sadisova mukhavaṇṇo hotīti attho. Kataṃ tavedanti idaṃ tava kammaṃ sudukkaraṃ.
analyzed: tattha tathā hi vaḥ ti tādisaḥ vaḥ tumhākam ubhinnam pi sadisaḥ uva mukha vaṇṇo hoti iti attho katam tava idam ti idam tava kammam su dukkaram
translated: Here “for the color of your face is the same as his” means “the color of your face is the same as his.” “This thing you have done” means “this deed of yours.”

original: Tato kumāro gāthamāha –
analyzed: kumāraḥ gātham āha
translated: Then the prince spoke this verse:

original: “Na dukkaraṃ kiñci mahettha maññe, yo mattumicche pituno pamokkhā;
analyzed: na dukkaram kiñci mahā itthā maññe yaḥ mattum icche pitunā u pamokkhā
translated: “I think there is nothing difficult here, that you would give yourself for your father’s release;

original: Mātu ca hetu paraloka gantvā, sukhena saggena ca sampayutto”ti.
analyzed: mātu ca hetu para loka gantvā sukhena saggena ca sampayuttaḥ ti
translated: For the sake of your mother, after going to the other world, you are united with happiness and a good companion.”

original: Tattha kiñci mahettha maññeti kiñci ahaṃ ettha na maññāmi. Idaṃ vuttaṃ hoti – yakkha
analyzed: tattha kiñci mahā ittha maññā iti kiñci aham ettha na maññāmi idam vuttam hoti yakkha
translated: Here “I think there is nothing difficult here” means “I think there is nothing difficult here.” This is what is said:

original: yo puggalo pitu vā pamokkhatthāya mātu vā hetu paralokaṃ gantvā sukhena sagge nibbattanakasukhena🔽sampayutto bhavituṃ mattumicche marituṃ icchati, tasmā ahaṃ ettha mātāpitūnaṃ atthāya
analyzed: yaḥ puggalaḥ pitu vā pamokkha atthāya mātu vā hetu para lokam gantvā sukhena sagge nibbattanaka sukhena  sampayuttaḥ bhavitum mattum icche maritum icchati tasmai aham ettha mātā pitūnam atthāya
translated: “If a man, for the sake of his father or mother, should go to the other world, and if he should wish to be happy and to be reborn in heaven,

original: jīvitapariccāge kiñci dukkaraṃ na maññāmīti.
analyzed: jīvita pariccāge kiñci dukkaram na maññāmi iti
translated: and if he should wish to die, then I should not consider it difficult to give up my life for the sake of my parents.”

original: Taṃ sutvā yakkho “kumāra, maraṇassa abhayānakasatto nāma natthi, tvaṃ kasmā na bhāyasī”ti pucchi. So tassa kathento dve gāthā abhāsi –
analyzed: tam sutvā yakkhaḥ kumāra maraṇassa abhayānakasatto nāma natthi tvam kasmā na bhāyasi iti pucchi so tassa kathentaḥ dve gāthāḥ abhāsi
translated: Hearing this, the ogre asked, “Prince, there is no one who is not afraid of death. Why are you not afraid?” He replied to the ogre in two stanzas:

original: “Ahañca kho attano pāpakiriyaṃ, āvī raho vāpi sare na jātu;
analyzed: aham ca kho attanaḥ pāpa kiriyam āvī rahaḥ vā api sare na jātu
translated: “I have never lied, either in public or in private, about my own evil deeds.

original: Saṅkhātajātīmaraṇohamasmi, yatheva me idha tathā parattha.
analyzed: yathā iva me tathā
translated: I am subject to birth and death. As it is here, so it is in the other world.

original: “Khādajja maṃ dāni mahānubhāva, karassu kiccāni imaṃ sarīraṃ;
analyzed: khādajja mam dāni mahā anubhāva karassu kiccāni imam sarīram
translated: “Now eat me, O mighty one, and do what you have to do with this body.

original: Rukkhassa vā te papatāmi aggā, chādayamāno mayhaṃ tvamadesi maṃsa”nti.
analyzed: rukkhassa vā te papatāmi aggā chādayamānaḥ mayham tvam adesi maṃsanti
translated: I will fall from the top of the tree and cover you with my flesh.”

original: Tattha sare na jātūti ekaṃseneva na sarāmi. Saṅkhātajātīmaraṇohamasmīti ahaṃ ñāṇena
analyzed: tattha sare na jātu uti ekaṃsena iva na sarāmi aham ñāṇena
translated: Herein, never lied means I do not lie at all. I am subject to birth and death means I am subject to birth and death by way of the aggregates.

original: suparicchinnajātimaraṇo, jātasatto amaraṇadhammo nāma natthīti jānāmi. Yatheva me
analyzed: su paricchinna jāti maraṇaḥ jāta sattaḥ amaraṇa dhammo nāma na atthi iti jānāmi yathā iva me
translated: I know that there is no living being that is not subject to death.

original: idhāti yatheva mama idha, tathā paraloke, yathā ca paraloke, tathā idhāpi maraṇato
analyzed: yathā iva mama tathā para loke yathā ca para loke tathā idha api maraṇataḥ
translated: As here, so in the world beyond,

original: mutti nāma natthīti idampi mama ñāṇena suparicchinnaṃ. Karassu kiccānīti iminā sarīrena
analyzed: mutti nāma natthi iti idam pi mama ñāṇena su paricchinnam karassu kiccāni iti iminā sarīrena
translated: I know that there is no escape from death.🔽Do what you have to do,

original: kattabbakiccāni kara, imaṃ te mayā nissaṭṭhaṃ sarīraṃ. Chādayamāno mayhaṃ tvamadesi
analyzed: kattabba kiccāni karaḥ imam te mayā nissaṭṭham sarīram chādayamānaḥ mayham tvam adesi
translated: Do what you have to do with this body. I have given up this body to you.

original: maṃsanti mayi rukkhaggā patitvā mate mama sarīrato tvaṃ chādayamāno rocayamāno yaṃ
analyzed: maṃsanti mayi ruj khaggāḥ patitvā mate mama sarīrataḥ tvam chādayamānaḥ rocayamānaḥ yam
translated: Covering me, you may take

original: yaṃ icchasi, taṃ taṃ maṃsaṃ adesi, khādeyyāsīti attho.
analyzed: yam icchasi tam tam maṃsam adesi khādeyyāsi iti
translated: From my body whatever you wish.

original: Yakkho tassa vacanaṃ sutvā bhīto hutvā “na sakkā imassa maṃsaṃ khādituṃ, upāyena naṃ palāpessāmī”ti cintetvā imaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: yakkhaḥ tassa vacanam sutvā bhītaḥ hutvā na sakkā imassa maṃsam khāditum upāyena nam palāpessāmi iti cintetvā imam gātham āha
translated: The spirit, frightened at these words, thought to himself, “It is impossible for me to eat his flesh. I will frighten him and then make my escape.” Accordingly he spoke the following stanza:

original: “Idañca te ruccati rājaputta, cajesi pāṇaṃ pituno pamokkhā;
analyzed: idam ca te ruccati rāja putta cajesi pāṇam pitunā pamokkhā
translated: “This pleases you, Prince, that you should give up your life to save your father.

original: Tasmā hi so tvaṃ taramānarūpo, sambhañja kaṭṭhāni jalehi aggi”nti.
analyzed: tasmai hi saḥ tvam taramāna rūpaḥ sambhañja kaṭṭhāni jalehi
translated: Therefore, O thou of exceeding speed, gather fuel and kindle the fire.”

original: Tattha jalehīti araññaṃ pavisitvā sāradārūni āharitvā aggiṃ jāletvā niddhūme aṅgāre kara, tattha te maṃsaṃ pacitvā khādissāmīti dīpeti.
analyzed: tattha jalehi iti araññam pavisitvā sāra dārūni āharitvā aggim jāletvā niddhūme aṅgāre kara tattha te maṃsam pacitvā khādissāmi iti dīpeti
translated: The meaning of the verse is this: “Go to the forest, bring back hard wood, kindle a fire, and make the coals free from smoke. I will cook my meat and eat it.”

original: So tathā katvā tassa santikaṃ agamāsi. Taṃ kāraṇaṃ pakāsento satthā itaraṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: saḥ tathā katvā tassa santikam agamāsi tam kāraṇam pakāsentaḥ satthā itaram gātham āha
translated: Having done as he was bidden, the prince returned to the Yakkha. The Master, in order to make clear this incident, related the second stanza:

original: “Tato have dhitimā rājaputto, dāruṃ samāharitvā mahantamaggiṃ;
analyzed: tatas have dhitimā rāja puttaḥ dārum samāharitvā mahantam aggim
translated: “Then the prudent prince, having gathered wood, kindled a great fire,

original: Santīpayitvā paṭivedayittha, ādīpito dāni mahāyamaggī”ti.
analyzed: santīpayitvā paṭivedayittha ādīpitaḥ dāni mahā ayam aggī iti
translated: And having caused it to blaze, announced to the Yakkha, ‘The great fire is now well ablaze.’“

original: Yakkho aggiṃ katvā āgataṃ kumāraṃ oloketvā “ayaṃ purisasīho, maraṇāpissa bhayaṃ natthi,
analyzed: yakkhaḥ aggim katvā āgatam kumāram oloketvā ayam purisa sīhaḥ maraṇā api issa bhayam natthi
translated: The Yakkha, when he saw the prince come back after kindling the fire, thought to himself, “This is a lion of a man. He has no fear of death.

original: mayā ettakaṃ kālaṃ evaṃ nibbhayo nāma na diṭṭhapubbo”ti lomahaṃsajāto kumāraṃ punappunaṃ
analyzed: mayā ettakam kālam evam nibbhayaḥ nāma na diṭṭha pubbaḥ ti lomahaṃsa jātaḥ kumāram punappunam
translated: For a long time I have never seen a man so fearless as this.” And he was thrilled with wonder.

original: olokento nisīdi. Kumāro tassa kiriyaṃ disvā gāthamāha –
analyzed: olokentaḥ nisīdi kumāro tassa kiriyam disvā gātham āha
translated: He sat down and looked at the prince again and again. The prince, seeing what he did, spoke the third stanza:

original: “Khādajja maṃ dāni pasayhakāri, kiṃ maṃ muhuṃ pekkhasi haṭṭhalomo;
analyzed: khādajja mam dāni pasayha kāri kim mama muhum pekkhasi haṭṭha lomo
translated: “Now eat me, you who act so cruelly; why do you look at me again and again, you with your bristling hair?

original: Tathā tathā tuyhamahaṃ karomi, yathā yathā maṃ chādayamāno adesī”ti.🔽Tattha muhunti punappunaṃ. Tathā tathā tuyhamahanti ahaṃ tuyhaṃ tathā tathā vacanaṃ
analyzed: tathā tathā tuyham aham karomi yathā yathā mam chādayamānaḥ adesi iti  tattha muhuti punappunam tathā tathā aham tuyham tathā tathā vacanam
translated: I will do just as you have told me, just as you have instructed me, that I should be covered and then eaten.”

original: karomi, idāni kiṃ karissāmi, yathā yathā maṃ chādayamāno rocayamāno adesi khādissasi,
analyzed: karomi idāni kim karissāmi yathā yathā mama chādayamānaḥ rocayamānaḥ adesi khādissasi
translated: Here, “again and again” means repeatedly. “I will do just as you have told me” means I will do just as you have instructed me. “Now what can I do?” means “Just as you have instructed me, that I should be covered and then eaten,

original: tasmā khādajja manti.
analyzed: tasmai
translated: therefore eat me now.”

original: Athassa vacanaṃ sutvā yakkho gāthamāha –
analyzed: athassa vacanam sutvā yakkhaḥ gātham āha
translated: Having heard his words, the yakkha spoke this verse:

original: “Ko tādisaṃ arahati khāditāye, dhamme ṭhitaṃ saccavādiṃ vadaññuṃ;
analyzed: kaḥ tādisam arahati khādita āye dhamme ṭhitam sacca vādim vadaññum
translated: “Who deserves to be eaten like this, one who abides by the Dhamma, who speaks the truth, who is generous?

original: Muddhāpi tassa viphaleyya sattadhā, yo tādisaṃ saccavādiṃ adeyyā”ti.
analyzed: muddhā api tassa viphaleyya sattadhā yaḥ tādisam sacca vādim a deyya ati
translated: The head of one who would eat such a truth-speaker would split into seven pieces.”

original: Taṃ sutvā kumāro “sace maṃ na khāditukāmosi, atha kasmā dārūni bhañjāpetvā aggiṃ
analyzed: tam sutvā kumāraḥ sace mam na khāditu kāmaḥ asi atha kasmai dārūni aggim
translated: Having heard that, the prince said, “If you do not wish to eat me, then why did you have the wood cut and have a fire made?

original: kāresī”ti vatvā “palāyissati nu kho, noti tava pariggaṇhanatthāyā”ti vutte “tvaṃ
analyzed: kāresi iti vatvā palāyissati nu kho no ti tava pariggaṇhana atthāya ati vutte tvam
translated: ” When asked, “Will he escape?,” he replied, “For the purpose of taking possession of you.”🔽“

original: idāni maṃ kathaṃ pariggaṇhissasi, yohaṃ tiracchānayoniyaṃ nibbatto sakkassa devarañño
analyzed: idāni mam katham pariggaṇhissasi yaḥ ham tiracchāna yoniyam nibbattaḥ sakkassa deva rañño
translated: “How will you now take me to be, when I have been reborn in the animal realm as a hare, and I have not been able to take care of myself,

original: attānaṃ pariggaṇhituṃ nādāsi”nti vatvā āha –
analyzed: attānam pariggaṇhitum na adāsin ti vatvā āha
translated: as Sakka, the king of the gods, has done?”

original: “Idañhi so brāhmaṇaṃ maññamāno, saso avāsesi sake sarīre;
analyzed: idam hi saḥ brāhmaṇam maññamānaḥ sasaḥ avāsesi sake sarīre
translated: “For this, thinking ‘A brahmin,’ the hare allowed him to live in his own body;

original: Teneva so candimā devaputto, sasatthuto kāmaduhajja yakkhā”ti.🔽Tassattho – idañhi so sasapaṇḍito “brāhmaṇo eso”ti brāhmaṇaṃ maññamāno “ajja imaṃ🔽sarīraṃ khāditvā idheva vasā”ti evaṃ sake sarīre attano sarīraṃ dātuṃ avāsesi, vasāpesīti
analyzed: tena iva saḥ candimā deva putto yakkha ati  tassa atthaḥ idam hi saḥ sa sapaṇḍitaḥ brāhmaṇaḥ esaḥ iti brāhmaṇam maññamānaḥ ajja imam  sarīram khāditvā idha iva vasāti evam sake sarīre attanaḥ sarīram dātum avāsesi vasāpesi iti
translated: Therefore, the moon-god, the son of the hare, the yakkha Kāmada, was called ‘the hare.’ ”

original: attho. Sarīrañcassa bhakkhatthāya adāsi. Sakko pabbatarasaṃ pīḷetvā ādāya candamaṇḍale
analyzed: attho sarīrañcassa bhakkha atthāya adāsi sakko pabbata rasam pīḷetvā ādāya canda maṇḍale
translated: The meaning is: for this, the wise hare, thinking “this is a brahmin,” allowed him to live in his own body, saying “today, after eating my body, live right here.” The meaning is: he allowed him to live, he gave his body to him to eat. Sakka, after pressing the mountain-juice, took it and made the hare’s mark on the moon-disk.

original: sasalakkhaṇaṃ akāsi. Tato paṭṭhāya teneva sasalakkhaṇena so candimā devaputto “sasī
analyzed: sa sa lakkhaṇam akāsi tatas paṭṭhāya tena iva sa sa lakkhaṇena so candimā devaputto sasī
translated: From that time on, because of that hare-mark, the moon-god, the son of the hare, the yakkha Kāmada, was called ‘the hare.’

original: sasī”ti evaṃ sasatthuto lokassa kāmaduho pemavaḍḍhano ajja yakkha virocati. Kappaṭṭhiyañhetaṃ pāṭihāriyanti.
analyzed: sasi iti evam lokassa kāmaduhaḥ pema vaḍḍhanaḥ ajja yakkha virocati kappaṭṭhiyan ha etam pāṭihāriyanti
translated: “Today, O Yakkha, the moon shines forth, the increaser of love, the giver of sensual delights to the world with its gods and men, just as though it were the chief of the Yakkhas himself.” This was the miracle that lasted for a week.

original: Taṃ sutvā yakkho kumāraṃ vissajjento gāthamāha –
analyzed: tam sutvā yakkhaḥ kumāram vissajjentaḥ gātham āha
translated: Hearing this, the Yakkha released the prince and spoke this verse:

original: “Cando yathā rāhumukhā pamutto, virocate pannaraseva bhāṇumā;
analyzed: candaḥ yathā rāhu mukhā pamuttaḥ virocate pannarasā iva bhāṇumā
translated: “As the moon, released from Rahu’s mouth, shines forth, resplendent on the fifteenth day,

original: Evaṃ tuvaṃ porisādā pamutto, viroca kappile mahānubhāva;
analyzed: evam tuvam porisādā pamuttaḥ viroca kappile mahā anubhāva
translated: So you, released from the hands of Porisada, shine forth in the land of the Kapilas, O mighty one.

original: Āmodayaṃ pitaraṃ mātarañca, sabbo ca te nandatu ñātipakkho”ti.
analyzed: āmodayam pitaram mātaram ca sabbaḥ ca te nandatu ñāti pakkhaḥ ti
translated: Delight your father and mother, and let all your kinsmen and relatives rejoice.”

original: Tattha bhāṇumāti sūriyo. Idaṃ vuttaṃ hoti – yathā pannarase rāhumukhā mutto cando
analyzed: tattha bhāṇumant ati sūriyaḥ idam vuttam hoti yathā pannarase rāhu mukhā muttaḥ cando
translated: Herein, resplendent means the sun. This is what is meant: Just as on the fifteenth day the moon released from Rahu’s mouth shines forth,

analyzed: vā bhāṇumā vā virocati evam tvam pi mama santikā muttaḥ kapilaraṭṭhe viroca mahā anubhāvā ati nandatu uti tussatu
translated: or just as the sun shines forth, so you, released from my hands, shine forth in the land of the Kapilas, O mighty one. Let all rejoice means let them be glad.

original: Gaccha mahāvīrāti mahāsattaṃ uyyojesi. Sopi taṃ nibbisevanaṃ katvā pañca sīlāni datvā
analyzed: gaccha mahāvīra iti mahāsattam uyyojesi saḥ api tam nibbisevanam katvā pañca sīlāni da tvā
translated: Go, O mighty hero, he sent the Great Being away. He, too, after paying his respects, gave the five precepts and
