analyzed: yakkhaḥ nu khalu esa no ti pariggaṇhantaḥ yakkhānam akkhīni rattāni honti a nimmisāni
translated: “Is he a demon or not?” He thought, “The eyes of demons are red and unblinking,

original: ca, chāyā na paññāyati, acchambhitā honti. Nāyaṃ yakkho, manusso eso. Mayhaṃ pitu
analyzed: ca chāyā na paññāyati a chambhitāḥ honti na ayam yakkhaḥ manussaḥ esaḥ mayham pitu
translated: they have no shadow, and they are fearless. This is not a demon, he is a human. My father

original: kira tayo bhātaro yakkhiniyā gahitā. Tesu etāya dve khāditā bhavissanti, eko puttasinehena
analyzed: kira tayaḥ bhātaraḥ yakkhiniyā gahitā tesu etāya dve khāditāḥ bhavissanti ekaḥ putta sinehena
translated: had three brothers who were seized by demonesses. Of them two must have been eaten, and one must have been

original: paṭijaggito bhavissati, iminā tena bhavitabbaṃ, imaṃ netvā mayhaṃ pitu ācikkhitvā
analyzed: paṭijaggitaḥ bhavissati iminā tena bhavitabbam imam netvā mayham pitu ācikkhitvā
translated: cared for out of affection for his child. This must be he. I will take him and show him to my father,

original: rajje patiṭṭhāpessāmī”ti cintetvā “ehi ambho, na tvaṃ yakkho, pitu me jeṭṭhabhātikosi,
analyzed: rajje patiṭṭhāpessāmi iti cintetvā ehi ambho na tvam yakkho me jeṭṭha bhātikaḥ asi
translated: and then I will establish him in the kingdom.” Thinking thus, he said, “Come, good sir, you are not a demon, you are my father’s eldest brother.

original: ehi mayā saddhiṃ gantvā kulasantake rajje chattaṃ ussāpehī”ti vatvā itarena “nāhaṃ
analyzed: ehi mayā saddhim gantvā kulasantake rajje chattam ussāpehi iti vatvā itarena na aham
translated: Come with me and go to the capital and have the parasol raised over you in the hereditary kingdom.” When the other said, “I am not

original: manusso”ti vutte “na tvaṃ mayhaṃ saddahasi, atthi pana so, yassa saddahasī”ti pucchitvā
analyzed: manussaḥ ti vutte na tvam mayham saddahasi atthi pana saḥ yassa saddahasi iti pucchitvā
translated: a human,” he said, “You do not believe me, but is there anyone else whom you believe?”

original: “atthi asukaṭṭhāne dibbacakkhukatāpaso”ti vutte taṃ ādāya tattha agamāsi. Tāpaso
analyzed: atthi asuka ṭṭhāne dibba cakkhuka tāpaso ti vutte tam ādāya tattha agamāsi tāpaso
translated: When the other said, “There is a seer of divine sight in such and such a place,” he took him and went there. The seer

original: te disvāva “kiṃ karontā pitāputtā araññe carathā”ti vatvā tesaṃ ñātibhāvaṃ kathesi.
analyzed: te disvāva kim karontā pitāputtāḥ araññe caratha iti vatvā tesam ñāti bhāvam kathesi
translated: When he saw them, he said, “What are you doing, father and son, wandering about in the forest?” And he told them who they were.

original: Porisādo tassa saddahitvā “tāta, tvaṃ gaccha, ahaṃ ekasmiññeva attabhāve dvidhā jāto,
analyzed: porisādaḥ tassa saddahitvā tāta tvam gaccha aham ekasmin ñeva atta bhāve dvidhā jātaḥ
translated: Pāyāsi believed him, and said, “My dear sir, you go on; I am a man of one nature, and I have been born in two places.

original: na me rajjenattho, pabbajissāmaha”nti tāpasassa santike isipabbajjaṃ pabbaji. Atha
analyzed: na me rajjena atthaḥ pabbajissāmahanti tāpasassa santike isipabbajjam pabbaji atha
translated: I have no use for a kingdom; I will become a recluse.” So saying, he became a hermit in the presence of the seer.

original: naṃ kumāro vanditvā nagaraṃ agamāsi. Tamatthaṃ pakāsento satthā –
analyzed: kumāraḥ vanditvā nagaram tam attham pakāsentaḥ satthā
translated: Then the prince saluted him and returned to the city. Expounding this matter, the Master said:

analyzed: tatas have dhitimā rāja putto katañjalī pariyāya porisādam
translated: “Then the wise prince, with hands uplifted, asked leave of Pāyāsi,

original: Anuññāto sotthi sukhī arogo, paccāgamā kapilamalīnasattā”ti. –

analyzed: samuggata bāla sūriyaḥ viya hoti bāhira pabbatesu pana ekaḥ ubbedhataḥ cha yojanikaḥ ekaḥ
translated: shine like the rising sun. But the outer mountains are six leagues high,🔽five, four, three, two, and one league high.

original: pañca, eko cattāri, eko tīṇi, eko dve, eko yojaniko, evaṃ sattapabbataparikkhittassa
analyzed: pañca ekaḥ cattāri ekaḥ tīṇi ekaḥ dve ekaḥ yojanikaḥ evam satta pabbata parikkhittassa
translated: The lake is surrounded by these seven mountains.

original: pana tassa dahassa pubbuttarakaṇṇe udakavātappaharaṇokāse mahānigrodharukkho atthi.
analyzed: pana tassa dahassa pubbuttara kaṇṇe udaka vāta ppaharaṇa ukāse mahā nigrodha rukkho atthi
translated: But in the north-east corner of the lake, in a place where the water is blown over by the wind, there is a great banyan tree.

original: Tassa khandho parikkhepato pañcayojaniko, ubbedhato sattayojaniko, catūsu disāsu
analyzed: tassa khandho parikkhepato pañca yojanikaḥ ubbedhato satta yojanikaḥ catūsu disāsu
translated: It is five leagues in girth and seven leagues in height.

original: catasso sākhā chayojanikā, uddhaṃ uggatasākhāpi chayojanikāva, iti so mūlato paṭṭhāya🔽ubbedhena terasayojaniko, sākhānaṃ orimantato yāva pārimantā dvādasayojaniko, aṭṭhahi
analyzed: catasso sākhā cha yojanikāḥ uddham uggata sākhā api cha yojanikā vaḥ iti saḥ mūlataḥ paṭṭhāya  ubbedhena terasa yojanikaḥ sākhānam orimantataḥ yāva pārimantā dvādasa yojanikaḥ aṭṭhahi
translated: It has four branches, each four leagues long, and a central branch seven leagues long.🔽Thus it is thirteen leagues in height from the base, and twelve leagues in circumference from one end to the other.

original: pārohasahassehi paṭimaṇḍito muṇḍamaṇipabbato viya vilāsamāno tiṭṭhati. Chaddantadahassa
analyzed: pāroha sahassehi paṭimaṇḍitaḥ muṇḍa maṇi pabbataḥ viya vilāsamāno tiṭṭhati chaddanta dahassa
translated: It is adorned with eight thousand terraces and shines like the jewel-mountain.

original: pana pacchimadisābhāge suvaṇṇapassapabbate dvādasayojanikā kañcanaguhā tiṭṭhati.
analyzed: pana pacchima disā bhāge suvaṇṇa passa pabbate dvādasa yojanikā kañcana guhā tiṭṭhati
translated: But in the western part of the Chaddanta’s region, on the Suvaṇṇapassapabbata, there is a golden cave twelve leagues long.

original: Chaddanto nāma nāgarājā vassāratte hemante aṭṭhasahassanāgaparivuto kañcanaguhāyaṃ
analyzed: chaddantaḥ nāma nāga rājā vassāratte hemante aṭṭha sahassa nāga parivutaḥ
translated: The nāga king Chaddanta lives in the golden cave during the rainy season, surrounded by eight thousand nāgas.

original: vasati. Gimhakāle udakavātaṃ sampaṭicchamāno mahānigrodhamūle pārohantare tiṭṭhatī.
analyzed: vasati gimha kāle udaka vātam sampaṭicchamānaḥ mahānigrodha mūle pārohantare tiṭṭhatī
translated: During the hot season he stands in the shade of a great banyan tree, in the middle of the nāga-palace, fanning the nāga-king with a yak-tail fan.

original: Athassa ekadivasaṃ “mahāsālavanaṃ pupphita”nti taruṇanāgā āgantvā ārocayiṃsu. So
analyzed: athassa eka divasam mahā sāla vanam pupphitanti taruṇa nāgāḥ āgantvā ārocayiṃsu saḥ
translated: One day the young nāgas came and told him that the Mahāsāla forest was in full bloom.

original: saparivāro “sālakīḷaṃ kīḷissāmī”ti sālavanaṃ gantvā ekaṃ supupphitaṃ sālarukkhaṃ🔽kumbhena pahari. Tadā cūḷasubhaddā paṭivātapasse ṭhitā, tassā sarīre sukkhadaṇḍakamissakāni
analyzed: sa parivāraḥ sāla kīḷam kīḷissāmi iti sāla vanam gantvā ekam su pupphitam sāla rukkham  kumbhena tadā cūḷasubhaddā paṭivāta passe ṭhitā tassā sarīre sukkha daṇḍaka missakāni
translated: and surrounded by his retinue, went to the Sāla-grove, saying: “I will play the game of Sāla-leaves.”

original: purāṇapaṇṇāni ceva tambakipillikāni ca patiṃsu. Mahāsubhaddā adhovātapasse ṭhitā,🔽tassā sarīre pupphareṇukiñjakkhapattāni patiṃsu. Cūḷasubhaddā “ayaṃ nāgarājā attano
analyzed: purāṇa paṇṇāni ca iva tamba kipillikāni ca mahāsubhaddā adhovāta passe ṭhitā  tassā sarīre puppha reṇu kiñjakkha pattāni cūḷa subhaddā ayam nāga rājā attanaḥ
translated: Cūḷasubhaddā stood in the windward position, and on her body fell dry sticks, leaves, and red ants. Mahāsubhaddā stood in the leeward position,

original: piyabhariyāya upari pupphareṇukiñjakkhapattāni pātesi, mama sarīre sukkhadaṇḍakamissāni
analyzed: piya bhariyāya upari puppha reṇu kiñjakkha pattāni pātesi mama sarīre sukkha daṇḍaka missāni
translated: and on her body fell flower-dust, and the feathers of the Kiñjaka bird. Cūḷasubhaddā thought: “This king of the Nāgas showers flower-dust and the feathers of the Kiñjaka bird on his beloved wife,

original: purāṇapaṇṇāni ceva tambakipillikāni ca pātesi, hotu, kātabbaṃ jānissāmī”ti mahāsatte veraṃ bandhi.
analyzed: purāṇa paṇṇāni ca iva tamba kipillikāni ca pātesi hotu kātabbam jānissāmi iti mahāsatte veram bandhi
translated: but on my body he showers dry sticks, leaves, and red ants. Well, I will know how to act.” And she conceived a hatred against the Great Being.

original: Aparampi divasaṃ nāgarājā saparivāro nhānatthāya chaddantadahaṃ otari. Atha dve taruṇanāgā
analyzed: aparam pi divasam nāga rājā sa parivāraḥ nhāna tthāya atha dve taruṇa nāgā
translated: On another day the king of the Nāgas, surrounded by his retinue, went down to the Chaddanta lake to bathe. Then two young Nāgas

original: soṇḍāhi usirakalāpe gahetvā kelāsakūṭaṃ majjantā viya nhāpesuṃ. Tasmiṃ nhatvā uttiṇṇe
analyzed: usira kalāpe gahetvā kelāsa kūṭam majjantāḥ viya tasmin nhatvā uttiṇṇe
translated: and bathed him as if he were washing a clump of usira-grass. When he had bathed and come out,

original: dve kareṇuyo nhāpesuṃ. Tāpi uttaritvā mahāsattassa santike aṭṭhaṃsu. Tato aṭṭhasahassanāgāsaraṃ
analyzed: dve kareṇuyaḥ nhāpesum tā api uttaritvā mahāsattassa santike aṭṭhaṃsu tatas aṭṭha sahassa nāgāsaram
translated: two female elephants bathed him. They too, when they had come out, stood near the Great Being. Then eight thousand elephants

original: otaritvā udakakīḷaṃ kīḷitvā sarato nānāpupphāni āharitvā rajatathūpaṃ alaṅkarontā
analyzed: otaritvā udaka kīḷam kīḍitvā sarataḥ nānā pupphāni āharitvā rajata thūpam alaṅkarontā
translated: came down from the elephant-hill, and after playing in the water, they brought various flowers from the lake, and after adorning the Great Being as if they were adorning the silver-thūpa,

original: viya mahāsattaṃ alaṅkaritvā pacchā dve kareṇuyo alaṅkariṃsu. Atheko hatthī sare vicaranto🔽sattuddayaṃ nāma mahāpadumaṃ labhitvā āharitvā mahāsattassa adāsi. So taṃ soṇḍāya🔽gahetvā reṇuṃ kumbhe okiritvā jeṭṭhakāya mahāsubhaddāya adāsi. Taṃ disvā itarā “idampi
analyzed: viya mahāsattam alaṅkaritvā pacchā dve kareṇuyaḥ alaṅkariṃsu atha ekaḥ hatthī sare vicarantaḥ  sattuddayam nāma mahāpadumam labhitvā āharitvā mahāsattassa adāsi saḥ tam soṇḍāya  gahetvā reṇum kumbhe okiritvā jeṭṭhakāya mahāsubhaddāya adāsi tam disvā itarāḥ idam pi
translated: they adorned the two female elephants. Then an elephant, wandering in the lake,🔽found a great lotus called sattudaya, and after bringing it, he gave it to the Great Being. He, after taking it with his trunk,

original: sattuddayaṃ mahāpadumaṃ attano piyabhariyāya eva adāsi, na mayha”nti punapi tasmiṃ veraṃ bandhi.
analyzed: sattu ddayam mahāpadumam eva adāsi na punar api tasmin veram
translated: sprinkled the pollen on his forehead, and gave it to the chief female elephant, Mahāsubhadda. After seeing it, the other one, “He gave this great lotus called sattudaya to his beloved wife, not to me,” again bound enmity in him.

original: Athekadivasaṃ bodhisatte madhuraphalāni ceva bhisamuḷālāni ca pokkharamadhunā yojetvā
analyzed: atha eka divasam bodhisatte madhura phalāni ca iva bhisa muḷālāni ca pokkhara madhunā yojetvā
translated: One day the Bodhisatta mixed some sweet fruits with honey and water,🔽

original: pañcasate paccekabuddhe bhojente cūḷasubhaddā attanā laddhaphalāphalaṃ paccekabuddhānaṃ
analyzed: pañca sate paccekabuddhe bhojente cūḷa subhaddāḥ attanā laddha phala aphalam paccekabuddhānam
translated: One day, when the Private Buddhas were eating, after the Bodhisatta had mixed sweet fruits with honey and sugar, Cūḷasubhaddā, having given the Private Buddhas the fruits she had received,

original: datvā “bhante, ito cavitvā maddarājakule nibbattitvā subhaddā nāma rājakaññā hutvā
analyzed: datvā bhante itas cavitvā madda rāja kule nibbattitvā subhaddā nāma rāja kaññā hutvā
translated: made the following Earnest Wish: “Reverend Sirs, after I have passed hence, may I be reborn in the family of the King of Madra, and become the King’s daughter, named Subhaddā.

original: vayappattā bārāṇasirañño aggamahesibhāvaṃ patvā tassa piyā manāpā taṃ attano ruciṃ🔽kāretuṃ samatthā hutvā tassa ācikkhitvā ekaṃ luddakaṃ pesetvā imaṃ hatthiṃ visapītena🔽sallena vijjhāpetvā jīvitakkhayaṃ pāpetvā chabbaṇṇaraṃsiṃ vissajjente yamakadante
analyzed: vaya pattā bārāṇasi raññaḥ agga mahesi bhāvam patvā tassa piyā manāpā tam attanaḥ rucim  kāretum samatthā hutvā tassa ācikkhitvā ekam luddakam pesetvā imam hatthim visa pītena  sallena vijjhāpetvā jīvita khayam pāpetvā chabbaṇṇa raṃsim vissajjente yamaka dante
translated: When I have reached maturity, may I become the chief consort of the King of Bārāṇasī, and be dear and beloved to him, and may I be able to do as I wish.

original: āharāpetuṃ samatthā homī”ti patthanaṃ ṭhapesi. Sā tato paṭṭhāya gocaraṃ aggahetvā
analyzed: āhara āpetum samatthā homi iti patthanam ṭhapesi sā tatas paṭṭhāya gocaram aggahetvā
translated: May I be able to send a hunter, after I have told him, and have him kill this elephant with a poisoned arrow, and after he has died, may I be able to have his tusks brought to me, which emit the seven colours, and are in pairs.”🔽From that time forth she did not go out for food,

original: sussitvā nacirasseva kālaṃ katvā maddaraṭṭhe rājaaggamahesiyā kucchimhi nibbatti,
analyzed: sussitvā nacirassa iva kālam katvā maddaraṭṭhe rāja aggamahesiyā kucchimhi nibbatti
translated: but remained in the same place, and after a short time died, and was reborn in the womb of the chief consort of the King of Madra.

original: subhaddātissā nāmaṃ kariṃsu. Atha naṃ vayappattaṃ bārāṇasirañño adaṃsu. Sā tassa
analyzed: subhaddā tissā nāmam kariṃsu atha nam vaya pattam bārāṇasi raññaḥ adaṃsu sā tassa
translated: They named her Subhaddā. When she grew up, they gave her to the king of Bārāṇasī to be his chief consort.

original: piyā ahosi manāpā, soḷasannaṃ itthisahassānaṃ jeṭṭhikā hutvā jātissarañāṇañca paṭilabhi.
analyzed: piyā ahosi manāpā soḷasannam itthi sahassānam jeṭṭhikā hutvā jāti ssara ñāṇañca paṭilabhi
translated: She became dear to him and endeared herself to him. She was the chief of sixteen thousand women and she attained the knowledge of her former lives.

original: Sā cintesi – “samiddhā me patthanā, idāni tassa nāgassa yamakadante āharāpessāmī”ti.
analyzed: sā cintesi samiddhā me patthanā idāni tassa nāgassa yamaka dante āharāpessāmi iti
translated: She thought to herself, “My desire is fulfilled. Now I will have the tusks of that elephant brought to me.”

original: Tato sarīraṃ telena makkhetvā kiliṭṭhavatthaṃ nivāsetvā gilānākāraṃ dassetvā sirigabbhaṃ
analyzed: tatas sarīram telena makkhetvā kiliṭṭha vattham nivāsetvā gilāna ākāram dassetvā sirigabbham
translated: So she anointed her body with oil, put on dirty clothes, and pretended to be sick. She went into the inner palace,

original: pavisitvā mañcake nipajji. Rājā “kuhiṃ subhaddā”ti vatvā “gilānā”ti sutvā sirigabbhaṃ
analyzed: pavisitvā mañcake nipajji rājā kuhim subhaddā iti vatvā gilānā ati sutvā sirigabbham
translated: and lay down on her bed. The king asked, “Where is Subhaddā?” When he was told that she was sick, he went into the inner palace,

original: pavisitvā mañcake nisīditvā tassā piṭṭhiṃ parimajjanto paṭhamaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: pavisitvā mañcake nisīditvā tassā piṭṭhim parimajjantaḥ paṭhamam gātham āha
translated: sat down on the bed, and began to rub her back. He spoke the first stanza:

original: “Kiṃ nu socasinuccaṅgi, paṇḍūsi varavaṇṇini;
analyzed: kim nu socasi nuccaṅgi paṇḍūsi varavaṇṇini
translated: Why do you grieve, O Uccā, why are you pale, O fair of hue?

original: Milāyasi visālakkhi, mālāva parimadditā”ti.
analyzed: milāyasi visālakkhi mālāva parimadditā ati
translated: Why do you fade, O wide-eyed one, as though a garland were crushed?

original: Tattha anuccaṅgīti kañcanasannibhasarīre. Mālāva parimadditāti hatthehi parimadditā padumamālā viya.
analyzed: tattha anuccaṅgī iti kañcana sannibha sarīre mālā ava parimadditā ati hatthehi parimadditā paduma mālā viya
translated: Here Uccā means one whose body is like gold. As though a garland were crushed means as though a lotus garland were crushed with the hands.

original: Taṃ sutvā sā itaraṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: tam sutvā sā itaram gātham āha
translated: On hearing this, she spoke the second stanza:

original: “Dohaḷo me mahārāja, supinantenupajjhagā;
analyzed: dohaḷaḥ me mahā rāja
translated: “My husband, O great king, in a dream appeared to me;🔽He is not so easy to find as is a man of common sort,

original: Na so sulabharūpova, yādiso mama dohaḷo”ti.
analyzed: na saḥ mama
translated: This husband of mine.”

original: Tattha na soti yādiso mama supinantenupajjhagā supine passantiyā mayā diṭṭho dohaḷo, so sulabharūpo viya na hoti, dullabho so, mayhaṃ pana taṃ alabhantiyā jīvitaṃ natthīti avaca.
analyzed: tattha na saḥ ti yādisaḥ mama supina antena upajjhagā supine passantiyā mayā diṭṭhaḥ dohaḷaḥ so sulabha rūpaḥ viya na hoti dullabhaḥ saḥ mayham pana tam a labhantiyā jīvitam natthi iti avaca
translated: Herein, he is not so easy to find as is a man of common sort means that the husband whom I saw in a dream is not so easy to find as is a man of common sort, he is hard to find, but if I cannot get him, there is no life for me.

original: Taṃ sutvā rājā gāthamāha –
analyzed: tam sutvā rājā gātham āha
translated: On hearing this, the king spoke the third stanza:

original: “Ye keci mānusā kāmā, idha lokamhi nandane;
analyzed: ye keci mānusā kāmāḥ idha lokamhi nandane
translated: “Whatever human pleasures there be, here in the world to give delight,

original: Sabbe te pacurā mayhaṃ, ahaṃ te dammi dohaḷa”nti.
analyzed: sabbe te pacurāḥ mayham aham te dammi
translated: All these are mine to give away, I give you, husband, this I swear.”

original: Tattha pacurāti bahū sulabhā.
analyzed: sulabhā
translated: Herein, all these are mine to give away means that they are many and easy to get.

original: Taṃ sutvā devī, “mahārāja, dullabho mama dohaḷo, na taṃ idāni kathemi, yāvattakā
analyzed: tam sutvā devī mahā rāja dullabhaḥ mama dohaḷaḥ na tam idāni kathemi yāvattakā
translated: On hearing this, the queen, “Great king, my husband is hard to find, I cannot tell you now, but all the hunters

original: pana te vijite luddā, te sabbe sannipātetha, tesaṃ majjhe kathessāmī”ti dīpentī anantaraṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: pana te vijite luddā te sabbe sannipātetha tesam majjhe kathessāmi iti dīpentī anantaram gātham āha
translated: in your realm, let them assemble, and I will tell you among them,” and so she spoke the fourth stanza:

original: “Luddā deva samāyantu, ye keci vijite tava;
analyzed: luddāḥ deva samāyantu ye vijite tava
translated: “Let hunters, O great king, assemble, all that there be in your realm;

original: Etesaṃ ahamakkhissaṃ, yādiso mama dohaḷo”ti.🔽Rājā “sādhū”ti sirigabbhā nikkhamitvā “yāvatikā tiyojanasatike kāsikaraṭṭhe luddā,
analyzed: etesam aham akkhissam yādisaḥ mama dohaḷaḥ ti  rājā sādhu uti sirigabbhā nikkhamitvā yāvatikā ti yojana satike kāsikaraṭṭhe luddā
translated: I will tell you what my hunter is like.”🔽The king said, “Very well,” and he ordered his ministers to beat the drum in order to assemble all the hunters in the kingdom of Kāsi, which extended for three leagues on every side.

original: tesaṃ sannipātatthāya bheriṃ carāpethā”ti amacce āṇāpesi. Te tathā akaṃsu. Nacirasseva
analyzed: tesam sannipāta tthāya bherim carāpetha ati amacce āṇāpesi te tathā akaṃsu nacirassa iva
translated: The ministers did so, and in a short time

original: kāsiraṭṭhavāsino luddā yathābalaṃ paṇṇākāraṃ gahetvā āgantvā āgatabhāvaṃ rañño ārocāpesuṃ.
analyzed: kāsiraṭṭha vāsinaḥ luddāḥ yathābalam paṇṇa ākāram gahetvā āgantvā āgata bhāvam raññaḥ ārocāpesuṃ
translated: the hunters of the kingdom of Kāsi came, bringing with them their various hunting implements.

original: Te sabbepi saṭṭhisahassamattā ahesuṃ. Rājā tesaṃ āgatabhāvaṃ ñatvā vātapāne ṭhito
analyzed: te sabbe api saṭṭhi sahassa mattāḥ ahesum rājā tesam āgata bhāvam ñatvā vāta pāne ṭhitaḥ
translated: They numbered sixty thousand. When the king heard that they had come, he stood at the window

original: hatthaṃ pasāretvā tesaṃ āgatabhāvaṃ deviyā kathento āha –
analyzed: hattham pasāretvā tesam āgata bhāvam deviyā kathentaḥ āha
translated: and, stretching out his hand, said to the queen,

original: “Ime te luddakā devi, katahatthā visāradā;
analyzed: ime te luddakāḥ devi kata hatthā visāra dā
translated: “These are the hunters, queen, skilled and bold,

original: Vanaññū ca migaññū ca, mamatthe cattajīvitā”ti.
analyzed: vanaññū ca migaññū ca mamatthe catta jīvitā ati
translated: Experienced in the forest and in beasts, and ready for my sake to lay down their lives.”

original: Tattha ime teti ye tvaṃ sannipātāpesi, ime te. Katahatthāti vijjhanachedanesu katahatthā
analyzed: tattha ime te iti ye tvam sannipāta apesi ime te kata hatthā ati vijjhana chedanesu kata hatthā
translated: Herein, these are the hunters means these are the hunters whom you caused to be assembled. Skilled means skilled in piercing and cutting.

original: kusalā susikkhitā. Visāradāti nibbhayā. Vanaññū ca migaññū cāti vanāni ca mige ca
analyzed: kusalā su sikkhitā visāra dā ati nibbhayā vanaññū ca migaññū ca ati vanāni ca mige ca
translated: and skilled in the good. And confident: fearless. And knowing the forest and knowing the deer: they know the forests and the deer.

original: jānanti. Mamattheti sabbepi cete mamatthe cattajīvitā, yamahaṃ icchāmi, taṃ karontīti.
analyzed: jānanti mamatthe iti sabbe pi ca ite mamatthe catta jīvitāḥ yam aham icchāmi tam karonti iti
translated: And for me: all these, though they have their own lives, are for me, they do what I want.

original: Taṃ sutvā devī te āmantetvā itaraṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: tam sutvā devī te āmantetvā itaram gātham āha
translated: Hearing this, the queen summoned them and spoke the next verse:

original: “Luddaputtā nisāmetha, yāvantettha samāgatā;
analyzed: ludda puttā nisāmetha yāvantā ittha samāgatā
translated: “Hunters’ sons, listen, all you who are assembled here;

original: Chabbisāṇaṃ gajaṃ setaṃ, addasaṃ supine ahaṃ;
analyzed: chabbisāṇam gajam setam addasam supine aham
translated: In a dream I saw a white elephant with six tusks;

original: Tassa dantehi me attho, alābhe natthi jīvita”nti.
analyzed: tassa dantehi me atthaḥ alābhe natthi jīvitanti
translated: I need his tusks; without them I cannot live.”

original: Tattha nisāmethāti suṇātha. Chabbisāṇanti chabbaṇṇavisāṇaṃ.
analyzed: tattha nisāmetha ati suṇātha chabbisāṇam ti chabbaṇṇa visāṇam
translated: Herein, listen means hear. With six tusks means with tusks of six colors.

original: Taṃ sutvā luddaputtā āhaṃsu –
analyzed: tam sutvā ludda puttāḥ āhaṃsu
translated: Hearing this, the hunters’ sons said:

original: “Na no pitūnaṃ na pitāmahānaṃ, diṭṭho suto kuñjaro chabbisāṇo;
analyzed: na naḥ pitūnam na pitāmahānam diṭṭhaḥ sutaḥ kuñjaraḥ chabbisāṇaḥ
translated: “Neither our fathers nor our grandfathers have seen or heard of an elephant with six tusks;

original: Yamaddasā supine rājaputtī, akkhāhi no yādiso hatthināgo”ti.
analyzed: yamaddasā supine rāja puttī akkhāhi naḥ yādisaḥ hatthi nāgaḥ ti
translated: Tell us what kind of tusker the princess saw in her dream.”

original: Tattha pitūnanti karaṇatthe sāmivacanaṃ. Idaṃ vuttaṃ hoti – devi neva amhākaṃ pitūhi,
analyzed: tattha pitūnam ti karaṇa atthe sāmi vacanam idam vuttam hoti devi na iva amhākam pitūhi
translated: Herein, fathers means in the instrumental case. This is what is said: Goddess, neither our fathers,

original: na pitāmahehi evarūpo kuñjaro diṭṭhapubbo, pageva amhehi, tasmā attanā diṭṭhalakkhaṇavasena
analyzed: na pitāmahehi evarūpaḥ kuñjaraḥ diṭṭha pubbaḥ pagā iva amhehi tasmai attanā diṭṭha lakkhaṇa vasena
translated: ‘No elephant like this has ever been seen by our grandfathers, let alone by us. So tell us,

original: akkhāhi no, yādiso tayā diṭṭho hatthināgoti.
analyzed: akkhāhi naḥ yādisaḥ tayā diṭṭhaḥ hatthi nāgaḥ ti
translated: according to the characteristics you have seen, what kind of elephant you saw.’

original: Anantaragāthāpi teheva vuttā –
analyzed: anantara gāthā api tehi iva vuttā
translated: The next verse was also spoken by them:

original: “Disā catasso vidisā catasso, uddhaṃ adho dasa disā imāyo;
analyzed: disā catassaḥ vidisā catassaḥ uddham adhas dasa disāḥ
translated: ‘The four quarters, the four intermediate directions, above and below, these ten directions:

original: Katamaṃ disaṃ tiṭṭhati nāgarājā, yamaddasā supine chabbisāṇa”nti.
analyzed: katamam disam tiṭṭhati nāga rājā yamaddasā supine chabbisāṇanti
translated: In which direction does the king of elephants stand, whom you saw in a dream with six tusks?’

original: Tattha disāti disāsu. Katamanti etāsu disāsu katamāya disāyāti.
analyzed: tattha disā ati disāsu katamanti etāsu disāsu katamāya disāya ati
translated: Herein, directions means in the directions. In which means in which of these directions.

original: Evaṃ vutte subhaddā sabbe ludde oloketvā tesaṃ antare patthaṭapādaṃ bhattapuṭasadisajaṅghaṃ
analyzed: evam vutte subhaddā sabbe ludde oloketvā tesam antare patthaṭa pādam bhatta puṭa sadisa jaṅgham
translated: When this was said, Subhadda looked at all the hunters and saw the one who stood out among them, who had feet like a pestle, shanks like a pot,

original: mahājāṇukaṃ mahāphāsukaṃ bahalamassutambadāṭhikaṃ nibbiddhapiṅgalaṃ dussaṇṭhānaṃ🔽bībhacchaṃ sabbesaṃ matthakamatthakena paññāyamānaṃ mahāsattassa pubbaveriṃ sonuttaraṃ
analyzed: mahā jāṇukam mahā phāsukam bahala massu tamba dāṭhikam nibbiddha piṅgalam dussaṇṭhānam  bībhaccham sabbesam matthaka matthakena paññāyamānam mahāsattassa pubbaverim sonuttaram
translated: big knees, big thighs, thick sinews and veins, a lean, tawny belly, a bad figure,🔽and was so terrifying that he was recognized by the head-anointed noble-warrior kings as the foremost of all in his clan.

original: nāma nesādaṃ disvā “esa mama vacanaṃ kātuṃ sakkhissatī”ti rājānaṃ anujānāpetvā taṃ
analyzed: nāma nesādam disvā esa mama vacanam kātum sakkhissati iti rājānam anujānāpetvā tam
translated: Seeing that hunter named Sonuttara, who was a descendant of the great being, she thought, ‘He will be able to do what I say,’ and after getting the king’s permission, she said to him:

original: ādāya sattabhūmikapāsādassa uparimatalaṃ āruyha uttarasīhapañjaraṃ vivaritvā uttarahimavantābhimukhaṃ
analyzed: ādāya satta bhūmika pāsādassa uparima talam āruyha uttara sīha pañjaram uttara himavanta abhimukham
translated: and, taking them, he ascended to the top of the seven-storied palace, opened the northern window,

original: hatthaṃ pasāretvā catasso gāthā abhāsi –
analyzed: hattham pasāretvā catassaḥ gāthāḥ abhāsi
translated: and, stretching out his hand towards the northern Himalayas, he spoke four verses:

original: “Ito ujuṃ uttariyaṃ disāyaṃ, atikkamma so satta girī brahmante;
analyzed: itas ujum uttariyam disāyam atikkamma saḥ satta girī brahmante
translated: “To the north of here, beyond the seven mountains, the Brahmas have a mountain called Suvannapassa,

original: Suvaṇṇapasso nāma girī uḷāro, supupphito kimpurisānuciṇṇo.
analyzed: suvaṇṇapassaḥ nāma girī uḷāraḥ su pupphitaḥ kimpurisa anuciṇṇaḥ
translated: which is very high, covered with flowers, and frequented by the Kinnaras.

original: “Āruyha selaṃ bhavanaṃ kinnarānaṃ, olokaya pabbatapādamūlaṃ;
analyzed: āruyha selam bhavanam olokaya pabbata pāda mūlam
translated: “Ascend the Kinnaras’ rock-cave and look down on the foot of the mountain.

original: Atha dakkhasī meghasamānavaṇṇaṃ, nigrodharājaṃ aṭṭhasahassapādaṃ.
analyzed: atha dakkhasī megha samāna vaṇṇam nigrodha rājam aṭṭha sahassa pādam
translated: Then you will see a king of the Nigrodhas, eight thousand feet high, with a color like a cloud.

original: “Tatthacchatī kuñjaro chabbisāṇo, sabbaseto duppasaho parebhi;
analyzed: kuñjaraḥ chabbisāṇaḥ sabba setaḥ duppasahaḥ parebhi
translated: “There lives a six-tusked elephant, all white, invincible to others.

original: Rakkhanti naṃ aṭṭhasahassanāgā, īsādantā vātajavappahārino.
analyzed: rakkhanti nam aṭṭha sahassa nāgāḥ īsādantāḥ vāta java ppahārino
translated: Eight thousand elephants guard him, with tusks like spears, swift as the wind.

original: “Tiṭṭhanti te tumūlaṃ passasantā, kuppanti vātassapi eritassa;
analyzed: tiṭṭhanti te tumūlam passasantā kuppanti vātassa api eritassa
translated: “They stand there, looking at the mountain peak, and are angry even at the wind that blows there.

original: Manussabhūtaṃ pana tattha disvā, bhasmaṃ kareyyuṃ nāssa rajopi tassā”ti.
analyzed: manussa bhūtam pana tattha disvā bhasmam kareyyum na assa rajaḥ api tassa ati
translated: But if they see a human there, they would reduce him to ashes, not even leaving his ashes behind.”

original: Tattha itoti imamhā ṭhānā. Uttariyanti uttarāya. Uḷāroti mahā itarehi chahi pabbatehi
analyzed: tattha itas ti imamhā ṭhānā uttariyanti uttarāya uḷāro ti mahā itarehi chahi pabbatehi
translated: Herein, from here means from this place. To the north means to the north. Uḷāra means greater than the other six mountains.

original: uccataro. Olokayāti ālokeyyāsi. Tatthacchatīti tasmiṃ nigrodhamūle gimhasamaye udakavātaṃ🔽sampaṭicchanto tiṭṭhati. Duppasahoti aññe taṃ upagantvā pasayhakāraṃ kātuṃ samatthā🔽nāma natthīti duppasaho parebhi. Īsādantāti rathīsāya samānadantā. Vātajavappahārinoti
analyzed: uccataraḥ olokayāti ālokeyyāsi tatthacchati iti tasmin nigrodha mūle gimha samaye udaka vātam  sampaṭicchantaḥ tiṭṭhati duppasaho ti aññe tam upagantvā pasayhakāram kātum samatthā  nāma natthi iti duppasaho parebhi īsā dantā ati rathīsāya samāna dantā vāta java pahārino ti
translated: Look means you should look. There stands means at the foot of that banyan tree it stands, warding off the hot winds during the hot season.

original: vātajavena gantvā paccāmitte paharaṇasīlā evarūpā aṭṭhasahassanāgā nāgarājānaṃ rakkhanti.
analyzed: vāta javena gantvā pacca amitte paharaṇa sīlāḥ evarūpāḥ aṭṭha sahassa nāgāḥ nāga rājānam rakkhanti
translated: Hard to overcome means there is none able to go near it and make it shake, therefore it is hard to overcome by others. With tusks like chariot poles means with tusks the same as chariot poles. With the speed of the wind means having gone with the speed of the wind, they are of the habit of striking enemies. Such eight thousand elephants guard the king of elephants.

original: Tumūlanti bhiṃsanakaṃ mahāsaddānubandhaṃ assāsaṃ muñcantā tiṭṭhanti. Eritassāti vātapaharitassa🔽yaṃ saddānubandhaṃ eritaṃ calanaṃ kampanaṃ, tassapi kuppanti, evaṃpharusā te nāgā.
analyzed: tumūlanti bhiṃsanakam mahā sadda anubandham assāsam muñcantā tiṭṭhanti eritassa ati vāta paharitassa  yam sadda anubandham eritam calanam kampanam tassa api kuppanti evaṃpharusāḥ te nāgāḥ
translated: Tumult means they stand, emitting a frightening, great sound, in succession. Of its shaking means of the shaking, moving, trembling, that is shaken, moved, trembled, in succession, by the wind that strikes it.

original: Nāssāti tassa nāsavātena viddhaṃsetvā bhasmaṃ katassa tassa rajopi na bhaveyyāti.
analyzed: tassa nāsa vātena bhasmam katassa tassa rajaḥ api na bhaveyya ati
translated: So rough are those elephants. Not even the dust means not even the dust of that which is scattered by the wind from its trunk, and made to ashes, would be.

original: Taṃ sutvā sonuttaro maraṇabhayabhīto āha –
analyzed: tam sutvā sonuttaraḥ maraṇa bhaya bhītaḥ āha
translated: Hearing this, Sonuttara, frightened by the fear of death, said:

original: “Bahū hime rājakulamhi santi, piḷandhanā jātarūpassa devi;
analyzed: bahū hime rājakulamhi santi piḷandhanāḥ jātarūpassa devi
translated: “There are many ornaments of gold in the royal palace, Queen;

original: Muttā maṇī veḷuriyāmayā ca, kiṃ kāhasi dantapiḷandhanena;
analyzed: muttā maṇī ca kim danta piḷandhanena
translated: Pearls, gems, and cat’s-eyes – what will you do with an ornament of ivory?

original: Māretukāmā kuñjaraṃ chabbisāṇaṃ, udāhu ghātessasi luddaputte”ti.
analyzed: māretu kāmā kuñjaram chabbisāṇam udāhu ghātessasi ludda putta iti
translated: Do you wish to kill the elephant with six tusks, or will you have the hunters killed?”

original: Tattha piḷandhanāti ābharaṇāni. Veḷuriyāmayāti veḷuriyamayāni. Ghātessasīti udāhu piḷandhanāpadesena luddaputte ghātāpetukāmāsīti pucchati.
analyzed: tattha piḷandhanā ati ābharaṇāni veḷuriya āmayā ati veḷuriya mayāni ghātessasi iti udāhu piḷandhana apadesena ludda putte ghāta a petu kāmā asi iti pucchati
translated: Herein, ornaments means adornments. Cat’s-eyes means made of cat’s-eye gems. Will you have killed means do you wish to have the hunters killed under the pretext of an ornament?

original: Tato devī gāthamāha –
analyzed: tatas devī gātham āha
translated: Then the queen spoke this verse:

original: “Sā issitā dukkhitā casmi ludda, uddhañca sussāmi anussarantī;
analyzed: sā issitā dukkhitā sussāmi anussarantī
translated: “I am jealous, hunter, and I am unhappy, and I am drying up, remembering;

original: Karohi me luddaka etamatthaṃ, dassāmi te gāmavarāni pañcā”ti.
analyzed: karohi me luddake etam attham dassāmi te gāma varāni pañca ati
translated: Do this for me, hunter, and I will give you five choice villages.”

original: Tattha sāti sā ahaṃ. Anussarantīti tena vāraṇena pure mayi kataṃ veraṃ anussaramānā.
analyzed: tattha sā ati sā aham anussarantī iti tena vāraṇena pure mayi katam veram anussaramānā
translated: Herein, I am means I am that one. Remembering means remembering the enmity that was done to me formerly by that tusker.

original: Dassāmi teti etasmiṃ te atthe nipphādite saṃvacchare satasahassuṭṭhānake pañca gāmavare dadāmīti.
analyzed: dassāmi te iti etasmin te atthe nipphādite saṃvacchare sata sahassu ṭṭhānake pañca gāma vare dadāmi iti
translated: I will give you means if this matter is accomplished I will give you five choice villages worth a hundred thousand a year.

original: Evañca pana vatvā “samma luddaputta ahaṃ ‘etaṃ chaddantahatthiṃ mārāpetvā yamakadante
analyzed: evam ca pana vatvā samma ludda putta aham etam chaddanta hatthim mārāpetvā yamakadante
translated: And having said this, he said: “Good hunter’s son, I will kill this six-tusked elephant and take the tusks,🔽

original: āharāpetuṃ samatthā homī’ti pubbe paccekabuddhānaṃ dānaṃ datvā patthanaṃ paṭṭhapesiṃ,
analyzed: āharāpetum samatthā homi iti pubbe paccekabuddhānam dānam datvā patthanam paṭṭhapesiṃ
translated: Having so spoken, she said, “Good Ludda, I have given gifts to the Private Buddhas and have made a vow, saying, ‘I am able to kill this Chaddanta and to bring away his tusks.’

original: mayā supinantena diṭṭhaṃ nāma natthi, sā pana mayā patthitapatthanā samijjhissati,🔽tvaṃ gacchanto mā bhāyī”ti taṃ samassāsetvā pesesi. So “sādhu, ayye”ti tassā vacanaṃ
analyzed: mayā supinantena diṭṭham nāma natthi sā pana mayā patthita patthanā samijjhissati  tvam gacchantaḥ mā bhāyi iti tam samassāsetvā pesesi saḥ sādhu ayya iti tassā vacanam
translated: I have never had a dream, but this vow of mine will be fulfilled.🔽Do not fear when you go.” Having thus comforted him, she sent him away. He said, “Very well, Madam,” and accepted her advice.

original: sampaṭicchitvā “tena hi me pākaṭaṃ katvā tassa vasanaṭṭhānaṃ kathehī”ti pucchanto imaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: sampaṭicchitvā tena hi me pākaṭam katvā tassa vasana ṭṭhānam kathehi iti pucchantaḥ imam gātham āha
translated: Then he asked her, “Well, tell me where he lives.” And he repeated this stanza:

original: “Katthacchatī kattha mupeti ṭhānaṃ, vīthissa kā nhānagatassa hoti;
analyzed: katthacchatī kattha mupeti ṭhānam vīthissa kā nhāna gatassa hoti
translated: “Where does he live? Where does he go? Where is his place? Where is his bathing-place?

original: Kathañhi so nhāyati nāgarājā, kathaṃ vijānemu gatiṃ gajassā”ti.
analyzed: katham hi saḥ nhāyati nāga rājā katham vijānemu gatim gajaḥ sa ati
translated: How does the king of elephants bathe? How shall we know the way of the elephant?”

original: Tattha katthacchatīti kattha vasati. Kattha mupetīti kattha upeti, kattha tiṭṭhatīti
analyzed: tattha katthacchati iti kattha vasati kattha mupeti iti kattha upeti kattha tiṭṭhati iti
translated: Herein, where does he live? Where does he go? Where does he stand?

original: attho. Vīthissa kāti tassa nhānagatassa kā vīthi hoti, kataramaggena so gacchati.
analyzed: atthaḥ vīthissa kā ati tassa nhāna gatassa kā vīthi hoti katara maggena so gacchati
translated: Attho. Vīthissa kā ti tassa nhānagatassa kā vīthi hoti, kataramaggena so gacchati.

original: Kathaṃ vijānemu gatinti tayā akathite mayaṃ kathaṃ tassa nāgarājassa gatiṃ vijānissāma,
analyzed: katham vijānemu gatim ti tayā a kathite mayam katham tassa nāga rājassa gatim vijānissāma
translated: Kathaṃ vijānemu gatin ti tayā akathite mayaṃ kathaṃ tassa nāgarājassa gatiṃ vijānissāma,

original: tasmā kathehi noti attho.
analyzed: tasmā kathehi no ti attho
translated: tasmā kathehi noti attho.

original: Tato sā jātissarañāṇena paccakkhato diṭṭhaṭṭhānaṃ tassa ācikkhantī dve gāthā abhāsi –
analyzed: tatas sā jātissara ñāṇena paccakkhataḥ diṭṭhaṭṭhānam tassa ācikkhantī dve gāthāḥ abhāsi
translated: Tato sā jātissarañāṇena paccakkhato diṭṭhaṭṭhānaṃ tassa ācikkhantī dve gāthā abhāsi –

original: “Tattheva sā pokkharaṇī adūre, rammā sutitthā ca mahodikā ca;
analyzed: tattha iva sā pokkharaṇī adūre rammā sutitthā ca mahodikā ca
translated: Tattheva sā pokkharaṇī adūre, rammā sutitthā ca mahodikā ca;

original: Sampupphitā bhamaragaṇānuciṇṇā, ettha hi so nhāyati nāgarājā.
analyzed: sampupphitāḥ bhamara gaṇa anuciṇṇāḥ ettha hi saḥ nhāyati nāga rājā
translated: Sampupphitā bhamaragaṇānuciṇṇā, ettha hi so nhāyati nāgarājā.

original: “Sīsaṃ nahātuppalamālabhārī, sabbaseto puṇḍarīkattacaṅgī;
analyzed: sīsam nahātu pala māla bhārī sabba seto
translated: Sīsaṃ nahātuppalamālabhārī, sabbaseto puṇḍarīkattacaṅgī;

original: Āmodamāno gacchati sanniketaṃ, purakkhatvā mahesiṃ sabbabhadda”nti.
analyzed: āmodamānaḥ gacchati sanniketam purakkhatvā mahesim
translated: Āmodamāno gacchati sanniketaṃ, purakkhatvā mahesiṃ sabbabhadda.

original: Tattha tatthevāti tassa vasanaṭṭhāneyeva. Pokkharaṇīti chaddantadahaṃ sandhāyāha.
analyzed: tattha tattha iva ati tassa vasana ṭṭhāneyā iva pokkharaṇī iti chaddanta daham sandhāya āha
translated: Tattha tatthevā ti tassa vasanaṭṭhāneyeva. Pokkharaṇī ti chaddantadahaṃ sandhāyāha.

original: Sampupphitāti duvidhehi kumudehi tividhehi uppalehi pañcavaṇṇehi ca padumehi samantato🔽pupphitā. Ettha hi soti so nāgarājā ettha chaddantadahe nhāyati. Uppalamālabhārīti🔽uppalādīnaṃ jalajathalajānaṃ pupphānaṃ mālaṃ dhārento. Puṇḍarīkattacaṅgīti puṇḍarīkasadisatacena
analyzed: sampupphitā ati duvidhehi kumudehi tividhehi uppalehi pañca vaṇṇehi ca padumehi samantataḥ  pupphitāḥ ettha hi saḥ iti saḥ nāga rājā ettha chaddanta dahe nhāyati uppala māla bhārī iti  uppala ādīnam jala ja thala jānam pupphānam mālam dhārentaḥ puṇḍarīka ttacaṅgī iti puṇḍarīka sadisa tacena
translated: Sampupphitā means covered all around with the two kinds of white lotuses, the three kinds of red lotuses, and the five kinds of golden lotuses. Herein, so means that the king of nāgas bathes in the Chaddanta Lake. Uppalamālabhārī means wearing a garland of the flowers of the water and the land, such as the white lotus, etc. Puṇḍarīkattacaṅgī means having the colour of a puṇḍarīka .🔽

original: odātena aṅgena samannāgato. Āmodamānoti āmoditapamodito. Sanniketanti attano vasanaṭṭhānaṃ.
analyzed: odātena aṅgena samannāgataḥ āmodamāno ti āmodita pamodito sanniketanti attanaḥ vasana ṭhānaṃ
translated: Sampupphitā means covered all around with the two kinds of lotuses, the three kinds of lilies, and the five kinds of water lilies. Herein, so means that the king of the nāgas bathes here in the Chaddanta Lake. Uppalamālabhārī means wearing a garland of water and land flowers such as the lotus. Puṇḍarīkattacaṅgī means having a body white like a puṇḍarīka. Āmodamānoti means being delighted and pleased. Sanniketanti means to his own dwelling place.

original: Purakkhatvāti sabbabhaddaṃ nāma mahesiṃ purato katvā aṭṭhahi nāgasahassehi parivuto
analyzed: purakkhatvā ati sabbabhaddam nāma mahesim puratas katvā aṭṭhahi nāga sahassehi parivutaḥ
translated: Purakkhatvā means surrounded by eight thousand nāgas, making the great queen named Sabbabhaddā go in front of him.

original: attano vasanaṭṭhānaṃ gacchatīti.
analyzed: attanaḥ vasanaṭṭhānam gacchati iti
translated: He goes to his own dwelling place.

original: Taṃ sutvā sonuttaro “sādhu ayye, ahaṃ taṃ vāraṇaṃ māretvā tassa dante āharissāmī”ti
analyzed: tam sutvā sonuttaraḥ sādhu ayye aham tam vāraṇam māretvā tassa dante āharissāmi iti
translated: Having heard that, Sonuttara said, “Good, Noble Lady, I will kill that elephant and bring his tusks.”

original: sampaṭicchi. Athassa sā tuṭṭhā sahassaṃ datvā “gehaṃ tāva gaccha, ito sattāhaccayena
analyzed: sampaṭicchi athassa sā tuṭṭhā sahassam da tvā geham tāva gaccha ito sattāha cayena
translated: He agreed. Then she, being pleased, gave him a thousand and said, “Go home for now. After seven days have passed,

original: tattha gamissasī”ti taṃ uyyojetvā kammāre pakkosāpetvā “tātā amhākaṃ vāsipharasu-kuddāla-nikhādana-muṭṭhikaveḷugumbacchedana-sattha-tiṇalāyana-asilohadaṇḍakakacakhāṇuka-
analyzed: tattha gamissasi iti tam uyyojetvā kammāre pakkosāpetvā tātā amhākam
translated: and you will go there.” After sending him away, she had the blacksmiths summoned and said: “Dears, we need knives, axes, spades, hoes, hatchets, saws, grass-knives, iron rods, chisels,

original: ayasiṅghāṭakehi attho, sabbaṃ sīghaṃ katvā āharathā”ti āṇāpetvā cammakāre pakkosāpetvā
analyzed: ayas siṅghāṭakehi attho sabbam sīgham katvā āharatha ati āṇāpetvā cammakāre pakkosāpetvā
translated: and iron ploughshares, bring all of these quickly.” After having the leather workers summoned she said:

original: “tātā amhākaṃ kumbhabhāragāhitaṃ cammabhastaṃ kātuṃ vaṭṭati, cammayottavarattahatthipādaupāhanacammachattehipi
analyzed: tātā amhākam kumbha bhāra gāhitam camma bhastam kātum vaṭṭati
translated: “Dears, we need a leather bag to carry the water, and we need leather straps, red leather shoes, sandals, and an umbrella,

He then made a passage for himself to enter the pit, and when he had finished the pit, he fastened the rope to the post, put on his yellow garments,🔽took his bow and poisoned arrow, and entered the pit.

original: saddhiṃ visapītena sallena dhanuṃ ādāya āvāṭaṃ otaritvā aṭṭhāsi. Tamatthaṃ pakāsento satthā āha –🔽“Khaṇitvāna kāsuṃ phalakehi chādayi, attānamodhāya dhanuñca luddo;
analyzed: saddhim visa pītena sallena dhanum ādāya āvāṭam otaritvā aṭṭhāsi tam attham pakāsento satthā āha  khaṇitvāna kāsum phalakehi chādayi attānam odhāya dhanuṃ ca luddaḥ
translated: Having dug the pit, he covered it with planks, and hid himself in it, taking his bow and arrow,🔽thinking, “I will kill the elephant.”

original: Passāgataṃ puthusallena nāgaṃ, samappayī dukkaṭakammakārī.🔽“Viddho ca nāgo koñcamanādi ghoraṃ, sabbe ca nāgā ninnaduṃ ghorarūpaṃ;
analyzed: passāgatam puthusallena nāgam dukkaṭa kamma kārī  viddhaḥ ca nāgo ghoram sabbe ca nāgāḥ ghora rūpam
translated: The elephant, hearing the terrible cry of the peacock,🔽ran to the place where the sound was heard.🔽The elephant, pierced by the poisoned arrow, uttered a terrible cry,🔽and all the other elephants, hearing the cry, ran in the direction of the sound,

original: Tiṇañca kaṭṭhañca raṇaṃ karontā, dhāviṃsu te aṭṭha disā samantato.
analyzed: tiṇam ca kaṭṭham ca raṇam karontā dhāviṃsu te aṭṭha disā samantataḥ
translated: making the earth tremble with their tread.

original: “Vadhissametanti parāmasanto, kāsāvamaddakkhi dhajaṃ isīnaṃ;
analyzed: vadhissam etanti parāmasantaḥ dhajam isīnam
translated: The hunter, seeing the yellow robe of the ascetic, thought, “I will kill the ascetic.”

original: Dukkhena phuṭṭhassudapādi saññā, arahaddhajo sabbhi avajjharūpo”ti.🔽Tattha odhāyāti odahitvā pavesetvā. Passāgatanti attano āvāṭassa passaṃ āgataṃ. So🔽kira dutiyadivase āgantvā nhatvā uttiṇṇo tasmiṃ mahāvisālamālake nāma padese aṭṭhāsi.
analyzed: dukkhena phuṭṭhassa udapādi saññā arahat hajo sabbhi avajjha rūpo ti  tattha odhāya ati odahitvā pavesetvā passa āgatam ti attanaḥ āvāṭassa passam āgatam so  kira dutiya divase āgantvā nhatvā uttiṇṇaḥ tasmin mahāvisālamālake nāma padese aṭṭhāsi
translated: The thought arose in him: “The Noble One has come to the pool.”🔽Thereupon he took his bow and arrow, and going to the pool, he stood on the bank and looked out for the Noble One.

original: Athassa sarīrato udakaṃ nābhipadesena ogalitvā tena chiddena luddassa sarīre pati.
analyzed: athassa sarīrataḥ udakam nābhi padesena ogalitvā tena chiddena luddassa sarīre pati
translated: The next day the hunter came and bathed in the pool. When he had finished bathing, he stood on the bank.🔽Water from the body of the Great Being flowed down into the hunter’s body through the opening in the wound.

original: Tāya saññāya so mahāsattassa āgantvā ṭhitabhāvaṃ ñatvā taṃ passāgataṃ puthunā sallena🔽samappayi vijjhi. Dukkaṭakammakārīti tassa mahāsattassa kāyikacetasikassa dukkhassa
analyzed: tāya saññāya saḥ mahāsattassa āgantvā ṭhita bhāvam ñatvā tam passāgatam puthunā sallena  samappayi vijjhi dukkaṭa kamma kārī iti tassa mahāsattassa kāyika cetasikassa dukkhassa
translated: By this sign the hunter knew that the Great Being had come and was standing there. He aimed an arrow at the Great Being’s heart

original: uppādanena dukkaṭassa kammassa kārako.🔽Koñcamanādīti koñcanādaṃ akari. Tassa kira taṃ sallaṃ nābhiyaṃ pavisitvā pihakādīni
analyzed: uppādanena dukkaṭassa kammassa kārako  koñcamanādī iti koñcanādam akari tassa kira tam sallam pavisitvā pihaka ādīni
translated: and shot him. The hunter had committed a wicked deed,🔽for he had caused the Great Being pain of body and mind.🔽The Great Being uttered a cry of distress. The arrow had entered his navel and had pierced his intestines, liver, and other organs.

original: sañcuṇṇetvā antāni chinditvā piṭṭhibhāgaṃ pharasunā padālentaṃ viya uggantvā ākāse
analyzed: sañcuṇṇetvā antāni chinditvā piṭṭhi bhāgam pharasunā padālentam viya uggantvā ākāse
translated: It then came out of his back, as if a hatchet had been used to cut his back to pieces.

original: pakkhandi. Bhinnarajatakumbhato rajanaṃ viya pahāramukhena lohitaṃ pagghari, balavavedanā
analyzed: pakkhandi bhinna rajata kumbhataḥ rajanam viya pahāra mukhena lohitam balava vedanā
translated: and he fled. Blood flowed from his mouth as he ran, like dye flowing from a broken dye-pot. He felt a sharp pain.

original: uppajji. So vedanaṃ adhivāsetuṃ asakkonto vedanāppatto sakalapabbataṃ ekaninnādaṃ🔽karonto tikkhattuṃ mahantaṃ koñcanādaṃ nadi. Sabbe cāti tepi sabbe aṭṭhasahassanāgā
analyzed: uppajji saḥ vedanam adhivāsetum a sakkontaḥ vedanā appatto sakala pabbatam eka ninnādam  karontaḥ tikkhattum mahantam koñcanādam nadi sabbe te api sabbe aṭṭha sahassa nāgā
translated: Unable to bear the pain, he uttered a loud cry, and the whole mountain echoed with the sound.

original: taṃ saddaṃ sutvā maraṇabhayabhītā ghorarūpaṃ ninnaduṃ anuravaṃ kariṃsu. Raṇaṃ karontāti
analyzed: tam saddam sutvā maraṇa bhaya bhītāḥ ghora rūpam ninnadum anuravam kariṃsu raṇam karontā ati
translated: All the other elephants, hearing the sound, were frightened by the fear of death, and they uttered a terrible cry of distress.🔽They rushed to the place where the fight was taking place.

original: tena saddena gantvā chaddantavāraṇaṃ vedanāppattaṃ disvā “paccāmittaṃ gaṇhissāmā”ti
analyzed: tena saddena gantvā chaddanta vāraṇam vedanā appattam disvā pacca āmittam gaṇhissāma ati
translated: Seeing the six-tusked elephant in pain, they thought, “We will capture our enemy.”

original: tiṇañca kaṭṭhañca cuṇṇavicuṇṇaṃ karontā samantā dhāviṃsu.🔽Vadhissametanti “bhikkhave, so chaddantavāraṇo disā pakkantesu nāgesu subhaddāya
analyzed: tiṇam ca kaṭṭham ca cuṇṇa vicuṇṇam karontā samantā dhāviṃsu  vadhissam etat ti bhikkhave saḥ chaddanta vāraṇaḥ disā pakkantesu nāgesu subhaddāya
translated: They rushed about in all directions, tearing up grass and trees.🔽“They will kill him” means that when the other elephants had fled in all directions, the she-elephant Subhaddā stood by the side of the six-tusked elephant,

original: kareṇuyā passe ṭhatvā sandhāretvā samassāsayamānāya vedanaṃ adhivāsetvā kaṇḍassa
analyzed: kareṇuyā passe ṭhatvā sandhāretvā samassāsayamānāya vedanam adhivāsetvā kaṇḍassa
translated: and by encouraging him, he was able to bear the pain.

original: āgataṭṭhānaṃ sallakkhento ‘sace idaṃ puratthimadisādīhi āgataṃ abhavissa, kumbhādīhi
analyzed: āgata ṭṭhānam sallakkhento sace idam puratthima disā ādīhi āgatam abhavissa kumbha ādīhi
translated: and he considered the place from which it had come: ‘If it had come from the east, etc.,

original: pavisitvā pacchimakāyīdīhi nikkhamissa, idaṃ pana nābhiyā pavisitvā ākāsaṃ pakkhandi,
analyzed: pavisitvā nikkhamissa idam pana nābhiyā pavisitvā ākāsam pakkhandi
translated: it would have entered by the navel, etc., and gone out by the back, but it entered by the navel and went up into the sky;

original: tasmā pathaviyaṃ ṭhitena vissaṭṭhaṃ bhavissatī’ti upadhāretvā ṭhitaṭṭhānaṃ upaparikkhitukāmo🔽“ko jānāti, kiṃ bhavissati, subhaddaṃ apanetuṃ vaṭṭatī”ti cintetvā “bhadde, aṭṭhasahassanāgā
analyzed: tasmā pathaviyam ṭhitena vissaṭṭham bhavissati iti upadhāretvā ṭhita ṭṭhānam upaparikkhitu kāmaḥ  kaḥ jānāti kim bhavissati subhaddam apanetum vaṭṭati iti cintetvā bhadde aṭṭha sahassa nāgā
translated: therefore it must have come from the earth.’ So he decided, and he wanted to examine the place where it had stood.

original: mama paccāmittaṃ pariyesantā disā pakkhandā, tvaṃ idha kiṃ karosī”ti vatvā, “deva,
analyzed: mama pacca amittam pariyesantā disā pakkhandā tvam idha kim karosi iti vatvā deva
translated: He thought, ‘Who knows what will happen? It would be well to take Subhadda away.’ And he said, ‘My dear, my enemies have gone away in the eight directions in search of me. What are you doing here?’

original: ahaṃ tumhe sandhāretvā samassāsentī ṭhitā, khamatha me”ti tikkhattuṃ padakkhiṇaṃ
analyzed: aham tumhe sandhāretvā samassāsentī ṭhitā khamatha mā iti tikkhattum padakkhiṇam
translated: ‘Your Majesty, I have been standing here encouraging you. Forgive me.’ She made three circumambulations of him, keeping him to her right,

original: katvā catūsu ṭhānesu vanditvā tāya ākāsaṃ pakkhandāya nāgarājā bhūmiṃ pādanakhena
analyzed: katvā catūsu ṭhānesu vanditvā tāya ākāsam pakkhandāya nāga rājā bhūmim pāda nakhena
translated: and she saluted him in the four places. As she went up into the sky, the king struck the ground with his toe. A crack appeared and she went down into it.

original: pahari, padaraṃ uppatitvā gataṃ. So chiddena olokento sonuttaraṃ disvā “vadhissāmi
analyzed: pahari padaram uppatitvā gatam saḥ chiddena olokentaḥ sonuttaram disvā vadhissāmi
translated: The king looked about and saw Sonuttara. ‘I will kill him,’ he thought.

original: na”nti cittaṃ uppādetvā rajatadāmavaṇṇasoṇḍaṃ pavesetvā parāmasanto buddhānaṃ isīnaṃ
analyzed: cittam uppādetvā rajata dāma vaṇṇa soṇḍam pavesetvā parāmasantaḥ buddhānam isīnam
translated: and he thought, “No,” and he entered the elephant-stable, and as he was looking about, he saw the yellow robe, the banner of the Buddhas and the Seers.

original: dhajaṃ kāsāvaṃ addakkhi. Luddo kāsāvaṃ mahāsattassa hatthe ṭhapesi. So taṃ ukkhipitvā🔽purato ṭhapesi. Athassa tena tathārūpenapi dukkhena phuṭṭhassa “arahaddhajo nāma
analyzed: dhajam kāsāvam addakkhi luddaḥ kāsāvam mahāsattassa hatthe ṭhapesi saḥ tam ukkhipitvā  puratas ṭhapesi athassa tena tathārūpena api dukkhena phuṭṭhassa arahaddhajaḥ nāma
translated: The hunter placed the yellow robe in the Great Being’s hand, and he raised it and placed it in front of him.

original: sabbhi paṇḍitehi avajjharūpo, aññadatthu sakkātabbo garukātabboyevā”ti ayaṃ saññā udapādi.
analyzed: sabbhi paṇḍitehi avajjha rūpaḥ añña datthu sakkātabbaḥ garukātabbaḥ yeva ati ayam saññā udapādi
translated: Then, although he was suffering from the pain of his wounds, the thought arose in his mind, “The banner of the Arahats is a thing that should be honoured and revered by all the wise.”

original: So tena saddhiṃ sallapanto gāthādvayamāha –
analyzed: saḥ tena saddhim sat lapantaḥ gāthā dvayam āha
translated: And as he was reflecting on the matter, he uttered two verses:🔽“He who, without casting off the stains,

original: “Anikkasāvo kāsāvaṃ, yo vatthaṃ paridahissati;
analyzed: a nikkasāvaḥ kāsāvam yaḥ vattham paridahissati
translated: should don the yellow robe,🔽is not worthy of the yellow robe,

original: Apeto damasaccena, na so kāsāvamarahati.
analyzed: apetaḥ dama saccena na saḥ
translated: if he be not endowed with self-control and truth.🔽“But he who, having cast off the stains,

original: “Yo ca vantakasāvassa, sīlesu susamāhito;
analyzed: yaḥ ca vantakasāvassa sīlesu su samāhitaḥ
translated: is well-established in virtue,🔽is worthy of the yellow robe,

original: Upeto damasaccena, sa ve kāsāvamarahatī”ti.
analyzed: upetaḥ dama saccena sa ve kāsāvamarahati iti
translated: if he be endowed with self-control and truth.”

original: Tassattho – samma luddaputta yo puriso rāgādīhi kasāvehi anikkasāvo indriyadamena
analyzed: tassa atthaḥ samma ludda putta yaḥ purisaḥ rāga ādīhi kasāvehi a nikkasāvaḥ indriya damena
translated: The meaning of this is as follows: “My dear son of a hunter, he who is not free from the stains of lust, etc., and who is not endowed with self-control and truth, is not worthy of the yellow robe, the banner of the Arahats.

original: ceva vacīsaccena ca apeto anupagato tehi guṇehi kasāvarasapītaṃ kāsāvavatthaṃ paridahati,
analyzed: ca iva vacī saccena ca apetaḥ anupagataḥ tehi guṇehi kasāva rasa pītam kāsāva vattham paridahati
translated: and who is devoid of and destitute of truth of speech, who wears the yellow robe dyed in Kasāva, the color of urine.

original: so taṃ kāsāvaṃ nārahati, nānucchaviko so tassa vatthassa. Yo pana tesaṃ kasāvānaṃ
analyzed: saḥ tam kāsāvam na arahati na anucchavikaḥ saḥ tassa vatthassa yaḥ pana tesam kasāvānam
translated: He does not deserve the yellow robe, he is not worthy of the robe. But he who is a monk in the true sense of the word,

original: vantattā vantakasāvo assa sīlesu susamāhito supatiṭṭhito paripuṇṇasīlācāro, so taṃ🔽kāsāvaṃ arahati nāmāti.
analyzed: vantattā vantaka sāvaḥ assa sīlesu su samāhito su patiṭṭhito paripuṇṇa sīla ācāro so tam  nāma ati
translated: who is well-composed and well-established in virtue, who is perfect in conduct, he deserves the yellow robe.🔽Having said this, the Great Being extinguished his anger, and asked, “Why do you try to kill me? Is it for your own sake, or have you been sent by another?”

original: Evaṃ vatvā mahāsatto tasmiṃ cittaṃ nibbāpetvā “samma kimatthaṃ tvaṃ maṃ vijjhasi, kiṃ attano atthāya, udāhu aññena payojitosī”ti pucchi. Tamatthaṃ āvīkaronto satthā āha –
analyzed: evam vatvā mahāsatto tasmin cittam nibbāpetvā samma kimattham tvam mam vijjhasi kim attanaḥ atthāya udāhu aññena payojito asi iti pucchi tam attham āvīkarontaḥ satthā āha
translated: To make this clear, the Teacher said:

original: “Samappito puthusallena nāgo, aduṭṭhacitto luddakamajjhabhāsi;
analyzed: samappitaḥ puthusallena nāgaḥ aduṭṭha cittaḥ luddakam ajjhabhāsi
translated: “The elephant, pierced by the arrow, spoke to the hunter with a mind free from anger:

original: Kimatthayaṃ kissa vā samma hetu, mamaṃ vadhī kassa vāyaṃ payogo”ti.
analyzed: kimatthayam kissa vā samma vadhī kassa vā ayam
translated: ‘For what purpose, good man, and for what reason, do you kill me? For whose use is this arrow?’”

original: Tattha kimatthayanti āyatiṃ kiṃ patthento. Kissa vāti kissa hetu kena kāraṇena, kiṃ
analyzed: tattha kim atthayanti āyatim kim patthento kissa vāti kissa hetu kena kāraṇena kim
translated: Herein, “for what purpose” means “what do you hope to gain in the future?” “For what reason” means “for what reason, for what cause, for what purpose?”

original: nāma tava mayā saddhiṃ veranti adhippāyo. Kassa vāti kassa vā aññassa ayaṃ payogo,
analyzed: nāma tava mayā saddhim veranti adhippāyaḥ kassa vā ati kassa vā aññassa ayam payogo
translated: “Whose is it? Whose is it? Whose is this purpose?

original: kena payojito maṃ avadhīti attho.
analyzed: kena payojitaḥ mama avadhi iti
translated: By whom was I sent to be killed?”

original: Athassa ācikkhanto luddo gāthamāha –
analyzed: athassa ācikkhantaḥ luddaḥ gātham āha
translated: Then the hunter, explaining, spoke this verse:🔽“The queen of King Kāsī, reverend sir,

original: “Kāsissa rañño mahesī bhadante, sā pūjitā rājakule subhaddā;
analyzed: kāsissa raññaḥ mahesī bhadante sā pūjitā rāja kule su bhaddā
translated: the honored Subhaddā in the royal family,

original: Taṃ addasā sā ca mamaṃ asaṃsi, dantehi atthoti ca maṃ avocā”ti.🔽Tattha pūjitāti aggamahesiṭṭhāne ṭhapetvā pūjitā. Addasāti sā kira taṃ supinante🔽addasa. Asaṃsīti sā ca mama sakkāraṃ kāretvā “himavantapadese evarūpo nāma nāgo asukasmiṃ
analyzed: tam addasā sā ca asaṃsi dantehi ca mamam avoca ati  tattha pūjitā ti agga mahesi ṭhāne ṭhapetvā pūjitā addasā iti sā kira tam  addasa asaṃsi iti sā ca mama sakkāram kāretvā himavanta padese evarūpaḥ nāma nāgaḥ asukasmin
translated: she saw me and she sent me, saying, ‘I want tusks.’ ”

original: nāma ṭhāne vasatī”ti mamaṃ ācikkhi. Dantehīti tassa nāgassa chabbaṇṇaraṃsisamujjalā
analyzed: nāma ṭhāne vasati iti ācikkhi dantehi iti tassa nāgassa chabbaṇṇa raṃsi samujjalā
translated: Herein, honored means she was honored after being placed in the position of chief queen. She saw means she saw him in a dream. She sent me means she did me honor and told me, “In the Himalayas there is a nāga like this, living in such-and-such a place.🔽I want tusks means that nāga’s tusks are radiant with six colors,

original: dantā, tehi mama attho, piḷandhanaṃ kāretukāmāmhi, te me āharāti maṃ avocāti.
analyzed: dantā tehi mama attho piḷandhanam kāretu kāmā amhi te me āhara ati mam avoca iti
translated: I want them, I want to make a necklace, bring them to me. She told me.

original: Taṃ sutvā “idaṃ cūḷasubhaddāya kamma”nti ñatvā mahāsatto vedanaṃ adhivāsetvā “tassā mama dantehi attho natthi, maṃ māretukāmatāya pana pahiṇī”ti dīpento gāthādvayamāha –
analyzed: tam sutvā idam cūḷasubhaddāya kammanti ñatvā mahāsattaḥ vedanam adhivāsetvā tassāḥ mama dantehi atthaḥ natthi mam māretu kāma tāya pana pahiṇi iti dīpentaḥ gāthā dvayam āha
translated: The Great Being, knowing that this was the work of Cūḷa Subhaddā, bore the pain and said two stanzas, in order to show that he had no need of his tusks, but that she had sent the hunter to kill him:

original: “Bahū hime dantayugā uḷārā, ye me pitūnañca pitāmahānaṃ;
analyzed: bahū hi me danta yugāḥ uḷārāḥ ye me pitūnam ca pitāmahānam
translated: 1. “These pairs of tusks of mine, so great, which are my father’s and my grandfather’s,

original: Jānāti sā kodhanā rājaputtī, vadhatthikā veramakāsi bālā.
analyzed: jānāti sā kodhanā rāja puttī vadhatthikā veramakā asi bālā
translated: The angry princess knows them well; the foolish one has made an enemy for the sake of death.

original: “Uṭṭhehi tvaṃ ludda kharaṃ gahetvā, dante ime chinda purā marāmi;
analyzed: uṭṭhehi tvam ludda kharam gahetvā dante ime chinda purā marāmi
translated: 2. “Rise up, O hunter, take the sharp axe and cut off these tusks before I die;

original: Vajjāsi taṃ kodhanaṃ rājaputtiṃ, nāgo hato handa imassa dantā”ti.
analyzed: vajjāsi tam kodhanam rāja puttim nāgaḥ hataḥ handa imassa danta ati
translated: You will go to the angry princess and say: ‘The tusks of the slain elephant are here.’“

original: Tattha imeti tassa kira pitu pitāmahānaṃ dantā mā vinassantūti guhāyaṃ sannicitā,
analyzed: tattha ime iti tassa kira dantāḥ mā vinassantu iti guhā ayam sannicitā
translated: Herein, these is said with reference to the tusks of his father and grandfather, which were stored in a cave, lest they should be lost.

original: te sandhāya evamāha. Jānātīti bahūnaṃ vāraṇānaṃ idha sannicihe dante jānāti. Vadhatthikāti
analyzed: te sandhāya evam āha jānāti iti bahūnam vāraṇānam idha sannicihe dante jānāti vadhatthikā iti
translated: He said this with reference to them. Knows them well: she knows the tusks which are stored here of many elephants. For the sake of death:

original: kevalaṃ pana sā maṃ māretukāmā appamattakaṃ dosaṃ hadaye ṭhapetvā attano veraṃ akāsi,
analyzed: kevalam pana sā mam māretu kāmā appamattakam dosam hadaye ṭhapetvā attanaḥ veram akāsi
translated: but she has made an enemy for herself, placing in her heart a slight anger, merely desiring to kill me.

original: evarūpena pharusakammena matthakaṃ pāpesi. Kharanti kakacaṃ. Purā marāmīti yāva na🔽marāmi. Vajjasīti vadeyyāsi. Handa imassa dantāti hato so mayā nāgo, manoratho te
analyzed: evarūpena pharusa kammena matthakam kharanti kakacam purā marāmi iti yāva na  marāmi vajjasi iti vadeyyāsi handa imassa danta ati hataḥ saḥ mayā nāgaḥ manorathaḥ te
translated: and he struck him on the head with such a blow as this. ‘Kharanti’ means ‘they are grinding’. ‘Purā marāmi’ means ‘before I die’. ‘Vajjasī’ means ‘you will say’. ‘Handa imassa dantā’ means ‘I have killed that elephant, your wish is fulfilled’.

original: matthakappatto, gaṇha, ime tassa dantāti.
analyzed: matthaka ppattaḥ gaṇhe ime tassa dantā ti
translated: and with such a cruel deed he struck him on the head. ‘Kharanti kakacam’ means ‘I will scratch the saw.’ ‘Purā marāmī’ means ‘before I die.’ ‘Vajjasī’ means ‘you will say.’ ‘Handa imassa dantā’ means ‘give me his tusks.’ ‘Hato so mayā nāgo’ means ‘that elephant was killed by me.’ ‘Manoratho te matthakappatto’ means ‘your desire has reached its peak.’ ‘Gaṇha, ime tassa dantā’ means ‘take, these are his tusks.’

original: So tassa vacanaṃ sutvā nisīdanaṭṭhānā vuṭṭhāya kakacaṃ ādāya “dante chindissāmī”ti
analyzed: so tassa vacanam sutvā nisīdanaṭṭhānā vuṭṭhāya kakacam ādāya dante chindissāmi iti

original: tassa santikaṃ upagato. So pana ubbedhato aṭṭhāsītihattho rajatapabbato viya ṭhito,
analyzed: tassa santikam upagataḥ saḥ pana ubbedhataḥ aṭṭhāsīti hatthaḥ rajata pabbataḥ viya ṭhitaḥ

analyzed: tena assa saḥ dantaṭṭhānam na pāpuṇi atha mahāsatto kāyam upanāmentaḥ heṭṭhā sīsakaḥ nipajji

analyzed: tadā nesādaḥ mahāsattassa rajata dāma sadisam soṇḍam maddantaḥ abhiruhitvā kelāsa kūṭe

analyzed: viya kumbhe ṭhatvā mukha koṭi maṃsam dhanukena paharitvā antar pakkhipitvā kumbhato

original: oruyha kakacaṃ antomukhe pavesesi, ubhohi hatthehi daḷhaṃ aparāparaṃ kaḍḍhi. Mahāsattassa🔽balavavedanā uppajji, mukhaṃ lohitena pūri. Nesādo ito cito ca sañcārento kakacena
analyzed: oruyha kakacam antomukhe pavesesi ubhohi hatthehi daḷham apara aparam kaḍḍhi mahāsattassa  balava vedanā mukham lohitena pūri nesādaḥ itas citas ca sañcārento kakacena
translated: and thrusting the axe into his mouth, he pulled it back and forth with both hands. The Great Being🔽felt a sharp pain, and his mouth filled with blood. The hunter, moving his head this way and that, was unable to cut it off with the axe.

original: chindituṃ nāsakkhi. Atha naṃ mahāsatto mukhato lohitaṃ chaḍḍetvā vedanaṃ adhivāsetvā
analyzed: chinditum na asakkhi atha nam mahāsattaḥ mukhataḥ lohitam chaḍḍetvā vedanam adhivāsetvā
translated: Then the Great Being, letting the blood flow from his mouth, endured the pain,

analyzed: kim samma chinditum na sakkosi iti pucchi āma sāmi iti mahāsatto satim paccupaṭṭhapetvā  tena hi samma mama soṇḍam ukkhipitvā kakaca koṭim gaṇhāpehi mama sayam soṇḍam ukkhipitum
translated: and asked, “What is the matter, my dear? Are you unable to cut it off?” “Yes, master.” The Great Being, recovering his presence of mind,

analyzed: atha nam te āharāpetvā gaṇhitvā samma ludda putta aham ime dante tuyham dadamānaḥ
translated: Then the hunter had them brought to him, and taking them, said, “My dear hunter, as I give you these tusks,

analyzed: na iva mayham appiyā ati dammi na sakkatta māratta brahmattāni patthentaḥ imehi pana
translated: “I do not give them to you because I hate them, nor because I desire honor, fame, or heavenly bliss;

original: me dantehi sataguṇena sahassaguṇena satasahassaguṇena sabbaññutaññāṇadantāva piyatarā,
analyzed: me dantehi sataguṇena sahassaguṇena sata sahassaguṇena sabbaññuta ññāṇa dantā ava piyatarā

analyzed: sabbaññu taññāṇa paṭivedhāya me idam puññam paccayaḥ hotu iti dante da tvā samme idam

original: anāgatesuyeva tesu nāgesu subhaddāya ca anāgatāya kālamakāsi. Tamatthaṃ pakāsento satthā āha –🔽“Uṭṭhāya so luddo kharaṃ gahetvā, chetvāna dantāni gajuttamassa;

analyzed: tam attham pakāsentaḥ satthā āha
translated: Expounding this matter, the Teacher said,🔽“The elephants, having wept and wailed,

translated: And, fair and straight, he set them on his car;🔽The hunter, all about whose body were

translated: “Having attained great power, he attained full enlightenment, and in the midst of the assembly he smiled.

translated: “At that time, monks, I was right there,
