translated: Thus must the Jātaka be remembered.

original: Imā gāthā dasabalassa guṇe vaṇṇentehi dhammasaṅgāhakattherehi ṭhapitā.
analyzed: imāḥ gāthāḥ dasabalassa guṇe vaṇṇentehi dhammasaṅgāhaka therehi ṭhapitā
translated: These verses were composed by the Dhamma-reciters, the Elders Tissa and Buddha, in praise of the virtues of the Master of the Ten Perfections.

original: Tattha sitaṃ akāsīti so sambodhippatto satthā mahānubhāvo alaṅkatadhammasabhāyaṃ
analyzed: tattha sitam akāsi iti saḥ sambodhi pattaḥ satthā mahā anubhāvaḥ alaṅkata dhamma sabhāyam
translated: In the first verse, the word “smile” means that the Teacher, the greatly powerful One who had attained Supreme Enlightenment,

original: alaṅkatadhammāsane parisamajjhe nisinno ekadivasaṃ sitaṃ akāsi. Nākāraṇeti “bhante,
analyzed: alaṅkata dhammāsane parisamajjhe nisinnaḥ eka divasam sitam akāsi na akāraṇā iti bhante
translated: one day, while seated in the midst of the assembly in the well-adorned Dhamma Hall,🔽on his well-adorned Dhamma seat, smiled. The Elder monks, who had destroyed the great taints, asked, “Venerable Sir,

original: buddhā nāma akāraṇe sitaṃ na karonti, tumhehi ca sitaṃ kataṃ, kena nu kho kāraṇena
analyzed: buddhāḥ nāma akāraṇe sitam na karonti tumhehi ca sitam katam kena nu kho kāraṇena
translated: Buddhas do not smile without a reason. You have smiled. For what reason🔽have you smiled?” The Teacher, thus asked,🔽pointing to a young nun, said, “Monks,

original: sitaṃ kata”nti mahākhīṇāsavā bhikkhū pucchiṃsu. Yamaddasāthāti evaṃ puṭṭho, āvuso,🔽satthā attano sitakāraṇaṃ ācikkhanto ekaṃ daharabhikkhuniṃ dassetvā evamāha – “bhikkhave,
analyzed: sitam katanti mahā khīṇāsavāḥ bhikkhū pucchiṃsu yam addasātha ati evam puṭṭhaḥ āvuso  satthā attano sita kāraṇam ācikkhantaḥ ekam dahara bhikkhunim dassetvā evam āha bhikkhave
translated: I have smiled because of this young nun who has gone forth,

original: yaṃ ekaṃ daharaṃ yobbanappattaṃ kumāriṃ kāsāyavatthaṃ anagāriyaṃ upetaṃ pabbajitvā
analyzed: yam ekam daharam yobbana pattam kumārim kāsāyavattham anagāriyam upetam pabbajitvā
translated: who is young, youthful, and has put on the ochre robe, and has gone forth into homelessness.

original: imasmiṃ sāsane carantiṃ addasātha passatha, sā tadā ‘visapītena sallena nāgarājaṃ🔽vijjhitvā vadhehī”’ti sonuttarassa pesetā rājakaññā ahosi. Tena gantvā jīvitakkhayaṃ
analyzed: imasmin sāsane carantim addasātha passatha sā tadā visa pītena sallena nāga rājam  vijjhitvā vadhehi iti rāja kaññā ahosi tena gantvā jīvita kkhayam
translated: You saw, you saw her going about in this Dispensation, she was the princess who sent Sonuttara to kill the king of nāgas🔽with a poisoned arrow. I was the king of nāgas who was killed by him. Devadatta,

original: pāpito ahaṃ tadā so nāgarājā ahosinti attho. Devadattoti, bhikkhave, idāni devadatto
analyzed: pāpitaḥ aham tadā saḥ nāga rājā ahosin ti attho devadatto ti bhikkhave idāni devadatto
translated: bhikkhus, is now Devadatta,

original: tadā so luddako ahosi.🔽Anāvasūranti na avasūraṃ, anatthaṅgatasūriyanti attho. Cirarattasaṃsitanti ito ciraratte
analyzed: tadā saḥ luddakaḥ ahosi  na avasūram anatthaṅgata sūriyanti attho cira ratta saṃsitanti itas cira ratte
translated: then he was the hunter.

original: anekavassakoṭimatthake saṃsitaṃ saṃsaritaṃ anuciṇṇaṃ. Idaṃ vuttaṃ hoti – āvuso, ito
analyzed: aneka vassa koṭi matthake saṃsitam saṃsaritam anuciṇṇam idam vuttam hoti āvuso itas
translated: Anāvasūra means not a bad day, not a bad time, the meaning is, not a bad day. Cirarattasaṃsitanti saṃsitaṃ saṃsaritaṃ anuciṇṇaṃ. This is what is said: Friend,🔽having gone about for many millions of years,

original: anekavassakoṭimatthake saṃsaritampi pubbaṇhe kataṃ taṃ divasameva sāyanhe saranto
analyzed: aneka vassa koṭi matthake saṃsaritam pi pubbaṇhe katam tam divasam eva sāyanhe sarantaḥ
translated: in the morning it is as if you are going to the evening of that very day,

original: viya attano caritavasena uccattā tāya rājadhītāya ca sonuttarassa ca caritavasena
analyzed: viya attano caritavasena uccattā tāya rāja dhītāya ca sonuttarassa ca caritavasena
translated: because of your own conduct, because of the conduct of the princess and Sonuttara,

original: nīcattā uccānīcaṃ caritaṃ idaṃ purāṇaṃ rāgādīnaṃ darānaṃ vigatatāya vītaddaro, ñātidhanasokādīnaṃ
analyzed: nīcattā uccānīcam caritam idam purāṇam rāga ādīnam vigata tāya ñāti dhana soka ādīnam
translated: and because of his humility, his conduct was both high and humble. He was free from fear because of the absence of the fears of lust, etc.,

original: abhāvena vītasoko, rāgasallādīnaṃ vigatattā visallo attanāva jānitvā buddho abhāsīti.
analyzed: abhāvena vīta sokaḥ rāga salla ādīnam vigata ttā visallaḥ jānitvā buddhaḥ abhāsi iti
translated: and free from grief because of the absence of grief for kinsmen, wealth, and so on. He was free from passion because of the absence of the dart of passion, etc. He was enlightened by himself and then spoke.

original: Ahaṃ voti ettha voti nipātamattaṃ, bhikkhave, ahaṃ tena kālena tattha chaddantadahe
analyzed: aham vo ti ettha vo ti nipāta mattam bhikkhave aham tena kālena tattha chaddanta dahe
translated: Here the word “I” is merely a particle. “Bhikkhus, I was that Chaddanta at that time and on that occasion.”

original: ahosinti attho. Nāgarājāti honto ca pana na añño koci tadā homi, atha kho nāgarājā
analyzed: ahosinti attho nāga rājā ati honto ca pana na añño koci tadā homi atha kho nāga rājā
translated: And when I was the king of the elephants, I was not someone else, but I myself was that king of the elephants.

original: homīti attho. Evaṃ cārethāti tumhe taṃ jātakaṃ evaṃ dhāretha uggaṇhātha pariyāpuṇāthāti.
analyzed: homi iti evam cāretha ati tumhe tam jātakam evam dhāretha uggaṇhātha pariyāpuṇātha ati
translated: Thus you should bear in mind this Jātaka, learn it, and master it.”

original: Imañca pana dhammadesanaṃ sutvā bahū sotāpannādayo ahesuṃ. Sā pana bhikkhunī pacchā vipassitvā arahattaṃ pattāti.🔽Chaddantajātakavaṇṇanā catutthā.🔽[515] 5. Sambhavajātakavaṇṇanā
analyzed: imam ca pana dhamma desanam sutvā bahū sotāpanna ādayo ahesum sā pana bhikkhunī pacchā vipassitvā arahattam pattā ti 🔽chaddantajātakavaṇṇanā catutthā 🔽
translated: And after hearing this teaching of the Dhamma, many became stream-enterers, etc. But that bhikkhunī later attained perfection by developing insight.

original: Rajjañca paṭipannāsmāti idaṃ satthā jetavane viharanto paññāpāramiṃ ārabbha kathesi. Paccuppannavatthu mahāumaṅgajātake āvi bhavissati.
analyzed: rajjam ca paṭipannā asma iti idam satthā jetavane viharantaḥ paññāpāramiṃ ārabbha kathesi paccuppanna vatthu mahā umaṅga jātake āvi bhavissati
translated: This story the Master told while dwelling at Jetavana, about the perfection of wisdom. The story of the present will be told in the Mahā-Ummagga Jātaka.

original: Atīte pana kururaṭṭhe indapatthanagare dhanañcayakorabyo nāma rājā rajjaṃ kāresi.
analyzed: atīte pana kururaṭṭhe indapattha nagare dhanañcaya korabyaḥ nāma rājā rajjam kāresi
translated: In the days of yore, in the city of Indapattha in the Kurū country, there reigned a king named Dhanañcayakorabhya.

original: Tassa sucirato nāma brāhmaṇo purohito atthadhammānusāsako ahosi. Rājā dānādīni puññāni
analyzed: tassa sucirataḥ nāma brāhmaṇaḥ purohitaḥ attha dhamma anusāsakaḥ ahosi rājā dāna ādīni puññāni
translated: He had a chaplain named Sucirata, who was a counsellor in state affairs. The king, who was performing works of merit such as almsgiving,

original: karonto dhammena rajjamanusāsi. So ekadivasaṃ dhammayāgaṃ nāma pañhaṃ abhisaṅkharitvā
analyzed: karontaḥ dhammena rajjam anusāsi saḥ eka divasam dhammayāgam nāma pañham abhisaṅkharitvā
translated: governed his kingdom righteously. One day he prepared a question, called a dhammayāga,

original: sucirataṃ nāma brāhmaṇaṃ purohitaṃ āsane nisīdāpetvā sakkāraṃ katvā pañhaṃ pucchanto
analyzed: suciratam nāma brāhmaṇam purohitam āsane nisīdāpetvā sakkāram katvā pañham pucchantaḥ
translated: and having seated the chaplain, the brāhmaṇa Sucirata, on a seat, and honoured him, he asked the question,

original: catasso gāthāyo abhāsi –
analyzed: catassaḥ gāthāyaḥ abhāsi
translated: and spoke four stanzas:

original: “Rajjañca paṭipannāsma, ādhipaccaṃ sucīrata;
analyzed: rajjañca paṭipannāsmaḥ ādhipaccam
translated: “We have obtained a kingdom, Sucirata, and great power;

original: Mahattaṃ pattumicchāmi, vijetuṃ pathaviṃ imaṃ.
analyzed: mahat tam pattum icchāmi vijetum pathavim imam
translated: I desire to obtain greatness, and to conquer this earth.

original: “Dhammena no adhammena, adhammo me na ruccati;
analyzed: dhammena naḥ adhammena adhammaḥ me na ruccati
translated: “By righteousness, not by unrighteousness, unrighteousness does not please me;

original: Kiccova dhammo carito, rañño hoti sucīrata.
analyzed: kiccā uva dhammaḥ caritaḥ raññaḥ hoti su cīrata
translated: Even if it be with difficulty, righteousness, when practised, is for the king, Sucirata.

original: “Idha cevāninditā yena, pecca yena aninditā;
analyzed: ca iva aninditā yena yena aninditā
translated: By what means is one not blamed?🔽By what means does one gain fame

original: Yasaṃ devamanussesu, yena pappomu brāhmaṇa.
analyzed: yasam deva manussesu yena brāhmaṇa
translated: Among gods and men, O Brahmin?”🔽“The purpose and the Dhamma, O Brahmin,

original: “Yohaṃ atthañca dhammañca, kattumicchāmi brāhmaṇa;
analyzed: yaḥ ham atthañca dhammañca kattum icchāmi brāhmaṇa
translated: That I wish to accomplish,🔽The purpose and the Dhamma, O Brahmin,

original: Taṃ tvaṃ atthañca dhammañca, brāhmaṇakkhāhi pucchito”ti.
analyzed: tam tvam atthañca dhammañca brāhmaṇakkhāhi pucchito ti
translated: Please explain to me when asked.”

original: Tattha rajjanti, ācariya, mayaṃ imasmiṃ sattayojanike indapatthanagare rajjañca,
analyzed: tattha imasmin satta yojanike indapattha nagare
translated: Here, teacher, we rule the kingdom of Indapattana, which is seven leagues in extent,

original: tiyojanasatike kururaṭṭhe issarabhāvasaṅkhātaṃ ādhipaccañca. Paṭipannāsmāti adhigatā
analyzed: ti yojana satike kuru raṭṭhe issara bhāva saṅkhātam ādhipaccam ca paṭipannā asma ati adhigatā
translated: And we exercise sovereignty, which is called lordship, over the Kurudhamma country, which is three leagues in extent. We have attained🔽greatness. I wish to conquer and rule this earth by Dhamma.

original: bhavāma. Mahattanti idāni mahantabhāvaṃ. Pattumicchāmi vijetunti imaṃ pathaviṃ dhammena🔽abhibhavituṃ ajjhottharituṃ icchāmi. Kiccovāti avasesajanehi rañño carito dhammo
analyzed: bhavāma mahattanti idāni mahanta bhāvam pattum icchāmi vijetum ti imam pathavim dhammena  abhibhavitum ajjhottharitum icchāmi avasesa janehi rañño caritaḥ dhammo
translated: I wish to overcome and subdue this earth by Dhamma. It is difficult

original: kicco karaṇīyataro. Rājānuvattako hi loko, so tasmiṃ dhammike sabbopi dhammiko hoti.
analyzed: kiccaḥ karaṇīyataraḥ rājā anuvattakaḥ hi loko so tasmin dhammike sabbaḥ api dhammikaḥ hoti
translated: for the king to accomplish the Dhamma, which is the duty of the people. The world follows the king; all of them become righteous when he is righteous.

original: Tasmā esa dhammo nāma raññova kiccoti.
analyzed: tasmai esa dhammo nāma rañño uva kicco ti
translated: Therefore this Dhamma is indeed the duty of the king alone.

original: Idha cevāninditāti yena mayaṃ idhaloke paraloke ca aninditā. Yena pappomūti yena
analyzed: ca iva aninditā ati yena mayam idha loke para loke ca aninditā yena yena
translated: “By which we may be unblamed in this world and the next,

original: mayaṃ nirayādīsu anibbattitvā devesu ca manussesu ca yasaṃ issariyaṃ sobhaggaṃ pāpuṇeyyāma,🔽taṃ no kāraṇaṃ kathehīti. Yohanti, brāhmaṇa, yo ahaṃ phalavipākasaṅkhātaṃ atthañca
analyzed: mayam niraya ādīsu a nibbattitvā devesu ca manussesu ca yasam issariyam sobhaggam pāpuṇeyyāma  tam naḥ kāraṇam kathehi iti yohanti brāhmaṇa aham phala vipāka saṅkhātam
translated: By which we may attain fame, glory, and sovereignty among gods and men,🔽Tell us the reason for that.”

original: tassa atthassa hetubhūtaṃ dhammañca kattuṃ samādāya vattituṃ uppādetuñca icchāmi.
analyzed: tassa atthassa hetu bhūtam dhammañca kattum samādāya vattitum uppādetum ca icchāmi
translated: “Brahmin, I wish to do, to undertake, to develop, that which is called the benefit and the Dhamma that is the cause of that benefit.🔽“That I ask of you,

original: Taṃ tvanti tassa mayhaṃ tvaṃ sukheneva nibbānagāmimaggaṃ āruyha apaṭisandhikabhāvaṃ
analyzed: tam tvam ti tassa mayham tvam sukhena iva nibbāna gāmi maggam āruyha apaṭisandhika bhāvam
translated: Having ascended the path that leads to Nibbāna with ease,🔽and having attained the state of non-rebirth,

original: patthentassa taṃ atthañca dhammañca pucchito akkhāhi, pākaṭaṃ katvā kathehīti brāhmaṇaṃ
analyzed: patthentassa tam atthañca dhammañca pucchitaḥ akkhāhi pākaṭam katvā kathehi iti brāhmaṇam
translated: ask me and tell me that benefit and Dhamma.

original: dhammayāgapañhaṃ pucchi.
analyzed: dhamma yāga pañham pucchi
translated: Explain it clearly to me.”

original: Ayaṃ pana pañho gambhīro buddhavisayo, sabbaññubuddhameva taṃ pucchituṃ yuttaṃ, tasmiṃ
analyzed: ayam pana pañhaḥ gambhīraḥ buddha visayaḥ sabbaññu buddham eva tam pucchitum yuttam tasmin
translated: This question was profound, the domain of the Buddha. It was fitting to ask the omniscient Buddha about it.

original: asati sabbaññutaññāṇapariyesakaṃ bodhisattanti. Sucirato pana attano abodhisattatāya
analyzed: asati sabbaññu taññāṇa pariyesakam bodhisattanti su ciratas pana attanaḥ a bodhisatta tāya
translated: But because he himself was not a Bodhisatta, he was unable to answer the question.

original: pañhaṃ kathetuṃ nāsakkhi, asakkonto ca paṇḍitamānaṃ akatvā attano asamatthabhāvaṃ
analyzed: pañham kathetum na asakkhi a sakkontaḥ ca paṇḍita mānam a katvā attanaḥ asamattha bhāvam
translated: And being unable to answer, he did not pretend to be wise, but told the king of his own incompetence.

original: kathento gāthamāha –
analyzed: kathentaḥ gātham āha
translated: And he spoke this verse:

original: “Nāññatra vidhurā rāja, etadakkhātumarahati;
analyzed: na aññatra vidhurāḥ rāje etat akkhātum arahati
translated: “No one but Vidhura, O King, is fit to answer this;

original: Yaṃ tvaṃ atthañca dhammañca, kattumicchasi khattiyā”ti.
analyzed: yam tvam atthañca dhammañca kattum icchasi khattiya iti
translated: For you wish to know the meaning and the Dhamma, O Khattiya.”

original: Tassattho – avisayo esa, mahārāja, pañho mādisānaṃ. Ahañhi nevassa ādiṃ, na pariyosānaṃ
analyzed: tassa atthaḥ avisayaḥ esa mahā rāja pañhaḥ mā ādisānam ahan hi na iva assa ādim na pariyosānam
translated: The meaning is this: “This question, O great king, is beyond the scope of people like me.

original: passāmi, andhakāraṃ paviṭṭho viya homi. Bārāṇasirañño pana purohito vidhuro nāma🔽brāhmaṇo atthi, so etaṃ ācikkheyya, taṃ ṭhapetvā yaṃ tvaṃ atthañca dhammañca kattumicchasi,
analyzed: passāmi andhakāram paviṭṭhaḥ viya homi bārāṇasi raññaḥ pana purohitaḥ vidhuraḥ nāma  brāhmaṇaḥ atthi saḥ etam ācikkheyya tam ṭhapetvā yam tvam atthañca dhammañca kattum icchasi
translated: For I do not see its beginning or its end; I am as if plunged into darkness. But there is a brahmin of Benares, the royal chaplain, named Vidhura,

original: etaṃ akkhātuṃ na añño arahatīti.
analyzed: etam akkhātum na aññaḥ arahati iti
translated: who might explain it. Apart from him, no one else is fit to answer this question, which you wish to know the meaning and the Dhamma of.”

original: Rājā tassa vacanaṃ sutvā “tena hi, brāhmaṇa, khippaṃ tassa santikaṃ gacchāhī”ti paṇṇākāraṃ datvā taṃ pesetukāmo hutvā gāthamāha –
analyzed: rājā tassa vacanam sutvā tena hi brāhmaṇa khippam tassa santikam gacchāhi iti paṇṇa ākāram da tvā tam pesetu kāmaḥ hutvā gātham āha
translated: The king, on hearing his words, said, “Well then, Brahman, go quickly to him.” And, wishing to send him, he spoke this verse:

original: “Ehi kho pahito gaccha, vidhurassa upantikaṃ;
analyzed: ehi kho pahitaḥ gaccha vidhurassa upantikam
translated: “Go, go, sent by me, to Vidhura’s side;

original: Nikkhañcimaṃ suvaṇṇassa, haraṃ gaccha sucīrata;
analyzed: nikkhañcimam suvaṇṇassa haram gaccha su cīrata
translated: Take this thousand of pure gold; go, well-behaved one;

original: Abhihāraṃ imaṃ dajjā, atthadhammānusiṭṭhiyā”ti.
analyzed: abhihāram imam dajjā attha dhamma anusiṭṭhiyā ati
translated: Give this present, for the instruction in the meaning and the Dhamma.”

original: Tattha upantikanti santikaṃ. Nikkhanti pañcasuvaṇṇo eko nikkho. Ayaṃ pana rattasuvaṇṇassa🔽nikkhasahassaṃ datvā evamāha. Imaṃ dajjāti tena imasmiṃ dhammayāgapañhe kathite tassa
analyzed: tattha upantikam ti santikam nikkhanti pañca suvaṇṇaḥ ekaḥ nikkhaḥ ayam pana ratta suvaṇṇassa  nikkha sahassam da tvā evam āha imam dajjāti tena imasmin dhamma yāga pañhe kathite tassa
translated: Herein, to his side means to his presence. Take this thousand of pure gold means one thousand of pure gold. This is a thousand of pure gold.

original: atthadhammānusiṭṭhiyā abhihārapūjaṃ karonto imaṃ nikkhasahassaṃ dadeyyāsīti.
analyzed: attha dhamma anusiṭṭhiyā abhihāra pūjam karontaḥ imam nikkha sahassam dadeyyāsi iti
translated: But he said, “Give this,” meaning that he would give this thousand of pure gold in making an offering of worship to him for the instruction in the meaning and the Dhamma when the question had been answered.

original: Evañca pana vatvā pañhavissajjanassa likhanatthāya satasahassagghanakaṃ suvaṇṇapaṭṭañca
analyzed: evam ca pana vatvā pañha vissajjanassa likhana tthāya sata sahassa gghanakam suvaṇṇa paṭṭam ca
translated: And after saying this, he gave him a gold plate worth a hundred thousand for writing down the question and the answer,

original: gamanatthāya yānaṃ, parivāratthāya balakāyaṃ, tañca paṇṇākāraṃ datvā taṅkhaṇaññeva
analyzed: gamana tthāya yānam parivāra tthāya balakāyam tam ca paṇṇa ākāram da tvā
translated: a vehicle for going, an army for a retinue, and the letter of introduction. And he sent him off at once.

original: uyyojesi. So pana indapatthanagarā nikkhamitvā ujukameva bārāṇasiṃ agantvā yattha🔽yattha paṇḍitā vasanti, sabbāni tāni ṭhānāni upasaṅkamitvā sakalajambudīpe pañhassa
analyzed: uyyojesi saḥ pana indapattha nagarā nikkhamitvā ujukam eva bārāṇasim a gantvā yattha  yattha paṇḍitāḥ vasanti sabbāni tāni ṭhānāni upasaṅkamitvā sakala jambudīpe pañhassa
translated: and he sent him away. He (the brahman) left the city of Indapattha and went straight to Bārāṇasī, and wherever🔽there were wise men, he went to all those places and asked them a question,🔽🔽

original: vissajjetāraṃ alabhitvā anupubbena bārāṇasiṃ patvā ekasmiṃ ṭhāne nivāsaṃ gahetvā
analyzed: vissajjetāram a labhitvā anupubbena bārāṇasim patvā ekasmin ṭhāne nivāsam gahetvā
translated: and sent him away. He left the city of Indapattha and went straight to Bārāṇasī. Wherever he went, he visited all the learned men, and not finding anyone in all India who could answer his question, he eventually reached Bārāṇasī and took up his residence in a certain place.

original: katipayehi janehi saddhiṃ pātarāsabhuñjanavelāya vidhurassa nivesanaṃ gantvā āgatabhāvaṃ
analyzed: katipayehi janehi saddhim pāta rāsa bhuñjana velāya vidhurassa nivesanam gantvā āgata bhāvam
translated: One day, at the time of breakfast, he went with a number of people to the house of Vidhura and announced his arrival.

original: ārocāpetvā tena pakkosāpito taṃ sake ghare bhuñjamānaṃ addasa. Tamatthaṃ āvikaronto
analyzed: ārocāpetvā tena pakkosāpito tam sake ghare bhuñjamānam addasa tam attham āvikaronto
translated: When he was invited in by Vidhura, he saw him eating in his own house. Expounding this incident,

original: satthā sattamaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: satthā sattamam gātham āha
translated: the Teacher pronounced the seventh stanza:

original: “Svādhippāgā bhāradvājo, vidhurassa upantikaṃ;
analyzed: svādhippā agāḥ bhāradvājaḥ vidhurassa upantikam
translated: “Bhāradvāja, who came from Svādhippā, visited the house of Vidhura;

original: Tamaddasa mahābrahmā, asamānaṃ sake ghare”ti.
analyzed: tam addasa mahābrahmā asamānam sake ghara iti
translated: The Great Brahmā saw him eating in his own house.”

original: Tattha svādhippāgāti so bhāradvājagotto sucirato adhippāgā, gatoti attho. Mahābrahmāti mahābrāhmaṇo. Asamānanti bhuñjamānaṃ.
analyzed: tattha svādhippāgā iti saḥ bhāradvāja gottaḥ su ciratas adhippāgāḥ gataḥ iti attho mahābrahmā ati mahābrāhmaṇaḥ asamānam ti bhuñjamānam
translated: Here “Svādhippā” means “he who came from Svādhippā.” “Mahābrahmā” means “the Great Brahmā.” “Asamāna” means “eating.”

original: So pana tassa bālasahāyako ekācariyakule uggahitasippo, tasmā tena saddhiṃ ekato
analyzed: so pana tassa bāla sahāyakaḥ eka ācariya kule uggahita sippo tasmā tena saddhim ekatas
translated: But this friend of his was a pupil of the same teacher, and so he ate with him.

original: bhuñjitvā bhattakiccapariyosāne sukhanisinno “samma kimatthaṃ āgatosī”ti puṭṭho āgamanakāraṇaṃ
analyzed: bhuñjitvā bhatta kicca pariyosāne sukha nisinnaḥ samma kimattham āgataḥ asi iti puṭṭhaḥ āgamana kāraṇam
translated: After the meal, when they had finished eating, they sat down comfortably. The other asked, “My friend, what is the reason for your coming?”

original: ācikkhanto aṭṭhamaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: ācikkhantaḥ aṭṭhamam gātham āha
translated: When the king’s messenger told him the reason for his coming, he spoke the eighth verse:

original: “Raññohaṃ pahito dūto, korabyassa yasassino;
analyzed: raññā uham pahitaḥ dūtaḥ korabyassa yasassinaḥ
translated: “I am the king’s messenger, sent by the famous king of Kosala.

original: ‘Atthaṃ dhammañca pucchesi’, iccabravi yudhiṭṭhilo;
analyzed: attham dhammam ca pucchesi id abravi yudhiṭṭhilo
translated: ‘Ask Vidhura about the meaning and the Dhamma,’ said King Yuddhiṭṭhila.

original: Taṃ tvaṃ atthañca dhammañca, vidhurakkhāhi pucchito”ti.
analyzed: tam tvam atthañca dhammañca vidhurakkhāhi pucchito ti
translated: So, when asked, Vidhura, please explain the meaning and the Dhamma to me.”

original: Tattha raññohanti ahaṃ rañño korabyassa yasassino dūto. Pahitoti tena pesito idhāgamiṃ.
analyzed: tattha raññohanti aham raññaḥ korabyassa yasassinaḥ dūto pahito ti tena pesitaḥ idha agamiṃ
translated: Herein, I am the king’s messenger: I am the messenger of the king of Kosala, the famous king. Sent: sent by him, I have come here.

original: Pucchesīti so yudhiṭṭhilagotto dhanañcayarājā maṃ dhammayāgapañhaṃ nāma pucchi, ahaṃ🔽kathetuṃ asakkonto “tvaṃ sakkhissasī”ti ñatvā tassa ārocesiṃ, so ca paṇṇākāraṃ datvā
analyzed: pucchesi iti saḥ yudhiṭṭhila gottaḥ dhanañcaya rājā mam dhamma yāga pañham nāma pucchi aham  kathetum a sakkonto tvam sakkhissasi iti ñatvā tassa ārocesim saḥ ca paṇṇa ākāram da tvā
translated: Asked: that King Yuddhiṭṭhila of the Yuddha clan asked me this question called the Dhamma sacrifice.🔽I, being unable to explain it,🔽knowing that you would be able, informed him of that. And he, giving me a letter,

original: pañhapucchanatthāya maṃ tava santikaṃ pesento “vidhurassa santikaṃ gantvā imassa
analyzed: pañha pucchana tthāya mam tava santikam pesentaḥ vidhurassa santikam gantvā imassa
translated: sent me to you to ask you the question, saying, “Go to Vidhura and ask him about the meaning and the Dhamma.”

original: pañhassa atthañca pāḷidhammañca puccheyyāsī”ti abravi. “Taṃ tvaṃ idāni mayā pucchito akkhāhī”ti.
analyzed: pañhassa atthañca pāḷidhammañca puccheyyāsi iti abravi tam tvam idāni mayā pucchitaḥ akkhāhi iti
translated: and the meaning and the letter of the question.” “You are now asked by me; tell me.”

original: Tadā pana so brāhmaṇo “mahājanassa cittaṃ gaṇhissāmī”ti gaṅgaṃ pidahanto viya vinicchayaṃ vicāreti. Tassa pañhavissajjane okāso natthi. So tamatthaṃ ācikkhanto navamaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: tadā pana saḥ brāhmaṇaḥ mahājanassa cittam gaṇhissāmi iti gaṅgam pidahantaḥ viya vinicchayam vicāreti tassa pañha vissajjane okāsaḥ natthi so tam attham ācikkhantaḥ navamam gātham āha
translated: But at that time the brahmin, thinking “I will win the hearts of the people,” was investigating the decision as if damming up the Ganges. He had no opportunity to answer the question. He, explaining that matter, spoke the ninth verse:

original: “Gaṅgaṃ me pidahissanti, na taṃ sakkomi brāhmaṇa;
analyzed: gaṅgam me pidahissanti na tam sakkomi brāhmaṇa
translated: “I would dam up the Ganges, brahmin, but I am not able;

original: Apidhetuṃ mahāsindhuṃ, taṃ kathaṃ so bhavissati;
analyzed: apidhetum mahā sindhum tam katham saḥ bhavissati
translated: to dam up the great ocean, how would that be?

original: Na te sakkomi akkhātuṃ, atthaṃ dhammañca pucchito”ti.
analyzed: na te sakkomi akkhātum attham dhammam ca pucchito ti
translated: Asked about the meaning and the letter, I am not able to tell you.”

original: Tassattho – brāhmaṇa, mayhaṃ “mahājanassa nānācittagatisaṅkhātaṃ gaṅgaṃ pidahissa”nti
analyzed: tassa atthaḥ brāhmaṇa mayham mahā janassa nānā citta gati saṅkhātam gaṅgam pidahissanti
translated: The meaning of that is: brahmin, I have the desire to dam up the Ganges, which is called the various thoughts and destinations of the people,

original: byāpāro uppanno, tamahaṃ mahāsindhuṃ apidhetuṃ na sakkomi, tasmā kathaṃ so okāso
analyzed: byāpāraḥ uppannaḥ tam aham mahā sindhum apidhetum na sakkomi tasmā katham saḥ okāsaḥ
translated: but I am not able to dam up the great ocean, therefore how would that opportunity

original: bhavissati, yasmā te ahaṃ pañhaṃ vissajjeyyaṃ. Iti cittekaggatañceva okāsañca alabhanto
analyzed: bhavissati yasmai te aham pañham vissajjeyyam iti citta ekagga tam ca iva okāsam ca a labhanto
translated: be, by which I could answer your question. Thus not getting one-pointedness of mind and an opportunity,

original: na te sakkomi akkhātuṃ atthaṃ dhammañca pucchitoti.
analyzed: na te sakkomi akkhātum attham dhammam ca pucchito ti
translated: I am not able to explain the meaning and the Law to you, though you ask me.”

original: Evañca pana vatvā “putto me paṇḍito mayā ñāṇavantataro, so te byākarissati, tassa santikaṃ gacchāhī”ti vatvā dasamaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: evam ca pana vatvā puttaḥ me paṇḍitaḥ mayā ñāṇavantataro saḥ te byākarissati tassa santikam gacchāhi iti vatvā dasamam gātham āha
translated: And after saying this, he said, “My son is wise; he is wiser than I. He will explain it to you. Go to him.” So saying, he pronounced the tenth stanza:

original: “Bhadrakāro ca me putto, oraso mama atrajo;
analyzed: bhadrakāro ca me puttaḥ orasaḥ mama atrajaḥ
translated: “My son is good and virtuous, born of my own loins;

original: Taṃ tvaṃ atthañca dhammañca, gantvā pucchassu brāhmaṇā”ti.
analyzed: tam tvam atthañca dhammañca gantvā pucchassu brāhmaṇa ati
translated: Go to him, Brahman, and ask him the meaning and the Law.”

original: Tattha orasoti ure saṃvaḍḍho. Atrajoti attanā jātoti.
analyzed: tattha orasā iti ure saṃvaḍḍhaḥ atrajā iti attanā jātaḥ iti
translated: Herein, born of my own loins means born of my own body.

original: Taṃ sutvā sucirato vidhurassa gharā nikkhamitvā bhadrakārassa bhuttapātarāsassa attano parisamajjhe nisinnakāle nivesanaṃ agamāsi. Tamatthaṃ pakāsento satthā ekādasamaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: tam sutvā su ciratas vidhurassa gharā nikkhamitvā bhadrakārassa bhutta pāta rāsassa attano parisamajjhe nisinna kāle nivesanam agamāsi tam attham pakāsentaḥ satthā ekādasamam gātham āha
translated: Hearing this, Vidhura left the house of the Brahman and went to the house of Bhadrakāra. When he arrived, Bhadrakāra had finished his breakfast and was sitting in the midst of his retinue. Expounding this, the Master pronounced the eleventh stanza:

original: “Svādhippāgā bhāradvājo, bhadrakārassupantikaṃ;
analyzed: su ādhippā agāḥ bhāradvājaḥ bhadra kāraḥ su pantikam
translated: “Bhadrakāra, the son of Bharadvāja, went to the house of Vidhura;

original: Tamaddasa mahābrahmā, nisinnaṃ samhi vesmanī”ti.
analyzed: tam addasa mahā brahmā nisinnam samhi vesmani iti
translated: The Great Brahman saw him sitting in the house.”

original: Tattha vesmanīti ghare.
analyzed: tattha vesmani iti ghare
translated: Herein, in the house means in the house.

original: So tattha gantvā bhadrakāramāṇavena katāsanābhihārasakkāro nisīditvā āgamanakāraṇaṃ puṭṭho dvādasamaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: saḥ tattha gantvā bhadrakāra māṇavena kata āsana abhihāra sakkāraḥ nisīditvā āgamana kāraṇam puṭṭhaḥ dvādasamam gātham āha
translated: So he went there, and after he had sat down and had received the hospitality offered by the young man Bhadrakāra, he was asked the reason of his coming, and he replied with the following verse:

original: “Raññohaṃ pahito dūto, korabyassa yasassino;
analyzed: raññā uham pahitaḥ dūtaḥ korabyassa yasassinaḥ
translated: “I am a messenger sent by the king, the famous king of the Kosalans;

original: ‘Atthaṃ dhammañca pucchesi’, iccabravi yudhiṭṭhilo;
analyzed: attham dhammam ca pucchesi id abravi yudhiṭṭhilo
translated: ‘Ask thou for wealth and for the Law,’ said Yudhittthila;

original: Taṃ tvaṃ atthañca dhammañca, bhadrakāra pabrūhi me”ti.🔽Atha naṃ bhadrakāro, “tāta, ahaṃ imesu divasesu paradārikakamme abhiniviṭṭho, cittaṃ
analyzed: tam tvam atthañca dhammañca bhadra kāra pabrūhi mā iti  atha nam bhadrakāraḥ tāta aham imesu divasesu paradārika kamme abhiniviṭṭhaḥ cittam
translated: Therefore do thou, O Bhadrakāra, tell me of wealth and of the Law.”

original: me byākulaṃ, tena tyāhaṃ vissajjetuṃ na sakkhissāmi, mayhaṃ pana kaniṭṭho sañcayakumāro🔽nāma mayā ativiya ñāṇavantataro, taṃ puccha, so te pañhaṃ vissajjessatī”ti tassa
analyzed: me byākulam tena tyā aham vissajjetum na sakkhissāmi mayham pana kaniṭṭhaḥ sañcaya kumāro  nāma mayā ativiya ñāṇavantataro tam puccha saḥ te pañham vissajjessati iti tassa
translated: Then Bhadrakāra said to him, “My dear sir, during these last few days I have been very much occupied with the wives of other men, and my mind is so confused that I am unable to give you an answer. But my younger brother Sañcayakumāra

original: santikaṃ pesento dve gāthā abhāsi –
analyzed: santikam pesentaḥ dve gāthāḥ abhāsi
translated: is much wiser than I am; go to him and ask him. He will answer your question.” So he sent him to his brother, and in doing so he uttered the following two verses:

original: “Maṃsakājaṃ avahāya, godhaṃ anupatāmahaṃ;
analyzed: maṃsa kājam avahāya godham anupatāmaham
translated: “I have left behind me the flesh-eating Godha, and have come to you;

original: Na te sakkomi akkhātuṃ, atthaṃ dhammañca pucchito.
analyzed: na te sakkomi akkhātum attham dhammam ca pucchito
translated: I am unable to tell you of wealth and of the Law, though you have asked me.

original: “Sañcayo nāma me bhātā, kaniṭṭho me sucīrata;
analyzed: sañcayaḥ nāma me bhātā kaniṭṭhaḥ me
translated: “My brother is named Sañjaya, my younger brother is named Sucīrata;

original: Taṃ tvaṃ atthañca dhammañca, gantvā pucchassu brāhmaṇā”ti.
analyzed: tam tvam atthañca dhammañca gantvā pucchassu brāhmaṇa ati
translated: Go and ask the Brahmans about the meaning and the law.”

original: Tattha maṃsakājanti yathā nāma puriso thūlamigamaṃsaṃ kājenādāya gacchanto antarāmagge🔽godhapotakaṃ disvā maṃsakājaṃ chaḍḍetvā taṃ anubandheyya, evameva attano ghare vasavattiniṃ
analyzed: tattha maṃsakājanti yathā nāma purisaḥ thūla miga maṃsam kājena ādāya gacchantaḥ antarāmagge  godha potakam disvā maṃsa kājam chaḍḍetvā tam anubandheyya evam eva ghare vasa vattinim
translated: Here the word “flesh-basket” is used to illustrate the following: A man, for instance, might go to the forest to kill deer, carrying a basket of meat.🔽On the way he might see a young calf and,

original: bhariyaṃ chaḍḍetvā parassa rakkhitagopitaṃ itthiṃ anubandhanto homīti dīpento evamāhāti.
analyzed: bhariyam chaḍḍetvā parassa rakkhita gopitam itthim anubandhantaḥ homi iti dīpentaḥ evam āha ati
translated: abandoning the basket of meat, might follow the calf. In the same way, I abandoned my wife, who was my own property, and followed another’s wife, who was guarded and protected by another.

original: So tasmiṃ khaṇe sañcayassa nivesanaṃ gantvā tena katasakkāro āgamanakāraṇaṃ puṭṭho ācikkhi. Tamatthaṃ pakāsento satthā dve gāthā abhāsi –
analyzed: saḥ tasmin khaṇe sañcayassa nivesanam gantvā tena kata sakkāraḥ āgamana kāraṇam puṭṭhaḥ ācikkhi tam attham pakāsentaḥ satthā dve gāthāḥ abhāsi
translated: At that moment, he went to Sañcaya’s house. After he had been treated with respect by Sañcaya, he was asked the reason for his coming. He told it. Expounding that matter, the Teacher spoke two stanzas:

original: “Svādhippāgā bhāradvājo, sañcayassa upantikaṃ;
analyzed: svādhippā agāḥ bhāradvājaḥ sañcayassa upantikam
translated: Bhāradvāja, who was desirous of his own welfare,🔽went to the house of Sañcaya.

original: Tamaddasa mahābrahmā, nisinnaṃ samhi vesmani.
analyzed: tam addasa mahā brahmā nisinnam samhi vesmani
translated: The Great Brahmā saw him sitting in the house.🔽“I am a messenger sent by the king,

original: “Raññohaṃ pahito dūto, korabyassa yasassino;
analyzed: raññā uham pahitaḥ dūtaḥ korabyassa yasassinaḥ
translated: the famous king of Kosala.

original: ‘Atthaṃ dhammañca pucchesi’, iccabravi yudhiṭṭhilo;
analyzed: attham dhammam ca pucchesi id abravi yudhiṭṭhilo
translated: ‘Ask about the meaning and the law,’ said Yuddhiṭṭhila.

original: Taṃ tvaṃ atthañca dhammañca, sañcayakkhāhi pucchito”ti.
analyzed: tam tvam atthañca dhammañca sañcayakkhāhi pucchito ti
translated: “You, who are asked about the meaning and the Law,

original: Sañcayakumāro pana tadā paradārameva sevati. Athassa so “ahaṃ, tāta, paradāraṃ sevāmi,
analyzed: sañcaya kumāraḥ pana tadā para dāram eva sevati atha assa saḥ aham tāta para dāram sevāmi
translated: “But Sañcaya was then living in adultery with another’s wife. He said, “Father, I live in adultery with another’s wife.

original: sevanto ca pana gaṅgaṃ otaritvā paratīraṃ gacchāmi, taṃ maṃ sāyañca pāto ca nadiṃ
analyzed: sevantaḥ ca pana gaṅgam otaritvā para tīram gacchāmi tam mama sāyam ca pāto ca nadim
translated: When I go to her, I cross the Ganges and go to the other bank. When I cross the river

original: tarantaṃ maccu gilati nāma, tena cittaṃ me byākulaṃ, na tyāhaṃ ācikkhituṃ sakkhissāmi,
analyzed: tarantam maccu gilati nāma tena cittam me byākulam na tyā aham ācikkhitum sakkhissāmi
translated: in the evening and in the morning, Death swallows me up, so to speak. Therefore my mind is disturbed, and I am not able to tell you.

original: kaniṭṭho pana me sambhavakumāro nāma atthi jātiyā sattavassiko, mayā sataguṇena sahassaguṇena
analyzed: kaniṭṭhaḥ pana me sambhava kumāraḥ nāma atthi jātiyā satta vassikaḥ mayā sataguṇena sahassaguṇena
translated: But my younger brother, named Sambhava, is seven years old. He is a hundred times, a thousand times,

original: satasahassaguṇenādhikañāṇataro, so te ācikkhissati, gaccha taṃ pucchāhī”ti āha. Imamatthaṃ
analyzed: sata sahassa guṇena adhika ñāṇataro so te ācikkhissati gaccha tam pucchāhi iti āha imam attham
translated: a hundred thousand times wiser than I. He will tell you. Go and ask him.”

original: pakāsento satthā dve gāthā abhāsi –
analyzed: pakāsentaḥ satthā dve gāthāḥ abhāsi
translated: To make this clear, the Teacher recited two stanzas:

original: “Sadā maṃ gilate maccu, sāyaṃ pāto sucīrata;
analyzed: sadā mam mat cu sāyam pātaḥ
translated: “Death always swallows me, in the evening and in the morning, when I cross the river.

original: Na te sakkomi akkhātuṃ, atthaṃ dhammañca pucchito.
analyzed: na te sakkomi akkhātum attham dhammam ca pucchito
translated: I am not able to tell you, when asked, the meaning and the Law.

original: “Sambhavo nāma me bhātā, kaniṭṭho me sucīrata;
analyzed: sambhavaḥ nāma me bhātā kaniṭṭhaḥ me
translated: “My brother is named Sambhava, my younger brother, who crosses the river.

original: Taṃ tvaṃ atthañca dhammañca, gantvā pucchassu brāhmaṇā”ti.
analyzed: tam tvam atthañca dhammañca gantvā pucchassu brāhmaṇa ati
translated: Go and ask him the meaning and the Law, O Brahman.”

original: Taṃ sutvā sucirato “ayaṃ pañho imasmiṃ loke abbhuto bhavissati, imaṃ pañhaṃ vissajjetuṃ samattho nāma natthi maññe”ti cintetvā dve gāthā abhāsi –
analyzed: tam sutvā su ciratas ayam pañho imasmin loke abbhutaḥ bhavissati imam pañham vissajjetum samatthaḥ nāma natthi maññā iti cintetvā dve gāthāḥ abhāsi
translated: Having heard that, Sucirata thought: “This question will be a marvel in this world; there is no one, I suppose, who is able to answer this question.” And he spoke two stanzas:

original: “Abbhuto vata bho dhammo, nāyaṃ asmāka ruccati;
analyzed: abbhutaḥ vata bho dhammaḥ na ayam asmāka ruccati
translated: “A marvel, indeed, is the Law, it does not please us;

original: Tayo janā pitāputtā, te su paññāya no vidū.
analyzed: tayo janā pitāputtā te su paññāya naḥ vidū
translated: Three persons, father and sons, they are wise, but not in this matter.

original: “Na taṃ sakkotha akkhātuṃ, atthaṃ dhammañca pucchitā;
analyzed: na tam sakkotha akkhātum attham dhammam ca pucchitā
translated: “You are not able to declare the meaning and the Law, when asked;

original: Kathaṃ nu daharo jaññā, atthaṃ dhammañca pucchito”ti.
analyzed: katham nu daharaḥ jaññāḥ attham dhammam ca pucchito ti
translated: How can a youth know the meaning and the Law, when asked?”

original: Tattha nāyanti ayaṃ pañhadhammo abbhuto, imaṃ kathetuṃ samatthena nāma na bhavitabbaṃ,
analyzed: tattha na āyanti ayam pañha dhammo abbhutaḥ imam kathetum samatthena nāma na bhavitabbam
translated: Herein, nāyaṃ means: “This question and this Law are a marvel; there is no one, I suppose, who is able to explain it.

original: tasmā yaṃ tvaṃ “kumāro kathessatī”ti vadati, nāyaṃ asmākaṃ ruccati. Te sūti ettha
analyzed: tasmai yam tvam kumāraḥ kathessati iti vadati na ayam asmākam ruccati te sūti ettha
translated: Therefore, what you say, ‘The youth will explain,’ does not please us.” Te su means:

original: su-kāro nipātamattaṃ. Pitāti vidhuro paṇḍito, puttā bhadrakāro sañcayo cāti tepi
analyzed: sukāraḥ nipāta mattam pitā ati vidhuraḥ paṇḍito puttāḥ bhadrakāro sañcayaḥ ca ati te pi
translated: The syllable su is merely a particle. Pitā means: Vidhura is wise; puttā means: Bhadraka and Sañjaya.

original: tayo pitāputtā paññāya imaṃ dhammaṃ no vidū, na vijānanti, añño ko jānissatīti attho.
analyzed: tayo pitāputtā paññāya imam dhammam no vidū na vijānanti aññaḥ kaḥ jānissati iti attho
translated: The three brothers, being without wisdom, do not understand this Dhamma, and do not know it. The meaning is: “Who else will know it?”

original: Na tanti tumhe tayo janā pucchitā etaṃ akkhātuṃ na sakkotha, daharo sattavassiko
analyzed: na tanti tumhe tayaḥ janā pucchitāḥ etam akkhātum na sakkotha daharaḥ sattavassiko

analyzed: so tassa niddāyantassa silāya matthakam padālesi mahāsatto tassa tam kammam ñatvā  uppatitvā sākhāya nisīditvā bho purisa tvam bhūmiyāḥ gaccha aham sākhaggena tuyham
translated: The Great Being, knowing that he was asleep,🔽and said to him, “Friend, you go on the ground; I will go by the branches of the trees,

original: maggaṃ ācikkhanto gamissāmī”ti taṃ purisaṃ araññato nīharitvā magge ṭhapetvā pabbatapādameva
analyzed: maggam ācikkhantaḥ gamissāmi iti tam purisam araññataḥ nīharitvā magge ṭhapetvā pabbata pādam eva
translated: and will show you the way.” He led the man out of the forest, and set him on the road. Then he went down to the foot of the mountain,

original: pāvisi. So puriso mahāsatte aparajjhitvā kuṭṭhī hutvā diṭṭhadhammeyeva manussapeto ahosi.🔽So satta vassāni dukkhapīḷito vicaranto bārāṇasiyaṃ migājinaṃ nāma uyyānaṃ pavisitvā
analyzed: pāvisi saḥ purisaḥ mahāsatte aparajjhitvā kuṭṭhī hutvā diṭṭhadhamme iva iva manussa petaḥ ahosi  so satta vassāni dukkha pīḷitaḥ vicarantaḥ bārāṇasiyam migājinam nāma uyyānam pavisitvā
translated: and the man, not seeing the Great Being, became a leper, and died in that very state.🔽For seven years he wandered about, afflicted with pain, and at last entered a garden called Migajina, near Benares.

original: pākārantare kadalipaṇṇaṃ attharitvā vedanāppatto nipajji. Tadā bārāṇasirājā uyyānaṃ
analyzed: pākārantare kadali paṇṇam attharitvā vedanā appattaḥ nipajji tadā bārāṇasi rājā uyyānam
translated: There he lay down, suffering great pain, having spread a plantain leaf on the ground, and having entered between the walls of the garden.

original: gantvā tattha vicaranto taṃ disvā “kosi tvaṃ, kiṃ vā katvā imaṃ dukkhaṃ patto”ti
analyzed: gantvā tattha vicarantaḥ tam disvā kaḥ asi tvam kim vā katvā imam dukkham patto ti
translated: Now the king of Benares, who was out hunting, entered the garden, and seeing him, asked, “Who are you, and how did you come to this state?”

original: pucchi. Sopissa sabbaṃ vitthārato ācikkhi. Tamatthaṃ pakāsento satthā āha –
analyzed: pucchi saḥ upissa sabbam vitthārataḥ ācikkhi tam attham pakāsentaḥ satthā āha
translated: and he in turn told him the whole story in detail. Expounding the matter, the Master said:

original: “Bārāṇasyaṃ ahū rājā, kāsīnaṃ raṭṭhavaḍḍhano;
analyzed: bārāṇasyam ahuḥ rājā kāsīnam raṭṭhavaḍḍhano
translated: “There was a king in Bārāṇasī, a ruler of the Kāsīs,

original: Mittāmaccaparibyūḷho, agamāsi migājinaṃ.
analyzed: mitta amacca paribyūḍhaḥ agamāsi miga ajinam
translated: who, surrounded by his friends and counselors, went to the Deer Park.

original: “Tattha brāhmaṇamaddakkhi, setaṃ citraṃ kilāsinaṃ;
analyzed: tattha sa itam citram kilāsinam
translated: “There he saw a brāhmaṇa, pale, variegated, and emaciated,

original: Viddhastaṃ koviḷāraṃva, kisaṃ dhamanisanthataṃ.
analyzed: viddhaḥ tam kisam dhamani santhatam
translated: with veins standing out, like a withered koviḷāra flower.

original: “Paramakāruññataṃ pattaṃ, disvā kicchagataṃ naraṃ;
analyzed: parama kāruññatam pattam disvā kiccha gatam naram
translated: “Seeing the man in distress, who had attained the highest compassion,

original: Avaca byamhito rājā, yakkhānaṃ katamo nusi.
analyzed: avaca byamhitaḥ rājā yakkhānam katamaḥ nusi
translated: the king asked him, ‘Who are you, of the yakkhas?’

original: “Hatthapādā ca te setā, tato setataraṃ siro;
analyzed: hattha pādā ca te setā tatas setataram
translated: “Your hands and feet are pale, and your head is even paler;

original: Gattaṃ kammāsavaṇṇaṃ te, kilāsabahulo casi.
analyzed: gattam kamma āsa vaṇṇam te kilāsa bahulaḥ casi
translated: your body is the color of flax, and you are full of sores.

original: “Vaṭṭanāvaḷisaṅkāsā, piṭṭhi te ninnatunnatā;
analyzed: vaṭṭa nāvaḷi saṅkāsā te ninna tunna tā
translated: “Your back is like a ship’s sail, with hollows and bumps;

original: Kāḷapabbāva te aṅgā, nāññaṃ passāmi edisaṃ.
analyzed: kāḷapabbā ava te aṅgā na aññam passāmi edisam
translated: your limbs are like black rocks—I see nothing like it.

original: “Ugghaṭṭapādo tasito, kiso dhamanisanthato;
analyzed: ugghaṭṭapādaḥ tasitaḥ kisaḥ dhamanisanthataḥ
translated: “Your feet are cracked, you are exhausted, emaciated, and full of veins;

original: Chāto ātattarūposi, kutosi kattha gacchati.
analyzed: chātaḥ ātatta rūpā asi kutas asi kattha gacchati
translated: you are thin, and your body is covered with hair—where do you come from, and where are you going?”

original: “Duddasī appakārosi, dubbaṇṇo bhīmadassano;
analyzed: duddasī appakāro asi dubbaṇṇaḥ bhīma dassano
translated: “You are hard to look at, you have little flesh, you are ugly, and you are terrifying to behold;

original: Janetti yāpi te mātā, na taṃ iccheyya passituṃ.
analyzed: jana itti yā api te mātā na tam iccheyya passitum
translated: Even your mother, Janetti, would not wish to see you.

original: “Kiṃ kammamakaraṃ pubbe, kaṃ avajjhaṃ aghātayi;
analyzed: kim kammam akaram pubbe kam avajjham aghātayi
translated: “What deed did I do in the past, what wrong did I do to whom?

original: Kibbisaṃ yaṃ karitvāna, idaṃ dukkhaṃ upāgamī”ti.🔽Tattha bārāṇasyanti bārāṇasiyaṃ. Mittāmaccaparibyūḷhoti mittehi ca daḷhabhattīhi
analyzed: kibbisam yam karitvānaḥ idam dukkham upāgami iti  tattha bārāṇasyanti bārāṇasiyam mitta amacca paribyūḍho ti mittehi ca daḷha bhattīhi
translated: What evil did I do, that having done it, I have come to this suffering?”

original: amaccehi ca parivuto. Migājinanti evaṃnāmakaṃ uyyānaṃ. Setanti setakuṭṭhena setaṃ🔽kabarakuṭṭhena vicitraṃ paribhinnena kaṇḍūyanakilāsakuṭṭhena kilāsinaṃ vedanāppattaṃ🔽kadalipaṇṇe nipannaṃ addasa. Viddhastaṃ koviḷāraṃvāti vaṇamukhehi paggharantena maṃsena
analyzed: amaccehi ca parivutaḥ evaṃnāmakam uyyānam setanti seta kuṭṭhena setam  kabara kuṭṭhena vicitram paribhinnena kaṇḍūyana kilāsa kuṭṭhena kilāsinam vedanāppattam  kadali paṇṇe nipannam addasa viddhaḥ tam vaṇa mukhehi paggharantena maṃsena
translated: There, at Bārāṇasī: at Bārāṇasī. Surrounded by friends and relatives: surrounded by friends and relatives. The deer park: a park by that name. The white: white with white plaster,🔽variegated with variegated plaster, scratched with the plaster of the itch. The itch-stricken: one who has reached the pain of the itch.🔽Lying on a plantain leaf: he saw him lying on a plantain leaf. Pierced like a kovidāra tree: like a flowering kovidāra tree,

original: viddhastaṃ pupphitakoviḷārasadisaṃ. Kisanti ekaccesu padesesu aṭṭhicammamattasarīraṃ
analyzed: viddha stam pupphita koviḷāra sadisam kisanti ekaccesu padesesu aṭṭhi camma matta sarīram
translated: pierced with flesh oozing from the mouth of the wound. Emaciated: in some places the body is just skin and bone,🔽covered with a net of hair. Terrified: frightened or amazed. Among the spirits:

original: sirājālasanthataṃ. Byamhitoti bhīto vimhayamāpanno vā. Yakkhānanti yakkhānaṃ antare
analyzed: sirā jāla santhatam byamhitaḥ ti bhītaḥ vimhayam āpannaḥ vā yakkhānam ti yakkhānam antare
translated: among the spirits.

original: tvaṃ katarayakkho nāmāsi. Vaṭṭanāvaḷisaṅkāsāti piṭṭhikaṇṭakaṭṭhāne āvunitvā ṭhapitāvaṭṭanāvaḷisadisā.
analyzed: tvam katarayakkhaḥ nāma asi vaṭṭanā vaḷi saṅkāsā ati piṭṭhikaṇṭaka ṭhāne āvunitvā ṭhapitā avaṭṭanā vaḷi sadisā
translated: “What kind of a yakkha are you?” “Vaṭṭanāvaḷisaṅkāsā” means “having the appearance of a rope that has been uncoiled and laid down on the ground.”

original: Aṅgāti kāḷapabbavallisadisāni te aṅgāni. Nāññanti aññaṃ purisaṃ edisaṃ na passāmi.
analyzed: aṅgā ti kāḷa pabba valli sadisāni te aṅgāni na aññanti aññam purisam edisam na passāmi
translated: “Aṅgā” means “having limbs like black iron rods.” “Nāññanti” means “I do not see any other man like you.”

original: Ugghaṭṭapādoti rajokiṇṇapādo. Ātattarūpoti sukkhasarīro. Duddasīti dukkhena passitabbo.🔽Appakārosīti sarīrappakārarahitosi, dussaṇṭhānosīti attho. Kiṃ kammamakaranti ito
analyzed: ugghaṭṭa pādaḥ ti rajaḥ kiṇṇa pādaḥ ātatta rūpo ti sukkha sarīraḥ duddasī iti dukkhena passitabbo  appakāro asi iti sarīra ppakāra rahitaḥ asi dussaṇṭhānaḥ asi iti attho kim kammam akaranti itas
translated: “Ugghaṭṭapādo” means “having dusty feet.” “Ātattarūpo” means “having a dry body.” “Duddasī” means “difficult to see.”

original: pubbe kiṃ kammaṃ akaraṃ, akāsīti attho. Kibbisanti dāruṇakammaṃ.
analyzed: pubbe kim kammam akaram akāsi iti attho kibbisanti dāruṇa kammaṃ
translated: “Appakāro” means “devoid of bodily form.” The meaning is: “You are difficult to look at.” “Kiṃ kammamakaranti ito pubbe” means “What deed did you do before this?” The meaning is: “What deed did you perform?” “Kibbisan” means “a terrible deed.”

original: Tato paraṃ brāhmaṇo āha –
analyzed: tatas param brāhmaṇaḥ āha
translated: After this, the brahmin said:

original: “Taggha te ahamakkhissaṃ, yathāpi kusalo tathā;
analyzed: tat ha te aham akkhissam yathā api kusalaḥ tathā
translated: “I will indeed tell you, as well as I can,

original: Saccavādiñhi lokasmiṃ, pasaṃsantīdha paṇḍitā.
analyzed: sacca vādin hi lokasmin pasaṃsanti idha paṇḍitā
translated: For in this world the wise praise the one who speaks the truth.

original: “Eko caraṃ gogaveso, mūḷho accasariṃ vane;
analyzed: ekaḥ caram go gavesaḥ mūḍhaḥ accasarim vane
translated: “Wandering alone, disguised as a cowherd, confused, in the forest,

original: Araññe irīṇe vivane, nānākuñjarasevite.
analyzed: araññe irīṇe vivane nānā kuñjara sevite
translated: In the wilderness, in the jungle, frequented by various elephants,

original: “Vāḷamigānucarite, vippanaṭṭhosmi kānane;
analyzed: vāḷa miga anucarite vippanaṭṭhaḥ asmi kānane
translated: “Wandering in the forest, lost in the jungle,

original: Acariṃ tattha sattāhaṃ, khuppipāsasamappito.
analyzed: acarim tattha sattāham khudh pipāsa samappito
translated: I stayed there for seven days, afflicted with hunger and thirst.

original: “Tattha tindukamaddakkhiṃ, visamaṭṭhaṃ bubhukkhito;
analyzed: tattha bubhukkhitaḥ
translated: There I saw a tinduka tree, standing unevenly, hungry;

original: Papātamabhilambantaṃ, sampannaphaladhārinaṃ.
analyzed: papātam abhilambantam sampanna phala dhārinam
translated: Hanging over a precipice, bearing ripe fruit.

original: “Vātassitāni bhakkhesiṃ, tāni rucciṃsu me bhusaṃ;
analyzed: vātassitāni bhakkhesim tāni rucciṃsu me bhusam
translated: I ate the wind-blown fruits, they suited me very well;

original: Atitto rukkhamārūhiṃ, tattha hessāmi āsito.
analyzed: a tittaḥ rukkham ārūhim tattha hessāmi āsitaḥ
translated: Greedy, I climbed the tree, there I would stay, well-fed.

original: “Ekaṃ me bhakkhitaṃ āsi, dutiyaṃ abhipatthitaṃ;🔽Tato sā bhañjatha sākhā, chinnā pharasunā viya.
analyzed: ekam me bhakkhitam āsi dutiyam abhipatthitam  sā sākhā chinnā
translated: One was eaten by me, the second was desired;🔽Then that branch broke, as if cut with an axe.

original: “Sohaṃ sahāva sākhāhi, uddhaṃpādo avaṃsiro;
analyzed: saḥ mama sahāva sākhāhi uddhaṃpādaḥ
translated: Then I, with the branches, fell upwards with my feet, downwards with my head;

original: Appatiṭṭhe anālambe, giriduggasmi pāpataṃ.
analyzed: appatiṭṭhe anālambe giriduggasmi
translated: Without support, without foothold, from the mountain’s peak into the abyss.

original: “Yasmā ca vāri gambhīraṃ, tasmā na samapajjisaṃ;
analyzed: yasmai ca vāri gambhīram tasmai na samapajjisam
translated: Because the water was deep, therefore I did not sink;

original: Tattha sesiṃ nirānando, anūnā dasa rattiyo.
analyzed: tattha sesim nirānandaḥ anūnāḥ dasa rattiyaḥ
translated: There I lay, without joy, for ten nights without a break.

original: “Athettha kapi māgañchi, gonaṅgulo darīcaro;🔽Sākhāhi sākhaṃ vicaranto, khādamāno dumapphalaṃ.
analyzed: athā itthā kapi gonaṅgulaḥ darīcaraḥ  sākham sākham vicarantaḥ khādamānaḥ duma phalam
translated: Then a monkey came there, a forest-dweller, a mountain-goer;🔽Roaming from branch to branch, eating the fruits of the trees.

original: “So maṃ disvā kisaṃ paṇḍuṃ, kāruññamakaraṃ mayi;
analyzed: saḥ mam disvā kisam paṇḍum kāruññam akaram mayi
translated: Seeing me, thin and pale, he had compassion on me;

original: Ambho ko nāma so ettha, evaṃ dukkhena aṭṭito.
analyzed: ambho kaḥ nāma saḥ ettha evam dukkhena aṭṭitaḥ
translated: “Who are you, sir, that are thus afflicted with pain?”

original: “Manusso amanusso vā, attānaṃ me pavedaya;
analyzed: manussaḥ amanussaḥ vai attānam me pavedaya
translated: “Whether you are a man or a spirit, tell me who you are.

original: Tassañjaliṃ paṇāmetvā, idaṃ vacanamabraviṃ.
analyzed: tasya añjalim paṇāmetvā idam vacanam abravim
translated: Having bowed to him, I spoke these words:

original: “Manussohaṃ byasampatto, sā me natthi ito gati;
analyzed: manusso ham bya sampatto sā me natthi itas gati
translated: “I am a man who has fallen into misfortune; I have no other recourse.

original: Taṃ vo vadāmi bhaddaṃ vo, tvañca me saraṇaṃ bhava.
analyzed: tam vaḥ vadāmi bhaddam vaḥ tvañca me saraṇam bhava
translated: I tell you this, may you be fortunate; be my refuge.

original: “Garuṃ silaṃ gahetvāna, vicarī pabbate kapi;
analyzed: garum silam gahetvāna vicarī pabbate kapi
translated: “Having taken a heavy rock, the monkey roamed the mountain;

original: Silāya yoggaṃ katvāna, nisabho etadabravi.
analyzed: silāya yoggam katvāna nisabho etat abravi
translated: Having made a bridge with the rock, Nīsaṃha spoke thus:

original: “Ehi me piṭṭhimāruyha, gīvaṃ gaṇhāhi bāhubhi;
analyzed: ehi me piṭṭhim āruyha gīvam gaṇhāhi bāhubhi
translated: “Come, mount on my back and hold on to my neck with your arms;

original: Ahaṃ taṃ uddharissāmi, giriduggata vegasā.
analyzed: aham tam uddharissāmi giri duggata vegasā
translated: I will lift you up, with the speed of one who has fallen from a mountain peak.”

original: “Tassa taṃ vacanaṃ sutvā, vānarindassa sirīmato;
analyzed: tassa tam vacanam sutvā vānara indassa sirīmataḥ
translated: “Having heard the words of that lord of monkeys, the glorious one,

original: Piṭṭhimāruyha dhīrassa, gīvaṃ bāhāhi aggahiṃ.
analyzed: piṭṭhim āruyha dhīrassa gīvam bāhāhi aggahim
translated: I mounted on the back of the wise one, and held on to his neck with my arms.

original: “So maṃ tato samuṭṭhāsi, tejassī balavā kapi;
analyzed: saḥ mam tatas samuṭṭhāsi tejassī balavā kapi
translated: “Then he rose up from there, the powerful monkey, full of energy;

original: Vihaññamāno kicchena, giriduggata vegasā.🔽“Uddharitvāna maṃ santo, nisabho etadabravi;
analyzed: vihaññamānaḥ kicchena giri duggata vegasā  uddharitvāna mam santaḥ nisabho etat abravi
translated: Afflicted with pain, with difficulty, with the speed of one who has fallen from a mountain peak.🔽“Having lifted me up, the peaceful Nīsaṃha spoke thus:

original: Iṅgha maṃ samma rakkhassu, pasupissaṃ muhuttakaṃ.
analyzed: iṅgha mama samma rakkhassu pasupissam muhuttakam
translated: “Come, my good friend, protect me for a moment.

original: “Sīhā byagghā ca dīpī ca, acchakokataracchayo;
analyzed: sīhā byagghā ca dīpī ca
translated: “Lions, tigers, and leopards, and the king of birds, the vulture;

original: Te maṃ pamattaṃ hiṃseyyuṃ, te tvaṃ disvā nivāraya.
analyzed: te mam pamattam hiṃseyyum te tvam disvā nivāraya
translated: They would harm me if I were careless, you must keep them away when you see them.”

original: “Evaṃ me parittātūna, pasupī so muhuttakaṃ;
analyzed: evam me pasupī saḥ muhuttakam
translated: “Thus I was protected from the wild beasts for a short time,

original: Tadāhaṃ pāpikaṃ diṭṭhiṃ, paṭilacchiṃ ayoniso.
analyzed: tadā aham pāpikam diṭṭhim paṭilacchim ayonisaḥ
translated: Then I abandoned the wrong view that I had formed without reason.

original: “Bhakkho ayaṃ manussānaṃ, yathā caññe vane migā;
analyzed: bhakkhaḥ ayam manussānam yathā caññe vane migā
translated: “This is food for humans, just like other deer in the forest;

original: Yaṃ nūnimaṃ vadhitvāna, chāto khādeyya vānaraṃ.
analyzed: yam nūnimam vadhitvāna chātaḥ khādeyya vānaram
translated: Now if I were to kill him, I could eat the monkey fresh.

original: “Asito ca gamissāmi, maṃsamādāya sambalaṃ;
analyzed: asitaḥ ca gamissāmi maṃsam ādāya sambalam
translated: “I will go without a load, taking the meat as provisions;

original: Kantāraṃ nittharissāmi, pātheyyaṃ me bhavissati.
analyzed: kantāram nittharissāmi pātheyyam me bhavissati
translated: I will cross the desert, it will be my provisions for the journey.

original: “Tato silaṃ gahetvāna, matthakaṃ sannitāḷayiṃ;
analyzed: tatas silam gahetvāna matthakam
translated: “Then I took a stone, and struck him on the head;

original: Mama gattakilantassa, pahāro dubbalo ahu.
analyzed: mama gatta kilantassa pahāraḥ dubbalaḥ ahu
translated: The blow was weak for one who had gone to the end of his life.

original: “So ca vegenudappatto, kapi ruhiramakkhito;
analyzed: saḥ ca vegena uda pattaḥ kapi ruhira makkhito
translated: “And he, coming on with speed, the monkey covered with blood,

original: Assupuṇṇehi nettehi, rodanto maṃ udikkhati.
analyzed: assu puṇṇehi nettehi rodantaḥ mama udikkhati
translated: With eyes full of tears, he looked up at me and wept.

original: “Māyyo maṃ kari bhaddante, tvañca nāmedisaṃ kari;
analyzed: māyyaḥ mam kari bhaddante tvam ca nāmedisam kari
translated: “Do not kill me, good sir, you should not do this to me;

original: Tvañca kho nāma dīghāvu, aññe vāretumarahasi.
analyzed: tvañca kho nāma dīghāvu aññe vāretum arahasi
translated: You are indeed a long-lived one, you are able to ward off others.

original: “Aho vata re purisa, tāvadukkarakāraka;
analyzed: aho vata re purisa tāvat dukkara kāraka
translated: “Oh, what a man, you are a doer of what is very difficult,

original: Edisā visamā duggā, papātā uddhato mayā.
analyzed: edisā visamā duggā papātā uddhataḥ mayā
translated: Such is the uneven, difficult, steep path that I have climbed.

original: “Ānīto paralokāva, dubbheyyaṃ maṃ amaññatha;
analyzed: ānītaḥ para lokā ava dubbheyyam mama amaññatha
translated: “You thought me deceitful, as if I had been brought from the world beyond.

original: Taṃ tena pāpakammena, pāpaṃ pāpena cintitaṃ.
analyzed: tam tena pāpa kammena pāpam pāpena cintitam
translated: Because of that evil deed, evil was thought by the evil one.

original: “Mā heva tvaṃ adhammaṭṭha, vedanaṃ kaṭukaṃ phusi;
analyzed: mā ha iva tvam adhammaṭṭha vedanam kaṭukam phusi
translated: “Do not, O you who stand in unrighteousness, experience painful feeling!

original: Mā heva pāpakammaṃ taṃ, phalaṃ veḷuṃva taṃ vadhi.
analyzed: mā ha iva pāpa kammam tam phalam veḷum iva tam vadhi
translated: Do not, O evil one, reap the fruit of your evil deed, as the reed reaps the fruit of its growth.

original: “Tayi me natthi vissāso, pāpadhamma asaññata;
analyzed: tayi me natthi vissāsaḥ pāpa dhamma asaññata
translated: “I have no confidence in you, O evil one, you who are unrestrained in your evil ways.

original: Ehi me piṭṭhito gaccha, dissamānova santike.
analyzed: ehi me piṭṭhitaḥ gaccha dissamānaḥ iva santike
translated: Come, walk behind me, and keep close by, so that I may see you.

original: “Muttosi hatthā vāḷānaṃ, pattosi mānusiṃ padaṃ;
analyzed: muttaḥ asi hatthā vāḷānam pattaḥ asi mānusim padam
translated: “You are freed from the hands of the wild beasts, and have regained your human state.

original: Esa maggo adhammaṭṭha, tena gaccha yathāsukhaṃ.
analyzed: esa maggaḥ adhammaṭṭha tena gaccha yathāsukham
translated: This is the way, O you who stand in unrighteousness. Go by it as you please.”

original: “Idaṃ vatvā giricaro, rahade pakkhalya matthakaṃ;
analyzed: idam vatvā giricaraḥ rahade pakkhalya matthakam
translated: “Having spoken thus, the mountain-dweller, having slipped on the rock,

original: Assūni sampamajjitvā, tato pabbatamāruhi.
analyzed: assūni sampamajjitvā tatas pabbatam āruhi
translated: having wiped his tears, then climbed the mountain.

original: “Sohaṃ tenābhisattosmi, pariḷāhena aṭṭito;
analyzed: saḥ aham tena abhisattaḥ asmi pariḷāhena aṭṭitaḥ
translated: “I was afflicted by him, and tormented by fever.

original: Ḍayhamānena gattena, vāriṃ pātuṃ upāgamiṃ.
analyzed: ḍayhamānena gattena vārim pātum
translated: With my body burning, I went to drink water.

original: “Agginā viya santatto, rahado ruhiramakkhito;
analyzed: agginā viya santattaḥ rahadaḥ ruhira makkhito
translated: “Like a heated furnace, the lake was covered with lotuses.

original: Pubbalohitasaṅkāso, sabbo me samapajjatha.
analyzed: pubba lohita saṅkāsaḥ sabbaḥ me samapajjatha
translated: All of it became like my former blood and flesh.

original: “Yāvanto udabindūni, kāyasmiṃ nipatiṃsu me;
analyzed: yāvantaḥ uda bindūni kāyasmin nipatiṃsu me
translated: “As many drops of water as fell on my body,

original: Tāvanto gaṇḍa jāyetha, addhabeluvasādisā.
analyzed: tāvantaḥ jāyetha
translated: So many boils will arise, the size of half a beluva leaf.

original: “Pabhinnā pagghariṃsu me, kuṇapā pubbalohitā;
analyzed: pabhinnā pagghariṃsu me kuṇapā pubba lohitā
translated: “My boils burst and pus and blood flowed out,

original: Yena yeneva gacchāmi, gāmesu nigamesu ca.
analyzed: yena yena iva gacchāmi gāmesu nigamesu ca
translated: Wherever I went, in villages and towns,

original: “Daṇḍahatthā nivārenti, itthiyo purisā ca maṃ;
analyzed: daṇḍa hatthāḥ nivārenti itthiyo purisā ca mama
translated: “Men and women with sticks in their hands restrained me,

original: Okkitā pūtigandhena, māssu orena āgamā.
analyzed: pūti gandhena māssu orena āgamā
translated: ‘Do not come near us, you who are oozing with a foul smell.’

original: “Etādisaṃ idaṃ dukkhaṃ, satta vassāni dāni me;
analyzed: etādisam idam dukkham satta vassāni dāni me
translated: “Such is my suffering, now for seven years,

original: Anubhomi sakaṃ kammaṃ, pubbe dukkaṭamattano.
analyzed: anubhomi sakam kammam pubbe dukkaṭa mattano
translated: I experience my own deeds, the evil I did in the past.

original: “Taṃ vo vadāmi bhaddante, yāvantettha samāgatā;
analyzed: tam vaḥ vadāmi bhaddante yāvantā itthā samāgatā
translated: “Therefore I say to you, good sirs, all assembled here,

original: Māssu mittāna dubbhittho, mittadubbho hi pāpako.
analyzed: mā assu mittāna dubbhitthaḥ mitta dubbhaḥ hi pāpakaḥ
translated: Do not be faithless to your friends, for faithlessness to friends is evil.

original: “Kuṭṭhī kilāsī bhavati, yo mittānidha dubbhati;
analyzed: kuṭṭhī kilāsī bhavati yaḥ
translated: “One who is faithless to friends becomes a leper, a leper,

original: Kāyassa bhedā mittaddu, nirayaṃ sopapajjatī”ti.
analyzed: kāyassa bhedā nirayam saḥ upapajjati iti
translated: With the breakup of the body, the faithless one goes to hell.”

original: Tattha kusaloti yathā cheko kusalo katheti, tathā vo kathessāmi. Gogavesoti naṭṭhe
analyzed: tattha kusalo ti yathā chekaḥ kusalo katheti tathā vaḥ kathessāmi go gaveso ti naṭṭhe
translated: Here, “skilled” means I will speak to you as a skilled person speaks. “Cattle and buffaloes” means when they are lost,

original: goṇe gavesanto. Accasarinti manussapathaṃ atikkamitvā himavantaṃ pāvisiṃ. Araññeti
analyzed: goṇe gavesantaḥ accasarinti manussa patham atikkamitvā himavantam pāvisim araññā iti
translated: I was looking for oxen. I went too far: I went beyond the human path and entered the Himalayas. In the forest:🔽in a kingless, deserted place. In a ravine:

original: arājake suññe. Irīṇeti sukkhakantāre. Vivaneti vivitte. Vippanaṭṭhoti maggamūḷho.
analyzed: arājake suññe irīṇeti sukkha kantāre vivaneti vivitte vippanaṭṭhaḥ ti magga mūḷhaḥ
translated: in a dry desert. In a wilderness: in a lonely place. I was lost: I was confused about the path.

original: Bubhukkhitoti sañjātabubhukkho chātajjhatto. Papātamabhilambantanti papātābhimukhaṃ
analyzed: bubhukkhitaḥ iti sañjāta bubhukkhaḥ chāta jjhattaḥ papātam papāta abhimukham
translated: I was hungry: I was hungry, my mouth was dry. I was hanging over a precipice: I was hanging over a precipice,

original: olambantaṃ. Sampannaphaladhārinanti madhuraphaladhārinaṃ. Vātassitānīti paṭhamaṃ
analyzed: olambantam madhura phala dhārinam vātassitāni iti paṭhamam
translated: facing it. Bearing ripe fruit: bearing sweet fruit. I ate the fruit: I first ate the fruit that had fallen

original: tāva vātapatitāni khādiṃ. Tattha hessāmīti tasmiṃ rukkhe suhito bhavissāmīti āruḷhomhi.🔽Tato sā bhañjatha sākhāti tassa abhipatthitassa atthāya hatthe pasārite sā mayā abhiruḷhā
analyzed: tāva vāta patitāni khādim tattha hessāmi iti tasmin rukkhe su hitaḥ bhavissāmi iti āruḷho mhi  tatas sā tassa abhipatthitassa atthāya hatthe pasārite sā mayā abhiruḷhā
translated: by the wind. I climbed up: I climbed up thinking, “I will be comfortable in that tree.”

original: sākhā pharasunā chinnā viya abhañjatha. Anālambeti ālambitabbaṭṭhānarahite. Giriduggasminti
analyzed: sākhā pharasunā chinnā viya abhañjatha anālambā iti ālambitabba ṭṭhāna rahite giri duggasmin ti
translated: Then it broke: Then that branch, which I had climbed up to for that purpose, broke like a branch cut off with an axe. There was no support: there was no place to hold on to. On a steep mountain:

original: girivisame. Sesinti sayitomhi.
analyzed: giri visame sesinti
translated: on a rough mountain. I hung: I hung there.

original: Kapi māgañchīti kapi āgañchi. Gonaṅguloti gunnaṃ naṅguṭṭhasadisanaṅguṭṭho. “Gonaṅguṭṭho”tipi🔽pāṭho. “Gonaṅgulī”tipi paṭhanti. Akaraṃ mayīti akarā mayi. Ambhoti, mahārāja, so🔽kapirājā tasmiṃ narakapapāte mama udakapothanasaddaṃ sutvā maṃ “ambho”ti ālapitvā
analyzed: kapi mā āgañchi iti kapi āgañchi gonaṅgulo iti gunnam naṅguṭṭha sadisa naṅguṭṭhaḥ gonaṅguṭṭhaḥ itipi  pāṭhaḥ gonaṅgulī itipi paṭhanti akaram mayi iti mayi mahā rāja saḥ  kapi rājā tasmin naraka papāte mama udaka pothana saddam sutvā mā ambho iti ālapitvā
translated: The monkey came: the monkey came. The goat’s hoof: his hoof was like a goat’s hoof. The reading is also “goat’s hoof.” Some read “goat’s hoof-print.” The axe struck me: the axe struck me. Oh: the monkey king, having heard the sound of my splashing in the water, called out to me, saying “Oh!”🔽🔽

original: “ko nāmeso”ti pucchi. Byasampattoti byasanaṃ patto, papātassa vasaṃ pattoti vā attho.
analyzed: kaḥ nāma iso ti pucchi byasampatto ti byasanam patto papātassa vasam patto ti vā attho
translated: The ape came: the ape came. The goat’s knee: his knee was like a goat’s knee. The reading is also “goat’s knee.” They also read “goat’s knees.” The rock struck me: the rock struck me. Oh: the ape king, great king, having heard the sound of my splashing in the water in that hell-pit, addressed me with “Oh,” and asked, “Who is this?” He has come to ruin: the meaning is that he has come to ruin, or he has come under the power of the pit.

original: Bhaddaṃ voti tasmā tumhe vadāmi – “bhaddaṃ tumhākaṃ hotū”ti. Garuṃ silanti, mahārāja,
analyzed: bhaddam vaḥ ti tasmai tumhe vadāmi bhaddam tumhākam hotu iti garum mahā rāja
translated: I say to you: “Good luck to you.” The rock is heavy: great king,

original: so kapirājā mayā evaṃ vutte “mā bhāyī”ti maṃ assāsetvā paṭhamaṃ tāva garuṃ silaṃ
analyzed: saḥ kapi rājā mayā evam vutte mā bhāyi iti mam assāsetvā paṭhamam tāva garum silam
translated: the ape king, having comforted me with “Do not be afraid,” having first taken a heavy rock,

original: gahetvā yoggaṃ karonto pabbate vicari. Nisabhoti purisanisabho uttamavānarindo pabbatapapāte
analyzed: gahetvā yoggam karontaḥ pabbate purisa nisabhaḥ uttama vānara indo pabbata papāte
translated: and having tested his strength, roamed about on the mountain. The best of men: the best of men, the lord of the best of apes, having stood on the mountain-side,

original: ṭhatvā maṃ etadabravīti.
analyzed: mama etat abravīti
translated: said this to me.

original: Bāhubhīti dvīhi bāhāhi mama gīvaṃ suggahitaṃ gaṇha. Vegasāti vegena. Sirīmatoti puññavantassa.🔽Aggahinti saṭṭhihatthaṃ narakapapātaṃ vātavegena otaritvā udakapiṭṭhe ṭhitassa ahaṃ
analyzed: bāhubhi iti dvīhi bāhāhi mama gīvam suggahitam gaṇha vegasā ati vegena sirīmato ti puññavantassa  aggahinti saṭṭhi hattham naraka papātam vāta vegena otaritvā udaka piṭṭhe ṭhitassa aham
translated: Bāhubhīti means with two arms.

original: vegena piṭṭhimabhiruhitvā ubhohi bāhāhi gīvaṃ aggahesiṃ. Vihaññamānoti kilamanto.
analyzed: vegena piṭṭhim abhiruhitvā ubhohi bāhāhi gīvam aggahesim vihaññamānaḥ iti kilamantaḥ
translated: Aggahinti means I climbed on his back quickly and seized his neck with both arms. Vihaññamānoti means being tired.

original: Kicchenāti dukkhena. Santoti paṇḍito, atha vā parisanto kilanto. Rakkhassūti ahaṃ
analyzed: kicchena ati dukkhena santo ti paṇḍitaḥ atha vā parisantaḥ kilantaḥ rakkhassu iti aham
translated: Kicchena means with difficulty. Santo means wise, or else parisanto means tired. Rakkhassū means I

original: taṃ uddharanto kilanto muhuttaṃ vissamanto pasupissaṃ, tasmā maṃ rakkhāhi. Yathā
analyzed: tam uddharantaḥ kilantaḥ muhuttam vissamantaḥ pasupissam tasmā mama rakkhāhi yathā
translated: am tired from pulling you out, so I will rest a moment, so protect me. Yathā

original: caññe vane migāti sīhādīhi aññepi ye imasmiṃ vane vāḷamigā. Pāḷiyaṃ pana “acchakokataracchayo”ti
analyzed: caññe vane migā ti sīha ādīhi aññe pi ye imasmin vane vāḷa migā pāḷiyam pana
translated: caññe means as other animals in the forest. In the text, they write “acchakokataracchayo.”

original: likhanti. Parittātūnāti, mahārāja, evaṃ so kapirājā maṃ attano parittāṇaṃ katvā muhuttaṃ
analyzed: likhanti mahā rāja evam saḥ kapi rājā mama attanaḥ parittāṇam katvā muhuttam
translated: Parittātūn means, great king, in this way that monkey king made me his protection and rested for a moment.

original: pasupi. Ayonisoti ayonisomanasikārena. Bhakkhoti khāditabbayuttako. Asito dhāto suhito.
analyzed: ayonisaḥ ayonisaḥ ti ayonisaḥ manasikārena bhakkho ti khāditabba yuttakaḥ asitaḥ dhāto su hitaḥ
translated: Ayoniso means with unwise attention. Bhakkho means suitable to be eaten. Asito means uncooked, dhāto means having the nature of, suhito means well-cooked.

original: Sambalanti pātheyyaṃ. Matthakaṃ sannitāḷayinti tassa vānarindassa matthakaṃ pahariṃ.
analyzed: sambalanti pātheyyam matthakam tassa vānara indassa matthakam pahariṃ
translated: Sambala means food. They struck the head of the king of the monkeys means they struck the head of that king of the monkeys.

original: “Sannitāḷaya”ntipi pāṭho. Dubbalo ahūti na balavā āsi, yathādhippāyaṃ na agamāsīti.
analyzed: pāṭhaḥ dubbalaḥ na balavā āsi yathā adhippāyam na agamāsi iti
translated: The reading “sannitāḷaya” is also correct. He was not strong means he was not strong enough to do what he intended.

original: Vegenāti mayā pahaṭapāsāṇavegena. Udappattoti uṭṭhito. Māyyoti tena mittadubbhipurisena
analyzed: vegena ati mayā pahaṭa pāsāṇa vegena udappatto ti uṭṭhitaḥ māyyaḥ iti tena mitta dubbhi purisena
translated: By the speed means by the speed of the stone I threw. He rose up means he got up. The monkey means the man who was treacherous to his friend.

original: silāya paviddhāya mahācammaṃ chinditvā olambi, ruhiraṃ pagghari. Mahāsatto vedanāppatto
analyzed: silāya paviddhāya mahā cammam chinditvā olambi ruhiram pagghari mahā sattaḥ vedanā patto
translated: When he was hit by the stone, the monkey tore off his own skin, hung on to it, and bled. The Great Being, who was in pain,

original: cintesi – “imasmiṃ ṭhāne añño natthi, idaṃ bhayaṃ imaṃ purisaṃ nissāya uppanna”nti.
analyzed: cintesi imasmin ṭhāne aññaḥ na atthi idam bhayam imam purisam nissāya uppannanti
translated: thought, “There is no one else here. This danger has arisen because of this man.”

original: So maraṇabhayabhīto olambantaṃ cammabandhaṃ hatthena gahetvā uppatitvā sākhaṃ abhiruyha🔽tena pāpapurisena saddhiṃ sallapanto “māyyo ma”ntiādimāha. Tattha māyyo maṃ kari
analyzed: saḥ maraṇa bhaya bhītaḥ olambantam camma bandham hatthena gahetvā uppatitvā sākham abhiruyha  tena pāpa purisena saddhim sallapantaḥ māyyaḥ manti ādim āha tattha māyyaḥ mam
translated: Frightened by the danger of death, he grabbed the skin that was hanging on to his hand, jumped up, climbed a branch,🔽and spoke to the wicked man, saying, “Don’t, my dear,” and so on. There, “Don’t, my dear” means “Don’t, my dear.”

original: bhaddanteti mā akari ayyo maṃ bhaddanteti taṃ nivāreti. Tvañca kho nāmāti tvaṃ nāma
analyzed: bhaddanta iti mā akari ayyaḥ mam bhaddanta iti tam nivāra iti tvam ca khaḥ nāma ati tvam nāma
translated: “Good sir” means “Don’t do this, good sir.” “You, sir” means “You, sir.”

original: evaṃ mayā papātā uddhaṭo edisaṃ pharusakammaṃ mayi kari, aho te ayuttaṃ katanti.
analyzed: evam mayā papātā uddhaṭaḥ edisam pharusa kammam mayi aho te ayuttam katam ti
translated: “So you have dug me out of the pit, and you do this cruel deed to me! Oh, how unfitting it is of you!”

original: Aho vatāti taṃ garahanto evamāha. Tāvadukkarakārakāti mayi aparajjhanena atidukkarakammakāraka.
analyzed: aho vata iti tam garahantaḥ evam āha tāva dukkara kāraka ati mayi aparajjhanena ati dukkara kamma kāraka
translated: “Oh, what a thing!” he said, reproaching him. “You have done a deed so hard to do!” he said, because of my not being angry with him.

original: Paralokāvāti paralokato viya ānīto. Dubbheyyanti dubbhitabbaṃ vadhitabbaṃ. Vedanaṃ
analyzed: para loka avāti para lokataḥ viyas ānītaḥ dubbheyyanti dubbhitabbam vadhitabbam vedanam
translated: “You have been brought from the other world!” he said, as if he had been brought from the other world. “You should be afraid!” he said.🔽“You should be afraid of the pain

original: kaṭukanti evaṃ santepi tvaṃ adhammaṭṭha yādisaṃ vedanaṃ ahaṃ phusāmi, edisaṃ vedanaṃ
analyzed: evam sante pi tvam adhammaṭṭha yādisam vedanam aham phusāmi edisam vedanam
translated: you will feel!” he said. “Even so, you who are bent on unrighteousness, may you not feel such pain as I do!

original: kaṭukaṃ mā phusi, taṃ pāpakammaṃ phalaṃ veḷuṃva taṃ mā vadhi. Iti maṃ, mahārāja,
analyzed: kaṭukam mā tam pāpa kammam phalam tam mā vadhi iti mama mahā rāja
translated: May you not feel such bitter pain! May you not reap the fruit of your evil deed, as I have reaped the fruit of mine!”

original: so piyaputtakaṃ viya anukampi.
analyzed: so piya puttakam viya anukampi
translated: Thus, sire, he took pity on me as on a dear son.

original: Atha naṃ ahaṃ etadavocaṃ – “ayya, mayā kataṃ dosaṃ hadaye mā kari, mā maṃ asappurisaṃ
analyzed: atha nam aham etat avocam ayya mayā katam dosam hadaye mā kari mā mama a sappurisam
translated: Then I said to him, ‘Reverend sir, do not bear malice against me for what I have done. Do not lead me, a wicked man,

original: evarūpe araññe nāsaya, ahaṃ disāmūḷho maggaṃ na jānāmi, attanā kataṃ kammaṃ mā nāsetha,
analyzed: evarūpe araññe nāsaya aham disāmūḷhaḥ maggam na jānāmi attanā katam kammam mā nā āsetha
translated: into the forest, for I am lost and do not know the way. Do not destroy the fruit of your own deed,

original: jīvitadānaṃ me detha, araññā nīharitvā manussapathe ṭhapethā”ti. Evaṃ vutte so mayā
analyzed: jīvita dānam me detha araññā nīharitvā manussa pathe ṭhapetha ati evam vutte saḥ mayā
translated: Give me my life, and take me out of the forest and put me on the road.” When this was said, I said to him:

original: saddhiṃ sallapanto “tayi me natthi vissāso”ti ādimāha. Tattha tayīti ito paṭṭhāya🔽mayhaṃ tayi vissāso natthi. Ehīti, bho purisa, ahaṃ tayā saddhiṃ maggena na gamissāmi,
analyzed: saddhim sallapantaḥ tayi me natthi vissāsaḥ ti ādim āha tattha tayi iti itas paṭṭhāya  mayham tayi vissāsaḥ natthi ehi iti bho purisa aham tayā saddhim maggena na gamissāmi
translated: Give me my life, and taking me out of the forest, set me down on the road of men.” When he had thus spoken, he argued with me, saying, “I have no confidence in you.” Herein, “tayi” means “from this time forth.”

original: tvaṃ pana ehi mama piṭṭhito avidūre dissamānasarīrova gaccha, ahaṃ rukkhaggeheva🔽gamissāmīti. Muttosīti atha so maṃ, mahārāja, araññā nīharitvā, bho purisa, vāḷamigānaṃ
analyzed: tvam pana ehi mama piṭṭhitaḥ avidūre dissamāna sarīraḥ iva gaccha aham rukkha gehe iva  gamissāmi iti muttaḥ asi iti atha saḥ mama mahā rāja araññā nīharitvā bho purisa vāḷamigānam
translated: “I have no confidence in you.” “Ehī” means “I will not go with you on the road, but you come and go behind me, your body being seen at a distance. I will go in the tree-house.”

original: hatthā muttosi. Pattosi mānusiṃ padanti manussūpacāraṃ patto āgatosi, esa te maggo, etena gacchāti āha.🔽Giricaroti giricārī vānaro. Pakkhalyāti dhovitvā. Tenābhisattosmīti so ahaṃ, mahārāja,
analyzed: hatthā muttaḥ asi pattaḥ asi mānusim padanti manussu upacāram pattaḥ āgataḥ asi esa te maggo etena gaccha āti āha  giri caro ti giri cārī vānaraḥ dhovitvā tena abhisattaḥ asmi iti saḥ aham mahā rāja
translated: “Muttosī” means “you are freed, O man, from the hands of the wild beasts.” “Pattosi mānusiṃ padan” means “you have come to the human world, you have come to the human path; this is your path, go by it.”

original: tena vānarena abhisatto, pāpakamme pariṇate tenābhisattosmīti maññamāno evamāha.
analyzed: tena vānarena abhisatto pāpa kamme pariṇate tena abhisatto asmi iti maññamānaḥ evam āha
translated: “Giricaro” means “the forest-roaming monkey.” “Pakkhalyāti” means “having washed.” “Tenābhisattosmi” means “I, O great king, thinking that I was cursed by that monkey, because of the evil deed that had been done, said thus.”

original: Aṭṭitoti upadduto. Upāgaminti ekaṃ rahadaṃ upagatosmi. Samapajjathāti jāto, evarūpo🔽hutvā upaṭṭhāsi. Yāvantoti yattakāni. Gaṇḍa jāyethāti gaṇḍā jāyiṃsu. So kira pipāsaṃ
analyzed: ekam rahadam upagataḥ asmi samapajjatha ati jātaḥ evarūpaḥ  hutvā upaṭṭhāsi yāvantaḥ iti yattakāni gaṇḍa jāyetha ati gaṇḍāḥ jāyiṃsu saḥ kira pipāsam
translated: “I was afflicted” means I was tormented. “I went” means I went to a certain pool. “I entered” means I was born.

original: sandhāretuṃ asakkonto udakañjaliṃ ukkhipitvā thokaṃ pivitvā sesaṃ sarīre siñci. Athassa
analyzed: sandhāretum a sakkontaḥ uda kañjalim ukkhipitvā thokam pivitvā sesam sarīre siñci
translated: and I served him. “As many” means as many as. “Boils appeared” means boils arose. It seems that, being unable to endure thirst, he raised a handful of water to his mouth, drank a little, and sprinkled the rest over his body.

original: tāvadeva udakabindugaṇanāya aḍḍhabeluvapakkappamāṇā gaṇḍā uṭṭhahiṃsu, tasmā evamāha.
analyzed: tāvat eva udaka bindu gaṇanāya aḍḍha beluva pakkappamāṇāḥ gaṇḍāḥ uṭṭhahiṃsu tasmai evam āha
translated: Then, just as he did so, boils the size of half a beluva leaf arose by the number of the drops of water. Therefore he said, “As many as the drops of water.”

original: Pabhinnāti te gaṇḍā taṃ divasameva bhijjitvā kuṇapā pūtigandhikā hutvā pubbalohitāni

analyzed: ohāya gacchāmase sabba kāme supaṇṇa
translated: we will leave all these things behind and go away. We will go to Supaṇṇa, to the land of the birds.”

analyzed: saṃyametum ti imam guyha vācam rahassa kāraṇam rakkhitum na asakkhim tad pakkhataḥ hi iti  idāni idam bhayam mama tassa acelakassa pakkhataḥ koṭṭhāsataḥ santikā āgatam iti atīta tthaḥ
translated: “I have not been able to restrain myself” means: I have not been able to keep this secret talk, this secret reason, hidden. “From the quarter of the ascetic”

translated: do you disparage it? But in the reading “Even the kind of wisdom that is not to be disparaged,” it is quite appropriate.
