analyzed: saccena ati ādīsu vacī saccena ca su carita dhammena ca paññā saṅkhātāya dhitiyā ca indriya damena
translated: In the passages beginning “By the truth of speech” and so on, by the truth of speech, by the state of good conduct, by the fortitude called wisdom, by the taming of the faculties,

original: ca alabbhaṃ dullabhaṃ aṭṭhasamāpattimaggaphalanibbānasaṅkhātampi visesaṃ abyāharati🔽āvahati taṃ nipphādeti naro idha, tasmā nārahasi acelaṃ nindituṃ, attānameva garaha.🔽Acelena hi attano paññavantatāya upāyakusalatāya ca vañcetvā tvaṃ rahassaṃ guyhaṃ
analyzed: ca alabbham dullabham aṭṭha samāpatti magga phala nibbāna saṅkhātam pi visesam a byāharati  āvahati tam nipphādeti naraḥ idha tasmai na arahasi a celam ninditum attānam eva garaha  a celena hi attano paññavanta tāya upāya kusala tāya ca vañcetvā tvam rahassam guyham
translated: he does not fail to obtain, he obtains, he produces, the distinction called the eight attainments, the path, the fruit, and Nibbāna.🔽Therefore, you have no right to disparage the naked ascetic; you should only blame yourself.🔽For, having deceived you by his own wisdom and skill in means, the naked ascetic, it seems,

original: mantaṃ pucchitoti attho.
analyzed: mantam pucchito ti attho
translated: asked you in private, in secret, to tell him your secret counsel.

original: Paramāti ete ubho bandhavānaṃ uttamabandhavā nāma. Nāssa tatiyoti assa puggalassa
analyzed: ete ubho bandhavānam uttamabandhavā nāma na assa tatiyaḥ ti assa puggalassa
translated: “The best of kinsmen”: these two are called the best of kinsmen.🔽“He has no third”: there is no third being who is a sympathizer with this person,

original: mātāpitūhi añño tatiyo satto anukampako nāma natthi, mantassa bhedaṃ parisaṅkamāno
analyzed: mātā pitūhi aññaḥ tatiyaḥ satto anukampakaḥ nāma natthi mantassa bhedam parisaṅkamāno
translated: who is a sympathizer with his mother and father.🔽“The wise one should not divulge even to them the secret that he has heard”:

original: paṇḍito tesaṃ mātāpitūnampi paramaṃ guyhaṃ na saṃseyya, tvaṃ pana mātāpitūnampi akathetabbaṃ
analyzed: paṇḍito tesam mātā pitūnam pi paramam guyham na tvam pana mātā pitūnam pi a kathetabbam
translated: you, however, have divulged to the naked ascetic something that should not be told even to one’s mother and father.

original: acelakassa kathesīti attho. Sahāyā vāti suhadayamittā vā. Sapakkhāti petteyyamātulapitucchādayo
analyzed: acelakassa kathesi iti attho sahāyāḥ vā ati suhadaya mittāḥ vā petteyya mātula pituccha ādayaḥ
translated: “Friends” are well-wishing friends. “Relatives” are paternal and maternal uncles, nephews, etc.

original: samānapakkhā ñātayo. Tesampīti etesampi ñātimittānaṃ na katheyya, tvaṃ pana acelakassa🔽kathesi, attanova kujjhassūti dīpeti. Bhariyā ceti komārī piyabhāṇinī puttehi ca
analyzed: samāna pakkhāḥ ñātayaḥ tesam pi iti etesam pi ñāti mittānam na katheyya tvam pana acelakassa  kathesi attanā uva kujjhassu iti dīpeti bhariyā ca iti komārī piya bhāṇinī puttehi ca
translated: “He should not divulge even to them”: you, however, have divulged to the naked ascetic.🔽“Let him alone be angry”: this is what is meant.

original: rūpena ca yasena ca upetā evarūpā bhariyāpi ce “ācikkhāhi me tava guyha”nti vadeyya,
analyzed: rūpena ca yasena ca upetā evarūpā bhariyā api ce ācikkhāhi me tava guyhanti vadeyya
translated: “Even if his wife, young, sweet-voiced, endowed with children and beauty and fame, should say to him, ‘Reveal to me your secret,’

original: tassāpi na saṃseyya.
analyzed: tassa api na saṃseyya
translated: he should not divulge it to her.”

original: Tato parā –
analyzed: tatas parā
translated: The rest is clear.

original: “Na guyhamatthaṃ vivareyya, rakkheyya naṃ yathā nidhiṃ;
analyzed: na guyham attham vivareyya rakkheyya nam yathā nidhim
translated: “He should not reveal a secret, but should guard it as a treasure.

original: Na hi pātukato sādhu, guyho attho pajānatā.🔽“Thiyā guyhaṃ na saṃseyya, amittassa ca paṇḍito;
analyzed: na hi pātukato sādhu guyhaḥ atthaḥ pajānatā  thiyā guyham na saṃseyya amittassa ca paṇḍitaḥ
translated: It is not good to make it known; the wise man should keep it secret.🔽The wise man should not discuss secrets with a woman, nor with an enemy,

original: Yo cāmisena saṃhīro, hadayattheno ca yo naro.
analyzed: yaḥ ca āmisena saṃhīraḥ ca yaḥ naro
translated: Nor with one who is a flatterer, nor with one who is a tale-bearer.

original: “Guyhamatthaṃ asambuddhaṃ, sambodhayati yo naro;
analyzed: guyhamattham asambuddham sambodhayati yaḥ naraḥ
translated: The man who reveals a secret that has not been revealed by another,

original: Mantabhedabhayā tassa, dāsabhūto titikkhati.
analyzed: manta bheda bhayā tassa dāsa bhūtaḥ titikkhati
translated: Out of fear of a breach of confidence, endures as a slave.

original: “Yāvanto purisassatthaṃ, guyhaṃ jānanti mantinaṃ;
analyzed: yāvantaḥ purisassa attham guyham jānanti mantinam
translated: As many as know the secret of a man who consults,

original: Tāvanto tassa ubbegā, tasmā guyhaṃ na vissaje;
analyzed: tāvantaḥ tassa ubbegā tasmai guyham na vissaje
translated: So many are his enemies; therefore one should not reveal a secret.

original: “Vivicca bhāseyya divā rahassaṃ, rattiṃ giraṃ nātivelaṃ pamuñce;
analyzed: vivicca bhāseyya divā rahassam rattim giram na ativelam pamuñce
translated: One should speak a secret by day in a secluded place, one should not utter a word at night beyond the proper time;

original: Upassutikā hi suṇanti mantaṃ, tasmā manto khippamupeti bheda”nti. –
analyzed: upassutikāḥ hi suṇanti mantam tasmā mantaḥ khippam upeti bhedanti
translated: For eavesdroppers hear the consultation; therefore a consultation soon reaches a breach.

original: Pañca gāthā umaṅgajātake pañcapaṇḍitapañhe āvi bhavissanti.
analyzed: pañca gāthāḥ umaṅga jātake pañca paṇḍita pañhe āvi bhavissanti
translated: Five verses in the Pañcapaṇḍitapañha of the Umaggajātaka will be given below.

original: Tato parāsu –
analyzed: tatas parāsu

analyzed: yathā api assa nagaram mahantam advārakam āyasam bhadda sālam
translated: Just as a great city has no gate, is made of iron, and has excellent watch-towers,

original: Samantakhātāparikhāupetaṃ, evampi me te idha guyhamantā.
analyzed: me te idha
translated: And is surrounded by a moat dug all around, so are my secret counsels here.

analyzed: ye guyha mantāḥ a vikiṇṇa vācāḥ daḷhā sa datthesu narāḥ dujivha  ārā amittāḥ byavajanti tehi āsīvisā vā riva sattu saṅghā ati  dvīsu gāthāsu bhadda sālanti āpaṇa ādīhi sālāhi sampannam

translated: The two verses: “The prosperous” : prosperous with shops, etc. “With moats dug all around” : surrounded by three moats dug all around. “They seem to me” : they seem to me to be like this.

analyzed: katare ye idha guyhamantā idam vuttam hoti yathā advārakassa ayomaya nagarassa
translated: Which ones? “Those who keep their counsel here” . This is what is said: just as in a city of iron, without doors,🔽the enjoyment and use of the people is only inside, they do not go out outside, and those from outside

analyzed: manussānam upabhoga paribhogaḥ antarā iva hoti na abbhantarimā bahi nikkhamanti na bāhirā  antar pavisanti apara aparam sañcāraḥ chijjati guyhamantā purisāḥ evarūpāḥ honti attanaḥ

original: atthesu thirā. Dujivhāti paṇḍarakanāgaṃ ālapati. Byavajantīti paṭikkamanti. Āsīvisā
analyzed: atthesu thirā dujivhā ati paṇḍaraka nāgam ālapati byavajanti iti paṭikkamanti āsīvisā
translated: In matters of profit, they are firm. “Two-tongued” : he addresses the white-footed bird. “They turn away” : they retreat. “Like a snake” :

analyzed: vā riva sattu saṅghā ati ettha vā iti nipāta mattam āsīvisā sattu saṅghā riva ati attho
translated: Here “like” is merely a particle; the meaning is “like a snake, a group of enemies.”

original: Yathā āsīvisato sattusaṅghā jīvitukāmā manussā ārā paṭikkamanti, evaṃ tehi guyhamantehi
analyzed: yathā āsīvisataḥ sattu saṅghāḥ jīvitu kāmāḥ manussāḥ ārā paṭikkamanti evam tehi guyhamantehi
translated: Just as people who desire to live turn away from a snake, a group of enemies, so too, from those men who are concealed,

original: narehi ārā amittā paṭikkamanti, upagantuṃ okāsaṃ na labhantīti vuttaṃ hoti.
analyzed: narehi ārā amittā paṭikkamanti upagantum okāsam na labhanti iti vuttam hoti
translated: enemies turn away; they do not get an opportunity to approach. This is the meaning.

original: Evaṃ supaṇṇena dhamme kathite paṇḍarako āha –
analyzed: evam supaṇṇena dhamme kathite paṇḍarakaḥ āha
translated: When Supaṇṇa had spoken thus in terms of Dhamma, the white-footed bird said:

original: “Hitvā gharaṃ pabbajito acelo, naggo muṇḍo carati ghāsahetu;
analyzed: hitvā gharam pabbajitaḥ acelaḥ naggaḥ muṇḍaḥ carati ghāsa hetu
translated: “The naked one, having left home, gone forth, shaven-headed, wanders for the sake of food;

original: Tamhi nu kho vivariṃ guyhamatthaṃ, atthā ca dhammā ca apaggatāmhā.
analyzed: tamhi nu kho vivarim atthā ca dhammā ca apaggatā amhā
translated: In him I opened up the hidden meaning, and we have gone beyond both profit and Dhamma.

original: “Kathaṃkaro hoti supaṇṇarāja, kiṃsīlo kena vatena vattaṃ;
analyzed: kathaṃkaraḥ hoti supaṇṇa rāja kiṃsīlaḥ kena vatena vattam
translated: “How does one act, Supaṇṇa king? What is his character? By what conduct does he live?

original: Samaṇo caraṃ hitvā mamāyitāni, kathaṃkaro saggamupeti ṭhāna”nti.
analyzed: samaṇaḥ caram hitvā kathaṃkaraḥ saggam upeti
translated: The ascetic, having given up what is mine, how does he go to a place of happiness?”

original: Tattha ghāsahetūti nissiriko kucchipūraṇatthāya khādanīyabhojanīye pariyesanto carati.🔽Apaggatāmhāti apagatā parihīnāmhā. Kathaṃkaroti idaṃ nāgarājā tassa naggassa samaṇabhāvaṃ🔽ñatvā samaṇapaṭipattiṃ pucchanto āha. Tattha kiṃsīloti katarena ācārena samannāgato.
analyzed: tattha ghāsa hetu uti nissirikaḥ kucchi pūraṇa atthāya khādanīya bhojanīye pariyesanto carati  apaggatā amhā ati apagatā parihīnā amhā kathaṃkaroti idam nāga rājā tassa naggassa samaṇa bhāvam  ñatvā samaṇa paṭipattim pucchantaḥ āha tattha kiṃsīlaḥ ti katarena ācārena samannāgato
translated: Herein, for the sake of food : he goes about seeking for what is to be eaten, namely, food and drink, not for the sake of gain.🔽We have lost : we have gone away, we have fallen away.

original: Kena vatenāti katarena vatasamādānena vattanto. Samaṇo caranti pabbajjāya caranto
analyzed: kena vatena ati katarena vata samādānena vattanto samaṇo caranti pabbajjāya caranto
translated: How does he act? The king of the nāgas, having understood that the ascetic was naked, asked him about the practice of an ascetic. Herein, what is his virtue? What is his conduct? What is his undertaking of the practice of virtue? How does an ascetic go about in the practice of going forth?

original: taṇhāmamāyitāni hitvā kathaṃ samitapāpasamaṇo nāma hoti. Sagganti kathaṃ karonto
analyzed: taṇhā mamāyitāni hitvā katham samitapāpa samaṇaḥ nāma hoti katham karontaḥ
translated: Having given up craving and the state of being mine, how does one become an ascetic with passions calmed? How does one who acts thus

original: ca suṭṭhu aggaṃ devanagaraṃ so samaṇo upetīti.
analyzed: ca suṭṭhu aggam devanagaram so samaṇaḥ upeti iti
translated: reach the foremost, the highest, the city of the gods?

original: Supaṇṇo āha –
analyzed: supaṇṇaḥ āha
translated: Supaṇṇa said:

original: “Hiriyā titikkhāya damenupeto, akkodhano pesuṇiyaṃ pahāya;
analyzed: hiriyā titikkhāya damena upetaḥ akkodhanaḥ pesuṇiyam pahāya
translated: “Endowed with shame, forbearance, and self-control, free from anger and slander,

original: Samaṇo caraṃ hitvā mamāyitāni, evaṃkaro saggamupeti ṭhāna”nti.
analyzed: samaṇaḥ caram hitvā evaṃkaraḥ saggam upeti
translated: The ascetic goes about, having given up craving and the state of being mine. One who acts thus reaches the state of the gods.”

original: Tattha hiriyāti, samma nāgarāja, ajjhattabahiddhāsamuṭṭhānehi hirottappehi titikkhāsaṅkhātāya
analyzed: tattha samma nāga rāja ajjhatta bahiddhā samuṭṭhānehi hirottappehi titikkhā saṅkhātāya
translated: Herein, “modesty” is patience called “modesty” that has arisen internally and externally.

original: adhivāsanakhantiyā indriyadamena ca upeto akujjhanasīlo pisuṇavācaṃ pahāya taṇhāmamāyitāni
analyzed: adhivāsana khantiyā indriya damena ca upetaḥ a kujjhana sīlaḥ pisuṇa vācam pahāya taṇhā mamāyitāni
translated: For here, O king of snakes, the monk is endowed with shame and fear of blame, with patience and endurance, with self-control and restraint of the senses, and is free from anger. He has given up slander and is free from greed and conceit.

original: ca hitvā pabbajjāya caranto samaṇo nāma hoti, evaṃkaroyeva ca etāni hirīādīni kusalāni
analyzed: ca hitvā pabbajjāya carantaḥ samaṇaḥ nāma hoti ca etāni hirī ādīni kusalāni
translated: Having gone forth, he is called a monk. And he who does these things, which are wholesome, such as shame, etc.,

original: karonto saggamupeti ṭhānanti.
analyzed: karontaḥ saggam upeti ṭhānan ti
translated: will go to a heavenly state.

original: Idaṃ supaṇṇarājassa dhammakathaṃ sutvā paṇḍarako jīvitaṃ yācanto gāthamāha –
analyzed: idam supaṇṇa rājassa dhamma katham sutvā paṇḍarakaḥ jīvitam yācantaḥ gātham āha
translated: Having heard this discourse on the Dhamma of the king of Supaṇṇas, Paṇḍaraka, begging for his life, spoke this verse:🔽“As a mother with her tender body

original: “Mātāva puttaṃ taruṇaṃ tanujjaṃ, samphassatā sabbagattaṃ phareti;
analyzed: mātā ava puttam taruṇam tanujjam samphassatā sabba gattam phareti
translated: caresses her dear child,🔽So do you appear to me, O king of birds,

original: Evampi me tvaṃ pāturahu dijinda, mātāva puttaṃ anukampamāno”ti.
analyzed: evam pi me tvam pātu rahu dijinda mātā ava puttam anukampamānā iti
translated: with compassion like a mother for her child.”🔽The meaning is as follows: Just as a mother, seeing her tender child, born of her own body,

original: Tassattho – yathā mātā tanujaṃ attano sarīrajātaṃ taruṇaṃ puttaṃ samphassataṃ disvā
analyzed: tassa atthaḥ yathā mātā tanujam sarīra jātam taruṇam puttam disvā
translated: caressing it with her tender body,

original: taṃ ure nipajjāpetvā thaññaṃ pāyentī puttasamphassena sabbaṃ attano gattaṃ phareti,
analyzed: tam ure nipajjāpetvā thaññam pāyentī putta samphassena sabbam attanaḥ gattam phareti
translated: placing it on her lap, and giving it milk to drink, delights in the contact with her child, and her whole body is thrilled with pleasure,

original: napi mātā puttato bhāyati napi putto mātito, evampi me tvaṃ pāturahu pātubhūto dijinda
analyzed: na pi mātā puttataḥ bhāyati na pi puttaḥ mātitaḥ evam pi me tvam pātu rahu pātu bhūtaḥ dijinda
translated: Nor does the mother fear the son, nor does the son fear the mother. So be you manifest to me, manifest, O King of Birds.

original: dijarāja, tasmā mātāva puttaṃ mudukena hadayena anukampamāno maṃ passa, jīvitaṃ me dehīti.
analyzed: dija rāja tasmai mātā ava puttam mudukena hadayena anukampamānaḥ mam passa jīvitam me dehi iti
translated: O King of Birds, therefore, look on me with a tender heart, as a mother on her son, and give me my life.

original: Athassa supaṇṇo jīvitaṃ dento itaraṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: atha assa supaṇṇaḥ jīvitam dentaḥ itaram gātham āha
translated: Then Supaṇṇa, giving him his life, spoke the other verse:

original: “Handajja tvaṃ muñca vadhā dujivha, tayo hi puttā na hi añño atthi;
analyzed: handa ajja tvam muñca vadhā dujivha tayaḥ hi puttā na hi aññaḥ atthi
translated: “So today you are released from death, you double-tongued one, for there are only three sons, there is no fourth.

original: Antevāsī dinnako atrajo ca, rajjassu puttaññataro me ahosī”ti.🔽Tattha muñcāti mucca, ayameva vā pāṭho. Dujivhāti taṃ ālapati. Aññoti añño catuttho
analyzed: antevāsī dinnakaḥ atrajaḥ ca rajjassu puttaññataraḥ me ahosi iti  tattha muñca ati mucca ayam eva vā pāṭhaḥ dujivhā ti tam ālapati añño ti catuttho
translated: The pupil, the adopted son, and the son born of the mother’s body, be you the other son to me.”

original: putto nāma natthi. Antevāsīti sippaṃ vā uggaṇhamāno pañhaṃ vā suṇanto santike nivuttho.
analyzed: puttaḥ nāma natthi antevāsī iti sippam vā uggaṇhamānaḥ pañham vā suṇantaḥ santike nivutthaḥ
translated: Herein, muñcā ti is the reading. Dujivhāti he addresses him. Añño ti there is no other fourth son. Antevāsī ti he is one who lives near, learning a craft or listening to a question.

original: Dinnakoti “ayaṃ te putto hotū”ti parehi dinno. Rajjassūti abhiramassu. Aññataroti
analyzed: dinnakaḥ uti ayam te putto hotu uti parehi dinnaḥ rajjassu iti abhiramassu aññatarā ti
translated: Dinnako ti he is given by others, saying “Let this be your son.” Rajjassū ti be you pleased. Aññataro ti

original: tīsu puttesu aññataro antevāsī putto me tvaṃ jātoti dīpeti.
analyzed: tīsu puttesu aññataraḥ antevāsī puttaḥ me tvam jātaḥ iti dīpeti
translated: among the three sons, the other son, the pupil, is born to me as your son.

original: Evañca pana vatvā ākāsā otaritvā taṃ bhūmiyaṃ patiṭṭhāpesi. Tamatthaṃ pakāsento satthā dve gāthā abhāsi –
analyzed: evam ca pana vatvā ākāsā otaritvā tam bhūmiyam patiṭṭhāpesi tam attham pakāsento satthā dve gāthāḥ abhāsi
translated: Having thus spoken, he descended from the air and set him on the ground. Expounding this matter, the Master pronounced the following Stanzas,

original: “Icceva vākyaṃ visajjī supaṇṇo, bhumyaṃ patiṭṭhāya dijo dujivhaṃ;
analyzed: iccā iva vākyam visajjī su paṇṇaḥ bhumyam patiṭṭhāya dijaḥ dujivham
translated: Even thus did Supaṇṇa set him free, and the bird, having set him on the ground, addressed the serpent, saying,

original: Muttajja tvaṃ sabbabhayātivatto, thalūdake hohi mayābhigutto.
analyzed: tvam sabba bhaya ativattaḥ thalūdake hohi mayā abhiguttaḥ
translated: “To-day thou art delivered from all fear; I have protected thee, both on the land and in the water.

original: “Ātaṅkinaṃ yathā kusalo bhisakko, pipāsitānaṃ rahadova sīto;
analyzed: ātaṅkinam yathā kusalaḥ bhisakkaḥ pipāsitānam rahadā uva sīto
translated: Even as a skillful physician is to those who are afflicted with disease, even as a cool lake is to those who are athirst,

original: Vesmaṃ yathā himasītaṭṭitānaṃ, evampi te saraṇamahaṃ bhavāmī”ti.
analyzed: yathā evam pi te saraṇam aham bhavāmi iti
translated: Even as a house is to those who are shivering with cold, even so am I to thee a refuge.”

original: Tattha icceva vākyanti iti evaṃ vacanaṃ vatvā taṃ nāgarājaṃ vissajji. Bhumyanti so🔽sayampi bhūmiyaṃ patiṭṭhāya dijo taṃ dujivhaṃ samassāsento mutto ajja tvaṃ ito paṭṭhāya
analyzed: tattha iti evam vacanam vatvā tam nāga rājam vissajji saḥ  sayam pi bhūmiyam patiṭṭhāya dijaḥ tam dujivham samassāsentaḥ muttaḥ ajja tvam itas paṭṭhāya
translated: Herein, even thus did Supaṇṇa set him free: having thus spoken, he set him free. On the ground:

original: sabbabhayāni ativatto thale ca udake ca mayā abhigutto rakkhito hohīti āha. Ātaṅkinanti
analyzed: sabba bhayāni ativatto thale ca udake ca mayā abhiguttaḥ rakkhitaḥ hohi iti āha ātaṅkinanti
translated: having set him on the ground, the bird addressed the serpent, saying, “To-day thou art delivered from all fear. From this time forth, both on the land and in the water, I have protected thee, I have guarded thee.” Those who are afflicted with disease:

original: gilānānaṃ. Evampi teti evaṃ ahaṃ tava saraṇaṃ bhavāmi.
analyzed: evam pi te iti evam aham tava saraṇam bhavāmi
translated: those who are sick. Even so am I to thee a refuge: even so am I a refuge to thee.

original: Gaccha tvanti uyyojesi. So nāgarājā nāgabhavanaṃ pāvisi. Itaropi supaṇṇabhavanaṃ🔽gantvā “mayā paṇḍarakanāgo sapathaṃ katvā saddahāpetvā vissajjito, kīdisaṃ nu kho
analyzed: gaccha tvanti uyyojesi saḥ nāga rājā nāga bhavanam pāvisi itaraḥ api supaṇṇa bhavanam  gantvā mayā paṇḍaraka nāgaḥ sa patham katvā saddahāpetvā vissajjitaḥ kīdisam nu kho
translated: “Go, then,” he said, and dismissed him. The king of the nāgas entered his nāga-palace, and the king of the supaṇṇas went to his supaṇṇa-palace.

original: mayi tassa hadayaṃ, vīmaṃsissāmi na”nti nāgabhavanaṃ gantvā supaṇṇavātaṃ akāsi. Taṃ🔽disvā nāgo “supaṇṇarājā maṃ gahetuṃ āgato bhavissatī”ti maññamāno byāmasahassamattaṃ
analyzed: mayi tassa hadayam vīmaṃsissāmi nanti nāga bhavanam gantvā supaṇṇa vātam tam  disvā nāgaḥ supaṇṇa rājā mam gahetum āgataḥ bhavissati iti maññamānaḥ byāma sahassa mattam
translated: “I made the white nāga swear an oath, and then I let him go. What sort of a heart has he for me? I will test him.” So he went to the nāga-palace and made a supaṇṇa-wind.

original: attabhāvaṃ māpetvā pāsāṇe ca vālukañca gilitvā bhāriyo hutvā naṅguṭṭhaṃ heṭṭhākatvā
analyzed: atta bhāvam māpetvā pāsāṇe ca vālukam ca gilitvā bhāriyaḥ hutvā naṅguṭṭham heṭṭhā katvā
translated: Seeing that, the nāga thought, “The king of the supaṇṇas has come to seize me.” He assumed a body a thousand leagues long, swallowed stones and sand, became heavy, put his tail under his body,

original: bhogamatthake phaṇaṃ dhārayamāno nipajjitvā supaṇṇarājānaṃ ḍaṃsitukāmo viya ahosi.
analyzed: bhoga matthake phaṇam dhārayamānaḥ nipajjitvā supaṇṇa rājānam ḍaṃsitu kāmaḥ viya ahosi
translated: and lay down with his hood on his back, as if he were eager to frighten the king of the supaṇṇas.

original: Taṃ disvā supaṇṇo itaraṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: tam disvā supaṇṇaḥ itaram gātham āha
translated: Seeing him, the supaṇṇa said the second stanza:🔽Sandhi, having made peace with an enemy,

original: “Sandhiṃ katvā amittena, aṇḍajena jalābuja;
analyzed: sandhim katvā amittena aṇḍa jena jalābu ja
translated: Aṇḍaja, born from the egg, Jalābuja, born from the womb,

original: Vivariya dāṭhaṃ sesi, kuto taṃ bhayamāgata”nti.
analyzed: vivariya sesi kutas tam bhayam āgatanti
translated: You lie with your mouth open; whence comes your fear?

original: Taṃ sutvā nāgarājā tisso gāthā abhāsi –
analyzed: tam sutvā nāga rājā tissaḥ gāthāḥ abhāsi
translated: Hearing this, the king of the nāgas spoke three stanzas:

original: “Saṅketheva amittasmiṃ, mittasmimpi na vissase;
analyzed: saṅketha iva amittasmin mittasmin pi na
translated: “In a foe who is a friend in disguise, One should not put one’s trust,

original: Abhayā bhayamuppannaṃ, api mūlāni kantati.
analyzed: abhayā bhayam uppannam api mūlāni kantati
translated: For fear may arise from a place of safety, And even the roots may be cut off.”

original: “Kathaṃ nu vissase tyamhi, yenāsi kalaho kato;
analyzed: katham nu vissase tyamhi yena asi kalahaḥ kataḥ
translated: “How can I trust you, since you have caused a quarrel?

original: Niccayattena ṭhātabbaṃ, so disabbhi na rajjati.
analyzed: nicca yattena ṭhātabbam so disabbhi na rajjati
translated: One should stand firm in one’s resolve, And not be swayed by the directions.”

original: “Vissāsaye na ca taṃ vissayeyya, asaṅkito saṅkito ca bhaveyya;
analyzed: vissāsaye na ca tam vissayeyya a saṅkitaḥ saṅkitaḥ ca bhaveyya
translated: “One should not trust one who should not be trusted, And one should be suspicious even of one who should be trusted.

original: Tathā tathā viññū parakkameyya, yathā yathā bhāvaṃ paro na jaññā”ti.
analyzed: tathā tathā viññū parakkameyya yathā yathā bhāvam paraḥ na jaññāti
translated: The wise one should act in such a way That the other will not know his thoughts.”

original: Tattha abhayāti abhayaṭṭhānabhūtā mittamhā bhayaṃ uppannaṃ jīvitasaṅkhātāni mūlāneva
analyzed: tattha abhayā ati abhaya ṭṭhāna bhūtā mittamhā bhayam uppannam jīvita saṅkhātāni mūlāni eva
translated: Herein, from a place of safety means from a friend. Fear may arise and even the roots, that is, the life, may be cut off.🔽You means in you. Since you have caused a quarrel means since you have caused a quarrel with someone.

original: kantati. Tyamhīti tasmiṃ. Yenāsīti yena saddhiṃ kalaho kato ahosi. Niccayattenāti🔽niccapaṭiyattena. So disabbhi na rajjatīti yo niccayattena abhitiṭṭhati, so attano
analyzed: tyamhi iti tasmin yena asi iti yena saddhim kalahaḥ kataḥ ahosi niccayattena ati  nicca paṭiyattena saḥ disabbhi na rajjati iti yaḥ nicca yattena abhitiṭṭhati saḥ attanaḥ
translated: One should stand firm in one’s resolve means one should stand firm in one’s resolve.🔽And not be swayed by the directions means one who stands firm in one’s resolve is not swayed by the directions, that is, by the eight worldly conditions.

original: sattūhi saddhiṃ vissāsavasena na rajjati, tato tesaṃ yathākāmakaraṇīyo na hotīti
analyzed: sattūhi saddhim vissāsa vasena na rajjati tatas tesam yathākāma karaṇīyaḥ na hoti iti
translated: He is not to be swayed by the directions, that is, by the eight worldly conditions. He is not to be swayed by the directions, that is, by the eight worldly conditions. He is not to be swayed by the directions, that is, by the eight worldly conditions. He is not to be swayed by the directions, that is, by the eight worldly conditions. original: attho. Vissāsayeti paraṃ attani vissāsaye, taṃ pana sayaṃ na vissaseyya. Parena asaṅkito
analyzed: atthaḥ vissāsaya iti param attani vissāsaye tam pana sayam na vissaseyya parena a saṅkitaḥ
translated: Attha. Vissāsaye means: one should inspire confidence in others, but one should not oneself be confiding. Parena asaṅkito means: one should not be known by others.

original: attanā ca so saṅkito bhaveyya. Bhāvaṃ paroti yathā yathā paṇḍito parakkamati, tathā
analyzed: attanā ca saḥ saṅkitaḥ bhaveyya bhāvam paroti yathā yathā paṇḍitaḥ parakkamati tathā
translated: Bhāvaṃ paroti yathā yathā a wise man advances, so so

original: tathā tassa paro bhāvaṃ na jānāti, tasmā paṇḍitena vīriyaṃ kātabbamevāti dīpeti.
analyzed: tathā tassa paraḥ bhāvam na jānāti tasmā paṇḍitena vīriyam kātabbam eva ati dīpeti
translated: others do not know his state. Therefore, the wise man should exert himself.

original: Iti te aññamaññaṃ sallapitvā samaggā sammodamānā ubhopi acelakassa assamaṃ agamiṃsu. Tamatthaṃ pakāsento satthā āha –
analyzed: iti te aññamaññam sallapitvā samaggā sammodamānā ubho pi acelakassa assamam agamiṃsu tam attham pakāsentaḥ satthā āha
translated: Thus, having spoken to each other, they both went to the hermitage of the naked ascetic, in harmony and in good spirits. Explaining that matter, the Teacher said:

original: “Te devavaṇṇā sukhumālarūpā, ubho samā sujayā puññakhandhā;
analyzed: te deva vaṇṇā sukhumāla rūpā ubho samā su jayā puñña khandhā
translated: “They, of divine appearance, of delicate form, both equal, well-born, heaps of merit,

original: Upāgamuṃ karampiyaṃ acelaṃ, missībhūtā assavāhāva nāgā”ti.
analyzed: upāgamum karampiyam acelam missībhūtāḥ assavāhā ava nāgā ti
translated: approached the naked ascetic Karampiya, mixed like horses and elephants in a horse-race.”

original: Tattha samāti samānarūpā sadisasaṇṭhānā hutvā. Sujayāti suvayā parisuddhā, ayameva
analyzed: tattha samā ati samāna rūpā sadisa saṇṭhānā hutvā sujayā ati suvayā parisuddhā ayam eva
translated: There, samā means: having become of equal appearance, of similar shape. Sujayā means: well-born, pure. This is

original: vā pāṭho. Puññakhandhāti katakusalatāya puññakkhandhā viya. Missībhūtāti hatthena
analyzed: vā pāṭhaḥ puñña khandhā ati kata kusala tāya puñña kkhandhā viya missībhūtā ati hatthena
translated: the reading. Puññakkhandhā means: like heaps of merit due to their past good deeds. Missībhūtā means: with their hands

original: hatthaṃ gahetvā kāyamissībhāvaṃ upagatā. Assavāhāva nāgāti dhure yuttakā rathavāhā
analyzed: hattham gahetvā kāya missībhāvam upagatāḥ assa vāhāḥ ava nāgāḥ ti dhure yuttakāḥ ratha vāhāḥ
translated: and took hold of his hand, and so came into close contact with his body.

original: dve assā viya purisanāgā tassa assamaṃ agamiṃsu.
analyzed: dve assā viya purisa nāgā tassa assamam agamiṃsu
translated: Just as two horses harnessed to a chariot come to the chariot, so did the two men come to the hermitage.

original: Gantvā ca pana supaṇṇarājā cintesi – “ayaṃ nāgarājā acelakassa jīvitaṃ na dassati,
analyzed: gantvā ca pana supaṇṇa rājā cintesi ayam nāga rājā acelakassa jīvitam na dassati
translated: When the king of the Supaṇṇas had gone there, he thought to himself, “This king of the Nāgas will not give up the life of the naked ascetic;

original: etaṃ dussīlaṃ na vandissāmī”ti. So bahi ṭhatvā nāgarājānameva tassa santikaṃ pesesi.
analyzed: etam dussīlam na vandissāmi iti saḥ bahi ṭhatvā nāga rājānam eva tassa santikam pesesi
translated: I will not pay homage to this wicked man.” So he remained outside and sent the king of the Nāgas to the naked ascetic.

original: Taṃ sandhāya satthā itaraṃ gāthamāha.
analyzed: tam sandhāya satthā itaram gātham āha
translated: With reference to this, the Teacher recited the second stanza,

original: “Tato have paṇḍarako acelaṃ, sayamevupāgamma idaṃ avoca;
analyzed: tatas have paṇḍarakaḥ acelam sayam eva upāgamma idam avoca
translated: “Then Paṇḍaraka himself went to the naked ascetic and said,

original: Muttajjahaṃ sabbabhayātivatto, na hi nūna tuyhaṃ manaso piyamhā”ti.
analyzed: sabba bhaya ativattaḥ na hi nūna tuyham manasaḥ
translated: ‘I am free from all fear, O you who are born of an egg; surely you are not dear to his heart.’

original: Tattha piyamhāti dussīlanaggabhoggamusāvādi nūna mayaṃ tava manaso na piyā ahumhāti paribhāsi.
analyzed: tattha dussīla nagga bhogga musāvādi nūna mayam tava manasaḥ na piyāḥ ahumha iti paribhāsi
translated: Here it is said, “Surely we are not dear to his heart,” and he reviled the king of the Nāgas, who was wicked and a liar and a lord of evil conduct.

original: Tato acelo itaraṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: tatas acelaḥ itaram gātham āha
translated: Then the naked ascetic recited the third stanza,

original: “Piyo hi me āsi supaṇṇarājā, asaṃsayaṃ paṇḍarakena saccaṃ;
analyzed: piyaḥ hi me āsi supaṇṇa rājā asaṃsayam paṇḍarakena saccam
translated: “The king of the Supaṇṇas was dear to me, and Paṇḍaraka spoke the truth without doubt;

original: So rāgarattova akāsimetaṃ, pāpakammaṃ sampajāno na mohā”ti.
analyzed: saḥ rāga rattaḥ uva akāsim etam pāpa kammam sampajānaḥ na
translated: He, in love with the fair one, did this evil deed, Knowing it, not through delusion.

original: Tattha paṇḍarakenāti tayā paṇḍarakena so mama piyataro ahosi, saccametaṃ. Soti so ahaṃ tasmiṃ supaṇṇe rāgena ratto hutvā etaṃ pāpakammaṃ jānantova akāsiṃ, na mohena ajānantoti.
analyzed: tattha paṇḍarakena ati tayā paṇḍarakena so mama piyataraḥ ahosi saccam etam saḥ iti saḥ aham tasmin supaṇṇe rāgena rattaḥ hutvā etam pāpa kammam jānantaḥ iva akāsim na mohena a jānantaḥ iti
translated: Herein, with the fair one : with you, the fair one, he was dearer to me, this is true. He : I, in love with the fair one, the bird, did this evil deed knowing it, not through delusion, not unknowing.

original: Taṃ sutvā nāgarājā dve gāthā abhāsi –
analyzed: tam sutvā nāga rājā dve gāthāḥ abhāsi
translated: On hearing this, the king of the nagas spoke two stanzas:

original: “Na me piyaṃ appiyaṃ vāpi hoti, sampassato lokamimaṃ parañca;
analyzed: na me piyam appiyam vā api hoti sampassataḥ lokam imam param ca
translated: I have neither dear nor yet undear, Beholding this world and the world beyond.

original: Susaññatānañhi viyañjanena, asaññato lokamimaṃ carāsi.
analyzed: su saññatā anañhi viyañjanena asaññataḥ lokam imam carāsi
translated: For, though well-controlled in outward show, Uncontrolled, you wander through this world.

original: “Ariyāvakāsosi anariyovāsi, asaññato saññatasannikāso;
analyzed: ariya avakāsaḥ asi an ariya uvā asi asaññataḥ saññata sannikāsaḥ
translated: You are a noble’s opportunity, yet live a low-down life, Uncontrolled, with the outward show of self-control.

original: Kaṇhābhijātikosi anariyarūpo, pāpaṃ bahuṃ duccaritaṃ acārī”ti.🔽Tattha na meti ambho dussīlanaggamusāvādi pabbajitassa hi imañca parañca lokaṃ sampassato
analyzed: kaṇha abhijātikaḥ asi an ariya rūpaḥ pāpam bahum duccaritam acāri iti  tattha na mā iti ambhaḥ dussīla nagga musāvādi pabbajitassa hi iman ca paran ca lokan sampassato
translated: You are of dark-born stock, of ignoble form, And have done much evil, much wrong-doing.🔽Herein, I have neither dear nor undear : for one gone forth, O you of evil conduct and false speech, who beholds this world and the world beyond,

original: piyaṃ vā me appiyaṃ vāpi meti na hoti, tvaṃ pana susaññatānaṃ sīlavantānaṃ byañjanena
analyzed: piyam vā me appiyam vā api me iti na hoti tvam pana su saññatānam sīlavantānam byañjanena
translated: I have neither dear nor undear. But you, with the outward show of self-control,

original: pabbajitaliṅgena asaññato hutvā imaṃ lokaṃ vañcento carasi. Ariyāvakāsosīti ariyapaṭirūpakosi.
analyzed: pabbajita liṅgena asaññataḥ hutvā imam lokam vañcento carasi ariya avakāso asi iti ariya paṭirūpakaḥ asi
translated: You are a deceiver of the world, going about in the guise of one gone forth. You are a counterfeit noble one.

original: Asaññatoti kāyādīhi asaññatosi. Kaṇhābhijātikoti kāḷakasabhāvo. Anariyarūpoti ahirikasabhāvo. Acārīti akāsi.
analyzed: asaññataḥ ti kāya ādīhi asaññataḥ asi kaṇha abhijātikaḥ iti kāḷaka sabhāvaḥ anariya rūpaḥ iti ahirika sabhāvaḥ acāri iti akāsi
translated: You are not restrained. You are not restrained in body, speech, and mind. You are of black birth. You are of a black nature. You are of an unashamed nature. You have acted.

original: Iti taṃ garahitvā idāni abhisapanto imaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: iti tam gara hitvā idāni abhisapantaḥ imam gātham āha
translated: Having thus rebuked him, he now spoke this verse in order to curse him:

original: “Aduṭṭhassa tuvaṃ dubbhi, dubbhī ca pisuṇo casi;
analyzed: a duṭṭhassa tuvam dubbhi dubbhī ca pisuṇaḥ casi
translated: “You are a slanderer of the innocent, and a slanderer of the good.

original: Etena saccavajjena, muddhā te phalatu sattadhā”ti.
analyzed: etena sacca vajjena muddhā te phalatu sattadhā ati
translated: By this truth, may your head split into seven pieces!”

original: Tassattho – ambho dubbhi tvaṃ aduṭṭhassa mittassa dubbhī cāsi, pisuṇo cāsi, etena saccavajjena muddhā te sattadhā phalatūti.
analyzed: tassa atthaḥ ambho dubbhi tvam aduṭṭhassa mittassa dubbhī ca asi pisuṇaḥ ca asi etena sacca vajjena muddhā te sattadhā phalatu iti
translated: The meaning is: “Hey slanderer, you are a slanderer of an innocent friend, and a slanderer of the good. By this truth, may your head split into seven pieces!”

original: Iti nāgarājassa sapantasseva acelakassa sīsaṃ sattadhā phali. Nisinnaṭṭhāneyevassa
analyzed: iti nāga rājassa sapantassa iva acelakassa sīsam sattadhā phali
translated: Thus the head of the naked ascetic, who was the king of the nāgas, split into seven pieces right there where he was sitting.

original: bhūmi vivaraṃ adāsi. So pathaviṃ pavisitvā avīcimhi nibbatti, nāgarājasupaṇṇarājānopi
analyzed: bhūmi vivaram adāsi saḥ pathavim pavisitvā avīcimhi nibbatti nāga rāja supaṇṇa rājāno api
translated: The earth opened up and he fell into Avīci Hell. The nāga kings and garuḍa kings

original: attano bhavanameva agamiṃsu. Satthā tassa pathaviṃ paviṭṭhabhāvaṃ pakāsento osānagāthamāha –
analyzed: attanaḥ bhavanam eva agamiṃsu satthā tassa pathavim paviṭṭha bhāvam pakāsento osāna gātham āha
translated: and returned to their own abodes. The Teacher, in order to make known the fact that the king had entered the earth, pronounced the following Stanza,

original: “Tasmā hi mittānaṃ na dubbhitabbaṃ, mittadubbhā pāpiyo natthi añño;
analyzed: tasmā hi mittānam na dubbhitabbam mitta dubbhā pāpiyaḥ natthi aññaḥ
translated: Therefore one should not offend his friends; there is no greater sin than the sin of offending a friend.

original: Āsittasatto nihato pathabyā, indassa vākyena hi saṃvaro hato”ti.
analyzed: āsittasattaḥ nihataḥ pathabyāḥ indassa vākyena hi saṃvaraḥ hataḥ iti
translated: The king who had been fed was slain by the earth; Saṃvara was slain by the word of Indra.

original: Tattha tasmāti yasmā mittadubbhikammassa pharuso vipāko, tasmā. Āsittasattoti āsittavisena
analyzed: tattha tasmā iti yasmai mitta dubbhi kammassa pharusaḥ vipākaḥ tasmai āsitta satto ti āsitta visena
translated: Herein, therefore, means because the fruit of the sin of offending a friend is so terrible. The king who had been fed means the king who had been fed with poison.

original: satto. Indassāti nāgindassa vākyena. Saṃvaroti “ahaṃ saṃvare ṭhitosmī”ti paṭiññāya
analyzed: satto indassa ati nāgindassa vākyena aham saṃvare ṭhitaḥ asmi iti paṭiññāya
translated: By the word of Indra means by the word of the king of the Nāgas.

original: evaṃ paññāto ājīvako hatoti.🔽Satthā imaṃ dhammadesanaṃ āharitvā “na, bhikkhave, idāneva, pubbepi devadatto musāvādaṃ🔽katvā pathaviṃ paviṭṭhoyevā”ti vatvā jātakaṃ samodhānesi – “tadā acelako devadatto
analyzed: evam paññātaḥ ājīvakaḥ hato ti  satthā imam dhamma desanam āharitvā na bhikkhave idānā iva pubbe pi devadatto musāvādam  katvā pathavim paviṭṭhaḥ yā iva iti vatvā jātakam samodhānesi tadā acelakaḥ devadattaḥ
translated: Saṃvara means the Ājīvaka who was known as “Saṃvara.”

original: ahosi, nāgarājā sāriputto, supaṇṇarājā pana ahameva ahosi”nti.
analyzed: ahosi nāga rājā sāriputto supaṇṇa rājā pana aham eva ahosinti
translated: The Teacher, having related this Dhamma, said, “Monks, this was not the first time Devadatta did this; in a previous state of existence also he entered the earth through lying.” So saying, he related a Jātaka of the past: “At that time the naked ascetic was Devadatta, the king of the Nāgas was Sāriputta, and I myself was the king of the Supaṇṇas.”

original: Paṇḍaranāgarājajātakavaṇṇanā aṭṭhamā.
analyzed: paṇḍara nāga rāja jātaka vaṇṇanā aṭṭhamā
translated: The Story of the White King of Elephants.

original: [519] 9. Sambulājātakavaṇṇanā
analyzed: rohita jātaka vaṇṇanā
translated: The Sambhulā Birth Story

original: Kā vedhamānāti idaṃ satthā jetavane viharanto mallikaṃ deviṃ ārabbha kathesi. Vatthu
analyzed: kā vedhamānā iti idam satthā jetavane viharantaḥ mallikam devim ārabbha kathesi vatthu
translated: “Who is it that is being pierced?” The Master told this story while dwelling at Jetavana, about Queen Mallikā.

original: kummāsapiṇḍijātake vitthāritameva. Sā pana tathāgatassa tiṇṇaṃ kummāsapiṇḍikānaṃ🔽dānānubhāvena taṃ divasaññeva rañño aggamahesibhāvaṃ patvā pubbuṭṭhāyitādīhi pañcahi
analyzed: kummāsa piṇḍi jātake vitthāritam eva sā pana tathāgatassa tiṇṇam kummāsa piṇḍikānaṃ  dāna anubhāvena tam divasaññā iva raññaḥ agga mahesi bhāvam patvā pubbuṭṭhāyi tā ādīhi pañcahi
translated: The story is related in the Kummāsapiṇḍi Birth Story.🔽But by the power of her gift of three piṇḍas of boiled rice to the Tathāgata, she became that very day the chief queen of the king.

original: kalyāṇadhammehi samannāgatā ñāṇasampannā buddhupaṭṭhāyikā patidevatā ahosi. Tassā
analyzed: kalyāṇa dhammehi samannāgatā ñāṇa sampannā buddha upaṭṭhāyikā pati devatā ahosi tassā

analyzed: āvuso mallikā devī kira vatta sampannā ñāṇa sampannā pati devatā iti satthā āgantvā
translated: “Brethren, Queen Mallikā is faithful to her husband, wise, and a faithful wife.” The Master came in and asked🔽them, “Monks, what is it that you are sitting here now talking about?” When they told him,

analyzed: na bhikkhave idānā iva pubbepesā vatta sampannā pati devatāya iva ati vatvā atītam āhari  atīte bārāṇasiyam brahmadattassa rañño sotthisenaḥ nāma putto ahosi tam rājā vaya ppattam
translated: “Monks, this is not the first time she has been well-spoken; she was also well-spoken in the past.” Then he told an old story:

analyzed: uparajje patiṭṭhapesi sambulā nāmassa agga mahesī ahosi uttama rūpa dharā sarīra ppabhā sampannā 🔽nivāte jalamānā dīpa sikhā viya khāyati aparabhāge sotthisenassa sarīre kuṭṭham uppajjati 🔽vejjā tikicchitum na asakkhiṃsu saḥ bhijjamāne kuṭṭhe paṭikūlaḥ hutvā vippaṭisāram patvā 🔽kaḥ me rajjena atthaḥ araññe anātha maraṇam marissāmi iti raññaḥ ārocāpetvā itthāgāram 🔽chaḍḍetvā nikkhami sambulā bahūhi upāyehi nivattiyamānā api a nivattitvā ava aham taṃ 🔽sāmikam araññe paṭijaggissāmi iti vatvā saddhiññā iva nikkhami saḥ araññam pavisitvā
translated: “Monks, this is not the first time she has been faithful to me; she was also faithful to me in the past.” With this he told an old tale.

original: sulabhamūlaphalāphale chāyūdakasampanne padese paṇṇasālaṃ katvā vāsaṃ kappesi. Rājadhītā
analyzed: sulabha mūla phala aphale chāyu udaka sampanne padese paṇṇasālam katvā vāsam kappesi rāja dhītā

analyzed: upaṭṭhapetvā danta kaṭṭhañca mukha dhovanañca upanāmetvā mukhe dhote nānā osadhāni pisitvā

analyzed: tassa vaṇe makkhetvā madhura madhurāni phala aphalāni khādāpetvā mukham vikkhāletvā  hatthesu dhotesu appamattaḥ hohi deva iti vatvā vanditvā pacchi khaṇitti aṅkusake ādāya

analyzed: udakam āharitvā nānā cuṇṇehi ca mattikāhi ca sotthi senam nhāpetvā punar madhura phala aphalāni 🔽upanāma iti paribhoga avasāne vāsita pānīyam upanetvā sayam phala a phalāni paribhuñjitvā
translated: and bathed his wound with warm water mixed with various powders and clay. Then she gave him various sweet fruits to eat.🔽After he had eaten, she gave him perfumed water to drink. Then she ate some fruits herself and

analyzed: nhatvā sudhota sarīrā uttaritvā vāka cīram nivāsetvā kandara tīre aṭṭhāsi athassā sarīra ppabhāya

analyzed: vanam ekobhāsam ahosi tasmin khaṇe ekaḥ dānavaḥ gocara tthāya carantaḥ tam disvā paṭibaddha citto

original: hutvā gāthādvayaṃ āha –
analyzed: hutvā gāthā dvayam āha
translated: He made a fire, and spoke two verses:

original: “Kā vedhamānā girikandarāyaṃ, ekā tuvaṃ tiṭṭhasi saṃhitūru;
analyzed: kā vedhamānā giri kandarāyam ekā tuvam tiṭṭhasi

translated: You are in the middle of my arms. Tell me your name and your family.”🔽“I am a human, a woman, a wife, a slave, a servant, a slave-woman. I am a human, a woman, a wife, a slave, a servant, a slave-woman.”

original: “Obhāsayaṃ vanaṃ rammaṃ, sīhabyagghanisevitaṃ;
analyzed: obhāsayam vanam rammam sīha byaggha nisevitam
translated: “You illuminate this lovely wood, frequented by lions and tigers;

Pāṇipameyyamajjheti hatthena minitabbamajjhe. Kā vā tvanti kā🔽nāma vā tvaṃ bhavasi. Abhivādemīti vandāmi. Dānavāhanti ahaṃ eko dānavo, ayaṃ namakkāro
analyzed: abhivādemi tam bhadde dānava aham namatthu te iti  tattha kā vedhamānā iti nhāna matta tāya sīta bhāvena kampamānā saṃhitūru iti sampiṇḍitūru  uttama ūru lakkhaṇe pāṇi pameyya majjhe ti hatthena minitabba majjhe kā vā kā  nāma vā tvam bhavasi abhivādemi iti vandāmi aham ekaḥ dānavaḥ ayam
translated: I pay homage to you, blessed one; may you be honored by the Dānavas.”

original: tava atthu, añjaliṃ te paggaṇhāmīti avaca.
analyzed: tava atthu añjalim te paggaṇhāmi iti avaca
translated: Here, “what are you” means “shaking” due to the cold from just bathing. “With well-rounded thighs” means with thighs having the characteristic of an excellent thigh. “With a waist that can be measured with the hand” means with a waist that can be measured with the hand. “What are you” means “what is your name?” “I pay homage” means “I pay respect.” “Dānava” means “I am a single Dānava.” This “namakāra” is your “atthu,” I raise my hands in añjali to you.

original: Sā tassa vacanaṃ sutvā tisso gāthā abhāsi –
analyzed: sā tassa vacanam sutvā tissaḥ gāthāḥ abhāsi
translated: Having heard his words, she spoke three verses:

original: “Yo putto kāsirājassa, sotthisenoti taṃ vidū;
analyzed: yaḥ putto kāsi rājassa sotthisenaḥ ti tam vidū
translated: “He who is the son of the king of Kāsi, known as Sotthisena;

translated: I am his wife Sambulā, know this, Dānava;

analyzed: abhivādemi tam bhante sambula aham namatthu te
translated: I pay homage to you, venerable one; I am Sambulā, may you be honored by me.

original: “Vedehaputto bhaddante, vane vasati āturo;
analyzed: vedeha puttaḥ bhaddante vane vasati āturaḥ
translated: “The son of the king of Videha, venerable one, lives in the forest, sick;

original: Tamahaṃ rogasammattaṃ, ekā ekaṃ upaṭṭhahaṃ.
analyzed: tam aham roga sammattam ekā ekam upaṭṭhaham
translated: When he was sick and suffering.🔽“When I brought him honey and meat

original: “Ahañca vanamuñchāya, madhumaṃsaṃ migābilaṃ;
analyzed: aham ca vanamuñchāya madhu maṃsam migā bilam
translated: From the deer-park, he ate it all.

original: Yadāharāmi taṃ bhakkho, tassa nūnajja nādhatī”ti.🔽Tattha vedehaputtoti vedeharājadhītāya putto. Rogasammattanti rogapīḷitaṃ. Upaṭṭhahanti🔽upaṭṭhahāmi paṭijaggāmi. “Upaṭṭhitā”tipi pāṭho. Vanamuñchāyāti vanaṃ uñchetvā uñchācariyaṃ🔽caritvā. Madhumaṃsanti nimmakkhikaṃ madhuñca migābilamaṃsañca sīhabyagghamigehi khāditamaṃsato
analyzed: yadā āharāmi tam bhakkhaḥ tassa nūnajja na ādhati iti  tattha vedeha putto ti vedeha rāja dhītāya putto roga sammattam ti roga pīḷitam upaṭṭhahanti  upaṭṭhahāmi paṭijaggāmi upaṭṭhita atipi pāṭhaḥ vanam uñchāya ati vanam uñchetvā uñchā cariyam  caritvā madhu maṃsanti nimmakkhikam madhuñca migābila maṃsañca sīha byaggha migehi khādita maṃsataḥ
translated: But now he does not eat at all.”

original: atirittakoṭṭhāsaṃ. Taṃ bhakkhoti yaṃ ahaṃ āharāmi, taṃ bhakkhova so mama sāmiko.🔽Tassa nūnajjāti tassa maññe ajja āhāraṃ alabhamānassa sarīraṃ ātape pakkhittapadumaṃ
analyzed: atiritta koṭṭhāsam tam bhakkho ti yam aham āharāmi tam bhakkho uva saḥ mama sāmiko  tassa nūnajjāti tassa maññe ajja āhāram a labhamānassa sarīram ātape pakkhitta padumam
translated: Herein, the son of the king of Videha is the son of the king of Videha’s daughter. Sick and suffering: afflicted by sickness. I tended him: I tended him, I looked after him. The reading “Upaṭṭhitā” is also correct. When I brought him honey and meat: when I brought him honey free from flies and a lump of meat left over from the lions, tigers, and deer that had eaten it, from the deer-park. He ate it all: whatever I brought, he ate it all. He was my husband.

original: viya nādhati upatappati milāyati.
analyzed: viya nādhati upatappati milāyati
translated: But now he does not eat at all: I think that today, not getting any food, his body does not hold up, does not endure, but withers away like a lotus cut from its stalk and laid out in the sun.

original: Tato paraṃ dānavassa ca tassā ca vacanapaṭivacanagāthāyo honti –
analyzed: tato param dānavassa ca tassā ca vacana paṭivacana gāthāyaḥ honti
translated: From here on are the verses of the reply by the brahmin student and his wife.

original: “Kiṃ vane rājaputtena, āturena karissasi;
analyzed: kim vane rāja puttena āturena karissasi
translated: “What will you do with a prince in the forest, who is sick?

original: Sambule pariciṇṇena, ahaṃ bhattā bhavāmi te.

translated: I am your slave, Samudda, who has been well-served by you.

translated: Be the best of them, who is successful in all her desires.

analyzed: nūna tāraka vaṇṇa ābhe yam kiñci manasi icchasi
translated: “Surely, you who are radiant like the stars, whatever you desire in your mind,

analyzed: sabbam tam pacuram mayham ramassu ajja mayā saha
translated: All that is at your disposal, enjoy yourself with me today.

analyzed: no ce tuvam maheseyyam sambule kārayissasi
translated: “If you will not be my queen, Samudda,

translated: you will be my breakfast, you will be my food for the question (you asked).

original: “Tañca sattajaṭo luddo, kaḷāro purisādako;
analyzed: tat ca sattajaṭaḥ luddo kaḷāro purisādako
translated: “That one with seven matted locks, the hunter, the dark-skinned man-eater,

analyzed: vane nātham apassantim sambulam aggahī bhuje
translated: saw Samudda, who was without a protector in the forest, and seized her by the arm.

analyzed: adhipannā pisācena luddena āmisa cakkhunā
translated: “She was oppressed by the ogre, the hunter, who had eyes for meat,

analyzed: sā ca sattu vasam pattā patim eva anusocati
translated: and she, who had fallen into the power of the enemy, lamented for her husband.

analyzed: na me idam tathā dukkham yat mama khādeyya rakkhasaḥ
translated: “It is not this that is so painful for me, that a demon might devour me,

analyzed: yat ca me ayya puttassa manaḥ hessati aññathā
translated: And what your husband’s mind will be, will be otherwise.

analyzed: na santi devā pavasanti nūna na hi nūna santi idha lokapālā
translated: “There are no gods, surely, for they do not appear; surely there are no guardians of the world here,

original: Sahasā karontānamasaññatānaṃ, na hi nūna santi paṭisedhitāro”ti.
analyzed: sahasā karontānam asaññatānam na hi nūna santi paṭisedhitāraḥ ti
translated: For those who do things rashly, without restraint, surely there are no restrainers.”

original: Tattha pariciṇṇenāti tena āturena pariciṇṇena kiṃ karissasi. Sokaṭṭāyāti sokāturāya.
analyzed: tattha pariciṇṇena ati tena āturena pariciṇṇena kim karissasi sokaṭṭāya ati soka āturāya
translated: Here, “by one who has attended on” : what will you do by one who has attended on the sick? “By one who is in the state of grief” : by one who is in the state of grief-sickness.

original: “Sokaṭṭhāyā”tipi pāṭho, soke ṭhitāyāti attho. Durattāyāti duggatakapaṇabhāvappattāya
analyzed: sokaṭṭhāya atipi pāṭhaḥ soke ṭhitāya iti atthaḥ durattāya ati duggata kapaṇa bhāva ppattāya
translated: “Sokaṭṭhāyā” is also a reading, the meaning being: “by one who is standing in grief.” “By one who is in the state of misfortune” : by one who has reached the state of misfortune, of poverty.

original: attabhāvāya. Ehimanti mā tvaṃ durattāmhīti cintayi, etaṃ mama girimhi dibbavimānaṃ,
analyzed: atta bhāvāya ehimanti mā tvam durattā amhi iti etam mama girimhi dibba vimānam
translated: “Come, do not think: ‘I am in misfortune.’ This is my divine palace on the mountain.

original: ehi imaṃ giriṃ āruha. Catussatāti tasmiṃ me vimāne aparāpi catussatā bhariyāyo atthi.
analyzed: ehi imam girim āruha catussatā ati tasmin me vimāne aparā api catussatā bhariyāyaḥ atthi
translated: Come, climb this mountain. There are four hundred” : in my palace there are four hundred other wives.

original: Sabbaṃ tanti yaṃ kiñci upabhogaparibhogavatthābharaṇādikaṃ icchasi, sabbaṃ taṃ nūna
analyzed: sabbam tat ti yam kiñci upabhoga paribhoga vattha ābharaṇa ādikam icchasi sabbam tam nūna
translated: “All that” : whatever things you desire, such as objects of enjoyment, ornaments, etc., all that is surely

original: mayhaṃ pacuraṃ bahuṃ sulabhaṃ, tasmā mā kapaṇāmhīti cintayi, ehi mayā saha ramassūti vadati.
analyzed: mayham pacuram bahum sulabham tasmai mā kapaṇāmhi iti ehi mayā saha ramassu iti vadati
translated: abundant and easy to obtain for me. Therefore do not think: ‘I am poor.’ Come, enjoy with me.”

original: Maheseyyanti, “bhadde, sambule no ce me tvaṃ mahesibhāvaṃ kāressasi, pariyattā tvaṃ🔽mama pātarāsāya, tena taṃ balakkārena vimānaṃ nessāmi, tatra maṃ asaṅgaṇhantī mama
analyzed: maheseyyanti bhadde sambule no ce me tvam mahesi bhāvam kāressasi pariyattā tvam  mama pāta rāsāya tena tam balakkārena vimānam nessāmi tatra mama a saṅgaṇhantī mama
translated: ‘If you will not do me the honour’: ‘If you will not, dear Sambula, do me the honour of being my wife, then my breakfast is ready,🔽and I will take you off to my palace by force. There you will have to wait on me, and you will be my breakfast tomorrow morning.’

original: sve pātova bhakkhā bhavissasī”ti evaṃ vatvā so sattahi jaṭāhi samannāgato luddako
analyzed: sve pātova bhakkhā bhavissasi iti evam vatvā saḥ sattahi jaṭāhi samannāgataḥ luddako
translated: So saying, the hunter, who was armed with seven plaits of hair, a terrible man with projecting teeth,

original: dāruṇo nikkhantadanto taṃ tasmiṃ vane kiñci attano nāthaṃ apassantiṃ sambulaṃ bhuje🔽aggahesi. Adhipannāti ajjhotthaṭā. Āmisacakkhunāti kilesalolena. Patimevāti attano🔽acintetvā patimeva anusocati. Mano hessatīti maṃ cirāyantiṃ viditvā aññathā cittaṃ
analyzed: dāruṇaḥ nikkhanta dantaḥ tam tasmim vane kiñci attanaḥ nātham apassantim sambulam bhuje  aggahesi adhipannā ati ajjhotthaṭā āmisa cakkhunā ati kilesa lolena patim eva ati attanaḥ  a cintetvā patim eva anusocati manaḥ hessati iti mam cirāyantim viditvā aññathā cittam
translated: seized Sambula by the arm, and she saw no protector in the whole forest.

original: bhavissati. Na santi devāti idaṃ sā dānavena bhuje gahitā devatujjhāpanaṃ karontī
analyzed: bhavissati na santi devā ti idam sā dānavena bhuje gahitā karontī
translated: ‘She was seized’: she was attacked. ‘With the eye of flesh’: with the eye of lust. ‘She grieved only for herself’: she grieved only for herself, not thinking of me. ‘Her mind will be changed’: thinking ‘She is keeping me waiting too long,’ her mind will be changed. ‘There are no gods’: this she said because she was seized by the demon, and was complaining of the gods.

original: āha. Lokapālāti evarūpānaṃ sīlavantīnaṃ patidevatānaṃ pālakā lokapālā nūna idha loke🔽na santīti paridevati.
analyzed: āha lokapāla ati evarūpānam sīlavantīnam pati devatānam pālakāḥ lokapālāḥ nūnam idha loke 🔽na santi iti paridevati
translated: ‘Guardians of the world’: she lamented, ‘Surely there are no guardians of the world, no gods to protect such virtuous women as I am.’

original: Athassā sīlatejena sakkassa bhavanaṃ kampi, paṇḍukambalasilāsanaṃ uṇhākāraṃ dassesi.
analyzed: sīla tejena sakkassa bhavanam kampi paṇḍu kambala silā āsanam uṇhākāram dassesi
translated: The radiance of her virtue shook Sakka’s palace, and the white-spread couch showed signs of heat.

original: Sakko āvajjento taṃ kāraṇaṃ ñatvā vajiraṃ ādāya vegena gantvā dānavassa matthake
analyzed: sakkaḥ āvajjentaḥ tam kāraṇam ñatvā vajiram ādāya vegena gantvā dānavassa matthake
translated: Sakka, perceiving this, understood the reason for it. He took his thunderbolt and went quickly. He stood over the head of the giver of gifts

original: ṭhatvā itaraṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: itaram gātham āha
translated: and spoke the second stanza:

original: “Itthīnamesā pavarā yasassinī, santā samā aggirivuggatejā;
analyzed: itthī namesā pavarā yasassinī santā samā
translated: “She is a woman, she is famous, she is holy, she is calm, she is wise, she is radiant as fire;

original: Tañce tuvaṃ rakkhasādesi kaññaṃ, muddhā ca hi sattadhā te phaleyya;
analyzed: tat ce tuvam rakkhasādesi kaññam muddhā ca hi sattadhā te phaleyya
translated: If thou shouldst eat this maiden, O demon, thy head would split in seven;

original: Mā tvaṃ dahī muñca patibbatāyā”ti.
analyzed: mā tvam dahī muñca patibbatāya ati
translated: Do not burn, let her go, she is a devotee.”

original: Tattha santāti upasantā, atha vā paṇḍitā ñāṇasampannā. Samāti kāyavisamādivirahitā.
analyzed: tattha santā ati upasantā atha vā paṇḍitā ñāṇa sampannā samā ati kāya visama ādi virahitā
translated: Here “calm” means “tranquil,” or “wise,” endowed with knowledge. “Holy” means “free from bodily impurity, etc.”

original: Adesīti khādasi. Phaleyyāti iminā me indavajirena paharitvā muddhā bhijjetha. Mā
analyzed: adesi iti khādasi phaleyyā ati iminā me inda vajirena paharitvā muddhā bhijjetha mā
translated: “Shouldst eat” means “shouldst devour.” “Split in seven” means “may my head be split by this thunderbolt of mine.”

original: tvaṃ dahīti tvaṃ imaṃ patibbataṃ mā tāpeyyāsīti.
analyzed: tvam dahi iti tvam imam patibbatam mā tāpeyyāsi iti
translated: “Do not burn” means “do not torment her.”

original: Taṃ sutvā dānavo sambulaṃ vissajjesi. Sakko “punapi esa evarūpaṃ kareyyā”ti cintetvā
analyzed: tam sutvā dānavaḥ sambulam vissajjesi sakko puna api esaḥ evarūpam kareyya ati cintetvā
translated: Hearing this, the demon let go of Sambula. Sakka thought, “He will do this again.”

original: dānavaṃ devasaṅkhalikāya bandhitvā puna anāgamanāya tatiye pabbatantare vissajjesi,
analyzed: dānavam deva saṅkhalikāya bandhitvā puna an āgamanāya tatiye pabbata antare vissajjesi
translated: Dāmanaka, having bound Devasaṅkhalika with the chain of the gods, let him go again to the third mountain range, never to return.

original: rājadhītaraṃ appamādena ovaditvā sakaṭṭhānameva gato. Rājadhītāpi atthaṅgate sūriye
analyzed: rājadhītaram appamādena ovaditvā saka ṭṭhānam eva gataḥ rājadhītā api atthaṅgate sūriye
translated: Having admonished the princess with the words, “Be diligent,” he went to his own place. The princess, when the sun had set,

original: candālokena assamaṃ pāpuṇi. Tamatthaṃ pakāsento satthā aṭṭha gāthā abhāsi –
analyzed: canda ālokena assamam pāpuṇi tam attham pakāsento satthā aṭṭha gāthāḥ abhāsi
translated: reached the hermitage by the light of the moon. Expounding this matter, the Teacher uttered these eight stanzas:

original: “Sā ca assamamāgacchi, pamuttā purisādakā;
analyzed: sā ca assamam āgacchi pamuttā purisādakā
translated: “She came to the hermitage, freed from the man-eating demon;

original: Nīḷaṃ paḷinaṃ sakuṇīva, gatasiṅgaṃva ālayaṃ.
analyzed: nīḷam paḷinam sakuṇī iva ālayam
translated: Like a bird from a net, like a deer from a snare.

original: “Sā tattha paridevesi, rājaputtī yasassinī;
analyzed: sā tattha paridevesi rāja puttī yasassinī
translated: “There she lamented, the famous princess;

original: Sambulā utumattakkhā, vane nāthaṃ apassantī.
analyzed: sambulā utumattakkhā vane nātham a passantī
translated: Without a protector in the forest, with disheveled hair, and drenched with rain.

original: “Samaṇe brāhmaṇe vande, sampannacaraṇe ise;
analyzed: samaṇe brāhmaṇe vande sampanna caraṇe ise
translated: “I pay homage to the ascetics and to the brahmans, whose conduct is perfect, who are wise;

original: Rājaputtaṃ apassantī, tumhaṃmhi saraṇaṃ gatā.
analyzed: rāja puttam a passantī tumhaṃmhi saraṇam gatā
translated: Not seeing the prince, I have gone for refuge to you.

original: “Vande sīhe ca byagghe ca, ye ca aññe vane migā;
analyzed: vande sīhe ca byagghe ca ye ca aññe vane migā
translated: “I pay homage to the lions and to the tigers, and to all the other forest beasts;

original: Rājaputtaṃ apassantī, tumhaṃmhi saraṇaṃ gatā.
analyzed: rāja puttam a passantī tumhaṃmhi saraṇam gatā
translated: Not seeing the prince, I have gone for refuge to you.

original: “Tiṇā latāni osajho, pabbatāni vanāni ca;
analyzed: tiṇā latāni osajhaḥ pabbatāni vanāni ca
translated: “I pay homage to the grass, to the creepers, to the herbs, to the mountains, and to the forests;

original: Rājaputtaṃ apassantī, tumhaṃmhi saraṇaṃ gatā.
analyzed: rāja puttam a passantī tumhaṃmhi saraṇam gatā
translated: Not seeing the prince, I have gone for refuge to you.

original: “Vande indīvarīsāmaṃ, rattiṃ nakkhattamāliniṃ;
analyzed: vande indīvarī sāmam rattim nakkhatta mālinim
translated: “I pay homage to the moon, the friend of the blue water lily, the night, the garland of stars;

original: Rājaputtaṃ apassantī, tumhaṃmhi saraṇaṃ gatā.
analyzed: rāja puttam a passantī tumhaṃmhi saraṇam gatā
translated: Not seeing the prince, I have come to you for refuge.”

original: “Vande bhāgīrathiṃ gaṅgaṃ, savantīnaṃ paṭiggahaṃ;
analyzed: vande bhāgīrathim gaṅgam savantīnam paṭiggaham
translated: “I pay homage to the Ganges, the daughter of the king of mountains, the best of rivers, the foremost of those that flow;

original: Rājaputtaṃ apassantī, tumhaṃmhi saraṇaṃ gatā.
analyzed: rāja puttam a passantī tumhaṃmhi saraṇam gatā
translated: Not seeing the prince, I have come to you for refuge.”

original: “Vande ahaṃ pabbatarājaseṭṭhaṃ, himavantaṃ siluccayaṃ;
analyzed: vande aham pabbata rāja seṭṭham himavantam siluccayam
translated: “I pay homage to the king of mountains, the best of mountains, the snow-covered Himalayas;

original: Rājaputtaṃ apassantī, tumhaṃmhi saraṇaṃ gatā”ti.🔽Tattha nīḷaṃ paḷinaṃ sakuṇīvāti yathā sakuṇikā mukhatuṇḍakena gocaraṃ gahetvā kenaci
analyzed: rāja puttam a passantī tumhaṃmhi saraṇam gatā ati  tattha nīḷam paḷinam yathā sa kuṇikā mukha tuṇḍakena gocaram gahetvā kenacid
translated: Not seeing the prince, I have come to you for refuge.”🔽Herein, a bird’s nest with young is a nest with young in it that a hen bird has made with her beak by bringing grass and leaves and then covering it with her feathers and sitting on it.

original: upaddavena sakuṇapotakānaṃ paḷinattā paḷinaṃ sakuṇinīḷaṃ āgaccheyya, yathā vā gatasiṅgaṃ
analyzed: upaddavena sa kuṇa potakānam paḷinattā paḷinam sa kuṇinīḷam āgaccheyya yathā vā gata siṅgam
translated: Or it is like a cow that has gone to her own shelter, the empty shed, after her calf has been taken away.🔽So too, she came to the empty hermitage.

original: nikkhantavacchakaṃ ālayaṃ suññaṃ vacchakasālaṃ vacchagiddhinī dhenu āgaccheyya, evaṃ🔽suññaṃ assamaṃ āgacchīti attho. Tadā hi sotthiseno sambulāya ciramānāya “itthiyo
analyzed: nikkhanta vacchakam ālayam suññam vacchaka sālam vacchag iddhinī dhenu āgaccheyya evam 🔽suññam assamam āgacchi iti tadā hi sotthisenaḥ sambulāya ciramānāya itthiyaḥ
translated: At that time, after the bamboo had been cut down for a long time, the women

original: nāma lolā, paccāmittampi me gahetvā āgaccheyyā”ti parisaṅkanto paṇṇasālato nikkhamitvā
analyzed: nāma lolā pacca amittam pi me gahetvā āgaccheyya ati parisaṅkantaḥ paṇṇa sālataḥ nikkhamitvā
translated: “Women are fickle. She might come back with my enemies.” Suspecting this, he came out of the leaf-hut,

analyzed: gacchantaram pavisitvā nisīdi tena itam vuttam utumattakkhāti soka vega sañjātena uṇhena
translated: went to the middle of the road, and sat down. Therefore it was said: “With a fevered mind” (he sat down). With a fevered mind born of the speed of grief,

original: utunā mandalocanā. Apassantīti tasmiṃ vane nāthaṃ attano patiṃ apassantī ito cito
analyzed: utunā manda locanāḥ apassanti iti tasmin vane nātham attano patim apassantī itas citas
translated: with his eyes rolling. “Not seeing” (he sat down): Not seeing in the forest a protector, her own husband, she wandered here and there,

analyzed: ca sandhāvamānā paridevesi  tattha samaṇe brāhmaṇa iti samita pāpa bāhita pāpe samaṇe brāhmaṇe sampanna caraṇa iti saha
translated: and lamented.

original: sīlena aṭṭhannaṃ samāpattīnaṃ vasena ca sampannacaraṇe ise vandeti evaṃ vatvā rājaputtaṃ
analyzed: sīlena aṭṭhannam samāpattīnam vasena ca sampanna caraṇe ise vandeti evam vatvā rāja puttam
translated: Herein, “ascetics and brahmins” (he sat down): Ascetics and brahmins who have destroyed evil and expelled evil. “With perfect conduct” (he sat down): With perfect conduct together with virtue and with the eight attainments, he worshipped the ascetics. Having said this, not seeing the prince,

original: apassantī tumhākaṃ saraṇaṃ gatā amhi. Sace me sāmikassa nisinnaṭṭhānaṃ jānātha, ācikkhathāti
analyzed: a passantī tumhākam saraṇam gatā amhi sace me sāmikassa nisinna ṭhānam jānātha ācikkhatha ati
translated: she said: “I have gone for refuge to you. If you know the place where my husband is sitting, please tell me.”

original: paridevesīti attho. Sesagāthāsupi eseva nayo. Tiṇā latāni osajhoti antopheggubahisāratiṇāni
analyzed: paridevesi iti attho sesa gāthāsu pi esa iva nayo tiṇā latāni antar pheggu bahisāra tiṇāni
translated: The meaning is: she lamented. The same method applies to the remaining verses. “Grasses and creepers” (he sat down): The grasses and creepers inside the house and outside the house,

original: ca latāni ca antosāraosadhiyo ca. Imaṃ gāthaṃ tiṇādīsu nibbattadevatā sandhāyāha.
analyzed: ca latāni ca ca imam gātham tiṇa ādīsu nibbatta devatā sandhāya āha
translated: and creepers, and medicinal herbs growing inside. He spoke this verse with reference to the deities born among the grass, etc.

original: Indīvarīsāmanti indīvarīpupphasamānavaṇṇaṃ. Nakkhattamālininti nakkhattapaṭipāṭisamannāgataṃ.
analyzed: indīvarī sāmanti indīvarī puppha samāna vaṇṇam nakkhatta mālininti nakkhatta paṭipāṭi samannāgatam
translated: Indīvarīsāmanti: having the color of indīvara flowers. Nakkhattamālininti: having the order of the stars.

analyzed: tumham mhi iti rattim sandhāya amhi iti āha bhāgīrathim evaṃpariyāya nāmikam
translated: Tumhaṃmhīti: with reference to the night, he said “amhi” . Bhāgīrathiṃ gaṅganti: the river named after the king Bhagīratha.

original: gaṅgaṃ. Savantīnanti aññāsaṃ bahūnaṃ nadīnaṃ paṭiggāhikaṃ. Gaṅgāya nibbattadevataṃ
analyzed: gaṅgam savantīnam ti aññāsam bahūnam nadīnam paṭiggāhikam gaṅgāya nibbatta devatam
translated: Savantīnanti: the receiver of many other rivers. With reference to the deity born in the Ganges,

original: sandhāyevamāha. Himavantepi eseva nayo.
analyzed: sandhāya ivam āha himavante pi
translated: he spoke thus. The same method in the Himalayas.

original: Taṃ evaṃ paridevamānaṃ disvā sotthiseno cintesi – “ayaṃ ativiya paridevati, na kho
analyzed: tam evam paridevamānam disvā sotthi senaḥ cintesi ayam ativiya paridevati na kho
translated: Seeing her lamenting thus, Sotthisena thought: “She is lamenting excessively. I do not know

original: panassā bhāvaṃ jānāmi, sace mayi sinehena evaṃ karoti, hadayampissā phaleyya, pariggaṇhissāmi
analyzed: panassāḥ bhāvam jānāmi sace mayi sinehena evam karoti hadayam pissā phaleyya pariggaṇhissāmi
translated: her state. If she does this out of love for me, her heart would burst. I will not accept her

analyzed: tāva nanti gantvā paṇṇasāla dvāre sā api paridevamānā ava paṇṇasāla dvāram gantvā
translated: yet.” Having thought thus, he went and sat at the door of the leaf-hut. She too, lamenting, went to the door of the leaf-hut🔽and saw him. She thought: “This is my husband. I will ask him.” She asked: “Sir, do you know me?”

original: tassa pāde vanditvā “kuhiṃ gatosi, devā”ti āha. Atha naṃ so, “bhadde, tvaṃ aññesu
analyzed: tassa pāde vanditvā kuhim gataḥ asi deva ati āha atha nam saḥ bhadde tvam aññesu
translated: and after worshipping his feet, said, “Where have you been, my lord?” Then he said to her, “My dear, you

original: divasesu na imāya velāya āgacchasi, ajja atisāyaṃ āgatāsī”ti pucchanto gāthamāha –
analyzed: divasesu naḥ imāya velāyai āgacchasi ajja atisāyam āgatā asi iti pucchantaḥ gātham āha
translated: and asked him where he had been. He replied, “My dear, on other days you do not come so late, but to-day you have come very late.” And he asked her the reason, reciting the first stanza:

original: “Atisāyaṃ vatāgañchi, rājaputti yasassini;
analyzed: atisāyam vata āgañchi rāja putti yasassini
translated: “Late, O lady of renown, thou comest,

analyzed: kena nujja samāgacchi kaḥ te piyataraḥ mayā ati
translated: Princess, what is the reason? Who is dearer to thee than I?”

analyzed: atha nam sā aham ayya putta phala aphalāni ādāya āgacchantī ekam dānavam passim  saḥ mayi paṭibaddha cittaḥ hutvā mam hatthe gaṇhitvā sace mama vacanam na karosi khādissāmi
translated: She replied, “My dear, as I was coming along, bringing fruits and roots, I saw a demon,

analyzed: āha aham tāya velāya taññā iva anusocantī evam paridevin ti vatvā gātham āha
translated: who seized me by the hand and said, ‘If you do not do as I tell you, I will eat you up.’ At that moment I was thinking of you, and I wept and lamented.” And she recited the second stanza:

analyzed: idam khalu uham tadā avocam gahitā tena sattunā
translated: “This was the answer I gave him, when seized by that demon;

original: Na me idaṃ tathā dukkhaṃ, yaṃ maṃ khādeyya rakkhaso;
analyzed: na me idam tathā dukkham yat mama khādeyya rakkhasaḥ
