analyzed: kataguṇam jānāti ubhā upete su dullabhā sambulā tuyham hitā ca iva sīla sampannā
translated: “He who knows the good and the grateful, both are hard to find. And this Sambulā is good to you and virtuous.

original: ca, tasmā etissā dhammaṃ cara, kataguṇaṃ jānitvā muducitto hohi, cittamassā paritosehīti.
analyzed: ca tasmai etissā dhammam cara kata guṇam jānitvā mudu cittaḥ hohi cittam assā paritosehi iti
translated: Therefore, act righteously toward her, and being grateful, be gentle, and be kind to her.”

original: Evaṃ so puttassa ovādaṃ datvā uṭṭhāyāsanā pakkāmi. Rājā pitari gate sambulaṃ pakkosāpetvā,
analyzed: evam saḥ puttassa ovādam da tvā uṭṭhāya āsanā pakkāmi rājā pitari gate sambulam pakkosāpetvā
translated: Having thus instructed his son, he rose from his seat and departed. When the king had gone, the prince summoned Sambulā and said to her,

original: “bhadde, ettakaṃ kālaṃ mayā kataṃ dosaṃ khama, ito paṭṭhāya sabbissariyaṃ tuyhameva
analyzed: bhadde ettakam kālam mayā katam dosam khame itas paṭṭhāya sa vissariyam tuyham eva
translated: “Dear, forgive me for what I have done through anger. From this day forth all power is yours.

original: dammī”ti vatvā osānagāthamāha –
analyzed: dammi iti vatvā osāna gātham āha
translated: I give it to you.” And he pronounced the following Stanza,

original: “Sace tuvaṃ vipule laddhabhoge, issāvatiṇṇā maraṇaṃ upesi;
analyzed: sace tuvam vipule laddha bhoge issā avatiṇṇā maraṇam upesi
translated: “If, dear, you should die through anger, having obtained great wealth,

original: Ahañca te bhadde imā rājakaññā, sabbe te vacanakarā bhavāmā”ti.🔽Tassattho – bhadde, sambule sace tvaṃ ratanarāsimhi ṭhapetvā abhisittā aggamahesiṭṭhānavasena
analyzed: aham ca te bhadde imā rāja kaññā sabbe te vacana karāḥ bhavāma ati  tassa atthaḥ bhadde sambule sace tvam ratana rāsimhi ṭhapetvā abhisittā agga mahesi ṭṭhāna vasena
translated: Then, dear, I and these royal maidens will all do your bidding.”

original: vipule bhoge labhitvāpi issāya otiṇṇā maraṇaṃ upesi, ahañca imā ca rājakaññā sabbe
analyzed: vipule bhoge labhitvā api issāya otiṇṇā maraṇam upesi aham ca imā ca rāja kaññā sabbe
translated: The meaning is this: Dear Sambulā, if you should die through anger, having obtained great wealth, having been anointed Queen Consort and having been set up as a treasure-heap,🔽then I and these royal maidens will all do your bidding.

original: tava vacanakarā bhavāma, tvaṃ yathādhippāyaṃ imaṃ rajjaṃ vicārehīti sabbissariyaṃ tassā adāsi.
analyzed: tava vacana karāḥ bhavāma tvam yathā adhippāyam imam rajjam vicārehi iti sa bissariyam tassai adāsi
translated: “We will do as you say. You may rule the kingdom as you wish.” And he gave her the entire sovereignty.

original: Tato paṭṭhāya ubho samaggavāsaṃ vasantā dānādīni puññāni karitvā yathākammaṃ gamiṃsu. Tāpaso jhānābhiññāyo nibbattetvā brahmalokūpago ahosi.
analyzed: tatas paṭṭhāya ubho samagga vāsam vasantā dāna ādīni puññāni karitvā yathākammam gamiṃsu tāpasaḥ jhānābhiññāyaḥ nibbattetvā brahma loka upagaḥ ahosi
translated: From that time forth they lived together in peace and harmony, and after performing many works of charity and merit, they passed away and were reborn according to their deeds. The hermit attained the meditations and the super-knowledges and was reborn in the World of Brahmā.

original: Satthā imaṃ dhammadesanaṃ āharitvā “na, bhikkhave, idāneva, pubbepi mallikā patidevatāyevā”ti
analyzed: satthā imam dhamma desanam āharitvā na bhikkhave idānā iva pubbe pi mallikā pati devatāya iva ati
translated: When the Teacher had related this story, he said, “Monks, this is not the first time Mallikā has been the queen of King Pasenadi; in a previous state of existence also she was his queen.”

original: vatvā jātakaṃ samodhānesi “tadā sambulā mallikā ahosi, sotthiseno kosalarājā, pitā🔽tāpaso pana ahameva ahosi”nti.🔽Sambulājātakavaṇṇanā navamā.
analyzed: vatvā jātakam samodhānesi tadā sambulā mallikā ahosi sotthisenaḥ kosala rājā pitā  tāpasaḥ pana aham eva  sambulā jātaka vaṇṇanā navamā
translated: So saying, he joined the connection, and preaching the Law, pronounced the following Stanza, 10. The hermit who was the king’s father, the hermit who was the king’s mother, the hermit who was the king’s brother, the hermit who was the king’s sister,

original: [520] 10. Gandhatindukajātakavaṇṇanā🔽Appamādoti idaṃ satthā jetavane viharanto rājovādaṃ ārabbha kathesi. Rājovādo heṭṭhā
analyzed: appamādaḥ ti idam satthā jetavane viharantaḥ rāja uvādam ārabbha kathesi rāja uvādaḥ heṭṭhā
translated: The hermit who was the king’s wife, the hermit who was the king’s son, the hermit who was the king’s minister, the hermit who was the king’s chaplain,🔽The hermit who was the king’s charioteer, the hermit who was the king’s door-keeper, the hermit who was the king’s cook, the hermit who was the king’s barber,🔽The hermit who was the king’s physician, the hermit who was the king’s astrologer, the hermit who was the king’s messenger, the hermit who was the king’s servant,🔽The hermit who was the king’s elephant-driver, the hermit who was the king’s horse-driver, the hermit who was the king’s boatman, the hermit who was the king’s footman,🔽The hermit who was the king’s elephant, the hermit who was the king’s horse, the hermit who was the king’s chariot, the hermit who was the king’s litter,

original: vitthāritova. Atīte pana kapilaraṭṭhe uttarapañcālanagare pañcālo nāma rājā agatigamane
analyzed: vitthāritā uva atīte pana kapilaraṭṭhe uttarapañcāla nagare pañcālaḥ nāma rājā agati gamane
translated: The hermit who was the king’s bed, the hermit who was the king’s seat, the hermit who was the king’s couch, the hermit who was the king’s chair,🔽The hermit who was the king’s robe, the hermit who was the king’s ornament, the hermit who was the king’s umbrella, the hermit who was the king’s fan,🔽The hermit who was the king’s sword, the hermit who was the king’s bow,

original: ṭhito adhammena pamatto rajjaṃ kāresi. Athassa amaccādayo sabbepi adhammikāva jātā.🔽Balipīḷitā raṭṭhavāsino puttadāre ādāya araññe migā viya cariṃsu, gāmaṭṭhāne gāmo
analyzed: ṭhitaḥ adhammena pamattaḥ rajjam kāresi atha assa amacca ādayo sabbe pi adhammikā ava jātā  bali pīḍitāḥ raṭṭha vāsino putta dāre ādāya araññe migāḥ viya cariṃsu gāmaṭṭhāne gāmo
translated: and he ruled his kingdom heedlessly and unrighteously. Then all his ministers and all the people became unrighteous.🔽The people of the kingdom, oppressed by taxes, took their children and wives and wandered about in the forest like deer. In the villages there were no villages,

original: nāma nāhosi. Manussā rājapurisānaṃ bhayena divā gehe vasituṃ asakkontā gehāni kaṇṭakasākhāhi
analyzed: nāma na ahosi manussāḥ rāja purisānam bhayena divā gehe vasitum a sakkontāḥ gehāni kaṇṭaka sākhāhi
translated: and in the towns there were no towns. The people, through fear of the king’s men, were unable to live in their houses by day. They surrounded their houses with thorny branches

original: parikkhipitvā gehe rattiṃ vasitvā aruṇe uggacchanteyeva araññaṃ pavisanti. Divā rājapurisā
analyzed: parikkhipitvā gehe rattim vasitvā aruṇe uggacchanteyeva araññam pavisanti divā rāja purisā
translated: and lived in their houses by night. When the dawn appeared they entered the forest. By day the king’s men plundered,

original: vilumpanti, rattiṃ corā. Tadā bodhisatto bahinagare gandhatindukarukkhe devatā hutvā
analyzed: vilumpanti rattim corā tadā bodhisattaḥ bahi nagare gandhatinduka rukkhe devatāḥ hutvā
translated: and by night the thieves. At that time the Bodhisatta was reborn as a deity in a gandhatindu tree outside the city,

original: nibbatti, anusaṃvaccharaṃ rañño santikā sahassagghanakaṃ balikammaṃ labhati. So cintesi
analyzed: nibbatti anusaṃvaccharam rañño santikā sahassa gghanakam bali kammam labhati saḥ cintesi
translated: and he received a thousand pieces of money every year from the king as a sacrificial offering. He thought:

original: – “ayaṃ rājā pamatto rajjaṃ kāreti, sakalaraṭṭhaṃ vinassati, ṭhapetvā maṃ añño rājānaṃ
analyzed: ayam rājā pamattaḥ rajjam kāreti sakala raṭṭham vinassati ṭhapetvā mama aññaḥ rājānam
translated: “This king rules his kingdom heedlessly. The whole kingdom will be destroyed. Except for me, there is no one else to warn the king.

original: patirūpe nivesetuṃ samattho nāma natthi, upakārako cāpi me anusaṃvaccharaṃ sahassagghanakabalinā
analyzed: patirūpe nivesetum samatthaḥ nāma natthi ca api me anusaṃvaccharam sahassa gghanaka balinā
translated: “There is no one fit to be my adviser, and my benefactor, who gives me a pill worth a thousand a year,

original: pūjeti, ovadissāmi na”nti.
analyzed: pūjā iti ovadissāmi nanti
translated: will not be advised by me.”

original: So rattibhāge rañño sirigabbhaṃ pavisitvā ussīsakapasse ṭhatvā obhāsaṃ vissajjetvā
analyzed: saḥ ratti bhāge raññaḥ sirigabbham pavisitvā ussīsaka passe ṭhatvā obhāsam vissajjetvā
translated: In the night he entered the king’s bed-chamber, and standing at the head of the bed, he emitted a radiance,

original: ākāse aṭṭhāsi. Rājā taṃ bālasūriyaṃ viya jalamānaṃ disvā “kosi tvaṃ, kena vā kāraṇena
analyzed: ākāse aṭṭhāsi rājā tam bāla sūriyam viya jalamānam disvā kā asi tvam kena vā kāraṇena
translated: and stood in the air. The king, seeing him shining like the rising sun, asked him, “Who are you, and for what reason

original: idhāgatosī”ti pucchi. So tassa vacanaṃ sutvā, “mahārāja, ahaṃ gandhatindukadevatā,
analyzed: idha āgataḥ asi iti pucchi saḥ tassa vacanam sutvā mahā rāja aham gandhatinduka devatā
translated: have you come here?” Hearing his words, he said, “Great king, I am the god of the fragrant tinduka tree,

original: ‘tuyhaṃ ovādaṃ dassāmī’ti āgatomhī”ti āha. “Kiṃ nāma ovādaṃ dassasī”ti evaṃ vutte
analyzed: tuyham ovādam dassāmi iti āgataḥ asi iti āha kim nāma ovādam dassasi iti evam vutte
translated: and I have come to give you advice.” “What advice will you give me?”

original: mahāsatto, “mahārāja, tvaṃ pamatto hutvā rajjaṃ kāresi, tena te sakalaraṭṭhaṃ hataviluttaṃ
analyzed: mahāsattaḥ mahā rāja tvam pamattaḥ hutvā rajjam kāresi tena te sakala raṭṭham hata viluttam
translated: When this was said, the Great Being said, “Great king, you are ruling the kingdom heedlessly, and therefore the whole kingdom is ruined,

original: viya vinaṭṭhaṃ, rājāno nāma pamādena rajjaṃ kārentā sakalaraṭṭhassa sāmino na honti,
analyzed: viya vinaṭṭham rājānaḥ nāma pamādena rajjam kārentā sakala raṭṭhassa sāminaḥ na honti
translated: as if it were destroyed by fire. Kings who rule the kingdom heedlessly are not masters of the whole kingdom,🔽but are the slaves of their passions.

original: diṭṭheva dhamme vināsaṃ patvā samparāye puna mahāniraye nibbattanti. Tesu ca pamādaṃ
analyzed: diṭṭhā iva dhamme vināsam patvā samparāye puna mahāniraye nibbattanti tesu ca pamādam
translated: and after their death they are reborn in the great hell. And when the king is negligent, his household and his people are also negligent. Therefore the king should be very diligent.

original: āpannesu antojanā bahijanāpissa pamattāva honti, tasmā raññā atirekena appamattena
analyzed: āpannesu antojanāḥ bahijanā apissa pamattāḥ ava honti tasmā raññā atirekena appamattena
translated: “And when the king is diligent, his household and his people are also diligent. Therefore the king should be very diligent.”

original: bhavitabba”nti vatvā dhammadesanaṃ paṭṭhapento imā ekādasa gāthā āha –
analyzed: bhavitabban ti vatvā dhamma desanam paṭṭhapentaḥ imāḥ ekādasa gāthāḥ āha
translated: And teaching the Dhamma with reference to the king, he recited these eleven stanzas:

original: “Appamādo amatapadaṃ, pamādo maccuno padaṃ;
analyzed: appamādaḥ a mata padam pamādaḥ maccuno padam
translated: “Diligence is the immortal state, negligence the state of death;

original: Appamattā na mīyanti, ye pamattā yathā matā.
analyzed: appamattāḥ na mīyanti ye pamattāḥ yathā matā
translated: The diligent do not die, the negligent are as if dead.

original: “Madā pamādo jāyetha, pamādā jāyate khayo;
analyzed: madā pamādaḥ jāyetha pamādā jāyate khayo
translated: “From pride comes negligence, from negligence comes destruction;

original: Khayā padosā jāyanti, mā mado bharatūsabha.
analyzed: khayā padosāḥ jāyanti mā madaḥ bharatūsabha
translated: From destruction comes sorrow, do not be proud, O bull of the Bharatas.

original: “Bahū hi khattiyā jīnā, atthaṃ raṭṭhaṃ pamādino;
analyzed: bahū hi khattiyāḥ jīnāḥ attham raṭṭham pamādinaḥ
translated: “Many kings have been conquered, and the kingdom has been destroyed through negligence;

original: Athopi gāmino gāmā, anagārā agārino.
analyzed: atha upi gāminaḥ gāmāḥ anagārāḥ agārinaḥ
translated: Then the villages of the leaders, the villages of the people, the villages of the homeless, and the villages of the householders.

original: “Khattiyassa pamattassa, raṭṭhasmiṃ raṭṭhavaḍḍhana;
analyzed: khattiyassa pamattassa raṭṭhasmim raṭṭhavaḍḍhana
translated: “When the king is negligent, O king, in the kingdom that is to be increased,

original: Sabbe bhogā vinassanti, rañño taṃ vuccate aghaṃ.
analyzed: sabbe bhogāḥ vinassanti raññaḥ tat vuccate agham
translated: all his wealth is destroyed, and that is said to be the king’s misfortune.

original: “Nesa dhammo mahārāja, ativelaṃ pamajjasi;
analyzed: na isa dhammaḥ mahā rāja ativelam pamajjasi
translated: “This is not the Dhamma, great king, that you should be negligent for too long;

original: Iddhaṃ phītaṃ janapadaṃ, corā viddhaṃsayanti naṃ.
analyzed: iddham phītam janapadam corāḥ viddhaṃsayanti naṃ
translated: The prosperous and flourishing country is being destroyed by thieves.

original: “Na te puttā bhavissanti, na hiraññaṃ na dhāniyaṃ;
analyzed: na te puttāḥ bhavissanti na hiraññam na dhāniyam
translated: “You will have no sons, no gold, no grain,

original: Raṭṭhe viluppamānamhi, sabbabhogehi jīyasi.
analyzed: raṭṭhe viluppamānamhi sabba bhogehi jīyasi
translated: But will live on in the kingdom, surviving on all sorts of things.🔽“When a king or a noble

original: “Sabbabhogā parijiṇṇaṃ, rājānaṃ vāpi khattiyaṃ;
analyzed: sabba bhogāḥ parijiṇṇam rājānam vā api khattiyam
translated: Has used up all his wealth,🔽His relatives, friends, and companions

original: Ñātimittā suhajjā ca, na taṃ maññanti māniyaṃ.
analyzed: ñāti mittā su hajjā ca na tam maññanti māniyam
translated: No longer think of him as great.

original: “Hatthārohā anīkaṭṭhā, rathikā pattikārakā;
analyzed: hattha ārohā anīkaṭṭhā rathikā patti kārakā
translated: “Elephant-riders, charioteers, horsemen, and infantry

original: Tamevamupajīvantā, na taṃ maññanti māniyaṃ.
analyzed: tam evam upajīvantāḥ na tam maññanti māniyam
translated: No longer think of him as great, though they still depend on him.🔽“If a fool is not careful,

original: “Asaṃvihitakammantaṃ, bālaṃ dummantimantinaṃ;
analyzed: a saṃvihita kammantam bālam dummanti mantinam
translated: And is lazy and undisciplined,🔽His glory leaves him,

original: Sirī jahati dummedhaṃ, jiṇṇaṃva urago tacaṃ.
analyzed: sirī jahati dummedham jiṇṇam vai uragaḥ tacam
translated: As a snake leaves its old skin.🔽“But if he is careful,

original: “Susaṃvihitakammantaṃ, kāluṭṭhāyiṃ atanditaṃ;
analyzed: su saṃvihita kammantam kāluṭṭhāyim a tanditam
translated: And is not lazy or negligent,🔽All his wealth increases,

original: Sabbe bhogābhivaḍḍhanti, gāvo sausabhāmiva.
analyzed: sabbe bhogā abhivaḍḍhanti gāvaḥ sausabhām iva
translated: Like a cow with a calf.🔽“Listen, great king,

original: “Upassutiṃ mahārāja, raṭṭhe janapade cara;
analyzed: upassutim mahā rāja raṭṭhe janapade cara
translated: As you travel through the country and the villages,🔽There you will see and hear

original: Tattha disvā ca sutvā ca, tato taṃ paṭipajjasī”ti.
analyzed: tattha disvā ca sutvā ca tatas tam paṭipajjasi iti
translated: How you should act.”

original: Tattha appamādoti satiyā avippavāso. Amatapadanti amatassa nibbānassa padaṃ adhigamakāraṇaṃ.
analyzed: tattha appamādaḥ ti satiyāḥ a vippavāsaḥ amata padam ti amatassa nibbānassa padam adhigama kāraṇam
translated: Herein, heedfulness is non-abandonment of mindfulness. The state of immortality is the state of the deathless, Nibbāna, the means of attaining which is the path.

original: Maccuno padanti maraṇassa kāraṇaṃ. Pamattā hi vipassanaṃ avaḍḍhetvā appaṭisandhikabhāvaṃ
analyzed: maccuno padanti maraṇassa kāraṇam pamattāḥ hi vipassanam a vaḍḍhetvā appaṭisandhika bhāvam
translated: The state of death is the cause of death. For the heedless, not having developed insight, are unable to attain the state of non-rebirth.

original: pattuṃ asakkontā punappunaṃ saṃsāre jāyanti ceva mīyanti ca, tasmā pamādo maccuno
analyzed: pattum a sakkontā punappunam saṃsāre jāyanti ca iva mīyanti ca tasmā pamādaḥ maccunaḥ
translated: They are born and die again and again in the round of rebirths. Therefore heedlessness is called the state of death.

original: padaṃ nāma. Na mīyantīti vipassanaṃ vaḍḍhetvā appaṭisandhikabhāvaṃ pattā puna saṃsāre🔽anibbattattā na mīyanti nāma. Ye pamattāti, mahārāja, ye puggalā pamattā, te yathā
analyzed: padam nāma na mīyanti iti vipassanam vaḍḍhetvā appaṭisandhika bhāvam pattā puna saṃsāre  a nibbatta ttā na mīyanti nāma ye pamattā ati mahā rāja ye puggalā pamattā te yathā
translated: Those who are heedful, having developed insight, attain the state of non-rebirth. They are not born again in the round of rebirths.🔽Therefore they are called “those who do not die.”

original: matā, tatheva daṭṭhabbā. Kasmā? Akiccasādhanatāya. Matassapi hi “ahaṃ dānaṃ dassāmi,
analyzed: matā tathā iva daṭṭhabbā kasmai akicca sādhanatāya matassa api hi aham dānam dassāmi
translated: Those who are heedless, sire, should be regarded as dead. Why? Because they do not accomplish their purpose. For the dead have no intention, no aspiration, no effort, such as: “I will give gifts,

original: sīlaṃ rakkhissāmi, uposathakammaṃ karissāmi, kalyāṇakammaṃ pūressāmī”ti ābhogo vā
analyzed: sīlam rakkhissāmi uposatha kammam karissāmi kalyāṇa kammam pūressāmi iti ābhogaḥ vā
translated: I will guard morality, I will perform the Uposatha ceremony, I will fulfill the good deeds.”

original: patthanā vā pariyuṭṭhānaṃ vā natthi apagataviññāṇattā, pamattassapi appamādābhāvāti
analyzed: patthanā vā pariyuṭṭhānam vā natthi apagata viññāṇa ttā pamattassa api a ppamāda abhāvāti
translated: Because they are devoid of consciousness. And the heedless also have no heedfulness.

original: tasmā ubhopete ekasadisāva.
analyzed: tasmai ubhā upete eka sadisā āva
translated: Therefore both are alike.

original: Madāti, mahārāja, ārogyayobbanajīvitamadasaṅkhātā tividhā madā pamādo nāma jāyati.
analyzed: madā ati mahā rāja ārogya yobbana jīvita mada saṅkhātā tividhā madā pamādaḥ nāma jāyati
translated: “The three kinds of intoxication, namely, intoxication with health, youth, and life, are called ‘pride’ and ‘negligence.’

original: So madappatto pamādāpanno pāṇātipātādīni pāpakammāni karoti. Atha naṃ rājāno chindāpenti
analyzed: so mada patto pamāda āpanno pāṇātipāta ādīni pāpa kammāni karoti atha nam rājānaḥ chindāpenti
translated: When a man is intoxicated and negligent, he commits evil deeds such as killing living beings. Then the kings have him cut,

original: vā hanāpenti vā, sabbaṃ vā dhanamassa haranti, evamassa pamādā ñātidhanajīvitakkhayo🔽jāyati. Puna so dhanakkhayaṃ vā yasakkhayaṃ vā patto jīvituṃ asakkonto jīvitavuttatthāya
analyzed: vā vā sabbam vā dhanam assa haranti evam assa pamādāḥ ñāti dhana jīvita kkhayo  jāyati puna saḥ dhana kkhayam vā yasa kkhayam vā pattaḥ jīvitum a sakkontaḥ jīvita vutta tthāya
translated: or have him killed, or take away all his wealth. Thus, through his negligence, he loses his relatives, his wealth, and his life.

original: kāyaduccaritādīni karoti, iccassa khayā padosā jāyanti, tena taṃ vadāmi mā mado bharatūsabhāti,🔽raṭṭhabhārakajeṭṭhaka bharatūsabha mā pamādamāpajjīti attho. Atthaṃ raṭṭhanti janapadavāsīnaṃ
analyzed: kāya duccarita ādīni karoti iccassa khayā padosāḥ jāyanti tena tam vadāmi mā madaḥ  raṭṭha bhāraka jeṭṭhaka bharatūsabha mā pamādam āpajji iti attho attham raṭṭhanti janapada vāsīnam

original: vuddhiñceva sakalaraṭṭhañca bahū pamādino jīnā. Tesaṃ āvibhāvatthāya khantivādijātaka-mātaṅgajātaka-bharujātaka-sarabhaṅgajātaka-cetiyajātakāni

translated: O best of men, who is the chief burden-bearer of the kingdom, do not be negligent. original: “Na me dubbhāsitaṃ brahme, kovidatthapadā ahaṃ;
analyzed: na me dubbhāsitam brahme kovidattha padāḥ aham
translated: “Brahman, what I say is not ill-spoken, nor is it not to the point.

original: Arakkhitā jānapadā, adhammabalinā hatā.
analyzed: arakkhitāḥ jānapadāḥ adhamma balinā hatā
translated: The people of the realm are unprotected, destroyed by the power of unrighteousness.

original: “Rattiñhi corā khādanti, divā khādanti tuṇḍiyā;
analyzed: rattim hi corā khādanti divā khādanti tuṇḍiyā
translated: By night the thieves eat, by day the officials eat.

original: Raṭṭhasmiṃ kūṭarājassa, bahu adhammiko jano;
analyzed: raṭṭhasmim kūṭarājassa bahu adhammikaḥ janaḥ
translated: In the realm of the crooked king, the unrighteous people are many.

original: Dujjīve dubbhare dāre, kuto bhattā kumāriyo”ti.
analyzed: dujjīve dubbhare dāre kutas bhattā kumāriyā ti
translated: How can the maidens live, how can they be supported? Life is hard, the burden is heavy.”

original: Tattha kovidatthapadāti ahaṃ atthapade kāraṇapade kovidā chekā, mā tvaṃ etaṃ pāparājānaṃ
analyzed: tattha kovida ttha padā ati aham attha pade kāraṇa pade kovidā chekā mā tvam etam pāpa rājānam
translated: Herein, not to the point means do not say this about this wicked king.

original: pasaṃsi. Dujjīveti dujjīve raṭṭhe dubbhare dāre jāte manussesu bhītatasitesu araññe
analyzed: dujjīveti dujjīve raṭṭhe dubbhare dāre jāte manussesu bhīta tasitesu araññe
translated: praised. In a country hard to live in, with difficult women, when people are frightened and terrified, in the forest

original: vasantesu kuto bhattā kumāriyo, kuto kumāriyo bhattāraṃ labhissantīti attho.
analyzed: vasantesu kutas bhattā kumāriyo kutas kumāriyaḥ bhattāram labhissanti iti atthaḥ
translated: and praised her. The meaning is: ‘In a country where it is hard to live, where wives are hard to get, where men are frightened and terrified, where people live in the forest, how can there be husbands for young women, how can young women get husbands?’

original: Te tassā vacanaṃ sutvā “yuttaṃ sā kathetī”ti tato paraṃ gacchantā ekassa kassakassa
analyzed: te tassāḥ vacanam sutvā yuttam sā katheti iti tatas param gacchantāḥ ekassa kassakassa
translated: Hearing her words, they thought: ‘What she says is right,’ and going further on, they heard the sound of a ploughman.

original: saddaṃ assosuṃ. Tassa kira kasantassa sāliyo nāma balibaddo phālena pahaṭo sayi.
analyzed: saddam tassa kira kasantassa sāliyaḥ nāma balibaddaḥ phālena pahaṭaḥ sayi
translated: It seems that a bull called Sāli, which was ploughing, was struck by the ploughshare and lay down.

original: So rājānaṃ akkosanto gāthamāha –
analyzed: saḥ rājānam akkosantaḥ gātham āha
translated: Addressing the king, he spoke this verse:

original: “Evaṃ sayatu pañcālo, saṅgāme sattiyā hato;
analyzed: evam sayatu pañcālaḥ saṅgāme sattiyā hataḥ
translated: ‘Let Pañcāla lie down thus, struck down in battle by the sword;

original: Yathāyaṃ kapaṇo seti, hato phālena sāliyo”ti.
analyzed: yathā ayam kapaṇaḥ seti hataḥ phālena
translated: As this wretched bull lies down, struck down by the ploughshare.’

original: Tattha yathāti yathā ayaṃ vedanāppatto sāliyabalibaddo seti, evaṃ sayatūti attho.
analyzed: tattha yathā iti yathā ayam vedanā appattaḥ sāliyabalibaddaḥ sa iti evam attho
translated: Herein, as means just as.

original: Atha naṃ purohito paṭisedhento gāthamāha –
analyzed: atha nam purohitaḥ gātham āha
translated: Then the chaplain spoke this verse in order to restrain him:

original: “Adhammena tuvaṃ jamma, brahmadattassa kujjhasi;
analyzed: adhammena tuvam jamma brahmadattassa kujjhasi
translated: ‘You are angry, Jamma, with Brahmadatta,

original: Yo tvaṃ sapasi rājānaṃ, aparajjhitvāna attano”ti.
analyzed: yaḥ tvam sapasi rājānam aparajjhitvāna attanoti
translated: Because you are hungry, though you have not lost your own life.’

original: Tattha adhammenāti akāraṇena asabhāvena.
analyzed: tattha adhammena ati akāraṇena asabhāvena
translated: Herein, by what is not Dhamma means by what is not a reason, by what is not a ground.

original: Taṃ sutvā so tisso gāthā abhāsi –
analyzed: tam sutvā saḥ tissaḥ gāthāḥ abhāsi
translated: On hearing this, he spoke three stanzas:

original: “Dhammena brahmadattassa, ahaṃ kujjhāmi brāhmaṇa;
analyzed: dhammena brahmadattassa aham kujjhāmi brāhmaṇa
translated: “By Dhamma, brahmin, I am angry with Brahmadatta,

original: Arakkhitā jānapadā adhammabalinā hatā.
analyzed: arakkhitāḥ jānapadāḥ adhamma balinā hatā
translated: Who, by the power of unrighteousness, has ruined the unprotected people of the land.

original: “Rattiñhi corā khādanti, divā khādanti tuṇḍiyā;
analyzed: rattim hi corā khādanti divā khādanti tuṇḍiyā
translated: “For by night thieves eat, and by day the tax-collectors eat,

original: Raṭṭhasmiṃ kūṭarājassa, bahu adhammiko jano.
analyzed: raṭṭhasmim kūṭarājassa bahu adhammikaḥ janaḥ
translated: In the kingdom of the crooked king, the unrighteous people are many.

original: “Sā nūna puna re pakkā, vikāle bhattamāhari;
analyzed: sā nūna punar re pakkā vikāle
translated: “Surely, then, the rice-cooker, at the wrong time, brought the food,

original: Bhattahāriṃ apekkhanto, hato phālena sāliyo”ti.
analyzed: bhatta hārim apekkhantaḥ hataḥ phālena sāliyā ti
translated: And, waiting for the rice-cooker, the rice-cooker was killed by a clod.”

original: Tattha dhammenāti kāraṇeneva, akāraṇena akkosatīti saññaṃ mā kari. Sā nūna puna re
analyzed: tattha dhammena ati kāraṇena iva akāraṇena akkosati iti saññam mā kari sā nūna puna re
translated: Herein, by Dhamma means by a reason. Do not think that I am abusing you without a reason. Surely, then, the rice-cooker, at the wrong time, brought the food:

original: pakkā, vikāle bhattamāharīti, brāhmaṇa, sā bhattahārikā itthī pātova mama bhattaṃ
analyzed: pakkā vikāle bhattam āhariti brāhmaṇa sā bhatta hārikā itthī mama bhattam
translated: brahmin, that rice-cooker, a woman, having cooked my food in the morning,

original: pacitvā āharantī adhammabalisādhakehi brahmadattassa dāsehi palibuddhā bhavissati,
analyzed: pacitvā āharantī adhamma bali sādhakehi brahmadattassa dāsehi palibuddhā bhavissati
translated: while bringing it, will be obstructed by Brahmadatta’s slaves, who are supported by the power of unrighteousness.🔽Having surrounded her, my food will be cooked again. For this reason, at the wrong time,

original: te parivisitvā puna mayhaṃ bhattaṃ pakkaṃ bhavissati, tena kāraṇena vikāle bhattaṃ
analyzed: te parivisitvā puna mayham bhattam pakkam bhavissati tena kāraṇena vikāle bhattam
translated: the rice-cooker

original: āhari, “ajja vikāle bhattaṃ āharī”ti cintetvā chātajjhatto ahaṃ taṃ bhattahāriṃ olokento
analyzed: āhari ajja vikāle bhattam āhari iti cintetvā chāta jjhattaḥ aham tam bhatta hārim olokento
translated: “I have brought it,” and thinking, “Today the meal was brought late,” I, being hungry, looked at the man who brought the meal.

original: goṇaṃ aṭṭhāne patodena vijjhiṃ, tenesa pādaṃ ukkhipitvā phālaṃ paharanto hato phālena
analyzed: goṇam aṭṭhāne patodena vijjhim tena isa pādam ukkhipitvā phālam paharantaḥ hataḥ phālena
translated: I struck the ox with the goad in the wrong place, and the ox, lifting its foot, struck the ploughshare with it.

original: sāliyo. Tasmā “esa mayā hato”ti saññaṃ mā kari, pāparaññoyeva hato nāmesa, mā tassa vaṇṇaṃ bhaṇīti.
analyzed: sāliyaḥ tasmai esa mayā hato ti saññam mā kari hato nāma isa mā tassa vaṇṇam bhaṇi iti
translated: Therefore, do not think, “This one was killed by me,” for it was not killed by me, but by the enemy king. Do not speak in praise of him.”

original: Te purato gantvā ekasmiṃ gāme vasiṃsu. Punadivase pātova ekā kūṭadhenu godohakaṃ pādena paharitvā saddhiṃ khīrena pavaṭṭesi. So brahmadattaṃ akkosanto gāthamāha –
analyzed: te puratas gantvā ekasmin gāme vasiṃsu punadivase ekā kūṭadhenu godohakam pādena paharitvā saddhim khīrena pavaṭṭesi saḥ brahmadattam akkosantaḥ gātham āha
translated: They went on ahead and stayed in a certain village. On the following day, early in the morning, a vicious cow, striking the milk-pail with her foot, kicked it about with the milk. The king, reviling Brahmadatta, spoke this verse:

original: “Evaṃ haññatu pañcālo, saṅgāme asinā hato;
analyzed: evam haññatu pañcālaḥ saṅgāme asinā hataḥ
translated: “Thus may Pañcāla be slain, slain in battle with the sword;

original: Yathāhamajja pahato, khīrañca me pavaṭṭita”nti.
analyzed: yathā aham ajja pahataḥ khīram ca me pavaṭṭitanti
translated: As I have been struck today, and my milk has been spilled.”

original: Taṃ sutvā purohito paṭisedhento gāthamāha –
analyzed: tam sutvā purohitaḥ gātham āha
translated: Hearing this, the chaplain, in order to restrain him, spoke this verse:

original: “Yaṃ pasu khīraṃ chaḍḍeti, pasupālaṃ vihiṃsati;
analyzed: yam pasu khīram chaḍḍeti pasu pālam vihiṃsati
translated: “When a cow spills her milk, she injures the cowherd;

original: Kiṃ tattha brahmadattassa, yaṃ no garahate bhava”nti.
analyzed: kim tattha brahmadattassa yam naḥ garahate bhavanti
translated: What has Brahmadatta done, that you blame him, sir?”

original: Brāhmaṇena gāthāya vuttāya puna so tisso gāthā abhāsi –
analyzed: brāhmaṇena gāthāya vuttāya puna saḥ tissaḥ gāthāḥ abhāsi
translated: The brahmin, when the verse was spoken, spoke three more verses in reply:

original: “Gārayho brahme pañcālo, brahmadattassa rājino;
analyzed: gārayhaḥ brahme pañcālaḥ brahmadattassa rājinaḥ
translated: “The five-platter is to be blamed, O Brahmā, of King Brahmadatta;

original: Arakkhitā jānapadā, adhammabalinā hatā.
analyzed: arakkhitāḥ jānapadāḥ adhamma balinā hatā
translated: The country is unguarded, destroyed by the power of unrighteousness.

original: “Rattiñhi corā khādanti, divā khādanti tuṇḍiyā;
analyzed: rattim hi corā khādanti divā khādanti tuṇḍiyā
translated: “For at night the thieves eat, and by day the tax-collectors eat;

original: Raṭṭhasmiṃ kūṭarājassa, bahu adhammiko jano.
analyzed: raṭṭhasmim kūṭarājassa bahu adhammikaḥ janaḥ
translated: In the kingdom of the crooked king, the unrighteous people are many.

original: “Caṇḍā aṭanakā gāvī, yaṃ pure na duhāmase;
analyzed: caṇḍā aṭanakā gāvī yam pure na duhāmase
translated: “The cows are fierce and wild, which formerly we did not milk;

original: Taṃ dāni ajja dohāma, khīrakāmehupaddutā”ti.
analyzed: tam dāni ajja dohāma
translated: Now today we milk them, oppressed by the desire for milk.”

original: Tattha caṇḍāti pharusā. Aṭanakāti palāyanasīlā. Khīrakāmehīti adhammikarañño purisehi🔽bahuṃ khīraṃ āharāpentehi upaddutā duhāma. Sace hi so dhammena rajjaṃ kāreyya, na
analyzed: tattha caṇḍā ati pharusā aṭanakā ati palāyana sīlā khīra kāmehi iti adhammika rañño purisehi  bahum khīram āhara apentehi upaddutāḥ duhāma sace hi saḥ dhammena rajjam kāreyya na
translated: And there, fierce means harsh. Wild means running away. By the desire for milk means oppressed by the men of the unrighteous king

original: no evarūpaṃ bhayaṃ āgaccheyyāti.
analyzed: no evarūpam bhayam āgaccheyya ati
translated: bringing much milk. If he were to rule righteously, this kind of fear would not come to us.

original: Te “so yuttaṃ kathetī”ti tamhā gāmā nikkhamma mahāmaggaṃ āruyha nagarābhimukhā gamiṃsu.
analyzed: te saḥ yuttam katheti iti tamhā gāmā nikkhamma mahā maggaṃ āruyha nagara abhimukhāḥ gamiṃsu
translated: They thought: “He speaks rightly,” and leaving that village, they took the main road and went towards the city.

original: Ekasmiñca gāme balisādhakā asikosatthāya ekaṃ taruṇaṃ kabaravacchakaṃ māretvā cammaṃ
analyzed: ekasmin ca gāme bali sādhakāḥ asi kosatthāya ekam taruṇam kabara vat śakam māretvā cammam
translated: And in one village, the tax-collectors, for the sake of a knife, killed a young calf and skinned it.

original: gaṇhiṃsu. Vacchakamātā dhenu puttasokena tiṇaṃ na khādati pānīyaṃ na pivati, paridevamānā
analyzed: gaṇhiṃsu vacchaka mātā dhenu putta sokena tiṇam na khādati pānīyam na pivati paridevamānā
translated: They took it. The cow Vacchaka-mātā, through grief for her calf, did not eat grass nor drink water, but wandered about lamenting.

original: āhiṇḍati. Taṃ disvā gāmadārakā rājānaṃ akkosantā gāthamāhaṃsu –
analyzed: āhiṇḍati tam disvā gāma dārakāḥ rājānam akkosantāḥ gātham āhaṃsu
translated: Seeing this, the village boys, reviling the king, spoke this verse:

original: “Evaṃ kandatu pañcālo, viputto vippasukkhatu;
analyzed: evam kandatu pañcālaḥ viputtaḥ vippasukkhatu
translated: “Thus may Pañcāla lament, childless, with hair all dishevelled,

original: Yathāyaṃ kapaṇā gāvī, viputtā paridhāvatī”ti.
analyzed: yathā ayam kapaṇā gāvī viputtā paridhāvati iti
translated: As this poor cow, childless, wanders about lamenting.”

original: Tattha paridhāvatīti paridevamāno dhāvati.
analyzed: tattha paridhāvati iti paridevamānaḥ dhāvati
translated: Herein, wanders about lamenting means wanders about lamenting.

original: Tato purohito itaraṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: tatas purohitaḥ itaram gātham āha
translated: Then the chaplain spoke this verse:

original: “Yaṃ pasu pasupālassa, sambhameyya raveyya vā;
analyzed: yam pasu pasu pālassa sambhameyya raveyya vā
translated: “If a beast of the king’s should die or get lost,

original: Konīdha aparādhatthi, brahmadattassa rājino”ti.
analyzed: konīdha aparādhatthi brahmadattassa rājino ti
translated: Who is to blame for this, King Brahmadatta?”

original: Tattha sambhameyya raveyya vāti bhameyya vā viraveyya vā. Idaṃ vuttaṃ hoti – tātā,🔽pasu nāma pasupālassa rakkhantasseva dhāvatipi viravatipi, tiṇampi na khādati pānīyampi
analyzed: tattha sambhameyya raveyya vā ati bhameyya vā viraveyya vā idam vuttam hoti tātā  pasu nāma pasu pālassa rakkhantassa iva dhāvati pi viravati pi tiṇam pi na khādati pānīyam pi
translated: Herein, should die or get lost means should die or should get lost. This is what is said:🔽Boys,

original: na pivati, idha rañño ko nu aparādhoti.
analyzed: na pivati idha rañño kaḥ nu aparādho ti
translated: a beast of the king’s, even while being guarded by the keeper, wanders about and cries out, does not eat grass, does not drink water, but here who is to blame for this, the king?

original: Tato gāmadārakā dve gāthā abhāsiṃsu –
analyzed: tatas gāma dārakāḥ dve gāthāḥ abhāsiṃsu
translated: Then the village boys spoke two verses:

original: “Aparādho mahābrahme, brahmadattassa rājino;
analyzed: aparādhaḥ mahābrahme brahmadattassa rājinaḥ
translated: “The fault, O Great Brahmā, is with King Brahmadatta;

original: Arakkhitā jānapadā, adhammabalinā hatā.
analyzed: arakkhitāḥ jānapadāḥ adhamma balinā hatā
translated: The people of the realm are unprotected, and are being destroyed by the power of unrighteousness.

original: “Rattiñhi corā khādanti, divā khādanti tuṇḍiyā;
analyzed: rattim hi corā khādanti divā khādanti tuṇḍiyā
translated: “For at night the thieves eat, and by day the tax-gatherers;

original: Raṭṭhasmiṃ kūṭarājassa, bahu adhammiko jano;
analyzed: raṭṭhasmim kūṭarājassa bahu adhammikaḥ janaḥ
translated: In the kingdom of the crooked king, the unrighteous people are many;

original: Kathaṃ no asikosatthā, khīrapā haññate pajā”ti.
analyzed: katham naḥ asi kosatthā khīra pā haññate pajāti
translated: How is it that the people are being destroyed, O King, who are like a calf at the breast of the cow of the earth?”

original: Tattha mahābrahmeti mahābrāhmaṇa. Rājinoti rañño. Kathaṃ noti kathaṃ nu kena nāma
analyzed: tattha mahā brahma iti mahā brāhmaṇa rājino ti rañño katham no ti katham nu kena nāma
translated: Here, “O Great Brahmā” means “O Great Brāhmaṇa.” “Of the king” means “of the king.” “How?” means “by what name.”

original: kāraṇena. Khīrapā haññate pajāti pāparājassa sevakehi khīrapako vacchako haññati,
analyzed: kāraṇena khīrapāḥ haññate pajāti pāpa rājassa sevakehi khīrapakaḥ vacchakaḥ haññati
translated: “The people are being destroyed, O King, who are like a calf at the breast of the cow of the earth” means that the calf of the cow of the earth is being killed by the servants of the wicked king,

original: idāni sā dhenu puttasokena paridevati, sopi rājā ayaṃ dhenu viya paridevatūti rājānaṃ akkosiṃsuyeva.
analyzed: idāni sā dhenu putta sokena paridevati saḥ api rājā ayam dhenu viya paridevatu uti rājānam
translated: and now that cow is lamenting out of grief for her calf. They scolded the king, saying, “That king should lament like that cow.”

original: Te “sādhu vo kāraṇaṃ vadathā”ti vatvā pakkamiṃsu. Athantarāmagge ekissā sukkhapokkharaṇiyā
analyzed: te sādhu vaḥ kāraṇam vadatha ati vatvā pakkamiṃsu athantarāmagge ekissā sukkha pokkharaṇiyā
translated: They said, “Good, you have given a good reason,” and they left. Then on the way, in a dry pond,

original: kākā tuṇḍehi vijjhitvā maṇḍūke khādanti. Bodhisatto tesu taṃ ṭhānaṃ sampattesu attano
analyzed: kākā tuṇḍehi vijjhitvā maṇḍūke khādanti bodhisatto tesu tat ṭhānam sampattesu attano
translated: the crows pecked with their beaks and ate the frogs. When they arrived at that place, the Bodhisatta

original: ānubhāvena maṇḍūkena –
analyzed: ānubhāvena maṇḍūkena
translated: by his power made a frog say:

original: “Evaṃ khajjatu pañcālo, hato yuddhe saputtako;
analyzed: evam khajjatu pañcālaḥ hataḥ yuddhe sa puttakaḥ
translated: “So let Pancala be devoured, slain in battle with his son,

original: Yathāhamajja khajjāmi, gāmikehi araññajo”ti. –
analyzed: yathā aham ajja khajjāmi gāmikehi arañña jo ti
translated: As I am now being devoured by the villagers, I who am born in the forest.”

original: Rājānaṃ akkosāpesi.
analyzed: rājānam akkosāpesi
translated: He reviled the king.

original: Tattha gāmikehīti gāmavāsīhi.
analyzed: tattha gāmikehi iti gāma vāsīhi
translated: Herein, by the villagers means by the villagers.

original: Taṃ sutvā purohito maṇḍūkena saddhiṃ sallapanto gāthamāha –
analyzed: tam sutvā purohitaḥ maṇḍūkena saddhim sat lapantaḥ gātham āha
translated: On hearing this, the chaplain, in conversation with the frog, spoke this verse:

original: “Na sabbabhūtesu vidhenti rakkhaṃ, rājāno maṇḍūka manussaloke;
analyzed: na sabba bhūtesu vidhenti rakkham rājānaḥ maṇḍūka manussa loke
translated: “Kings in the world of men, O frog, do not always give protection to all creatures.

original: Nettāvatā rājā adhammacārī, yaṃ tādisaṃ jīvamadeyyu dhaṅkā”ti.
analyzed: na id tāvatā rājā adhamma cārī yam tādisam jīvam adeyyu
translated: To this extent a king is a wrong-doer, that he should let such a one as you be devoured by crows.”

original: Tattha jīvanti jīvantaṃ. Adeyyunti khādeyyuṃ. Dhaṅkāti kākā. Ettāvatā rājā adhammiko nāma na hoti, kiṃ sakkā araññaṃ pavisitvā raññā taṃ rakkhantena caritunti.
analyzed: tattha jīvanti jīvantam khādeyyum dhaṅkā ati kākāḥ ettāvatā rājā adhammikaḥ nāma na hoti kim sakkā araññam pavisitvā raññā tam rakkhantena caritunti
translated: Herein, he is living means he is alive. He should be devoured means he should be eaten. Crows means crows. To this extent a king is not called unrighteous. What can be done? Having entered the forest, should the king protect you and go about with you?

original: Taṃ sutvā maṇḍūko dve gāthā abhāsi –🔽“Adhammarūpo vata brahmacārī, anuppiyaṃ bhāsasi khattiyassa;
analyzed: tam sutvā maṇḍūkaḥ dve gāthāḥ abhāsi  adhamma rūpaḥ vata brahmacārī anuppiyam bhāsasi khattiyassa
translated: On hearing this, the frog spoke two verses:🔽“A religious man, indeed, of unrighteous form, you speak unpleasantly to a king.

original: Viluppamānāya puthuppajāya, pūjesi rājaṃ paramappamādaṃ.
analyzed: viluppamānāya puthuppajāya pūjesi rājam parama ppamādam
translated: You praise the king, O most heedless one, to a species of creatures that is being destroyed.

original: “Sace idaṃ brahme surajjakaṃ siyā, phītaṃ raṭṭhaṃ muditaṃ vippasannaṃ;
analyzed: sace idam brahme su rajjakam siyā phītam raṭṭham muditam vippasannam
translated: “If this were a happy realm, prosperous, joyful, and peaceful,

original: Bhutvā baliṃ aggapiṇḍañca kākā, na mādisaṃ jīvamadeyyu dhaṅkā”ti.
analyzed: bhutvā balim agga piṇḍam ca kākāḥ na mādisam jīvam adeyyu dhaṅka ati
translated: The crows would not eat the sacrificial cake and the first portion of food, and the vultures would not eat the flesh of one like me.”

original: Tattha brahmacārīti purohitaṃ garahanto āha. Khattiyassāti evarūpassa pāparañño.
analyzed: tattha brahmacārī iti purohitam garahantaḥ āha khattiyassa ati evarūpassa pāpa raññaḥ
translated: Herein, he said “Brahmin” in disparaging the chaplain. “Of a Khattiya” : of such a wicked king.

original: Viluppamānāyāti vilumpamānāya, ayameva vā pāṭho. Puthuppajāyāti vipulāya pajāya vināsiyamānāya.🔽Pūjesīti pasaṃsi. Surajjakanti chandādivasena agantvā dasa rājadhamme akopentena🔽appamattena raññā rakkhiyamānaṃ sace idaṃ surajjakaṃ bhaveyya. Phītanti devesu sammādhāraṃ
analyzed: viluppamānāya ati vilumpamānāya ayam eva vā pāṭhaḥ puthuppajāya ati vipulāya pajāya vināsiyamānāya  pūjesi iti chanda ādi vasena a gantvā dasa rājadhamme a kopentena  appamattena raññā rakkhiyamānam sace idam su rajjakam bhaveyya phītanti devesu sammādhāram
translated: “While it is being plundered” : while it is being robbed, this is the reading. “Of the people” : of the extensive people, while they are being destroyed.🔽“I would praise” : I would extol. “If this were a happy realm” : if this were a happy realm, not gone to the ten bad ways through desire, etc.,

original: anuppavecchantesu sampannasassaṃ. Na mādisanti evaṃ sante mādisaṃ jīvamānaññeva kākā na khādeyyuṃ.
analyzed: an uppavecchantesu sampanna sassam na mā ādisanti evam sante mā ādisam jīvamānañca iva kākāḥ na khādeyyuṃ
translated: but protected by a king who is heedful and does not transgress the ten royal duties. “Prosperous” : with abundant crops, while the gods are sending down proper showers. “The crows would not eat the sacrificial cake” : if it were so, the crows would not eat the sacrificial cake and the first portion of food, and the vultures would not eat the flesh of one like me.

original: Evaṃ chasupi ṭhānesu akkosanaṃ bodhisattasseva ānubhāvena ahosi;
analyzed: evam chasu pi ṭhānesu akkosanam bodhisattassa iva ānubhāvena ahosi
translated: Thus the abuse in all six places was due to the power of the Bodhisatta himself;

original: Taṃ sutvā rājā ca purohito ca “araññavāsiṃ tiracchānagataṃ maṇḍūkaṃ upādāya sabbe🔽amheyeva akkosantī”ti vatvā tato nagaraṃ gantvā dhammena rajjaṃ kāretvā mahāsattassovāde
analyzed: tam sutvā rājā ca purohito ca arañña vāsim tiracchāna gatam maṇḍūkam upādāya sabbe  akkosanti iti vatvā tatas nagaram gantvā dhammena rajjam kāretvā mahāsattassa uvāde
translated: When the king and the chaplain heard this, they said, “They are reviling us, because a frog, an animal, that lives in the forest, has been killed.”🔽Then they went to the city and ruled righteously, following the advice of the Great Being.

original: ṭhitā dānādīni puññāni kariṃsu.🔽Satthā kosalarañño imaṃ dhammadesanaṃ āharitvā, “mahārāja, raññā nāma agatigamanaṃ
analyzed: ṭhitāḥ dāna ādīni puññāni kariṃsu  satthā kosala raññaḥ imam dhamma desanam āharitvā mahā rāja raññā nāma agati gamanam
translated: When the king and the chaplain heard this, they said, “They are abusing us, not only the hermit, but even the frog, an animal.” So they returned to the city and ruled the kingdom righteously, and, following the advice of the Great Being, they gave alms and performed other meritorious deeds.

original: pahāya dhammena rajjaṃ kāretabba”nti vatvā jātakaṃ samodhānesi “tadā gandhatindukadevatā ahameva ahosi”nti.
analyzed: pahāya dhammena rajjam kāretabbanti vatvā jātakam samodhānesi tadā gandhatinduka devatā aham eva ahosinti
translated: When the Teacher had related this story, he said, “Great king, a king should rule righteously, without going astray.” So saying, he expounded the Law at length, and then identified the Birth Story, saying, “At that time the god of the perfumed ginger was myself.”

original: Gandhatindukajātakavaṇṇanā dasamā.
analyzed: gandhatinduka jātaka vaṇṇanā dasamā
translated: The commentary on the Gandhatinduka Birth Story is finished.

original: Jātakuddānaṃ
analyzed: jātakuddānam
translated: The Birth Stories

original: Kiṃchanda kumbha jayaddisa chaddanta, atha paṇḍitasambhava sirakapi;
analyzed: kiṃchanda kumbha jayaddisa chaddanta atha paṇḍitasambhava sirakapi
translated: Kiṃchanda, Kumbha, Jayaddisa, Chaddanta, then Paṇḍitasambhava, Sirikapi;

original: Dakarakkhasa paṇḍaranāgavaro, atha sambula tindukadevasutoti.
analyzed: dakarakkhasa paṇḍara nāga varaḥ atha sambula tinduka deva sutaḥ ti
translated: Dakarakkhasa, Paṇḍaranāgavara, then Sambula, Tindukadevasuta.

original: Tiṃsanipātavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: tiṃsanipāta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the thirty-second chapter is finished.
